HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FLEET FINANCE SETTLES GEORGIA LENDING LAWSUIT

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Fleet Finance Inc., which was accused in several lawsuits in Georgia of luring poor people into high interest second-mortgage loans, settled the final large pending case yesterday for $5.9 million. The proposed settlement, which would mark the end of a fierce three-year battle, was filed in Cobb County Superior Court and could receive final approval in 60 days. Fleet Finance admitted no wrongdoing. 
 Fleet Finance, a subsidiary of the Fleet Financial Group, was accused of charging excessive loan rates and using abusive collection practices. The case was scheduled to be tried in February, but a delay was granted while settlement talks proceeded. In the settlement, all 7,000 plaintiffs will receive letters clearing their credit records of any problems related to their dealings with Fleet Finance. About 3,000 people will split the cash settlement. Fleet Finance agreed last year to provide $115 million in loans to settle two other suits and a state lending discrimination investigation.

HEADLINE: Two Votes for Quality Health Care

 BODY:
The Senate is poised to vote on two health-care items that will bear heavily on the quality of American medicine and on medical institutions in the New York City area. Both items are in the health-care bill introduced by the majority leader, George Mitchell, and are expected to be the subject of early votes.
One item is a wholly justifiable tax on health insurance premiums that Mr. Mitchell proposes to pay for training doctors and conducting medical research. Republicans, in a blind anti-tax fervor, want to block this tax as well. But that would greatly damage the research and training programs that have made American medicine the finest and most innovative in the world. 
 Mr. Mitchell's premium tax is needed because much of the money that is currently spent to train doctors and pay for research -- $16 billion -- is to disappear. The money is taken out of fees that hospitals charge Medicare and private patients. But Congress is about to drastically reduce Medicare reimbursements to pay for health reform, and private patients are increasingly signing up with managed-care plans that are unwilling to subsidize high-quality medical training. Under Mr. Mitchell's bill, patients would pay a tax that would generate about $13 billion a year by 2001 (adjusted for inflation) for training and education -- less than they pay now.
The second item up for an early vote is a provision in the Mitchell bill that would have Washington decide not only how many residents hospitals will train each year but also whether those training slots should be assigned to generalists or specialists. The provision would undercut a process that should be decided by the marketplace; Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, will rightly propose to strike it out.
Congress has no idea what specialists will be needed two years from today, let alone in a decade or more. One researcher, for example, has estimated that if every health plan patterned itself after an H.M.O. in Denver, the nation could stop training urologists for almost 20 years before a shortage occurred.
With science and treatment practices radically changing, it makes no sense for Congress to presume it knows best. The best route to reform is for health plans to hire the specialists they need and for medical students to gravitate where job opportunities are opening up.
Admittedly, New York City -- which trains 15 percent of the nation's residents -- would be disproportionately harmed if Congress votes the wrong way on these two issues. But other major health centers would be diminished as well. Innovative research and highly skilled doctors benefit all Americans.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plays Game With Cuban Immigrants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The report of Cubans hijacking a ferry to come to the United States, and possibly sparking a new Mariel boat lift, highlights the hypocrisy of United States immigration policy toward Cuba (news article, Aug. 7). Under President Reagan, the United States agreed to take as many as 20,000 Cuban immigrants a year, but in reality only a few thousand visas are granted annually. 
 On the other hand, unlike United States policy toward other Caribbean or Latin neighbors (as the sad saga of Haitian refugees illustrates), all Cubans who make their way to the United States are allowed to stay. This means that instead of getting a visa at the United States interest section in Havana and boarding a plane to Miami in a safe, dignified fashion, Cubans who want to come here must risk their lives or risk the lives of others by hijacking a boat or plane.
If they reach Florida shores, they are hailed as heroes. If they die at sea, they are mourned as casualties of Fidel Castro's cruel dictatorship.
Cuba has maintained that would-be United States immigrants can only leave the country if they have been granted a United States visa, and that those trying to leave illegally would be stopped. Whenever the Cubans stop illegal emigrants, however, Washington delights in shouting: "See, people are so desperate to leave that they will risk their lives on rafts. And what does Castro do? He won't even let them leave!"
And what happens when Fidel Castro threatens to stop doing the dirty work for the United States and let everyone leave who wants to? He is a devil who wants to wage an immigration war against the United States.
Yet according to Treasury Department regulations, Americans who travel to Cuba, unless they are journalists, professional researchers or Cuban-Americans visiting relatives, are threatened with 10-year jail sentences and fines of $250,000.
A group called the Freedom to Travel Campaign has had its bank account frozen since June for organizing an educational trip to Cuba.
We should grant Cubans the 20,000 visas a year the agreement we signed permits, and allow United States citizens the right to travel to Cuba.
Indeed, why not lift the whole embargo? Helping improve Cuba's economy and insuring a peaceful post-Castro transition is our best immigration policy.
 
MEDEA BENJAMIN
Director, Global Exchange
San Francisco, Aug. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Foster Care's Ills Include Runaway Children

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Languishing in Foster Care" (editorial, Aug. 2) omits what may be the most telling symptom of the ills that plague the foster care system: the prevalence of recurrent runaway behavior among foster children. 
 A recent survey by the National Association of Social Workers showed that 20 percent of the children living in homeless shelters across the country had arrived there directly from foster care. Other studies, including one in New York City, have determined that as much as half the runaway population has spent time in foster care or in a group home.
The overrepresentation of foster children among the thousands of children who run away suggests not just the susceptibility of foster children to such behavior, but also the inability of agencies to provide stability and permanence to many children.
To be young, homeless and poor almost always entails a sense of desperation that can reach far into the future. The incidence of survival sex among runaways, for example, accounts for the high prevalence of human immunodeficiency virus infection among that populace.
Many others are ensnared by chronic welfare dependency, unemployment and family conflict. That so many foster children are drawn to this dead-end existence bespeaks the quality of life that young people endure in state care.
 
KEVIN RYAN
Senior Staff Attorney, Covenant House
New York, Aug. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: A City's Dreams Go to Market

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

 BODY:
BARRY BENEPE has been arranging blue-tipped pins on a giant topographical map in his West 16th Street office this summer. Mr. Benepe, the director of Greenmarket, a project of the New York City Council on the Environment that operates 20 open-air food emporiums where farmers sell directly to consumers, explained that each pin indicates a farm from which a vegetable grower, a cider maker, a fisherman or a dairy or poultry farmer drives to the city's Greenmarkets. To Mr. Benepe, who helped found the project in 1976, the pins represent 200 family farms that have been saved by the money they make at the city's markets.
And when he runs his finger from the blue pin near the Finger Lakes in upstate New York south to Manhattan, or from the cluster of blue pins in New Jersey north to the Bronx, he is tracing a web that connects urban life with rural life, a web that continues to change and grow -- and that continues to amaze Mr. Benepe. 
 The more that Greenmarkets become fixtures in city neighborhoods, the more they resemble the proverbial backyard fence where neighbors meet to exchange recipes and gossip and concerns about their streets. The markets are meeting places for children's play groups, dissemination points for public-education and community organizations, platforms for local politicians and stages for concertina players and performance artists. The markets mirror the local quotidian. They sell fresh food, but they promote community.
Nearly a quarter of the city's Greenmarkets are in public parks and squares that had previously fallen into disuse, like Union Square in Manhattan and Joyce Kilmer Park in the Bronx. Ironically, it took the lure of consumerism to draw people back to these public spaces, said William H. Whyte, an urban planner and the author of "City: Rediscovering the Center" (Doubleday, 1989), a study of American cities that focuses on public spaces. "This particular form of commerce has restored the kind of intimate, personal exchange that the city has lost over the years," he said.
By importing slices of the country, the city realized something it had lost.
"I hadn't been to Joyce Kilmer Park in a good 10 years; it had gotten bad," said Elmira Johnston, as she bought sweet corn recently at the Bronx Sunday Market at the Grand Concourse and East 162d Street. "My daughter and I bring the grandchildren every Sunday, shop, make a picnic, talk to folks we haven't seen in years."
There was little doubt when the Greenmarket program was established that selling retail could help save small farms. Even though farmers pay a nominal fee to rent their spaces and have to travel far and hire extra workers to sell retail, the economics of direct marketing are in their favor.
"Selling to wholesalers, a farmer's share of the produce dollar is about 21 cents," said Robert A. Lewis, who founded the program with Mr. Benepe and is now the chief marketing representative for the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. "Selling direct, his share is 100 percent."
The team also suspected that Greenmarkets could transform city blocks. But neither of them imagined the number or variety of groups that would begin using the concept to create discrete town squares in the city. Mr. Lewis said that besides the 20 markets sponsored by the council, there are five farmers' markets organized by community groups in the city and several others being planned.
From a pastoral point of view, a Greenmarket's aroma of basil, mint and peaches, as well as its kaleidoscope of flowers and produce, transforms city corners, emanating what one shopper at La Marqueta, an open-air market in East Harlem, recently described as "ripples of hope." In some neighborhoods, the sensory onslaught kindles an interest in flavor and novelty, freshness and variety. In others, the ripples of hope extend far beyond dinner.
Increasingly, farmers' markets are being used to create what Chineda Lewis called "a center of wholesome family life." Ms. Lewis, a member of People United for Local Leadership, a community association in Far Rockaway, Queens, worked with two tenant organizations to create a Saturday market, not only to bring fresh produce to the 14,000 families who live in the six nearby housing projects, but also "to create a place where our young can learn about entrepreneurship."
"They help clean the market, set up the market and are planning to market products of their own," she said.
With hopes of creating a town square in the midst of housing projects, as well as providing residents with high-quality produce, the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, a community housing coalition, organized a weekly farmers' market. So rare is fresh, unpackaged food in some parts of the borough that the Bronx Perinatal Consortium, a program dedicated to improving maternal and infant health, began two farmers' markets in the Mott Haven section, as part of the federally funded Healthy Start Program.
Across the country, community groups, ecology-awareness associations, private developers and city governments are raising the flag for urban farmers' markets. According to the 1994 National Farmers' Directory, published by the United States Department of Agriculture, 1,755 such markets have opened in the last decade. There were less than 100 20 years ago. Many, like the Pike Place Market in Seattle, grew from the ashes of longstanding markets and brought new life to downtrodden areas. Others, like the farmers' market in Ann Arbor, Mich., were created in tenuous areas and became beacons for neighborhood renewal.
The Union Square Greenmarket in Manhattan is an honored parable in the world of direct farm marketing. Even Mr. Benepe, who organized the market, continues to be amazed when he sees real estate advertisements that boast "Views of Union Square."
Only the naive, though, claim that the market alone transformed the dross of Union Square into gold.
"There were many other forces," Mr. Benepe said. "An active neighborhood association and business association, and an increasing number of residents who held the market and various other quality-of-life issues in common." He added that, in his 18-year tenure, he has opened as many markets that have failed as have succeeded.
Nevertheless, before the Greenmarket opened in 1977, Union Square was so drug-infested that students from Xavier High School on 16th Street could be expelled for stepping foot in the place, he said. Now, packed with farm stands four days a week, the square is the heart -- or perhaps the soul -- of a vibrant, food-centric neighborhood.
Since the Union Square Greenmarket made its debut, the average retail rents on lower Fifth Avenue have jumped from $20 a square foot to $75, said Joseph Gardiner, the president of 100 Fifth Avenue Company, a real estate firm in the area. Discount department stores have been supplanted by businesses like Emporio Armani, Paragon Sports and ABC Carpet and Home, and about a dozen former coffee shops have been turned into stylish restaurants.
The Union Square Market, Mr. Benepe said, grosses $9 million a year, half of the $18 million generated by the 20 Greenmarkets in the city. Union Square is to farmers what Broadway is to actors.
But while the 20,000 people who brouse among the 80 stands at Union Square each week are as varied as the produce sold there, most other markets are not places where the haves meet the have-nots. They are places where people of similar incomes and ethnic backgrounds meet. In Greenmarkets in stylish neighborhoods, conversations tend to be about the exquisiteness of a particular farmer's tomatoes. In beleaguered areas, where the markets are tiny and often the sole patch of green amid acres of concrete and asphalt, people talk about who has the best price on tomatoes.
For growers like John Schmid of Goshen, N.Y., Union Square is small potatoes; the Bronx Sunday Market is big potatoes. Total market revenues are beside the point. He knows that red-skinned potatoes smaller than gum balls will draw lines of eager customers at Union Square and will languish at the market along the Grand Concourse.
"People at Union Square buy food they can talk about," Mr. Schmid said. "In the Bronx, people buy food they can eat."
For market organizers like Hilary Baum, big potatoes anchor the web that connects the city with the country, and neighbors with one another. Ms. Baum, who helped found Public Market Partners, a consulting firm in the Bronx that has organized 16 markets nationally, now manages the La Marqueta open-air market, an emporium outside the venerable but partly shuttered market in East Harlem.
People go to markets for the food and for the clean, well-patrolled open space, she said. They stay for the art activities for children, the cooking demonstrations and the nutrition and public health information that are offered at the markets she manages.
As he watched the neighborhood cluster around the four vendors at 115th Street and Park Avenue, Paolo Hernandez, a retired cabdriver, said the scene "reminds me of the old days when La Marqueta was a big deal."
"It gives me a good, warm feeling to see people coming back out on the street again," he said.
Exactly, Ms. Baum said. She surveyed the half-block patch of asphalt that is one of her own particular fields of dreams and -- above the creak of shopping carts, calls for "Corn here!" and the caw of birds -- she said, "If you organize a market well, people come."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A report in The Living Section on Wednesday listing Greenmarket locations in New York City included an erroneous entry supplied by the Greenmarket Project. The Greenwich Village market, at Gansevoort and Hudson Streets, has not been open since July 30; Community Board 2 has scheduled a public hearing for Sept. 7 to consider reopening it in another location.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: The House;
House Action on Health Measure May Wait Till After Labor Day

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders today acknowledged that they had no clear idea when they could begin work on health care legislation, but said it might be after Labor Day, a prospect that dismayed many advocates of a health care overhaul.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader, told members in a closed Democratic caucus today that the Congressional Budget Office had yet to complete its analyses of the House's health care bills, and that the House could therefore not begin to act on them. 
 Mr. Gephardt told members that if, as expected, the budget office was still not finished when the House completes its work on the crime bill this week, they might be sent home, according to participants in the caucus.
With this newest delay on the horizon, some advocates of a health care overhaul said they worried that the mood and the momentum for a comprehensive bill were waning in the House as the clock winds down to the elections in November. "I've said repeatedly the one thing the leadership doesn't have to give away is time," said Representative Pete Stark of California, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. "Members go home for two weeks, it gives people a lot of time to complain."
The majority leader maintained that there was still the possibility of moving faster on health care legislation if the budget office reports back in the next two weeks. But he was clearly exasperated when reporters asked when the debate might begin. "The answer to the question of 'when' has been, is and for some time will be, 'I don't know,' " he said. "I can say that 40 or 50 ways, but that's the answer. I don't know, and I know of no one who knows."
Participants at the caucus said Mr. Gephardt told them to stay flexible because they might be called back before Labor Day. The House will not officially adjourn, which is widely seen as an effort to keep pressure on the Senate and the budget office to continue working on the legislation.
But Mr. Gephardt acknowledged in the caucus that the House might not take up the bill until after Labor Day, participants said, adding that if that occurred, members would stay in session through the weekend of Sept. 9 to try to complete action before Yom Kippur begins on Sept. 14.
In an interview tonight, the majority leader said it was impossible to get a hard prediction from the budget office on when it would be finished. The analysis, he said, "is an interactive process," with the authors of the various bills under scrutiny given the opportunity to make changes and have those changes analyzed in turn. The budget office is analyzing several plans, including the leadership's proposal, a Republican alternative and a new measure from a group of bipartisan moderates.
The latest delays in the House heightened the anxiety of members committed to passing major health legislation this year, even as they shared the leadership's frustration with the budget office.
"Delay is something that does not work to our advantage," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland and a leadership ally on health. Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said, "It's going to push the calendar very hard."
 
'Perception of Disarray'
 Representative Pat Williams, a Montana Democrat who is active in health issues, said that while the actual "legislative days" lost were insignificant, the "helter-skelter nature of the scheduling is harmful, because of the perception of disarray."
Republicans have scoffed that the real reason for the delay is that Democrats do not have the votes for their plan. But Democrats insist that they cannot even begin to count heads and make their case until the budget office evaluates the financial impact of competing plans, expected to be at the heart of the debate.
There are several broad political concerns: All along, Democratic strategists have worried that sending members home for the August recess before voting on a bill would expose them to further lobbying and feed their jitters at a critical time. Moreover, some Republicans have mounted a campaign to argue that there is no reason to "rush through" health legislation.
According to the polls, their arguments are finding an increasingly receptive audience, with many Americans now saying it makes sense to slow down and "do it right," thus easing the pressure to act.
Finally, some Democratic strategists say, there is the unknown impact of the Senate's action, which could be largely complete by the time the House gets down to work. This could help with the Democratic effort in the House, if the Senate upholds some form of requirement that employers help pay for their workers' insurance if coverage goals go unmet.
 
Gloom Among Backers
 But some strategists in the House say it could make the effort to pass the far more sweeping Gephardt bill more difficult, if the Senate waters down the plan proposed by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader.
There was a distinct gloom today among some of the members most involved in the health care debate.
Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington and a leader of the liberal wing of the Democratic caucus on health issues, said, "I sat and answered my own phones for a while last night, and people were saying they don't want the Gephardt bill, they don't want the Mitchell bill, and by the way they don't want crime either. So the opposition is pretty well organized."
He added, "Each day makes it less and less likely that we'll have real reform." And Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee, an advocate of the bipartisan plan, said, "The clock is a very tough adversary." He said it was his impression that it would take "a couple of weeks" for the budget office to finish work on the plans.
John Rother, legislative director for the American Association of Retired Persons, which has endorsed the Democratic leadership's bills in both houses, said, "Our polling still shows strong public support for each of the key elements of the Gephardt legislation. But Congress has been hearing mostly from those who want exceptions, exemptions and delay for financial reasons."
Mr. Rother added, "The fate of the bill in the House probably rests with how vocal the majority that supports the bill is during the next two weeks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, at right, spoke to Representative Mike Synar yesterday as they met with groups representing the elderly and disabled at a news conference to oppose the Rowland-Bilirakis bill, a bipartisan bill that would not go as far as Mr. Gephardt's health care proposal. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A21)
 
Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
YESTERDAY
 As Senators continued their speeches on health care, a coalition of moderates worked on a counterproposal to the bill introduced by the majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine. In the House, however, Democratic leaders said delays in the Congressional Budget Office's analysis of rival plans could delay debate for weeks.
 
CONGRESS
 Senate Mr. Mitchell took the Senate floor to say he was tired of hearing Republicans inaccurately describe his bill as a Government takeover of health care. He said his proposal would actually give Americans more choices than they have today. The moderate group, calling itself the "mainstream coalition," may propose its alternative plan to Mr. Mitchell and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. "We've got to scale back the proposal in order to get something passed," said one of the group, Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska.
House The majority leader, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, said uncertainty over when the Congressional Budget Office would complete its work meant that debate would start no later than Sept. 8.
 
WHITE HOUSE
White House officials said legislation that did not include universal coverage could actually result in higher insurance costs. The White House economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said, for example, that Senator Dole's proposal could end up costing families $200 more a year in insurance premiums.
 
(pg. A21)

HEADLINE: Chinese Accused of Pirating Disks

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SUZHOU, China

 BODY:
There is no telephone listing for the Suzhou Polydisk Factory, and visitors to the modern factory sheathed in blue reflecting glass and rose-colored marble are met at the gate by an unsmiling guard who asks them to leave. Now.
"No photographs," the guard says angrily, standing not far from a large billboard quoting China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping: "Science and Technology Are the Number One Productive Force." 
 There is good reason for the hostile reception. According to investigators working for American recording companies, the Suzhou factory's owners are among the biggest pirates of compact disks in Asia. The factory is believed to have pressed hundreds of thousands of pirated disks last year at a cost to the American recording industry and its artists of millions of dollars in lost royalties.
Over all, the United States estimates that Chinese piracy of American intellectual property has cost its companies and performing artists about $1 billion a year.
Consequently, little more than two months after President Clinton renewed special trading privileges for China, the Clinton Administration is threatening to impose sanctions on China unless it closes the nation's 26 compact disk factories and curbs other rampant piracy of videotapes, audio tapes, computer software and books.
In June, the Administration formally designated China a priority target under a clause of the American trade law that gives the Chinese six months to resolve the piracy issue or face sanctions equal to the damage done to the American economy.
After meeting with her Chinese counterparts last month, the deputy United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said in Beijing that while China had "world class" laws to protect intellectual property rights, they were too rarely enforced.
The Chinese Government does not deny that piracy occurs, but its officials say the United States is acting rashly by threatening trade sanctions so soon after China tightened its copyright laws. Last month, the Chinese Government announced new penalties for copyright infringement, including criminal punishments.
"We need more time," said Gao Linghan, deputy director of the National Copyright Administration of China. "Give us five years to end this problem. If we can solve these problems in five years, then I think we will have done a good job."
As for the compact disk factories, Mr. Gao said: "I do not know that all of the 26 factories are producing pirated compact disks. We've asked the Americans to give us evidence, but so far they have not."
But industry specialists say that pirated compact disks are flooding out of China by the tens of millions each year, most headed to the black markets of Southeast Asia.
 
Sound Quality Is High
 While the dubbing on cassette tapes bootlegged in Asia can sound sloppy, the quality of China's pirated compact disks approaches that of legitimate disks, because digital technology makes possible nearly perfect reproduction. And the price is far lower. In Beijing, pirated disks of best-selling albums sell in street markets for about $2, and for not much more when exported to other capitals of Southeast Asia.
"In China, there are very few CD plants that are not involved in blatant piracy," said J. C. Giouw, regional director of the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry. He said Chinese Government investigators did not close the factory in this city, about 75 miles west of Shanghai, even after they discovered that it was pirating works by everyone from Whitney Houston to Kenny G to several Hong Kong pop stars who sing in Cantonese.
Mr. Giouw said the federation had filed suit in China against a Taiwan businessman, Shih Hua Luk, who was accused of making compact disks at the plant in Suzhou and another plant in nearby Hangzhou.
 
Damages Are Sought
 The suit, which seeks about $2 million in damages, contends that Mr. Shih was involved last year in the production of at least 139,000 pirated compact disks at the two Chinese plants, with most of them intended for export to distributors as far away as Argentina.
Mr. Shih was reported to have returned home to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland earlier this year. His lawyer in Shanghai said Mr. Shih denied any wrongdoing. The Suzhou factory's owners did not respond to requests for an interview.
Ms. Barshefsky, the American trade official, noted that China's compact disk factories had a production capacity of about 75 million disks a year, and added that virtually every one of the disks produced in China was pirated. "These factories must be shut down," she said.
 
Family Connections Used
 Industry officials say that most compact disk factories in China are joint ventures with investors from Hong Kong or Taiwan, who cleverly sought partners among the relatives of officials of the Chinese Communist Party. These connections, they said, may explain why there has been so little copyright enforcement until now.
"Because of the Chinese factories, we think we've lost $25 million in Hong Kong alone," said Paul Ewing, vice president and regional director of Warner Music International in Hong Kong. The British crown colony is the destination of millions of Chinese-made pirated disks each year.
Mr. Ewing said the Chinese factories were able to make pirated disks within days of the release of almost any major recording. Only a few weeks after the spring release of a new hit single by Prince, "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World," the song began turning up in Chinese-made pirated compact disks smuggled across the border into Hong Kong.
"They're pirating people like Prince, Phil Collins, Madonna," Mr. Ewing said.
 
Tough for American Companies
 Neil Turkewitz, senior vice president of the Recording Industry Association of America, said that American recording companies had found it "very hard to do business in China" because of Chinese media laws that restrict the distribution of cassette tapes, compact disks or any other form of recording.
As a result, he said, the major recording companies have never reached agreement for their works to be produced in China. Yet the recordings are being reproduced illegally by the tens of millions, with the Chinese Government continuing to assist plant owners by granting import concessions for the machinery needed to make compact disks.
"There are used CD plants that you can acquire for less than $1 million, and because the equipment is viewed as high-tech, the Chinese give inducements for the investment," Mr. Turkewitz said.
The Chinese Government has made at least token efforts to enforce the new intellectual property laws.
 
Software Distributor Raided
 In June, the authorities raided a computer software distributor and four retail shops in Beijing and seized hundreds of computer disks bearing pirated software. Last month, a new intellectual property court in China agreed to hear complaints from three American companies -- Microsoft, Lotus Development and Autodesk -- that their software was being pirated by Chinese retailers.
But those moves came nowhere close to satisfying American industry. "Things are happening much too slowly," said Diane Smiroldo, a spokeswoman in Washington for the Business Software Alliance, which represents most major American companies in the industry.
"We have found targets and brought them to the attention of the Chinese," she said, "and the cases have sort of languished."
The Software Alliance estimates that nearly 95 percent of all the software used in China is pirated and that the resulting losses to American companies totaled more than $300 million last year.
The American recording industry put its losses in China at nearly $345 million last year from pirated compact disks.

HEADLINE: Florida Nearing Emergency As Cuban Exodus Increases

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Nearly 500 Cuban refugees were picked up off the Florida coast today, nudging state officials closer to declaring an immigration emergency that would include the mobilization of the National Guard and state workers to shelter, medically screen and transport large groups of people to relocation centers.
The Coast Guard said late tonight that 537 Cubans had arrived in Florida today, compared with 339 on Tuesday, 282 on Monday and 170 on Sunday. The daily numbers have steadily risen since the beginning of the year and are now the highest since the 1980 Mariel boatlift, which brought 125,200 Cubans to the United States in five months. 
 More than 6,400 Cuban refugees, mostly small groups on makeshift crafts, have made it to the United States since January, compared with 3,656 for all of 1993. Among those passing through the Transit Home for Cuban Refugees on Stock Island today was a 91-year-old woman who left Cuba with 16 others in a raft three days earlier.
A senior State Department official today attributed the exodus to a policy shift by President Fidel Castro of Cuba.
 
Policy Change on Rafters
 "The reason this increase is happening is Castro has changed his policy on rafters," the official said. "He's still stopping big boats, but not rafters. He's stopping boats that are assets of value to Cuba. But he's not stopping people from leaving in rafts. This is a policy decision he took a week and a half ago."
But the official said the current influx was not Mariel II or a slow-motion Mariel.
"The principal characteristic of Mariel was a bunch of people took boats from Florida and picked up people in Cuba," the official said. "There is no sign at all of that happening."
Rafael Dausa, director of political affairs at the Cuban Interest Section in Washington, denied that there had been a change in policy by Havana but warned that unless the United States took measures to stop the refugee flow itself, "we will be in the position of not putting any obstacles" to the departures.
Among the measures he wants the United States to take, Mr. Dausa said, are lifting the economic embargo on Cuba and stopping radio broadcasts from Miami to Cuba.
Both Federal and state officials said on Tuesday that they could still manage without putting into action emergency plans that include blocking vessels and mobilizing thousands of National Guard and state law-enforcement officers to transport large numbers of refugees to processing centers.
 
Governor Prods White House
 Gov. Lawton Chiles called for "an expanded presence" of the Border Patrol and the Immigration and Naturalization Service in South Florida and a "comprehensive test" of the Federal plan to deal with a possible major influx.
Tonight, at a news conference in Key West, the Governor said the situation was "critically approachinhg an emergency," and added: "I'm insisting that the Federal Government prepare to invoke its emergency plan."
Mr. Chiles also said that he had been in touch with the White House and that he might make his request official on Thursday.
Ana Cobian, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department, said that more personnel from both agencies had already been deployed, and that it was adequate for the current needs. She declined to describe the extent of the increase in personnel.
State officials were poised to activate an emergency plan that would dispatch thousands of National Guardsmen and law-enforcement officers to pick up Cuban refugees and take them to temporary reception centers, and then to Homestead Air Force Base south of here for relocation out of state. The plan is meant to support a Federal response for the first 72 hours of the emergency.
 
'No Magic Number' Needed
 But the officials said there was no particular number of refugees to be reached before putting the plan into effect.
"There's no magic number; it varies from county to county," said Eric Tolbert, bureau chief of the Division of Emergency Management in the Florida Department of Community Affairs.
In Dade County, where most Cuban refugees have historically settled, officials were more worried about long-term effects. On Tuesday they asked Attorney General Janet Reno for emergency immigration money for housing, health care and public safety from a $35 million Federal fund that is expected to increase soon to $75 million.
State officials, who have also asked for Federal aid, put the cost to Florida at $1 billion.
As they arrive in increasing numbers, the refugees say they risked dehydration and sharks to escape repression and misery in Cuba. Many said they were prompted to flee by a Government crackdown on the black market, which they say they had relied on for food.
Today the Coast Guard brought in a body on a raft found off Miami. Lieut. Comdr. Jim Howe, a Coast Guard spokesman in Miami, said a pleasure boat spotted the raft that was carrying one dead man and a male companion who survived the trip but was later hospitalized.
 
Scrambling for Supplies
 Refugees said today that despite the risks, many in Cuba were scrambling for supplies to make the 90-mile trip across the Florida Straits to Key West.
A group of 28 Cubans from Villa Clara province said each person in the group of four families and a few friends played a role in making a 22-foot boat in three weeks: one man stole aluminum irrigation pipes from the sugar cane field where he worked to fashion the boat's hull, another bought or traded gathered spare parts and rebuilt the boat's engine from a 1956 Ford.
Most refugees stay with relatives, said workers with the United States Catholic Conference, which helps resettle them. Those who are alone are put into motels until they get their working papers in order. Most are relocated out of state to job markets that offer work in hotels, restaurants and construction.
Today some of the new arrivals who had been moved into motels in Miami spent the time contacting out-of-state relatives by telephone, watching television or simply sitting out near the street.

At the Coast Guard station in Miami Beach, a guardsman lifted a child from the cutter Manitou, which picked up a total of 47 refugees yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Lawyer Says Rifkin's Brain Shows a Defect

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 17

 BODY:
The lawyer for the confessed serial killer Joel Rifkin said today that preliminary neurological testing indicated Mr. Rifkin suffered from a brain dysfunction that might have contributed to his killing spree.
The lawyer, Martin Efman, made his comments on the final day of hearings in Suffolk County, where Mr. Rifkin is charged with killing two women. 
 The hearings were to determine whether a confession that Mr. Rifkin made would be admissible at his coming trial.
Mr. Rifkin, 34, of East Meadow, has admitted killing 17 women, many of them prostitutes, and then dumping their bodies throughout the New York area.
He was convicted in Nassau County of killing one woman and was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison.
 
Testing Is Requested
 During Wednesday's hearing, Mr. Efman asked Judge John Jones of Suffolk County to authorize further testing for Mr. Rifkin, saying, "We want to be able to locate the source of the abnormality."
The judge's authorization was required because Mr. Efman is a court-appointed lawyer and bills in the case are paid by the state.
The defense argues that Mr. Rifkin should not be held criminally responsible for the killings because he suffered from a mental disease or defect.
Mr. Efman said the neurological disorder was one of several factors contributing to the defect.
The defense also plans to contend that Mr. Rifkin, 34, an unemployed landscaper from East Meadow, suffered from adoptive child syndrome. Mr. Rifkin's adoption as an infant caused him such trauma that he became mentally defective, according to the defense.
Mr. Rifkin took the stand today and testified that he asked for a lawyer "at least 20 times" while making a statement to police.
Police detectives testified that that was untrue.
He was charged with killing Leah Evens and Lauren Marquez, both 24, of Manhattan, whose bodies were found in wooded areas of Riverhead.
Judge Jones said he would rule on both the confession and further neurological testing on Aug. 26.

American Cyanamid is being bought for 60 percent more than than its market value, But Wall Street likes the deal, and American Home Products stock has stayed strong. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Seoul Drawing Fire for Crackdowns

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Kim Young Don, a 23-year-old senior at Sogang University, spent last weekend at a "pan-national" rally with thousands of other students, calling for reunification of the Korean peninsula and the expulsion of American troops from South Korea.
The police tried to break up the rally and clashed with studentsarmed with sticks and stones. About 200 people were injured. Finally the police dispersed the crowd by pouring tear-gas fluid on them from helicopters. 
 "We do not think of the Government as a democratic government," Mr. Kim said on Tuesday, the day after the rally ended. "If it was a real democratic Government, people could come out with different views."
The student, a mass communications major, said the police were looking for him because he recently wrote an article praising the late North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung. Such an act is considered illegal in South Korea.
There is not a lot of sympathy in South Korea for Mr. Kim's views on Kim Il Sung. But some critics are beginning to question whether South Korea should be coming down so hard on students for expressing their opinions.
 
Prospects Look Brighter
 The crackdowns, which have intensified since the North Korean President's death last month, come when prospects are growing for an improvement in relations between the two Koreas. One sign was the agreement reached last weekend between the United States and the North Korean Government in Pyongyang on North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons program.
On the same day the demonstrators were doused by helicopter for espousing reunification, South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, proclaimed in a speech that "the Korean people cannot live divided forever." He offered aid to North Korea if it would change its ways.
The South has triumphed in the economic contest with the Communist North. But instead of basking it its victory, some critics say, the South remains locked in a cold-war rivalry that compels it to act like a police state, harming its reputation abroad.
The United States Government has called upon South Korea to change its national security law, which bans any unauthorized contact with North Korea and any show of support for the Communist nation.
But the South Korean Government maintains that the students and other dissidents are being directed by North Korea to destabilize the South and often initiate violence. On Monday, radicals in Kwangju, a city in the southwest, bombed a police station.
 
1,300 Taken Into Custody
 "Acts such as the outright support of the North Korean policies and the use of such murderous weapons as iron pipes, which were wielded against the police -- these acts severely disturb our law and order and are an affront to the state's power," Choi Hyong Woo, the Home Affairs Minister, said at a news conference on Tuesday. "These acts will be sternly dealt with from the standpoint of protecting free democracy."
The police have taken more than 1,300 of the weekend demonstrators into custody.
"It's not proper for the South Korean Government to take an attitude that is so contradictory to the international megatrend," said Lee Boo Young, a National Assembly member from the opposition Democratic Party who was once a student demonstrator.
Mr. Lee, who was scorned for suggesting that South Korea send condolences after the death of Kim Il Sung, said the suppression of dissident views only generated sympathy for a student movement that was "very trivial and small." The chairman of the Democratic Party, Lee Ki Taek, has called the crackdowns a "McCarthyite witch hunt."
South Korea has a decades-long tradition of violent protests by students, and the spraying of tear gas is almost a political rite of passage. "Many of the good officials in our Government have been demonstrators," said Koo Bon Tae, assistant minister of the National Unification Board, which deals with North Korean issues. As a college student in the 1960's, Mr. Koo protested the normalization of relations with Japan, Korea's former colonial ruler.
 
Movement Loses Some Vigor
 The protests have helped bring about democratic changes in South Korea. By all accounts, since the election a year and a half ago of Kim Young Sam, the first civilian President in more than three decades, the student movement has lost some of its reason for being and its vigor.
Some say it is surprising that President Kim, who was himself a dissident fighting the military dictatorships that once ruled South Korea, should be so harsh on the students. Some analysts here say it is simply politics. Conservatives who revile North Korea and Kim Il Sung form the base of support for President Kim's Democratic Liberal Party.
The student demonstrations are organized by student councils on each campus that are in turn coordinated by the Federation of Korean Student Councils.
Fear about the students rose last month when the Rev. Park Hong, a Jesuit priest and the president of Sogang University, said he had evidence that the student protesters were being fed instructions from North Korea. More recently he said in a newspaper interview that "jusapa," or followers of Kim Il Sung's ideology of self-reliance, had also infiltrated religious organizations, newspapers and political parties.
Newspaper editorials and Government officials are now demanding that Father Park provide proof of his statements. For his part, the university president is lying low, and he declined a request for an interview.
 
180 Students Join Protest
 On Tuesday, the student council office at Sogang was a pigsty of empty soft drink cans and food cartons, buckets of paint and crumpled banners left over from the pan-national rally, which took place from Saturday through Monday, coinciding with a national holiday commemorating Korea's liberation from Japanese colonial rule.
Mr. Kim, the 23-year-old protester, said he was one of 180 students from Sogang who attended the rally, which was held at Seoul National University. On other occasions, he said, such protests have been able to draw up to 800 of Sogang's 7,000 students.
Mr. Kim, who has a friendly smile and easy manner, said he joined the student movement to fight for democracy, reunification and the expulsion of American troops, who symbolize "the colonial relationship between America and South Korea."
Asked how he could call for greater democracy in South Korea yet not criticize far greater restrictions on rights in North Korea, Mr. Kim said that while North Koreans could not speak freely, "if you look at it from a Korean point of view it does have its own style of democracy."
"In Western theory," he continued, "the more you suppress, the more people revolt. But North Korea has sustained their society for decades" without revolt. "Why have they been able to do it? They have their own type of democracy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students confronting the police on Sunday at Seoul National University. The police broke up their rally. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Pataki Charges Cuomo Put Mansion Budget to Own Use

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
In a campaign dog-and-pony show -- minus the pony but starring the dog -- the Republican gubernatorial candidate, George E. Pataki, yesterday used an array of props and the less-than-original vehicle of a Lettermanesque Top 10 list to charge that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has misused taxpayer money to enhance his life style.
Atop Mr. Pataki's list of "Mario's most wasteful spending" was the use of the Executive Mansion budget last year to pay for flea collars and housebreaking "wee-wee pads" for Mr. Cuomo's dogs, Cara and Max. To illustrate that expenditure, Mr. Pataki summoned his own dog, Jefferson, into the news conference at his Manhattan headquarters. Jefferson, who is named for the third President, a Democrat, dutifully sat and barked for a milk bone at his master's command. 
 The event and the Cuomo campaign's response were typical of what New York's gubernatorial campaign has become in the political doldrums before Labor Day.
Although Mr. Pataki, a State Senator from Putnam County, faces a Sept. 13 primary against Richard M. Rosenbaum, he and Mr. Cuomo and their surrogates have spent the last month exchanging a volley of charges, countercharges, news releases and lawsuits about personal finances and campaign practices. While each candidate has worked to sully the other's integrity, they have devoted far less attention to issues like crime and the economy, which polls show are the primary concerns of the voters.
 
Christmas Tree an Issue
 At one point yesterday, Mr. Pataki took Mr. Cuomo to task because Executive Mansion officials spent $105.80 last year for mail-order Christmas trees. "With millions of trees growing in the Adirondacks, with our Christmas trees good enough to be in the White House, year after year Mario Cuomo sends to an exclusive mail-order catalogue for out-of-state Christmas trees," he said indignantly.
Cuomo officials fired back that the artificial trees were a one-time purchase and that the mansion's primary tree is bought each year from a New York grower. Joel R. Benenson, Mr. Cuomo's campaign press secretary, then characterized Mr. Pataki's charge as "another example of George Pataki saying things that simply aren't true."
Mr. Pataki said his main message yesterday was that Mr. Cuomo's government has wasted money at a time when the state budget was growing faster than inflation and when "we're seeing taxes drive jobs and opportunity out of this state."
Mr. Benenson responded by saying, "If George Pataki truly has the taxpayer's interest at heart, what he should do is release his Top 10 list of personal-tax loopholes that show he paid no Federal income tax in a year when he made a $400,000 killing in a real-estate deal."
 
Examining Mansion Budget
 That was a reference to last week's disclosure in Mr. Pataki's tax returns, which he allowed reporters to review on Friday, that he and his wife paid no Federal income taxes in 1986. They made a profit of $401,666 that year on the sale of a piece of land, but their accountant said they were allowed to defer paying capital-gains taxes on the profit because they immediately bought a more expensive investment property. Payment of the tax is deferred until the investment property is sold, the accountant said.
Mr. Pataki gleaned the examples in his Top 10 list from news reports published over the last five years about spending at the Executive Mansion and about the Governor's use of state aircraft for uses other than state business. He said he thought he could halve spending at the mansion, except for security. He pledged that he and his family would use state aircraft for state business only.
Among the items on Mr. Pataki's list was the use of the mansion's budget to buy a $19,000 stereo system and to pay for subscriptions to fashion magazines. The mansion budget was $462,700 when Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983, rose to a peak of $772,000 in 1989 and is now $484,000.
After Newsday revealed some of the expenditures last month, Mr. Cuomo said that a few of the items, including the dog-care products, were inappropriate purchases that had fallen through the cracks. He said he would reimburse the state $25 to pay for them. Mr. Cuomo and his aides also emphasize that the Governor returns $30,000 of his $130,000 salary to the state each year.
Mr. Cuomo and members of his family periodically use the state airplane and helicopters to take personal trips that do not involve state business. His aides contend that it is appropriate for Mr. Cuomo to use the plane for personal trips because, in Mr. Benenson's words, "he is Governor 24 hours a day."

HEADLINE: Arms Plants Provide Civilians' Power

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOMSK, Russia

 BODY:
What could be wrong with the agreement last June between Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia to close the two reactors here that keep making bomb-grade plutonium? After all, most people think there is already too much plutonium and no place to put it.
"Tomsk would be frozen," is the answer from Nikolai A. Vyatkin, general director of Tomskenergo, the electric utility here in this provincial capital in Siberia, about 2,500 miles east of Moscow. 
 The Soviet Union integrated its bomb manufacturing with its civilian economy so thoroughly that the city of Tomsk is connected to these reactors by an umbilical cord, four steel pipes, each 4 feet in diameter, that carry steam from the reactor 19 miles through the birch and cedar woods. The heat, produced as the reactors create bomb fuel, keeps apartment buildings and factories in this city of 500,000 from freezing through the nine-month winter.
The reactor is in a nearby settlement called Tomsk-7, which is still a closed military zone. The city depends on the reactor for about a quarter of the heat used in the district heating system.
Russia has agreed to close the plant by 2000 and the United States has agreed to help look for financing, but a close look at developments here suggests that the deadline is not likely to be met.
A conventional power plant, the first of five that local officials say will be needed and will cost $740 million, has been under construction at the edge of town for the last six years -- so long that its brick facade is already crumbling in places, and the dandelions and ragweed have covered up some of the construction debris.
The plant would burn oil, gas or coal, whichever is available, to make electricity and steam. It is already hooked into the gas and steam pipes, and the tracks are in place to bring in brown coal from Krasnoyarsk, also in Siberia.
But in June, 1,200 workers from a construction enterprise in Tomsk 7, unpaid for three months, went home. The Russian federal government promised 70 billion rubles for the project but has paid only 16 billion.
The United States Trade and Development Agency promised a grant of up to $1 million to write a feasibility study for this plant and four others; the study could be used to apply for financing from the World Bank or other sources.
But under current circumstances no one would loan the money, because the utility charges only a pittance for its services and collects even less. One kilowatt-hour of electricity sells for one-third of a cent, a thirtieth of its cost in the United States, and the steam to heat a three-room apartment costs about 65 cents a month. Even that is evidently too high for the customers; Tomskenergo says it is owed 80 billion rubles, or $40 million, by factories, hospitals, colleges, schools and others.
 
An Economy in Crisis
 No one is anxious to charge more because, despite rapid inflation, salaries here remain low and the economy is in desperate straits.
Tomskenergo itself is in something of a time warp. Engineers there have a detailed plan for replacing the reactor's steam -- illustrated with a chart hand-drawn in colored pencil.
There are many other ways Tomsk could keep warm. The natural gas that comes out of the oil fields a few hundred miles northwest of here is routinely burned as waste, because the local price is 10 to 15 rubles a cubic meter, about one-sixth the international price, said Mr. Vyatkin. The gas could be turned into electricity that was sent here over existing electric lines, according to local officials. But that, too, takes money.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Measuring the pain of the deadlock on health care reform.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH Democrats badly split over health care reform and Republicans caught up in the role of spoilers, the prospect for health care legislation this year is dimming. Does it matter?
It certainly does to President Clinton, who can ill afford another legislative bruise in a town that shows no mercy to lamed politicians. 
 The tougher question is whether deadlock on health care reform would change other Americans' lives for the worse. And while the answer obviously depends on what sort of reforms are really at stake -- the politics are so fluid that just about anything could emerge from Congress if and when it is galvanized to act -- much also turns on the way one expects the system would evolve without Washington's help.
Martin Feldstein, an economist at Harvard and former adviser to President Reagan, is relatively sanguine. "This is not a magic moment," he argues. "If legislation doesn't pass in the next four weeks, it doesn't mean legislation won't pass in the next four years."
More to the point, though, he is not particularly worried that the alleged problems of the system are destined to fester. The fact that most new jobs lack medical insurance does not prove that a crisis is looming, he says.
"The big growth in the labor force has been second earners," he argues, "who don't need the coverage and would rather take home higher wages."
Then there is the issue of cost containment, which was the original focus of the Clinton task force. "A lot of the market-based reforms are already happening," Mr. Feldstein notes.
Insurers and big employers, he points out, are using their bargaining power to ratchet down the prices charged by physicians and drug companies. And programs that reimburse providers per illness rather than per service have "put a lot of pressure" on costs. "I'm pleasantly surprised by the hospitals' lack of success in gaming the system," he reports.
What's more, Mr. Feldstein is not ready to lose sleep over the uninsured. No one, he notes, can be turned away at the emergency room door for lack of a Blue Cross card.
And while Mr. Feldstein acknowledges the shortcomings of a rag-tag system that spends too much on acute care for the poor and too little on preventive care, he does not see universal coverage as a moral imperative.
Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, could hardly disagree more. For one thing, he worries that the window for reform is closing rapidly and may not reopen in the foreseeable future.
The midterm election will probably add Republicans to the Senate, he notes, deepening the conservative-liberal split on health care with the House and making a nonpartisan compromise far less likely.
Mr. Aaron agrees that President Clinton would be in a position to make another push for reform if he is re-elected in 1996. But he wonders whether the President would "have the stomach for reviving what was a futile effort."
None of this would matter, of course, if health care-as-usual were adequate -- and destined to remain so.
But Mr. Aaron does not share Professor Feldstein's sanguinity. He acknowledges that cost pressures have abated somewhat in the last few years, but doubts that the pause reflects any enduring capacity of the system to repair itself.
Mr. Aaron points out that when health care inflation is plotted over the last quarter century, there are dips comparable to the current one, but no discernible trend toward a lower rate.
And he does not expect a favorable trend to emerge: "Science has not lost its cunning" to generate expensive medical technology, he insists; nor have medical providers lost their incentives to overuse it.
Uwe Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School, adds an ominous note to the debate about whether incipient market forces are indeed taming cost inflation.
Most of the savings, he argues, have actually been driven by employers and insurers who have become more vigilant in preventing physicians and hospitals from passing along costs not covered by Medicaid or by walk-in patients lacking the means to pay.
"A lot of this fat will be squeezed out," he predicts. And as a result, the pressures to skimp on the quality of care for the poor will grow, he argues, and "the unwritten catastrophic insurance" now provided to the formally uninsured "may not get financed."
Perhaps the most distressing aspect of this disagreement about the potential consequences of inaction is the context: After more than a year of maneuvering and speculation about health care reform, the real issues are only now being debated.
That may be the way of modern American democracy, and it may yet work out for the best. But then again, maybe it will not. Too much, Mr. Aaron argues, could turn on whether "we have the guts to begin the process of change."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From the Senate Debate on the Mitchell Health Care Legislation

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from statements made yesterday on the Senate floor in the eighth day of debate over the health care bill, as transcribed by The New York Times from a broadcast on C-Span:
 
 
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR GRASSLEY
 To contrast the Mitchell bill to the status quo alternative:
Today any insurance company can, first of all, deny you coverage. Secondly, impose a pre-existing-condition exclusion so they can say, Well, look, if you have that pre-existing condition, we can exclude you for that existing condition. Limit your lifetime benefits so that your protection runs out when you need it the most. They can cancel it and cancel your coverage when you get sick.
We've had several examples in the very recent weeks of employers for good companies that had their health care canceled for all of their employees because of the incidence of illness among just a few of their employees and just effectively canceled out within a two- or three-month period.
There's also the exclusion of any service from coverage, even a service that might turn out to be most important to you if someone in your family becomes seriously ill.
And no American is guaranteed choice.
And I think these following points are worthwhile to keep in mind:
If your employer doesn't offer a plan you like, you can be out of luck. And 84 percent of employers offer only one plan. Of the employers that make available health insurance to their employees, they provide one plan. Effectively, out of luck if you wanted an alternative choice. You take it or leave it.
Secondly, if your employer doesn't offer a plan that allows you to keep your family doctor, you're also out of luck. . . .
And the Dole plan is better than the status quo alternative, but it's still I don't believe good enough. The insurance companies can still impose pre-existing-condition limitations, they can sell you a policy that doesn't cover the service you may need the most . . . because policies aren't required to provide comprehensive coverage.
 
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR SMITH
 My office has received thousands of phone calls and letters, more phone calls and letters, I think, than anything since I've been in the Congress, on the issue of health care reform. Both sides.
I hosted a statewide health care conference earlier this year, in April, that featured leading policy experts from every facet of the health care delivery system. There were doctors, and there were providers and nurses and patients and everyone who had in some way had an impact, or were impacted by any change in legislation in the health care industry. . . .
In addition to that, I have 10 counties in my state and I have held a town meeting in each of those counties. . . . We were there to directly hear from constituents regarding the issue of health care reform. And they spoke out. There were hundreds of them, in all of those town meetings, more than any ever attended any of my citizen forums on any issue. . . .
In short, I guess the fairest thing to say is I've heard New Hampshire speak to me, with me, on this issue. And overwhelmingly what they're saying is that they don't want the Government any more involved in health care than it is already involved now. In other words, less Government involvement.
I think there's a concern, unfortunately, that comes through as I listen to these constituents and providers, and all of those who are in any way affected by this pending legislation. There's a concern that the Government is going to do something to me on this issue.
I think that's coming through loud and clear, and it's a very valid concern: Rather than helping us, they're going to do something to me that may cost me my good quality health care.
And the polls, the national polls, which have changed dramatically from overwhelming support to what President Clinton had proposed to the opposite now, . . . show that Americans share the same feelings as those people in New Hampshire. So I don't think there's a great difference between the states, no matter what state you represent on this issue.
I believe that based on what I have heard, people that I've talked with, that most Americans would oppose not only the underlying finance bill, which is technically on the floor, but also the Clinton-Mitchell-Gephardt, or Clinton-Mitchell bill, as we have here. Fifty-three percent, according to the polls, worry that Congress will pass a plan that gives the Federal Government too much control. And that's a very valid concern. They're suspicious because Government has proven again and again that it's not efficient, it's not compassionate, it's not thrifty and therefore shouldn't be trying to provide for the health care needs of people, least of all health care.
If a mistake is made by a Government official in, perhaps, the administration of the I.R.S., or some other program -- post office, perhaps, late delivering the mail -- it's a problem, maybe, but it's a minor problem compared to some slip-up in the treatment of your health.
 
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR HATFIELD
 What we're trying to do in Oregon is to provide everybody with standard, primary health care. We're not going to separate every Siamese twin born in Oregon; we're not going to guarantee, in essence, that everybody has the right to any medical procedure -- over 9,000 of them under Medicare alone. We have prioritized them.
People say, Oh, that's rationing health care. Well, we're rationing health care, yes, but we're doing that today under an economic face which is certainly discriminatory, far more discriminatory than saying to a person 80 years old, If you have a life expectancy added to your life by one year, are we going to engage in a very costly medical procedure as against covering 100 women with prenatal care? No. We can't afford to do it.
Now that gets down to where the real rubber hits the road in terms of having to make the tough decisions that somehow we're going to offer anyone any medical procedure or access to any medical procedure. That's the implication, because we've not addressed those thousands of medical procedures and we . . . have the attitude that any one of them -- and it's very, very clear -- any one of them would be open for anyone.
What Oregon has done is it focuses on the provision of preventive health care services and assesses an access to primary health care before serious health problems develop. Now, it looks at the effectiveness of treatment, it draws lines, as I say, to exclude payment of services that are not effective nor add to the individual's quality of life.
I think we have to face this reality in the national picture as well.
 
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR MITCHELL
 I hope the American people will not be fooled by the rhetoric they're hearing here today. And I hope the American people will also think about the irony of these Republican senators getting up here day after day after day and denouncing Government health insurance and Government health care as bad for their constituents even as they benefit from it themselves as individuals and their families.
Every member of this Senate participates in the Government-run health insurance system that's available to all Federal employees. And the Government pays 72 percent of the cost of that health insurance for these Republican senators who are standing here telling their constituents that it's bad for the constituents even as they participate in it for themselves and their families.
You American taxpayers are paying through the Government, 72 percent of the cost of health insurance in a Government-organized health insurance system for the very Republican senators who are now telling you that you shouldn't want Government-run health insurance.
And you are entitled to ask yourselves if it is so bad for you, why is it so good for them and their families.
Has one of them stood up and said, "My constituents, Government health insurance is bad for you, and to prove how much I believe that statement, I'm going to voluntarily drop out of the Government insurance system. And I'm going to put my family in the same place where your family is."
Have you heard one say that yet? No. And you're not likely to.
Now that's just the insurance. Now let's talk about direct care.
If one of these Republican senators doesn't feel well, if he gets a headache, or his stomach aches, he walks a few feet down the Capitol and he goes to the office of the Capitol physician, a Government employee. He is greeted by a clerk who is a Government employee, checked by a nurse who is a Government employee and then goes in to see the doctor, who is a Government employee.
If Government health care is so bad, why do these Republican senators insist on having it for themselves? And then if they get sick, if the doctor says, You've got to go to the hospital, they go to the Bethesda Naval Hospital, or the Walter Reed Army Hospital, Government hospitals. Well, my gosh, ask yourselves, Mr. and Mrs. America, If these Government facilities are so bad, why do these Republican senators want to go there themselves?
And it's not just senators. President Reagan and President Bush were in their capacities as President the most powerful men in the world. And they were independently wealthy, and they could have gone anywhere in the world when they got sick.
And where did they go? Why they went to these Government hospitals. And who can forget the photographs taken of them waving out the window to the public and the press in those Government hospitals?
Why, are you telling us that it's good enough for Presidents, but it's not good enough for ordinary Americans?
 
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR BRADLEY
 The Senate's effort to reform the American system of health care has important consequences for all Americans. It will determine the availability and the extent of health care for each of us. It will determine in part how long our parents will live and how healthy our children will be.
As we debate this issue, let's remember what brought us here in the first place. We are not debating this issue by chance. There's a reason why we all speak of this effort as health care reform. In dozens of living rooms and conference halls, in emergency rooms of hospitals and on street corners, the message that I hear from the people of New Jersey is that we need reform.
Our current system is not working as it should; those who have health coverage are paying too much for it, and those without health coverage deserve it. . . .
What people want most is some control of escalating health care costs. What people fear the most is losing their health care if they change jobs or get laid off or lose a job because of a corporate bankruptcy.
What perplexes them as well, when they're confronted with all these escalating costs of health care, is the power of the insurance industry. Want coverage for your heart problem? The insurance company says no because it's a pre-existing condition. In other words, the insurance company will insure you for everything but the heart condition that is most likely to generate the health costs for your family.
In confronting skyrocketing health care costs, small business is left to the mercy of insurance companies. Small businesses have no leverage to negotiate with insurance companies. Too often they're presented with a take-it or leave-it choice that only offers exorbitant costs for health care coverage.
Each of us can enumerate countless occasions in our states when we've had interactions with small-business people who've simply said they can't afford to cover the workers in their particular small business, they can't afford to cover because they were told by the insurance company that it's $6,000 or $7,000 a person and they have no leverage to negotiate with the insurance company.
If you get open-heart surgery, the tab is $49,000. A Caesarean section birth, $7,500.
Remarkably, women of higher incomes have more Caesarean section births. I don't think that's related to a differential in the size of the birth canal; it's related to the ability to afford to pay.
And a visit to an orthopedist, $300 for the first visit, $175 for each visit after that.
Most people have become accustomed to good health care, even with these costs. The health care simply costs too much, more than it should cost.
When President Clinton proposed health care reform last year, none of us thought he was imagining the problem. There was consensus that we should act, we should do something. The political noise of the last 12 months aside, health care reform is as needed today as it was then. The families who need it are still here, in New Jersey and all of our states. The families that don't have the health care need it as much today as they did a year ago. All those of us who were paying health costs today are paying too much today, just as we were paying too much a year ago. . . .
It is the job of Government to protect the public health and welfare in the short and long term of its citizens.
How to do this in the area of health care is the essence of what this debate is all about. Our fundamental goal should be to enable a competitive health care marketplace to keep people healthy but take care of them when it does not.
By and large, America's health care system is an excellent system, but it does have a few glaring faults. We should block or undermine those elements that work in our current system. We should fix those areas that don't work, and in so doing, improve the overall system.
Recent trends suggest the health care markets are becoming more competitive and efficient. We can spur that process by insuring that insurance companies compete on price and quality, not on their ability to omit high-risk patients. Managed competition is beginning to bring better health care at lower prices to many Americans.
