HEADLINE: Haitian Chief Buffs Image On the Streets

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras strode confidently down the street, looking not like the dictator and impediment to democracy that Washington makes him out to be, but like an earnest candidate on the campaign trail.
Dressed in civilian clothes for a foray into the countryside on Monday, General Cedras shook hands, smiled and danced with his wife during a stop at a cantina as the television cameras focused on him. 
 After a career spent avoiding the limelight and exercising power from the shadows, the military strongman who toppled Haiti's elected civilian president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in a September 1991 coup has suddenly stepped out of the barracks and into the streets. During the last three weeks, General Cedras has made more public appearances than in the last three years.
 
A Public Relations Blitz
 To threats by the United States that it will invade Haiti if he does not step down, General Cedras has responded less with arms than with a public relations campaign. His Haitian supporters and foreign diplomats agree that the target of that effort is not just the Haitian public but also audiences abroad, mainly in the United States.
During his trip on Monday to the town of Petit-Goave, about 40 miles southwest of the capital, General Cedras actually had little to say. But the sight of the normally formal and dour commander in chief of the Haitian armed forces walking the streets in blue jeans, smiling and greeting the populace, sent a message: rather than backing down in the face of Washington's threat to invade, General Cedras remains confident, reasonable and in complete command.
"Threats to invade, or even the passage of Resolution 940 clearly don't mean anything to these people," one diplomat said, referring to the July 31 United Nations resolution that authorizes the United States and its allies to use "all necessary means" to overthrow the Haitian military.
That message has not been lost on Father Aristide's supporters, either. "Each day there is a new sign of the military's intention to stay," Micha Gaillard, a spokesman for Konakom, an umbrella group of pro-Aristide political organizations, said of General Cedras's recent high visibility.
 
A Campaign Stop?
 "He looked to me like he's thinking of running for president and that was the start of his campaign," another opposition leader said on Tuesay of General Cedras's outing on Monday. "It's a very smart thing for him to come out in public like that, because it signals his people that the boss is standing firm and isn't worried."
General Cedras's show of confidence has to some extent also undermined the economic sanctions imposed on Haiti that were intended to encourage the country's economic elite to move against the military.
"If you Americans think that business people can force the military to leave now, you're crazy," a leading businessman said last week, speaking on condition he not be identified. "What kind of pressure can we exert? If we go to Cedras and tell him he has to leave, he will laugh at us."
The position of General Cedras and his associates was bolstered further on Tuesday when, in remarks widely reported here, Secretary of Defense William Perry told NBC News that an invasion of Haiti would only be a last resort. Mr. Perry added that while the situation there continues to be of concern to Washington, Haiti was not of vital interest to the United States.
 
Family Man and Churchgoer
 General Cedras's campaign began in late July when he and his family showed up for dinner one night at a popular seafood restaurant in Petionville, the capital's most elite suburb, with a small security team and seated themselves at a table among the other diners. A few days later, he attended Sunday morning services at a Methodist church here, where he was filmed by American television crews that had been alerted in advance of his appearance.
At the same time, General Cedras was making himself available to selected reporters. In an interview with Robert Novak of CNN, General Cedras said he thought a United States invasion of Haiti was inevitable, and warned that American soldiers would be killed if they land here. But for the most part, General Cedras has avoided a belligerent tone and sought to portray himself as a patriot, family man and churchgoer.
The excursion into the countryside on Monday was preceded by an Assumption Day mass at the cathedral here, celebrated by a Roman Catholic bishop sympathetic to the military, that was also the culmination four days of "national reflection and prayer" on the crisis. General Cedras, a Protestant, attended the Catholic ceremony with all nine members of the military high command, an unusual concentration of top brass that seemed intended to dispel persistent rumors of divisions among the military leaders.
"He's pulling out all the stops, and showing that he can be very good at this sort of pubic relations thing," one diplomat said of General Cedras. "Of course, his position hasn't changed at all. But people are looking at him in a new light, and that itself is a victory for the Government."

HEADLINE: A Matter of Timing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In raising interest rates on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve invoked a belief that is dogma on Wall Street and often challenged elsewhere -- that the American economy is not capable of moving toward more prosperity now.
That view is not stated so baldly. Softer language is used. The nation does not have enough qualified workers to supply a stronger economy, the argument goes. Nor are there enough factories, machinery and computers, or enough steel and other materials used in manufacturing. So allowing economic growth to continue unchecked will result in too much competition for scarce resources and a lot of inflation. 
 This is sometimes the case. But there is evidence to suggest that now might be just the wrong moment to invoke the "capacity" argument, as the Fed has done, as a justification for raising interest rates to slow the economy.
The National Association of Manufacturers says plenty of elbow room exists for more production. The Federal Reserve's own statistics are not alarming. And even if capacity is running short, some economists, including the Fed's new vice chairman, Alan Blinder, say that not much extra inflation is likely to result.
"My view is that if you have a small overshooting of normal capacity, then you have a small acceleration of inflation," Mr. Blinder said in an interview the week before the Fed decided to make short-term interest rates a half-point higher.
Mr. Blinder, who joined the Fed this summer from President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, voted for Tuesday's increase in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent from 4.25 percent, and the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges for its own loans to banks, to 4 percent from 3.5 percent. But he differs, he said, from the prevailing view on the Fed, that overshooting on capacity by even a small amount will cause a big rise in inflation.
Whatever the viewpoint, everyone -- the economists, the politicians, business executives, bankers and labor leaders -- agrees on one point. If the Federal Reserve, which has raised interest rates five times this year, gets them high enough, then the economy will slow, capacity will go begging and fewer and fewer jobs will be created.
That is where the agreement ends and the debate begins. And with increasing openness it is a debate about the trade-off between jobs and inflation. "Governments today have only one effective way to control inflation: restrain economic growth," Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant, said. "In cruder terms, this means establishing and maintaining sufficient unemployment to keep labor costs under control."
Of course, if inflation rises fast enough and high enough, it almost certainly becomes a greater evil than the rising unemployment that results from slower economic growth and less use of capacity and people. The question is, is that likely to happen in the coming months?
Mr. Blinder seems less concerned that this will happen than Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who expresses a view widely held on Wall Street: Inflation is likely to accelerate rapidly as more of the nation's capacity is employed, and then it becomes very hard to stop.
Although inflation today is only about 3 percent, the acceleration has begun, says David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street investment house. "In this environment, with companies operating at close to full capacity, a little expansion results in a sudden acceleration in inflation," he said.
Mr. Jones's firm has a stake in this debate. Its clients are people who have accumulated wealth and loan it out through various investments, including those managed by Wall Street firms like Lanston. For these people, and there are millions of them, inflation, or even the possibility of it, is anathema; it destroys the purchasing power of their savings. For the savers, inflation is a greater evil than joblessness, and, they say, nothing pushes up inflation faster than the demands for wage increases that come with rising employment.
 
 
'Leading Edge'
 "The wage issue is really one involving skilled labor," Mr. Jones said. "That is where the wage pressure begins to arise. We are getting pockets of skilled labor shortages around the country and they will become the leading edge for wage pressures that will spread."
Labor capacity, in sum, is being used up. But that is an assertion that the National Association of Manufacturers, no ally of wage pressures, flatly rejects. The association seldom criticizes the Federal Reserve but did so this week, appealing to the Fed on the eve of its meeting not to raise interest rates.
In doing so, the manufacturers' association gave the debate a different twist. True, it said, employment is rising and factories are using up more capacity than six months ago -- but there is no shortage of capacity, nor a danger of one.
"There has been too much looking at plant capacity and not enough examination of labor and that has led to an incorrect estimate of capacity utilization," said Gordon Richards, a senior economist at the association.
 
 
'Not Making Wage Demands'
 "There are large numbers of temporary, part-time and contract workers out there who are counted as employed but are in reality competing for permanent jobs, and they are not making wage demands," he said. "There are enormous amounts of disguised slack in the labor market."
Neither the view that capacity is ample, as Mr. Gordon argues, or in short supply, as Mr. Jones believes, is strongly supported -- or strongly undercut -- by Government statistics.
The Federal Reserve staff compiles the data on utilization of industrial capacity. The figures show that manufacturers, the key group, were using 83.1 percent of their capacity in July, which is slightly above the average of 81.2 percent for the years 1967 through 1993, and below the levels for the late 1970's (87.3 percent) and the late 1980's (85.1 percent). These were the last two periods of sharply rising inflation.
Sheets of steel are often cited as a prime example of a key material in short supply. American manufacturers are operating almost flat out in making this item and the price has risen by 12 percent over the last year. "But there is still plenty of capacity elsewhere in the world to make this steel and that puts a damper on sheet steel prices," said Walter Carter, the steel specialist at DRI/McGraw-Hill. "The prices of imported sheet steel have risen only 4 percent in the past year."
 
 
Unemployment Rate
 The Labor Department's unemployment number, a relatively low 6.1 percent in July, is similarly hard to evaluate. Many economists believe that it is low enough to signal nearly full employment and the beginning of labor shortages and wage pressures. But the unemployment rate is based on a monthly survey that the Labor Department revamped this year. Until the Department has had more experience with the survey, it will not be able to judge the accuracy of the unemployment figures, economists say.
Suppose the Fed had not raised rates on Tuesday? What might have happened? Mr. Jones and others argue that the economy would spurt ahead, beyond its capacity. And while plenty of jobs might be created, inflation would jump. Then the Federal Reserve's efforts to bring down inflation, through a big increase in interest rates, might create a recession and many of the people who got jobs would lose them. Better to create fewer jobs now and avoid the layoffs later, this argument goes.
But what if the economy were allowed to grow smartly now and inflation did not rise very strongly? "We don't have great shortages, with people waiting in line, and a let-it-rip approach would lead to only a modest increase in inflation," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
What's more, he added, even if the Fed did not exist and there were no one to manipulate interest rates, a robust economy would eventually slow down on its own. "That's the nature of business cycles," Mr. Gordon said. "And people would lose jobs."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Mixed A Day After Fed Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with longer maturities giving up a little of the gains made Tuesday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's move to increase short-term interest rates half a percentage point.
The 30-year bond fell 9/32 , to a price of 1019/32 , yielding 7.39 percent, up from 7.37 percent on Tuesday, following the market's biggest rally in two weeks after the Fed's fifth interest rate rise of the year. 
 Prices of shorter-maturity bills and intermediate-term notes increased with investors' confidence that the Fed is through for the moment in raising rates to fight inflation or the fear of it. The three-month bill rates dropped 4 basis points, to 4.56 percent, while a six-month rate was down a couple, to 4.91 percent.
Alan Kral, a portfolio manager for Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., an investment management firm, said he was pleased how things had worked out. "I'm encouraged by the market's performance," he said. "We're bullish and think rates are coming down further," he said. "We are now six months into this cycle of interest rate hikes and inflation still has not shown in up in any of the indicators." There is no way, he added, that "we think inflation is going to go to 4.75 percent and eliminate the real rate of interest now set in the Federal funds rate." He said, "Mr. Greenspan, we think has achieved what he wanted."
With regard to the economy's rate of growth, Mr. Kral believes that since the economy is coming out of a slow growth period, it can handle a 3.5 percent rate of growth for a little longer, without sparking inflation, than some other analysts think. "I see the long bond rallying for the rest of the year," he said.
 
A Shift in Fed Policy
 According to a number of market analysts, the Fed increase on Tuesday disclosed one new point about the central bank's policy. There has been a shift in the strategy of the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee away from frequent quarter-point moves to a less frequent half-point moves.
Peter McTeague, a market analysts with MCM MoneyWatch in Boston, a market research and analysis firm, said his firm's latest weekly investor survey conducted on Monday just before the rate rise showed investors in their most defensive posture this year. "Now with many thinking the worst is out of the way, it would seem that the bulk of the selling is done for the near term and managers will be looking to put money to work," he said. He says that where they are most "under-invested" is in the 5-to-10-year maturities.
In the municipal bond market, prices received a boost from declining investor concern about inflation. It helped raise demand for the $2.2 billion in new securities coming to market.
One trader noted that the market is driven by greed and fear, and on Tuesday the Fed removed some of that fear.
In perhaps the week's largest debt offering, California priced $700 million of various-purpose general-obligation bonds that were won by Merrill Lynch in competitive bidding.
Serial bonds were priced to yield from 4.30 percent in 1996 to 6.05 percent in 2013 and 2014. Except for the bonds due in 1999, 2007 and 2019, which are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's, the rest of the financing is insured by either the Ambac Indemenity Corporation, the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, or the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated triple-A.
Underwriters said the deal was well recieved by the large institutional investors.
Goldman, Sachs won the Illinois offering of $687 million in 4 3/4 percent general obligation certificates. In the first part $187 million of certificates due April 17, 1995, were priced to yield 3.85 percent; $200 million due May 15, 1995, were priced to yield 3.95 percent, and $300 million of the certificates due June 15, 1995, were priced to yield 4 percent.
Underwriters said the deal was rated MIG-1 by Moody's and SP1+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Benjamin Esterman, 88, Dies; Ophthalmologist and Surgeon

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Benjamin Esterman, an eye surgeon who helped found the specialized glaucoma clinic at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital in 1936, died on Sunday at Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 88 and lived in Lawrence, L.I.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 In the 1960's, Dr. Esterman devised a simple and economical method of measuring loss of peripheral vision resulting from eye disease, injury or brain disorders. The American Academy of Ophthalmology honored him for it in 1972 and again two years ago, citing him also for his overall contributions in the field.
He was associated with Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat for more than 40 years, performing thousands of operations and training hundreds of young physicians before his retirement in 1980. During those years he also worked at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and served as director of eye surgery at Peninsula Hospital Center and Long Island Jewish Medical Center.
Born in Vilna, Lithuania, Dr. Esterman was brought to this country as an infant and grew up in Brooklyn. He graduated from Columbia College and Cornell University Medical School and completed his specialized training at New York Post-Graduate Hospital and Knapp Memorial Hospital.
He kept a private practice in Far Rockaway and Lawrence from 1937 until recently.
He contributed many articles to professional journals. He also wrote "The Eye Book, a Specialist's Guide to Your Eyes and Their Care," which was published by Great Ocean Publishers in 1977 and remains in print.
Dr. Esterman is survived by his wife of 21 years, Cinnabelle Morris Esterman; a daughter, Laura Esterman of Manhattan; three sons, Daniel of Manhattan, Mark of Arlington, Va., and the film maker Errol Morris of Cambridge, Mass., and seven grandchildren. His first wife, Sophie Milgram Esterman, died in 1968.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed as Dow Falls 8.09

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
A day after the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates, the stock market closed mixed but largely unchanged for big stocks.
Smaller over-the-counter stocks, however, continued their rally for the eighth session yesterday, magnifying Wednesday's gains. The bond market kept most of its price advance, but closed slightly lower. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.09 points, to 3,776.48, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.16 point, to 465.17. The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.15 points, to 742.66.
Blue chips like International Paper and J. P. Morgan fell, but drug stocks like Eli Lilly and Merck rose.
 
Big Rise in O-T-C Stocks
 The main news was the big rise in over-the-counter technology stocks. The Nasdaq index rise nearly tripled the gain of 2.62 points on Tuesday. Of the top 10 gainers in Nasdaq stocks, eight were technology or biotechnology stocks. Intel rose 23/16 , to 63 3/4, on traders' speculation that some computer makers will use Intel's Pentium microchip. Intell was the most active stock, at 9.7 million shares. Microsoft rose 1, to 55 7/8, while Cisco Systems rose 1 1/2, to 24.
The bond market fell a little, after the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose more than one and a half points yesterday to 10118/32 . The price of the long bond fell 9/32 yesterday, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.39 percent from 7.37 percent.
The dollar fell yesterday, despite the Fed's interest-rate move, which pays foreigners and other investors more money to hold dollar-denominated assets. Commodity prices were largely unchanged, in part a reflection of traders' more optimistic outlook on inflation in the wake of the Fed move. The Commodity Research Bureau index rose 0.36 point, to 229.53, in part on price rises in lumber, cotton and soybean meal that were offset by falls in pork bellies and coffee.
 
Reaction to Fed Move
 The unsettled market reaction yesterday to the Fed's move stemmed from uncertainty as to how to assess the consequences of the increase. The move is sure to slow the economy further, bolstering bonds and strengthening the weak dollar, at least for yesterday.
But it would also weaken corporate profits and thus hurt stocks, at least for the short run. As the markets approach the Sept. 30 end of the third quarter, more traders are likely to grumble about poor quarterly earnings, as well as raise the specter of a Fed-caused recession.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.15 point, to 256.40, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks, 1,190 to 963. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.28 points, to 444.94.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 312.8 million shares changing hands.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 14 fell, led by International Paper, which fell 1 1/4, to 71 7/8, on no immediate news. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 186 rose, led by Eli Lilly, which rose 3, to 57 1/2..
Lilly's stock rose ahead of news that came out after the market closed that Lilly and Sphinx Pharmaceuticals had settled lawsuits blocking Lilly's acquisition of Sphinx.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Tapping the Briny Deep;
Pacific Ocean Spritzers By a California Venture

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Aug. 17

 BODY:
Trying to catch the wave of New Age soft drinks like Watermelon Kiwi and and Mango Madness, a California company plans to offer beverages with their own special ingredient: the Pacific Ocean.
The Seaborn Beverages Company says it is the first to make its drinks from desalinated ocean water, straight out of the Pacific. The company, based in Newport Beach, Calif., says it wants to sell the public on the "qualities and mystique of drinking a great-tasting, ultra-pure, ocean-water-based product." 
 Seaborn, which was started about a year and a half ago, plans to sell 1.15 million shares at $5 each in an initial public offering underwritten by La Jolla Securities. The company hopes to raise almost $5 million, which it plans to use to promote its drinks and take them beyond Southern California.
Some analysts are skeptical.
"When you think of desalinated water, you think of a pile of salt, and that's not the most romantic image," said Tom Pirko, an analyst with Bevmark Inc., a soft drink consulting company.
Desalination is usually an expensive process used in parts of the world where there are shortages of water, like Saudi Arabia. Seaborn's water is drawn from a depth of 500 feet about 30 miles off the California coast, near Santa Catalina Island. The water is transported to Seaborn's desalination plant in Long Beach, Calif.
There are economic and environmental benefits to desalinating water, said Frederik Rodenhuis, Seaborn's 39-year-old chief executive. It costs Seaborn no more to desalinate its water than it does for competitors to filter their spring water, he said.
While natural spring water brands like Evian and Perrier can promote the purity of their products, experts say ocean water, stripped of salt and other chemicals, is just, well, water. "I think it's a gimmick," said Kevin Olmstead, a civil engineering professor at the University of Detroit Mercy. "There aren't any health benefits in desalinated water that I'm aware of."
So far, Seaborn has been struggling. The company lost $751,400 between its inception on Feb. 1, 1993, and Dec. 31, while generating no revenues. Its accumulated deficit is $993,500.
In the company's prospectus, Seaborn's auditor, Arthur Andersen & Company, acknowledges the investing risk, saying, "The absence of significant revenues and the need to raise additional capital raise a substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern."
Nonetheless, Mr. Rodenhuis is optimistic. "I think we really have something special here," he said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices of Crude Oil Surge As Tensions Rise in Nigeria

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices staged a late rally yesterday after Nigeria's military ruler indicated that he would scrap the leadership of the country's striking oil workers' unions, creating a climate for intensified clashes.
In a speech to be delivered by Gen. Sani Abacha, the Government said it would appoint administrators to run the affairs of the unions and the Nigeria Labor Congress, the nation's largest trade union. 
 At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September delivery, the most active contract, closed 38 cents higher at $18.11 a barrel after hitting 13-week lows early in the day.
"I can't see it being resolved and it appears to be moving toward civil war," said Tom Bentz of Quantum Financial Services.
Nigeria, the 10th-largest OPEC producer, exports 1.6 million barrels a day. The shipments have been largely maintained during the six-week strike by oil workers, who walked out in support of Moshood K. O. Abiola, who is believed to be winner of the 1993 election, which was annulled by the military Goverment. He was arrested on treason charges after he declared himself president on the anniversary of the election.
Government negotiators did not show up yesterday for scheduled talks with union leaders, who said they would order attacks against oil plants if the Government deposed them.
"The Government not showing up for the meeting with the unions was substantial," said Mark Tunkel, an oil trader at Daiwa Securities America. "The sentiment is that we may start to see more problems in the next week or two."
Gasoline prices also rose yesterday. Domestic inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute showed gas supplies dropped 2.65 million barrels last week. Gasoline for September delivery rose 1.61 cents, to 56.53 cents a gallon.
In other commodity markets, coffee prices plummeted while cotton and soybean prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.36 point, to 229.53.
Coffee prices reversed course after rising sharply rising Monday as it became apparent to traders that coffee roasters were not rushing in to buy. Coffee beans for September delivery sank 12.5 cents, to $1.7945 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Talk of a large export sale of cotton to Asian countries and reports of damage to Georgia's cotton crop from the remnants of Tropical Storm Beryl lifted cotton prices.
"We do expect some damage to the cotton crop as a result of continued excessive rains Georgia has had for the past two months," said Don Shurley, an agricultural economist in Tifton, Ga., with the University of Georgia.
Cotton for October delivery jumped 0.94 cent, to 68.93 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some analysts think now is the time to buy steel stocks.

BYLINE: By John Holusha 

 BODY:
IS now a good time to buy steel stocks? Some people think so. The industry certainly is having a spectacular year after a decade of sagging orders, slumping prices and plant closings.
Steel shipments in the first half of the year rose 5.8 percent, to almost 47 million tons, the highest level in 13 years, the American Iron and Steel Institute, the principal trade group, reported recently. The American industry is running flat out and is expected to do so for at least another year. 
 The comeback is more than cyclical, analysts say. The revival in the Rust Belt means that manufacturers are increasing their use of steel and consumption is increasing relative to the general level of economic growth. The last time that happened was in the late 1950's.
According to the institute, steel use by auto manufacturers was up 17.1 percent, construction and contractors' products were up 7.8 percent, and machinery, industrial equipment and tools gained 7.4 percent in the six months ended in June.
With demand booming, steel producers have been demanding, and getting, price increases. Two rounds of spot-market price increases earlier this year have stuck and another is due Jan 1. Prices in longer-term contract markets are going up as well, with the automobile companies expected to pay 7 percent to 10 percent more for a material whose inflation-adjusted price has been declining for a decade.
It doesn't really matter if it is 7 percent or 10 percent, said Michelle G. Applebaum, a steel industry analyst with Salomon Brothers. "It has been zero for the last dozen years."
The chief beneficiaries of this flat-out demand for steel have been the big, integrated mills, the ones that make steel from iron ore and coal, Ms. Applebaum said. Mini-mills, which make steel from scrap, are facing a pinch as demand is forcing the price of scrap higher.
Steel companies like to complain about imports, but much of the steel that is being imported now is raw slabs for processing to fill the gap between the companies' capacity to produce liquid metal and the volume of customer orders. Customers are reportedly paying premium prices for imports of finished steel, rather than turning to them as a low-cost alternative, as in the past.
Ms. Applebaum has buy recommendations on most steel stocks, but said she particularly favored Bethlehem, Inland and U. S. Steel. Part of the reason, she said, is that they are large-capitalization, actively traded stocks. "Liquidity is an issue, and these are very liquid," she added.
Inland, she noted, is a steel distributor as well as a manufacturer, and there is room for growth in distribution even while the company's steel making is straining against capacity limits. All three are heavily focused on the flat-rolled business, which stands to benefit from price increases for steel used in automobiles and appliances.
Charles A. Bradford of UBS Securities is also recommending Inland and Bethlehem, but urges a degree of caution: "The time to buy these stocks is when nobody likes them, when the multiple is high because they don't have any earnings. The time to sell is when the multiples are low because they are at peak earnings."
Are we at or near the peak? Probably not, Mr. Bradford said. "The peak will probably come some time next year; there is probably some room to go."
A flashing red light and loud gong of a sell signal would be if any of the big, integrated mills announced that they were going to significantly add to production capacity. "These guys always wanted to have the capacity to sell the last ton in a peak year and that means they have expensive capacity sitting around idle 80 percent of the time," he said. "That's what imports are for, to satisfy peak demand."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips a Bit as Traders Await Move by Bundesbank

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday as traders awaited a signal from Germany's Bundesbank about the direction of European interest rates.
Some traders speculated that the Bundesbank's rate-setting council, which meets today, might lower rates or signal future monetary easing. 
 The meeting of the German central bank follows increases on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve of half a percentage point in two key interest rates: the discount rate and the Federal funds rate.
 
Rate Gap Narrows
The Fed's move narrowed the gap between short-term American interest rates and higher German rates, making dollar-based investments more competitive. A Bundesbank easing would further close the gap.
"People were looking for two shoes to drop," said David Glowacki, senior trader at National Bank of Detroit. "They expected the Fed to raise rates, which it did. Now, we're waiting for the other shoe to drop from the Bundesbank."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.5524 German marks from 1.5585 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was also weaker against the Japanese yen, falling to 100.13 yen, from 100.50 on Tuesday.
 
Italian and Swedish Moves
Today's Bundesbank meeting, the first after a monthlong summer recess, is viewed as especially important after the Italian and Swedish central banks increased interest rates last week. Those increases caused fear of possible rising inflation in Europe and cast doubt on the potential for significant easing by the Bundesbank.
If the Bundesbank does not act today, it would leave Germany's discount rate at 4.5 percent, compared with the 4 percent discount rate set by the Fed on Tuesday. That would probably hurt the dollar, however, traders said. They noted that the dollar was vulnerable after a disappointing performance lately.
"The dollar is acting rather poorly given the bold move by the Fed," said Ross Taylor, head of foreign exchange at the Daiwa America Corporation. "People were expecting a strong rally and they didn't get one."
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.3058 Swiss francs, down from 1.3114 on Tuesday; 5.3287 French francs, down from 5.3545, and 1,590 Italian lire, down from 1,594. The British pound rose to $1.5415, from $1.5395 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Russian Controls on Bomb Material Are Leaky

SERIES: After the Arms Race: The Next Nuclear Threat -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Russia has no way of knowing for sure if any of its vast supply of bomb ingredients is missing, many of its own nuclear officials and scientists admit.
An investigation of nuclear security in Russia, including interviews with numerous officials and independent experts in Moscow and in Siberia, where many nuclear materials are kept, reveals that the country is far from establishing an effective system for protecting and accounting for the plutonium and highly enriched uranium, the critical ingredients for making nuclear weapons. 
 Much of the West's focus in recent years has been directed at keeping any of Moscow's 30,000 warheads from falling into the hands of terrorists or nations like Iraq and Iran that have nuclear ambitions. But Russia's supplies of nuclear bomb materials are also spread across scores of less closely guarded research institutes, weapons laboratories and assembly plants, power plants, nuclear waste storage facilities, naval fuel depots and other installations.
In the past, authorities here relied on a system of rewards for its nuclear elite and the iron grip of the Soviet state to protect nuclear materials. Now, when citizens travel freely and wheel and deal, when criminal syndicates marshall vast economic resources while workers and even scientists are sometimes not paid for months, protection of bomb materials requires far closer and constant scrutiny, many Western and Russian experts say.
"We would like to bring some order to the area of stockpile accountability," said Yuri Vishevsky, the director of Gosatomnadzor or GAN, a Russian agency loosely modeled on the United States' Nuclear Regulatory Commission. "Unfortunately today, there are too many possessors of nuclear material. We have to find out who possesses nuclear materials and get them to carry out an inventory."
In the face of repeated German seizures of plutonium and highly enriched uranium that German officials say were smuggled from Russia, the head of the Ministry of Atomic Energy here charges that Western intelligence agencies have mounted a plot to discredit the Russian nuclear establishment, leaping to blame Russia without proof.
But many Russian and American experts say Russia's nuclear network is so balkanized and its system of checks so uncertain that no one can say for sure whether any of its nuclear bomb material -- which totals some 170 tons of military and civilian plutonium and 1,000 tons of highly enriched uranium, according to Western estimates -- has been lost or stolen. The challenge is especially great because the amount of plutonium needed to make a bomb, several kilograms, is no bigger than a can of soda.
President Boris N. Yeltsin has signed lofty summit statements pledging to improve nuclear security and publicly exhorted Russia's intelligence services to crush "any attempt to gain unauthorized access to nuclear components."
The United States, for its part, has earmarked $133 million to help Russia prevent nuclear thefts, and Clinton Administration officials say that Russian and American nuclear specialists are beginning to cooperate in ways that would have been unthinkable during the Cold War.
But calling for change on the nuclear front and mustering the political will, money and organization to carry it out are two different things. Russian and American officials say that reform has been hampered by lack of funds and inattention from Russia's fractious Parliament.
Significantly, proposed changes have also run into resistance from Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy, Minatom. Its powerful chief, Viktor N. Mikhailov, was a senior nuclear official going back to Soviet days. In 1993 he wrote an autobiography, "I'm a Hawk," covering his career in weapons development.
He is openly suspicious of Western intentions and determined to preserve his nuclear domain. Of the suggestion that Russia is vulnerable to nuclear theft, he said, "There are certain groups, intelligence services in the West, which promote this opinion to undermine Minatom."
Ambassador James Goodby, the American official who has led the talks with Russia to strengthen its nuclear controls, said, "There has been some progress, but it has been very, very slow going. The worry is that something could happen that would throw us into a tail spin."
 
The Past
Loosening The Controls
 In the past, Washington's main worry was not the security of Russia's nuclear materials, but its burgeoning arsenal of nuclear-tipped missiles and bombs that were aimed at the United States.
Russia's system for protecting bomb-grade materials had its limitations. Russian officials kept account of how much plutonium and highly enriched uranium was produced and distributed to physics research centers and reactors, weapons laboratories, nuclear fuel fabrication plants and other installations.
But officials rarely conducted inspections or detailed measurements to check how much was still there. Each institute or laboratory, in effect, kept its own account.
"Probably the most deficient component of Minatom's safeguards is the system of material control and accounting," wrote Oleg Bukharin, a Russian physicist who is now a visiting scholar at Princeton University.
 
Monitoring System Blocked
 Yevgeny P. Velikhov, former President Mikhael S. Gorbachev's science adviser and the director of the Kurchatov Institute, a research center that has been working to design a new system of nuclear safeguards, said in an interview he had advocated a system of independent monitoring of the disparate nuclear installations, only to be rebuffed by the nuclear agency and security services.
"It is possible to present it as a national system, but this does not exist in reality," Mr. Velikhov said.
While the theft of a nuclear warhead poses the greatest potential threat, the plutonium and highly enriched uranium at scattered research centers, power plants and other sites are far more vulnerable. Less well protected than military installations, many of Russia's once-prestigious nuclear research institutes have become collections of ill-paid specialists, who may, many experts fear, be vulnerable to bribes.
While most of the former Soviet Union's nuclear laboratories and installations are in Russia, much the same vulnerability exists in the other former Soviet states, like Belarus and Ukraine.
Adding to Western concern, classified American intelligence reports indicate that well-financed agents of Middle Eastern nations are operating in the former Soviet Union, prompting fears that they could be seeking bomb materials.
At the Institute of Physics and Power Engineering at Obninsk, 60 miles outside Moscow, storage site for nearly a ton of enriched uranium, enough for dozens of bombs, as well as plutonium, officials deny that their materials have turned up in Germany. But they do not deny that they have a serious security problem.
 
Once a Closed Area
 During the Cold War, Obninsk was a closed area, off-limits to foreigners and to Russians without special permission. But now foreigners and Russian citizens can travel freely to the area, which contains a large network of nuclear laboratories connected by above-ground steam pipes.
Salaries at the institute, where the world's first commercial-scale nuclear reactor was built, are down about 70 percent during the last five years, and about a third of the staff has left.
"Our headache is the problem of materials that have a significant price," said Igor P. Matveyenko, the director of the institute's division of experimental physics. "We've put it in samples that it's possible to pocket," he added, as he slipped a stainless steel disk about the size of a hockey puck into the pocket of his white lab coat.
That disc contained lead, but Mr. Matveyenko has thousands of such disks, some with highly enriched uranium, some with natural uranium, some with weapons-grade plutonium, some with reactor-grade plutonium. These disks, not too dangerous to handle or transport, are used to fuel a small research reactor.
To protect the material, engineers have taken some steps. The foot-thick door between the control room and the reactor room, where the disks are used, was opened regularly when the reactor was not running. Now it is normally locked shut and employees walk through another door fitted with a radiation detector that can sense when a disk is passing through.
But Mr. Matveyenko said he needs more money, to buy equipment to monitor security and to develop inventory control procedures. Moreover, he stressed, equipment alone will not solve the problem. Unless salaries are raised, some researchers may find nuclear smuggling too great a temptation to resist.
"There are dishonest men in various levels, including in the bureaucracy," he said. "It's possible to buy anything in our country, including weapons and samples."
Anatoly V. Vorobyov, deputy head of the institute's international department, agreed that security was a problem. "We need to trust every person in this laboratory," he said.
 
The Response
Reforming The System
 To improve its controls, Russia is trying to create a system of independent oversight and is also working with Washington to better protect Russia's supply of plutonium. It has also pledged to stop further production of weapons-grade plutonium. But these efforts have slowed to a crawl.
President Yeltsin has called on GAN to oversee Russia's sprawling network of nuclear laboratories, power plants and institutes.
From the start, recalled Aleksei V. Yablokov, an adviser to Mr. Yeltsin on environmental issues, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, the head of the Russian Ministry of Defense, and Mr. Mikhailov of the Atomic Energy Ministry fought to limit the regulatory's agency's authority to oversee their agencies' installations.
And top officials from GAN said they still lack the legal authority from Russia's Parliament, the funds and the inspectors and equipment to do their job effectively.
"We are only at the beginning of the road in creating a national system of accounting," said Stanislav D. Loutsev, the deputy head of safeguards at GAN.
 
Shortcomings in System
 "We do inspections, but not in the scale and volume we would like," he added. "We do not have the legal basis. The measurements we have made are not very accurate because we do not have the necessary instruments."
As a result, Mr. Loutsev acknowledged, it is impossible to tell if nuclear materials at some of Russia's installations have been stolen, used up or simply lost track of.
His boss, Mr. Vishevsky, estimated that it would take five to seven years, and about $1 billion, to get the system under control. But his agency's total budget this year is about $7 million.
Clinton Administration officials also say that the lack of procedures and equipment for measuring nuclear materials and detecting efforts to divert it is a major weakness and that Western help is needed to correct it.
Critics complain, however, that of the $1.2 billion Washington has budgeted to help arms reduction efforts in the former Soviet Union, only $133 million has been earmarked to protect bomb-usable plutonium and uranium. The remainder is dedicated to tasks such as helping Russia dismantle its missiles and transporting warheads from the former Soviet republics to Russia.
"Not one single improvement has been made in the physical security or material control and accounting at a fixed site in Russia as a consequence of funds allocated by Congress, " said Thomas B. Cochran, senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group in Washington.
But Clinton Administration officials say that the United States has been unable to spend the relatively modest funds it has allocated for strengthening Russia's nuclear controls because of resistance from Minatom, where Mr. Mikhailov has been wary of Western intentions and reluctant to give American experts wide-ranging access to nuclear sites.
When American officials offered $10 million to help set up a model system of controls for bomb-grade materials, for example, Russian officials proposed that the safeguards be established instead at a section of a fuel-fabrication plant near Moscow that handles low-enriched uranium, which does not present a threat.
More recently, the Clinton Administration has offered $10 million in aid to make "quick fixes" in controls at nuclear sites. Russian officials recently toured the United States' Hanford nuclear reservation to study the American system of safeguards and have arranged for a reciprocal visit by American experts to their civilian plutonium storage site at Mayak in the Ural Mountains. But they have yet to take up the $10 million dollar offer.
The Clinton Administration also offered a further $10 million to the Russians so that they could upgrade their controls at the site where Russia is transforming bomb-usable highly enriched uranium into low enriched uranium for sale to the United States. But Russian officials said that the aid was unnecessary.
Other American initiatives have also been moving slowly. To protect the vast stores of plutonium Russia is recovering from its dismantled warheads and to encourage Moscow to continue its arms reductions, the United States is contributing $91 million to help Russia design, build and equip the first of two planned storage installations. The United States Energy Department came up with an extra $1 million to pay a St. Petersburg company to design the installation after the Russian Government failed to make the payment.
American officials had hoped that Russia would begin building the installation this summer, but construction has yet to start.
A widely publicized Clinton Administration effort to dissuade Moscow from producing even more plutonium requires difficult economic problems that Russian authorities have been reluctant to confront.
In a June agreement with the United States, Russia has pledged to shut down by the year 2000 plutonium-producing reactors in Tomsk-7 and Krasnoyarsk-26, which are simultaneously used to heat the surrounding Siberian communities. But Russia's cash-starved authorities have taken few steps to build the costly coal and gas fueled plants that would be needed to replace them.
 
The Future
Plugging The Leaks
 Chainsmoking cigarettes in his Moscow headquarters, the chief of Minatom, Mr. Mikhailov, is not worried about the slow progress of the efforts to strengthen its controls.
"There are certain problems of control, but they exist everywhere, especially today, when large scale dismantling is going on," Mr. Mikhailov said.
He dismissed reports of diversion of Russian nuclear materials as a "provocation" by Western intelligence agencies to discredit Moscow's nuclear establishment.
American officials, particularly those at the Department of Energy, which is deeply involved in the effort to assist Russia, say it is too soon to declare failure.
 
Direct Ties Sought
 They say that dealing with the new Russia requires patience. American officials also note that the United States is also trying to sidestep Minatom by encouraging American nuclear laboratories to cooperate directly with Mr. Velikhov's Kurchatov Institute and other nuclear institutes. The Clinton Administration has allocated $12 million for this new effort through 1995 and would like to spend $50 million on such laboratory cooperation in 1996.
American officials also say they have sought to guard against theft by helping establish an international center in Russia to support former weapon scientists and by trying to negotiate an agreement that would enable American inspectors to monitor nuclear materials from dismantled warheads.
Mr. Velikhov, for his part, said that international pressure was having some effect. But he was skeptical that an rigorous nationwide system of modern equipment an trained personnel will be put into place.
"The most critical problem is funding, and I am not very optimistic," said Mr. Velikhov. "With the situation with the American budget, it does not seem like there will be billions and billions of dollars to spend on Russia. And on our side there is our bureaucracy and the inefficiency of our government system today.
 
 
 
MAKING BOMBS: DESIGN CRUCIAL
 Obtaining a sufficient quantity of plutonium or highly enriched uranium may be the most difficult task facing a would-be bomb-builder, but it is hardly the only challenge. Equally essential are a design, high explosives and advanced electronic equipment.
The designs of bombs in government arsenals, which aim to get the most explosive force from a quantity of fuel, are secret. But the general principles for making a fission weapon are widely known among scientists. In 1978 an undergraduate at Princeton University submitted a bomb design as a paper in a physics class; the United States Government said it would work and classified his paper.
At the core of the simplest plutonium bombs are hollow spheres of plutonium, not quite concentrated enough to constitute the "critical mass" needed to sustain a chain reaction. Conventional explosives, detonated with precise timing, squeeze the mass together quickly at the same instant that another device in the bomb introduces neutrons to set off the chain reaction.
Uranium bombs can be even simpler; the first one, which was not even field tested before it was dropped on Hiroshima 49 years ago this month, used something resembling an artillery piece to merge two masses of uranium and create a critical mass.
A would-be bomb-builder would also have to procure electronic devices the sales of which are closely monitored by Western governments.

HEADLINE: Blacks Make Boycott Hurt A Small Town

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BATTLEBORO, N.C., Aug. 12

 BODY:
No one disputes the origins of the episode last April 20. Marilyn B. Powell, while driving her car, noticed that her niece had been stopped at an intersection where two white police officers were checking licenses and seat belts. Mrs. Powell, who is black, pulled over and asked the officers to let her take a 3-week-old infant from her niece's car because of the heat. The police told her to wait, and she objected.
Accounts of the scuffle that followed differ, but by the time it ended, Mrs. Powell, a 36-year-old substitute teacher and nurse's aide with no police record, had been sprayed with Mace and charged with three misdemeanor counts of disobeying, resisting and assaulting a police officer. 
 The ensuing turmoil in Battleboro, which has a population of 524 and is 45 percent black, has forced attention on complaints by blacks here and in other small, isolated towns that police harassment is routine, and it has fanned long-simmering complaints of economic and political bias.
Only white men serve in Battleboro's police department, on its five-member Board of Commissioners and on its seven-member Planning Board. The Mayor is also white. To press their demands for a black police chief, blacks have banded together into a group called Concerned Citizens of Battleboro and have staged an effective boycott against white-owned businesses.
On July 30, the town's biggest retail store and second-biggest taxpayer, a Red and White supermarket, went out of business, saying the boycott had cost it 25 percent of its business.
With blacks doing more of their shopping in Rocky Mount, six miles to the south, several other businesses are ailing. "Faces I used to see every day don't come in anymore," said Robert Hayes, the proprietor of the Kitchen Korner restaurant. He said the town's commissioners "have done absolutely nothing" to try to accommodate black residents.
Blacks have yet to get a black police chief, but partly because of the dispute the department has been reduced from three full-time officers and three part-timers to just one: the Chief, David Snyder.
Impressed by the events in Battleboro, black politicians in the region say the stage is set for protests in more small towns where accusations of police brutality are commonplace. "Battleboro is a first," said the Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Clark, pastor of the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Rocky Mount and a commissioner of Edgecombe County, which shares jurisdiction over Battleboro with Nash County. "The benefits that are going to come of this are enormous. They showed they had economic power even though they're politically powerless." In June, the Rev. Jesse Jackson led a demonstration here in support of the boycott.
Mrs. Powell, who is preparing to sue the town, declined to discuss the April incident on the advice of her lawyer. Her friends say the police officers hit her first. Chief Snyder claims that Mrs. Powell struck first and that the officers were trying to prevent trouble rather than start it.
In a report in July, Howard S. Boney Jr., the area District Attorney, said the police had acted "overzealously" and ordered the charges against Mrs. Powell dropped. But he said the officers had not broken the law or acted with malice or racial hostility. That report enraged many civil rights leaders in the state.
Battleboro, in eastern North Carolina, is in many respects an easygoing place. Residents of both races say blacks and whites coexist uneventfully in schools, farms, shops and the nearby factory of Abbott Laboratories, a pharmaceutical company.
The harmonious racial mingling ceases away from the main intersection. Most well-off white families live on large lots on the west side of Highway 301. A few black and some white families live along a semi-industrial strip on the highway's east side, where most homes are smaller. That area stops at the railroad tracks, parallel to the highway, where the town spreads from Nash County into Edgecombe County. The population on the other side of the tracks, both within the town and for several blocks beyond, is almost exclusively black.
Those who reside within the town limits pay property taxes to the town and receive its services, and they can vote and run for town office. But no one here recalls any blacks running for office -- perhaps, blacks say, because they would stand little chance of winning. Commissioners are elected citywide, not by district. With whites in the majority, no one from a predominantly black area can win when people vote along racial or neighborhood lines.
 
Pocketbook Issues
 For those blacks who live a few blocks beyond the tracks, where the town's unincorporated section begins, the complaints are mainly economic.
Households in the unincorporated area do not pay the town's property taxes and other small levies, and the people who live there cannot vote in town elections. But most buy water from the town, and they pay twice the fees of people in the town -- typically about $80 a month for a family of four, compared with $40 in town.
Such differences in fees are common in North Carolina because of the cost of laying water lines in rural areas. Here, however, most of the blacks in the unincorporated section live just a block or two from people who pay the lower fees.
Those blacks are asking to be annexed to the town, in part so they can have the political power to contest the fees. Annexation could give blacks a majority of the town's votes, depending on the size of the annexed area.
Neighborhoods can petition to be annexed, but the process is fraught with delays and confusion. Dr. Clark said it required such legal and technical expertise that it would stymie people in unincorporated areas who had little experience with bureaucracy.
Decades of complaints over water bills and the lack of political power for the unincorporated area had no effect on the town until the arrest of Mrs. Powell in April. Since then, many whites in Battleboro have also found fault with the police. "They try to do a good job, but they do the job to the extreme" in enforcing local laws, said Mr. Hayes, the restaurateur.
Jerry P. Bulluck, a commissioner who owns a convenience store in the black area just outside town, called the department "overaggressive."
 
The Chief Is Alone
 But Chief Snyder, who has been in Battleboro for two years, defends his performance. "When I got here, we went out and enforced the law pro-actively," he said. By pro-actively, he said, he meant acting to prevent or deter crime rather than reacting to it. "Any department that pro-actively enforces the law will be accused of being overzealous," he said.
Chief Snyder is now the only police officer in Battleboro; county police officers handle any serious incidents when he is not on duty. Within days of Mrs. Powell's arrest by two police officers, one officer resigned to take a job in another town. The second was assigned to desk duty, and he resigned early this month. On Aug. 2, the Battleboro commissioners, without explanation, voted to stop the use of three part-time officers.
When he had a full force, Chief Snyder quintupled the town's revenues from fines, most of them for speeding and seat-belt violations.
But for James Berkley, the head of Concerned Citizens of Battleboro, tougher enforcement amounts to harassment. He said the police had tailed his wife, night after night, from her job at Abbott Laboratories until she was finally stopped for speeding.
Many people in town, white and black, like the idea of a black police chief, or at least some black officers. But solving the problem may involve more than promising to recruit black officers.
Chief Snyder said that he had hired a black officer last year but that he had stayed only one month. Like all new officers here, he was paid $6 an hour, about the lowest police wage in the nation. "He left to take a job making $10," Chief Snyder said.

 CORRECTION:

He is Dr. Thomas L. Walker, not Dr. Thomas L. Clark.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE MIDDLE GROUND;
Health Debate Has a Senator In a Crossfire

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The health care battlefield around Senator John H. Chafee is littered with the corpses of good ideas gone bad.
The Rhode Island Republican, praised by Democrats for his moderate leanings but distrusted by some Republicans for his efforts toward bipartisan compromise, is leading the movement to get influential senators to devise a health care formula that is comprehensive, cost-conscious and middle-of-the-road. 
 It is a task that becomes more tangled every day for Mr. Chafee, a 71-year-old New England patrician, who has been working on health care issues since he became Governor of Rhode Island in 1963.
"Everything's a struggle," he said with a sigh today as he began another day of behind-the-scenes meetings and debate that ended with an announcement tonight that an agreement on a proposed compromise had been reached.
 
A Mitchell-Dole Struggle
 In many ways, the immediate political fight over health care has become a struggle between two political leaders. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, has introduced an alternative that is being picked apart in public on the Senate floor and in private by fellow Democrats who worry that it is too dense and tax-heavy to succeed.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, has sponsored his own measure, and complains that the "mainstream coalition" undercuts Republican arguments that the health care system may be cracked, but not broken.
Running the coalition has fallen largely to Mr. Chafee, a three-term Senator who is seeking re-election this fall. Although he holds no official leadership role in the Senate, he has welcomed as many as 20 senators to the daily meetings that began as once-a-week breakfast sessions four years ago.
Mr. Chafee is joined at the group's core by two other moderate Republicans, Senators John C. Danforth of Missouri and Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, but the sessions have expanded to include Democrats like Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, David L. Boren of Oklahoma and John B. Breaux of Louisiana.
 
In Search of a Consensus
 Participants say they fret, debate, vote and then often begin debating again as they search for a consensus each day. But their efforts are viewed with suspicion by many Republicans, who maintain that Mr. Chafee is consorting with the enemy.
"What I don't want are three Republicans -- Senators Danforth, Durenberger and Chafee -- trying to direct the rest of us, 40 of us, where we should go," Mr. Dole groused on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" last weekend.
Mr. Mitchell, by contrast, has eagerly encouraged the activities of the Chafee group, even though several of its members have said that his health care alternative is unacceptable. He met with them on Wednesday, and Senators Sam Nunn of Georgia, a Democrat, and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, a Republican, met with the group today to discuss their own compromise legislation.
Mr. Chafee is sanguine about the criticism he has attracted as his mainstream coalition has become the center of gravity -- and a target of criticism -- in the health care debate.
"There's no question but that there are people in the Republican Party who want to do nothing," the Senator said in an interview this morning.
"The changes we are proposing will have cost containment and will increase the coverage.," he added. "And if the President gets some credit out of it, so be it, but we just can't keep from doing anything in a whole variety of areas because somebody says, 'Oh the President will take credit for it.' "
This attitude has won Senator Chafee some quiet support from White House officials, who fear they would doom the coalition's efforts if they endorsed them publicly. Any compromise on health care, they say privately, is better than no bill at all.
"The problem is the political pressure, and whether he can withstand it," one White House official said.
Mr. Chafee's opponents are counting on the disagreements to split the group as it searches for the center.
"To the extent that Chafee is trying to lead a substantial amount of Republicans to work with Mitchell, I think he'll fail," said Bill Kristol, the former adviser to Vice President Dan Quayle who heads the Project for a Republican Future, a conservative group. "A huge majority of Republicans feel Mitchell's bill fundamentally goes in the wrong direction and is unimprovable."
On the opposite side of the political spectrum, proponents of universal coverage, provisions for long-term care and other benefits financed by employer contributions contend that their principles -- originally championed by President Clinton -- are being consistently traded away.
 
'An Exercise in Minimalism'
 "The proposals by the mainstream group become less and less meaningful," said Ron Pollack, a supporter of the Clinton plan who is executive director of Families USA. "Soon the word 'reform' has no content to it."
"There is no question it's moving," he said of the negotiations. "It's moving in a negative way, and it's becoming an exercise in minimalism."
But Senator Chafee has managed to disagree with all sides without squandering the good will he built in years of crossing party lines to work with Senator Mitchell on the Clean Air Act or to walk lockstep with his colleagues to defeat Mr. Clinton's $16.3 billion economic stimulus package last year.
"I strongly disagree with John Chafee on health care," said Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican. "But as a human being, the Lord didn't make any senators who are any better than John Chafee."
Mr. Chafee's military background may serve him well as he deals with political crossfire and mine fields. He enlisted in the Marine Corps soon after the United States entered World War II, and landed on Guadalcanal as a 19-year-old private in August 1942. He was later commissioned a second lieutenant and saw combat on Okinawa. After receiving a bachelor's degree from Yale in 1947 and a law degree from Harvard in 1950, he was recalled to active duty in the Korean War, where he served as a rifle company commander.
After 35 years in Rhode Island politics, Mr. Chafee faces this autumn's race for a fourth term with a measure of security unusual for a Republican holding office in a heavily Democratic state. He served as Governor for three terms, but was ousted in 1968 after advocating a state income tax.
He served briefly as Secretary of the Navy under President Richard M. Nixon, then returned to Rhode Island to challenge the state's senior Senator, Claiborne Pell, only to be defeated once again. But by 1976, Mr. Chafee had re-established his support among independents, and took advantage of disarray in the Democratic Party to gain enough support to win election to the Senate.
For a time, Mr. Chafee was Hillary Rodham Clinton's favorite Republican. He now says it has been months since he talked to her.
But the Senator continues to show up for work every day, drinks his hot, honey-sweetened tea and prepares to arm-wrestle a workable health care bill onto the Senate floor.
His power over the centrist Democrats and Republicans he leads, he said, is fleeting. "Senator Lieberman said they gave me papal authority," Mr. Chafee said, referring to the mainstream group. "But it doesn't amount to much."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit In June Was A Bit Smaller

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In a report that analysts said reflected a recovering global economy, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the nation's monthly trade deficit fell slightly in June.
The 1.6 percent decline, to a seasonally adjusted $9.37 billion, from $9.51 billion in May, was primarily due to larger exports, which rose to a record level in June. 
 Still, the deficit with Japan widened, unnerving the currency markets and sending the dollar back to less than 100 yen. [Page D13.]
The 3.6 percent gain in overall exports, to $58.17 billion, helped offset a 2.8 percent increase in imports, to $67.54 billion. Nearly half the import increase was due to a record monthly purchase of foreign oil.
While the export statistics confirmed an increase in demand for American products, analysts said the rise in imports was additional evidence that the United States economy entered the second half of 1994 under a healthy head of steam.
 
Visions of a Robust Economy
 "These numbers only confirm the still-robust nature of the U.S. expansion," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said.
There was optimism, too, from Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company, who said: "It is absolutely true that the United States is growing faster than the rest of the world. And all countries that are growing fast experience trade deterioration. But it is important to note that Europe and Japan are turning around. Every aspect of this report points to strong growth and a strengthening global economy."
With foreign economies showing increasing signs of recovery, the dollar weakening against major currencies and the chances increasing that the American economy would experience slower growth in the second half, analysts said the trade deficit was likely to narrow further over the next six months and beyond.
But that prospect did little to alter their predictions that for all of 1994, the American merchandise trade deficit would come close to equaling the record of $152.1 billion set in 1987.
"We will still have a record or near-record merchandise trade deficit," Mr. Lipsky said. "But relative to gross domestic product, the imbalances are moderate compared to what they were in the mid-1980's, because the domestic economy has been growing at a faster pace."
Despite the slight improvement in trade, the report showed that the United States' deficit with Japan widened in June by $1.13 billion, to $5.52 billion, the biggest monthly deficit since March. Imports from Japan totaled $10.08 billion, also the highest since March.
C. Michael Aho, senior international economist at Prudential Securities, said that the American deficit with Japan, calculated in yen, was already starting to improve. But because the effects of currency fluctuation on trade figures lag by 12 to 18 months, he said it would be some time before the Japanese trade surplus began to narrow in dollar terms.
"For the depreciating country, things get worse before they get better," Mr. Aho said.
While the United States ran its largest trade deficit with Japan, a number of other countries also continued to have very large surpluses with Washington.
China, which has been under pressure to liberalize its trading practices, recorded a $2.2 billion surplus with the United States in June, the Commerce Department said. And Canada and the countries of Western Europe had trade surpluses of more than $1 billion.
The increase in exports was led by sales of aircraft and telecommunications equipment.
Aside from oil imports, which rose to a record 249.29 million barrels, breaking the previous high of 230 million barrels in July 1993, imports of capital goods and automobiles recorded big gains in June.
But the pace of import growth is likely to slow, Mr. Lipsky of Salomon Brothers said, adding:
"We experienced such strong import growth in the second quarter that we do not feel the gains are going to be sustained. Over the next couple of quarters, import growth should be slower than growth for exports."

HEADLINE: A Brooklyn Woman Is Charged After the Death of Her Infant Son

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
A Brooklyn mother was arrested yesterday morning and charged with endangering the welfare of a child after the death of her 19-month-old son, who had severe internal injuries, the police said.
The baby, Angel Cruz Jr., was pronounced dead at Wyckoff Hospital on Wednesday afternoon, said Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman. While the cause of death has not been determined by the Medical Examiner's Office, the mother, Lisa Cruz, 24, of 1532 Gates Avenue in Bushwick, was arrested yesterday after undergoing hours of questioning by detectives at the 83d Precinct. 
 Mrs. Cruz, who is unemployed, told investigators she had left the baby with her boyfriend in her second-floor apartment.
 
Accusations of Neglect
 Mrs. Cruz's other children, Jamie, 5, and Angelica, 4, were taken away yesterday by workers from the Child Welfare Administration.
City officials would not comment on the family's situation, but family members and neighbors along Mrs. Cruz's rundown block said the two oldest children were taken away by child welfare workers about three years ago because of neglect. At that time, Angelica was taken to the hospital with a broken arm and leg, relatives said.
The children were returned to her home after Mrs. Cruz underwent two years of counseling, and she has been dedicated to her children since then, said her mother, Judy Santana, who lives down the hall in a dilapidated two-story, red brick building.
The baby had severe internal injuries and some bruises, Sergeant McCluskey said. Investigators said they did not know how the injuries occurred or whether they were inflicted by the mother.
Mrs. Cruz was charged with endangering the welfare of a child because of the nature of the injuries and because she was not with the child at the time, said Sgt. Edward Caro, another police spokesman. The boyfriend, whose name was not released, has not been charged, but he was questioned at length, the police said.
Before his death on Wednesday, Angel, a playful child with big brown eyes, could not stop crying, Mrs. Santana said. About 4 P.M. Mrs. Cruz's boyfriend fed him, changed his diapers and tried to put him to bed, the mother said. But he was still crying.
"The boyfriend ran down the hall in hysterics and asked me what he should do," said Mrs. Santana, who said the child had been sick with a virus about three weeks ago. "That's when I went over to see the baby. His stomach was swollen and hard and he was cold. I panicked and told him to call 911. I was so scared."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angel Cruz Jr., 19 months old, who died on Wednesday, in a family photograph with his brother, Jamie, 5, and sister, Angelica, 4.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
WOOLWORTH CORP. (Z,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter loss widened because of a $30 million charge from the sale of Woolco stores in Canada and losses at discount stores in the United States and Germany.
For the second quarter, which ended on July 30, Woolworth recorded a loss of $42 million, or 32 cents a share, compared with a loss of $10 million, or 8 cents a share, for the corresponding quarter last year. 
 Wall Street had expected a loss of 2 cents a share, based on a survey of five analysts by Institutional Brokers Estimate System.
Woolworth said losses at its general merchandise and specialty operations narrowed because of the sale or closing of 1,112 discount stores in the United States and Canada. "The improvements, however, were offset by losses in other operations, primarily those in Germany, reflecting the weak economic conditions in that country," the company said.
Woolworth, based in New York, has been shedding less profitable operations to concentrate on specialty stores. The company posted a $495 million loss in fiscal 1994. On March 30, Woolworth said that it would restate quarterly results for the year that ended in January, citing accounting irregularities. The company later said the accounting problems did not affect its full-year financial results for fiscal 1994 and 1993.
For the second quarter, sales at the company's 7,472 specialty stores, including Foot Locker, Kinney, Northern Reflections and the Bargain Shop, rose 9.4 percent. Sales at Woolworth's 1,069 general merchandise stores declined 3.2 percent. Sales figures for both divisions exclude revenues from closed or sold stores.
Total sales declined 18 percent, to $1.88 billion from $2.29 billion. Sales outside of the United States fell 36 percent, while domestic sales fell 4.6 percent.
