HEADLINE: Feared Effect Of Rate Rise Drops Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday for the first time in a week amid concern that the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate increases would slow the economy too much and hurt corporate profits.
The Fed "may have done more than slow the economy, and we may see significant slowing of earnings," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation. 
 Higher rates are bad for stocks because they encourage people to put their money into fixed-rate investments that are perceived as less risky. They also slow the economy and raise the cost of borrowing, both of which hurt corporate profits.
 
Bond Yields Rise
 The decline in stocks accelerated as bonds slumped on worries that the Federal Reserve's five interest rate increases this year might not have prevented inflation from accelerating. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32 , to 1005/32 , for a yield of 7.49 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 21.05 points, to 3,755.43, hurt by losses in Caterpillar, General Motors and Boeing. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2, to 463.17.
Auto stocks slumped amid concerns that higher rates would discourage consumers from buying new cars. General Motors fell 1 1/8, to 49 7/8; Ford Motor lost 1 1/8, to 29 1/2, and Chrysler dropped 1 1/8, to 47 1/4.
"Their stocks peak about a year and a half before earnings do," Richard Cripps, director of equity marketing at Legg Mason, said. "People now are looking over the mountain."
Shares of regional Bell telephone operating companies slipped a day after a long-distance provider, MCI Communications, asked Illinois regulators to establish new ground rules that would open up competition in local phone services.
Southwestern Bell fell 5/8, to 41 3/4; Ameritech slid3/4, to 41 5/8; Bell Atlantic dropped 1/2, to 55 5/8, and Pacific Telesis fell 3/4, to 31 7/8.
Shares of drug and health care companies fell, reversing gains from Wednesday, when American Cyanamid said it would accept a buyout offer of $101 a share from American Home Products. The S.& P. health care index, up 6.6 percent since Aug. 8, fell 5.48, to 363.14. Abbott Laboratories fell 7/8, to 30 1/4; Bristol-Myers Squibb declined 3/4, to 57 3/8, and Johnson & Johnson dropped 1 1/8, to 48 1/8. The Nasdaq composite index fell 0.49 point, to 742.17, after closing on Wednesday at its highest level since June 6. The decline was led by shares of Microsoft, Lotus Development and Intel.
Declining stocks outpaced advancers, 1,299 to 890, on the New York Stock Exchange, where 293.7 million shares were traded.
Select Media Communications, Cisco Systems, Lotus Development, Intel and American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico were the most active stocks on all the markets.
 
Lotus Earnings at Issue
 Lotus Development slid 47/16 , to 415/16 . Steven Frankel, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill, cut his estimate of Lotus's third-quarter earnings to 37 cents a share from 44 cents.
Shares of Coca-Cola rose 1 1/2, to 47 5/8, after Warren E. Buffett, the investor and a Coca-Cola director, disclosed that he had bought 4.9 million shares of Coca-Cola last month. Mr. Buffett, whose investment decisions are closely watched on Wall Street, now owns 99.87 million shares, or about 7.75 percent, of Coke's shares outstanding.
Gupta fell 1 1/2, to 10 1/2, after Oracle ended discussions with the software maker concerning a potential business combination. Oracle, which rose 1/4, to 40 1/8, also said it had shed its holdings in the company.
Harley-Davidson added 1 7/8, to 54 1/2. The maker of motorcycles declared a 2-for-1 stock split, payable Sept. 12 to shareholders of record Aug. 29.

HEADLINE: Insurance Rollbacks Are Upheld

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The California Supreme Court yesterday upheld an insurance reform measure passed by California voters in 1988 that required insurance companies to roll back auto insurance premiums and gave the state insurance commissioner broad powers to control prices and profits.
The ruling clears the way for the commissioner to order insurance companies to refund as much as $1 billion to millions of California auto insurance customers. The court decision, which was unanimous, also affirmed the authority of the commissioner to require the 700 insurance companies operating in the state to obtain approval for rate changes for all property and casualty insurance that includes homeowner policies. 
 Before the proposition was passed, California insurance companies were free to charge whatever rates the market would bear, with no approval required from regulators before raising rates.
 
 
Big Savings
 "Over time, this will save consumers in the state billions of dollars in premiums," said Harvey J. Rosenfield, an author of what was known as Proposition 103 in the state's 1988 election and an advocate of insurance reform. He credited the proposition for a slight decline in auto insurance rates since 1988, down from double digit increases in previous years.
Insurance companies fought the ballot measure bitterly in 1988 and in the courts after it was passed. In arguments before the state's Supreme Court, they said the proposition and the actions of the commissioner were illegal because they amounted to a confiscation of property and did not allow them to earn a fair return.
"This is a bad day for free enterprise," said Kim Brunner, a vice-president of State Farm Insurance, based in Bloomington, Ill. State Farm has disputed whether it owes a refund on auto insurance policies as called for by Proposition 103, and has a request pending with the commissioner for an 8.3 percent increase in homeowner insurance.
Mr. Brunner and insurance industry analysts said they were worried that the commissioner's authority to set rates at levels that limit the companies' profits would result in too little profit to grow and prosper. They said that the commissioner's profit target, equal to a 10 percent return on the company's capital, was too low. The commissioner used a 10 percent rate of return to calculate the refunds.
A superior court judge in Los Angeles last year agreed with most of the company's arguments, but in an appeal that went directly to the state's Supreme Court, the companies lost. The opinion by Justice Stanley Mosk said the insurance companies' property rights would be violated only in cases of "deep financial hardship," but noted that the insurance department had rules to consider special hardship cases.
So far, 29 of the 700 insurance companies doing business in California have paid $833 million of refunds, or an average of about $117 to each of more than six million policyholders. Of the 29, 10 companies were ordered by the commissioner to pay refunds and 19 volunteered.
Four more companies have been ordered by the commissioner to pay refunds, but have refused. The largest amount owed by any one of them is $235 million by State Farm, the state's largest insurer. Other large companies which have not yet paid refunds include USAA, Nationwide, Farmers Insurance and 20th Century. Among the 10 companies which paid refunds as ordered, payments averaged about 48 percent of the amounts initially requested by the commissioner.
In the case of 20th Century, which lost more than half of its capital in the Los Angeles earthquake early this year, state officials said they would negotiate a settlement of the $106 million it owes to policyholders so that the solvency of the company is not threatened by the refunds.
 
 
'Less Attractive Place'
 "I don't see the refunds as being a life-and-death issue for any companies in the state," said John Snyder, senior vice president at A. M. Best & Company, an insurance rating firm. "What I do worry about, however, is that the commissioner's authority to control not just insurance prices, but also insurance company profits, could make the state a much less attractive place to do business."
Although it has taken six years for the court to uphold Proposition 103's key provisions, its impact has already been felt in many parts of the country.
"The California vote was a psychological boost to reformers all over the country who were trying to stand-up to insurance companies," said Mr. Rosenfield, the insurance reform advocate. Insurance commissioners in 12 states are now elected, "so politically ambitious people can be elected to positions where they can make pro-consumer reforms," Mr. Rosenfield added.
 
 
A Bitter Commissioner
 John. Garamendi, the California insurance commissioner, gained much publicity and many enemies among insurance companies after he was elected in 1990 for his fight to collect refunds ordered by Proposition 103 and for his moves to protect homeowners hurt by brush fires in the state. Earlier this year, however, he was defeated in a bid for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination by Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer. His term expires Jan. 2, and Mr. Garamendi said he would like a job in Washington, where his wife, Patricia, is a Peace Corps official.
With only five months remaining in office, Mr. Garamendi is bitter about the constant legal battle with insurance companies during his four-year term. He said the companies had spent $100 million in legal fees and called them "disingenuous and a bunch of liars" for their efforts to misrepresent his efforts.
For example, he noted that company warnings about the unfairness of regulations aimed at limiting profits to 10 percent of a company's capital are unfounded "because we have not made a decision" about the appropriate profit level. The profit target, he said, would depend on future developments, like the level of inflation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Garamendi, California's insurance commissioner, is bitter about his constant legal battles with insurance companies. (Associated Press) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities' Prices Sag

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday, after the market was again reminded that although inflation may be out of sight, it is not out of mind.
Concerns about inflation were revived after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that prices paid by area manufacturers for raw materials surged to a five-year high in August. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 12/32 , to 1005/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.49 percent, from 7.39 percent on Wednesday. In the last two days, the bond market has given up nearly all the gains it posted Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve raised the discount rate and the Federal funds rate by a half-point each in an effort to keep a lid on inflation.
"I saw the day's market activity as an internal correction, using the Philly Fed report as an excuse," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist for the Dreyfus Corporation. "The selloff was more technically driven than news driven."
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, in its survey of 150 manufacturers in Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey, said that its prices-received index rose to 24.5 in August from 15.8 in July, and its prices-paid index rose to 48.4 from 36.4.
 
Strong Economy Cited
 Some traders say that the economy is strong and that the increases in short-term rates have not been enough to slow it and may lead the Fed to tighten credit again. As long as the market continues to have expectations of another rate increase, bonds will not improve, analysts say.
"The long bond now appears to be headed to about 7.50 percent, its home base for the past few months," Mr. Hoey of Dreyfus said.
Also weighing on the market yesterday was a weaker dollar. In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 98.57 Japanese yen from 100.13 yen on Wednesday. It was the lowest level against the yen since Aug. 1. The dollar also fell against the German mark and other leading currencies. A weaker dollar makes it harder for foreign investors to hold onto Treasury securities, since a falling dollar diminshes their value.
Bond traders showed little reaction to two national economic reports yesterday. The Government said the trade gap narrowed 1.6 percent in June to $9.37 billion, as strong exports offset the fourth monthly record for merchandise imports. Economists had expected the deficit to be unchanged in the month.
The Government also reported jobless claims rose by 3,000 last week to 327,000. Economists had expected an increase of 1,000, to 322,000, with the four-month moving average the lowest since Dec. 25, 1993, when it fell to 319,500. The lackluster growth in claims supports the perception of an improving labor market, some economists said, with expectations of a strong job report for the month of August.
 
First Chicago Offering
 In the corporate market, the First Chicago Corporation sold $1 billion of triple-A rated securities backed by credit card loans through a special trust, with Salomon Brothers as the lead underwriter.
Half the issue, $500 million in floating-rate notes with an average life of 5.02 years, was priced to yield 18.75 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, which was about 4.81 percent late in the day. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The remaining $500 million, consisting of fixed-rate notes with an average life of 5.02 years, was priced at $997.20 per $1,000 of notes to yield 7.322 percent.
At the Treasury's auction of $16.75 billion in new one-year bills yesterday, the average yield was 5.67 percent, up from 5.20 percent last month and the highest since July 25, 1991, when it was 5.88 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slides Against Yen As Japan Trade Gap Widens

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled about 1.5 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday, after a Government report showed that the United States trade deficit with Japan widened in June.
When the deficit expands, Japanese exporters find themselves with more dollars that they must sell for yen in order to bring their profits home, thus putting downward pressure on the United States currency. 
 "It has basically been a free fall," said Joe Francomano, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. "The market's falling as far as it wants to go."
The dollar also dropped, though not as steeply, against the German mark, after the Bundesbank left its interest rates unchanged. That leaves German rates higher than those in the United States, making mark-denominated investments relatively more attractive than those priced in dollars.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 98.57 yen, its lowest level since Aug. 1, from 100.13 yen on Wednesday. It also dropped to 1.5443 marks from 1.5512 marks.
The shortfall in American exports trade with Japan widened to $5.5 billion in June from $4.4 billion in May. The size of the trade deficit with Japan has been a primary reason for the dollar's 11 percent slide against the yen this year, traders said.
The increase in the trade deficit with Japan "keeps a lot of pressure on the dollar on the downside," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president at Industrial Bank of Japan.
Concern about the deficit grew when Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown called the trade gap "way too high" yesterday. The dollar continued to slip, even after Mr. Brown said he was "hopeful" that the United States and Japan will reach an agreement in current talks aimed at increasing Japanese Government purchases of American goods.
The dollar fell against the mark after the Bundesbank left its repurchase rate unchanged at 4.85 percent. That is the rate the bank uses to signal changes in monetary policy, just as the Federal Reserve uses the Federal funds rate, an overnight lending rate. The Fed increased the funds rate to 4.75 percent from 4.25 percent on Tuesday.
Many analysts had thought that if the Bundesbank did not cut rates yesterday, it was unlikely to do so again until after Germany's federal elections in October.
"That led people to flock into the mark" at the dollar's expense, said Hugh Walsh, a trader at ING Capital Markets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKET;
Concerns About Inflation Help to Raise Gold Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold prices posted their largest one-day gains in nine weeks yesterday as the dollar's plunge made gold cheaper for foreign investors and as a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia raised concerns about inflation.
The dollar fell about 1.5 percent against the yen, after the Commerce Department said the United States trade deficit with Japan widened in June. A weaker dollar can lead investors to buy precious metals to protect against declines in dollar-denominated investments like bonds. 
 Also, the index of prices paid by manufacturers surged to a five-year high, the Philadelphia Fed reported in its survey of 150 manufacturers in Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey.
The Philadelphia Fed report "means inflation is not going to go away very quickly," said Leonard Kaplan, vice president and chief trader with Imperial Bank in Los Angeles.
 
December Gold at $385.90
 Gold for December delivery, the most active futures contract, jumped $3.60, to $385.90 an ounce. That is its highest settlement since Aug. 1 on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Other metals also gained. September silver rose 4.5 cents, to $5.162 an ounce on the Comex, while October platinum rose $4.70, to $416.30 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Before yesterday's surge, gold had been trading at its lowest point since early May, languishing as demand for gold bullion from jewelers falls into a seasonal lull. That is expected to change soon as jewelry manufacturing picks up in the fall.
 
Oil Prices Tumble
 On other commodity markets, crude oil retreated and pork bellies rose. The Commodity Research Bureau's index rose 0.37 point,to 229.90.
Crude oil tumbled amid speculation that no supply shortages were emerging from the six-week strike by Nigerian oil workers. September crude fell 39 cents, to $17.72 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, its lowest point since May 25.
The United States, which obtained 10 percent of its imports from Nigeria before the strike, saw its overall supplies rise 1.1 percent last week because of a 15 percent rise in imports, especially from the North Sea.
And pork bellies rose as the hog slaughter slowed this week, which could temporarily reduce fresh belly supplies. February pork bellies rose 1.4 cents, to 43.1 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
"The last couple of days we haven't had as heavy a hog flow to the market," said Chuck Levitt, an analyst with the Alaron Trading Company in Chicago.

HEADLINE: Venezuela's Tight Grip Has Investors Gasping

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Venezuela's largest foreign investor, a consortium led by the GTECorporation, is slashing by 40 percent its budget for upgrading the country's antiquated telephone system.
American Airlines is ending its daily flight from Caracas to New York next month, and is curtailing two other flights, to Miami and San Juan, P.R., effectively cutting its service by nearly half. 
Buffeted by a severe recession and burdensome new economic controls, Venezuela, once one of the region's hot investment markets, is quickly losing its sparkle. Even now, it remains the United States' third-largest Latin American destination for exports and investment, after Mexico and Brazil, and the United States' second-largest source of oil, after Saudi Arabia.
In the short term, Venezuela is enduring what is expected to be the worst economic performance of any South American country this year. Eleven Venezuelan banks, responsible for half of all domestic deposits, have failed so far this year because of poor practices and a lack of Government supervision. Economists predict that by the end of the year, Venezuela's imports will have dropped in half, inflation will have nearly doubled and economic activity will have shrunk by 8 percent.
But beyond this slump, investors worry about Venezuela's future under its new President, Rafael Caldera, a 78-year-old populist with an authoritarian streak. Since he took office in February, Mr. Caldera has reversed free-market policies implanted here only a few years ago, and has slapped so many controls on the economy that the Government's discretionary power over business ranks behind only that of Cuba in the region.
In late June, the Government imposed controls on all foreign currency transactions and on hundreds of prices. To combat "hoarding," President Caldera also decreed that the Government could seize private property without compensation.
"The Government's response to the country's severe banking and exchange-rate crisis has only made matters worse," said Francis Freisinger, Venezuela analyst for the Economist Intelligence Unit, a London-based group. He said Venezuela's creditworthiness had taken a beating.
The impact has been felt not just by Venezuelans but also by foreign investors. "American businessmen are very disillusioned, particularly American businessmen who were planning to use Venezuela as a regional base," said an American diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But more important, new American investment is not going to come."
Fabian Ponce Alban, American Airlines' country director, attributed the cutbacks in the airline's service to Venezuela's recession and its imposition of new foreign-exchange controls. "We are expanding everywhere else in South America," Mr. Ponce said.
The Venezuelan-American Chamber of Commerce and Industry, long a cheery booster for more foreign investment, has fallen silent. "We are not promoting investment," said Antonio A. Herrera-Vaillant, the chamber's general manager. "It's a catastrophe on every front."
Even Conapri, a semiprivate Venezuelan council that promotes investment, said in a recent bulletin that the Government's new system of currency controls "has made doing business extremely difficult in Venezuela."
To Government officials, the measures are temporary and are justified by the nation's financial emergency. Venezuela's shaky insurance industry has come under close watch since Aug. 5, when a group of banks rescued the nation's largest insurance company, Seguros La Seguridad, from collapse.
"These control measures were not taken for ideological reasons, but for reasons of necessity," said Fernando Luis Egana, a presidential aide. "Venezuelan laws don't foresee the emergency situation we are living through."
The most obvious catastrophe has been the suspension of foreign currency trading. To stop a flight of capital, Venezuelan officials forced one of Latin America's most import-dependent economies onto a radical dollar diet.
All decisions on the foreign-exchange needs of a $60 billion annual economy are now centralized in a five-member Exchange Administration Board. Aware that Venezuela's last experience with exchange controls, in the mid-1980's, led to the theft of billions of dollars by Government officials in collusion with businessmen, the new board believes it can insure honesty only by personally approving each request.
In the first seven weeks of the new system, only $80 million of requests were approved. As of Aug. 11, the board had approved just 40 out of a reported 120,000 foreign currency requests. How many dollars are actually flowing is unclear.
Until the exchange controls were imposed, Venezuela was importing $22 million worth of goods a day.
"Nobody has gotten a dollar," Mr. Herrera-Vaillant reported after polling a directors' meeting of the Venezuelan-American chamber. "The port is paralyzed. There are no rules to the game."
With Government officials determined to maintain controls for at least another six months, the drought of dollars is rippling through the economy.
The Venezuela subsidiaries of Ford, General Motors and Chrysler gave their employees Christmas vacations in July for lack of work. Chrysler de Venezuela is delaying the start of a $12 million expansion until the economic picture clears.
"If they don't give us foreign exchange as soon as possible, the entire auto parts industry will stop in the next two weeks," Jose Luis Hernandez, a director of the national association for auto parts producers. The industry, which he said normally imported $400 million worth of materials a year, had not received any dollars for six weeks.
Jacinto Marin, president of a national truckers group, warned recently that without imported tires and spare parts, trucking might gradually slow throughout Venezuela.
In a country that imports 70 percent of its food, the exchange controls are expected to start causing food shortages next month. Living off its oil wealth, Venezuela neglected its agriculture for decades. As the only Andean nation that is not self-sufficient in coffee, it planned to import 500 tons of coffee this year.
"Both price and exchange controls have created a very difficult situation for us," said the general manager of one American processed food company here. "We spend hours meeting with Government functionaries to discuss whether we can raise this or that product by 10 cents. So far, I don't think any big producer in the processed foods sector has received foreign exchange."
With the Government enjoying such enormous discretionary power, few American business people want to stick their necks out by talking to reporters. Of 10 American manufacturing and banking executives reached this week, only two agreed to talk, both on the condition that names not be used.
"We have only one month of raw materials left in the pipeline -- labels, bottles, boxes, ingredients," said the manager of one American pharmaceutical company. "After two months of no imports, you miss one or two ingredients and production starts to fall off the track."
 
 
No Crowds for Breakfast
 The impact of dwindling investment can be seen at the largely deserted executive breakfast buffet at the Caracas Hilton, a high-rise lounge that used to fill daily with foreign and Venezuelan executives.
"We just lost 3,000 room nights with a Latin American cellular telephone convention that has been postponed," Peter Schaepe, the hotel's general manager, said.
With its annual per capita income of $3,100 among the highest in Latin America, Venezuela has long been the largest foreign trading partner for the state of Florida. But this year Florida expects to see its exports to Venezuela fall to half of last year's level, $3.2 billion.
Neighboring Colombia, a comparatively poor nation, recently opened an $80 million credit line to Venezuela to keep bilateral trade flowing. Venezuelan companies now owe Colombian exporters $200 million.
Reviewing the exchange control debacle, the Economist Intelligence Unit has reduced Venezuela's credit risk rating to 75, South America's worst. Venezuela's credit risk, which ranked with Mexico's when Mr. Caldera took office, has dropped to the level of Algeria's and Nigeria's. Moody's and Standard & Poor's have also cut their ratings on Venezuela's foreign currency debt.
American investors describe as particularly sobering the experience of GTE, which manages the largest investment in Venezuela's private sector. The star among new American companies attracted by free-market policies adopted after 1989, GTE led the privatization of Venezuela's state-run telephone system, Cantv, in late 1991. The consortium also includes AT&T and Telefonica of Spain.
 
 
Unpaid Phone Bills
 Promising first-world telephone service to Venezuelans long abused by crackling lines and dead telephones, GTE announced an eight-year, $6 billion investment program. In the last two years, GTE more than doubled the number of public telephones and increased the number of telephone lines by almost 50 percent.
But successive governments let their unpaid telephone bills balloon to $250 million. Partly because of this, Cantv borrowed heavily from foreign banks to meet its capital spending targets. On Aug. 1, Cantv failed to meet a payment on a $40 million loan because the Exchange Control Board refused to grant it dollars.
Cantv has threatened to cut off telephone service to eight Government ministries, starting on Aug. 19. In response, aides to President Caldera have hinted that future access to dollars may be tied to forgiveness of the Government's telephone debt.
In such an environment, Cantv is cutting $600 million off a 1994-95 capital budget of $1.5 billion.
"The Government now faces an uphill battle to regain the trust of the international community," said Mr. Freisinger of the Economist Intelligence Unit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foreign-exchange offices like this one in Caracas have been shut down by the Venezuelan Government's stiff new controls on foreign currency. Such restraints have made Venezuela less attractive to foreign investors. (Reuters)
 
Graph: "Bust to Boom To Bust" shows growth of Venezuela's gross national product from '89-'94 (est). (Sources: Venezuelan Planning Ministriy, Venezuelan economists)

HEADLINE: New Claims By Jobless Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims last week rose to the highest level since the end of July, the Labor Department said today.
Initial weekly unemployment claims increased 3,000, to 327,000. The results show labor markets have stabilized after seasonal manufacturing layoffs and floods in Georgia caused first-time claims numbers to bounce up and down in July. 
 "The numbers are sustaining the improvement we have seen in the payroll numbers over the past couple of months," said David Cohen, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco.
The four-week moving average for jobless claims, a less volatile gauge of employment conditions, fell to 323,750 last week, from 339,500, the lowest level since the end of 1993.
"This really doesn't display any new trends in terms of labor market conditions; however, if the four-week moving average continues to fall over the next couple months, it might be a red flag to the Federal Reserve," said Kevin Flanagan, an economist with Dean Witter Reynolds in New York.
On Tuesday, the Fed raised interest rates for the fifth time this year in an effort to contain inflation spurred by the expanding economy.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Pledges 2d Installment Of Tax Cuts In the Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 18

 BODY:
In a campaign in which tax cuts have emerged as both a promise and a political weapon, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today pledged a second installment in the cuts enacted this year, saying he wants to reduce the state tax burden as much as $1.5 billion more over several years.
The announcement was the latest in a series of dueling tax cut promises from the three men running for Governor. Mr. Cuomo's two Republican rivals today portrayed his proposal -- which contained no specifics and was essentially a pledge to develop a plan -- as hollow electioneering. His main rival, George E. Pataki again used the opportunity to attack Mr. Cuomo over the state's tax rate, though he himself has released only the barest details of his own plans. 
 Mr. Cuomo went to great lengths to say the announcement was unrelated to the campaign, and aides said it grew from a study of the tax system he ordered in January. But in a statement, Mr. Cuomo said his plan would be "a cornerstone of my legislative program for my next term should I have the good fortune of continuing to serve this great state."
In his announcement, he set a tax-cutting goal during several years of $1 billion to $1.5 billion and directed his staff to develop "a multiyear blueprint" to be released before Election Day. That is in addition to the $475 million in tax cuts enacted by the Governor and Legislature this year, a cut that will grow to an annual maximum of $1.6 billion in 1997.
"Will we be able to afford it?" the Governor asked at a news conference in Manhattan. "Yes, of course, you'll be able to afford it as long as the economy is growing. If the economy doesn't grow, then the place dies anyway."
 
Questioned on Specifics

 But affordability was hardly the issue for the other two candidates, Mr. Pataki and Richard M. Rosenbaum, the former state Republican chairman who has proposed cutting the personal income tax by 24 percent and slashing state spending $4 billion a year.
They criticized Mr. Cuomo for what they said was a poor record holding down taxes and questioned the lack of specifics in the plan.
"Why should anyone believe he would enact such an agenda in the fourth term?" asked Lisa Linden, Mr. Rosenbaum's spokeswoman. "An empty proposal like this certainly offers no reassurance to the voters."
Caroline Quartararo, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, said Mr. Pataki intended to release his own tax-cutting plan soon. So far, he has proposed a further reduction in the personal income tax and a cut in the alternate minimum income tax, lowering capital gains taxes and immediately abolishing the corporate surcharge tax, though he has specified few details and has not outlined how he would pay for the cuts. He voted against spending increases eight times in the 10 years he was in the Legislature.
Ms. Quartararo said Mr. Cuomo's announcement smacked of "political opportunism."
"Can we believe him?" she asked. "I don't think so."
Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said the announcement was released along with a new study of the state's tax system, which Mr. Cuomo ordered in January from the Department of Taxation and Finance as he proposed tax cuts in this year's budget. At the time, the Republicans who control the Senate said the cuts were too low, and by the end of the Legislative session, the reductions were more than doubled.
 
New York Ranks 22d
 New York State ranks 22d in the nation in state tax burden. Mr. Cuomo said today that his goal was to drop that ranking to the lowest third of states.
Mr. Conroy said such a drop would be consistent with Mr. Cuomo's record: the state burden has dropped from 13th in the nation when he took office. Opponents, however, argue that the state has shifted much of the burden to local governments, and they point out that when state and local taxes are combined, New York ranks second only to Alaska in tax burden. Overall, statistics show that the entire tax burden, state and local, has remained relatively consistent during Mr. Cuomo's tenure.
In his proposal, Mr. Cuomo laid out three conditions for any cuts: "You cannot do it by savaging essential services," he said. "You cannot do it by putting the burden on Mayor Giuliani and local governments. Third, it has to be done fairly. You should have the people who can afford to pay taxes pay taxes. The people who can't shouldn't and the people who can afford less should pay less."
For the first time in years, Mr. Cuomo expressed a willingness to cut further the personal income tax, which has dropped to the current top rate of 7.875 percent from 10 percent in 1985. The top tax was scheduled by law to drop to 7 percent in 1990, but that reduction was deferred because of the recession, and since then Mr. Cuomo has expressed reservations about a further cut.
"We can cut further," he said today. He added that the current schedule for reducing the personal income tax was faulty, in that it would have increased taxes for some law-income earners.
Without further details, it was impossible to gauge how a reduction of another $1.5 billion would affect individual taxpayers or businesses. Last week, the Business Council of New York State released a report saying that the state would have to cut taxes an additional $2.3 billion, in addition to the cuts made this year, to make up for economic activity lost since the recession.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
Tapes are renting as strongly as ever this summer, but other formats are pushing ahead, too. Take video on demand, the term for the instant delivery of any title at any time by various carriers, including telephone companies. That level of service is many years away at best, but for early tests Bell Atlantic and the other so-called regional Baby Bells are beginning to stock up on movies and other titles from Hollywood studios.
Unlike cable operators, telephone companies have no ready-made pool of programming and need to build a supply of titles from scratch. "We're looking for tens of thousands," said Bob Townsend, the president for interactive multimedia products in Bell Atlantic's video-services division. 
 But video on demand doesn't yet faze the home-video industry, which is breaking ground of its own. One new area is CD-ROM, and distributors are starting to adapt the disk format to some of the same kinds of promotions they profit from on tape.
For instance, on Sept. 14, Turner plans to release the CD-ROM "The People v. O. J. Simpson: An Interactive Companion to the O. J. Simpson Trial," which is to begin four days later. The disk, which will be available for both I.B.M. and Macintosh platforms, is perhaps home video's (or anybody else's) first interactive instant publishing title.
The CD-ROM, which will cost under $20, draws from a voluminous Simpson file compiled by CNN, the news network owned by Turner. An hour of full-motion video drawn from CNN broadcasts is included, along with reams of testimony and information about evidence, strategy and other aspects of the case. In addition, purchasers will have access to Compuserve's daily on-line coverage of the trial.
Some news accounts describe the disk as a kind of video game in which the object is to reach a verdict. Stuart Snyder, the executive vice president of Turner Home Entertainment, said he strongly disagreed and called the title nothing more or less than a reference work for those who are following the case. "It's a companion piece," he said.
Like Turner, other video distributors are finding different applications for CD-ROM's. In October, Image Entertainment, a laser-disk company, plans to release "The Terminator," the first of a series of movies on CD-ROM (among them "Dances With Wolves" and "The Silence of the Lambs"), also available for both I.B.M. and Macintosh.
For various technical reasons, movies played on computers can use only a quarter of the screen and proceed at a rate of 15 frames a second, which results in quality inferior to videotape. That might seem an odd comedown for a distributor of laser disks, which provide by far the sharpest video images available. But Martin Greenwald, the chairman of Image Entertainment, said that with 30 million personal computers in use (as opposed to about 1.5 million laser disk players), CD-ROM's can't be ignored.
For now, quality doesn't concern Mr. Greenwald. "What's important is that it's passable," he said, adding that quality will eventually improve. The immediate goal is introduce movies to the format.
Besides, the price is right: as low as $10.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
Four Weddings and a Funeral
1994. Polygram. $95.99. Laser disk, $39.99. 116 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Wednesday.
 Continually on call as an attractive best man, Charles (Hugh Grant) makes his way between nuptials, with one death intervening, in a long round of socializing with friends and acquaintances. Mike Newell's film could have gone nowhere from there, but funny material and charming performances by Mr. Grant and a fine supporting cast find a fresh way across familiar ground. Only Andie MacDowell as a hard-boiled American doesn't fit into a deft English comedy with, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, "a light, engaging style that is very much its own."
 
The House of the Spirits
1994. LIVE. $94.98. 132 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
Bille August's film never reaches for the complexity or mysticism of Isabel Allende's novel, but it does take chances of its own with the story of a South American family caught in political upheaval. Heading a cast capable of just about anything are Jeremy Irons as the cold, conservative estate owner, Meryl Streep as the woman he marries, Glenn Close as his repressed sister, Winona Ryder as his rebellious daughter and Vanessa Redgrave as Ms. Streep's mother. Mr. August's style is naturally severe, but here he adds fanciful touches to a "cool, ravishing film filled with odd gaps and understated miracles" (Maslin).
 
I'll Do Anything
1994. Columbia Tri-Star. $95.51. 116 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
Originally intended as a musical, James L. Brooks's film does best as a satire of Hollywood at its most boorish, particularly in the person of the arrogant director Burke Adler (Albert Brooks). Nick Nolte is an unemployed actor who has the misfortune of working for Adler as a chauffeur, and Whittni Wright is the actor's 6-year-old studio-wise daughter, spectacularly hip to the manipulative ways of the movie business. Though the father-daughter relationship never develops, bubbling through are "some wonderfully satirical ingredients, touches that are no less scathingly hilarious than anything in 'The Player' " (Maslin).
 
Knife in the Head
1980. New Yorker. $79.95. 108 minutes. German with English subtitles. No rating.
In Reinhard Hauff's stark study of sociopolitical currents in West Germany, Bertolt Hoffmann (Bruno Ganz) goes to find his estranged wife, who is living with her leftist lover, and is critically injured in a skirmish with the police. Left to cope with severe brain injuries, Bertolt tries to get a fix on his life in a story that becomes part metaphysical mystery story and part denunciation of the German right and left. Though Mr. Hauff lacks the flair of a Rainer Werner Fassbinder, say, he directs with methodical command, and Mr. Ganz shows a "film presence that finds power even in utter passivity" (Vincent Canby).

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton: Defend Your Trade Pledge

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration fought for consumers when it signed a trade accord in April with more than 100 other countries in Marrakesh, Morocco. But it besmirched its record when it sent Congress implementing legislation that contradicted the Marrakesh accord in dozens of places. It was as if the Commerce Department had decided to protect powerful corporate friends in steel, textiles and cement rather than consumers or the vast number of U.S. companies that need to buy low-cost foreign goods.
Then House and Senate committees took the Administration's draft and made it worse. Conferees will meet soon to hammer out final language -- providing a chance to fix the wrongs. 
 At issue are anti-dumping statutes, which require foreigners to sell in the U.S. at fair prices; foreign companies may not sell at prices either below what they charge in their home country or below their cost of production. But the U.S. and other countries manipulate anti-dumping laws to shut out imports that are not dumped. The Marrakesh accord tries to limit this protectionist practice.
The accord says that the U.S. must make a fair comparison between prices here and abroad. But the Senate committee, at the insistence of Ernest Hollings of South Carolina, proposes a formula that, by treating profit differently here and abroad, would artificially deflate the calculation of prices some foreign businesses charge in the U.S. -- and make conviction for dumping near-certain.
The accord also recognizes that production costs typically decline for new companies during a break-in period; the U.S. is supposed to calculate a foreign company's costs at the end of the break-in period. But the Administration and Congressional committees propose making such costs appear high by using an earlier period.
The Marrakesh accord allows countries to retaliate only if domestic industry has been harmed. To show harm, the U.S. would have to demonstrate substantial imports compared with the size of domestic production. House and Senate committees, with Administration support, propose to make U.S. production look small -- and dumping look harmful -- by ignoring a substantial part of U.S. output, known as captive production. Captive production refers to goods made not for sale but for use in other goods -- a computer business's production of semiconductors, for example.
In Marrakesh, the Administration stood for open trade and economic growth. At home, it proposed sizable doses of protectionism. The conferees will now decide which version of U.S. policy will be the final version.

HEADLINE: Before We Wreck the Health System . . .

SERIES: HEALTH CARE SECOND OPINIONS -- An occasional series.

BYLINE: By Ross Perot; Ross Perot, independent candidate for President in 1992, is author of "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country."

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
America's health care system the world's finest -- consists of tens of millions of very complex parts. It took nine years and $300 million, for example, just to develop and test Mevacor, the pill that reduces cholesterol. And that is but one tiny part of the health care industry.
The health industry is twice the size of the U.S. auto industry. It is 14 percent of our economy. It affects every American from birth to death. Successfully reshaping health care is far more complicated than building an aircraft carrier or designing the space shuttle or inventing the atomic bomb. 
 The Clinton Administration's health care plan was drafted in secret by talented, well-intentioned group whose leaders had little experience in health care. This plan did not attract widespread support in Congress, or with the American people.
 Now the Clinton plan is being hurriedly redrafted into a variety of new bills by Congressional staffers who have little experience with health care. Most of these bills include a vast new Government bureaucracy to oversee the health system. Senate leaders are rushing to force a vote in the next few days on bills that have not been read. Moreover, this restructuring has been undertaken along partisan lines. The American people have been subjected to propaganda and emotional anecdotes instead of having these "reforms" explained to them in a logical and rational manner.
Worse yet, no one can accurately estimate what these bills will cost American taxpayers. We do know that the costs will be massive. In 1965, Congress thought the new Medicare program would cost $9 billion a year by 1990. The actual cost of Medicare in 1990 was $110 billion! With our $4.6 trillion debt, we can no longer afford to make such mistakes.
 Can the Government effectively manage health care for the entire nation? Consider the nationwide health care program it manages now -- our veterans' hospitals, where services are so poor that only 10 percent of veterans make use of this system.
But there is a rational way to improve the health system, deliver care to the uninsured and keep costs in line.
First, identify the parts of the system that need to be improved. Bring in leading authorities to design the improvements. When this detailed plan has been completed, explain the system carefully to the American people in plain language. Skip the propaganda.
 Once a consensus is reached, carefully figure out the cost of these changes and frankly explain how health care will be paid for. Don't mislead the American people by claiming "companies will pay for it" and implying that health care will be free -- indeed, it will be the ultimate hidden tax on the ordinary American, because companies will simply increase their prices and consumers will wind up paying the entire cost.
 Finally, conduct pilot programs to make sure these improvements work as planned and their costs can be determined. The logical pilot group would include every member of Congress, every member of the White House staff and every Federal employee.
Testing a Government-run program on Government employees shouldn't impose much of a hardship. They already have an excellent health benefits program, so they should have good ideas about the operation of a nationwide system. This would guarantee every citizen that any health care plan would be debugged, optimized and trouble-free before it is imposed on the entire nation.
Once the pilot operation is working successfully, at a cost we can afford, with the American people fully informed of the plan and its costs, the decision to make changes nationwide can be made with all the facts on the table and at minimal risk. Compare this rational approach with the propaganda, emotional appeals and name calling in Washington today.
Obviously, no one wants rationing of health services and waits of up to 18 months for surgical procedures, items that are prevalent in Government-run health programs in Europe, Canada and our own veterans' hospitals.
 Democrats and Republicans must work together to carefully design, test and price the new health system. Encourage them to go slow, take their time, get it right. What's the hurry?
 Let's not destroy health care in a well-intentioned effort to save it. Remember, the first rule of medicine is "do no harm." The process I have described could take two years or more. It took nine years to develop Mevacor, just one pill. This is a process that we cannot short-circuit if we want a cost-effective health system that truly benefits the American people. In the words of the carpenter, "measure twice, cut once."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed; Series

COMPANY: AMERICA'S HEALTH PLAN INC (59%);

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S., IN NEW POLICY, INTENDS TO DETAIN CUBAN IMMIGRANTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
With hundreds of Cubans continuing to flee each day in rafts and rubber dinghies, the Clinton Administration announced tonight, in a sharp change of policy, that it would detain Cubans for an indefinite period after they arrived in the United States.
The move, effective immediately, is a major departure from an open-door policy toward Cubans, who, for three decades, have usually been granted free entry into the United States after a brief interview by immigration authorities. 
 Attorney General Janet Reno announced the new policy at an unusual late-night news conference, saying the move was intended to slow the fast-growing flow of refugees from Cuba to the United States, which Ms. Reno ascribed to deep dissatisfaction with the Government of Fidel Castro.
The announcement came just hours after President Clinton rebuffed a plea from the Governor of Florida to declare a state of emergency there in response to the wave of Cuban refugees.
The abrupt nature of Ms. Reno's announcement appeared to be intended to comfort the many Florida residents who say that President Clinton was too quick to reject the plea from Gov. Lawton Chiles for millions of dollars in Federal aid to deal with the more than 2,000 Cubans who have reached Florida this month.
In her four-minute appearance at 10:40 P.M. at the White House, Ms. Reno said the new detention policy would be undertaken to insure that the Administration was doing what it could "to discourage people from risking their lives."
"It is an unsafe trip," she added. "We are trying to discourage people from coming from Cuba."
Governor Chiles said he was pleased by the Administration's switch in policy. "This keeps Castro from being able to call the shots," he said in an interview on CNN.
Governor Chiles added, "It's a day that I'm delighted is here."
President Clinton has scheduled a news conference for 1:30 P.M. on Friday, and the Cuba decision is expected to be formally announced then.
Governor Chiles said: "I'm looking forward to the President's announcement tomorrow. I'm trusting, because I had a conversation with him today, that this is going to be a further good, firm statement."
Mr. Chiles added, "We are not going to allow Castro to dictate our immigration policy."
Earlier in the day, Administration officials said they were searching for a policy that would stop Cubans from fleeing in flimsy vessels, an exodus that officials said had caused dozens of Cubans to drown this month.
Under the new policy, the Cubans will be held indefinitely in Federal installations, including units run by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. That is a sharp change from the previous policy, under which many Cuban refugees were turned over to relatives within hours after the Coast Guard picked them up in at sea and brought them ashore in Florida.
The policy announced tonight was less drastic than another proposal that Administration officials said they had been considering: turning back some of the Cuban refugees instead of continuing the longstanding policy of granting virtually all Cubans entry. Another option that was considered was to transfer Cuban refugees to third countries or safe havens -- a policy similar to the one adopted to handle the flood of Haitian immigrants this summer.
Administration officials acknowledged that both those options would be likely to anger many Cuban-Americans, and they hoped that those people, worried about the drownings of their countrymen, would be more sympathetic to a policy of detentions.
For the Administration, one advantage of the new policy is that it can easily be reversed if Cuban-Americans attack it. Administration officials said tonight that they had adopted the new policy only after consulting with Cuban-American groups.
In resisting the plea of Governor Chiles to declare a state of emergency in Florida, President Clinton finds himself torn between domestic politics and foreign policy imperatives.
On one hand, the President wants to help Governor Chiles, a fellow Southern Democrat who faces a tough re-election race this November, possibly against former President George Bush's son Jeb.
In a midterm election year when the Democrats fear major reversals, especially in the larger, more influential states, one of the last things the Administration wants is to lose the Governor's Mansion in Florida, the fourth most populous state, which has 25 electoral votes.
With an eye on November, Mr. Chiles is insisting that the Administration declare a state of emergency, partly to show Florida voters that he has clout in Washington. He is also asking for $75 million in emergency Federal financing to counter Republican charges that he is spending too much on social services for immigrants and others.
But diplomatic concerns are giving President Clinton a strong tug in the other direction. Administration officials said today that they were reluctant to declare a full-scale emergency because it would send a signal to Cubans that the door was open wide for them to flee in their boats and rafts. At the same time, declaring an emergency would tell Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, that he had succeeded in unnerving the Administration.
 
Emergency Meeting
 After an emergency high-level White House meeting on the Cuba situation today, Administration officials said they were considering numerous contingency plans. These included increasing the number of Coast Guard vessels off Cuba and enabling more Cubans to gain refugee status by applying in Havana, rather than by taking to rafts. The Coast Guard now has a dozen cutters and 31 small boats patrolling the Florida Straits.
Pentagon officials said Navy personnel were trucking tents from Gulfport, Miss., to Homestead Air Force Base in Florida in case the wave of Cubans surged suddenly.
Administration officials say wretched economic conditions in Cuba are the underlying factor behind the exodus, but they add that the immediate reason for it is that Mr. Castro has stopped prohibiting Cubans from fleeing in rafts, inner tubes and small boats.
According to Administration policymakers, Mr. Castro has permitted the recent wave of refugees in the hope that it would vex the Administration and pressure it to ease its trade embargo against Cuba. That would enable Cubans and Mr. Castro to breathe more easily at a time when the Cuban leader faces the most domestic dissent in years.
Senior American officials said today they had ruled out relaxing the embargo, which Mr. Castro asserts is destroying Cuba's economy and causing the wave of refugees.
In a news conference today in Key West, where the Coast Guard has taken most of the Cuban refugees, Governor Chiles declared an emergency situation within his state. He said the Florida National Guard, marine patrol and other branches of government would be used to respond to the influx of Cubans.
"These large numbers create an emergency situation for services and assistance," Governor Chiles said. "Already, this emergency creates a burden on local and state resources."
At a news conference, Ms. Reno treated Mr. Chiles's depiction of the situation as an exaggeration, saying the Administration was handling the problem "in an orderly way and without disruption." She said the Immigration and Naturalization Service was adding more than a dozen workers in Florida to handle the Cuban refugees.
"We do not believe that this current influx has been a burden yet on the community," she said. To buttress this point, she noted that 75 percent of the Cuban refugees who have arrived this year had been settled with relatives in Florida and 15 percent with relatives in other states, primarily New York and New Jersey. The other 10 percent, she said, have also been placed outside of Florida.
But Administration officials said they were analyzing the situation day to day and would not rule out putting an emergency plan into effect.
"'We're watching it very closely, but to date we've been able to manage the situation and we expect we'll continue to be able to," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House Press Secretary.
 
Would Bar Mariel Repeat
 Administration officials vow not to allow a replay of the Mariel exodus, in which an estimated 90 percent of the refugees were carried by boats belonging to Cuban-Americans from Florida.
The Coast Guard has been ordered to increase patrols to stop and seize boats heading to Cuba from Florida to pick up refugees.
"We are not going to permit another massive exodus," said Ms. Myers. "We will not allow Fidel Castro to dictate our immigration policy."
One senior State Department official said he doubted that the flow of Cubans would grow to the same proportions as the wave of Haitians did last June. Since Cuba does not have free enterprise, he said, it is harder for Cubans to build medium-sized boats to carry lots of refugees. That is why Haitian refugees often fled 50 or 100 to a boat, while the Cubans flee 5 or 10 to a raft.
Attorney General Reno seized on the new exodus to indict Mr. Castro. "To divert the Cuban people from seeking democratic change, the government of Cuba has resorted to the unconscionable tactic of letting people risk their lives by leaving in flimsy vessels through the treacherous waters of the Florida Straits," she said.
"An uncontrolled exodus from Cuba will do nothing to address Cuba's internal problems. The solution to Cuba's problems is rapid, fundamental and far-reaching political and economic reform."

HEADLINE: Russia Treasures Plutonium, But U.S. Wants to Destroy It

SERIES: After the Arms Race -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD with MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
To the Americans it is an albatross, an economic liability and a threat to global security that must be rendered untouchable or destroyed. But to the Russians it is, as one official put it, "a national treasure," to be husbanded now and to produce boundless energy for future generations.
The object of these clashing views is prime, bomb-grade plutonium, produced during the cold war by each side at enormous cost in money, health and environmental damage. With the arms race winding down, huge stocks of plutonium are coming out of bombs -- during the next decade at least 50 tons each in the United States and Russia, American officials say. In Russia, that comes on top of plutonium stocks accumulated for use in power plants. 
 But now, as the United States searches for a safe way to get rid of plutonium, Russia not only wants to save the material being taken from weapons but also to make still more in the quest for energy.
The country is planning a new generation of nuclear power plants called breeders that create more plutonium than the nuclear fuel they consume. And that plutonium, while not as pure as that from weapons, would still be readily usable by a bomb-maker.
What is more, senior Russian officials say they plan to pay for these costly factories in part with dollars from the United States Government, money that that the Ministry of Atomic Energy here will earn from an unprecedented contract to sell America still another bomb fuel, highly enriched uranium. The United States has contracted to buy about 500 metric tons of highly enriched uranium -- which Russia had prepared for weapons use -- during the next 20 years for a total of about $10 billion dollars. The Russians will dilute the uranium so that the United States can burn it in civilian reactors for energy, but the real American purpose was to reduce the chances of theft or sales on the world market, a goal that could be undercut by the Russians' use of the revenues to build breeder reactors.
Thus while the cold war may be over, the gulf in attitudes about its nuclear legacy could hardly be larger. And the Russian approach, Americans fear, will add to the long-term security risk. Russia will keep its surplus weapons plutonium in a pure form, the form in which it is used in weapons, thus making it attractive to terrorists or nations that want a bomb; as little as four kilograms, or less than 10 pounds, a chunk smaller than a fist, would be enough. And Russia's planned breeder reactors would produce more weapons-usable plutonium, slightly less pure but also readily usable in bombs.
Even without thefts, the more plutonium that remains in an easily accessible form in either country, the easier it would be for a future Russian or American government to rebuild a giant nuclear arsenal in a short time. While American officials say their own stockpiles are safely guarded for now, they argue that disposal of plutonium now could help protect future generations.
The United States, which first synthesized plutonium and has spent billions of dollars and created substantial damage to the environment and human health in the process, is ready to dispose of it. That process is a costly and difficult enterprise in it own right, and will be pursued with none of the sense of national mission that attended its manufacture.
"Plutonium has essentially a negative economic value," said John Gibbons, the White House science adviser, stressing that even using already available plutonium as fuel in reactors would cost far more than using uranium. The United States argues that uranium, cheap now, will stay that way for decades.
 
'Global Security Risk'
 "The plutonium we no longer need for weapons is a global security risk and an economic liability," said Hazel R. O'Leary, Secretary of Energy.
The United States is pondering methods of making its surplus weapons plutonium as unusable as possible, perhaps by mixing it in glass with highly radioactive wastes from the plutonium's creation, and burying the mixture deep underground, or perhaps by running it through reactors, burning some and rendering the remainder highly radioactive.
Russian officials could not disagree more. "This is a sacrilege," said Viktor M. Murogov, director of the Institute of Physics and Power Engineering at Obninsk, who refers to plutonium as "our national treasure." To the Russians, plutonium is a prize pearl that America now appears ready to throw out with the oyster shells.
"We have spent too much money making this material to just mix it with radioactive wastes and bury it," said Viktor N. Mikhailov, Russia's Minister of Atomic Energy.
In Russia the damage to the environment and to human health has been substantially larger, and is probably still continuing. But the Russians believe that in future decades, the world nuclear industry will revive and uranium will become scarcer and more expensive, making plutonium more attractive as a fuel.
"The 21st century will belong to nuclear power," said Mr. Mikhailov in an interview here. He also argued that a future generation of plutonium-burning reactors could have the added benefit of destroying the most toxic elements of nuclear waste.
Another senior official, Yuri Vishevsky, the head of Gosatomnadzor or GAN, the Russian equivalent of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said in a separate interview that breeders were the only rational way for plutonium to be used.
"Will our children and grandchildren be thankful to us when they experience a lack of fuel in the future?" he asked.
For now, Russia's elaborate construction plans may be little more than pipe dream. Minatom, as Mr. Mikhailov's ministry is known, is so cash-strapped that it is months behind in paying weapons scientists and other nuclear workers, who sometimes seize their workplaces and stage strikes. Still, design work is continuing at Obninsk, about 60 miles from Moscow.
 
The U.S.
Changing Course On Plutonium

Though the United States once envisaged using plutonium to make electricity, now it thinks that would be uneconomical and would present terrorists with inviting targets for theft.
The United States did spend $1.7 billion on a breeder reactor in the 1970's and early 80's. But that was when uranium was expensive and the number of nuclear power plants in the United States and abroad was expected to soar.
Economics and politics undermined the nuclear industry. Partly as a result, the price of uranium, $40 a pound in 1982, is only a little over $5 a pound now. America dropped its breeder plans a decade ago.
American experts believe that there is a long-term glut of uranium. So the Department of Energy is looking for ways to get plutonium out of circulation.
All the separated, readily usable plutonium in the United States today is in the hands of the military -- in weapons, stockpiles or components from disassembled weapons. Plutonium from dismantled weapons in the form of "pits," or steel-wrapped spheres, is now piling up in bunkers at the Pantex plant, near Amarillo, Tex., where it is considered safe from theft for the time being.
 
Plan for Commercial Use
 A commercial lobby is developing for turning plutonium into reactor fuel rather than encasing it in glass. Some existing plants could be modified to take plutonium, mixed with uranium. But there are also proposals for new reactors.
Combustion Engineering, a subsidiary of Asea Brown Boveri, has proposed building two huge new reactors at the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C., to burn the plutonium, with the electricity being sold to utilities. The surplus American stockpile could be burned up in 25 years. The end product would still have about 80 percent of the plutonium of the original, but mixed into spent fuel, a form that would give a thief a lethal radiation dose within minutes.
"We're talking about taking plutonium that is already a weapons concern and converting it into something that's less of a risk," said George A. Davis, the company's project manager for the South Carolina plan.
The reactors do not make sense as an energy project, he acknowledged. "Nobody in their right mind would put up with the risks and headaches just to generate electricity," he said. But they are a relatively cheap way to get rid of the plutonium, he said.
Savannah River also has a factory that is supposed to encase nuclear wastes into strong glass, which some say could be a vessel for disposing of plutonium. But operation has been stalled by severe technical problems.
It is not clear yet which alternative would be cheaper or environmentally safer, but mixing the plutonium with glass has one advantage: it would not undermine American arguments abroad that no one should use plutonium for civil power projects. Also, Americans do not want to encourage Russia to use its plutonium in its existing power plants unless they can be upgraded to meet Western safety standards.
Both methods pose technical hazards, and there is as yet no place to bury the products that would result, either steel-wrapped glass cylinders 2 feet in diameter and 10 feet long, or spent fuel rods from power plants.
The object is to make weapons disassembly as irreversible as possible.
"I'd like to be in a race with them, and I'd like them to win," Mrs. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, said in an interview in May.
 
Russia
Do Fuel Needs Outrank Security?
 But Russia has a distinctly different idea of what it is racing to. Here, mixing good plutonium with glass or squandering it in light-water reactors is out of the question.
Mr. Murogov, director of the Obninsk institute, said in an interview that if the plutonium that Western engineers fret over today is not economically viable immediately, that does not mean that it is garbage; it means that the economy will eventually change to favor its use.
"These are the products for future technology, which we cannot use today," he said.
He rejects the American sense of urgency about transforming the plutonium into a form less usable in bombs: "One has to think that any haste here is not necessary."
"When people in the nuclear industry use such words as expediently, or short period of time, I visualize Chernobyl," he said.
Russian scientists recognize that virgin uranium is far cheaper than plutonium, but they -- with some support in Japan and Europe -- do not believe this will last.
Russia is ready to invest in the long term with money it does not have. But it will be getting some hard currency soon, $10 billion over 20 years from the United States.
Mr. Mikhailov, the minister, said he hopes to use some of that money to help build new breeder reactors that will produce plutonium, another bomb-usable material. It is not clear how the United States could stop such use of the money.
Mr. Mikhailov dismisses the threat of nuclear theft, foresees a vast new generation of reactors and a pressing need for plutonium to run them. Completing the first two reactors and a factory to turn the plutonium into reactor fuel would cost $2.5 billion, according to experts at the Institute of Physics & Power Engineering.
Energy Department officials say the idea that the United States might indirectly finance the breeders is very troubling. But some are skeptical of the Russian plans.
"Reviving the nuclear industry is romanticism," said Mrs. O'Leary. If the Russians have money to continue, she added, "how is it they haven't paid their workers?"
But Russia, other officials point out, if no longer a superpower, is still a sovereign state.
"Some people say they don't want the Russians doing anything with nuclear power because they don't think the Russians can do anything well," said Glenn E. Schweitzer, the executive director of the International Science and Technology Center in Moscow and an American expert on Russian science. "In the longer view, in the next 10 years or 15 years, they're going to control their own destiny."
He visited one of the breeder reactor sites, in Beloyarsk, earlier this year, and described it as "stuck in the mud" for want of money, but said that the Ministry for Atomic Power is determined to proceed.
Russia is a country of remarkable variety in its level of technical achievement. Moscow, for example, is a city of rotary-dial telephones, each of which receives only one line. Mr. Mikhailov, the energy minister, in a sign of status, has eight on his desk, seven white and one red.
But if Russia lags in telecommunications, it excels in its variety of nuclear reactors, used in everything from icebreakers to spacecraft.
And Minatom is not ready to stop. The Soviet logic still holds for the ministry: that using reactors at home made more oil and gas available for export, and that in a vast land with limited rail and pipeline transport, shipping uranium fuel is far easier than shipping coal, oil or gas.
 
Disposal
Burn Plutonium Or Bury It?

Not everyone agrees. Aleksei V. Yablokov, an adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin and a former environment minister, said in an interview that it was no longer clear that existing nuclear reactors, let alone new ones, made economic sense.
The country could replace all its reactors with natural gas and coal-fired power plants for $6 billion to $7 billion over six or seven years, he said. In contrast, he said, the International Atomic Energy Agency had told him that upgrading the existing reactors to Western safety standards would take between $26 billion and $120 billion.
But, he said, "Minatom is a country inside a country, with its own rules, its own morals. They have not only nuclear facilities; they have a construction organization, their own air fleet, their own railways."
"If Mikhailov and Minatom have a choice, they will make a choice that is suitable and profitable for Minatom, not for the country," he said.
Minatom has a momentum and an institutional problem that in some ways resembles those of the United States Department of Energy, which has also lost its main mission, making weapons. Western experts say Minatom has 1 million employees, many with no clear purpose today.
The decision to build breeders would eventually have to be approved by President Yeltsin and other top officials. But in numerous conflicts in the last two years, said Mr. Yablokov, Mr. Mikhailov, an entrenched bureaucrat whose ministry is the mainstay of whole cities, has usually prevailed.
If they do go ahead, the Russian engineers envisage keeping the weapons plutonium in storage for the next few decades and use their existing surplus of reactor-grade plutonium instead. The reason is that some components of reactor-grade plutonium break down over the course of a few years and become more radioactive and thus harder to handle; the weapons-grade plutonium is immortal, in human terms.
Even as Russian and American officials grope for the most sensible policy, commercial interests are actively pushing their own proposals. An American company is lobbying the Russians to adopt yet another kind of reactor. General Atomics, of San Diego, Calif., has for years been trying to market a reactor fueled by uranium or plutonium in ceramic pellets, and cooled by helium gas.
In a sign of the aggressive marketing, Mr. Velikhov, director of the Kurchatov Institute, has a brass plaque hanging on his Moscow office wall proclaiming him the winner of the 1992 General Atomics/University of California at San Diego Scientific Achievement Award.
If an answer to the plutonium problem is elusive in Russia, it is elusive in the United States, too, though perhaps not with the same urgency. The Department of Energy hopes to make a proposal later this year, and building a new reactor to destroy plutonium is a possibility, said Mrs. O'Leary, "If it can burn up existing stuff and not be left with a bigger problem than I started out with."
She was wary, she said, of solutions that did not include a final form and a final repository. Otherwise, she said, disposal of plutonium would only create "a second-generation problem that then belongs to a governor or a mayor."
 
YESTERDAY Because of poor accounting, Russia cannot know for sure if any nuclear bomb ingredients have been stolen.
 
TODAY Russia and the United States have drastically different intentions for their growing surplus stocks of weapons plutonium.
 
TOMORROW Fears of nuclear proliferation are raised by the energy plans of America's closest allies.
 
 
A Nuclear Glossary
 URANIUM, an element found in nature, must be "enriched" for use in most power plants. It is processed to raise the proportion of one form, U-235, the kind that is easiest to split in a reactor or bomb and comprises only 0.7 percent of natural uranium.
LOW-ENRICHED URANIUM, which is 3 to 5 percent U-235, fuels conventional power reactors in the United States, Japan and Western Europe.
HIGHLY ENRICHED URANIUM, for use in bombs and some research and submarine reactors, is over 90 percent U-235. Like plutonium it can be used to make bombs, but larger quantities are needed and it is more easily rendered useless for weapons through mixing with natural uranium.
PLUTONIUM, an element that exists in only trace amounts in nature, is manufactured in reactors by bombarding atoms of the uranium isotope U-238 until they absorb a neutron and become Pu-239.
WEAPONS-GRADE PLUTONIUM, prized by scientists making bombs, is separated from uranium that has been kept only briefly in a reactor, so that more than 93 percent is Pu-239.
REACTOR-GRADE PLUTONIUM is separated from uranium that spent months or years in the reactor, so that many of the atoms have absorbed more than one neutron and become Pu-240 or Pu-241. It is less efficient as a weapons fuel but can still be used to make bombs.
MIXED OXIDE FUEL (MOX) is reactor fuel made by mixing uranium oxide and plutonium oxide, rather than the conventional fuel, pure uranium oxide. This allows use of plutonium to fuel certain conventional reactors.
REPROCESSING means chopping up spent reactor fuel rods and chemically separating the plutonium, uranium and other products left over from splitting uranium. This produces plutonium that can be re-used in power plants or used in bombs.
SEPARATED PLUTONIUM, as the plutonium product of reprocessing is known, is poisonous but not highly radioactive, in contrast to the plutonium that remains in spent fuel rods, and is thus an inviting target for theft by covert bomb-makers.
NUCLEAR REACTORS use uranium or plutonium fuel to produce energy. In the process they also produce plutonium, although conventional models consume more fuel than they produce.
LIGHT-WATER REACTORS, most common in power plants, use ordinary water in the core to create conditions conducive to a chain reaction; in the former Soviet Union many reactors use graphite for the same purpose.
BREEDER REACTORS, of which there are only a handful in the world, create plutonium in greater quantities than the uranium or plutonium fuel they burn.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "The plutonium we no longer need for weapons is a global security risk and an economic liability." HAZEL R. SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk
