HEADLINE: Democrats' New Overseer Is Everybody's Mr. Inside

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
When Congress last year was blocking final Government approval of a genetically engineered hormone that had cost hundreds of millions of dollars to develop, the drug's maker, the giant chemical concern Monsanto, turned for advice to a man renowned for his skills as a legislative strategist.
When Sun Diamond Growers, the California agribusiness, organized a dinner earlier this year to retire the Congressional campaign debt of Henry Espy, brother of Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, it called on one of the most prolific fund-raisers in the history of the Democratic Party. 
 And last week, when President Clinton was looking for a gifted political pro who could rebuild the President's popularity and rescue sagging Democratic prospects for the November elections, he chose a man with an encyclopedic knowledge of the nation's Congressional districts.
The man whose expertise is so prized by so many disparate groups? Tony L. Coelho, who left Congress as House majority whip in 1989 for a lucrative career as a New York investment banker amid accusations that he had improperly used his political contacts to arrange and finance a $100,000 junk-bond investment for himself.
Since leaving the House, Mr Coelho has commuted to New York, where he has learned the intricacies of money management. At the same time, he has kept his hand very much in the Washington game, and the announcement last week that he was accepting a three-month unpaid stint as chief strategist and spokesman at the Democratic National Committee brought mixed responses.
While the coterie of Democratic campaign consultants and career politicians embraced it as a savvy move by a miscue-prone White House, others worried that Mr. Coelho was once again blurring the lines among business, politics and personal interest.
"I'm never happy unless I have several balls in the air," Mr. Coelho said in a recent interview. And that he has.
Since Mr. Clinton's election almost two years ago, Mr. Coelho has served as an informal adviser to the White House, attending several high-level strategy meetings a month. He is raising money for the legal defense fund that will help the President fight Whitewater accusations and a former Arkansas employee's sex harassment charges. And his former aides hold important posts in the Clinton Administration.
What Mr. Coelho calls his "extended family" includes Thomas R. Nides, chief of staff to Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative; Marcia L. Hale, head of the White House office that deals with governors and state legislators, and Kim Schnoor, senior aide to Agriculture Secretary Espy. Leon E. Panetta, his former colleague in the California Congressional delegation, is now the White House chief of staff and was instrumental in the selection of Mr. Coelho as the new party overseer.
 
Common Cause Sees A Danger
 At the same time, Mr. Coelho earns more than $1 million a year as president of a subsidiary of Wertheim Schroder & Company, a New York investment bank that manages nearly $4 billion for pension funds, corporations and well-heeled individuals. Mr. Coelho's contacts, and the investment bank's impressive track record, have made it one of the fastest-growing such companies on Wall Street.
Fred Wertheimer, president of the public-interest lobbying group Common Cause, says Mr. Coelho's roles at the White House and in the Democratic Party put him in a "quasi-public, quasi-private" position that could allow his banking company to take advantage of inside information about government policy. "That's not an argument that he's going to do it," Mr. Wertheimer said. "But it's a dangerous situation."
Mr. Coelho says he gains no business advantages from his ties to the Clinton Administration and never lobbies for companies or friends who need help from the Government, although he acknowledges that clients frequently seek his counsel on the ways of Washington.
"It happens all the time," Mr. Coelho said. "I will give people advice. People will say to me, 'Tony, I'm having this problem with Joe Schmo or X bill or agency.' I will give them my best advice, based on 25 years in government. But if they want something done, I say, 'Go see this law firm or that lobbyist.' "
Mr. Coelho said he saw no reason to disclose a list of his clients, as Mr. Wertheimer of Common Cause has suggested. He agreed that it would be improper for him to remain on Wall Street if he held a paid position in the Democratic Party, saying, "I would have to make a complete break."
Lloyd N. Cutler, who accepted a temporary stint as White House counsel, took a leave of absence from his law firm to do so. And several of the political consultants who advise Mr. Clinton, including James Carville and Paul Begala, have publicly disclosed their client lists.
But both Mr. Carville and Mr. Begala are paid for their work, under contract with the Democratic National Committee. In contrast, Mr. Coelho said, "I don't get a cent."
"I'm an adviser," said Mr. Coelho, who, unlike some of Mr. Clinton's other informal advisers, has never held the permanent pass that grants unfettered access to the White House. "I don't have an office, I don't have hours. I'm a citizen of this country who is advising the people who run my party."
Few citizens, however, have his connections or cachet.
Consider how Mr. Coelho advised Monsanto on its struggle to win approval for the genetically engineered hormone, bovine somatotropin, which enhances the milk production of cows. It is a case study of the interlocking relationships that Mr. Coelho can call on. As he put it, "I've lived in this town for 30 years, and I love networking."
 
A Call to Coelho, A Call From Him
 At a House hearing in June 1986, Mr. Coelho, then a subcommittee chairman, seemed opposed to the hormone, repeatedly asking why the Agriculture Department had helped develop it when the American dairy industry faced a milk glut. (Mr. Coelho says now that he did not really oppose the hormone and that he held the hearing only to placate a Wisconsin Republican whose vote he needed on his own dairy bill.)
Seven years later, Monsanto's president, Robert B. Shapiro, called Mr. Coelho at the suggestion of a friend. Congress, which Mr. Coelho had long since left, had just imposed a 90-day moratorium on the sale of the hormone and was demanding further study of its economic impact on small dairy farmers. When he called Mr. Coelho, Mr. Shapiro said in an interview, the company was "eager to find people who could give us advice and perhaps be helpful."
Mr. Coelho, who has epilepsy, says he saw the drug as the vanguard of a biotechnology revolution that could bring cures for many diseases. "We need to have breakthroughs," he said. "and, well, here was the first breakthrough, and these people were trying to stop it." Mr. Coelho says he never had business dealings with Monsanto or Mr. Shapiro. His investment bank, a spokesman said, holds stock in neither Monsanto nor any biotechnology company.
After receiving that call from Mr. Shapiro, Mr. Coelho called the Agriculture Department to find out where things stood. Mr. Coelho has some of his strongest ties at Agriculture. Secretary Espy won his first race for Congress, in 1986, with substantial financial help from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which was then headed by Mr. Coelho. Further, Mr. Espy's selection by Mr. Clinton as Agriculture Secretary came on Mr. Coelho's recommendation. And before the new Secretary picked his staff, Mr. Coelho proposed several choices to him; one, Kim Schnoor, a former Congressional aide of Mr. Coelho, became Mr. Espy's domestic counselor.
It was Ms. Schnoor who received the call that Mr. Coelho made to the Agriculture Department to see whether anyone there was blocking approval of the hormone. According to an internal Monsanto memo, Mr. Coelho stood ready to hammer home the company's concerns at a dinner he was planning with Mr. Espy.
The Monsanto memo, dated Sept. 21, 1993, expressed hope that Mr. Coelho would enlist Mr. Espy to persuade Mr. Panetta, then the head of the White House Office of Management and Budget, to "duck" a request from Congress for a study of the hormone's economic effects.
Within a few days, a copy of the internal Monsanto memo was obtained and made public by the Washington-based Foundation on Economic Trends, a group that questions the hormone's safety. The dinner meeting between Mr. Espy and Mr. Coelho never took place.
Nonetheless the hormone received final approval from Congress, a few months after the Office of Management and Budget, in completing its study, had concluded that the economic effects of the hormone would be minimal.
Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, says the conversation between Ms. Schnoor and Mr. Coelho was inappropriate. The Monsanto memo, he says, is proof that Ms. Schnoor provided "sensitive information to give Coelho ammunition to make Monsanto's case with the Secretary."
Tom Amontree, deputy press secretary at the Agriculture Department, disagrees. He says Ms. Schnoor engaged in a brief conversation with Mr. Coelho in which she explained only that the Office of Management and Budget was handling the study.
In a letter hand-delivered to the Agriculture Department, Mr. Rifkin demanded at the time that the department investigate the incident. But no inquiry was ever undertaken, and Mr. Amontree says the letter from Mr. Rifkin was lost. Mr. Rifkin says he plans to renew his protest this week, this time to Attorney General Janet Reno.
Six months after the tussle over Monsanto, Mr. Coelho lent a helping hand to a politician in need. This time the beneficiary was Mr. Espy's brother Henry, who had unsuccessfully run for the Secretary's old Congressional seat in Mississippi.
The campaign had left Henry Espy saddled with a $75,000 debt, and his campaign treasurer wrote to Federal election officials that "an enormous amount of individual pledges, against which checks were issued, were not honored subsequent to Mr. Henry Espy's defeat."
Into the breach stepped Mr. Coelho and Richard Douglas, senior vice president of Sun Diamond Growers. Mr. Coelho had many contacts with the company in his years representing a California agricultural district in Congress, and his investment bank now manages about $12 million of Sun Diamond's pension money.
Mr. Douglas, a lifelong friend of Secretary Espy, sent letters on Sun Diamond's stationery inviting prospective contributors to a dinner last March 31. At the dinner, Mr. Coelho says, he gave a 20-minute presentation that reminded the audience that Henry Espy was a "good investment" who would be heard from again in politics. Secretary Espy, Mr. Coelho says, did not attend.
After the dinner, Mr. Douglas wrote to those who had attended. He thanked them for their help with "a most difficult task" and noted that Mr. Coelho stood ready to call other prospective contributors. Mr. Coelho says no one ever asked him to make any such calls, however.
Mr. Coelho's own return to prominence was not a sure thing in 1989, when he resigned from the House over his purchase of $100,000 in junk bonds from Drexel Burnham Lambert, financed in part with a loan from a troubled California savings and loan association.
After two years of investigation, Mr. Coelho says, he received a letter from the Justice Department informing him that the case had been closed. The Justice Department confirms that it declined prosecution in the matter.
After leaving Congress, Mr. Coelho ruled out the choice of many other former lawmakers: Washington lobbying. Instead, he joined a Wertheim Schroder subsidiary, Wertheim Schroder Investment Services, which had fallen on hard times.
Wertheim Schroder Investment Services manages money for large investors, union-management pension funds, corporations and individuals. Its investment performance has dramatically improved since 1989, and Mr. Coelho's contacts and persuasiveness have helped increase the amount of money it manages to nearly $4 billion, from $700 million.
Steven Kotler, president of Wertheim Schroder & Company, says an investment banking company that performed similarly but without Mr. Coelho's contacts or skills as a manager would need 10 years to achieve that much growth.
Jack Marco, president of a Chicago-based company that is a consultant to 118 union-management pension plans, notes that many firms boast flashy performance numbers. But it is personality, he says, that opens doors.
"Certainly people love to be around a star," Mr. Marco said. "Our clients say it: 'That's somebody that's in the press. I know him. He comes to our meetings. I could call him up today.' "
Mr. Coelho, Mr. Marco said, can get his company's name on a pension fund's short list more easily than many. "But if he didn't have the numbers," Mr. Marco said, "he wouldn't get the money."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE STATE RESPONSE;
Florida Gets the Decisiveness It Sought

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 18

 BODY:
For days, Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida had pressed the Clinton Administration to do something decisive about the wave of Cuban refugees flowing to the state's southernmost shores. Tonight the Governor got his wish.
The announcement by United States Attorney General Janet Reno that the Government would begin detaining the arriving Cubans for an indefinite period was greeted warmly by Mr. Chiles, who said in an interview on CNN, "It's a day that I'm delighted is here." 
 Ms. Reno's announcement came at the end of a day in which Mr. Chiles, a Democrat who faces a tough race for re-election in November, stepped up the pressure on the Clinton Administration by declaring an immigration emergency in the state and asking the Administration to do the same.
Under the Governor's declaration, the state opened a command post in a telephone company building in downtown Key West to coordinate the efforts of Federal, state and local agencies. It deployed extra state law-enforcement officers to South Florida. And it also made plans to activate as many as 1,000 National Guard troops and, for the refugees' shelter, to use the Key West Naval Air Station as well as an outdoor area of the Monroe County jail on Stock Island, adjacent to Key West.
In addition, the state began looking for a temporary staging center to process and medically screen the stream of people -- more than 2,000 so far this month -- arriving from Cuba on boats and rafts.
 
Prodding Washington
 Those efforts by the state were envisioned only as support for a Federal operation. Mr. Chiles's declaration of an emergency was meant to prod the Government into a sense of crisis that would lead to the creation of Federal processing centers and to a naval blockade to deter more boats from coming.
"We're going to step out on our own and tell them to come join us," the Governor said of Federal officials in issuing his declaration today.
Later in the day the Administration, saying the migration was under control, declined to declare an emergency of its own, turning down Florida's request for millions of dollars in crisis aid.
But within hours the Administration had engaged in a striking about-face. Ms. Reno's announcement tonight said nothing about more money for Florida but made clear that the policy of indefinite detention would begin immediately.
 
Contrast to Mariel
 In issuing his declaration of emergency earlier in the day, Mr. Chiles said the state's efforts might be enough, for the next few days, to deal with the vast migration of Cubans even without Federal help.
Those efforts by the state were in stark contrast to its response to the Mariel boatlift of 1980, in which 125,200 Cuban refugees arrived over a period of five months and caught Florida unprepared. Back then, Dade County -- Miami and its environs -- was forced to set up a processing center in a park and turn the Orange Bowl into a tent city.
That earlier influx cost the state an estimated $150 million in unreimbursed expenses for increased social services, although some economists later said the refugees had given a boost to South Florida's economy by taking jobs as laborers, dishwashers and repairmen, mostly for Hispanic businesses.
"Back then we had nothing," Tony Ojeda, assistant Dade County manager, said of the migration from the Cuban port of Mariel 14 years ago. "I got a call in our offices one day saying there are Cubans coming in a bus. Now we have the experience of what happened, and the Governor has taken action to contain the process and assist local authorities."
 
Cursory Processing to End
 To this point, the new Cuban refugees have received only cursory Federal processing before being released into the country, in keeping with a three-decade-old open-door policy toward Cubans who flee the Havana Government.
Before Ms. Reno's announcement tonight, Joaquin G. Avino, the Dade County Manager, had asked her to open a special Federal center to process the new Cuban arrivals and to hold them until they find a relative or other sponsor able to support them financially for at least a year.
And Mr. Chiles's office, expressing certainty that events would ultimately force the Government to create such holding centers, said he would exercise his executive authority as Governor of the state to prevent any refugees from leaving the centers until they were screened for health problems and criminal records.
Immigration has long been a source of friction between Federal officials and Mr. Chiles, who was a United States Senator during the Mariel boatlift. At the time, he expressed dissatisfaction with what he regarded as President Jimmy Carter's late response to the crisis.
Now the Governor, who wants Washington to assume responsibility for immigrants to his state, has sued the Government to try to recover more than $800 million a year in costs associated with illegal immigration.
The arrival of refugees on South Florida's shores continued without respite today. As of 9 o'clock tonight, the Coast Guard said, the total for the day was 527, virtually equal to the 537 who arrived on Wednesday.
On the busiest day of the Mariel boatlift, aides to the Governor said, about 850 arrived. Still, as Mr. Chiles himself noted, the current flow "is not a trickle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As hundreds of Cuban refugees continued to pour into South Florida, several more, on the shores of the city of Cojimar, about 10 miles east of Havana, prepared to depart in a tiny boat yesterday. (Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE REFUGEES;
A Journey That Began 2 Years Ago

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 18

 BODY:
Dayely Gonzalez de la Olivia, is a skinny 12-year-old with long brown hair and a fashion sense so keen that when they distributed the new clothes at the refugee center here, she managed to find a pink and white shirt that perfectly matched the rosy gemstones in the earrings she wore on her trip across the Florida Straits.
Of everything she had owned in Cuba, those earrings were the only possessions she still had from her old life. She and her parents, 48-year-old Pedro Felix Gonzalez Pita and his wife, 34-year-old Maura de la Olivia, came with nothing but the clothes they wore. They had no money, no suitcases, not even family snapshots -- those were left behind with Dayely's grandparents. 
 They are among the hundreds of Cubans who have headed for Florida in boats and rafts in recent days, many built of foam, inner tubes or wood, and some powered by old automobile engines.
For this family, the craft was a 17-foot motorboat towing a five foot dinghy. Aboard were 15 men, women and children and a terrier named Sisi.
 
A Two-Year Journey
 For the Gonzalez family, the journey began two years ago as the Cuban economy crumbled without the support of Soviet subsidies. That's when Mr. Gonzalez bought the motorboat on the black market with American dollars. He said he got the money by selling an old Soviet-made Lada automobile, which he had fixed up after buying it with money he had made by selling gasoline at his Government job as a gas depot attendant.
They lived in an industrial neighborhood on the outskirts of Havana, and kept the boat with a friend 25 miles away in Mariel. For two years they waited for the right time to leave, which came two weeks ago when Cuban President Fidel Castro threatened to no longer block the departures of Cubans.
By last week, the new arrivals said, it was obvious that Mr. Castro's threat had come partly true, and that it had become clear to Cubans that if they left on their own boats -- and not on vessels stolen from the Government -- nobody would block their passage. "They didn't say it clearly, but everybody knows," Ms. de la Olivia said.
The group of 15, 7 of whom had traveled from Havana on three motorcycles with sidecars, assembled Monday evening in Mariel. They got in the boats and headed north. "The Cuban Coast Guard saw us from the land. They let us go," she said. "Before, they would throw you in jail."
On the way, all but 4 of the 15 got seasick, but other than that, it was a ride of relative comfort. They had good weather, calm seas and plenty of water, ham sandwiches and Pepsi. The soft drinks and meat had been bought on the black market.
On Wednesday, after nearly two days at sea, they were spotted by the crew of a Key West fishing boat, Black Beans. The fishermen called the Coast Guard, which took the Cubans to Key West where they were interviewed by agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and then turned over to the transit home for Cuban refugees near Key West.
Like many Cubans who have lived their entire lives under Fidel Castro's 35-year-old rule, Ms. de la Olivia said she just wanted something different for herself and her family." I was born in 1960. I was born with Fidel, and I want to have what I've never had before," she said. "We never celebrated Christmas in Cuba."
For Mr. Gonzalez, living in the United States will mean being able to do business without the threat of arrest, he said. He plans to use his skills as an auto mechanic to support his family in Miami, where they hope to settle down with an aunt.
And for Dayely, her hopes for the future are clear. She said she'll start with high school, where she said picking up English wouldn't be that hard, especially since she had taken a year of English in Cuban primary school and is well versed at a basic, "Hello, what is your name?" From there she wants to be a fashion model, and after that a lawyer. "I'd like to do it to defend people," she said. "People who deserve to be defended."
On Thursday afternoon, the Gonzalez family boarded an air-conditioned bus that would take them 150 miles up the Florida Keys to Miami. Clutching a bag given to her at the transit home that contained a doll, a stuffed animal and some new clothes, Dayely found a seat next to her father and smiled. "This is the most wonderful country," she said, and they headed for the mainland.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dayely Gonzalez de la Olivia hugs her mother, Maura, yesterday at the Cuban refugee center in Key West, Fla., as Ms. de la Olivia's husband sits beside them. The family left Cuba on Monday with 15 others and a dog. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 820 words

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THOSE who missed the F.D.I.C.'s clearance sale a few years back have few chances left to establish a hefty presence in Texas banking. Most of the merchandise is long gone.
By far the largest bank still based in Texas is Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc., its headquarters not Houston or Dallas but slower, sleepier San Antonio. In recent years, its sale has been forecast as often as hot weather in a San Antonio August. 
 The state's next-largest banks, about half its size, are in Laredo (population 128,433) and Victoria (population 56,987).
A gust of takeover talk about a year ago lifted Cullen/Frost stock from the low $30's to almost $40 a share. It has since slipped, but improving profits and reduced loan losses have restored it to $38 as of yesterday in Nasdaq trading.
Investors, analysts and other bankers still find that scrutinizing the Cullen/Frost loan portfolio or calculating financial ratios isn't nearly as much fun as playing matchmaker.
Executives of the much larger Bank One Texas, whose parent company is based in Columbus, Ohio, are frank about their affections. "Tom Frost knows we love him,' said Harvey Mitchell, the Bank One Texas chief executive, in an interview.
About the only one not playing matchmaker is Mr. Frost, Cullen/ Frost's lanky chief executive, whose great-grandfather founded the bank in 1868. None of his larger rivals can charm him enough to smooch.
"They're doing very well with the money I paid the F.D.I.C. to keep them in business," he said in an interview earlier this year. He was referring to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's bailouts allowing Banc One, Nationsbank and others to buy Texas institutions that failed.
When Mr. Frost mentions Texas Commerce Bank -- "Excuse me. I meant Chemical" -- he wants nobody to forget that it has a corporate parent (though in a deal without Federal aid) based in New York.
Mr. Frost, who is 66, has four sons working for his company. To further discourage a takeover, the elder Mr. Frost and other top executives have generous golden parachutes. In a change of control, he would get as much as $1.9 million.
A chief executive's denials about wanting to sell out are sometimes mere coyness, but the price of Cullen/ Frost's stock indicates that at least some investors believe him.
It trades at between 11 and 12 times the $3.30 in per-share earnings that analysts expect this year. That price probably includes a few points for the possibility of a takeover, but other Southwestern banks that seem more eager to be acquired trade at higher multiples.
Banks wanting to enter Texas or expand here have proved willing to pay up. About a year ago, Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis, which announced a plan yesterday to buy the Worthen Banking Corporation of Little Rock, Ark., successfully offered $28.16 a share for the First Amarillo Bancorporation when its stock was trading at $19. Analysts estimate Cullen/Frost would bring $50 a share, at the very least.
Texas -- now the second-largest state in population, its economy growing faster than the nation's -- has many attractions for outsiders, and even Mexicans are looking to buy in. But the state is already teeming with many of the country's sharpest, most competitive banks.
Whatever price his company might fetch, Mr. Frost contends that he can best serve shareholders by raising profits and remaining independent. Last year was his first since the 1980's without large charge-offs for bad loans.
William I. Baldwin, an analyst at Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, says that a reorganization and some cutbacks last year lowered expenses, but they remain high. Mr. Frost agrees, noting the need to move out of some offices that he describes as "big, high shrines."
Next, his company needs to expand its lending. The same conservatism that barely pulled it through the Texas banking depression has kept loans to 36 percent of its $3.7 billion in assets, about 10 percentage points below the Texas average.
Cullen/Frost investors or acquirers now have the added incentive of a Mexico play. The company has correspondent relationships, involving business referrals across the border, with 14 Mexican banks. Many of those ties were developed by Mr. Frost himself.
In the bank's latest annual report, a map labeled "Cullen/Frost Markets" includes everything from the Texas panhandle down to the jungles of Chiapas, Mexico. Mr. Frost boasts of listening to Spanish talk radio to keep up with his customers in San Antonio, the nation's largest city with a Hispanic majority.
He spends less time listening to analysts and writers who have long said that medium-sized banks, like his, are being squeezed out by small niche players and large efficiency experts. Just recently, he said, a trade publication warned in-betweeners to find bigger partners to survive. "I can't find the article now," he said yesterday. "It's somewhere in my garbage pail.'

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sony's Operating Profits Up, But Net Plunges in Quarter

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation reported today that operating profits for the first quarter rose 25.7 percent from a year earlier. Net income, however, plunged 49.2 percent, in large measure because the company did not make as much money as it did last year from currency hedging.
Sony said revenues for the quarter, which ended on June 30, increased 4.3 percent, to 864.5 billion yen, or $8.73 billion when translated at 99 yen to the dollar. Operating income was 31.8 billion yen, or $321.2 million. Net income dropped to 3.9 billion yen, or $39.5 million. 
 Sony, which is based here, said earnings were hurt by the continued sluggishness of the economy in Japan and by the gains in the yen against the dollar and other foreign currencies. Had the yen remained at the same level as a year ago, sales would have increased by 9.5 percent instead of 4.3 percent, the company said.
Sony's movie business, which was mired in losses last year, also dragged down profits. Operating income was not reported separately for the movie business, Columbia and Tristar Pictures, but sales decreased 4.3 percent, to 64.3 billion yen, or $649.2 million.
But Sony said operating profits benefited from cost cutting and from strong business in Asia and the United States and with an improvement in the economy in Europe.
Sony's worldwide sales of compact disk players, Walkman portable stereos and color televisions were up, though sales of video recorders remained flat.
Sony's music business, based on the former CBS Records, turned in a strong performance because of hit albums like Mariah Carey's "Music Box." Sales of the music group rose 12 percent, to 108.1 billion yen, or $1.1 billion.
In the first quarter a year ago, Sony's net income was bolstered by a 20.4 billion yen gain in foreign exchange because of currency hedging contracts. In the most recent quarter, the yen did not fluctuate as much and foreign exchange gains were only 7.5 billion yen. That accounted for the drop in net income despite the improvement in operating income, Sony said.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. Halts Hundreds of Cubans At Sea in Abrupt Policy Change

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The United States today plucked hundreds of Cuban refugees from rafts and boats off the Florida coast and began to transfer them to detention camps in Guantanamo Bay as President Clinton ordered an end to the longstanding policy of welcoming fleeing Cubans with open arms.
With more Cubans taking to the seas than at any time since 1980, the abrupt change of American policy was aimed at averting a new Caribbean exodus, much as the Administration has sought to discourage Haitians from leaving their country by denying them entry to the United States. 
 Instead of being ferried on to Florida, all fleeing Cubans now intercepted by the Coast Guard and the United States Navy are to be delivered to new camps at the American base in Guantanamo, near Cuba's southeast tip, where they will join some 15,000 Haitians already being held there.
By 8:30 P.M., Coast Guard cutters patrolling the Straits of Florida had picked up 454 Cuban refugees from 40 boats, a flow that maintained an alarming stream that began early this month. They could be transferred as early as Saturday to another vessel to begin the 42-hour journey to the military base that will at least temporarily be their new home.
The action drew strong criticism among Cuban-Americans, many of whom said it was wrong to punish Cubans for seeking refuge from Fidel Castro. Because Mr. Clinton offered no immediate new plan to encourage the ouster of the Cuban leader, Republican leaders and some Democrats in Congress also found fault with it, saying that it ignored the main reason that so many Cubans sought to flee the island. [Page 11.]
In an attempt in part to answer some of the criticisms, Mr. Clinton met at the White House tonight with a half-dozen Cuban-American leaders, including Jorge Mas Canosa, the head of the Cuban American National Foundation. The President also approved a statement announcing new steps aimed at putting pressure on the Castro Government, including seeking United Nations condemnation of human rights abuses in Cuba, an expanded United States ban on commercial air traffic to Cuba to include charter flights, and cutting in half, to $150 per quarter, the amount of money an American household may send to Cuban citizens.
Administration officials also said specially equipped American EC-130 military aircraft would soon begin flights near Cuba to broadcast messages urging Cubans to avoid taking to the seas.
The President's new instructions mark an end to 28 years in which the United States has allowed Cuban refugees who made their way here or who were rescued offshore to stay. Under the new policy, even Cubans who do somehow land in the United States are to be held until their applications to stay in the country can be reviewed, and some of those who have arrived in recent days were detained today.
Mr. Clinton, who announced the plan at a news conference, said the change was necessary to prevent "a cold blooded attempt" by Mr. Castro to export an internal crisis by flooding south Florida with refugees. He said a failure by the United States to shut its doors would risk repetition of the Mariel boat lift of 1980 in which 120,000 Cubans made their way to American shores.
"We tried it that way once," Mr. Clinton said of the previous open door. "It was wrong then, it's wrong now, and I'm not going to let it happen again."
The President's announcement, which came after 24 hours of awkward scrambling and mixed signals within the Administrationwas greeted with relief by Governor Lawton Chiles of Florida, who also attended tonight's White House meeting, and others in the state who had urged that Washington act quickly to head off the potential crisis.
For now, the change means that fleeing Cubans will be treated the same as fleeing Haitians since Mr. Clinton decided in May to stop returning them to that troubled country, holding them instead in tent camps in Guantanamo while seeking havens for them outside American territory.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said tonight that many questions about the new policy remained unsettled. But they said the Administration hoped to transfer quickly any Cubans sent to Guantanamo elsewhere, perhaps Panama or the Turks and Caicos Islands, a British colony in the Bahamas, which had offered refuge to Haitians.
It was clear, however, that what the Administration sought most in its new policy was to alter the equation in which, during the last week alone, the all but certain promise of refuge in the United States tempted more than 2,000 Cubans to hazard the treacherous crossing.
Today, the President dispatched at least two American warships to the Straits of Florida to assist the Coast Guard in patrolling the waters that divide the two countries. To those Cubans who might still consider attempting the passage, Attorney General Janet Reno warned: "The odds of ending up in Guantanamo are going to be very, very great. The odds of ending up in the United States are going to be very, very small."
 
New Housing for Cubans
 Already some 14,700 Haitians are camped in Guantanamo, where a combination of boredom and poor conditions has twice in the last week ignited disturbances in which American military policemen were injured.
Cubans brought to the base in the next few days will be housed in a section of one existing camp, where cots and tents for 2,000 are erected and vacant. A senior Defense Department official said today, however, that the military would build two new camps, with a total capacity of 10,000, for Cubans brought there in the future.
Only Thursday morning, Attorney General Janet Reno had said that the Administration was not considering any change in the Cuban policy that since 1966 has welcomed virtually all fleeing Cubans to the United States.
But by late Thursday, it was Ms. Reno, at an odd late-night appearance in a partly-lit White House briefing room, who revealed that the Administration had settled on a shift in policy.
 
A Day of Wrangling
 Today, officials at the White House and other agencies said that announcement had come only after a contentious and somewhat chaotic day of wrangling about what the Administration should do to answer Governor Chiles' pleas for help.
Mr. Clinton himself had endorsed the new policy by early evening after reviewing options drafted by Anthony Lake, his national security adviser, that were presented in a day of top-level meetings. While news reports had cast the Administration as turning a cold shoulder to Governor Chiles, the President and Mr. Lake agreed that the decision would be kept secret until today's news conference.
But Ms. Reno, a former Dade County prosecutor, appealed throughout the evening to Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, that she disclose the change quickly to quell concern in her native Florida and dissuade Cubans who might attempt to flee overnight.
Finally, at 10:40 P.M., Ms. Reno read a halting statement to a half-dozen reporters and cameramen at the White House, after aides made a series of frantic telephone calls to news organizations.
The Attorney General said only that Cuban refugees would from now on be detained, but she left without providing further details. Senior officials described frustration within the Administration over the handling of such a major policy announcement.
 
Pentagon Scrambles
 There was also apprehension at the Pentagon about its new tasks of assisting the Coast Guard by transporting Cuban refugees to the Guantanamo base and running what will now amount to separate detention camps for Cubans and Haitians there.
A Navy amphibious ship, the Whidbey Island, was picking up tents from what was to have been a Haitian refugee processing center in the Turks and Caicos today to bring them to Guantanamo for use by the Cubans, and is to take up station in the Straits of Florida by Tuesday, a senior Pentagon official said. In the meantime, one of the 10 Coast Guard cutters or patrol boats in the region is likely to be used to shuttle the refugees to the military base.
A second Navy amphibious ship, the Nashville, may also be used in the operation. But the Nashville is one of two ships now off Haiti as part of a mission to stand by in case of trouble there, and the Pentagon was scrambling tonight to send another amphibious ship to the Straits of Florida to avoid disruption to the Haiti operation.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A United States Coast Guard raft picking up five Cuban refugees yesterday from a small boat being towed by a larger one, shown at right. The Coast Guard then returned to pick up passengers on the bigger boat. (Phillippe Diedrich for The New York Times) (pg. 1); President Clinton yesterday before announcing the end of the longstanding government practice of accepting Cubans fleeing the Castro regime. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. 10)
 
Chart: "A Closer Look: U.S. Policy Toward Cuban Refugees"
Refugees from Cuba have long had a special status under United States law. Until today nearly all those seeking to enter the United States automatically admitted. Their special status was granted under the Cuban Refugee Adjustment Act of 1966, one of several measures that marked the decades of tension between Fidel Castro and the United States. The act gives the President the latitude to determine the conditions under which Cuban refugees can remain. Following is a summary of the provisions of that act and others.
 
The Cuban Refugee Adjustment Act of 1966
This law allowed refugees from Cuba who were picked up by American authorities while attempting to flee or who entered the United States after January 1, 1959 (the beginning of Mr. Castro's regime), to apply for permanent resident alien status after a one-year stay in the United States. Permanent resident status is necessary before an alien can apply for citizenship. Prior immigration law had required nationals of Western Hemisphere countries to obtain an immigrant visa at the U.S. Consular office in their native country. The U.S. Consular Office in Cuba closed Jan. 3, 1961.
 
Trade Embargo With Cuba
 The regulations spelling out the embargo were issued by the United States Government on July 8, 1963 under the Trading With the Enemy Act:
* With some exceptions, no U.S. products, technology or services may be exported to Cuba, either directly or through third countries.
 
 * Cuban goods and services may not be imported into the U.S.
 
Cuban Democracy Act of 1992
 The purpose of this act was to tighten the economic embargo while holding out the possibility of assisting Cubans. It provides the following:

 * Tightened prohibitions regarding the licensing of trade with Cuba by foreign subsidiaries of American firms.
 
 * Authorizes direct mail delivery via the United States Postal Service between Cuba and the United States; improves telephone communications. (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN MIAMI;
Cuban-Americans Ambivalent on Shift

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Cuban-Americans today appeared to be of two minds on changing American policy on Cuban refugees.
Many railed against closing the door on 28 years of special status for Cubans fleeing Fidel Castro that enabled any who reached these shores to remain here. 
 President Clinton said today that all refugees picked up at sea will be now be sent to safe havens at Guatanamo Naval Base in Cuba and elsewhere. Those who manage to get past Coast Guard and Navy ships and land in Florida will be taken to mainland detention camps.
Though the policy change was drawing heavy criticism, it appeared at the same time that many Cuban-Americans did not welcome a repeat of the Mariel boatlift, which brought 125,000 refugees to Florida in several months in 1980. Many said that the escape of too many disgruntled refugees from Cuba would help Mr. Castro stay in power by easing tensions within Cuban society..
Since the 1960's, most Cuban refugees have been allowed to remain in the United States, no matter how they got here, with little formal processing. After the Mariel boatlift, however, the Government detained thousands who had criminal backgrounds in Cuba or who had mental problems. It tried to deport many hundreds who committed crimes while here.
 
'A Reverse Mariel'
 "Cuban-Americans don't want another Mariel," said Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, Republican of Miami. "Cuban-Americans want a reverse Mariel to go and ignite the spark of liberation in Cuba."
In Miami's politically charged atmosphere, few Cuban-Americans seemed to concede that the change in United States policy might help domestic pressures build for Mr. Castro by shutting off the route to America for the island's most frustrated citizens.
Spanish talk radio shows blazed against the policy change and the word on the lips of hosts and callers was "betrayal."
Mario Cabriera, who came here from Cuba a quarter-century ago, said that he backed the Clinton plan and that he thought that disgruntled Cubans should stay home and topple the Castro regime.
 
Called Castro Supporters
 Mr. Cabriera, 69 years old, a portrait photagrapher, expressed a view of the new wave of refugees that is heard often in private conversation but muted in public. "These same people are the ones who until quite recently were Castro supporters and forced us to leave our homeland."
He and others also said that they feared this generation of Cuban refugees, who have lived all their lives under Communism, would encounter great difficulty in adjusting to American life.
Another issue is that many of the new refugees are dark-skinned. How they will be received in Miami among light-skinned refugees of a generation ago is an open question. Many of those in the Mariel boatlift were also dark-skinned and it took years before they were assimilated into jobs.
 
Admiration and Sympathy
 Most of those interviewed today on the streets of the Little Havana section of Miami expressed admiration and sympathy for the men, women and children who put to sea in small boats and rubber rafts to find a better life in this country, and said that their bravery should be rewarded.
"It's not fair after the policy being one way all this time and all of a sudden changing," stormed Lazaro Cardentey, 36. The Government, said Mr. Cardentey, a refugee who landed here seven months ago from Cuba, "should recognize the courage of those risking their lives to get here."
Several of those interviewed said they resented comparisons with Haitian refugees who routinely are turned back by American ships or sent into detention camps at Guatanamo or in this country. Cubans were trying to escape Communism, not wretched economic conditions alone, and that status should be honored, not abandoned, they said.
"I think Clinton is trying to make sure there is no conflict in the community between Haitians and Cubans," said Janet Dagnesses, 24. "But until he decides what to do with Cuba and Castro there is no point in keeping the refugees from their families if they are here already."
In Key West, emotions were running high as the policy change went into effect, trapping a few hundred new arrivals in the detention net as others were the last to slip through it.
 
Under the Wire
 "We started detainment enforcement shortly before the Attorney General made the announcement," said Lemar Wooley, an Immigration and Naturalization spokesman explained. "Anyone who was on a ship or had not been processed was subject to detention."
One of the last to get in under the wire and walk free on American ground was Miriam Delgado, 30, who was rescued Thursday by the Coast Guard after spending four days adrift in a raft.
She said that she was sad for those coming behind her who would be taken to an uncertain future at Guatanamo. "It's horrible there," said Ms. Delgado, who had worked as a Government accountant in Mariel. "It's worse than being in prison in Cuba."
 
Sought Freedom in 1991
 Another who walked the streets of Key West today, unhappy about the newly erected barrier, was a man who made his dash to freedom in 1991 and became a hero in Miami. Orestes Lorenzo was the Cuban Air Force pilot who defected in a MIG fighter and returned in a Cessna to Cuba the next year to pick up his wife and children on a coastal highway and fly them to the United States.
He has been flying that same propeller plane over the Florida Straits this past week, directing rescue boats to the dots of rafts bobbing along in their high-risk escape away from their island home.

They were among the last refugees to be granted political asylum before the new policy on Cuban refugees took effect. (Cindy Karp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Effort to Solve Energy Woes Clashes With Nuclear Safety

SERIES: After the Arms Race: Third of three articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
If the collapse of nuclear controls in Russia poses the near-term threat that terrorists could seize plutonium to make nuclear weapons, longer-term fears arise from nuclear energy programs launched by America's closest allies: Japan, Britain and France.
Over the next two decades these countries, as well as Russia, plan to vastly increase the world's stockpiles of plutonium. They are producing it to fuel a generation of nuclear power plants whose time has never quite come. 
 And in the process they are deflating the post-cold-war optimism that the world's supply of bomb-usable materials would drastically shrink. Moreover, the race to produce plutonium for energy is also sustaining a rationale that nuclear aspirants like North Korea have used to justify building nuclear energy installations that can quickly be turned to weapons production.
The plutonium can be used to fuel existing reactors, in place of uranium, but also for planned breeder reactors, nuclear plants that were first conceived with enormous enthusiasm, as a virtually self-sustaining source of electric power. These reactors burn nuclear fuel while "breeding" more, and for decades seemed to offer a solution to two major problems at once.
By recycling fuel, breeders would cut down on the amount of nuclear waste that would otherwise have to be buried or sunk in the ocean. And at first blush, the technology promised billions of dollars in savings.
But the long-promised economies have evaporated, and the spread of weapons projects in the last several years -- in North Korea, Iraq, Pakistan and elsewhere -- has only underscored the inherent dangers of a world energy system based on recycled plutonium. Nuclear weapon science is everywhere, it is now clear, and the greatest obstacle to bomb production is not know-how, but access to plutonium or highly enriched uranium -- materials which, under the energy strategies being pursued by several countries, will remain in plentiful supply.
The new supplies of separated plutonium are the result of "reprocessing" -- extraction of plutonium and uranium from the spent fuel of conventional nuclear power plants. Because the extraction of plutonium is rapidly outpacing the building of the breeder reactors it was intended to fuel, a surplus of plutonium is building.
The International Atomic Energy Agency estimates there are now over 100 tons of separated civilian plutonium stockpiled around the world. Most of it is stored in Britain, France and Russia. Japan plans to obtain 50 tons more over the next 15 years, mainly produced in European plants, and within seven years it plans to open up a huge new reprocessing plant of its own. If diverted to weapons use, those supplies could produce thousands of nuclear weapons.
While officials in several countries concede that the breeder-reactor strategy is wildly uneconomical today, they say that the world will thank them one day when uranium -- the fuel for ordinary reactors -- becomes scarce and expensive.
"We take the long-term view, not the short-term," said Yasutaka Moriguchi, the director of the nuclear fuel division of Japan's Science and Technology Agency. "We are looking out 40 years ahead."
Similar views are voiced in France, Britain and Russia. But critics charge that officials in Japan and elsewhere are simply justifying expensive programs that have already created large vested interests.
 
Asian Worries About Japan
 The rise of a "plutonium economy" has created several new threats. Britain and France are nuclear powers already, but Japan's repeated insistence that it would never use its stockpile to make nuclear weapons have left its Asian neighbors unconvinced. Many point out that Japan does not actually need to build a weapon to gain strategic leverage: Its plutonium supplies, combined with the country's obvious technological prowess, create a de facto nuclear capability, without the political complications of actually possessing a weapon.
But the main fear is that a huge commerce in plutonium would be a ripe target for theft by terrorists or countries secretly desiring to build nuclear weapons.
Moreover, the spread of reprocessing technology creates a justification for countries that want to make nuclear weapons to follow suit, under the guise of conducting energy research or developing energy sources.
 
North Korean Program
 North Korea is a vivid example: Rather than obtain bomb materials from Russia or China, it produced its own from spent nuclear fuel as part of what it calls a national electrification project. And in response to the West's demands that it permanently cease reprocessing activities, Pyongyang has consistently offered a straightforward response: Japan is allowed to do it, so why not us?
China is talking about building a breeder reactor. South Korea's military leaders endorsed the idea last year, presumably in response to the North's project. There is talk of it in Taiwan, a country that was forced to abandon a nuclear weapons program of its own several years ago.
"Would you be comfortable in a world in which every country that wanted a reprocessor could have one?" asked Christopher Paine of the Natural Resources Defense Council, an American environmental group.
Officials from the International Atomic Energy Agency readily concede that the spread of reprocessing technology is creating more nuclear material than they can reliably track. Japan's project alone, still in its infancy, takes up roughly 20 percent of the agency's inspection resources.
And even if inspections are accurate, the North Korean crisis has given the world a glimpse of the "breakout" problem: Any signatory to the treaty against the spread of nuclear arms can build a reprocessing center, get technological assistance from the nuclear agency, and then declare that in three months it is withdrawing from the treaty. At that point, it is legally free to use the installations for bomb production.
"It is a huge hole in the treaty," said Andrew Mack, a professor at Australia National University who has written extensively on the subject. "And as the North Koreans showed us, just the threat of pulling out brings everyone to their knees."
As a result, the multibillion dollar plutonium trade between Europe and Japan has cast the United States in an enormously uncomfortable position. The United States stopped reprocessing nuclear materials for civilian use 17 years ago, during the Carter Administration, for fear that it would speed the spread of plutonium.
 
Exception for U.S. Allies
 Last year the Clinton Administration announced a global goal of phasing out the production of all new fissile materials that could produce weapons. But Washington has gingerly danced around the question of how to persuade the allies to back away from plutonium production for civilian reactors, carving an exception for them rather than risk a confrontation with its closest global partners.
Legally, the United States could prohibit the transport or reprocessing of nuclear material that originated in the United States, a category that includes almost all of Japan's supplies. But the political pressure not to do so has been intense.
"We encouraged them to get into this in the midst of the Cold War," a senior intelligence official said recently, "and now we can't turn off the spigot."
What has slowed the process is economics. While the Europeans are producing plutonium, they have canceled many of their breeder reactor plans. And Japan, the biggest customer for reprocessed plutonium, has been forced to scale back its ambitious program, for reasons of both politics and economics.
But earlier this year Britain started operations at a huge reprocessing installation in which it and Japan had invested billions. The Japanese are building another on the northern coast of the island of Honshu. At this point, many nuclear power executives concede, so much has been invested that there is no easy way out.
 
The Threat
Can Nuclear Fuel Produce a Bomb?
 At the core of the allies' justification for their elaborate plans is a traditional argument that there are two types of plutonium: "Reactor-grade" plutonium suitable for nuclear power generation, and "weapons-grade" for making bombs. In weapons-grade plutonium, 93 percent or more of the material is in the form of the Pu-239 isotope. Reactor-grade plutonium has a lesser concentration of Pu-239.
Japan has always insisted that because it deals only in the first type, and never in the second, any suspicions that it could decide to make nuclear weapons, or that terrorists could seize its supplies, are unfounded and alarmist.
In June, after former Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata took Japan's bureaucracy by surprise when he said that "Japan has the capability to possess nuclear weapons, but it has not made them," those arguments were rolled out again.
The Government repeated its commitment never to make or possess nuclear weapons and insisted that it "does not have any expertise or experience" in building bombs and therefore "does not have the capability to produce them."
While many experts doubt these protestations of insufficient expertise, certainly there is no public will in Japan today for the country to acquire nuclear arms.
"It is impossible, it is just simply impossible," Ryo Ikegame, the executive vice president of Tokyo Electric Power, Japan's largest utility company, said in April at an industry conference held quite deliberately in Hiroshima, in an effort to turn plutonium into a symbol for the peaceful use of energy. "No one has produced weapons from reactor fuel," he said.
 
U.S. Test in 1962
 In fact, information declassified in recent years by the Department of Energy and statements by a number of American weapons designers suggest that Japan's official argument is wrong. In 1962, American weapons laboratories built and tested at least one bomb built from reactor-grade fuel. American officials say that while perhaps four kilograms of bomb-grade plutonium are needed to make a bomb, only slightly more reactor-grade plutonium is needed.
For terrorists or countries desiring only a few weapons, "the theft of weapon-grade material or of actual weapons is likely to be the preferred path," Richard L. Garwin, a senior researcher at I.B.M., wrote recently. "But reactor grade material is also a feasible approach to the manufacture of nuclear weapons."
But, as Mr. Garwin concluded recently, "The Japanese don't want to hear this."
 
The Origins
Troubled Progress For an Industry
 Though the Japanese are the most vociferous advocates of breeder reactor technology these days, their program was not born in Tokyo. It was Washington's idea.
As soon as the American occupation ended in the early 1950's, Japan became ripe ground for the "Atoms for Peace" project. With no oil reserves of its own, even a country with a profound nuclear allergy felt it had little other choice. And in 1966, just as conventional, uranium-burning nuclear power plants were springing up along the sea coast, the Government formally declared that it would start a major project to create self-sufficient breeder reactors.
But by the 1970's, amid worries about the spread of nuclear technology and clear evidence that breeder reactors would be much more costly than conventional reactors, America's program went into decline. Congress dropped the last financing for a breeder reactor in 1983.
But by that time Tokyo had assembled a classic industrial consortium: A Government-backed firm, called the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation, was created to coordinate reprocessing and to develop the use of plutonium as a fuel.
This spring, after decades of planning, Japan finally fired up the $5 billion "Monju" breeder reactor, named for the Buddhist god of wisdom. But by the time it opened the wisdom was under fire: Uranium prices have been so low for so long that the reactor will be an incredibly expensive source of power, in a country that already produces the world's most expensive electricity.
 
New Plant Is Begun
 Ground has been broken for a $7 billion reprocessing plant that would take nuclear waste from around the country and turn it into plutonium for re-burning. That plant, in turn, is generating pressure to build more breeder reactors, to make the whole enterprise more viable.
Japan has also invested more than $3 billion in reprocessing installations in Sellafield, England, and La Hague, France that are already operating. For several years Japan has been exporting almost all of its nuclear waste, though so far only one shipment of plutonium fuel derived from it has come back.
In short order, Japan has become a vital customer for the Europeans. Originally, the European reprocessing installations were supposed to produce fuel for European breeder reactors and conventional reactors using mixed-oxide fuel that combines uranium and plutonium. But gradually, that vision has crumbled.
After long dispute, the Germans, who began breeder work in 1956, canceled their plans after a series of technical problems. The British, after experimenting with small reactors, decided in 1988 to end their major projects, and they are unwilling to invest heavily in plans for a European breeder for fear there would be no commercial customers.
The French have been more enthusiastic. But their troubled plant called Superphenix was 2.5 times more expensive than a conventional reactor, and it was forced to shut down in 1990 because of leaks in its sodium cooling system, only recently limping backinto service.
Searching for another role for its breeders, France is studying how such reactors could consume plutonium rather than breed it, and how they could also convert long-lived, toxic radioactive isotopes in nuclear waste into material that would be radioactive for a shorter time.
Though the customers are fewer and fewer, reprocessing is continuing at a rapid pace. After years of legal delays, Britain just opened its giant Thorp reprocessing center. France's competing reprocessing center at Le Hague now takes in 130 to 140 tons of nuclear waste a month, and produces 11 tons of plutonium from it annually. But much of the waste and the plutonium sit in storage, awaiting a use. "Plutonium is a high value energy source," said Jean Louis Ricaud, the vice president of Cogema. "And its cost will come down."
 
Transportation
Plutonium Ship Sets Off an Uproar
 As the Japanese learned late in 1992 and early last year, just moving that plutonium around the world is fraught with both technical and political dangers. Its first shipment of plutonium from La Hague touched off an international uproar, made greater by environmental groups that warned countries that a shipload of some of the world's most toxic material was about to pass through their waters. South Africa, Brazil, Argentina, the Philippines and a number of small South Pacific nations banned the ship from their waters.
The outcry forced Japan to think about scaling back its plans, and no one in Tokyo dares suggest a second shipment in the near future. But big industrial projects are never abandoned in Japan, and far too much had been invested in this one. So a series of committees were created last year in Tokyo with a foreordained conclusion: To find a way to drastically slow the plutonium program without giving up the goal of a self-sustaining fuel system.
The committee never dealt with a more radical alternative proposed by Paul Leventhal, the head of the private Nuclear Control Institute in Washington. He suggests that Japan stockpile many years' supply of relatively inexpensive uranium as a way to assure a stable energy supply.
 
Japan Slows Schedule
 In June, the Japanese Government began to greatly slow its schedule. The next breeder reactor will not start operation until around 2010, if then. A second reprocessing plant, once described as a vital necessity, will not even be considered until 2030. And Japan will attempt to burn excess supplies of plutonium as mixed-oxide fuel in existing power plants, even though that flies in the face of creating a self-sustaining fuel cycle.
But as Mr. Mack wrote recently, mixing plutonium with uranium "makes no economic sense." It is far more expensive than burning the standard enriched uranium. But the alternative is that Japan will be left with upwards of 50 tons of plutonium by 2010 -- and to quell fears it might be tempted to build a bomb, it has promised that it will never stockpile more plutonium than it can use.
Japan's answer, and Europe's, has been to mount a major public relations drive to dispel the thought that plutonium is as dangerous as it sounds. Earlier this year the Japanese nuclear industry distributed an animated film to schoolchildren in which a fictional young boy drank plutonium-tainted water, with no ill effect. The letter drew an immediate protest from Hazel O'Leary, the United States Secretary of Energy, asking that the film be withdrawn.
Japanese officials, clearly embarrassed, said the film showed poor judgment, but they refused to ban it. Utility company officials also declined several public challenges to drink a similar potion themselves.
 
Regulation
Nuclear Agency Faces Challenge
 The spread of reprocessing is already creating a huge strain on the International Atomic Energy Agency. It is already strapped for funds and inspectors.
But while American policy is opposed to commercial plutonium production, the agency officially favors it, because one of its chief missions is to help promote new forms of nuclear energy. "Even the much maligned breeder reactors may one day be warmly welcomed," Hans Blix, the agency's director general, said recently, though he added that "the economic case for breeders is not present today."
Mr. Blix acknowledges, however, that his agency could be overwhelmed by the task of keeping track of so much plutonium. Japan already uses so much plutonium that several agency inspectors are permanently stationed there. Even so, upwards of 150 pounds of plutonium was recently determined to be unaccounted for, because it was stuck in the pipes of Japan's fuel fabrication plant. Japan said it would all be accounted for; critics said it showed how easy it would be for any country to make off with several bombs' worth of material under the cover of ordinary "shrinkage" in processing.
So far, there is no international mechanism to protect plutonium when it is being transported, the moment when it is presumably most vulnerable to hijacking. And as the agency learned in Iraq and North Korea, even extensive inspections cannot detect the full scope of plutonium production.
"If the use of plutonium increases, naturally we will need a far bigger mechanism for keeping track of it all," Mr. Blix said several months ago. "Right now, we do not have anything of that scale ready."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN CUBA;
On Beach Near Havana, Many Still Try to Flee

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Dozens of Cubans were still setting off by raft from a beach east of Havana today, even as President Clinton ordered that Cubans picked up at sea by the Coast Guard not be allowed to enter the United States.
Foreign reporters saw six rafts, made from inner tubes and wood, set off in the space of about 40 minutes from Cojimar beach, 10 miles east of the capital. People among the small crowds milling around on one section of the beach said many more rafts had left during the morning. Each raft carries about four to six people. 
 Cojimar has been a key spot in recent days for the increased flow of Cubans leaving the Communist-ruled Caribbean island by raft.
In its morning news program today, Cuba's state-run radio reported the announcement late Thursday by the United States Attorney General, Janet Reno, that Cubans arriving in the United States without visas would from now on be detained.
 
Exodus Into Flordia
 But Granma, the Communist Party newspaper, reported that Ms. Reno had said Washington was not currently contemplating a policy change on immigration. The article, noting that Florida had seen unprecedented numbers of Cubans arriving this week, said the United States was paying the price for a "hostile" immigration policy.
On the beach at Cojimar, few people were aware of the American shift. But when told about Ms. Reno's comments, several people said it would still be worth going off on a raft even if they risked detention.
"Nothing's going to stop people from going," commented one man, who said he was there to watch the spectacle of so many people leaving.
There was no official reaction yet in Havana to the Clinton Administration announcement, which amounted to a major change of the United States' 30-year-old policy of accepting all Cuban refugees.
 
Complaints by Cuba
 Under the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, Cubans who left the island without papers -- generally in rafts or flimsy boats -- were automatically allowed to stay in the United States. Havana has long complained that this stimulated illegal exits, since Washington at the same time restricted the number of visas it granted.
The number of people leaving Cuba, which is facing a severe economic crisis, has shot up in the last few days to the highest levels since the Mariel boatlift of 1980, when 125,000 left in an exodus that flooded Florida's social services.
The rise appears to be a result of the Cuban authorities' turning a blind eye to people trying to leave, so long as they set off in their own vessels. President Fidel Castro, reacting to a spate of hijackings of state-owned vessels, warned two weeks ago that Cuba would no longer put obstacles in the way of Cubans trying to leave the island by boat, or of their relatives in Florida coming to pick them up, if Washington did not change its immigration policy.
Almost 3,500 people have been picked by the United States Coast Guard so far in August, prompting Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida to declare a state of emergency on Thursday.

LENGTH: 928 words

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, appears to have been more reluctant than some of his colleagues to raise interest rates earlier this summer, judging from the notes of a meeting in July of top Fed officials.
The central bank's top interest-rate policy panel voted at its July meeting to allow Mr. Greenspan to raise interest rates at his discretion during the following weeks rather than wait for the next meeting of the group, according to minutes of the meeting released today. 
 But Mr. Greenspan did not exercise this discretion, and the Federal Reserve did not raise rates until its top policy makers met on Tuesday. Then Mr. Greenspan joined the other six members of the Federal Reserve Board in a unanimous vote for an increase of half a percentage point in the discount rate, which the central bank charges banks for overnight loans.
Also that day, the larger policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, made up of the Fed members and five presidents of the Fed's regional banks, voted a half-point increase in the target for the Federal funds rate. That is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans.
The vote on the Federal funds rate has not been disclosed, but presumably Mr. Greenspan would not have supported a discount rate increase while opposing a rise in the Federal funds rate.
The latest jump in short-term interest rates, along with the four that have preceded it this year, won a cautious endorsement today from President Clinton. At a news conference he gave credit for the current economic expansion to his Administration's policies and said: "So I think that we have to recognize that the Fed did respond to the efforts we made, and what it's responding to now is a robust and growing economy. Of course it could be slowed down too much, but we don't have any evidence at this time that that has, in fact, occurred."
During late July and early August, Mr. Greenspan was perceived within the Federal Reserve, according to some officials, as more skeptical than his colleagues about whether higher rates were needed to slow the economy's strong growth. Consumer spending had slowed some and a large buildup in inventories developed during the second quarter, signaling a possible slowdown that might make a rate increase unnecessary.
But some evidence has emerged in the last few days that spending remains strong, notably a Commerce Department report on Tuesday that housing starts had jumped 4.7 percent in July.
While Mr. Greenspan can act on his own to raise rates, and did so as recently as April 18, the committee's vote on July 6 to give him that discretion seemed a vote of confidence amid reports suggesting he had lost some influence with the group.
Earlier this year, the panel had repeatedly raised interest rates at regularly scheduled meetings, without explicitly giving Mr. Greenspan the discretion to do so on his own in the periods between meetings. Some analysts interpreted this as a signal that the Fed's other top policy makers, without a discussion or a vote, had taken from Mr. Greenspan much of his authority.
Federal Reserve officials vehemently denied this at the time, saying that Mr. Greenspan had not lost any of his influence.
 
Playing Down Dissent

 
 J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, has been the most frequent dissenter pressing for faster interest rate increases, according to today's minutes and the minutes of previous meetings. But in an interview in the spring, he strongly stated his view that disagreements over policy should not be interpreted as a lack of confidence in Mr. Greenspan, pointing out that dissents also occurred under previous Fed chairmen like Arthur F. Burns, G. William Miller and Paul A. Volcker.
"I've been watching these meetings since 1973," said Mr. Broaddus, who attended the gatherings as a senior Fed economist before he became president of the Richmond Fed last year. "I don't see anything different now -- there were sharp disagreements under Burns, there were sharp disagreements under Miller and there were sharp disagreements under Volcker."
Federal Reserve officials are prohibited from giving interviews a week before and after each panel meeting and were not available for comment today.
The Open Market Committee raised the Federal funds rate by a fourth of a percentage point at its meetings on Feb. 4 and March 22, and by half a point at its meeting on May 17. Mr. Greenspan raised the Federal Funds rate by a fourth of a percentage point on April 18, acting on his own authority after consulting by telephone with the other governors of the Federal Reserve Board and with the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks.
 
A Previous Increase

 
 Before this week's rise in the discount rate, the Federal Reserve Board had also raised that rate, also by half a percentage point, in May.
At the July meeting, the panel voted 10 to 1 to approve the decision to give Mr. Greenspan the discretionary authority, according to the minutes released today. The only dissenting vote came from Mr. Broaddus.
The dissent appears to have reflected Mr. Broaddus's general view that interest rates were too low to prevent inflation from rising again. Mr. Broaddus also dissented at the March 22 meeting of the panel, contending that an increase of a fourth of a percentage point was inadequate.
The minutes of the July meeting stated, "Mr. Broaddus dissented because he believed that additional near-term tightening was necessary to contain inflation."

HEADLINE: Judge Faults Affirmative Action at Law School

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 19

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled today that the admissions policy used by the University of Texas law school in 1992 to encourage the enrollment of minority students had unconstitutionally discriminated against white applicants.
The ruling by U.S. District Judge Sam Sparks came in a lawsuit by four whites who had sought admission to the Austin law school in 1992. Two were rejected, one was admitted and one was put on a waiting list. 
 In today's ruling, the judge ordered the university to pay $1 each to the plaintiffs, Cheryl Hopwood, Douglas Carvell, Kenneth Elliott and David Rogers, and said that those who had been rejected and put on the waiting list were entitled to re-apply to the law school for the 1995-96 school year without paying further fees.
In finding the admissions policy had violated the constitutional prohibition against race discrimination, Judge Sparks objected to a separate evaluation of whites and minorities.
"Commitment to affirmative action programs in educational institutions does not imply that the individual rights of non-minorities should fall by the wayside or be ignored," he wrote.
But Judge Sparks said the university had produced evidence that the four plaintiffs would probably not have been admitted even under a constitutional standard.
Terral Smith, lawyer for the four, said proving they would have been admitted was "an impossible burden."
The lawyer said the plaintiffs would probably appeal to seek an order admitting them to the law school.
The law school has already said it is changing its admissions system, beginning with the class that enters in 1995.
Under the old policy, more than half of each first-year law school class was admitted on the basis of their combined grades and law school exam scores.
Discretionary factors, including race, gender, age and economic background, were used to evaluate the rest of the applicants. Among that group, minority students were compared with other minorities, and whites with whites.
"Using the color of an applicant's skin to limit the degree of individual comparison between the races neither serves societal goals nor sufficiently protects individual rights under our Constitution," the judge said.
The new admissions policy does not include such a separate evaluation, said Barry Burgdorf, a lawyer for the university.
