HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE EMPLOYER MANDATE;
Big Companies Use Little-Company Arguments to Resist Insuring Workers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Over and over, giant corporations that employ low-wage workers offer the same reason for withholding company-paid health insurance from them: Millions of qualified applicants are willing to take the jobs without it.
While much of the debate over uninsured workers has focused on those at small companies, more than 4.5 million of the 22 million working Americans without any health insurance are employed at big corporations like Bank of America, Wal-Mart, Pepsico, J. C. Penney and Dayton-Hudson, surveys show. These corporations are lobbying hard against any bill that would require them to insure all their workers. 
 "If there were a tighter labor market with fewer people looking for work, we might have to offer health insurance," said Norman Snell, a senior vice president at Bank of America, with headquarters in Los Angeles. "But no one has run into that problem in California, which has so many college students who are potential part-time employees."
Bank of America has 95,000 employees, of whom 20,000 are uninsured by the bank. Most of them are tellers and bank clerks who work fewer than 20 hours a week and earn under $8 an hour, two common characteristics of the uninsured at big companies. Many work for a few weeks or months, and then quit, another common characteristic.
Mr. Snell argues that insuring these workers would add substantially to the bank's costs and that profits would suffer, hurting shareholders.
 
Insurance From Wages
 But the cost-and-profit argument often masks a more important issue, wages. Studies show that most companies that offer health insurance finance as much as 85 percent of the company's contribution by limiting or cutting back wages. That is hard to do, however, for workers who earn only the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour or a dollar or two above it.
The big companies that employ such workers would have to raise prices to cover the cost, or take the money out of profits, says James G. Waters, a benefits specialist at Towers, Perrin, a management consulting firm.
"I don't see that paying for health insurance will make a profitable company unprofitable," Mr. Waters said. "But it is so antithetical to the American ethic, to penalize profitability."
So most Americans who earn less than $7 an hour do not have health insurance, at least not from the companies that employ them, Labor Department surveys show.
"We are perpetuating the notion that the employer is giving something to the employee, when in fact there is a tradeoff between wages and benefits," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, which evaluates the health insurance bills. "When you get down to the minimum wage or near it, then the tradeoff has to come in the form of higher prices or out of profits."
As a solution, companies like Pizza Hut Inc., which is the fast-food division of Pepsico, and Dayton-Hudson, which owns Marshall Field and other department stores, do endorse Federal subsidies to pay health insurance premiums for low-income people. "I would favor using general tax revenue to pay for subsidies for the working poor," said Edwin H. Wingate, a Dayton-Hudson vice president.
Without the subsidies, health insurance largely paid by the companies for all employees would be disastrous for profits, says Robert Doughty, a spokesman for Pizza Hut Inc. Now, Pizza Hut pays $23 million a year for health insurance for its 11,000 full-time workers. The remaining 120,000, who are part-timers working 20 hours a week or fewer for the minimum wage, or just above it, are ineligible for any company-paid health insurance until they have been on the job six months. Few remain that long.
"Under President Clinton's original plan, we would have been required to insure everyone from day one of their employment," Mr. Doughty said, "and our cost would go up to between $120 and $200 million a year, which would have cut in half our $370 million profit last year."
Without challenging the mathematics involved in this assertion, David Card, a Princeton University labor economist, says that company-paid health insurance for low-wage workers might result in cost savings, just as raising the minimum wage often brings savings that offset the cost of the higher wage. For example, Mr. Card says, higher pay makes workers more reluctant to quit. So turnover declines and with it the cost of constantly training new workers.
Pizza Hut became embroiled in the debate over health insurance after supporters of a health bill that would require employers to insure all their workers noted that the fast food chain insured its workers abroad, while declining to cover all its employees in the United States. Germany, in particular, was cited. While acknowledging that the assertion was correct, Mr. Doughty argued that the high cost of benefits abroad had forced up pizza prices overseas, and that the German operation rarely had a profitable year.
In the United States, while Bank of America in California argues that it can recruit qualified part-timers without offering health insurance, Chase Manhattan Bank in New York says that it cannot.
Chase classifies only 1,500 of its 20,000 American employees, most of them in New York, as part-timers ineligible for company-paid health insurance in their first year on the job. Although Chase and Bank of America share the problem of staffing their branches with extra people in peak hours, Chase employs a much smaller percentage of part-timers to do so.
"Our whole concept is to hire and retain the best people, and in New York you have to offer health insurance to do that," said John Farrell, a Chase senior vice president. "We have flexible work arrangements, but that does not cause us to have many part-timers."
Chase has already built health insurance into its pay package for low-wage workers. They earn $8 an hour or more, in addition to the company's payment of 80 percent of the health insurance premium, Mr. Farrell said.
Bank of America pays many tellers and clerks in the $8-an-hour range, Mr. Snell said, but makes no payment for health insurance. If the bank had to pay the insurance premium, too, wages might have to be held back, he said. "The market is too competitive to raise bank fees," he added.
Most of the 4.5 million uninsured Americans employed at companies with more than 1,000 employees earn less than $7 an hour, the Labor Department reports. They represent 21 percent of the nearly 22 million working Americans without health insurance, according to the Labor Department and the Employee Benefit Research Institute, which base their data mostly on surveys completed last year.
By comparison, 7.6 million of the uninsured workers, or 35 percent, are employed at small companies, which are those with fewer than 25 workers. An additional 5.7 million workers at big companies, while not insured by these companies, do have health insurance through the policies of a spouse or a relative at another job.
In their lobbying efforts, small companies have argued through their trade associations that their profits are too marginal to afford health insurance for all their employees, or that the companies have too few workers to negotiate low group insurance premiums.
The big companies do have the negotiating clout. But apart from warning about lower profits and higher prices, they have taken a different tack. Many argue that their low-wage part-time workers are often healthy young people seeking to earn some extra money by working for a while, but are uninterested in health insurance.
"Minimum-wage workers are not who you think they are; they are largely teen-agers living at home and glad to have a job while going to school," said Jeffrey Joseph, a vice president at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Citing a Labor Department study, the Chamber says that 30 percent of all Americans earning the minimum wage are teen-agers and 20 percent of all minimum-wage workers come from households with incomes of $50,000 or more.
The unions take a different view of low-wage workers, particularly the United Food and Commercial Workers, whose members include thousands of part-timers. Rather than the minimum wage, the union's members earn $7 an hour at supermarkets like A.&P., Pathmark and Safeway. All of these supermarket employees also have company health insurance.
"For lower-paid workers, a job with benefits is extremely important," said Gregory Denier, a union spokesman, disputing the Chamber of Commerce's claim. But to help offset the cost of the health insurance, the union has agreed to hold back on wage gains.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From News Conference Announcing Policy on Refugees

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference, including his opening statement and the questions and answers that followed, as transcribed by the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service:
 Good afternoon. In recent weeks, the Castro regime has encouraged Cubans to take to the sea in unsafe vessels to escape their nation's internal problems. In so doing, it has risked the lives of thousands of Cubans and several have already died in their efforts to leave. This action is a cold-blooded attempt to maintain the Castro grip on Cuba and to divert attention from his failed Communist policies. He is trying to export to the United States the political and economic crisis he has created in Cuba, in defiance of the democratic tide flowing throughout this region.
 
 Let me be clear: the Cuban Government will not succeed in any attempt to dictate American immigration policy. The United States will do everything within its power to insure that Cuban lives are saved and that the current outflow of refugees is stopped. Today I have ordered that illegal refugees from Cuba will not be allowed to enter the United States. Refugees rescued at sea will be taken to our naval base at Guantanamo while we explore the possibility of other safe havens within the region.
 To enforce this policy, I have directed the Coast Guard to continue its expanded effort to stop any boat illegally attempting to bring Cubans to the United States. The United States will detain, investigate and, if necessary, prosecute Americans who take to the sea to pick up Cubans. Vessels used in such activities will be seized.
 I want to compliment the Coast Guard and the Immigration and Naturalization Service for their efforts, and I want to thank Florida's officials, including Governor Chiles and the Florida Congressional delegation, for their help in protecting and saving the lives of Cubans who seek to escape the regime.
 
Crime Bill Compromise
 Now I'd like to speak just for a moment about the crime bill. In the last week, I have fought hard to put this crime bill back on track. After extensive talks with members of both parties, I have indicated my support for strengthening the provisions that require sexual predators to report to the police and make sure their communities are notified of their presence.
 And I support cutting overall spending in the bill by 10 percent. These cuts will insure that every dollar authorized in the bill will actually be paid for -- not with new taxes and not by diverting dollars from other needed programs, but, as I have always insisted, with the savings we will gain from reducing the size of the Federal Government by over a quarter of a million people over the next six years, to its lowest size in over 30 years, since President Kennedy was here. And all these historic savings will go back to the American people to make their streets and their homes, their schools safer.
 I have insisted that we keep the most profoundly important elements of the crime bill -- to keep it tough by putting 100,000 police officers on the street, building more prisons, putting violent criminals away for good, by making "three strikes, you're out" the law of the land, and by other stronger provisions on sentencing.
 And we're going to keep it smart with the sensible crime prevention programs that steer our kids away from drugs and gangs and give them things to say yes to. The crime bill must ban handguns for juveniles and take deadly assault weapons off our streets. Even though we've come under intense pressure from forces that will apparently say anything to take the assault weapons out of the bill, I have refused to do so.
 Let's keep in mind what this crime bill is all about. It's about removing fear from our streets, our schools and our homes. Innocent Americans should not have to fear being preyed upon, as so many do today. Innocent children should not have to fear losing their childhoods, as so many do today. We owe it to the American people that do the work and pay the bills in this country to make sure that people who commit crime get caught, that those who are guilty get convicted and that those who are convicted serve their time. We also owe it to them to do whatever we can to prevent crime in the first place. That's what the police and the prevention programs are all about.
 That's why it is so important and why I have worked so hard to make sure that we do not turn this crime issue into yet another Washington partisan issue. This is a grass-roots, mainstream, nonpartisan issue, and so it should remain. It must be an American crime bill. We have worked hard on it, and I call upon Congress to pass it without delay.
 
U.S. Policy Toward Cuba
 Q. Mr. President, on behalf of all the press corps, we want to wish you a happy birthday.
 A. Thank you.
 Q. And now ----
 A. Well, you could all do a lot to make it happy -- that is not a guilt trip; feel no pressure. Thank you.
 Q. Mr. President, in the last 35 years, we've had an embargo against Cuba. . . . What is the problem with taking a few small, albeit brave steps to negotiate a possible movement toward democracy with Cuba? We've dealt with many Communist countries through the last 35 years, and we're dealing with them now.
 A. There aren't many left. I support the embargo and I support the Cuban Democracy Act, which was passed in 1992. And I do not believe we should change our policy there. The fundamental problem is democracy is sweeping the world; democracy and freedom are sweeping our hemisphere. In the Caribbean alone and in Central and South America, in all of this region, there are only two countries now not democratically governed with open societies and open economies.
 The real problem is the stubborn refusal of the Castro regime to have an open democracy and an open economy, and I think the policies we are following will hasten the day when that occurs. . . .
 Q. Mr. President, recognizing that you're slowing down the process, do people fleeing Cuba still get automatic entry to the United States as political refugees if they're not criminals or ill?
 A. No. The people leaving Cuba will not be permitted to come to the United States. They will be sent to safe havens. . . . The people who reach here will be apprehended and will be treated like others. They will be -- their cases will be reviewed, and those who qualify can stay, and those who don't will not be permitted to. They will be now treated like others who come here. . . .
 Q. Mr. President, under the law it has always been clear that Cuban refugees had a certain priority on staying here, and the policy, of course, was then that anybody who got here got to stay. What restraints are you operating under in terms of the law in changing this policy? Are you likely, sir, to be sued over this?
 A. No. . . . The Cuban Adjustment Act will continue to be the law of the land, but we are doing our best within that -- we will detain the Cubans who come here now. They will not simply be released into the population at large. And we will review all their cases in light of the applicable law, including the Cuban Adjustment Act. . . .
 Q. Can you give us some more details? Are these people going to be taken to Guantanamo? What kind of strain might this place on our naval forces, the Coast Guard? Already we're being told that drug interdiction is being cut back. And can you respond to criticism already from Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich? In particular, Mr. Gingrich said that your new policy is appalling, it's an example of mixed morality, and that he thinks it is illegal under the act.
 A. Well, first let me answer the factual questions. The refugees, those who are fleeing, will be taken first to Guantanamo, where we will seek safe havens for them. That is plainly not illegal under international law, nor do we believe it is illegal under the Cuban Adjustment Act.
 Secondly, as to whether it is immoral, I just would say it is my belief that the American people, and that the Cuban-American people, and the people of Florida, but the people of the entire United States, do not want to see another Mariel boat lift. They do not want to see Cuba dictate our immigration policy. They do not want to see Mr. Castro able to export his political and economic problems to the United States.
 Now that is what is plainly being set up. We have gone through that once. We had 120,000 people sent to this country as a deliberate attempt -- not because they themselves initially wanted to flee -- they were encouraged to flee; they were pushed out. We had jails open, we had mental hospitals open, all in an attempt to export all the problems of Cuba to the United States. We tried it that way once. It was wrong then and it's wrong now, and I'm not going to let it happen again. . . .
 
Reviving the Crime Bill
 Q. President Clinton, previously you said that the crime bill was something that you supported, that you wanted to sign as it was. Now you're saying you can take 10 percent out of it. Why shouldn't the American people believe that there's still a lot of fat that should come out of it?
 A. First of all, any time you start -- I've never seen a bill that started new programs that you couldn't cut some and maintain its fundamental integrity. I said that crime bill was a strong and good bill as it was, and it was a strong and good bill. But one of the things that happened in conference that I think has been largely overlooked is that, in an attempt to get as much money as possible for police officers and law enforcement and for prisons and for border patrol, funds were appropriated or were authorized in the crime bill that came out of conference in an amount greater than we could provide in the trust fund.
 Keep in mind the great beauty of this crime bill is it's the first major program in American history that's being financed entirely by reducing the size of the Federal bureaucracy and taking all the savings from the Federal Government and putting it in a trust fund to help grass-roots Americans get better control over their own lives. The practical impact of what we are doing by cutting 10 percent of this will be to be able to put everything that's left into the trust fund. So in terms of real dollars, I believe there will be more money actually appropriated and spent for tough law enforcement and for police officers.
 And I believe that all the fundamental important things in the prevention strategy will be maintained at a very high level and dramatically higher than now. The principles of the bill are intact. It's the biggest increase in police in the history of the country. It's the toughest increase in punishment in the history of the country. It's the biggest increase in prevention programs in the history of the country. . . .
 I'm not a member of the Congress. They have to work out all the details. If they'd produced this bill out of the conference, I would have happily supported this as I did the other one.
 Q. Were you just giving in to politics then by accepting the original here?
 A. Now, that's one of those questions designed to spoil your birthday. Because it's something else designed to confuse the American people about what really goes on up here. The President is not a member of the Congress. The Congress made a decision that they had a bill that they all wanted. They accommodated the interests as best they could. It met all my fundamental criteria -- assault weapons ban, ban on handgun ownership by kids, tougher penalties, longer imprisonment, more prevention. So does this bill. . . .
 
Reaction of Cuban-Americans
 Q. Mr. President, you say that you are not going to allow Fidel Castro to dictate U.S. immigration policy, but hasn't he just done that by forcing you to reverse three decades of a policy? And secondly, what do you say to Cuban-Americans, especially in Florida, who feel betrayed by this change in policy?
 A. Well, I believe that most Cuban-Americans want us to be very firm. The Cuban-Americans that I know, without regard to their party, supported the Cuban Democracy Act, and they remember how awful it was for the United States when the Mariel boat lift occurred. They remembered what it did in this country and how -- the feelings that it generated in this country. And I do not believe they want another Mariel boat lift, and I do not believe we can afford to do that.
 And so my own view is that most Cuban-Americans will support what we're trying to do and wish us to be firm. . . .
 Q. By telling Cubans to basically to stay home and at least temporarily to stomach conditions there, does that make it incumbent on you to be more active in seeking to oust Castro?
 A. Well, what we are telling Cubans is that we have a provision for their coming to the United States through in-country processing, and at least as of this date, we have no evidence that the Castro Government has done anything to discourage Cubans from coming to the in-country processing, applying for the visas if they're eligible to come here, and getting them. . . .
 
'Keep Working' on Health Bill
 Q. Mr. President, one of your fellow Democrats in the Senate, Sam Nunn of Georgia, said yesterday that it would be months, if not years, before a health care reform bill is produced, and the Congressional Budget Office said that a possible moderate compromise didn't cost out. There's a growing feeling in Washington that this health care crusade is hopelessly bogged down in Congress at this point. What is your view of the situation?
 A. That they should keep working at it. That if we don't move now, there's a chance that it won't happen at all. You know, the congressional timetable is often different from the American timetable. I mean, it took seven years to pass the Brady bill and seven years to pass family leave, but for 60 years, people have acknowledged that not covering all Americans and having no system for dealing with the explosive costs and the inequalities in the health care system were a problem.
 They have reached a significant crisis stage here, with five million more Americans losing their health insurance in the last five years alone, with the costs exploding in the last 12 years, and I believe that the time has come to deal with this.
 Now, Senator Nunn simply observed what I think is clearly a fact, which is that in the Senate there is unlimited debate and you can have unlimited amendments. But a lot of these issues do need to be worked through. I think that the comments Senator Kennedy and Senator Mitchell made today about the fact that this bipartisan group was at least attempting to work with them and, in the process of so attempting, finding out how hard it is -- it's easy to stand on the sideline and lob brickbats at these efforts, and quite another thing to produce your own effort. But their comment made me believe that there is still a chance that people will work together and resolve this. . . .
 
Ban on Assault Weapons
 Q. Mr. President, back to the crime bill. If the approach you're offering, the changes you're offering now, does not produce enough votes to pass the bill, will you under any circumstances agree to sever the assault weapon ban for a separate vote in the House and Senate?
 A. I won't agree to that because I think it's a mistake. And let me say -- I don't want to overly comment on it, but let me try to describe what the problem is. The bill has already passed the House, but in the Senate, as you know, we could have 55, 56, 57, 59 votes for that bill in the Senate and it could still be filibustered, and we should not permit that to happen. . . .
 
An Ambitious Agenda
 Q. Mr. President, I hate to ask you one of those questions that might spoil a birthday again, but in light of the problems that you have been having up on Capitol Hill, many people are wondering if changing your communications strategy, shuffling your staff might not be really addressing the problem, that perhaps -- I was wondering if you've thought about this -- that as a President elected with 43 percent, you may be trying to do too much, too fast, and Democrats on Capitol Hill may be trying to take too much of a partisan advantage of having control of the entire Government and perhaps exceeding your mandate?
 A. Well, first, I don't want the Democrats to take partisan advantage. I just want us to get what's necessary for the country done. I do not believe the country believes that we should sit still up here. And for all your talk about trouble, let me remind you that every objective survey says that in 1993, this Administration got more support from Congress than any Administration since World War II except President Eisenhower in 1953, when he had a less ambitious agenda, and President Johnson in 1965, when he had a bigger mandate and more support from the Congress. So I think we're doing quite well with the Congress if you look at it in any kind of historic pattern.
 Now, I realize the fights and the conflicts and the delays endure more than the achievements, but we reversed Reaganomics. We passed an economic program that was part of a strategy that has given us three years of deficit reduction for the first time since Truman, over four million jobs. We have the most advances in trade than we've had in a generation in the last year and a half. This economic program is working. We broke seven years of gridlock with the Brady bill. We passed Nafta, which was deader than a doornail when I became President. We revived it and passed it. . . .
 But I believe what I have to do is to keep trying to change things. Any time you try to provoke as much change as I have, you are going to have resistance, and you will be criticized. Is it more difficult that I had 43 percent of the vote? Perhaps it is. But I think you can make another argument, which was that 62 percent of the American people voted for fundamental change. . . .
 If anything, I would say that I've been most disappointed, looking back, not so much in my inability to get things done -- because once people look at the list, it's a very long and impressive list -- but I haven't been as successful in changing the way it works; that is, in trying to get the Democrats and Republicans to reach across to each other in good faith and work through these things. That's why I think this crime bill could be an important thing. It would be a way of people in both parties saying we're putting you first, for a change -- not ourselves. . . .
 
No Criticism for the Fed
 Q. Mr. President, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates again this week. Some Democrats are saying that it could cause an economic slowdown. How many more rate increases will you take before you also criticize the Fed?
 A. Well, when the Federal Reserve raised rates this week, the chairman, Mr. Greenspan, said that he thought that this would be sufficient for a time. The truth is that our economic strategy has produced more rapid growth than they thought it would and that we thought it would. We are even doing better than we thought we would. We've got over four million jobs already in the last year and a half, and we've got rapid growth in the economy, dramatic new investments in the private sector, so they are worried about inflation.
 I -- when it is apparent to me that the drag on the economy will be more about slowing the economy down than stopping inflation, I will do what I can to influence that policy. But I think my policy of letting them do their job and having me do mine has worked out rather well. . . .
 
Mexico and the Middle East
 Q. Mr. President, happy birthday. Next Sunday, Mexico is going to have presidential elections. Can you give us your assessment? What do you think? What do you expect? And what is going to be the impact in the relations of Mexico and the United States? Do you expect continuity?
 A. I expect the elections to be free, open and fair, and I expect them to produce a result which will be accepted by the people of Mexico. And I expect the United States to continue its deepening friendship with Mexico. I think that our relationships are growing. I think in spite of the political changes and the economic difficulties of Mexico in the last two years, we have had great success. I think Nafta clearly was a great success if you look at the economic benefits to the United States and what has happened. So I'm looking forward very optimistically to the future with Mexico.
 Q. Mr. President, on the Middle East, sir, progress continues between Israel and the Palestinians but there's still violence. I wondered, sir, if you have an assessment on that. Is there any update on the Syrian front? Have you heard recently from President Assad? And also, has any progress been made in countering worldwide terrorism?
 A. You asked me a lot of questions, there. Let me answer -- try to answer them all. I believe we are still on a path of steady progress in the hope of achieving an agreement that resolves the differences between Israel and Syria. Serious problems remain, but I would say significant advances are being made.
 With regard to the Palestinian agreement, I think everyone always knew there would be some operational difficulties because the P.L.O. had -- to be fair to them -- never been in charge of a country. That is, they had never had to operate a government and to deal with all the mundane and maybe sometimes even boring day-to-day problems that, unless they're properly managed, you can't keep a society together. I think we're making some headway there. I don't want to minimize the difficulties, but I do not expect them to be so great as to derail what we're doing.
 
Clinton's Wish List
 Q. What stirs within you as you celebrate another birthday? And if you could have three wishes fulfilled today, what would those three wishes be?
 A. Well, I woke up this morning just grateful to be here. That's what I'm feeling. I'm grateful to be alive, grateful to have my health, grateful to have my family, grateful to have the chance to serve. And you know, I like the tough fight, so this is an exhilarating period for me. I like the big challenges. I think we're all put on this earth to try to make a difference.
 If I had three wishes, I would wish for the crime bill to pass -- one. I would wish that I would make more progress on the way we do things around here as well as on the substance, because if we can open our minds and hearts to each other and play a little less politics, we can solve the health care problem, too, and other things. And I would wish that I won't have to give up my whole vacation -- because I still have dreams of breaking 80 on the golf course before I'm 50. . . .
 Thank you very much.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SUBJECT: REFORM AND REORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CUBA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); CRIME AND CRIMINALS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; MEDICINE AND HEALTH; HEALTH INSURANCE PRESS CONFERENCES (90%); REFUGEES (90%); IMMIGRATION (90%); US PRESIDENTS (89%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (89%); IMMIGRATION LAW (88%); LEGISLATION (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); POLITICS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL ASYLUM (73%); NAVIES (72%); ARMED FORCES (71%); RESCUE OPERATIONS (68%); SEX OFFENSES (64%); TAXES & TAXATION (62%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (54%);

PUB-DATE: August 20, 1994

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1957 words

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From the Senate Debate on Revisions in the Health Care System

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
For much of this week, Senate Democrats have repeatedly argued that Congress should pass a health insurance overhaul that provides all Americans with coverage equal to what Congress itself enjoys under the Federal Employees Health Benefits program.
Republicans have just as consistently replied that the Federal plan is nothing extraordinary and dismissed the argument as demagogic. But the strategy of the Democrats, played out for the C-Span television audience, has clearly annoyed their opponents. 
 The Federal employees' program provides about nine million workers with a choice of various private insurance programs, with the Government typically contributing 72 percent of the cost of premiums and employees 28 percent -- close to the national average. Bills sponsored by Republicans and Democrats alike would allow people in the private sector to join the plan, though the conditions for doing so would vary.
This morning, two Democrats, Senators Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Harry Reid of Nevada, followed the Senate's required form of debate and began a friendly -- and calculated -- dialogue on the subject as a challenge to Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. Eventually, several Democrats took their credit-card-sized insurance cards from their wallets to wave them in the air. At one point, Mr. Wellstone asked Mr. Warner if he had a card.
Reaching into his hip pocket, Mr. Warner replied, "I'll have to check." But referring to the Democrats' proposals, he added, "I know one thing: this plan will take every last dollar I've got in this wallet."

Following are excerpts from today's exchange, the 10th day of the debate in the Senate, as transcribed by The New York Times from a broadcast on C-Span.

WARNER I freely admit the following: My father was a doctor, a very prominent, a very successful physician here in northern Virginia and the nation's capital. And I admit, Madam President, if I'd had enough brains I would have been a doctor, but here I am today.
 
WELLSTONE . . . I disagree with the Senator from Virginia. I think he has more than enough brains.
 
WARNER But I learned at my father's knee several things about medicine, and I'd like to pose them to my good friend in the form of a question. What we've done is transformed this magnificent chamber into an operating room. We're like so many physicians, bending over this patient, ready to take the scalpel and make a major incision into a system which has served this country for some 200 years, which has served 80-plus percent of our people quite adequately.
Now does the system have problems? Yes, it does have some problems. And we have been dealing with them, ostensibly, here for a few days. But I think we've done little more than a pedicure -- clipped a nail here and polished a little bit there. We haven't gotten into the problem in terms of how it's to be paid for, the balance between further government intervention in the private sector. Those are the major issues. . . .
Time and time and time we have rejected diagnosis after diagnosis. This thing's becoming almost like a "M*A*S*H" comedy, and that's not what the American public wants. They want answers. And I say to my good friend, when the practicing doctors and the patients reach this type of situation where we find ourselves in today, they go and get a second opinion. That's dead-rock practice in medicine today, a second opinion. And I ask my good friend, is it not time to get a second opinion? And that opinion, in my judgment, can only be rendered by the people of the United States of America. . . .
 
MADAM PRESIDENT (BOXER) The Senator from Minnesota does have the floor and is entitled to answer the question at some point.
 
WARNER That is correct, Madam President. I get that message, and that's the message I'm trying to send to my friend, that it's time we get a second opinion and come back next year and commit, although we cannot bind the next Congress, commit the two-thirds of us who will be here.
 
MADAM PRESIDENT Does the Senator from Minnesota understand the question by the Senator from Virginia?
 
WARNER Madam President, he understands the question.
 
WELLSTONE Madam President, I certainly do understand the question. Having been a teacher for many years, I'm very familiar with long questions, and my colleague from Virginia is his usual articulate self. Let me just simply respond very briefly and then go on with the second opinion that I'm now going to present on the Mainstream proposal, because I think we should have a debate about ideas and policy proposals, and just simply say to my colleague from Virginia that I smile a little bit to myself about second opinions because health care, universal health care coverage, is an idea whose time has come over and over and over again in our country, going all the way back to before World War I. So since we have been debating this question as a nation for well over a half a century, and since we are really almost alone among the ranks of the advanced economies in the world in our failure to figure out how to finance and deliver health care for all of our citizens -- high quality care, which I know your father would have insisted on -- it seems to me that we've had plenty of time for debate, discussion and second opinions.
We've had many committee hearings here, and there comes a time in public life where you step up to the plate. I agree with my colleague, I'd like to get to the core of this and go after the tough issues, and you'd vote. That's what we're here for, is to vote.
 
REID Would the Senator from Minnesota yield?
 
WELLSTONE I'd be pleased to yield to my colleague from Nevada, and I also just want to remind my colleague, since I know we want to go to amendments, that I want to make sure that I do have time to present an analysis of the Mainstream group proposals because I want that to be a matter of record, but I'd certainly be pleased to yield.
 
REID The Senator has the floor and the Senator can speak as long as the Senator wishes under the present frame of debate. I would ask the Senator from Minnesota, is it not true that during this Congress there's been over 80 hearings held on various health care bills by the Finance Committee and the Education and Labor Committee? Is that true, over 80 committee hearings?
 
WELLSTONE That is correct.
 
REID Isn't it true, I say to my friend from Minnesota, isn't it true that during this period of time there have been hundreds of witnesses testify before those two committees?
 
WELLSTONE That is correct.
 
REID Isn't it true that one of the basic elements that we're trying to establish, as indicated by the Senator from Minnesota, is the fact that we have been through over 50 years of debate, off and on, during this? And during the past several years debate all year long. We've been through six or seven Presidents that have talked about universal health coverage, isn't that true?
 
WELLSTONE That is correct.
 
REID And, Mr. President, I reach in my wallet here and I can flip through this wallet, and I have a card here that says, "Government-Wide Service Benefit Plan, Blue Cross-Blue Shield Federal Employee Program." Now isn't it true, Mr. President, that there's been -- isn't that true, I say to my friend from Minnesota, that we've had debate on this floor for over two weeks trying to indicate to the American public and to the United States Senate that we're not trying to do anything very difficult or elaborate, we're trying to give the American public the same coverage that we have, isn't that true?
 
WELLSTONE That is correct.

Number one, yes, I mean, to talk about we really need to slow all this up, we need another second opinion, ignores almost 75 years of debate and discussion about this. And second of all, of course your perspective about whether or not we need to stop or we need to block or we need to filibuster or whatever it is that we do, depends upon the situation of yourself and your family. And if, in fact, you've reached a point where you don't have insurance, or you're under-insured, or you're terrified of losing your coverage because you might lose your job or because of a sickness, then from your point of view it is really important that this doesn't get put off yet once again.

HEADLINE: Stocks Take 'Witching' In Stride, Ending Mixed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed but essentially unchanged yesterday, despite a "double witching hour" and fallout from the Federal Reserve's steep increase in interest rates earlier in the week.
Such witching-hour days, when options on stock indexes and individual stocks expire at the same time, usually lead to hectic sessions and many trading imbalances, as traders hurry to buy and sell stocks before their options expire. But the New York Stock Exchange reported no trading imbalances yesterday, and the trading volume of 279.7 million shares was below average. 
 Blue chips like J. P. Morgan and Coca-Cola fell, but conglomerates like General Electric and computer companies like I.B.M. rose. Over-the-counter stocks like Microsoft and Cisco Systems declined.
 
Insurer's Stock Tumbles
 Trading in some stocks was notable. Shares of 20th Century Industries, an insurance company, fell 3 5/8, to 12 3/4, after the California Supreme Court upheld a Government order for the company to pay $119 million in refunds. The company had $113 million in net income in 1993.
Quaker Oats fell 1/8, to 81 7/8, after rising sharply on Thursday on takeover rumors. But an analyst at Salomon Brothers said it was unlikely that Unilever, a rumored bidder, would attempt a takeover of Quaker.
The most active stock, with nearly 11 million shares traded, was Cisco, which fell 7/8, to 22 5/8. The company, which makes computer networking equipment, reported earnings that were somewhat below analysts' estimates. It reported a fourth-quarter profit of 34 cents a share, compared with 21 cents a share in the comparable period a year earlier.
Wall Street had expected Cisco to earn 35 cents a share. But traders often discount those estimates as conservative, so a company often must report a better-than-expected profit to get an increase in its share price.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged, at 1005/32 . Its yield was also unchanged, at 7.49 percent.
The dollar was mixed but little changed against leading currencies. It rose to 98.65 Japanese yen from 98.57, but fell to 1.5396 German marks from 1.5440. It was unchanged against the British pound, at $1.549 to 1.
Commodity prices were basically unchanged, but gold futures contracts for September delivery rose $1.10, to $381.90 an ounce. The Commodity Research Bureau futures index fell 0.23 point, to 229.77, led by declines for unleaded gas, coffee and live hogs.
 
No Summer Rally
 A summer rally has not materialized, and Wall Street strategists who believe that the stock and bond markets are locked in wide trading ranges appear to be correct, especially after the Fed's increase in interest rates did little to shake the markets out of these ranges this week.
Since late June, the Dow Jones industrial average has fluctuated in a range of 3,600 to 3,800. Since early June, the bond market has been in a range where the long bond's yield has varied from 7.2 percent to 7.7 percent.
Yesterday, the Dow fell 0.32 point, to 3,755.11, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.51 point, to 463.68. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.26 point, to 742.43.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.32 point, to 255.81, with advancing stocks outnumbering those that declined by 1,157 to 917. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.90 points, to 445.45.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 fell, led by J. P. Morgan, which fell 1 1/8, to 63 1/4, mainly because a single unidentified investor sold 500,000 shares, or a third of the daily volume.
 Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 226 rose, led by General Electric, which rose 3/4, to 47 7/8, on no immediate news.
In Tokyo yesterday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 350.07 points, or 1.68 percent, to 20,512.70. On Thursday, the index gained 38.21 points.

HEADLINE: Steel Gains in Home Building

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
For more than 50 years the American steel industry has been promoting its product for residential construction -- with a stunning lack of success. According to the National Association of Home Builders, as recently as 1990, 94 percent of new homes were built with wood framing, with concrete block the most frequently used alternative.
But things are changing. According to the American Iron and Steel Institute, an industry trade group, the number of steel-framed homes increased to 15,000 last year from 500 in 1992, with 75,000 projected this year. 
 The boomlet can largely be laid to simple economics. In the last year, the near exhaustion of old growth timber has become critical, sending the price of wood soaring and the quality of what is available into decline. Reluctantly, builders have begun looking for other alternatives, and some are switching to steel.
 
 
Nature's Role
 But acts of God have also played a role. The devastation left in Florida by Hurricane Andrew in August 1992, and by recent earthquakes in California, have highlighted the need for strong and flexible housing. And among larger buildings, steel-framed ones clearly did better than those made of wood or masonry.
Steelmakers who struggle with high fixed costs and highly cyclical markets in their traditional automotive, appliance and construction applications, see a much needed stable outlet. "There are 1.1 million to 1.8 million housing starts a year," said Richard Haws, manager for light construction at the Iron and Steel Institute. "Since each house uses five to six tons, it could be a huge market."
Still, a number of obstacles to wider use of steel remain, not the least of which is custom and habit. Though steel is strong, not flammable and impervious to termites or rot, in the past residential builders avoided it because they found it more difficult to cut and join.
 
 
Distribution Network
 However, high-rise use of steel has helped establish a manufacturing and distribution network for metal building studs and related material that is ready to expand -- and to help educate residential builders. Studs are the concealed vertical supports for the walls of a house, and are usually cut from two-by-fours.
As for cost, the price of 1,000 board feet of lumber went from about $300 last July to about $500 last December and is now about $400, according to Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. That puts steel, which once was twice as expensive as lumber, in a nearly competitive position, and has attracted builders who had signed contracts to build houses for a fixed price.
As for quality, structural timbers, boards 2 inches by 6 inches or larger, must be cut from dense, old-growth trees to have sufficient strength. But 90 percent of the old growth has been cut down, and much of what is left is protected for environmental reasons.
"The forest management practices of the last 40 to 50 years have exacerbated the problem," said Nels C. Johnson, a forest ecologist with the World Resources Institute in Washington. Wood products companies, he said, typically replace diverse natural forests with tree plantations, using one species of fast-growing tree.
This allows them to harvest the trees sooner, but the wood produced is less dense and less strong than that of old growth. Builders complain that wood from the smaller plantation trees is more likely to have excessive knots and is more prone to twisting and splitting.
"The quality of lumber has gotten a lot worse," said Jim McAleer, executive vice president of Kevin Scarborough Inc., a builder of single-family houses in southern New Jersey and Delaware. "It's green, it twists and has so many knot holes it looks like chipmunks have been running through it."
Officials of the American Forest and Paper Association, the lumber industry's principal trade group, conceded that builders have a perception of deteriorating quality in lumber.
 
 
'More Accurate Mix'
 In the past, the officials said, mills mixed higher-quality lumber with lower grades because there was little price difference. But since prices have risen, mills have been stricter about sorting. "You see a more accurate mix now," said Robert Glowinski, a vice president of the association. "But builders on the job site may be disappointed that the higher grades are not in there."
A lot of builders are thinking about alternative materials, although few have actually made the switch yet. "We surveyed our members and found that about 2 percent of them are using steel, but that 45 percent are thinking about it," Mr. Carliner of the home builders group said.
Another obstacle to the wider use of steel in housing is that most building codes are designed around a wood structure and the fractious companies that fabricate the lightweight studs that can replace lumber have been unable to agree on standards. Many builders are reluctant to deviate from established codes for fear that they will have to pay for additional engineering to have their houses certified as safe.
 
 
'Not Had Good Information'
 "We are not talking U. S. Steel or Bethlehem here; there are 100 little companies that buy the steel from them and do the fabrication," said Larry Zarker of the home builders association's research center. "They tend to fight with each other a lot and, as a result, the home building industry has not had good information."
To promote the use of metal studs in building homes, the Iron and Steel Institute and its members are holding joint seminars with the home builders association to teach builders, who are often small-business people with no research staff, the economics and mechanics of using steel. And they are donating material to build 200 houses in an area of Homestead, Fla., hard hit by Hurricane Andrew.
Edward R. diGirolamo, president of All American Steel Homes Inc., which is based in St. James, L.I., and sells steel framing, said many builders were concerned that switching from lumber to steel would disrupt their carefully honed production methods. "Their biggest concern is how it will affect their subcontractors," he said. "We know that we have to provide training as part of the package."
Building a house of steel does involve different techniques from using wood. Instead of a hammer and nails, framers use self-tapping strews and and electric drive gun. Driving the screws takes longer than hammering a nail, but because the studs are pre-punched for electrical and plumbing connections, less cutting is involved.
In fact, since steel framing is manufactured, builders can order the pieces cut to length, so there is less need to cut in the field and pre-assemble some part, such as roof trusses. Since wood comes in standard lengths, it has to be cut to fit on the job site. According to Allen Hershkowitz, a solid waste specialist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization in New York, as much as one-third of the wood used in a single family home is discarded as waste.
 
 
No Rust Problem
 Whatever the differences in framing techniques, steel industry officials and builders say the resulting house will look and feel like one constructed of wood. Since the steel studs are almost always made from galvanized sheet, rust is not an issue and some added insulation can compensate for the metal's greater heat conductivity. Because of their strength, steel studs can be spaced more widely than wood, so there is no interference with radio and television signals.
Steel is not the only alternative to studs sawed from logs. Small pieces of wood can be joined together with various glues to form what is known as engineered lumber. But engineered lumber costs more than ordinary wood, and its long-term advantages are yet to be proved.
Jim McAleer, for one, says his company plans to use nothing but steel framing on all its future projects. "We not getting into it to save money; at the moment it costs a little more," Mr. McAleer said. "The point is it produces a better product and we think it is the wave of the future."

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Track Dollar And End Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slightly mixed yesterday, tracing the dollar's course in the currency markets.
The dollar's early weakness caused the bond market to slump, and nearly erased all of the market's gains since the Federal Reserve increased interest rates on Tuesday. 
 Market analysts said trading was thin yesterday, with no motivation to push the market out of its recent pattern. High interest rates in Europe also kept buyers away, they said.
 
Varied Results
 The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 10056/32 , to yield 7.49 percent. In the shorter-maturity securities, trading was mixed. The three-month bill rate was up one basis point, to 4.54 percent, while the six-month issue was down two basis points, to 4.90 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
William Basa, a bond market analyst with McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., said the half-point increase in interest rates on Tuesday should have helped the dollar, but did not.
Compounding matters, he said, is the political uncertainty in Washington and the fact that higher rates abroad are reducing the dollar's relative attractiveness.
One positive factor in the near term, he said, is the limited progress being made in the trade talks between the United States and Japan.
"Unfortunately," he said, "this is not just a yen problem, for the dollar index looks weak, as does the dollar versus the mark and Swiss franc."
 
Few Foreign Buyers Seen

 
 Eugene J. Sherman, director of research for M. A. Schapiro & Company, said he saw few price changes yesterday, with bonds bouncing around in thin trading.
"The dollar was the major issue," he said, "suggesting that foreign investors are reluctant to buy U.S. securities, fearing a decline in the price of those securities."
Mr. Sherman said that with the move of 50 basis points higher in the discount rate and Federal funds target rate on Tuesday, the market had set aside, for a time, its concern that the Fed would increase rates again in the months ahead.
"One underlying worry investors and dealers do have, because of the poor tone in trading, is that the tightening by the Fed will not be enough over time to slow sufficiently the momentum in the economy," Mr. Sherman said.
He cited the report this week on initial jobless claims, noting the decline shown in the four-week moving average after two consecutive weeks of sharp drops.
"This is an indication that the labor market is strong and payroll increases for August, which will be reported in September, will show another large increase," Mr. Sherman said.
 
Bank Lending Said to Be Strong

 
 "Also, interest rate hikes earlier in the year have had no impact on bank loans; they continue to be very strong," he added. "In fact, they accelerated in the post-period of the May 17 tightening by the Fed. And that suggests to me that interest rates have had no impact on slowing the economy."
Next week the Treasury plans to sell $52.65 billion of new bills and notes, of which $28.25 billion will be in two- and five-year notes. On Tuesday the Treasury will auction $17.25 billion of two-year notes and Wednesday, $11 billion of five-year notes.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent, and the five-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 6.92 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Flat After Early Losses Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against other leading currencies yesterday, recovering from an early drop as traders saw threats of intervention by central banks and heard some positive comments on American-Japanese trade issues.
The Mexican peso strengthened on expectations that the presidential election in Mexico tomorrow will go smoothly. The ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party's candidate, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, is favored to win the election and is widely expected to continue the market-oriented economic policies of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. It took 3.3585 pesos to buy a dollar yesterday, down from 3.3755 on Thursday. 
 The dollar ended in New York at 98.65 Japanese yen, up slightly from 98.57 yen on Thursday. But it slipped to 1.5396 German marks from 1.5440 marks.
The dollar began its slide in Asia, and the decline continued in Europe. Dealers said the drop reflected residual selling after the plunge on Thursday that was prompted by the report of a widening trade deficit between the United States and Japan.
Still, the dollar bounced back in New York yesterday. Win Thin, an economist for MCM Currencywatch Inc., said the Bank of Japan was widely believed to have bought dollars to prevent a further weakening against the yen.
While the intervention was unsuccessful, he said, speculation that the Japanese central bank left buy orders with American banks helped discourage dollar sellers from trying to drive the currency lower.
"It caused a lot of quick moves to buy dollars," he said. "People are nervous about the prospect of another central bank intervention."
Further supporting the dollar was a report in the Japanese financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun quoting the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, as saying the gap between American and Japanese positions in the trade talks was "extremely small."
Washington has threatened to impose sanctions against Japan's exports if the two sides fail to resolve a dispute over Japanese Government procurement practices by the end of September.
The currency market is extremely sensitive to any hints of heightened trade tension between the two countries. Japan's huge surplus generates a steady flow of Japanese-held dollars that must be exchanged for yen, undermining the value of the dollar, and the Clinton Administration is still widely believed to favor a strong yen to help narrow the trade gap. When the yen rises in value, it tends to make Japanese exports more expensive for American consumers.

HEADLINE: Theodore Conrad, 84, Modeler And Architecture Preservationist

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Theodore Conrad, who distilled modern architecture as a model maker and defended historic architecture as a preservationist, died yesterday at his home in Jersey City. He was 84.
He died of congestive heart failure, said a friend, Colin Egan. 
 In 1931, when he was a student at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, Mr. Conrad began making architectural models. He was a pioneer in the use of Plexiglas and metal for models, rather than the traditional wood and cardboard. And he earned increasingly high-profile commissions.
Many modern landmarks assumed their earliest three-dimensional form in Mr. Conrad's Jersey City studio. It was one of his models that gave Jacqueline Kennedy the first glimpse of what her husband's grave would look like at Arlington National Cemetery.
From his studio, he could see the final versions of his work defining the skyline of Manhattan -- "no bigger than the model at that distance and scarcely more substantial looking," The New Yorker said in a 1956 profile.
 
Modeler of New York
 "Well, there's Metropolitan Life -- I did that," Mr. Conrad said in 1981, while surveying the skyline across the Hudson River. "Chase Manhattan. You can't see the Museum of Modern Art -- it's too low. Seagram Building is covered up now. But there's Rockefeller Center, Equitable Life. And of course I built all of lower Manhattan below Houston Street. That's downstairs."
On his model of the Air Force Academy in Colorado, he placed 10,000 airmen, each one-quarter of an inch high. At 16 feet, the Seagram Building model had to be taken to New York over the George Washington Bridge, as it would not fit through the Lincoln Tunnel.
Most recently, Mr. Conrad was best known as a preservationist. In the late 1960's, he led a citizens committee to save the abandoned 60-year-old Hudson County Courthouse, which was threatened with demolition. The group succeeded in having the property listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1970. In the 1980's, it was restored and returned to civic use.
He was also involved in the fight over Loew's Jersey Theater, a 3,200-seat Baroque movie palace on Journal Square in Jersey City that a developer planned to demolish. It was acquired by Jersey City in 1993 and Mr. Conrad, then 83, was present for the 2 A.M. vote by the City Council. Its restoration is being overseen by Jersey City Economic Development Corporation.
Mr. Conrad is survived by his wife, Ruth; two daughters, Doris C. Brown of Jersey City, and Carin Lewis of Berwick, Pa., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Increase in Home Gardening Yields Bumper Crop of Sales

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Wendi Winters, passionate gardener, is growing tomatoes, peppers, beans, sage "and lots more basil this year," she said. And for the first time she has even put in cilantro, "which we know is chic, even though it tastes like soap."
"Everyone has a garden this year, and in fact, the people next door just put one in," added Ms. Winters, who has three garden plots at her Montclair, N.J., home. She is not alone. Despite higher-than-average rainfall and a later-than-usual spring, 10 million more Americans are growing vegetables this season in comparison with last year, according to a study of the nation's gardening business. 
 Retail sales are up 10 percent over last year's $1.1 billion in vegetable-gardening revenues. This year gardeners are spending more and a sampling of suppliers across the country shows that sales growth in seeds, plants and fertilizers by the end of the year should be the largest since 1991.
"There's a real gardening rebound this year," said Bruce Butterfield, research director of the National Gardening Association in Burlington, Vt., which tracks consumer gardening trends on an annual basis.
Over all, lawn and garden sales, of which vegetable gardening is a part, have been flat during the last three years, at about $22 billion annually, according to the association. The average annual growth of 5.3 percent in retail sales during the 1980's dropped to 2.5 percent annually in the 1990's, until this year, Mr. Butterfield said.
According to a recent poll for the gardening association by the Gallup Organization, 35 percent of the nation's 96.4 million households are vegetable gardening, compared with 26 percent of households last year.
For each of the last 22 years, Gallup has conducted 1,500 in-home interviews. The 1994 poll will not be completed until the end of the year, but Gallup conducted an interim telephone poll of 1,000 interviews in late June. It has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
If the present surge continues, Mr. Butterfield said, by the end of the year, Americans will have spent more than $50 a household on vegetable gardening, up from $43 last year.
Industry executives corroborate the upswing as well. "I think people were suffering from cabin fever, after being snowed under, this winter," said George Ball, chief executive of the W. Atlee Burpee Company of Warminster, Pa., explaining his company's increasing sales. "Spring broke late this year, and gardeners were just champing at the bit."
Last year "the weather wasn't good, all over the country," said Horace Hagedorn, the 79-year-old founder and chief executive of Stern's Miracle-Gro of Port Washington, L.I. There was rain and flooding in the Midwest, he said, and in the East a hot summer that discouraged many gardeners from planting, weeding and picking.
Stern's Miracle-Gro Plant Food is the market leader among home garden fertilizers, and its sales have often served as an industry barometer. This year sales of the company's water-soluble fertilizer are up 15 percent, Mr. Hagedorn said.
Paul Pichieri, manager of Ploch's Garden Center in Clifton, N.J., a large retail outlet, suggested a link between the gardening sales gain and the recovering economy. "Over the last year a lot of people bought houses thanks to the low interest rates, and they've really been putting in the vegetables," he said.
Gardening sales at Ploch's were up 20 percent in April and May during the vegetable-buying peak, Mr. Pichieri said, and sales have been "generally up" ever since. "Perhaps people have extra disposable income this year," he said.
Since 85 percent of vegetable gardeners grow tomatoes, according to the National Lawn and Garden Distributors Association, it means that the remainder of August will be the time of tomato mania. In fact, one of the nation's premier discount retailers of exotic specialty produce, Gourmet Garage in Manhattan, has initiated its own "Great Tomato Roundup," a contest for home gardeners.
The winning Lycopersicon esculentum, a humble tomato, will take the place of honor in a store that has sold truffled liver mousse and chanterelles. The victorious gardener "is to receive $500," said John Gottfried, the store's co-founder, "which, when you consider the cost of terrace gardening in Manhattan, could be the price tag of a single tomato."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Israel's Volatile Market Braces for an Onslaught

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
ISRAEL'S stock market is the fastest-growing, most volatile, riskiest exchange in the risk-taking Middle East. This week, its investors got an added shot of uncertainty.
The Israeli Government on Tuesday proposed a 10 percent tax on stock transactions, and braced itself for a donnybrook. In the tax-heavy country, stock transactions are one of the few things that escape the tax collector. The last time the Government tried to institute such a tax, 30 years ago, it roiled the market. 
 To give investors' tempers time to cool, the Government closed the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, where 616 stocks trade, until tomorrow. Many analysts expect a large, if temporary, selloff when it reopens. "I hope it will be O.K. Sunday," Doron Levy, Israel's income tax commissioner, said. "I am crossing my fingers."
Under the sketchy proposal by the dominant Labor Party, a 10 percent tax on stock profits would be imposed beginning Jan. 1 on both Israeli citizens and foreigners. The tax, which needs the approval of the Israeli Parliament would be adjusted for inflation and probably collected by banks and brokerage firms.
The tax would raise about $180 million, according to the Government, which intends to make offsetting tax cuts elsewhere to spur investment. The plan is the brainchild of Jacob Frenkel, the governor of the Israeli central bank and a former University of Chicago economist.
The Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is hoping the tax will encourage Israelis to view their stocks as long-term investments and thereby reduce the market's notorious volatility. If it succeeds, long-term investors could benefit. Last year, the top 100 stocks on the Tel Aviv exchange rose 21 percent, compared with a 13 percent increase in the Dow Jones industrial average. But inflation fears have pushed those Israeli stocks down 28 percent this year, while the Dow has recovered to virtually where it started the year.
 "Israelis aren't known as smart investors," said Victor Halpert, research manager for Israel Equity Research and Management Ltd. in Chicago. "That's because a long-term investment in Israel is a month."
Such short investment horizons help explain why Israelis are girding for a sharp stock selloff. Israeli mutual funds expect a surge of redemptions by individual investors when the market reopens.
Based on reaction in New York at the end of the week, the mutual funds have reason to be worried. "Five minutes after the tax announcement on Tuesday, we were buried underneath phone calls," said Eddy Shalev, managing director of the Tel Aviv office of Oscar Gruss & Son of New York, a major dealer in Israeli stocks. "People wanted to sell stocks like crazy in New York because they couldn't do it in Israel."
Moreover, Israeli companies that issue American depository receipts, which are traded on American exchanges and represent shares of foreign companies, saw those receipts fall sharply at the end of last week. Even a well-regarded company, like Teva Pharmaceutical, with $502 million in revenues last year, was not spared. Its A.D.R.'s fell to $26.125 on Friday from $27.938 on Monday, before the tax proposal was announced. In all, about 60 Israeli companies and companies with substantial Israeli holdings are listed on the New York, American excahnges and on Nasdaq.
For the short run, Israeli stocks may become a bargain for those brave enough to risk the churning waters. "If the Israelis are going to give their stocks away, Americans should step in and buy them," said Robert J. Mittleman, chief executive officer of Oscar Gruss & Son.
Besides Teva, Mr. Mittleman's firm recommends Scitex, a computer software developer, ECI Telecom, a maker of telecommunications equipment, and Tadiran, a military contractor that also makes communications equipment. Most of those companies' A.D.R.'s have fallen since the proposal was announced.
The growing prospects for peace in the Middle East, despite recent bloodshed in Gaza and Jericho, have been good for the 41-year-old Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. From about $4 billion in market capitalization in 1984, the exchange grew to nearly $44 billion in 1993. A bear market for much of this year, fed by inflation fears, knocked that capitalization to some $37 billion in May. Most American investors in Israel have been big institutions, including mutual fund companies like Fidelity Investments and pension funds like the New York State Teachers Retirement System.
Adopting a gains tax could have surprising consequences, said Mark Meiras, managing director of Pacific Mediterranean Capital Markets, an investment bank in Herzelia, Israel. As in Switzerland, anonymous numbered bank accounts are popular.
"There is perhaps $2 billion to $4 billion of gray money -- I hesitate to say black money -- in Israel," Mr. Meiras said. "With the increased scrutiny that comes from collecting the tax, a lot of this money may simply vanish." Based on Mr. Meiras's estimate, that would be the equivalent of 5 to 10 percent of the country's stock market capitalization.
In a conference call with American and British institutional investors yesterday, Meyer Shavit, Israel's Commissioner of Capital Markets, emphasized that the Government did not plan major changes in its tax proposal, such as allowing stock losses to offset profits. A member of Parliament, however, is said to be preparing just such an amendment.
Mr. Shavit said the Government wanted to encourage long-term investment and, therefore, might consider a sliding scale, imposing a 10 percent gains tax on investments held for just one year and smaller tax bites on investments held longer.

HEADLINE: BANKING;
Top Rates and Best Deals On Certificates of Deposit

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
WITH interest rates rising and the stock market stagnating, certificates of deposit provide a soothing choice for conservative investors. Some banks are dusting off C.D.'s with gimmicks, like rates that adjust or that track the stock market, for wider appeal. But these souped-up products often carry below-average rates and may lock in investors for long terms.
"Go short term and roll over," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. "Don't lock in at long-term rates, because you'll be able to get higher numbers down the road." 
 Even in the short term, though, investors with enough to invest will do better with Treasury securities. The rate on a six-month T-bill, which can be bought in denominations as small as $10,000, rose 1.74 percentage points from Feb. 2 through Wednesday, when it stood at 4.90 percent. In the same period the average rate on a six-month C.D. rose 0.78 of a percentage point, to 3.53 percent.
In lieu of raising their rates, banks often try to capture attention with unusual products. Especially popular are certificates with flexible rates, sold with names like "rising-rate," "bump-up" or "two-step."
The Heritage Bank in Watertown, Conn., offers an 18-month certificate with a recent rate of 4.60 percent. If interest rates rise, a depositor can adjust once during the term.
Adding a few bells and whistles, Bank Leumi Trust in New York offers a two-year C.D., "Triple Choice Time Deposit," which allows one addition in the first year. Also, depositors can lock in a new rate once and can make one withdrawal of up to half the principal without penalty. On Wednesday, the rate was 4.75 percent.
People who believe the stock market correction presents a buying opportunity but are risk averse will find a middle ground in the form of bank deposits linked to a stock index, typically the Standard & Poor's 500.
Although Bankers Trust and the Republic National Bank of New York recently discontinued their stock-indexed C.D.'s, others can be found. Republic's one-year certificates that matured earlier this month returned only 1.89 percent (75 percent of the return of the Standard & Poor's 500 over the last year) and 2.26 percent (50 percent of the S.& P. 500 plus one percentage point).
To help investors guard against such poor returns, Charter One Financial in Cleveland is offering three-year and five-year Wall Street C.D.'s that pay returns based on the average quarterly rise of the S.& P. 500. Even if the index does not rise, the bank guarantees at least a 5 percent annual return for a five-year certificate, or 4 percent for three years.
"To the best of our knowledge, no other insured stock-indexed C.D. in the nation offers guaranteed minimum returns as high," Charles John Koch, president of Charter One, said.
Perhaps, but in exchange for the guarantee investors lock up their money for the long term, and the guaranteed rate is below the national average of 5.53 percent for a five-year certificate on Wednesday. The highest rate on Wednesday was 6.65 percent from MBNA America in Wilmington, Del., reported The Bank Rate Monitor (800) 327-7717.
Below-average rates are also common among certificates that adjust and that have unusual features, like penalty-free withdrawals or interest paid up front. The highest rates tend to be at banks in regions with the strongest economies -- the Midwest, the Rocky Mountain states and the South, Mr. Heady said.
Probably the only rates well above average are paid on the "naked" C.D.'s offered by institutions that operate without Federal deposit insurance, like Home Savings and Loan in Oklahoma City, which offers a six-month certificate at 5.50 percent and a one-year certificate at 6 percent.

HEADLINE: Too Little Money for Mandates

 BODY:
Last year's motor-voter act requires states to arrange for registering people to vote when they apply for driver's licenses. That is a proper matter for Federal law, strongly supported by this page. But it was also another case of Washington ordering state action without money to pay for it -- an "unfunded mandate" that will cost states tens of millions of dollars a year.
The cost of such mandates has become so burdensome for state and local governments that they are lobbying for relief; state and local authorities seek relief in Congress, while local authorities also seek relief in their state capitals. But it is wrong to demand, as some do, that governments pay for all they decree. As a matter of national policy, some things -- like civil rights -- are local responsibilities but governed by Federal statute. Unemployment insurance is another example. 
 There is no clear line between mandates that should be federally financed and those that should not be. Some require substantial outlays, like Medicaid and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Others are small or cannot even be measured, like the repeal of automatic retirement at age 65. The funding issue is often cloaked in constitutional debate about Federal versus state powers, but commonly resolved by how much money is available and how much muscle the interested parties apply.
Before the Federal deficit ballooned in the Reagan years, Congress voted money for mandated programs more often than it does now; in the deficit squeeze it kept on mandating, but cut the money. The Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations counts 27 major laws enacted in the 1980's with new or expanded regulatory impact at state and local levels -- more than in any previous decade. Among them are laws on fair housing, drug-free workplaces, clean air, child abuse, ocean dumping and highway safety.
Governors and mayors are fighting unfunded mandates because their budgets are tight too; the last thing they need is orders from Washington to spend more, which forces them to tax more. But their campaign also serves conservatives who fight government regulation in general, including state and local regulation.
Governors who rail against the supposed injustice of Federal mandates are guilty themselves, of burdening local governments with state mandates. The New Jersey Legislature recently considered repealing some, such as a requirement that police chiefs be paid at least 5 percent more than deputy chiefs. Mayors want it repealed, but when chiefs turned up en masse in Trenton to object, the repeal bill died.
The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee has approved a bill co-sponsored by its chairman, John Glenn of Ohio, and Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho. It is less rigid than an earlier proposal by Senator Kempthorne and others to require funding for all Federal mandates, which would pose an insurmountable roadblock to needed legislation.
The committee bill would require cost estimates by the Congressional Budget Office early in the gestation of bills that mandate state or local action, with updated estimates along the way. Currently, the Budget Office estimates the cost only after a bill comes out of committee, too late to be useful in the initial shaping. The committee bill also requires Congress to consider how to pay the cost, and to take a vote on payment if a member asks for it.
Proposed amendments could still sink the Glenn-Kempthorne compromise. One would require early cost estimates for mandates imposed on the private sector as well. That makes sense too, but it is so broad that the process would bog down; it makes more sense to start on a smaller scale.
The basic problem of unfunded mandates is so obvious it should not need a law. But it does, and Glenn-Kempthorne meets that need. The cost of even the worthiest cause warrants consideration.
