HEADLINE: Brazil Is Now Leading Foreign Supplier of Handguns to the U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil

 BODY:
With taxes and permit requirements hurting sales at home, Brazilian handgun manufacturers are increasing exports, making their country the leading foreign supplier of handguns to the United States.
"The U.S. is now our largest market," said Carlos Alberto Murgel, president of Brazil's largest handgun manufacturer, Forjas Taurus S. A. Taurus now accounts for about 10 percent of all handguns sold in the United States. 
 With highly efficient assembly lines in this southern city, Brazil's largest handgun manufacturers feed American demand for reliable, inexpensive guns. The American market receives about 75 percent of Taurus exports and about one half of the production of Brazil's second-largest handgun maker, Amadeo Rossi S. A.
According to one recent survey, Brazil exports 775,000 handguns a year -- three times the number sold annually in this country of 160 million people.
The spread of Brazilian-made handguns was underscored in April when Mexican police officials identified a .38-caliber Taurus revolver as the weapon used to kill Mexico's leading presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio. The gun trail passes through a California gun shop to a Porto Alegre assembly line.
Here in this gray workaday city, in the southeastern corner of Brazil nearly 700 miles from Rio de Janeiro, Taurus managers have applied the driving business techniques of industrialized countries to transform a dusty, 55-year-old company.
Benefiting from a recent $20 million investment in new machinery, Taurus assembly lines churned out almost half a million handguns last year. Of these, about 230,000 went to the United States. Rossi, the only other Brazilian handgun exporter, has 3 percent of the United States market.
The importance of the American market to gun makers is as clear as the plaque on Mr. Murgel's office wall: "If guns are outlawed, only outlaws will have guns."
Because the Brazilian Government does not agree with that philosophy, Mr. Murgel has made exports the key to growth at his company. Last year, 80 percent of Taurus's $85 million in sales were to overseas markets.
At home, a thicket of regulations discourages legal handgun ownership.
With taxes accounting for nearly 75 percent of Brazilian sales prices for guns, Taurus revolvers are often twice as expensive here as in Miami. In addition, many Brazilian states require waiting periods before handgun purchases. After submitting proof of fixed residence and employment, a buyer has to wait up to two weeks for a criminal record check.
In Rio de Janeiro, to get a permit to carry a handgun, an applicant must submit character references from three neighbors, results of medical and psychiatric tests and a certificate from a police firearms course.
Responding to public nervousness about firearms and crime, Rio's Mayor, Cesar Maia, decreed in January a ban on all gun sales in Rio. The ban was ruled unconstitutional.
Brazilian civilians are not allowed to carry handguns more powerful than a .38-caliber pistol. As a result, the Taurus line of high-powered weapons is almost entirely for export.
Because of these and other restrictions, an estimated 400 small gun shops in Brazil have closed since 1990, the year Brazil entered a sharp recession.
To guarantee access to the American market, Taurus has become a Brazilian multinational company, operating a subsidiary plant in Miami: Taurus International Manufacturing Inc.
"My fear is that things will go too far in one direction," Mr. Murgel said when asked if he worried that controls will tighten on handgun sales in the United States.
"We arms manufacturers are not criminals," he said. "We make a product that could be a deterrent to crime."

HEADLINE: Siberia: 5 Million Miles of Frozen Dreams

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YAKUTSK, Russia

 BODY:
They shot it out at noon, not long after a hard summer rain had turned the city roads to mud. By the time the turf battle for one of Siberia's wildest outposts had ended, two gang leaders lay dead, six others were on their way to the hospital, and this untamed city -- filled with enough strivers, gamblers, con men and thieves to make Dodge City seem like Larchmont -- had taken one step closer to anarchy.
"This has always been a crazy place but it sure is getting wilder," said Rima Yakovleva, a 28-year-old fur trader whose friend was killed in the shootout this month. "When people say freedom is dangerous in Russia I think I know what they mean. Because no place is freer or more dangerous than Siberia." 
 She may be right. Siberia has always been animated by a frontier spirit, a combustible blend of danger and possibility. Bigger than anyplace on earth -- it would take India, the United States and much of Western Europe to fill it up -- the region stretching roughly from the Urals to the Sea of Okhotsk has for centuries produced suffering and dread on a scale practically unrivaled in the world. Siberia: the word itself has become a synonym for isolation, exile and despair.
Yet Siberia is not a simple, or even a single, place these days. It is the most reactionary part of Russia, and the most open. Democracy, opportunity and entrepreneurial adventure are rapidly on the rise. So are poverty, desolation and rage.
A speculator would drool over the natural treasures that lie beneath the frozen earth here: more diamonds, more gold, more silver, tin, lumber and oil than anywhere in the world. Yet thousands of northern villages established to mine that wealth are dying. Millionaires with car phones carry their rubles in huge bricks. Yet there may never have been a time, not even when Stalin turned Siberia into one of history's biggest prison camps, when more people here have lived with less hope for the future.
Nowhere are the complicated chords of the emerging Russia more evident than here in central Siberia, where most homes lack running water and rich young men cruise the unpaved roadways in $40,000 Jeeps.
Yakutia -- with the world's biggest coal fields, much of the oil in the former Soviet Union and nearly all of its diamonds and tin -- has as much promise for development as any place in a Russia hungry for exports. But local newspapers are filled with advertisements from people so desperate to get out that they are offering to trade large apartments for a single container to box and ship their possessions to Moscow.
"There are just not many reasons for being optimistic about Siberia," said Aleksei A. Tomtosov, the Mayor of Yakutsk, which with 200,000 residents is the largest city in Yakutia, a 1.2-million-square-mile region.
"People have been sent here with promises that have not been kept," Mr. Tomtosov said. "Food is three times more expensive here than in Moscow. Every trained person who can get a job somewhere else is leaving. I know a lot of people are making money here now, but I think more are losing everything they believed in. I don't think anybody had any idea the free market could be so cruel."
 
The Lure
Diamonds Glitter In the Permafrost
 It is in the "North," an often majestically unkempt, seemingly unbroken expanse of tundra and permafrost that covers the top two-thirds of Russia, where the new realities of the nation have perhaps been most painful. Until two years ago, nearly 11 million people lived here, mostly in thousands of small mining towns set up by the Soviets to harness the wealth of the land east of the Urals. But at least a million have fled since then, and officials here and in Moscow worry that another million will leave in the next year.
Many of the region's aging residents were lured there during the glory days of Communism with promises of extra pay, fancy vacations, subsidized food and a guaranteed pension after 15 years of work. They followed their ideals and what was called "the long ruble," the extra money and prestige that went with the extra hardships.
"You came here and you were special," said Aleksandr I. Gritskevich, a 45-year-old police officer in Verkhoyansk, a particularly bleak Arctic town that is most famous for its claim of registering the lowest temperature ever recorded in a settled place (90.04 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit).
Like many northern villages, the town, 400 miles north of Yakutsk, is a monument to abandoned Soviet dreams. There is a half-built day care center, a pile of bricks that was going to be a bakery and an empty space for the new school.
"It just fell apart a couple of years back," Mr. Gritskevich said. "All of a sudden it was like we were dead."
 
Towns Built on Hope
 As long as the promises held, the privations had all seemed worth it. Frontier towns like Verkhoyansk, Sangar, and Komsomolsk-on-Amur were cobbled together with wood beams and blind hope. The deal was simple: survive the coldest weather in the world, harvest the oil fields, mines and rivers, and live the communist good life back in the European part of the country forever after. The deal held for at least two decades.
But it is over now. Investment is rapidly falling in these remote towns, largely because they cost way too much to support in any rational economy. Almost nothing grows on the icy ground, so everything -- apples, milk, tomatoes, clothes -- must be imported. Vodka, even more essential here than in most parts of Russia, costs about $7 a bottle, or four times what it costs in Moscow. It costs almost $17 a gram to extract gold from Siberian mines, compared with $13 to purchase a gram on the open market. It doesn't take Karl Marx or Milton Friedman to figure out the implications of that kind of economics.
Salaries remain higher than in other parts of the country, but few people are working these days and fewer of them are still getting paid. Without the type of subsidies that existed in the past, nobody knows how to keep these cities alive.
 
Workers Held Hostage
 "This is a catastrophic situation," said Vladimir Sturov, a member of the Russian Parliament from Siberia. "The people in the north are literally hostages. They have been invited there by the state and now we can't get them out."
When the Soviet Union started to fall apart, Siberia, always fiercely individualistic, was among the first places to proclaim its independence. Regions like Yakutia, Magadan and Khabarovsk began to think about setting up a separate republic. They saw "Russia," as they still call the European part of the country, as a big government that did little for them but fritter away their great wealth or turn it into dollars for other people.
Although the calls for secession have faded away, there is some truth to the complaint: even last year the Russian far north produced 15 percent of the country's gross national product but almost 60 percent of its hard currency earnings.
"People here are living through one of the greatest betrayals in Russian history," said Tamara S. Shamshurina, editor of the newspapers Success and Youth of Yakutia, who has spent her life in the region and has no desire to leave it. "They are not getting what they deserve. They are stranded, living like animals, without a hope in the world."
 
The Reality
Cellular Phones And Outhouses
 There is a hope of course: the marketplace. It has already begun to work in the Far East. In Khabarovsk, near the Manchurian border, restaurant and hotel toilets have automatic heating sensors, there are satellite telephones in the airport, and cellular phones are for sale on the street. Only 200 miles away, though, in Komsomolsk-on-Amur, there are virtually no public toilets and people still have to wait in line at the central post office to get permission to place a telephone call out of the city.
In Yakutsk, perhaps the most adventurous of Siberian cities, hundreds of young entrepreneurs from Russia and many other countries are eager to develop the land, harvest the forests, build factories, housing and cities. There are diamond and gold stores all along the main street, but almost no other street in town is paved. Water pumps are still the norm, and wooden outhouses are used by the vast majority of people.
Even now, Yakutsk has the look of a boom town during the California Gold Rush. It is said to be the only city in the world built completely on permafrost, the ice that sits permanently beneath the soil, so shiny insulated pipes thread surreally through the air, buildings stand on concrete pylons, and the Lena River freezes solid by the first of October when temperatures begin their mind-boggling plunge below zero.
But none of that stops the diehards. Despite annual interest rates at banks that have inched beyond 200 percent, there are many "players" in town -- people eager to get diamonds, gold or phosphate out of the ground. It is a place with a million schemes, where fast talk can make you rich in a week, or get you killed in a minute. And now, it is a place where economic realities, and the new gangs, rule.
 
Survival of Economic Fittest
 A few weeks ago the first car dealership in town was burned to the ground right before its grand opening. Nobody considered it an accident. In most cases, though, the rules are clear: if a project has merit it can succeed; if a city should die it will.
"Moving to solid economics, to a market, has been a very difficult thing for all of us," said Viktor S. Budishchev, president of Olivico, a successful new conglomerate here that deals in everything from Volvo car parts to construction cranes.
"But we have done it and we all have to do it," he said. "We have to take this place, Siberia, that was set up in the most irrational way by the Soviets, and we have to make some sense of it. That means many of the cities they constructed simply should not be. The market can make these decisions better than we can."
Mr. Budishchev conceded that the death of such towns was "painful for all those who live there, a catastrophe of course." But, he added, "if they can't sustain themselves in a real economy what should we do about it?"
 
The Future
Moscow Fiddles As Siberia Freezes
 For Siberia that is the ultimate question: What should we do about it? Despite its depressing reputation, the promise of the region, even its stark beauty, is obvious to anyone who has been there. But Moscow is not doing a thing to encourage the free market to flourish, so the people who get ahead are those who hustle the fast buck.
New import taxes and duties were imposed across the nation on July 1. In Alaska and in Canada's Northwest Territories -- comparably difficult places to invest and work -- there are long lists of tax incentives for companies willing to brave the frontier. Russia permits no such thing.
Experts say that while many cities exist where it makes no sense for people to live -- on the frigid permafrost, deep into the Arctic Circle, on rivers that freeze 8 months a year -- there are ways of turning big profits in Siberia. The main one is simple: instead of erecting huge, inefficient towns that need to be heated and fed from the west all winter, it would be better to rotate mining crews the way they do on oil rigs in the North Sea.
 
Promises Broken or Ignored
 "The Russians know all this," said Ronald W. Miller, a lawyer based in Alaska who represents several mining, fishing and timber concerns scattered across Siberia.
The Government has acknowledged the difficulties in working in Siberia, pledging tax breaks and subsidies to enterprises. But so far none have materialized. This year, the Russian Parliament cut subsidies to the northern territories nearly in half, from 9.5 trillion rubles to 5.5 trillion rubles, making it even more difficult for workers there to feel that the Government is committed to them.
"I just don't think they give a damn," Mr. Miller said. "Everyone talks about the problems of making money in Siberia. Well there is really one problem: the Government doesn't want anybody to do it. The technology is there for getting these gems out of the ground. There are companies that know how to and want to do it. We are here because, well, like they say, there's gold in them hills. But everyone has a breaking point. In Siberia its tough to reach, but if somebody doesn't pay attention a lot of people are going to reach it soon."

HEADLINE: To Change or Not to Change? Mexicans Are Voting Today

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20

 BODY:
How much change do Mexicans want?
The question has echoed throughout the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari, asked again and again as he dismantled a protectionist, state-run economy, toppled idols of the 1910 Revolution, and moved under rising pressure to cede some of his party's authoritarian control of the political system. 
 As they prepared to choose a successor to Mr. Salinas on Sunday, many Mexicans appeared fed up with the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has held power for 65 years. Peasant rebels in southern Chiapas State threatened new fighting if the election was not clean. Middle-class housewives complained of crime and corruption that seemed only to rise, along with their taxes.
But while opponents have tested the party called the PRI as never before, much of the anger that threatened to topple it only a few months ago seems to have been tempered, much of the frustration put aside. If several of the opinion polls are to be believed, the governing party candidate, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, leads his closest competitor by roughly 20 points.
 
'Reluctant to Change'
 "People report that things are worse, or that if they are not worse for them personally, they perceive them as being worse in general," said John Bailey, an expert on Mexican politics who heads the Latin American studies department at Georgetown University in Washington. "And yet they are reluctant to change; they are afraid of change."
With the polls carefully taken but their validity uncertain, and about a fifth of the voters saying they are undecided, opposition politicians have insisted that a surprise is not out of the question. But Mr. Zedillo's two main rivals showed little sign of gathering momentum as the race came to an end.
Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the somber leftist leader who broke from the PRI seven years ago, has campaigned vigorously and with a far better organization than he had in 1988, when many Mexicans believe he was robbed of victory.
The crowds he has drawn have appeared outsized given his modest support in the polls. He has already called on his supporters to take to the streets Monday, threatening demonstrations if the vote is clouded by fraud. But with Mr. Cardenas getting barely 10 percent backing in recent surveys, few independent analysts still count him in the race.
The candidate of the right-of-center National Action Party, Diego Fernandez de Cevallos, has held on to about twice the support of Mr. Cardenas with a campaign promising, "The only change that's safe."
But after surging forward in the polls by battering Mr. Zedillo in the country's first debate among major presidential candidates, on May 12, Mr. Fernandez almost vanished from public view, campaigning infrequently while he said he was preparing for a second debate, which never took place.
 
Does He Want to Win?
 The combative, supremely confident man who began to persuade many Mexicans that the PRI might finally be beaten has never quite returned. His rallies have often been small, his presence on the hustings lackluster. Some of his supporters have questioned whether the former congressman, a key opposition supporter of Mr. Salinas's economic and political reforms, really wants to win.
Although the PRI campaign may have been hurt by widespread suspicions that hard-line elements of the party may have had a role in the assassination in March of its first presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, Mr. Zedillo has continued to fight with overwhelming advantages.
Having lost badly in the first debate, Mr. Zedillo avoided a promised rematch. Even with many PRI members unenthusiastic about his candidacy, the party has cranked up its formidable machine again, marshaling the energies of hundreds of thousands of Mexicans whose livelihood depends on its power.
In a final report on the election campaign, the country's most prominent observer group, Civic Alliance, said on Friday that the conditions for a fair and reliable contest "have not existed nor do they exist yet." Today, the group made public samples of what it said were huge stacks of blank copies of the backs of voter registration cards. The copies, discovered by accident in a Mexico City print shop, appeared to have been produced so people could alter their cards to vote repeatedly.
On Thursday in the west coast town of Coyuca de Benitez, foreign election observers reported the sort of scene that has continued to blur the lines between the PRI and the Government, new laws and all.
 
The Message Is Clear
 As heavily armed policemen surrounded the town plaza and military helicopters and planes buzzed overhead, hundreds of peasants lined up to receive subsidy checks from a Government agricultural program, the leader of an observer team, Eric F. Quezada, said. Political parties were barred from campaigning after Wednesday and the program itself has been prohibited from advertising in the weeks before the vote, but the message was nonetheless clear: Vote for the PRI and continue to cash in.
For all of his dependence on the powers of incumbency, however, Mr. Zedillo has by no means run on Mr. Salinas's record.
For instance, Mr. Zedillo, a former Minister of the Budget and of Education, has scarely mentioned the North American Free Trade Agreement, the trophy that only last fall seemed to represent sure Mexican steps toward the developed world. With discontent rife in the countryside, Mr. Zedillo has also appeared to evade discussion of some of the most contentious changes of the Salinas Administration, including the cancellation of the revolution's standing promise of land for peasants.
Instead, Mr. Zedillo has laid out proposals for changes in the economy, social programs, the environment and the corrupt legal system. And in an election in which Mexicans under the age of 40 make up 63.3 percent of the eligible voters, the 42-year-old Yale-educated economist has begun to strike even some of his critics as the most experienced and forward-looking man in the race.
 
'Civil Society' on the Move
 Mr. Zedillo himself has played only lightly on the fears of Mexicans, mostly by accusing Mr. Cardenas of threatening violence. But other PRI leaders have been less subtle. In some areas where opposition support is strong, recent army sweeps have also been understood by many people as an ominous message of what might happen should the PRI lose.
Carlos Arevalo, 30, a truck driver who lives near the western city of Guadalajara, said he had heard Mr. Salinas promise to hand over power to whoever won a fair vote but put more stock in reports of the army getting new helicopters, of big troop deployments in the countryside, and of 500 assault rifles disappearing from a stockpile in the coastal city of Puerto Vallarta.
"There will be a war if the PRI does not win, and if there is a war, nobody is going to turn over anything to anyone," Mr. Arevalo predicted, saying he would vote for the governing party despite his stronger sympathies for the conservative opposition. "If the PRI wins, people will be out in the streets, but there will be fewer of them."
Such images clash with others of the campaign: tens of thousands of volunteers spreading out around the country to observe the vote; "citizen magistrates" taking over the federal elections board from the Government; delegates trooping into the rain forest for a "National Democratic Convention" organized by the rebels in Chiapas; politicians and intellectuals of different ideologies joining to press for further democratic reforms.
"Ahead of the parties, beyond the elections, what is on the move in Mexico is civil society," the novelist Carlos Fuentes wrote in an article published today in the Mexico City newspaper La Jornada.
 
Cynicism Still Prevails
 The surge of citizen involvement in the elections is indeed remarkable for a country in which important political decisions have been left largely to bargaining among elites since the last clearly free election in 1911. Yet from conversations with hundreds of voters in recent months and the polls that have registered their most important concerns, the movement in support of democracy appears still an incipient counterweight to the cynicism with which many Mexicans look on their politics.
"Imagine!" demanded Hector Arias, 25, a salesman hanging out in front of his squat row house in a working-class Guadalajara neighborhood. "These guys in power are rich and they steal! What would the others, who are poor, do if they take over? If there is real change, we will be in trouble."
Standing nearby, a friend of Mr. Arias, a 46-year-old butcher named Nestor Melgarejo, begged to differ.
"We are in trouble now," he insisted. "Who doesn't have three jobs? Who has enough to eat? What we are now is in trouble!"
So why wouldn't Mr. Melgarejo be voting for Mr. Fernandez, whom he described as his favorite candidate?
"The Congress will still be controlled by the PRI," the butcher reasoned. "All the bureaucracy will still be of the PRI. They would wipe him out."
 
Some Shared Pledges
 In fact, many analysts believe the PRI is far more likely to lose its control over the Congress than it is the presidency. Depending on its magnitude, such a loss could turn the legislature, long a rubber stamp for executive decisions, into a forum of real influence over Government policy.
Less directly, the probability that the next President will not receive a majority vote could force whoever takes office to follow through on the main candidates' shared pledges to cede more power to state governments and the judiciary and to include rival parties in the next Cabinet.
"Just as they opened us up to competition from abroad, they are going to have to face more political competition in this country," one of Mexico's most powerful industrialists, who asked not to be identified, said this week in the northern city of Monterrey. "That is going to force them to take decisions more carefully, to be less arbitrary. The PRI may remain in power, but it will remain there only because people want it to."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "THE LEADING CANDIDATES: Vying for the Mexican Presidency"
 
National Action Party
Partido Accion Nacional
 
Diego Fernandez de Cevallos, 53.
A civil litigation lawyer who has long been involved in politics, Fernandez served in the Mexican Congress from 1991 until this year. He was one of the most vocal opposition leaders negotiating with the Government over economic and other reforms instituted by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
Fernandez surged into contention with a strong performance in the country's first-ever presidential debate, on May 12, but faded in late June and July, campaigning infrequently and failing to press for an expected second debate.
Fernandez is associated with the PAN's most socially conservative wing, and his strong opposition to the legalization of abortion has been an issue in the campaign. He has sharply criticized Government economic policy, calling for greater social spending and more competition, particularly among newly privatized banks.
 
Democratic Revolutionary Party
Partido de la Revolucion Democratica
 
Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, 60
Cardenas led a four-party leftist coalition in the 1988 election that won more than 30 percent of the vote. In 1989 he helped found the P.R.D., which has become Mexico's strongest leftist party.
During his two campaigns, Cardenas has called for the Government to be more active in distributing wealth, although in recent months he has embraced more free-market policies.
He is the son of a national hero and former President, Lazaro Cardenas del Rio. Before splitting with the goerning party in 1987, Cardenas was Governor of the state of Michoacan and a federal Senator. He graduated from the National Autonomous University of Mexico in 1956 with a degree in civil engineering; in the early 1970's he directed a steel plant bearing his father's name.
 
Institutional Revolutionary Party
Partido Revolucionario Institucional
 
Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, 42,
Zedillo is the former campaign manager for Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, the former PRI candidate, who was assassinated on March 23.
As one of the principal technocrats of the Salinas Administration, he helped develop and carry out sweeping economic reforms over the last five years. He served as the Education Minister from 1992-1993, and Planning and Budget Minister from 1988-1992. Zedillo has pledged to continue the economic policies of the Salinas Administration and separate the ruling party from the Government.
He received a doctorate from Yale University in economics in 1978, writing his dissertation on managing government debt. During his four-month campaign, he has stressed his working-class origins: he grew up in the border city of Mexicali, Baja California, where his father was an electrician.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN CUBA;
Cuba Assails Clinton on Guantanamo Detentions

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Cuba accused President Clinton of planning a "concentration camp" at Guantanamo Bay, where American officials are detaining rafters seeking to enter the United States.
A Foreign Ministry statement said Cuba strongly rejected the United States use of the Guantanamo Bay base, on Cuba's southeast tip, to house Cuban refugees. Washington had decided to add to a "dangerous situation," the statement said, referring to some 15,000 Haitian boat people already camped at the base and to previous protests by Havana over this use of the base. 
 The statement also repeated Cuba's longstanding claim that the base, on land leased to the United States early this century, is an illegal occupation of Cuban territory.
Despite Mr. Clinton's announcement of a new policy of turning away refugees, dozens of Cubans continued to set out to sea from at least one spot, Cojimar, east of the Cuban capital.
The town, 10 miles from Havana, has been a focal point for the recent surge in Cubans leaving by sea. The rise is apparently because Cuban authorities have begun turning a blind eye to people trying to leave the island, so long as they set off in their own vessel.
 
A $1,500 Raft
 On Friday night, small crowds of people milled around Cojimar's rocky shore as they have done for the last few days, preparing rafts or watching the latest departure. One man wandered around offering a raft for sale for $1,500.
Most people, asked about why they are undertaking such a perilous journey, cite economic reasons, saying they are fed up with battling severe shortages amid Cuba's current economic crisis. Many of those who leave are young men.
People on the beach at Cojimar seemed unconcerned by the prospect of going to the Guantanamo Bay base. Some seemed not to believe they would be sent to there. Others said that they would press ahead anyway with their plans.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: WASHINGTON AT WORK;
Budget Director, the Conscience of Congress, Turns Ideas Into Dollar Signs

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
There are moments in this final phase of the health care struggle when people yearn, just a little, for the old leap-of-faith days of policy-making. Before the Congressional Budget Office was tallying up the costs, the risks and the impact on the deficit of every good intention.
Robert D. Reischauer, the 53-year-old director of the budget office, is smack in the center of the legislative action these days. Mr. Reischauer, a tall, ascetic-looking economist, strides from the meetings of the "mainstream coalition" in the Senate to the huddles of the Democratic leaders in the House. He and his 20 health analysts are supposed to function as a careful, wary superego in the Congressional psyche. (Do you realize the subsidies it takes to reduce the number of uninsured from 15 to 10 percent of the population? Do you recognize the difficulty in turning over vast new regulatory responsibilities to the states?) 
 Lawmakers look to the budget office as an arbiter in a terrifyingly complicated, fiercely partisan debate. But the C.B.O. has also become a target as the effort to pass a health care bill comes dangerously close to running out of time -- and as more and more of what is left is spent "waiting for C.B.O. estimates." Has the budget office become the latest institution to be overwhelmed by the health care struggle?
"Overwhelmed would imply we're flailing around," Mr. Reischauer said in an interview on Thursday night in his office at the foot of Capitol Hill. "And we aren't flailing around. We're working long hours, without relief, but not overwhelmed. The task is monumental, and the time frame that people would like to have our analyses in is very short."
At that moment, Mr. Reischauer and his staff were responsible for analyzing three thick health care plans in the House and the principal Republican plan in the Senate. House Democratic leaders had just announced that they might have to put off debate and floor action on health care until after Labor Day -- a move that dismayed many advocates of health care restructuring -- because they had yet to receive the necessary estimates from the C.B.O.
 
Keeping a Nightmare at Bay
 On Thursday morning, Mr. Reischauer and a few top aides provided guidance to the "mainstream group" in the Senate, meeting with them in their crowded clubhouse in the Capitol. ("It's like an Indian sweat lodge," Mr. Reischauer said. "Twenty-five senators in their shirtsleeves, roasting hot, probably 45 or 50 staff hanging off the walls.")
Then, topping off the workload, he was asked, as of Thursday evening, to analyze 93 amendments to the Democratic health bill on the floor of the Senate. All of this, of course, concerns one-seventh of the American economy.
"I guess my worst nightmare would be that some poorly thought-out plan is passed, and the American people would greet that plan with tremendous dissatisfaction, and it's repealed two years from now," Mr. Reischauer said.
The C.B.O. was created during the Nixon Administration, largely because Congress wanted its own -- rather than the Administration's -- analyses of the budget, along with various policy and fiscal alternatives. Over the years, its responsibilities have grown, but it has never tackled a job as big as restructuring the health care system -- and neither has Congress.
His admirers describe Mr. Reischauer's office as an invaluable, impartial umpire in a debate that badly needs one. "Their own success has created the problem," said Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Connecticut and a member of the Ways and Means Committee. "People believe their numbers."
 
Bottleneck or Whipping Boy?
 But some lawmakers complain that time after time, during committee deliberations and the move to the floor, the struggle to produce a health care bill has been slowed while everyone waits for the C.B.O. to analyze one hot idea or another. "I'm sympathetic to the problem of a small organization asked to do 20 different iterations all at once," said Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington and another influential member of Ways and Means. But he added, "They are the plug."
There is, on the other hand, considerable suspicion that the budget office is a convenient whipping boy for Democratic leaders who are not ready to bring their bill to the floor because they do not have the votes. There are ample reasons for the House to wait, like the exhausting, utterly distracting fight over the crime bill and the persistent desire among backbenchers to let the Senate go first on health.
A few things are clear: In both houses, the Democratic majority leaders have been struggling to find a consensus on health care and, as a result, have presented their plans much later than expected.
"Don't blame C.B.O.," said Representative Pete Stark, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. "It's my colleagues who can't decide what they want to do."
Moreover, rival plans and rump groups have endured -- and even, at this late stage, proliferated -- thus generating further demands for C.B.O. analyses. "Who would have thought that everybody would have their own plan?" Mrs. Kennelly said.
Finally, C.B.O. analyses have been slowed down because legislation keeps getting revised, rewritten and revamped even after it is presented to the budget office. Mr. Reischauer, a man of utmost delicacy when talking about Members of Congress, and particularly the leaders, said, "We provide a preliminary set of numbers, which often makes the sponsor of the plan want to make adjustments to the plan because sometimes it costs more than the sponsor anticipates."
He added, with a small smile: "There are components of these plans that are provided by other committees, for example: 'Here, Mr. Leader, this won't cost anything.' And it gets tucked into the bill. And then you say, 'Sorry, it's not quite that way. This provision for Indians or rural health or veterans that you haven't been paying careful attention to costs a lot more than you anticipated.' "
So the sponsor of the bill changes that element and resubmits the proposal for analysis. The numbers are run through anew, and the C.B.O. people move on to another element of the bill. In other words, the author of the legislation can have considerable control over how long it takes to analyze the bill.
"Absolutely," Mr. Reischauer said. "The interactive process, in effect, can go on forever."
Still, there is a widespread sense on Capitol Hill that the C.B.O. is simply understaffed for a job this big. Aides close to the Democratic leadership in both houses say that the issue was raised with Mr. Reischauer and that discussions focused on the idea of hiring new people or even subcontracting out some work. Mr. Reischauer said his current budget had been developed long before anyone could have anticipated this last-minute logjam.
By spring, when Democratic leaders and their staff recognized the problem that was developing, Mr. Reischauer said, it was too late "to suddenly shift gears" and contract with outside groups. Consistency -- the knowledge that every plan is being analyzed by the same set of people using the same assumptions -- is at the heart of the budget office's credibility, he argued.
 
Peering Into the Future
 The economist, trained at Harvard and Columbia, takes his nightmare scenario of a vast failure in health policy very seriously; throughout Mr. Reischauer's analyses of the various proposals, from President Clinton's to that of Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, runs a note of caution, a warning that nobody can truly foresee the consequences, intended and unintended, of policy-making at this scale.
But he also worries, he said, about too much caution in the modern era of policy-making. "We've become obsessed in this country with the budgetary impacts of policies," Mr. Reischauer said. "We're in a sense paying for the sins of our predecessors, who didn't worry at all about these things, and as a result we're left with gaping budget deficits.
"But it is a concern that the first test that has to be met is a budgetary test. And often that appears to be the only test that people are concerned with, rather than the notion that we should fashion responsible, progressive social policy that might solve the serious problems our society faces."
It is a variation of the argument made by Hillary Rodham Clinton, who mused to reporters last week that President Franklin D. Roosevelt "didn't have to carry around actuarial tables and then have arguments with people on television."
Mr. Reischauer, on this quiet Thursday night, did not have to think very long about the argument the modern "policy analysis world" would have presented against Social Security. "People would have said, 'Why, this is going to cause many able-bodied working 68-year-old men to drop out of the labor force!' "
A budgetary worldview, in other words, can carry a Congress only so far.

HEADLINE: Tax-Exempt Bonds Issued for Renovation at Kennedy

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Continuing New York City's efforts to help renovate aging terminals at Kennedy International Airport, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has issued $83 million in tax-exempt bonds to help American Airlines pay for the renovation and expansion of its passenger terminal.
The financing agreement, with the city's Industrial Development Agency, will enable the airline to complete a multimillion-dollar project it began in 1989 to rebuild its terminal and one next to it. 
 The agreement, announced yesterday by the Mayor's office, follows the announcement last month that a consortium of four foreign airlines had agreed to build the first new passenger terminal at Kennedy in more than two decades. The development agency also agreed to sell $435 million in bonds to raise money for that project.
In a statement, Mr. Giuliani praised the agreement with American, saying that it would create about 400 jobs and that it could encourage other airlines to rebuild at Kennedy, which is owned by the city and leased to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
 
Investing in Infrastructure
 "This kind of investment in our infrastructure by private industry is crucial to maintaining our franchise as a leader in transportation technology and efficiency," the Mayor said.
Under the agreement, the development agency sold the bonds on Aug. 2 on behalf of the airline, which must pay them off when they mature in 2024. The agency, part of the city's Economic Development Corporation, is a public nonprofit corporation that authorizes tax-exempt financing for manufacturers and other private companies to expand, renovate or buy new buildings in the city.
Michael W. Gunn, the senior vice president of marketing for American, said in the statement that the financing would allow the airline to expand its terminal by 340,000 square feet, adding five new passenger gates and more ticketing and baggage-claim areas.
In 1990, the development agency also raised $83 million for the airline to begin improvements at its terminals at La Guardia Airport, as well as at Kennedy. The agency has also financed projects by Japan Air Lines, Nippon Cargo Airways and Air France.

HEADLINE: Decision Is Near on Route 1 Link to Turnpike

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
After 56 years, a highway spur intended to ease congestion along the Route 1 corridor in central New Jersey has finally reached the point at which it will be built or scrapped.
The road, Route 92, was originally conceived as an east-west freeway cutting across some of central New Jersey's busiest north-south routes to link Route 206 near Princeton with Route 33 near Hightstown. 
 In its latest incarnation, which has drawn opposition from a coalition of environmentalists, local officials and area residents, Route 92 would be part of the New Jersey Turnpike and would connect Route 1 in South Brunswick Township with the turnpike at Exit 8A at Monroe Township. It is estimated that the 6.6-mile link would cost more than $200 million.
"Something's got to be done to move traffic out of the Route 1 corridor," said Frank X. McDermott, the chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. The Legislature, which wanted the road built but could not pay for it, handed the project over to the authority in 1992.
 
'It Makes No Sense'
 But opponents say that the project is too expensive and that the highway would cause environmental and development problems.
"It may have been a good idea about 60 years ago, but today it makes no sense and should not be built," said Michael S. Chunko, chief spokesman for "No 92," a coalition of organizations opposed to the road.
He continued, "This project contradicts public policy, including the state master plan, which says that rural areas are supposed to remain rural. It would force a rezoning of the area to allow more business and would increase air- and water-quality problems."
Opponents also doubt whether the highway would bring benefits equal to its costs. Charles Klatskin, a general partner of the Forsgate Industrial Complex in Monroe Township, near the proposed construction, said the turnpike's studies predicted only a 14 percent decrease in traffic on other east-west roads in the area. "That's a lot of money for that," he said.
Residents of a cluster of communities for people 55 or older near the Forsgate Country Club have signed petitions objecting to the anticipated increase in noise and air pollution from increased truck traffic on the elevated portion of the proposed roadway that will tie into Exit 8A.
Turnpike officials estimate that Route 92 would carry as many as 41,000 vehicles a day by the year 2015, a total roughly equal to the traffic on Route 1 today.
"We have to keep building highways, even though some people think the turnpike wants to pave the state over from the ocean to the Delaware River," Mr. McDermott said. "And an east-west road is still needed from Route 1 to the turnpike."
 
Economic Advantages
 He also argued that there were economic advantages to building the road now. "The turnpike has been the mother of construction in this state and has kept the building trades going for the last several years when they've really been hurting," he said. "One benefit from this is that the cost has been cheaper than ever because of increased competition."
But Joseph G. Peters, spokesman for the Southern South Brunswick Residents Alliance, said the road, as planned, should not be built at any cost: "Originally, it promised a real solution to regional transportation problems, but now it's just a turnpike spur. And it goes through farmlands, woodlands and wetlands, some of the most environmentally sensitive areas of Middlesex County."
Some South Brunswick officials, including Mayor Roger Craig, say they believe it is just too late for the new road, and the township has dropped Route 92 from its master plan. It is asking the state to improve other east-west roads instead.
But master plans are advisory, and South Brunswick's action will not affect the turnpike's decision.
Other nearby towns that would not be directly affected by the construction of Route 92 still support the project, citing benefits of improved traffic flow, as do Mercer and Middlesex County governing bodies.
The final decision on Route 92's fate is likely to rest on money. Although the turnpike can charge tolls to retire its construction bonds, which was the reason the Legislature handed it the project, the authority is already looking at budget problems that may force it to seek a toll increase next year whether it builds Route 92 or not.
Environmental and engineering studies have been completed for the road at a cost of about $1.7 million. Now Mr. McDermott is awaiting the results of a study that will examine construction costs and determine what tolls would have to be charged on the spur to retire the bonds. That study is due in September.
The land acquisition and construction from the turnpike to Route 1 will cost about $200 million. Extending the road a couple of miles farther to Route 27 could add $40 million. These figures do not take into account the cost of offsetting the loss of 27 acres of wetlands to road construction. In similar cases in the past the state has required the authority to build more park-and-ride lots or to create ponds and plant vegetation to attract certain species of wildlife.
Lynn Fleeger, the chief spokeswoman for the turnpike authority, said a final decision on whether to build Route 92 could come next month. "Once the decision is made," she said, "we'll either go ahead with it or put it to bed forever."

HEADLINE: A Slaying Chills Young Japanese in New York

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
His American dreams were at once modest and just beyond reach, centered on racing cars, boxing and the possibility of a green card. Before he was shot to death in a robbery attempt in Queens earlier this month, it seemed like Kei Sunada was inching toward a few of them.
Like many young Japanese who find their way to New York, but unlike most other immigrants his age, Mr. Sunada was lured not by money -- he had plenty of that back home -- but by the chance to pursue an offbeat career. 
 People inside or with close ties to the Japanese community in New York say that Mr. Sunada, 22, was one of the hundreds of young people who flock here from Japan each year, many of them leaving behind wealthy families or good jobs in favor of waiting tables or playing jazz in Washington Square Park.
Many live in the East Village, where they work in Japanese restaurants or bars, or in Astoria, Queens, or northern New Jersey.
 
An Independent Spirit
 Mr. Sunada's friends and family said that he was an independent spirit, haunted perhaps by his parents' divorce and determined to earn his family's respect by defining himself outside of his culture and disconnected from its social conventions.
"Japan is a very rich country," said Takayuki Kanematsu, who knew Mr. Sunada from the Kingsway Boxing Center, on West 40th Street in Manhattan, where both worked out. "But it doesn't have a dream."
Friends and relatives said that Mr. Sunada, who left his home in Fukuoka last year for New York, had been anxious to escape his father, who pressured him to go to college and abandon plans to become a chef and a Formula One race-car driver.
After living with family friends in New Jersey for a few months, Mr. Sunada found a job as an assistant chef in a Manhattan restaurant. He soon found a room to rent in an apartment in Lefrak City, Queens.
It was there that police say he was killed by two robbers who confronted him on Aug. 4 in the stairwell of his building and shot him in the eye. He died three days later. Armond McCloud, 20, and Reginald Cameron, 19, both of Queens, have since been arrested and charged with his murder.
"I told him this was a really tough city," said Nachiko Kudo, one of the family friends who housed him in New Jersey. "I told him he could stay with us, but he wanted to share with Americans.
"He wanted to prove himself to his father," she said. "He wanted to establish himself. He had had a rough time as a child, with the divorce."
Among Japanese as in other immigrant communities, the ties between newcomers and old-timers in the city are strong. Tips about apartments, jobs and where to find Japanese bread or videos are shared through a network of thousands of young people who come to the metropolitan area each year, including 4,160 last year on student visas.
 
Finding Themselves
 "The difference between young Japanese and other immigrants is that their country is close to America economically," said Thomas Gardner, a special assistant at the Japanese Consulate. "They don't come to save themselves as much as to find themselves."
Interviews with dozens of Japanese in New York indicate that many of those in their 20's who leave for the United States do so to escape a a rigid career path requiring them to work doggedly through school and settle into a company job. Many say they long to express a personal style, difficult even in big Japanese cities, where they say there is pressure to dress and behave in a uniform way.
For women, it often means pressure to marry and a lack of career opportunities. For those interested in films or rock music, there are limited outlets, the young people say.
Yuko Koseki, 27, left Kanagawa in 1990 with dreams about film. "I wanted to study film production, but in Japan there are no film schools," she said. She now studies at Hunter College and works at a Japanese-language cable station.
"As a woman, living here is easier for me because in Japan, a woman has social pressure to get married by 25," she added.
Naoto Katafuchi said he would be content with a job in the computer industry, but what he loves about living in the East Village, rather than in Tokyo is that he can grow his hair long and play his guitar.
"If you dress differently there it is hard," he said. "Everything had to be neat and nice. No ripped jeans. Everyone looks the same. I have to use polite words all the time."
Go Restaurant on St. Mark's Place in the East Village is a magnet for young Japanese newcomers who will settle for waiting tables in exchange for the chance to live in New York. Mari Yoshida, 27, a waitress at Go, traded exports at Mitsubishi in Tokyo, but left last summer. "I had a dream from my childhood to come here and study English," she said. "I like New York, but sometimes I am afraid."
 
Told Not to Fight
 The police and Mr. Sunada's friends say that his boxing skills and self-defense instincts may have led him to resist his attackers, who the police say had robbed before but never killed. "We told him not to fight if he was robbed," said Ms. Kudo. "Even though we told him over and over again to be careful, he was a boy and only here for a short while."
Mr. Sunada's killing, which followed fatal shootings of young Japanese victims in Louisiana and California in the last two years, underscored the rising anger in Japan over American gun violence. Last week, about a dozen students who called themselves Japanese Students Against Violence protested in Times Square.
Part of the problem, say many Japanese people, is that newcomers are ill prepared to protect themselves. "A lot of Japanese don't see themselves as unsafe, which is partially why they are," said Mr. Gardner. "They go into Alphabet City late at night and see drug dealers and say, 'This is really interesting, just like the movies,' and that is how they get into trouble."
Most people interviewed, however, said that they did not fear violence, and thought that Mr. Sunada's death was a horrible twist of fate. "When I heard about his death, I thought someone had to stand up," said Masaaki Nishine, 21, who organized the protest. "I wanted to keep his death from being meaningless."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Offbeat careers and the opportunity to express a personal style, not money, are often the driving force behind the immigration of young Japanese to the metropolitan area. Mari Yoshida, 27, is waiting tables at Go Restaurant in the East Village as the trade-off for being able to live in New York City. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In a Colombian Port City, the Only Hope Lies in Leaving

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUENAVENTURA, Colombia

 BODY:
Guillermo B., a tall, thin man in his mid-20's, has tried to leave this poverty-ridden port city five times. With little schooling and a disabled mother to support, his ambition is to go to the United States, find work and return with a fortune.
His first attempt to leave came last year. One night, he bribed a port guard with a counterfeit $100 bill and hid himself in a container that was to go on a cargo ship bound for Florida. As the vessel crossed the Panama Canal, two sailors discovered him and alerted immigration officials in Miami. A month later, the ship returned Guillermo, who asked that his full name not be used, to this Pacific port 200 miles southwest of Bogota. 
 Since then, the police have caught him every time he has tried to smuggle himself out of the country as a stowaway. Yet for him, as for hundreds of other young men here, the cargo ships that enter and depart one of Latin America's busiest Pacific ports are the only means to escape poverty.
Although the bustling port here has thrived under Colombia's economic liberalization and free trade policies, the city's 350,000 mostly black inhabitants have been denied the benefits from the billions of dollars in commerce that pass through each year.
What remains after the ships depart are images of wealth and abundance from abroad. "I wanted to go because people told me that life in the United States was good," said Carlos Murillo, a 34-year-old photographer who tried to leave as a stowaway three times. "I was told that the poor there lived like the rich here."
In the crowded city center, shoeshiners, contraband vendors and cafe owners announce their services to the swarms of seemingly idle people standing about on street corners. Business and industry are nowhere to be found. About 70 percent of the people here are unemployed. The few who find occasional work as port hands earn less than the minimum wage of $110 a month and receive no benefits. Most Buenaventurans share a life of poverty. They also express a common desire: They want to leave.
Guillermo dreams of becoming a "norteno," one of the tiny minority of stowaways who have managed to reach the United States unnoticed and, once there, have struck gold. As illegal aliens with sparse education, many nortenos, or northerners, have found fortune by resorting to drug dealing, and a few make a meager living doing menial work.
With plenty of cash and presents for their families, nortenos return to Buenaventura to lavish their wealth. They drive imported cars, wear gold chains, listen to rap music and pepper their Spanish with American slang. Clad in colorful shirts and imported shoes, they contrast conspicuously with the rest of the population.
As nortenos return to build new homes in the areas where they grew up, they have turned Buenaventura into a city of contrasts. In Bellavista neighborhood, unsturdy wooden shacks that harbor many failed stowaways and threaten to sink when it floods are huddled alongside opulent homes exhibiting flower-laden gardens, spiral staircases and doors that open by remote control.
Yet far from eliciting resentment among the destitute majority here, nortenos serve to strengthen the resolve of those who hope to escape to a brighter future. A local journalist recalled how his best friend had returned a rich man. "I want to be like that," he said. "At the first chance I get, I will leave too."
The areas surrounding the port are filled with throngs of would-be stowaways like Guillermo, waiting for the chance to slip on board a passing ship. For many, it is not the first attempt. A port official here estimated that six or seven people try to leave as stowaways every day.
As more cargo vessels take advantage of the port's recent privatization and added efficiency, the number of stowaways increases. Yet as they begin their journey, the majority face death, apprehension or the prospect of deportation.

HEADLINE: Political Notes

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
It's a common enough promotional device: a special advertising section to tout a state's economy and attract new businesses. But when Fortune magazine recently discussed doing just such a section on New York State, some potential advertisers balked.
Their concern: the 10-page section was scheduled to appear in the Oct. 3 issue -- smack in the middle of a gubernatorial race. 
 The potential advertisers worried that the section -- and therefore their companies -- would appear to be promoting the re-election of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat. Because of their misgivings, the section has been postponed until March.
"There was a concern among some companies of this being perceived, even though it's not, as taking a pro-Cuomo position," said Fran Hall, director of special projects for Fortune. "I don't mean to say they are anti-Cuomo; it's just that they don't want to be seen as taking any position."
The section is being promoted by the Business Alliance for a New New York, a joint venture between the state's Department of Economic Development and 11 New York utilities. In July, the alliance sent letters to scores of companies encouraging them to purchase advertising "units" for $19,800. According to the letter, the state planned to distribute 25,000 reprints of the section.
Republicans called the alliance's efforts an attempt to pressure state-regulated companies to underwrite a campaign venture. "If Mario Cuomo wants to develop an ad campaign for his re-election bid, he ought to pay for it himself," said William D. Powers, the Republican state chairman.
State officials said the section was timed to coincide with a national convention of real-estate agents in New York City, not the November election.
"You have to tell your story, and we're not doing it," said Tony Gaetano, a senior deputy commissioner for economic development.
 
Whom Will Giuliani Support? In Primary, None of the Above

New York City's Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has done his best to keep people wondering about whom he will support in this year's gubernatorial race. And now he has clouded the issue further by saying he will not endorse either candidate -- Richard M. Rosenbaum or George E. Pataki -- in the Sept. 13 Republican primary.
The choice posed something of a dilemma for Mr. Giuliani. On one hand, Mr. Rosenbaum, a former state Republican chairman, has raised money for Mr. Giuliani in past races and is close to several of the Mayor's top advisers.
Yet Mr. Pataki, a State Senator from Putnam County, is a heavy favorite to win the primary. But he is also a protege of Mr. Giuliani's sometime rival, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Mr. Giuliani also faces a conundrum in the general election. He could hurt himself among Republican faithful if he drags his feet in supporting their standard bearer. But he has not ruled out the possibility of endorsing the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has bent over backwards at times to help the city and its mayor.
Republican State Committee officials say they think Mr. Giuliani will support the eventual Republican candidate. But Karen Crowe, a spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani, said he is keeping his options open and plans first to interview all comers.
"He could support any candidate," she said. "It will depend on who can provide the best possible assistance to New York."
 
D'Amato Praises Mitchell, Only to Be Corrected
 Senator D'Amato has never been shy about attacking his opponents, but last week on the Senate floor he lavished praise on one: the majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, whose health care bill Mr. D'Amato dislikes.
Mr. D'Amato rose to say that the process of debating health insurance was too rushed and reminded him of events leading up to the vote he most regretted casting in his 14 years in the Senate: for the 1986 tax act that, among other things, eliminated deductibility for Individual Retirement Accounts.
"I always said to myself, 'Yeah, Senator Mitchell voted the other way, and I applaud him.' He stood up and he voted that way. I wish I had."
Then Mr. Mitchell asked to reply: "I thank the Senator for giving me credit, but I think I better make clear that I voted for it." He added, in a gentle reference to Mr. D'Amato's recent outrage over inconsistent testimony by Treasury Department officials in the Whitewater inquiry: "I thought one thing we better do around here now is correct the record as soon as we can."
Mr. D'Amato, by now chuckling steadily, said: "I was upset with myself for not having gone down there and voted that way."
"I will not tell you why," added the New Yorker, who eviscerated the young Treasury chief of staff, Josh Steiner, for trying to back away from embarrassing diary entries under oath and who seldom misses an opportunity to make a political point. "I try to do it in my diary. I hope the diary does not lie."

HEADLINE: In the Twilight of Deng, China's Rising Stars Jostle

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 20

 BODY:
With his 90th birthday two days away, his hearing almost gone and his body racked by Parkinson's disease, Deng Xiaoping is still playing an active, though more limited, role as China's paramount leader, United States officials say.
At the same time, they say, President Jiang Zemin has taken important steps to consolidate his power in advance of Mr. Deng's death, as other contenders for China's Communist Party throne maneuver for influence, or even to challenge Mr. Deng's chosen heir. 
 Evidence of Mr. Deng's continuing role, the American officials say, can be seen in his direct contact with Communist Party chieftains on how to handle the delicate transition in North Korea and Beijing's contentious struggle with Washington on human rights and trade.
"On Korea and on how to deal with the United States, Deng has been involved in telling them what strategy to take," an American specialist on Chinese affairs said.
 
Dominant View on Rights
 Beijing's cautious policy of supporting international negotiations to keep nuclear weapons off the Korean peninsula, while refusing to join any openly confrontational pressure campaign against North Korea's leaders, is a hallmark of Mr. Deng's approach, the officials say.
On human rights, they say official thinking is still dominated by Mr. Deng's trenchant view that outside pressure for democratic reform is an attempt to undermine Communist Party rule. That view was prevailing in March when Chinese leaders subjected Secretary of State Warren Christopher to a diplomatic skewering when he arrived to extract concessions on human rights.
On the surface, the notion that Mr. Deng is still pulling the strings might seem to run counter to the assertion by some Western intelligence agencies that his physical and mental faculties have so faded in the last year as to bring on a "pre-transition" in which senior leaders are maneuvering for power upon Mr. Deng's death.
But the two are not necessarily in conflict.
"Deng's role as paramount leader has withered," one China analyst said. "There are fewer and fewer issues that people take to him."
 
A More Creative Approach
 As a result, Mr. Deng's nominal successors are being more creative within the parameters of policy that is collectively known as the Deng line.
"But the line is there until he goes and probably for some time beyond," the analyst said, underscoring that in China, to be paramount leader means that "the daily ability just to breathe in and out still counts heavily."
Five years after the pro-democracy uprising at Tiananmen Square, it is also Mr. Deng's controlling viewpoint that prevents any consideration of reversing the official verdict that the students took part in a "counter-revolutionary rebellion," a verdict that has shattered the lives of thousands of young Chinese and tarred many of them with criminal records.
Although Mr. Deng is frail and virtually invisible, he remains China's most important private citizen. The significance of his participation, and the state of his health, still means everything in a country where no rule of law exists to guide the coming political succession.
Near the end of what is already called the Deng era, simultaneous political repression and phenomenal economic expansion have kept China a study in contradictions, a magnet for moral condemnation as well as for foreign investment. Mr. Deng's passing from the scene will very likely begin an era of uncertainty, perhaps even instability and chaos.
 
The Maneuvering Begins
 And so the maneuvering has begun. Whether they are angling to come out on top, or just to survive, China's younger generation of leaders are engaged in battle with one another in a consensus-driven oligarchy carrying out the Deng line.
While the chief maneuverer seems to be President Jiang, there also appears to be a stirring of political activity from the man he replaced, Yang Shangkun, and from Zhao Ziyang, the disgraced Communist Party chief who took the official blame for the Tiananmen uprising.
Mr. Jiang, the 68-year-old former Mayor of Shanghai, was a dark horse when Mr. Deng selected him in 1989 to become the next paramount leader. Today, he is busy building a network of loyalists in the military and security forces. This spring, President Jiang promoted 19 officers to full general, thus stacking the top ranks of the People's Liberation Army with men who can be expected to show some loyalty in return.
Mr. Jiang last year named one of his old Shanghai cronies to head the People's Armed Police, an 800,000-member force that represents a second military establishment in China. It was built with a $2 billion investment to prevent public assemblies from ever getting out of hand again, as the one did at Tiananmen in 1989.
 
Top Leaders Cooperate
 But an internal United States military analysis of Mr. Jiang's moves concludes that because the influence of the President's military allies "is heavily founded on his relationship to Deng Xiaoping," it "may not outlast his mentor's death." Many analysts, including the late Richard M. Nixon, have argued that Mr. Jiang will be swept aside just as Mao Zedong's designated successor, Hua Guofeng, was swept aside by Mr. Deng in 1978.
For now, Mr. Jiang, Prime Minister Li Peng and Executive Vice Prime Minister Zhu Rongji are showing an extraordinary degree of cooperation as the core of the larger leadership group, Western officials say. It was just a year ago that Mr. Lidisappeared for months after a heart attack in April 1993. His absence raised questions about whether the unpopular and hard-line Prime Minister would be jettisoned for his political liability in issuing the order -- with Mr. Deng's consent -- for the military crackdown in 1989.
But Mr. Li has moved decisively to reclaim his post at the top of the Cabinet and as chairman of the group that runs foreign policy. American officials say he was an influential architect of the security crackdown by China this spring and its tough line toward Washington on human rights.
If Mr. Li leads a grab for power after Mr. Deng's death, he will have to attract powerful backing in the military and among the aged revolutionary heroes that outlive Mr. Deng. Preeminent is Chen Yun, a soft-spoken economist who has grudgingly supported Mr. Deng's economic reforms since 1978. Mr. Chen, who is 89, has seemed more interested in influencing policy than controlling it.
 
Fallen Leader Speaks Out
 That is not the case with Mr. Yang, who still seems seems spry at 87 and who cut a powerful figure during his years as President and second in command of China's military forces. Mr. Yang is decidedly pro-American, while Mr. Chen is decidedly anti-American.
Mr. Yang and his younger half-brother, Yang Baibing, 74, lost their posts at the top of the military in 1992 when Mr. Deng apparently decided that they were building up an independent power base that would threaten Mr. Jiang.
But loss of title has not stopped Mr. Yang from maintaining a public profile as one of China's revolutionary heroes and party stalwarts. The fact that his movements and speeches still command notice in regional newspapers keeps alive the speculation that Mr. Yang, perhaps in alliance with other leaders who are believed to favor reversing the verdict of Tiananmen Square, will make a comeback after Mr. Deng's death.
Such speculation usually groups Mr. Zhao, the disgraced party chief; Wan Li, a former parliamentary chief, and Qiao Shi, a former security chief who now heads the National People's Congress, in an alliance of moderates who would challenge hard-liners for control.
The most important action signaling a recent political move from Mr. Zhao's camp was the leak of his secret speech to the party elders as they were stripping him of power in June 1989.
 
National Strategy Indicted
 Mr. Zhao's words, reported this summer in the Hong Kong press and carried into China, are a powerful indictment of national strategy under Mr. Deng, which emphasizes economic reform and authoritarian political repression. Mr. Zhao's 1989 call to the party was to abandon the notion that China could have an economic revolution without a political revolution.
"I used to think that so long as we did well in reforming the economic structure and developing the economy and people's living standards went up, then the people would be satisfied and society would be stable," Mr. Zhao told party leaders.
"But as I later discovered, this is not the way things are. After living standards and cultural levels have been raised, the people's sense of democracy and sense of political participation will grow stronger. If the building of democracy and a legal system fails to keep up, then society will not be stable."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "WHO'S WHO: The Paramount Leader and Those Who Would Suceed Him"
 
DENG XIAOPING
 Deng Xiaoping, 89, officially retired . . . continues to exert control over domestic and foreign policy despite failing health . . . has designated President Jiang Zemin as his successor to be China's next paramount leader.
 
JIANG ZEMIN
Jiang Zemin, 68, President and Politburo chairman . . . chosen by Deng Xiaoping as a compromise to be the "third generation" paramount leader . . . strengths are the mantle he was given and his ability to control appointments of the security forces chiefs who will keep him in power . . . but few think he is tough enough to keep the job.
 
LI PENG
Li Peng, 66, Prime Minister and Politburo member . . . the man held most responsible for the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square . . . Moscow-trained engineer . . . abrasive and unpopular . . . adopted son of the Zhou Enlai, Prime Minister under Mao Zedong . . . support would come from the conservative old comrades and party ideologues who want China to reform slowly to insure strong party rule . . . weaknesses: heart attack in 1993, unpopularity . . . strength: his toughness.
 
ZHAO ZIYANG
Zhao Ziyang, 75, the disgraced Communist Party chief who took the blame for the Tiananmen Square uprising . . . an ardent supporter of economic and democratic reforms . . . would have to pick up strong support from old comrades . . . his speech on democracy to the party leadership is gaining an audience in China
 
YANG SHANGKUN
Yang Shangkun, 86, former President and former No. 2 official in charge of the military . . . onetime bridge partner of Deng Xiaoping . . . support to replace Mr. Deng as paramount leader would come from a broad network of allies in the army and the Communist Party . . . controlled party personnel decisions in the 1950's . . . served as deputy to Mr. Deng on the Central Military Commission, which controls the military . . . believed to have been removed for empire building.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Benny Ong: A Farewell To All That

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
BENNY Ong, Uncle Seven, International Adviser for Life of the Hip Sing Tong, the Godfather of Chinatown, lay in state at the Wah Wing Sang Funeral Home the other day, surrounded by enough flowers to cover much of lower Manhattan.
Floral wreaths from businessmen, families and the myriad associations of Chinatown's social network -- family organizations like the important Lee family, the Engs, associations from villages and regions in Canton province, home of the original settlers -- lined the walls and were stacked up on the floor. Funeral banners hung in long narrow strips, proclaiming Mr. Ong's many qualities, notably from officials of the Nationalist government in Taiwan. 
 "High Virtue, Great Expectations" read the characters flanking one side of the entrance, where bulky men in tight black suits greeted mourners for the 87-year old tong leader. The sign on the other side said: "Your success is reflected in the Chinese Community in New York."
Across Mulberry Street, the police, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the F.B.I. and other law-enforcement operatives photographed the mourners from surveillance trucks and observation posts. On a high terrace of the new Federal courthouse a long-lensed camera on a tripod recorded the scene.
For decades, Benny Ong and the Hip Sing -- and the rival On Leong Tong -- dominated the shadowy life of Chinatown, a world almost totally isolated from the larger American society, impenetrable to low faan, the universal term for outsiders, meaning "barbarian."
But Benny Ong's world -- traditional Chinatown, the tight, inward-looking, circumscribed few blocks of homogeneous Cantonese mores, strictly, often harshly, ordered -- is, in many ways, being buried along with him.
It was a world created not just by Chinese culture, but American racism. Poor farmers were recruited from Canton in the mid-19th century for the mines and railroads in the West. But by the 1870's, scapegoated for economic depression, pitted against white workers and union organizers, the Chinese were being lynched and murdered. The Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, barring importation of Chinese laborers, shaped the future; Chinese could not become citizens until 1943.
Some fled the violence to Mott and Pell Streets in the 1890's. The Chinese formed an institution called a tong (meeting hall), drawing on the tradition and romance of secret Triad societies of the late 17th century that challenged invading Manchu rulers. It was a self-help organization, like those of other immigrant groups, but it also provided protection against the larger, hostile society, a means of settling disputes, since no law applied.
Tongs, too, ran the high-stakes gambling dens and houses of prostitution that served an almost entirely bachelor society. By loophole and subterfuge, Chinatown grew as men came to climb the Golden Mountain.
Benny Ong arrived in 1922, worked in a laundry at 16 and soon took the ritual oath of the Hip Sing. He was a soldier in the Tong Wars raging into the 1930's, where the weapon of choice led to the term "hatchet man" and the crook in Doyer Street became the "bloody angle." In 1935 he was jailed for 17 years for second-degree murder (he took the fall, it was said, for a higher-up) and in 1974 he became tong boss. He did another year in 1977 when a wire picked him up boasting of payoffs to the law. Oft-cited in government reports on organized crime, he was said to have spent his final years quietly playing mah jongg.
The vast, sometimes contradictory changes sweeping the Chinese community stem from the 1965 Immigration Act opening the door to Asians.
Chinatown has leapt Canal Street, displacing all but a few carefully preserved restaurant blocks of Little Italy -- once a similar closed enclave, where men of mysterious income sipped espresso in unmarked social clubs -- and spread to new Chinatowns in Flushing, Queens, and Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The new families are no longer all Cantonese, and the tongs do not rule the outlying areas.
Chinese crime is not ending. Chinese organizations are supplanting the Mafia in heroin. Gangs extort merchants. Fujianese smuggle immigrants, enforcing the $30,000 debt by kidnapping and torture.
But, change is inevitable. Joss sticks burned in the funeral home and the old gangster's favorite dish, boiled chicken, was there to sustain him on his trip to the afterworld, along with the bribes that would get him past the devils along the way.
He really couldn't speak about Chinatown, Benny Ong's stepson said politely. He himself worked for IBM.
