HEADLINE: Raymond J. Burke; Admiralty Lawyer, 81

 BODY:
Raymond J. Burke, a founder of the law firm Burke & Parsons in Manhattan, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 and had lived in Palm Beach.
The cause was cancer, his son Raymond Jr. said. 
 Mr. Burke grew up in Manhattan, and graduated from Columbia University in 1944 and New York University Law School in 1947. A specialist in admiralty law for 45 years, Mr. Burke founded Burke & Parsons in 1965 with J. Lester Parsons. In 1975, Mr. Burke was appointed special admiralty counsel to the Government of Indonesia in connection with a financial crisis involving the national oil company, Pertamina.
Mr. Burke is survived by his wife of 56 years, Catherine, of Palm Beach; a daughter, Katherine Murphy of Birmingham, Mich.; two sons, Raymond Jr. of Manhattan and Richard E. of New Canaan, Conn.; seven grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Discouraging Cubans

 BODY:
Low politics, not high principle, inspired President Clinton's ditching of the double standard that for the last 28 years gave Cuban refugees near automatic entry to the United States. Now, fleeing Cubans risk being stopped at sea by the Coast Guard or Navy and returned to, of all places, the U.S. base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
It is a hasty, harsh and unnecessary move. But at least it brings a semblance of equality to Washington's treatment of those fleeing impoverished Caribbean tyrannies. And it implicitly recognizes that, with the cold war over, Cuba is no longer a special case. The next logical step, which the Administration unfortunately shows no sign of taking, would be to formulate constructive diplomatic policies toward Cuba that could help ease the way to a democratic post-Castro future. 
 The new policy is designed to deter the thousands of Cubans who have been preparing to leave since Fidel Castro's regime stopped interfering with departures earlier this month. Those who elude the Coast Guard and reach U.S. soil will be detained indefinitely upon arrival. Only those who apply and are found eligible for asylum before leaving Cuba will now receive automatic admission.
That is roughly the same policy now applied to Haitians, with one crucial difference. To apply for asylum while still living in Haiti is to court murderous retaliation from government thugs, while discontented Cubans, at least for now, are virtually being encouraged to leave. In both countries, the U.S. is intentionally contributing to popular discontent with tough economic sanctions.
In both cases, generous treatment of the unintended victims of U.S. foreign policy has been defeated by the politics of populist panic. Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, facing a tough re-election fight, triggered Mr. Clinton's move by declaring a statewide emergency Thursday. Mr. Clinton, whose own 1980 re-election bid in Arkansas was damaged when Cuban detainees from the last mass exodus rioted at an Arkansas detention camp, readily sympathized with his fellow Democrat's political plight. He also needs Florida's electoral votes for himself in 1996.
The latest departures began after an anti-Castro riot on the Havana waterfront two weeks ago, the most visible political protest in years. The Castro regime may not exactly be in its death throes, but it is reeling from the global collapse of Communism, the loss of Russian trade subsidies and the lack of any obvious successor to Mr. Castro.
That would seem to offer openings for a diplomatic mixture of incentives and threats that have begun to lure Communism's other orphans, like Vietnam and North Korea, out of their isolation. Yet for fear of angering the ferociously anti-Castro lobbies that are so powerful in Florida and New Jersey politics, U.S. policy has been purely punitive, aimed at building up explosive pressures in Cuba. The Administration is trying to sell its refugee ban -- and new package of economic and political pressures -- to Cuban-American hard-liners as part of this same effort.
Interestingly, Bernard Aronson, who served as Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America in the Bush Administration and whose hard-line credentials are not in doubt, presented in The Washington Post last week a more nuanced policy that would offer specific U.S. diplomatic incentives as a reward for steps toward democracy in Cuba. Such a policy is, in fact, suggested by the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992. Unlike the sanctions provisions of that legislation, the suggestions for a possible diplomatic opening have never been followed up.
It is not in the best tradition of the United States to interdict refugees. It is surely not in the best interest of the United States -- or of Cuban democracy -- to encourage violent upheaval in Cuba without also offering some hope of peaceful change.

HEADLINE: The Man Who Loved Shakespeare

BYLINE: By Benedict Nightingale; Benedict Nightingale, a former Sunday drama critic for The New York Times, is the chief drama critic of The Times of London.

 BODY:

JOE PAPP
An American Life.
By Helen Epstein.
Illustrated. 554 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $24.95. 
 Joe Papp was smaller than average and larger than life. When I first met him in his Public Theater in 1983, surrounded by trophies and posters commemorating the glory days of the 1960's and 70's, it seemed to me that he combined the looks of a sleek vole with the charisma of the tragic hero so marvelously described by the Renaissance critic Lodovico Castelvetro: he was dynamic and proud, he "intensely wanted what he wanted," he did not endure injury patiently, he was naturally immoderate, he followed his instincts without apology, he was temperamentally more inclined to go to war than to law, and he was most likely capable of "killing both strangers and relatives," in Castelvetro's language. It is no surprise to learn from "Joe Papp: An American Life," Helen Epstein's fascinating biography, that early on he concluded that any theater needed "a strong monarch," and that in his later years some of his associates thought of him as an erratic, arbitrary but still formidable King Lear.
But you could hardly say, with Goneril, that the best of his time was but rash. Has there been a more energetic, effective figure in the modern American theater? It was not merely the well-known accomplishments: the Homeric battle to provide free Shakespeare to New Yorkers and build the Delacorte Theater in Central Park; the conversion of the Astor Library into that vast creative caldron, the Public Theater; the discovery of David Rabe and many another striking playwright, and of Meryl Streep and scores of other fine actors; the pioneering dedication to colorblind casting and minority-group theater; and much more. It was also that fierce missionary zeal, the example it gave and the idealism it kept alive. If it is still possible in America to think of theater in its original Greek way -- a vital experience that the polis should be offering as a right to all its citizens, not just to the educated or moneyed few -- Joe Papp is more to be thanked than anybody else.
As Ms. Epstein evokes it, Papp's Brooklyn childhood explains why he became the sort of producer he did, yet makes it hard to understand why he became a producer at all. His father was a trunk maker who spent long periods unemployed, and his mother did not learn to read or write English until she was in her 60's. Though he played Scrooge in a school "Christmas Carol" at age 8, his family was far too poor to afford trips to any theaters, let alone those on Broadway. He ran wild, plucked chickens and shined shoes for pocket money, and did not continue his education after high school. Somehow he managed to land a respectable job with a company of jewelry manufacturers, and would probably have made a career in that trade, had he not been fired for organizing a strike and telling his boss off in very colorful language.
AS that suggests, he was radicalized as well as toughened by late Depression Brooklyn. He became a Communist and remained one deep into the 1950's. Ms. Epstein also tells us that he never forgot the beating he received at age 14 from an anti-Semitic 17-year-old called Whitey. What he learned from this thug -- "if you want to make an impact, you hit first, hard and without any kind of feeling" -- he would one day teach others. In 1958, CBS thought it could quietly fire Papp from his then job as a stage manager after he pleaded the Fifth Amendment at a House Committee on Un-American Activities hearing, and it was wrong. In 1959, the Parks Commissioner, Robert Moses, the political powerhouse who commanded the very shape and appearance of New York City, believed he could stop the presentation of free Shakespeare in Central Park, and he was wronger still. To take on Papp was often to end up on your back in the ring, stunned by the man's chutzpah, resourcefulness and aggression.
Two things turned Joseph Papirofsky, as he was called until his mid-30's, into Joe Papp. One was a love of literature, and especially of Shakespeare, great slabs of which he could quote from high school onward. The other was the wartime Navy, where for no very good or clear reason he found himself entrusted with organizing variety shows for bored sailors. At all events, the later 1940's saw him first at the Actors' Laboratory in California, next presenting Shakespeare to tiny audiences in a church hall in New York City. And bit by bit the cultural islet expanded into an empire that at one time stretched beyond Broadway, where "A Chorus Line" and "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf" and many other plays that Papp had originally opened downtown were regularly to be found, to Lincoln Center, which he tried and failed to transform into an offbeat American National Theater.
Ms. Epstein, a freelance journalist, relates Papp's professional achievements interestingly and lucidly, though there are odd gaps. Why, for instance, did Sam Shepard storm out of the Public after the production of his "True West" and why did he never return? That not-insignificant contretemps is barely mentioned, let alone explained. But if there is an overall criticism to be made of the book, it is about its handling of Papp's private life. I sometimes felt Ms. Epstein could have dug deeper, asked harder questions, and maybe speculated more about the workings of that odd, elusive psyche. There were even moments when I wondered if she wasn't the victim of her friendship with Papp and his family. The book was, after all, once conceived as a quasi-official biography, written in cooperation with the producer.
Not that Ms. Epstein is obviously evasive or willfully busy with the airbrush. She tells us that Papp himself felt he had "not been praiseworthy in my private life," and up to a point she explains why. He was married four times and had five children. But he did not even know of the existence of his eldest daughter for many years; he was denied access for a time to a son; and he was, on the whole, a neglectful father to his other children. His middle two marriages can hardly have been helped by the fact that like many Jewish people in the 40's, he was "passing" as a gentile. He told one wife that his father was Russian and his mother a Briton who "had tea every afternoon at 4 with a silver service," and another that he was Anglo-Polish and "the youngest graduate ever of Columbia University." It is scarcely surprising that his divorces were marked by what Ms. Epstein calls "great bitterness," but she tells us little or nothing of the form this bitterness took.
IS it just prurient curiosity to want amplification? Or do we all have a legitimate interest in a man -- in my view a great man -- whose professional achievements were clearly actuated by inner needs and drives of immense complexity and intensity? Think of that proto-Papp, Napoleon, and the answer is obvious. Again, Ms. Epstein tells us a certain amount about the turbulence behind the tough-guy exterior. There were nightmares, anxiety attacks, bouts of depression and psychosomatic seizures that do not appear to have halted until after he began to see a therapist, on whom he became strongly dependent. According to his third wife, Peggy, this made him less emotionally cut off, yet had an effect that was, she told Ms. Epstein, "catastrophic." But precisely what she meant by that is unclear.
With time, Papp's private life became more settled. He embraced his Jewishness with pride. His marriage to Gail Merrifield in 1976 became lasting and seems to have been happy. He became closer to his children, notably his son Tony, who died of AIDS when he was 28, shortly before Papp himself succumbed to cancer in 1991 at the age of 70. There is a touching passage describing his first, tearful meeting with his "lost" daughter, Barbara, when she was 35. But paternal devotion still had its limits. Ms. Epstein needs to provide more -- and more direct -- testimony from his surviving children. But she is convincing when she argues that the brood receiving most of Papp's care and attention were his playwrights. Again and again their voices are to be heard in her book, voicing filial love and gratitude, Oedipal anger, or both at once. "I thought that we playwrights represented the kind of children Joe would have liked to have had," Thomas Babe is quoted as saying, "gifted, screwed up in some way, and largely dependent -- boys who could . . . absorb the blows and remain loyal, whatever happened."
The final portrait that emerges might have been jointly painted by Goya, Whistler and Francis Bacon, so hard is it to categorize. Papp was charming, funny, intelligent, interesting, warm, loyal and utterly likable. He was arrogant, myopic, hostile, cruel, cold, treacherous and utterly unlikable. For better or worse, or both, he broke the rules. You don't abruptly fire long-term colleagues like his associate producer, Bernard Gersten, for little or no reason. You don't persistently run up huge debts and insist on others paying them. You don't harass and harangue politicians, or bully and snub potential donors. You don't refuse money because you dislike the source. You don't ring up critics, as Papp did with Clive Barnes at The New York Times, and let rip a tirade of obscene invective. Yet maybe American culture needs a few more people who combine that commitment with those street-fighting skills.
Certainly it is difficult to be patient with the mandarin detractors Ms. Epstein quotes. Papp was a cultural opportunist with no distinct esthetic? But his view was always that theater should be questing, diverse, catholic, appealing to more than one set of tastes; it should embody "Hair" and a pop "Pirates of Penzance" as well as the plays of John Guare and David Hare. He was publicity mad? Maybe, but he insured that his theaters were always at the center of public attention. He was absurdly profligate with ideas, the airier the better? Yet it was not just rhetoric when he said, as he often did, "Don't tell me anything is impossible, let's try it first." He was the irresistible force that changed that immovable object, the American theater.
 
 
 
'A CHORUS LINE' IS BORN
 Michael Bennett . . . had long wished to create his own musical about dancers and, in January of 1974, had taken a first step. He had invited 21 dancers to a midnight gathering. . . . They sat in a circle and Bennett asked them to give their name, date and place of birth, talk about their childhood and describe how they first became interested in dancing. They talked for five hours, took a break and then talked until noon the next day. Bennett played some of those tapes for Papp. . . .
The two men hit it off. . . . Bennett had done 16 Broadway shows under the standard Broadway scenario, which began with five weeks of tightly scheduled rehearsal, a few weeks of out-of-town tryouts and then a New York opening. Workshop conditions at the Public, during which he could develop his idea with a cast of dancers, gave him respite from time and money pressures. . . . In August, Papp was invited to sit in at final callbacks for dancers, who auditioned . . . by reading the transcripts of the tapes some of them had made half a year earlier.
Those who were chosen for Bennett's first workshop began the process of creating "A Chorus Line" -- five weeks of working 14 hours per day in the Newman Theater for $100 per week. . . . Many of the dancers found . . . the ongoing interviewing process, by which both the play and the songwriting continued, intrusive and left. . . . In December . . . Michael Bennett reassembled his dancers and collaborators for their second workshop. With James Kirkwood, a novelist and playwright, the team . . . plunged into another three months of work, bringing Papp's investment and his anxiety about its development to a high. . . . On May 21, the day of the press opening, Papp sent Bennett his standard letter to playwrights, inviting him to come back and fail at the Public but by then, almost everyone at the Festival knew that they had something extraordinary in the building. . . . "Anyone who saw the show would just sit there and weep," recalled a staffer. "There were standing ovations from the beginning." . . . In July . . . Papp moved it to Broadway where it would win the Festival its third Pulitzer Prize and break all records.
"A Chorus Line" would also, as Papp had foreseen, break many connections as well. Bennett became a millionaire. The show's several collaborators quarreled and several dancers felt cheated. But Bennett and Papp maintained the cordial relation they had pledged to uphold. Their association was one that Papp would later recall as simple, constant and untroubled. It stood him in good stead as, at 54, he plunged into what would be the most glamorous as well as frustrating period of the New York Shakespeare Festival.
 From "Joe Papp."
 
 
 
BIOGRAPHERS AREN'T BURGLARS
 Helen Epstein is on a high. She's just back from a two-week publicity tour in Prague where her first book, "Children of the Holocaust," has finally been published in Czech -- 15 years after its appearance in English. "This was very important to me," the author, who was born in Prague, explained. The book, which broke new ground in 1979, has been published in several languages, but "none as significant as this one," Ms. Epstein said.
In a telephone interview from her vacation home in the Berkshires, the author, now 46, spoke about her new book, "Joe Papp: An American Life," and about her collaboration with Gail Merrifield Papp, his widow, who asked her to write this biography shortly after his death. Ms. Epstein has written that Papp's widow "respected the integrity of the writing process. . . . She never imposed her convictions on me."
But "almost everyone," she continued, "expressed fear of a whitewash. People believe that if you are given access to private papers, you essentially have to trade your independence for that access. I think that kind of investigative journalism mentality is driving attitudes toward authorized biographies, which is basically that they're suspect. Many, many professional and personal friends actually came right out and said, 'How are you going to do this?' They didn't believe I could pull it off. But biographers who do it know that if you respect the process, the process takes care of itself."
Nevertheless, she said, "It was very, very difficult. I got really angry at some of the recent accusations about biographers being burglars and immoral people. All the biographers I know are incredibly respectful of people's privacy.
"This biography involved extraordinary tightrope walking between private and public, between what to divulge and what not to divulge. It wasn't only Gail. There were five Papp children involved here and two ex-wives about whom I was extremely sensitive because they're lovely people.
"There was an enormous number of people whose feelings, whose sexuality, whose alcoholism, had to be hidden or respected. Some people wanted to be identified as homosexuals; some didn't. The hardest thing about writing this book was dealing with everybody's psychological problems."
The author characterized her relationship with Joseph Papp as that of a portrait painter to her canvas. "It was hard to react to the whole person because there are so many different parts of him and I feel so differently toward each one of them. Some I admired and some I didn't."
"As for the collaboration," she said, "it was harder on me than my marriage. My husband is in business and I don't see him all day."
 LYNN KARPEN

A review on Aug. 21, about "Joe Papp: An American Life," described a daughter of Joseph Papp, the theatrical producer, incorrectly. Mr. Papp's daughter Barbara, whose existence he was unaware of for many years, was his second daughter, not his first. A letter explaining the mistake was received by the Book Review soon afterward, but it was misdirected.

HEADLINE: The Case of the Murdered Candidate

BYLINE: By Tim Golden; Tim Golden is the Mexico City bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
IN THE VIDEOTAPES OF LUIS DONALDO COLOSIO'S last campaign speech, the working-class neighborhood spreading before him in Tijuana looks like any other colonia of half-paved streets and yards fenced in by bedsprings. Women in nylon dresses press against a line of men guarding the candidate's path. College students hold up a banner proclaiming "Enough!" of the 65-year rule of Colosio's Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI. But on the plywood shacks and cinder-block cubes that fill the steep canyon called Lomas Taurinas, there are many more banners: "Colosio," they read, "Colosio, We're Going for More" and "Colosio, I Love You."
As cameras follow him out of a brown Chevrolet Suburban just before 4:30 P.M. on March 23, Colosio radiates a confidence that had been missing from his campaign. The seemingly calm, upbeat country that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had bequeathed to him with the governing-party nomination in November had disappeared with the New Year. The peasant rebellion that erupted in the southern state of Chiapas took the Government by surprise. Bombings in Mexico City, the kidnappings of two powerful businessmen, new pressure for political change and an angry backlash from hard-liners within his party -- all of that had battered a candidate who stood for the status quo. 
 Finally, though, Colosio was regaining momentum. Lashing out at the system through which he had risen, he vowed on March 6 to tear the roots of authoritarianism from Mexican soil. The day before his arrival in Tijuana, his chief rival within the party, Manuel Camacho Solis, finally abandoned his threat to seek the presidency himself. In March, the polls still showed Colosio comfortably ahead. On the videotape, as he clambers onto the bed of a pickup truck to speak, the crowd in Lomas Taurinas smiles back at him enthusiastically, quite sure that he will be their next President.
"Friends of Tijuana, friends of the working-class colonias, this political campaign should allow us on the 21st of August to give Baja California and our country a secure destiny, a path of certainty," he tells them. "We are going to win!"
As the candidate hops down from the pickup and pushes back through the crowd, the smile never leaves his face. A jumpy ranchera song blares over the public address system, and he reaches over the shoulders of his bodyguards to shake hands. A gun reaches over them, too, sliding up out of the crowd and settling just behind Colosio's right ear.
What the tapes don't show is whose hand pulls the trigger on the battered .38-caliber revolver that was later picked out of the dirt at the scene. In half a second, the gun simply appears, fires and shatters the certainty with which Mexico had so long been governed.
Who killed Colosio? Like the Zapruder film of the Kennedy assassination, the videotapes of Colosio's death are vague enough to allow all sorts of interpretations. A 23-year-old factory worker named Mario Aburto Martinez was tackled at the scene and reportedly confessed to committing the crime while acting alone. But that convinced almost no one. In the frenzied search for conspiracies, some Mexicans pointed to Tijuana's most powerful cocaine traffickers, who had been sought for 10 months in the still-unsolved murder of a Roman Catholic cardinal, and to "narcopoliticos," the corrupt politicians believed to protect them. Others suspected hard-line members of the PRI, renegade members of the security forces, even Salinas himself. It was only a measure of the cold war's distance that the Central Intelligence Agency went unmentioned.
Even as Mexicans go to the polls for today's elections, with Colosio's former campaign manager, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon at the head of the PRI ticket, they are still waiting to find out who, if anyone, moved Mario Aburto's hand. Although President Salinas swore at Colosio's graveside that "justice will be totally done," the Government's subsequent performance raised doubts among cynical Mexicans. Only days after Government officials described the killer as a lonely fanatic, the special prosecutor assigned to the case, Miguel Montes Garcia, shocked the country by announcing that "several individuals" had helped Aburto close in on Colosio in the crowd. Three months later, Montes reversed himself, returning to the lone-gunman theory and raising a storm of criticism that was quieted only after Salinas reopened the case with a new investigator.
What Montes did not do was to confront openly the suspects on whom most Mexicans -- particularly those within the Government -- focused right away: the corrupt, conservative factions of the PRI that have resented Salinas's drive for economic modernization. The suspicions were perhaps inevitable in a society where killings of political dissidents have often gone unsolved and where promises of democracy and a more equitable distribution of wealth have long gone unfulfilled. No hard evidence of such a plot has emerged. No specific motives have been discerned. But by what it left out as much as what it turned up, the Government's faltering inquiry has cast a shadow over the PRI and its future. If the Government cannot convincingly explain the killing of its own presidential candidate, Mexicans have asked, how can it promise justice for people with no power? And without at least a vaguely credible legal system, how far can the country's push for economic and political reform progress? The case of the murdered candidate involves more than a crime. The killing has exposed fault lines in a society that, notwithstanding its rising stock market and confident young technocrats, remains divided and uncertain.
FOR DAYS AFTER COLOSIO'S death, Ernesto Ruffo kept asking, perhaps disingenuously, "Why Tijuana?" As Mexico's first opposition-party governor since the PRI was formed in 1929, Ruffo had grown uncomfortably familiar with hidden agendas. He had fought with Mexico City over Federal money that his state, Baja California, did not receive and over the huge sums that Salinas poured directly into Federal antipoverty programs. He had found political meddling in the fight against drugs, and drug interests mixed in the fights of local politicians. But there is no shortage of answers to his question.
The city itself, a pastiche of glitzy nightclubs and cheap brothels, glass office towers and endless slums terraced with old tires, dramatizes the tensions of a country teased by the riches of its northern neighbor and anchored painfully to a bitter, underdeveloped south. Some of the locals who had spoken from the pickup truck before Colosio made the point plainly: they were striving, unsatisfied people who had mostly come from other parts of the country, wanted better than they got and would work to get more. They lived on the border, one of them noted, but were proud enough not to cross it.
There was no mention in the speeches of another, violent side of Tijuana, but that was one Colosio might have taken for granted. Three weeks before his arrival, a highly regarded young Federal police commander and four other people had been killed in a shootout near a Tijuana shopping mall. Their opponents were gangsters tied to the Arellano brothers, the homegrown brood of violent, cocaine-trafficking yuppies who were being hunted for the killing of Juan Jesus Cardinal Posadas Ocampo at the Guadalajara airport in May 1993. No sooner had the two most important traffickers of the lot been captured than they were allowed to sneak out the back door of the state police headquarters by a cooperative commander.
Neither Colosio nor Salinas was especially popular with their party's traditionalists in Tijuana. Baja had delivered Salinas one of the worst defeats of any Mexican state in his July 1988 election. The new President had quickly exacted revenge, throwing out the legendarily corrupt governor, Xicotencatl Leyva. When Ruffo defeated the PRI in the ensuing gubernatorial election, Colosio, then the president of the party, earned the hatred of its local leaders by quickly recognizing the opposition's victory. It was the first time in its 60-year history that the governing party had accepted such a loss.
Salinas and Colosio "had to show right at the door of the United States that there was going to be democracy in this country," says Jesus Blancornelas, the editor of Tijuana's independent weekly newspaper, Zeta. "But the party did not like it at all."
Cries of "Colosio Traitor!" and "Death to Colosio!" went up among some of the labor-union leaders and other party bosses. But for the president of the PRI and his direct superior, Salinas, Baja California became an experiment in how to remake a broken political party. Lomas Taurinas, the province of a wiry political boss named Agustin Perez Rivero, became one of their laboratories.
Under a scheme that the party began to perfect in the 1970's, the PRI turned to men like Don Agustin, as he likes to be called, to gain control over the vast squatter settlements that had sprung up on publicly owned land. With the blessing of local officials, Don Agustin would sell small plots for $500 or $1,000, from which party and Government officials would take a cut. Little if any paper changed hands. In return for Government tolerance and the occasional attentions of public works officials, Don Agustin would do his best to assure that his colonia voted solidly for the PRI.
"Every time Don Agustin woke up, he needed some new sandals," says Sofia Colin, a 28-year-old housewife who moved to the neighborhood upon arriving from Mexico City in 1985. "If he took a breath, he needed a new shirt. His secretaries would leave a white envelope and you had to put in what you could. When politicians would come from Mexico City, he made everyone dress up in green shirts and white pants; they called it the 'Coalition of People's Colonias.' And anyone who did not go to one of those meetings, they would take away their land."
Part of Salinas's strategy for breaking these strangleholds was his lavish antipoverty initiative, the National Solidarity Program. Under the program, neighbors would form small committees to decide whether they most needed a sewer, a school or something else. They would then contribute labor or money to the job, which would be supervised and mostly financed by the Government. The program circumvented inefficient and corrupt Federal and local agencies, and often gave squatters title to their land. The principal result was to steadily build the popularity of a president whose election had been marred by accusations of fraud and to cut people like Don Agustin out of the loop.
"They came in and started telling us that what we didn't do for ourselves nobody was going to do for us," Colin recalls, describing her first attendance at one of the seminars that the local Solidarity office organized for some of the feistier women in Lomas Taurinas. "They said we didn't need our little leaders for anything. So we started asking them where all the money we gave them was going."
As president of the PRI until early 1992, Colosio tried to generate similar struggles around the country. He largely failed in his quest to turn the rusted machine of interest groups cutting secret deals into a real party of voters. But thereafter, dispensing the Solidarity program's riches as the new Secretary of Social Development, he began to inherit the support that Salinas had built. Colosio was confident enough of his independence from the party machine that, soon after his nomination, the PRI logo began to disappear from his campaign.
EVEN TENS OF THOUSANDS OF solidarity committees, however, do not make a revolution. How little things had actually changed in Tijuana became apparent as soon as the assassination investigation began. An hour before midnight on March 23, Diego Valades, the bookish constitutional lawyer who in January had become Salinas's fourth attorney general, stopped to see Ruffo in his Tijuana office. With him went Manlio Fabio Beltrones, the tough, 41-year-old governor of the neighboring Sonora state. Beltrones had risen through the political elite as an aide to Salinas's former interior minister, Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, a veteran of 30 years in the upper reaches of the country's secret police.
Valades had been seething about Baja California for three weeks, since state police released the drug traffickers who had been arrested in the slaying of the Federal police commander. Even as Colosio lay dying in the Tijuana General Hospital, people had spoken to Valades about the possible involvement of members or former members of the same force.
"This is your police that are involved again," Ruffo recalls Valades telling him. "Your police are scum!" Ruffo objected that there was no such information.
By the next day, he says, Valades had changed his tone. He even greeted the deputy state prosecutor, whom he would later have arrested at gunpoint for setting the drug traffickers free. For reasons that never became entirely clear, Salinas pulled Valades off the investigation within days and forced him to resign six weeks after that. The attorney general's suspicions about the involvement of corrupt cops in the assassination would later be borne out. But the corrupt cops would not be Ruffo's.
The strange things that began happening immediately after the assassination seemed to concentrate around the one Tijuana cop with a notable reputation for honesty. Jose Federico Benitez, a former businessman with the air of a boy scout troop leader, had cleaned out nearly a third of of the city police force during 16 months as its chief. Though he had no jurisdiction over the Colosio case, he was approached the day after the murder by a man who said he had been given a valise for safekeeping by Aburto's mother. The man said he went to the city police because no one paid attention to him at the Federal attorney general's office. The story never quite made sense to Benitez, but when he opened the valise he found a trove of Aburto's belongings, including a collection of strange, amateurish drawings, a small address book and a ledger full of rambling, misspelled diatribes against the Government. The items were quickly handed over to Federal agents, and within 48 hours the contents began to leak out selectively, supporting a presumption that Aburto was deranged.
"He does not seem to be crazy, but like a zealot," one of the officials calling around to reporters said. "It seems now like he acted alone. There are drawings."
Aburto's own statements seemed to contradict this idea. He told his interrogators that he belonged to some sort of political group and that he had "saved Mexico." What he might have meant by this provoked frantic speculation about possible conspiracies. Photos of the crowd at Colosio's rally began to appear in newspapers and magazines with little circles around the heads of suspects later questioned by Federal investigators. Politicians and Government officials who participated in the fight over Colosio's replacement, found themselves mentioned in newspaper stories about the investigation.
On April 4, the special prosecutor, Montes, went on national television to announce that he had four new suspects in custody and was hunting for two more.
"Several individuals agreed that they undertook a concerted action with the common goal of taking the life of Luis Donaldo Colosio," he said, presenting portions of a videotape that showed a tight crowd of men jostling one another in Colosio's path. A retired state police official named Vicente Mayoral Valenzuela "opened the way to the victim" for Aburto, Montes said. Mayoral's unemployed son, Rodolfo, set out "to push and block" one of Colosio's bodyguards. Tranquilino Sanchez Venegas, a 57-year-old former store security guard shown on the videotape with a happy grin, "facilitated" Aburto's approach to the candidate, Montes said.
All three of the suspects were members of the crowd control team assembled by the Tijuana branch of the PRI. They had been recruited by a local PRI official and former state police commander named Jose Rodolfo Rivapalacio, who was also taken into custody. All Montes left out was a motive. But Rivapalacio, in particular, gave conspiracy theorists ample material to work with, even after he was released by a Federal judge for lack of evidence. He declined to be interviewed in his home, which looked rather luxurious for that of a retired cop with a sixth-grade education. In the office of his lawyer, however, Rivapalacio could hardly stop talking.
Yes, it was true that he used to bring home shopping bags with $10,000 or $20,000; the money came from rewards he received from American insurance companies for recovering stolen cars taken across the border. Yes, it was true that he had investigated political dissidents and arrested all of Ruffo's bodyguards when he was running for governor in 1988. Sure, he would be happy to talk to the San Diego detectives who had been trying to speak to him for seven years about an unsolved attack on his ex-wife, who was stabbed 17 times with an ice pick. No, he would not cross the border to do so: he owed some back taxes on a factory he once owned.
"They got Al Capone for not paying his taxes," Rivapalacio observed.
JESUS BLANCORNELAS, THE newspaper editor, is Tijuana's resident expert on murder conspiracy investigations. He watched the videotapes of the Colosio killing, checked into the backgrounds of the suspects and pronounced himself unimpressed. Even by local standards, the jailed cops didn't seem either nasty or smart enough to take on such a big job. And what could Aburto possibly consider sufficient compensation for taking the fall?
"Every reporter who comes to town brings his own theory about a plot, which he insists on proving even when there is no proof," said Blancornelas, a slight man with a well-trimmed, graying beard and wire-rimmed glasses. "I think it has become a matter of shame, that they cannot accept that one man overcame the entire national security apparatus of the country."
As the weeks passed, Montes said almost nothing publicly about the case, leaving speculation to run wild. But as court files began to leak out, his case began to look far less certain. The most his lip readers could produce from the videotapes was a claim that Rodolfo Mayoral had appeared to say something in Aburto's vicinity that sounded like "Wait." He also uttered a word with the letter A. As in, "Avientalo!" they suggested, "Blow him away!"
According to an official who saw the case summary prepared for Montes by Federal investigators, it had not even mentioned a mysterious security agent, Jorge Antonio Sanchez Ortega, who was arrested near the murder scene by Tijuana police and then mysteriously freed despite having tested positive for having fired a gun. When Montes finally tracked down the two suspects he had mentioned earlier but had not been able to identify, he decided against arresting them. Again, he declined to explain.
More questions were asked by the Tijuana police chief, Benitez, in the weeks following the assassination. On orders from Ruffo, he had dug up police files on members of Rivapalacio's crowd control force. It called itself the Tucan Group, after a Spanish acronym for Ruffo's and Benitez's political party: "Everyone United Against National Action." Benitez would wonder aloud about the case to anyone who dropped by his tiny downtown office. What about the different trajectories of the bullets that hit Colosio? Might they have come from different guns? And the strange valise Benitez had received? Why had Colosio's military bodyguards told some of his officers they would be going to look for the murder weapon at the scene -- even though they knew that the Taurus revolver Aburto said was his had already been recovered?
On April 28, Benitez was murdered. He was being driven home from work when his pickup truck was pinned by two cars not far from Lomas Taurinas. He and his driver were both shot dead. State officials suggested that the killing might have been ordered by local drug traffickers. But as the weeks passed they produced no evidence to sustain their explanation.
In his four months as special prosecutor, Montes visited Tijuana only once, briefly. From conversations with Aburto's neighbors, co-workers and relatives, it wasn't clear that his dozens of carefully selected investigators had been energetic, either. A neighbor who told of Aburto discussing guns over the man's cellular telephone said he was never questioned. A young woman who had worked with Aburto at a dingy cassette-tape assembly plant near the United States border said he had told her shortly before the assassination that he was about to receive a lot of money for something he would do, that politics was involved and that he might end up on television. Her testimony was taken and appears to have been discounted.
Montes paid much more attention to another girl Aburto had worked with, Graciela Gonzalez, the 16-year-old daughter of a retired army captain. In a series of statements to investigators while she was closeted in a Tijuana hotel, Gonzalez described in almost photographic detail how she and Aburto encountered Tranquilino Sanchez, one of the four men jailed after the killing, as they strolled through a Tijuana park. She also claimed that Aburto had told her of going to Chiapas around the time of the peasant revolt and of belonging to some sort of political group.
Months later, however, it turned out that she had picked Sanchez from a police lineup filled with the detectives who had been interrogating her. It hadn't been Sanchez she had seen, she later testified, but Vicente Mayoral. Subsequently, she disavowed her most important testimony almost entirely. "The court lawyer wrote it," one of the investigators admitted later about Gonzalez's testimony. "It is what is called a 'maquinazo,' an invention of the typewriter." And yes, the investigator acknowledged, Tranquilino Sanchez had given some ofhis testimony from a wheelchair, having apparently been beaten by police interrogators.
Montes complained privately to at least two officials that some unofficial investigators were getting in his way, interviewing potential witnesses before his men arrived and perhaps affecting their testimony. The investigators appeared to have been dispatched, Montes said, by a man named Miguel Nazar Haro, a former head of the Federal Security Directorate, a shadowy and notoriously corrupt branch of the Interior Ministry. Nazar, who jumped $200,000 bail in San Diego (he was charged in 1982 with participating in a huge stolen-car ring run out of the directorate), had apparently been advising Governor Beltrones of Sonora on security matters. The Governor did not answer requests for comment on his role in the Colosio case.
Court documents show that there were in fact three security contingents present at the assassination site: Rivapalacio's, Colosio's and an additional force called the Omega Group. The group, which numbered about 160 men around the country, was headed by a man named Fernando de la Sota. According to several officials, de la Sota had been an agent in the Federal Security Directorate, which was eventually disbanded, and later was dismissed from the Federal Judicial Police. He was never implicated in Colosio's death, and nothing more was disclosed about the Omega Group.
MONTES'S CASE FOR A conspiracy had been built largely on three pillars: the videotapes, Graciela Gonzalez's testimony about Sanchez's friendship with Aburto and Sanchez's admission to that effect. But by now the videotapes had been discredited by the Spanish experts, Gonzalez had retracted most of her "testimony," and Sanchez was still wearing a neck brace. Montes began to back away from what he had always insisted was merely a theory about "concerted action."
"It is possible that somebody with enough ability, seeing Mario Aburto's personality, could have stimulated him somehow, directly or indirectly," Montes said in an interview. "That's possible. It's very possible that he went to different kinds of political meetings. But this office is only working on a criminal investigation, not a political and social investigation.
"I never used the word 'plot.' " he adds. "I never used the word 'conspiracy.' And I get a little desperate when people keep saying, 'The truth cannot be known.' The truth they have thought up in advance is some ghost of their own making. Whenever there are magnicides, there is some important number of people who cast doubt on the results of any investigation. That happens in every latitude. How many people in your country believe the Warren Commission report?"
Meanwhile, Colosio's widow, Diana Laura Riojas, suggested pointedly that she was still waiting to learn who had killed her husband. After hiring one of the country's leading criminal lawyers, she left Mexico for a long vacation in Europe. When Montes announced his return to the lone-gunman theory, the lawyer promptly dismissed it as "ridiculous, period." A long list of Colosio's friends published a letter in Mexico City newspapers asking for something more credible. Some of them told friends that they then received death threats over the phone.
Nearly lost in all of the uproar over Montes's conclusions about the lone-assassin theory was the known assassin. Along with psychiatric studies showing him to be paranoid and narcissistic, Montes produced some old criminal records about Aburto's father having once been sought for murder in an old shootout. The Government distributed copies of Aburto's ledger, authenticated by handwriting experts, which showed at the very least that he didn't like the PRI. According to Montes, Aburto had asked his jailers for "Don Quixote."
HOW FAR COLOSIO might have carried Mexico's political reform can only be guessed. He was neither the brightest nor the most forceful of Salinas's heirs. But to many Mexicans he came to represent the possibility that the next government could balance the country's rising demands for change against the resistance of the old guard.
Although Colosio had not yet confronted the party's "dinosaurs," his closest aides say that curtailing their power was his central goal. Before gaining his nomination by the traditional, entirely undemocratic means, he had seemed to believe with Salinas that Mexico could make the inevitable transition to democracy without putting the power of the governing party at risk. That is, the PRI should face open competition but only as the economy produced wider benefits and the party was restructured to make it more representative. With his death, the country he had begun to to describe as "hungering and thirsting for justice," seemed to grow less patient.
No matter how badly the Government may have botched the investigation, a plurality of Mexicans may well vote for the PRI anyway, whether out of cynicism, dissatisfaction with the alternatives or fear of change. But whoever wins is unlikely to gain a majority of the vote. A consequence, at least starting out, could be the weakest Mexican President in memory. Even if the victor is Zedillo, the Colosio investigation will leave a cloud over the new Government. Dispersing it could require steps as difficult as holding fair elections, rooting out corruption and building a credible legal system.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
San Francisco's Chefs Explore Beyond the Bay

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER is a reporter for the style department of The Times.

 BODY:
TRAVELERS to San Francisco this summer in search of what is new and hot on the restaurant front may have to cross a bridge or two to find out. So far this year, a half dozen or more leading chefs have opened second or third restaurants in the surrounding countryside, from Marin, Napa and Sonoma Counties in the north to Palo Alto in the south.
This gastronomic greening trend has several causes. For one, San Francisco, which is finally emerging from a long recession exacerbated by the 1989 earthquake, is saturated with restaurants. At the same time, many affluent suburbs suffer from a dearth of fine dining. Add to this the allure of the tourist-rich wine country, and it's no wonder chefs are expanding out of town. 
 Several of the new out-of-town restaurants I visited recently were clearly works in progress, with rough edges here and there. Nevertheless, all of these establishments can be recommended, even as they hone their acts. Wine aficionados will find an intriguing selection of small, lesser known labels that are fun to sample, and most are offered at fair prices.
 
The Left Bank
One of the first major chefs to carry his pans across the Golden Gate was Bradley Ogden, the chef at San Francisco's highly regarded restaurant in the Campton Place Hotel, who left there five years ago to open a restaurant in The Lark Creek Inn in Larkspur, population 12,000, about 14 miles north of the city. It continues to thrive, a countrified restaurant only 15 minutes from downtown San Francisco. In early July another well-known chef put down stakes in Larkspur: Roland Passot, the amiable French owner of the cozy La Folie in San Francisco. Mr. Passot's new brasserie-style venture, called the Left Bank, represents his longtime passion for a simple, friendly place "where people can drop in and have just oysters and a glass of wine or a full meal."
The Left Bank, on the ground level of The Blue Rock Inn, a former hotel that is now an apartment building, is a big, cheery place, a pale yellow expanse with a stone fireplace and simply appointed tables. A bar menu includes French staples like croque-monsieur; the Mediterranean pizza, pissaladiere, and rillettes of pork and duck. The long wooden bar has an easygoing, neighborly feeling -- two of our nibbling neighbors were Mr. Ogden and his wife, Jody, taking a night off from their own restaurant.
From the main menu we sampled a lovely onion and leek tart with a bracing foundation of smoked bacon, and a pleasing warm melange of mussels, roasted artichokes and garlic. Main courses range from the whimsically named, like the roasted eggplant sandwich "Jacques Pepin" with mozzarella and sun-dried tomatoes, to brasserie standards such as hearty roast pork loin Normandy style, with apples, celery, onions and Calvados, or steak with french fries. For those who like quenelles, the scallop version here is light and full flavored, served with a tomato, olive and mushroom sauce. One of the few letdowns is dry and underseasoned rillettes.
The most entertaining -- and delicious -- dessert is a frothy shake of blueberries, milk and ice cream in a tall cone-shaped glass, garnished with straw-shaped cookies. It is available in a variety of fresh berry flavors.
 
The French Laundry
The town of Yountville was the home of a popular little restaurant called the French Laundry from 1977 until earlier this year, when it closed for renovations after Thomas Keller purchased it. In the late 1980's, Mr. Keller was the chef at a restaurant called Rakel in Manhattan, and later in Los Angeles at the Checkers Hotel Kempinski. The French Laundry reopened early last month.
The new Keller establishment, a delightful 90-minute drive up Route 29 in the Napa Valley through amber hills punctuated by expanses of dark green vines, is a bucolic gem. The two-level cottage is done in understated ivory tones with gentle lighting and sprays of fresh flowers. Mr. Keller serves sophisticated contemporary American cuisine that is authoritatively seasoned, artfully presented and usually surprising in one way or another. On the current menu are dishes like pan-sauteed California squab with braised red mustard greens, bacon-wrapped saddle of rabbit with roasted fennel and herb-crusted New England codfish with a ragout of summer vegetables.
A concentrated "martini" of crystalline tomato water infused with fresh herbs tastes like summer liquefied. A golden disk of quarter-sized sauteed potato slices is topped with unusually tasty summer truffles. Mr. Keller also serves a ripe tomato terrine with a warm red onion marmalade and chives, and a chilled fricassee of fresh baby artichokes in a basil-infused olive oil.
For a main course, perfectly cooked salmon is served on a plate dusted with spicy orange-based powder with a lovely citric sauce. An enticingly lacquered squab suffers from dryness, however.
One of the more diverting desserts is "coffee and doughnuts," little cinnamon doughnuts served with cups of cappuccino semifreddo. Sorbets and ice creams are terrific, as is the warm Valhrona chocolate truffle cake with caramel cream.
 
Stars Oakville Cafe
Two miles up Route 29, the town of Oakville, ringed by the wineries Mondavi, Opus One, Vichon and Robert Pepi, is also distinguished by a restaurant owned by a celebrated California chef. Stars Oakville Cafe, which Jeremiah Tower of Stars and Stars Cafe in San Francisco opened last October, is modest looking from the outside, a squat white building off the main highway. The front dining room is as stark as a contemporary gallery, with framed photographs and artwork surrounding cafe tables.
At this time of year a larger dining area is open in the back under a green-and-white striped tent facing a garden and aviary. The day we were there a cook was tending a whole baby lamb that was rotating over a wood fire -- unfortunately it was for a private party that evening to which we were not invited.
All the salads can be recommended, their ingredients so fresh they appear to have been relayed from a local garden by a sprinter. The golden onion tart is a paragon, lusciously sweet and with a perfect crust. Not so an attractive but lackluster appetizer of marinated gulf prawns, roasted sweet pepper and mint.
Among the main courses for lunch is a wonderful cherry-smoked pork chop, as thick as the San Francisco Yellow Pages, and remarkably moist and tender. It comes with roasted eggplant and marinated tomatoes. Another restorative entree is the wood-oven-roasted chicken cut up and served amid a Tuscan-style bread salad. Desserts are simple and satisfying, especially the ripe little strawberry tartlet and the chocolate hazelnut torte.
 
Catahoula
About six miles north of Oakville on Route 29, on the northern fringe of the Napa Valley, is an engagingly rustic new place, Catahoula, run by another Campton Place alumnus, Jan Birnbaum. Housed in the Mount View Hotel and Spa, the restaurant specializes in wood-oven roasting, which is done in a brick oven with a roaring fire in view of diners. Given Mr. Birnbaum's comforting and copious specialties it is nice to know that there is a treadmill on the premises, even if you have no intention of touching it.
The main dining room, with its cement floor, heavy wooden tables, and industrial-looking abstract sculpture, is a refreshing change from the more mannered restaurants that dot the valley. Mr. Birnbaum, a hearty and generous man, reinforces that theme. A Louisiana native, he worked with Paul Prudhomme at K-Paul's Louisiana Kitchen in New Orleans before heading north, eventually taking over the kitchen of Campton Place.
Starters include nicely charred wood-oven pizza with spicy andouille sausage; spicy rooster gumbo, and two seasonal dishes, crawfish tamales stoked with three kinds of hot peppers, and fried crawfish salad with pickled jalapenos and carrots. Among the more unusual main courses are roast loin of pork scented with lavender and ringed with fresh figs, a moist baby chicken served in a broth with summer vegetables, and a striped bass fillet with a shellfish and rice mixture. Catahoula -- it is named for the state dog of Louisiana -- has a good wine selection well suited to this robust food. Meals are also served around a pool behind the spa -- but given Mr. Birnbaum's full-plate tendencies, this might not be a place to test your buoyancy.
 
 
 
TWO ADDITIONS TO CITY'S MENU
 A second stage of the San Francisco restaurant boom continues to gain momentum, and two relatively new places visited recently -- one American, one French -- are worth seeking out. Prices are per person for a three-course meal with wine, but not including tax and tip.
The five-month-old Rubicon, a stylish brick-and-wood establishment with snug booths along one wall and a semi-exposed kitchen on the other, is named after a wine produced by Francis Ford Coppola in Napa County. Mr. Coppola is one of Rubicon's owners, along with Drew Nieporent, a well-known New York restaurateur.
The chef, Traci Des Jardins, most recently worked at the cross-cultural Elka restaurant in San Francisco, and before that in Los Angeles with Joachim Splichal at the renowned Patina.
Rubicon's contemporary American menu includes such winners as rare slices of lamb over basil mashed potatoes with fava beans, grilled John Dory with braised onions, truffle oil and salsify, and Muscovy duck breast with a fruit compote and shiitake ravioli. The wine list is exceptionally well chosen, both for price and for its compatability with the food.
Rubicon, at 558 Sacramento Street in San Francisco, is open for lunch Monday to Friday and dinner Monday to Saturday. Lunch is $25, dinner $35. All major credit cards accepted. Phone (415) 434-4100).
Year-old Bizou, in a San Francisco neighborhood known as SOMA (South of Market Street), is bright and upbeat, swabbed glowing yellow outside and ocher-toned within. A relaxing spot for lunch, it is more animated in the evening.
The chef, Loretta Keller, came from Jeremiah Tower's Stars and Stars Cafe. At lunch recently, a sweet pepper stuffed with a mildly seasoned brandade de morue (seasoned pureed salt cod) was served with a snappy caper sauce. Crispy homemade flatbread is a perfect accompaniment. An unusual and compelling entree is called beef-and-potato straw cake, a loosely bound melange of julienned potatoes, onions, peppers and beef redolent of thyme.
Typical dinner entrees include wood-oven baked quail with sweet corn, roasted chilis and barley pilaf, and beef cheeks with mustard, watercress and new potatoes.
Bizou, 598 Fourth Street at Brannan, is open for lunch Monday to Friday and dinner Monday to Saturday. Lunch is $20, dinner $30. Visa, Mastercard, American Expresss; (415) 543-2222.

HEADLINE: Another View Of an Airport

 BODY:
The article describing the expansion plans at Sikorsky Memorial Airport ("Aftermath of a Crash: Should an Airport Grow?" July 31) left out several important issues.
The airport is geographically challenged. It is surrounded on all sides by the Town of Stratford, Long Island Sound and the Housatonic River. There is very little room for a lengthened runway, an access road and the existing structures. 
 The two major corporate residents of the area, Sikorsky and Lycoming, both military contractors, are downsizing or consolidating, and the most active airline operator, Business Express, has restructured, laid off 15 percent of its workforce, and moved its management from Westport to Portsmouth, N.H. Corporate aviation growth forecasts are paltry at best. Do these facts support commercial arguments for airport expension?
In severe weather, Long Island Sound and the Housatonic River have flooded the runways, suspending airport operations. Will the runways be elevated? Will dikes be built? Will this have any consequences for the ecology of the area surrounding the airport?
As for safety concerns, a startling piece of information has been ignored or downplayed. At the eastern end of the runway to be lengthened, almost directly in the runway centerline, stands a large occupied condominium complex complete with marina. Not too many years ago a small private plane, departing from the runway in question, lost power and was forced down in a field just yards to the west of the condominiums.
Luckily, there were no injuries, but it was made very clear that the proximity of this complex to the airport presents a clear and present danger. With a longer runway, allowing operations of larger aircraft, the margin of safety is even further diminished.
Doesn't lengthening the runway increase the probability of a more tragic accident?
Given the local weather conditions, given the fact that the tower is shut down after 10 P.M., given the fact that the residents of Milford, already in the flight path for departures to the east, would be dealing with larger aircraft climbing out at lower altitudes, with whose safety is the commission really concerned?
What is the real motivation for this entire issue? Prior to the accident, the commission was clamoring to expand the airport for commercial reasons. Immediately following the possibility of Donald Trump building a casino in Bridgeport, airport expansion became a hot topic. And now we have a Donald Trump amusement park proposal. And a greyhound track proposal.
Could the commission's chairman, the Mayor of Bridgeport, have multiple agendas? Remember, this is the Mayor who chose not to stand in the way of the Unification Church's takeover of the University of Bridgeport. This is the Mayor who predicted new job creation in the depressed area surrounding the university. Should we really trust his judgments?
Who pays the bill for airport expansion?
Who will reap the benefits of airport expansion?
Many years ago, the city of Portland, Ore., decided that the road to prosperity was going to be a freeway that would bisect the city. After years of pitched battle, the city decided to modify its arrogant stance and try a new approach. It would enlist the help and cooperation of all the communities affected by the proposed freeway in an effort to improve the city's traffic problems and to end the conflict with the neighborhoods.
Portland did not build a freeway. Portland did not create new slums, create more tensions between the haves and the have nots. What it did was create a trolley-based transportation system that did not undermine the economic and social values of the neighborhoods it serves. It built a system and innovatively solved a problem in a way that increased the value of the city and guaranteed its future as a mighty nice place to live.
It would be nice if the City of Bridgeport could borrow from Portland's experience. The Mayor has enormous problems facing him. His focus should be on solutions with social value and long-term economic returns within the borders of his fair city. He should spend less time worrying about his outpost airport. He should try working with, not fighting against, the residents of Stratford.
And most importantly, he should be sure he knows the cause of the recent tragedy at the airport before he sets the stage for an even greater tragedy.
CARL THOMPSON
Stratford

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Lease Buyouts;
As the Market Firms, Tenants Can Get Off the Hook

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, a tenant that wanted to buy its way out of a lease was pretty much out of luck. With prime real estate going begging throughout the recession-ravaged city -- and with financially troubled tenants demonstrating a tendency to default on their rents -- few landlords would let reliable bill-payers out of their lease obligations. The few that did asked such high prepayment penalties that tenants went scurrying after sublessees anyway.
Times are changing. As the real estate market continues to firm up, more and more landlords are letting tenants out of leases, for as little as half their remaining obligation. 
 In fact, many actually welcome the chance to accommodate new tenants who are likely to stay well beyond the original tenant's lease expiration date. And many welcome even more the opportunity to combine the departing tenant's space with other space in the building to create a larger, and thus more marketable, block of contiguous floors.
"Lease buyouts are a classic win/win situation," said Robert Constable, a managing director at the real estate firm Edward S. Gordon. "The tenant gets to avoid risk and consolidate its balance sheet and the landlord reduces downtime between tenants."
Examples abound. The Cigna Insurance Company had two years left on a floor at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, at 47th Street. W&M Properties, the building's manager, was having no luck renting the vacant floor below Cigna. So Anthony E. Malkin, W&M's president, let Cigna buy its way out of its lease and began marketing the two floors together.
"We actually had two tenants compete for the two-floor block," Mr. Malkin said.
Gerald W. Griffin, a partner at Cooper & Dunham, helped get the two floors for his law firm. Mr. Malkin, who has done several lease buy-out deals at W&M properties in Stamford, Conn., wants to do more at 1185. He will probably take back Cigna's remaining floor, as well as a floor from another tenant that wants to give up space, and again market them as a two-floor block.
Management at 199 Water Street, near Fulton Street, went through similar maneuvers to attract the big news agency Reuters. It let Lloyds Bank buy its way out of 30,000 square feet, even though Lloyds was paying more than $50 a square foot and had 10 years left on the lease. The reason: Reuters was looking for 90,000 square feet and the building had only 60,000 square feet to give it.
"If Reuters hadn't been in the wings, Lloyds would still be looking to sublet," said Mr. Constable, who represented Lloyds.
Sometimes a departing tenant has enough space on its own to make a lease buyout palatable. Quantum Chemical, which had two years left on a lease for 72,000 square feet at 99 Park Avenue, at 40th Street, was making no bones about its plans to move to Cincinnati.
"It seemed a good time to find a credit-worthy, long-term tenant," said Bruce Mosler, a vice chairman at Galbreath Riverbank, who handles the building's leasing. He let Quantum out of its obligations for half of what its remaining cost would have been and rented the space to R.R. Donnelly, the printing firm, for 15 years.
Not everyone is enamored of the buyout concept. Many tenants either do not have the cash to make a large upfront payment or don't want to confront their shareholders or boards with that prospect.
Some landlords are equally reluctant to confront their lenders or investors with deals that terminate a stable source of cash flow.
"I have a fiduciary responsiblity to get every dime of cash flow I can get," said Joseph T. Wright, a senior vice president of JMB Realty, which manages 1211 Avenue of the Americas, at 47th Street.
Indeed, most tenants whose leases are winding down now are paying above-market rents. Yet most landlords believe Manhattan rents are creeping up again. Many cannot see the logic of letting a tenant who is paying, say, $40 a square foot in a building that commands no more than $30 now, end its lease when chances are good that, when the lease term ends, the space can be rented out for more than it can be today.
Moreover, by waiting, they can also put off paying for tenant improvements, broker's commissions and other costs of doing a deal.
"I'M still better off getting cash flow now and putting off new deals until concession packages are down and rents are up," said Caleb D. Koeppel, vice chairman of Koeppel Tener Real Estate Services, which manages 26 Broadway, at Beaver Street, and 575 Lexington Avenue, near 51st Street.
Still, arguments for buying space back seem to outnumber those against. Tenants with a few years left on a lease have little chance of subletting. Those with a more marketable term often do not want the headache of being a sublessee's landlord -- or the risk of having the sublessee default. And commissions and tenant improvements can be as costly in a sublet deal as they are when a landlord is renting space direct.
Sometimes tenants can even spread out the cost of buying out their lease. Mitsui Fudosan, which owns 1251 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street, took back 226,000 square feet under lease to Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, to provide Kidder Peabody with the 350,000 square feet it wanted. No cash changed hands; the Japanese owner sublet back much of the accounting firm's space, thus reducing the rent paid rather than exacting a lump payout.
One reason Mitsui was so agreeable: Kidder is paying several dollars a square foot more in rent than Coopers was paying. No one involved would say whether Mitsui took a large profit or whether it gave the departing tenant a deal on a sublet. Barry Gosin, the Newmark & Company chief executive who handles the building's leasing, said simply, "It was a winning situation all around."
Generally, landlords try hard to hide from existing tenants the fact that they need the space for another deal. Tenants, for their part, like to pretend they have sublessees ready to move in. Whoever's bluff gets called generally bears the lion's share of the costs.
Mr. Wright recalls one tenant at his building who paid dearly to get out of the six years left on its lease. Less than a month later, JMB had rerented the space.
"The first tenant did not realize I already had another tenant on my arm, so we got a real home-run deal," Mr. Wright said.
MANY landlords are settling for single-base deals as well. Those with a disturbing number of leases rolling over at the same time often want to write a new lease in an off year, thus easing the risk of sudden high vacancies. Others want to appear to be actively seeking deals. ("Brokers who see you as proactive will ask if you can make space available, rather than just rely on what you're actively marketing," Mr. Malkin noted.).
And some owners just don't like to gamble. After all, no one can be sure that a new tenant will show up when an existing lease runs out. As for rising rents -- well, everyone knows what happened to hapless owners in the mid-80's who gambled that the real estate boom would last forever.
In fact, some of the more conservative owners are letting tenants buy out of some space in exchange for agreeing to stay longer in the space that remains. James B. Frederick, a principal at Colliers ABR, recently represented a tenant that wanted to shed 10,000 of its 70,000 square feet. The tenant's space was on low floors that the owner knew he would have trouble re-renting. So he let the tenant turn back the small fraction of space, in return for extending its lease for an extra five years on the remainder.
"The owner felt that keeping a large credit-worthy ) tenant in the building's base would add to the building's financial stability," Mr. Frederick recalled.
Sometimes landlords will agree to lease buyouts because it lets them remeasure the space. First City Securities, a financial services firm, had three years left on a lease for what, 12 years ago, had been rented as a 6,450-square-foot floor at 767 Third Avenue, at 48th Street. Since then the owner had remeasured the building and is now renting the floors at 6,850 square feet. He found a new tenant for the "larger" floor, and let First City buy out for what came to about 60 percent of its remaining obligation.
"The change in the way the space was measured, combined with the strengthening market, made the deal work," said Mr. Frederick, who represented First City.
Chances are that, as the market continues to strengthen, landlords will need fewer and fewer extenuating circumstances to agree to lease buyouts. In fact, some are even considering letting existing tenants out of leases before new tenants show up.
"Two years ago I would have needed a new tenant's signed lease in hand before I'd even consider letting an old tenant off the hook," said Peter di Capua, a senior vice president at ATCO Corporation, which manages several Manhattan buildings. "In this market I'm more likely to bet on the come."
