HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Tarrytown;
Rich History, Picturesque River Setting

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

 BODY:
THE cross-country team at Sleepy Hollow High School represents a student body from 14 countries. It trains on the paths of the Rockefeller family estate and it competes under the banner of the headless horseman, the school mascot.
Welcome to Tarrytown, a village with rich and varied historical and cultural roots and a splendid setting overlooking the three-mile width of the Hudson River. The Dutch called this point, the river's widest, the Tappan Zee -- Tappan probably for a group of Indians and Zee meaning "sea" in Dutch. Wealthy industrialists built estates in its hills and its shores have drawn industries that have employed hundreds of newly arrived immigrants. 
 The past is present in this eclectic village, home to corporate executives as well as to blue-collar workers. Among the remaining mansions is Lyndhurst, the Gothic Revival jewel of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, designed by Alexander Jackson Davis for New York City Mayor William Paulding and completed in 1838. It was later owned by Jay Gould, the railroad financier.
On the waterfront next to and south of the 104-year-old recently restored Victorian railroad station, the county asphalt plant and a recycling plant, among other small industries, still hum. And teen-agers knock balls around in the waterfront Loosee and Pierson Parks. Nearby are the Washington Irving and Tarrytown Boating Clubs with a total of 320 slips.
"Tarrytown is a wonderful, very mixed community with an even more mixed school system," said Kathleen DeFemia, an administrative assistant at Village Hall. "My kids have had friends of all different skin colors, and I think it has made them better people -- it's what the world is all about."
The world has known about Tarrytown for a century and a half, thanks to its legendary equestrian ghost. Who does not know of Brom Bones, Ichabod Crane and the lovely Katrina, made famous by Washington Irving, a noted resident? And Tarrytown also has a place in real history: Major John Andre, the British spy, was captured there as he tried to help Benedict Arnold betray West Point.
After a century as an active river port and a regional industrial center, Tarrytown entered its golden age in this century as a mecca for the wealthy. Home to industrial tycoons including William E. Dodge, a merchant and philanthropist; J.D. Maxwell, an automobile pioneer, and several members of the Lehman banking family. It also attracted Albert Bierstadt, the landscape painter, and Samuel L. Clemens.
With the Rockefellers and other prominent families in North Tarrytown, the area was dubbed "the millionaire's colony." Tarrytown incorporated as a village in 1870, adjacent North Tarrytown in 1874.
Modern Tarrytown is a transportation hub connecting Westchester and Rockland Counties with New York City via excellent train connections and the Tappan Zee Bridge, which connects to I-287, Westchester's major east-west highway. Traffic has also been the village's biggest nightmare.
When it was built in 1955, the bridge was considered a boon to development. Office parks sprang up and hotels as well, among them the Tarrytown Hilton and the Westchester Marriott. But few were prepared for the traffic that threatened to choke off the village as frustrated rush-hour commuters tried to get onto the Tappan Zee by seeking alternative routes through the village.
"It used to be a disaster," Ms. DeFemia recalled, "especially on Friday nights. You couldn't even go out for a quart of milk."
Peace returned after last year's agreement by the state to install a removable barrier on the bridge, freeing an extra lane for Westchester-bound traffic in the morning and an extra lane westbound in the evenings.
A COMMUTER bus service bringing Rockland County residents to the train has also helped, said Eileen Pilla, Mayor of Tarrytown for the last decade. She presides over a village board that six years ago approved a revised a master plan, in the process rezoning the village near the bridge to reduce density.
"Development was overtaking events," said Mayor Pilla. "We wanted more open space and we wanted to prevent such dense development it would take away from the attractiveness of the community."
In 1980 village officials rejected a proposal for a shopping center on the site of what is now the Talleyrand Office Park, opting to revitalize the downtown shopping district instead. This has gone slowly, but momentum is building with technical assistance from the New York Main Street Alliance, a nonprofit group based in Mount Kisco that is dedicated to preserving the state's downtowns.
Residents hope their historic past and a spruced-up downtown will be keys to their economic future as the region's industrial tax base declines. Taxpayers in the two villages are concerned about the announced departure of the General Motors assembly plant in North Tarrytown, planned for 1996. Although the plant pays no village taxes in Tarrytown, it contributes almost 10 percent of the consolidated school budget.
Mayor Sean Treacy of North Tarrytown said his village was actively seeking developers for the 98-acre site as the Sleepy Hollow Seaport, with a marina, a mix of shops and housing and an automobile museum.
The region has become an increasingly popular tourist destination because of Sunnyside, Washington Irving's home; Kykuit, the Rockeller family home, and Philipsburg Manor Upper Mills in North Tarrytown. .
Today, Main Street looks remarkably as it does in photos taken 50 years ago, with three- and four-story Victorian storefronts dominating the street. After the designation of the street as a local historic landmark in 1980, shopkeepers had to get permission to make architectural changes.
Antiques shops abound, mixed with delis, clothing stores and restaurants featuring Italian, Mexican and Portuguese specialities.
The most prominent building on Main Street is the Queen Anne style Music Hall, built in 1885 to bring grand opera and vaudeville to the village and be the site of an annual flower show. It is now a thriving performing arts center where this summer Arlo Guthrie and the New Orleans Preservation Hall band, among others, performed.
The clearest sign of diversity is Tarrytown's housing stock, from the tiny rowhouses in the inner village to the elegant free-standing brownstones on North Washington Street to the rambling Victorians in Wilson Park. About 40 percent of the 4,311 housing units in Tarrytown are one-families, including several Hudson River Victorians with fine river views.
Aside from a scattered lot here and there, no new housing has been built in the village since the mid-80's, said Michael Blau, Village Administrator. There is little available land, he said, except for about 220 acres in the south end of the village owned by the Unification Church.
ONE of the most luxurious condominiums among 12 complexes in the village is Carrollwood, where a total of 208 two- and three-bedroom units surround Axe Castle, once known as Carrollcliffe. The castle was purchased last March by a group of investors headed by Hanspeter Walder, a Tarrytown resident, is now seeking approval for an inn/restaurant in the 94-year-old Norman-style castle.
In Tarrycrest, a one-family-home neighborhood, three-and four-bedroom ranches and colonials sell for $225,000 to $325,000. Several surround the fields of the Hackley School, a private co-ed day and five-day boarding school. Others are near the Tarrycrest Swim Club, a private club with tennis courts, and some are near the two Tarrytown Lakes, a back-up reservoir where people fish in the summer and skate in the winter.
Beyond the lakes is the Wilson Park neighborhood, which many brokers consider the most prestigious part of town and where some Victorians sell for $600,000 and up. Residents are surrounded by open space, most of it owned by the Rockefeller family, and by the four-year, 700-student Marymount College, a private women's college.
Brian and Carol Kelly bought their rambling white colonial on a hill in the neighborhood because of its river views and its proxmity to both Kykuit, at the end of the street, and the downtown, just a walk away. Mr. Kelly, an advertising executive with Ammirati & Puris, looks forward to weekends when the couple take Sarah, 3, and Will, 5 months, on long rambles at Kykuit, accompanied by Abbie, their golden retriever.
Next year, Sarah will enter the Tappan Hill School in Tarrytown, one of six schools in the consolidated system, each designated for particular grade levels. Like most children in Tarrytown, Sarah will stay for two years, then enter first grade at the John Paulding School in North Tarrytown, attending the Winfield L. Morse School in North Tarrytown for second and third grades.
The Washington Irving Intermediate School in Tarrytown houses grades 4 through 6 and students return to the Sleepy Hollow Middle School (in North Tarrytown) for grades 7 and 8 and spend their last four years in Tarrytown at Sleepy Hollow High School.
Eighty percent of the 100 members of this year's senior class are headed for further education.
Dr. Donald R. Kusel, the district school superintendent, said the system had been building up a surplus to offset the anticipated loss of revenue from General Motors.
It is a system, he said, that now offers seven languagues, including Russian; 17 advanced placement courses and has recently instituted new math and language arts curriculums.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Sayonara' the Musical In Revival in Elmsford

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN; "Sayonara," produced by Westchester Broadway Theater, 1 Broadway Plaza, Elmsford. Performances continue through Sept. 18. The box office number is 592-2222.

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
IN the evolution of a musical, things are meant to change for the better. Consider among the theater's vagaries how a show can devolve into a shadow of once promised substance.
In its 1987 world premiere at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., "Sayonara" (from the Michener novel) blossomed; ravishingly so, given a production of visual wonder. Yet, the score (by George Fischoff) and the book (by William Luce) existed almost in separation -- an odd thing for an incurably romantic tale about lives intertwined, those of an ace flier -- they call him Ace -- who falls in love with Hana-ogi, the star of Japan's leading musical theater troupe, and a private (Joe Kelly) who marries a Japanese girl (Katsumi). 
 For all its potential, "Sayonara" the musical, in the language of show business, did not have legs -- until last year when a revised version opened at Theater Under the Stars in Houston, leading to other stagings and revisions. The show at the Westchester Broadway Theater, its management says, is approximately 75 percent changed and almost entirely recast since the New Jersey opening.
And it is newly directed by Philip Wm. McKinley, who has been in charge of "Sayonara" productions in five cities in the past year. It is in Mr. McKinley's staging that the better changes are best reflected.
In a new production concept, the Takarazuka numbers, now less flamboyant but far more functional and considerably more frequent, deliberately exist on the fringe of the story. That would theoretically strengthen the book songs if only they were less disposable. Still, a new emphasis on showiness provides a theatrical urgency, which recalls the fantasy numbers in "Kiss of the Spider Woman" and the score as accompaniment in the film "Cabaret."
Mr. McKinley's direction, in its interweaving of book and musical scenes, is more seamless than Mr. Luce's writing, jolting as that tries to be from the first scene, a nasty piece of military meanness that leads to the story in flashback.
Besides a removable overlay of sentimentality, "Sayonara" suffers an irreversible point of view problem, which does not have to go out of its way to offend. To perpetuate the notion that the Japanese "girl," as opposed to the American "dish," has the genetic predisposition to please a man -- and to trick him into marriage -- is to turn "Sayonara" into a musical in praise of geisha training rather than an East-is-East, West-is-West take on star-crossed lovers.
And the Japanese woman who marries the American man can look forward to a permanent name change, as from Katsumi to Babe.
That government legislation lifting the "forbidden" act of "flagrant fraternization" between American soldiers and Japanese women (and what's more, allowing Americans to take their Japanese wives back to the States) was passed a year after these events, which occurred in occupied Japan in 1952, makes of the "Sayonara" story an ephemeral thing. To reiterate the legal changes in the context of the musical is to negate the author's accent on sacrifice and a climactic try for tragedy.
There is simply no real inevitability, tragic or circumstantial, in the separate resolutions of the two interracial couples. In one case, it might be more plausible to opt for the sentimentalized ending of the 1957 movie -- a change reportedly made at the insistence of the star, Marlon Brando.
And given a shift in global economic power, which adds to "Sayonara" the aftertaste of a whole meal of leftovers, force-fed, the preachy tone of Mr. Luce's writing is pointless. A period piece is a period piece. The contemporary validation of "Sayonara," musical or otherwise, must be found in its theatrical adornments.
In spite of one or two silly smoky pit effects -- given theater trends, if there's a smoke machine, use it -- the production benefits from the graceful scenery by Gregory Hill, with all manner of ornamentation including bamboo branches, lanterns, streamers, masks, fireworks, a puppet show and a delicate moving bridge.
In a score more extenuated than enhanced by time, the title song and the ballad "Where You Go" remain winning, though Hi Gilbert's lyrics (sample: "You'll always be so very near and yet so far away") remain losers.
Joseph Mahowald is an efficient Ace, Michael O'Steen, an ace Kelly. Tony Gilbert, one remaining member of the original cast, plays one of the musical theater's wormiest villains, Col. Calhoun Craford. Frances Epsen and Judith McCauley have the insufferable roles of Ace's American fiancee and mother-in-law-to-be -- the first insufferably noble, the second insufferably ignoble.
Sala Iwamatsu has an air of authority and vulnerability as Hana-ogi, but Ako appears trapped by coy stereotyping in the role of Katsumi. In its second life, "Sayonara" has to search for a third -- and again, for legs.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SCHUYLERVILLE;
New to the 'New' Bronx: New Cars

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
"Everyone said we were crazy, that it would never last," says Barry Milea, the 42-year-old president of Milea Truck Sales Corporation. That was 13 years ago, when Mr. Milea and his cousins, Robert Milea and Albert Sanfilippo, opened their truck dealership in the South Bronx.
But after years of working "around the clock," Barry Milea says, and setting up his living quarters above the dealership office, the partners proved the skeptics wrong. Milea Truck Sales, which is at 885 East 149th Street at the corner of Bruckner Boulevard, has sales of $40 million a year and 150 employees. 
 And last Tuesday, the partners once again defied the traditional wisdom, at a groundbreaking ceremony for the Bronx's first new car-and-truck dealership in a decade. "Everyone thinks this is a low-income borough," said Mr. Milea, "but they're wrong. It's a middle-income borough where people need cars."
The new enterprise, Milea Pontiac/GMC Truck, is located at 3211-3215 East Tremont Avenue, at the corner of Waterbury Avenue in Schuylerville.
For years, there were a handful of new-car dealerships along with the dozens of used-car lots on Jerome Avenue north of 170th street. Most of them moved out, said William Bollinger, director of planning and development for the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, because of high taxes and low security.
"Car dealerships tend to cluster together, and when one moved out, the others followed," Mr. Bollinger said.
Other auto-related businesses, like parking garages and car-repair services, took their place. "We're still trying to figure out what to do with that strip," he said.
The new dealership is scheduled to open in January and will create 50 new jobs, Barry Milea said.
Nancy Mendelson, a spokeswoman for the development corporation, commenting on the Milea partners' decision to expand, said: "Slowly, there's a recognition that there's a huge market in the Bronx, especially with all the new housing going up. We are not building apartments, but new houses with garages and driveways." MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS;
Mixed Notices, in Advance, For Memorial to Malcolm X

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Sometime this fall, three artists -- a muralist and two sculptors -- are expected to emerge from their studios with final plans for a memorial to Malcolm X.
Selected from among nearly 100 applicants, the artists have won the right to place their works in an area of the Audubon Ballroom where Malcolm X was assassinated. That section of the ballroom, which is on Broadway between West 165th and 166th Streets, will be preserved while Columbia University builds a long-disputed biomedical research complex around it. 
 But many members of the Save the Audubon Ballroom Coalition, which opposed the compromise that is preserving a little more than half of the original ballroom, say they believe the memorial will be a sham. Elombe Brath, a member of the coalition and a graphic artist, compares it to saving only a portion of Ford's Theater in Washington, where Lincoln was shot, in order to build a factory around it.
"I think what it's going to end up to be is just a small acknowledgement that there was a fight to save it," Mr. Brath said. "There was such a rich history to the place, and I don't think this memorial will reflect any of that."
But the plan has many supporters, including Dr. Betty Shabazz, Malcolm X's widow, and Dr. Howard Dodson, director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. Both are members of the Malcolm X Memorial Commission, which was created by Mayor David N. Dinkins to oversee the project.
The ballroom fell into disrepair after it was closed in the 1970's because of unpaid taxes. The battle to save it and to keep the research center from being built, raged for more than a decade. In the end, the center's developers -- Columbia, the city's Economic Development Corporation and the New York State Urban Development Corporation -- agreed to save 55 percent of the original ballroom, including the stage where Malcolm X was gunned down on Feb. 21, 1965. Retail outlets and a mental-health clinic will share the space with the memorial.
Daniel Galvez, a muralist from Oakland, Calif., and two Manhattan sculptors, Gabriel Koren and Colin Chase, will present finished drawings and models for the memorial, which will then be reviewed by city and community groups.
"What I want to do is essentially to portray visually what everybody has already seen of images from his life so they can draw from it what they will," Mr. Galvez said. "I'm really trying to capture the meat of his life." RANDY KENNEDY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK/GOWANUS;
Southwest Brooklyn Presses Its Economic Case

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
There are no greengrocers, no pharmacies, no bakeries in Red Hook. Gowanus has no health services -- the nearest public clinic is about two miles away, in Fort Greene, and hard to reach because of a lack of public transportation.
Local officials have begun looking to new state and Federal programs to boost the economy in southwest Brookyn. Last month, the area that encompasses Red Hook, Gowanus and Sunset Park was chosen by the state as one of 21 new enterprise zones. 
 Now, the recently formed Southwest Brooklyn Enterprise Community, a collection of 40 organizations that include block associations, small-business groups and community boards, is campaigning to have the area declared a Federal enterprise community. The program is part of a Clinton Administration plan to free up $9 million in city, state and Federal funds to spur economic growth in each of 65 urban areas around the country.
Some development officials and community leaders contend that local enterprise programs often do little beyond shuffle jobs and businesses from one area to another within a designated area. But the state says its enterprise-zone program has helped create 4,500 new jobs and has stimulated almost $750 million in business investment.
"This is a very dynamic time right now, and we're all looking ahead to brighter days," said Craig Hammerman, the district manager of Community Board 6, which covers Red Hook, Gowanus and parts of Sunset Park. "We want to take vacant storefronts and put life into them."
The state designation is intended to help neighborhoods keep existing businesses and attract new ones with tax credits, low-interest loans, reduced property taxes and discounted utility bills.
The new Federal enterprise communities will be announced in November. Meanwhile, state and local officials say that Washington's decision will depend largely on the lobbying efforts mounted by the neighborhoods and the support shown by city and state officials and Congressional representatives.
The Federal designation is also being sought by the South Bronx and the Grand Concourse and Crotona Park East, also in the Bronx; the greater Williamsburg-Navy Yard and Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn, and South Jamaica, Queens.
Areas like southwest Brooklyn that have won the state enterprise designation have an advantage, said Bette Stoltz, the executive director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation, a nonprofit community organization, because they can show they have widespread support and a mechanism in place to make use of the money.
The enterprise community program is separate from another Federal plan to designate six blighted urban areas as "empowerment zones" and award them each $100 million in grants and other benefits. A section of the City, including parts of Harlem and the South Bronx, is expected to win this designation.
If southwest Brooklyn receives the Federal designation, community leaders say, the $9 million will be used to market and promote local businesses and to develop job training programs in the area's existing maritime, construction and trucking industries. There are also plans to make low-interest loans available to small-business owners. GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Hair Wars: Underground on 125th Street

SERIES: The Bottom Rung: A periodic look at new immigrants' struggles to gain an economic foothold in New York.

BYLINE: By CLAUDINE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
IT IS 10 A.M., and 125th Street is choked with people trying to weave past vendors selling T-shirts, African trinkets and jewelry. Mounas G. and several other women in colorful African print dresses stand outside a storefront that has no sign and eye the passing parade. In particular, they look for those lingering at the photographs on the storefront's windows.
"Miss, Miss, do you want to get your hair done?" Mounas asks one shopper, who immediately points to a photo of an elaborate braid style. 
 "This, can you do this?" she asks.
Mounas smiles and says, "Seventy dollars." The customer nods and is ushered into another world.
Call it a makeshift hair-braiding factory. Mounas and two dozen other women sit on high stools, their fingers manipulating clumps of hair into intricate patterns and styles. The women are so crammed together that it is difficult for them to work without bumping elbows with their neighbors. And it is hot. Four fans move air around the salon. Every now and then a braider adjusts a fan to give a burst of air to a customer who is fanning herself.
There are no mirrors on the walls. When a braid is done, the customer holds a jagged, cracked mirror up to her face. Sometimes she is taken next door to use the mirrors at the Subway sandwich store.
The shop is one of the many braiding salons that seem to crop up overnight along 125th Street and around the city to meet the growing demand for African-inspired braiding. They have become a refuge for Caribbean and African immigrants trying to stay afloat, allowing them to use skills they learned in their homelands. But the shops have also raised questions about sanitary practices; partly with those in mind, the State Legislature recently wrote language into the cosmetology law that specifically requires braiders to be licensed.
Mounas, a 43-year-old Senegalese immigrant who lives in a one-bedroom apartment in West Harlem, says the shop helps her make ends meet when her cabdriver husband is out of work and she needs money for her baby daughter or to send back home.
She says she learned about the shop a year ago through word of mouth and began renting a station. Over the year, more women came to set up their stations, and now there is barely space for one more braider.
"We never turn anyone down." she says. "Friends work here. Relatives come in to help. But now it is so full, I don't think we are taking any more people."
Many established braiders who are proud of the craft of locking and twisting and weaving hair into intricate patterns feel that some of the new shops diminish the status of their profession through poor standards and the use of quick-buck techniques like pulling in people from the streets. Some are also bothered by the immigrants' claims of "authentic" braiding, which they say implies that the work of American black women is somehow less genuine. Still, they say they are eager to pull the immigrants into the mainstream.
"When I saw that shop on 125th, I was stunned," said Diane Bailey, the vice president of International Braiders Network, a trade group with 300 members. "My eyes filled with tears. It was a sweat shop. There was not any order. People had combs stuck in their mouths and in their hair. That simply is not safe."
"Braiding is about nurturing natural care," said Ms. Bailey, a member of a state advisory committee on cosmetology. "It is not about a quick service. We are not the McDonald's of hair care. In 20 years we will not be looked at as hair braiders. We will be looked at as hustlers."
Mounas agrees that cleanliness can be a problem. "Some people are clean, some people are dirty. That is why I want to open my own shop and keep it clean. I have 10 combs. When I go home, I wash them one by one and put them in paper towels."
The work itself is difficult and stressful, requiring long hours of concentration and repetitive motions. A braider working too hard may find her fingers swelling and her back aching. Some develop eye trouble.
But in the low-paying universe of the immigrants, the pay can be fairly good. Mounas says she rents her station for $140 a month and works several days a week, charging from $70 for an uncomplicated braid to $200 for a difficult and time-consuming pattern that takes all day. Those rates are slightly higher than what is offered by others in the shop. In a regular salon, the cost could be twice that; the job could take twice as long.
Mounas is paid in cash, which is one the reasons she insisted her last name not be used. On a busy day, she may have as many as four customers.
"Some days I get three," she says. "Some days I get two people. Some days no one comes. But it does not last long. People always want to get their hair done."
Mounas's specialty is a braid called the Senegalese twist, a style in which natural hair is twisted with synthetic hair or a wool fiber into tiny single braids that resemble rope. She imports the wool from Senegal.
For the braiders, the skill was easy to learn. Mounas was taught by her cousins in Senegal.
Gladys Esowe, a Nigerian, said: "In Africa, we grow up with it. We have an open market. So anyone who wants to braid hair can go there. We would cook for the person in exchange for them teaching us how to braid. You just find a comb."
Ms. Esowe, who is 43, said she was trained as a housekeeper but is having trouble because she can't get a work permit.
"I tried and tried to find work without a permit," she said. "I got frustrated. I was walking down the street one day about three months ago and I saw this place. What should I do? I don't have any alternative. I like to work. I want to work."
Most of the braiders are either illegal immigrants or have no work permits; Mounas says she has a green card and a permit. None of the braiders are licensed, so they often must move from shop to shop.
The women know little of the new licensing law or its grandfather clause giving braiders until next July to avoid enrollment in a cosmetology school by providing proof of experience. But since most fear any contact with the authorities, the transition will be difficult.
"No one ever asks me if I have a license," Mounas says. "If you know how to braid hair, they pay you money."
For Mounas, who came to the United States five years ago, the goal is to keep sending money home to Senegal and eventually return there. America is too violent, she says. Every night she watches the television news and hears about a murder. She wonders if she's next.
"Life was not that hard at home," she said. "There was no violence. Africa is poor and people come here to satisfy themselves and their families."
A few days later, the storefront on 125th Street closes down. The shop moves next door. The workers usher customers through a half-closed gate.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ON THE WATERFRONT;
On Greenpoint's Piers, An Island of Regulars

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries.
Herman Melville, "Moby Dick"
ONCE the city's raison d'etre and the inspiration of poetry and song, the waterfront has fallen to the status of civic embarrassment, its jagged edges and fearsome highways acting as if under divine order to keep us from an expansive view or a salty breeze. 
 Now, in a spasm of municipal will, City Hall is weighing plans to open the land's edge, and officials have a basic design for an "urban boulevard" north from Battery Place on the West Side. As for the park alongside, some worry about stirring the loins of large-scale development.
Protagonists should keep their eyes on the prize, evident on the East River. On a summer day, pockets of folks, scavengers of urban pleasures, expropriate piers and rare parkland in unregulated joy. A pig is roasted. A child roars with delight over a gambling table. Ninetta Galarza sells rum and coke in East River Park. "The King of India Street" reclines on a Greenpoint pier. The scenes serve to mock the forces that conspire to keep us chronically landbound.
Along the abandoned and ramshackle piers off India Street in Greenpoint, a few hardy sun worshipers stretch out on the cracked concrete. Others cast their lines and crab nets into the Brooklyn side of the East River, hoping to catch the day's fare. Every so often a brave soul, or two, dives into the river for a few laps.
Nearby, amid the overgrown weeds, a group of men chat quietly, pounding down a few Budweisers. They toast a Budweiser blimp flying over the gray sky.
 "We're having a great time," says David Ruiz as salsa jangles the still, humid air.
"This is our world, and you're just in it," his friend Paco Velasquez tells a visitor.
This makeshift park attracts neighborhood people: working and unemployed, longtime residents, Polish and Hispanic immigrants. They are people with the imagination to create their own islands of relaxation.
But for all its kindred serenity, the place can get rowdy, particularly after one beer too many. Simple discussions can escalate into fistfights and ethnic name-calling.
"Sometimes a Polish guy and a Spanish guy drink and they have some trouble," said Jerry Urbanski, an unemployed construction worker. "They start talking and end up fighting."
This group has never set foot on Martha's Vineyard; the Hamptons are terra incognita. But India Street will do. And just as some richer people have beach cottages, Hector Malave has his home away from home.
Mr. Malave is known as the "King of India Street." His habitat consists of stacks of boxes filled with bottles and other knickknacks from nearby dumps. A disconnected telephone receiver sits on a night table.
One day last week, Mr. Malave, who is 60 years old, lay lazily on an aluminum cabinet with a plastic-covered cushion under a wide umbrella. He comes here in summer from his daughter's house nearby and says he spends all of his time at the pier.
"This is beautiful," he said. "I could stay here forever." GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FULTON FERRY;
Decision Time For Empire Stores

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
After decades of grand plans gone awry, the latest scheme for revamping a cluster of nine state-owned warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront is fast approaching a watershed. Last week, officials of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation said they would choose a developer for the buildings, known collectively as the Empire Stores, next month.
The state agency wants to transform the ground floors of three of the buildings into a cultural and retail center that would house art galleries, artists' studios, boutiques, cafes and a theater. 
 Last year the department sought bids from developers to devise a plan for the 40,000 square feet of space in buildings 5, 6 and 7, on Water Street between New Dock and Main Streets. Two proposals were received, one from Urban Space Management, which consulted on the design of the Grand Central Terminal market and has created retail centers in England. The other bidder is Bridge Visions Inc., which designed the former Amazon Village restaurant and dance club on Pier 25 and the Amazon Club in Sag Harbor, L.I.
Joan K. Davidson, the commissioner of the state agency, would not comment on the cost of the Empire Stores project, but she said it was "at the very top of my priorities." Once a plan is approved, she said, she hopes to have the project completed by next summer.
Although community leaders and the waterfront's growing number of artists generally welcome the new proposal, they are skeptical. The stores, a beehive of commercial activity during the 19th and early 20th centuries, were closed after World War II, and various plans to develop them have come and -- when the financing failed to materialize -- gone. The 1991 version called for development of all nine of the warehouses at an estimated cost of $107 million.
The current plan is much more modest, but Allen Swerdlowe, president of the Fulton Ferry Association, a community group, said: "Anything incremental will have a positive effect on the waterfront. Over time we're going to understand more clearly the exact best use for the area."
Sharon Derechin Rozsay, a member of the Brooklyn Waterfront Artists Coalition, added, "I would love to see this happen. As an artist, if it just grew up around us, it would be wonderful." GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Two Rookie Owners Just Can't Stay Still

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
Rookie owners, like rookie players, must pay their dues before speaking out. This is one of the unwritten rules of the major league baseball jungle.
Peter Angelos of the Baltimore Orioles and Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies think they have paid their dues. One hundred and seventy-three million of them in Angelos's case. And about $150 million in expansion fees and startup costs in the case of the ownership of the two-year-old Rockies, which McMorris heads up. 
 Now, because of a players strike and negotiations that often seem frozen in time, the two owners have watched their franchises pay even more, by way of lost gates and the lost faith of those who were flocking in record numbers to Camden Yards and Mile High Stadium this season. Which is why both Angelos and McMorris have tried in their own ways to cajole both sides into finding a way to make peace from the moment a players strike shut down the game on Aug. 12.
Angelos and McMorris haven't broken with other owners. They have suggested even-handed solutions to the age-old paradox that is labor negotiations in baseball. Such approaches can often be perilous. Just ask Fay Vincent, the last commissioner. He was deposed partially because he entered negotiations to end the 1990 lockout and prodded management to remove its ill-fated pay-for-performance proposal from the table in order to dislodge stalled talks.
Owners are no more encouraged to chart their own course than are commissioners. They are not even encouraged to speak for fear of undermining assertions of a united front. Only Bud Selig, the acting commissioner; and Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief negotiator, are to speak for management, it was announced even before the strike began.
Yet three owners did speak out on the eve of the strike. One was the Yankees' George Steinbrenner. The other two, surprisingly, were the new guys, Angelos and McMorris, and their alarm is akin to newlyweds of Hatfields and McCoys who only began to comprehend the depth of the animosity in the feud after the marriages were performed.
"The level of mistrust and the literal breach between ownership and the players and their union is far deeper than I ever did believe," said McMorris, a trucking magnate who has long dealt with unions such as the Teamsters. "It's a much bigger problem than I ever would have expected it to be."
The very idea that baseball and the players and their union continue to mix morality with finances almost three decades into their dealings is also astonishing to the Rockies' president, who says it occurs "more frequently in this industry than in any other industry that I've ever seen."
That is probably why veteran owners would wish the new guys wait to earn battle scars like theirs before professing to fully understand the war. Still, doesn't someone who spent, say, $173 million, to buy into the owners' club already have more than a vested interest? Especially when his investment dwarfs the initial investments of others who paid as little as $3 million for clubs? Or, especially when he has 173 million more dollars on the line than, say, the growing number of C.E.O.s who merely represent corporate-owned teams?
Angelos, in his first season as proprietor at Camden Yards, bought the Orioles for that mind-boggling $173 million even though he said he knew a work stoppage was possible. Still, when he saw that players were poised to walk out because of the owners' insistence on a salary cap, he suggested that the hot-button issue be tabled in exchange for the players vowing not to strike but, instead, play and negotiate.
"I felt that it needed to be said, in that one should invite the opposing side to negotiate, not just say, 'My way or the highway," Angelos said Friday. "As it was, both sides were hardened in their position. There was no place to go."
McMorris also called for conciliation on the cap issue, though insisting that a new way of doing business is crucial for baseball to restore balance in the game and assure "economic sanity."
Still, McMorris spoke out, in a fashion he said has been consistent with his beliefs since joining the game. "I think everybody in baseball has understood from the beginning that the Colorado Rockies want to play ball, as most of the teams want to play ball," he said. "But we're sitting in a very special situation here. We were on track to draw 4.7 million people, which would have meant we would have drawn over nine million people in our first two years. So we feel we had the most to lose by not playing ball."
Morris spoke about the special chemistry found between the players, the club and the fans who pour into Denver from over a dozen surrounding states. "I hate to see us messing with that," he said. Unending work stoppages do that, he believes.
"My sense is that the public thinks we're all spoiled," he said. "Fans are tired of the whining. And I don't see how this industry continues to do this at every labor negotiation and can't figure out that this thing could be even better for everybody than it is, now, if we could only get on the same page."
Both Angelos and McMorris hope that a map to that better day was starting to be drawn up Friday. That's when mediators not only unveiled plans to bring both sides back to the table Wednesday, but coaxed owners to attend, as well.
"It's another set of ears, another set of eyes, five or six additional intellects to try to help find a solution," McMorris said. "I'm hopeful that we can start making some progress."
Will Angelos and McMorris be among the owners who sit down with players? Angelos said Friday he has not been invited. McMorris, reputed to be in a second group of the teams of five being selected by Selig, refused to comment on the report.
But, as yet another owner said, there are guys out there who could make a difference. One would be hard put to find one with any more reason to do so, or interest in making a difference, than Peter Angelos or Jerry McMorris.

HEADLINE: Hotels See Benefits From Repeal of Tax

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE hated hotel tax is almost history. The Sept. 1 repeal of the 5 percent surcharge on New York State hotel rooms is making Westchester hotel people very happy.
"All of us in the industry are delighted," said Marcia Dmochowski, speaking about members of the Westchester County Hotel Association. "The repeal of the tax will make Westchester much more affordable for meeting planners." 
 Ms. Dmochowski, who is president of the hotel group and manager of the Tarrytown Hilton in Tarrytown, said that the four-year surcharge on hotel rooms, coming at the same time as the recession, made it very difficult for Westchester hotels and conference centers to compete with their rivals in New Jersey and Connecticut.
"Now that the playing field is even, we are all redoubling our marketing efforts to attract new business to Westchester," she said.
Indeed, the hotel managers' efforts will be aided by renovation and capital improvement programs designed to appeal to meeting planners. Such plans are under way at half a dozen hotels and conference centers.
At the Hudson River Inn and Conference Center in Ossining, Wes La Bay, one of the hotel's owners and its general manager, said that a $250,000 renovation program of the inn's meeting rooms and public spaces had been completed last year.
"And we have just finished a $50,000 renovation of Bayfields, our gourmet restaurant, in time to accommodate a three-day New York State Republican women's conference that was held here recently," he said. "We had about 100 guests staying with us, plus another 200 coming in for meals."
 
Business Reservations Up
 In addition to the refurbished 30 conference and meeting rooms, Mr. La Bay said the inn had recently installed a course designed for adventure training and team building programs. Moreover, he said, the inn's fall reservations from business groups are up "100 percent over the same period last year, with 50 percent of it coming from repeat clients and 50 percent from those who are new to us."
At Tarrytown House Conference House in Tarrytown, the sales and marketing director, Jeff Weggeman, said conference bookings at Tarrytown House were running unusually strong for the first quarter of 1995.
"That is a very good sign that perhaps the recession is behind us because normally January, February and March are very slow months," Mr. Weggeman said. "However, we have publicized the $4 million renovation program we have under way, which includes constructing an entire new kitchen and new ballroom space so we can increase the size and number of meetings and conferences and social events."
 
Renovation at Arrowwood
 And in Rye Brook, Doral Arrowwood, a resort conference center, began a multifaceted renovation program in June. John Wilderman, Doral's regional vice president and managing director, said that virtually all areas of the 272-room, 114-acre property, including conference rooms, banquet rooms, guest rooms and public spaces, are involved in the renovation. The first stage, costing more than $1.6 million, is expected to be completed by the beginning of next year.
"Keeping Arrowwood as up to date as possible has been a priority since we first opened," Mr. Wilderman said. And for conference guests, he continued, Arrowwood's 120-seat amphitheater will be upgraded and refurbished with extensive improvements in lighting, sound and audiovisual equipment.
 
A More Even Footing
 Teleconference capability has increased with the installation of satellite video-conferencing equipment in conjunction with interactive conference networks. By way of satellite, corporate groups can interact with others at more than 60 network sites.
Kristin Garbarini, director of sales and marketing at Arrowwood, said: "About 80 percent of our overall business is generated from conferences. Repeat business is strong. What frequently happens with companies is that we get exposure by hosting a meeting for senior management people who in turn will then book us to hold conferences for their entire departments or divisions."
The repeal of the hotel tax, Ms. Garbarini emphasized, will certainly make Doral Arrowwood more competitive. "It will put us on an even footing with other glamor conference centers such as Hamilton Park in New Jersey and similar upscale centers in Florida and Arizona."
What hotel people find especially attractive about conference business is that it guarantees that blocks of rooms are sold. "An empty hotel room represents a loss that can never be regained," Ms. Dmochowski said, adding that in order to gain more conference business for the Tarrytown Hilton, the hotel has taken what was formerly the Pennybridge Restaurant and transformed it into a conference-banquet dining room.
"It is really a more efficient, better use of space," she said. "We are able to use it for multipurpose events. For instance, we can convert it from conference use during the week to a banquet room for weddings or Sunday brunch on the weekends."
She added, however, that two new restaurants -- Da Vinci's, featuring Mediterranean cuisine, and Sports Edition, an informal restaurant -- have been opened. "Both are popular with hotel guests, the majority of whom are business travelers."
At the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, the general manager, Ernest H. Rechtermann, said that some guest rooms at the Rye Town Hilton have been converted into six new conference rooms. "We needed additional conference rooms to keep us competitive because small meeting spaces are very much in demand," Mr. Rechterman said.
A surge in one-day meetings for small groups is also taking place at Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains, reported Elie G. Zod, director of operations. "We are anticipating an increase in two- or three-day meetings from clients who blamed the hotel tax as a reason not to hold their meetings in Westchester."
Because accommodations for group activities are currently deemed important by meeting planners, Mr. Zod continued, "we recently installed a regulation volley ball and a boccie court, and both are very popular with not only corporate guests but our leisure guests, too."

HEADLINE: ULTRAMARATHON;
A Run to Moonlight For Food and More

BYLINE: By ALEX MARKELS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEADVILLE, Colo., Aug. 20

 BODY:
To Manuel Luna Guitierez, there's only one good reason to run a 100-mile race. "I run for my pueblo," said the wiry, 31-year old Tarahumara Indian, a native of northwest Mexico's Copper Canyon. "I run for the food we will win."
But to most of the nearly 300 other runners in today's Leadville Race to the Sky, the motivation for undertaking one of the world's most grueling foot races is less pragmatic. Most ultrarunners are American engineers, nurses, business consultants and the like in their 30's, 40's and even 50's. And though a few top runners have corporate sponsors, the lack of prize money insures that most competitors are strictly amateurs. 
 "They're just looking for another dragon to slay," said Ken Chlouber, the race organizer who is also a runner. "Money isn't what it's all about. In fact, I don't think you could pay people to endure the discomfort, pain and sickness a race like this takes."
 
Through Passes and Streams
 At 4 A.M. this morning, Guitierez, Chlouber and the rest of the field lined up at the starting line 10,000 feet above sea level. The course would twice take them over Hope Pass (elevation: 12,600 feet), across icy streams and treacherous boulder-strewn slopes. The first of the runners will finish by moonlight around midnight.
Guitierez and six other Tarahumara came from Mexico at the behest of Rick Fisher, who has gathered runners from three Tarahumara villages, promising the winner's village one ton of corn and a half-ton of beans.
Fisher, an outdoor guide and amateur anthropologist who has led trips into Copper Canyon for 15 years, hopes to inspire Guitierez and his 40,000 brethren to revive their ages-old running-race tradition.
Called Ralajipame, it is a team-based endurance contest played with a wooden ball that's kicked around a course until the losing team gives up from exhaustion. The races often last days and can cover 100 miles or more. Wagering up to a quarter of each village's collective wealth, the competition begins with an intense gambling fest that can last almost as long as the race itself.
"It's more than a game to them," said John Kennedy, a retired anthropology professor from Santa Fe, N.M. "It's obviously a pleasant diversion, but it's also an economic activity, a force for social cohesion and a channel for aggression. If it were removed from Tarahumara life, the effect would be greater than if some sporting activity were dropped from our own culture." (Like, say, baseball?)
The Tarahumara, agrarian peasants who live in the deep canyons and pine-covered plateaus of Mexico's 35,000-square-mile Sierra de Tarahumara wilderness, always ran because they needed to: traveling great distances to herd goats and coax corn and beans from the rocky, unproductive soil. Now they spend their lives on the run, between the canyon rim and its tropical floor 6,000 feet below, where they winter.
With a high-carbohydrate, low-fat vegetarian diet, the svelte Tarahumara are perfectly adapted for running. Early American explorers noted their remarkable endurance in carrying supplies and mail, and Tarahumara athletes have twice raced in Olympic marathons (Amsterdam, 1928, and Mexico City, 1968), although culture shock left them far back.
But with increased road building and logging in the region, many younger Tarahumara have abandoned their running legacy, opting instead to hitch rides on passing trucks. Over the last decade, running challenges have dwindled from an intense competition between 40 villages to occasional races among only a few.
 
Willing Participants
 Wary of being perceived as a huckster but desperate to preserve the tribe's traditions, Fisher says he has brought the Tarahumara to Leadville the past three years for one reason only: because they wanted to come.
"People are always trying to sell them on something," Fisher said, "but almost nobody has gone onto Indian land and looked at what the Indians were interested in. These people call themselves the Raramuri, the 'foot racers.' I could work to build a hospital or a school, but the people I work with don't want those things."
More interested in Tarahumara culture than in ultrarunning, Fisher's first foray into coaching proved disastrous. In their first Leadville 100 in 1992, not one Indian finished. Accustomed to running in their huarache sandals homemade from old tires and leather, the runners' feet understandably swelled in the Converse Chuck Taylor high-top sneakers Fisher had supplied them. And like the torches they carry at night at home, they held the flashlights provided for the Leadville race facing skyward.
But their ultimate undoing may have been their appreciation of the world around them. Thirty miles into the race, Chlouber came across the Tarahumara sitting at the edge of the trail admiring the view.
"I was trotting along and I saw two of them sitting on their haunches looking at the valley," he said. "I thought to myself, 'They're a lot smarter than I am.' "
 
How to Win
 When three Tarahumara returned last year, Fisher brought them to a Leadville junkyard where they made new huaraches from abandoned tires. Before the race, he also explained to them that unlike their competitions, where they may only accept food and water from their own villagers, they should take sustenance from race volunteers along the course.
They started the race at the back of the pack, trotting along in near effortless Ever-ready battery bunny steps. But as more than half the field gave way to exhaustion, the three Tarahumara slowly made their way to the front. By the 80th mile, the first Tarahumara, 55-year-old Victoriano Churro, took the lead. He and his comrades finished first, second and fifth, with Churro finishing 40 minutes ahead of the nearest competitor.
"It was amazing," said Harry Dupre, 56, of Mustang, Okla., who has run the Leadville race 12 times. "They seemed to move with the ground. Kind of like a cloud or a fog moving across the mountains. Here were these little guys wearing sandals, who never actually trained for the race. And they blew away some of the best long-distance runners in the world."
When they came to accept their winning trophy, however, they appeared miffed. "I think they were looking for something a little more utilitarian than a pan full of fool's gold," said Chlouber sheepishly, "although one did say he thought the pan would be good for eating out of."
For today's race, Fisher made sure the Tarahumara's would have plenty of incentive. In addition to offering the winner a four-month supply of grain, he also arranged for a grant from Rockport, which paid for travel costs and supplied the Tarahumara with high-tech cross-training shoes.
"They're good," said Guitierez as he unstitched the shoes to reveal deeply callused feet. "But I will use my huaraches. They bring me good luck."
Said Chlouber: "Kind of makes me wonder whether I should throw out those hundred dollar running shoes of mine."

HEADLINE: Banks Revise Credit Access For Low-Income Borrowers

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS 

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND banks have been developing policies, products and business partnerships intended to increase the accessiblity of credit for low- and moderate-income communities.
But some critics contend that the money is not enough and is not reaching those requesting it. 
 Bankers say their increased interest does not stem just from Federal and state proposals to expand the powers of the Federal Community Reinvestment Act. The law obligates banks to work with low- and moderate-income communities and individuals in exchange for special privileges.
The Federal law, enacted in 1977, was intended to eliminate "redlining," or excluding, poor or minority-group areas and denying loans even to depositors.
On Long Island, where the median income for a family of four is $63,100, according to the Census, moderate income at 50 to 80 percent of the median is $31,000 to $51,040. Low income is below $31,000.
Most Census tracts on the Island are middle income, from $51,040 to $63,100, or 80 to 100 percent of the median.
To be eligible for credit under the reinvestment act, housing or business developments have to be in low- or moderate-income tracts. Individuals may buy property anywhere.
The European American Bank has begun a $20 million Neighborhood Mortgage Program and a small-business lending program in Roosevelt. The president of the bank, Edward Travaglianti, said such programs were not established solely to impress regulators. The investments make long-term sense for Long Island, Mr. Travaglianti said, adding:
"The appropriate thing to do is to give opportunities to hard-working dedicated people who want to make their lives better. And it is the responsibility of banks to provide those funds."
EAB has also committed $2 million to the Long Island Housing Partnership, which was founded in 1988 to build housing. The partnership, which has built 213 houses, has expanded its membership and programs to include most banks on the Island and many business organizations.
Banks contribute 7 percent of the money for partnership developments, which the Federal and state governments also subsidize.
"When we first started we had trouble getting banks interested in our projects," the president of the partnership, Jim Morgo, said. "Just when we're gaining momentum the recent raising of interest rates by the Federal Reserve is threatening to hurt those families the partnership attempts to help."
The organization has built 15 houses in Long Beach, at $70,371 each, with construction loans and mortgages from EAB; 72 units at $58,584 in Amity Villas in North Amityville, with construction and loans primarily from the Roosevelt Savings Bank, and 53 houses in Central Islip.
Under construction are the first East End program, with 30 houses starting at $83,590, in East Quogue; 42 houses on scattered sites in Brentwood and North Bellport, and 33 condominiums in Middle Island.
"The law was most effective in the 1970's and 80's, when banks were monitored for compliance," said Barbara Mack, assistant director of the Suffolk County Community Development Agency, which administers Federal housing money designated for blighted neighborhoods.
After the savings-and-loan bailout in 1990, the Community Reinvestment Act law was weakened, and banks concentrated on "process," rather than investment, Ms. Mack said.
"C.R.A. is a hot topic on Long Island now, because of the Clinton Administration's desire to see it revamped with less paperwork," said Catherine Mullarkey, a vice president of EAB.
Fleet Bank now has an $8 billion Incity program, and the Chase Community Development Corporation has a $200 million program, both focusing primarily on metropolitan areas.
"Long Island's needs are just as great," said Mr. Margo.
"There are now 1,500 applicants to the Suffolk County Community Development Agency," said Ms. Mack.
Ms. Mack said banks paid "more lip service than financial service to their C.R.A. obligations, with the exception of EAB." The county, she added, depends on banks to provide mortgages for recipients in housing and urban-development programs.
"These recipients historically have a lower default rate than conventional borrowers," Ms. Mack said. "The banks get C.R.A. brownie points for doing paperwork, joining nonprofit housing organizations, running seminars and listening attentively. But we need them to make the loans."
She said she agreed with a former State Banking Superintendent, Derrick D. Cephas, that the Community Reinvestment Act was far too subjective. "Banks shop regulators to get maximum C.R.A. credit," Ms. Mack said.
The director of housing and intergovernmental affairs in Nassau, Don Campbell, said: "C.R.A. officers are not beating our doors down to do projects. But we don't have many problems with financing, because we provide most of the resources. Some C.R.A. bank officers are window dressing, because they are not authorized to write loans."
 
"I Certainly Did Not Discriminate'
 The community development officer at Fleet, Crosby Donald, defended the banks, saying: "As a minority branch manager since 1963, I can tell you that Long Island banks have made tremendous progress since the law was enacted. I certainly did not discriminate against qualified individuals who met the policies of the bank even before the law. But for years banks did not have the products to serve low- to-moderate-income applicants that they have now."
In the last few years, Mr. Donald said, banks have been developing products like mortgages that require 5 percent down payments or no down payments. The banks are also more flexible in evaluating debt-to-income ratios, an alternative way to gauge credit risk.
Most banks offer counseling to applicants to insure that they understand the commitments and can afford them. The banks, Mr. Donald said, have been willing to keep the mortgages in their portfolios, because they usually do not meet the criteria for the secondary market.
"Home ownership gives people self-esteem, pride in their community and incentives to work that they don't get as renters," Mr. Donald said. "If a family is paying $900 to rent and we can help them to buy, it's better for Long Island, too. It would be a disservice to push these mortgages to people who might foreclose. The banks don't want to own homes."
Some banks help family members who would live together to pool resources and co-sign the mortgage commitment.
Shirley Cobb, a single mother who has moved into in a three-bedroom ranch in Medford, pays $700 a month for principal, interest and taxes on her new $79,000 house, compared with the $850 that she paid in monthly rent for a two-bedroom apartment in Happauge.
 
State Grants of $5,000
 Miss Cobb obtained a Sonyma mortgage under a state program for first-time homebuyers when interest rates were at 6 percent. "I could not have done it without the Down Payment Assistance Program of the Suffolk County Community Development Agency, which gave me the down payment of $4,800," she said.
That program provides up to $5,000 for low- to moderate-income first-time buyers whose new houses are in one of the 15 municipalities in the agency's consortium.
"I tried and I tried, but all of the banks I went to steered me away," said Miss Cobb, who earns $28,000 a year as an occupational therapist at the Kings Park Psychiatric Center and from an additional part-time job.
"I read a lot," she said, "and applied for every special program I saw advertised. I must have seen 100 houses in one year. I was accepted for one of the Long Island Housing Partnership's subsidized homes, as well as the Farmers' Home Administration Program, which subsidizes the mortgage by 75 percent.
"But I rejected those two, because I wasn't satisfied with the areas the Long Island Housing Partnership was offering, and the farmers' program, which has a very lengthy application process, would subsidize purchase only on a house in their inventory. Also you have to pay back the subsidy at the end of the 30-year mortgage or whenever you sell."
When she began applying for mortgages, "the banks were not at all helpful," Miss Cobb recounted, adding: "Their ads were like a fallacy that they wanted to help. If you don't make $50,000 a year they won't work with you. I had to come up with another $8,000 in closing costs and I couldn't get the mortgage until the house, which was vacant, was fully repaired."
Miss Cobb hired an engineer to inspect the house, which she said she believed that an investor owned, and the seller was required to make repairs before the mortgage was approved. The repairs included a new kitchen, new windows and new boiler, "everything but the paint," she said.
The pastor of the First Baptist Church in Wyandanch, Michael Talbert, credited Leo Toca of the Chase Manhattan Bank for helping him buy a house in Wyandanch with 95 percent financing and no points.
In addition to mortgages for people who qualify, Long Island banks are offering home-improvement loans on new and existing houses to low- and moderate-income owners.
 
Subsidies for 3% Interest
 In some programs, deferred loans do not have to be repaid until the house is sold, and subsidies could lower the interest rate to 3 or 6 percent.
EAB signed an agreement in May to provide $250,000 in improvement loans to homeowners in the Town of North Hempstead, which is revitalizing New Cassel, and $200,000 to residents of New Cassel.
A Chase subsidiary, the Chase Community Development Corporation, is lending $10.3 million to build the Landmark Project in Port Washington. That conversion of the Main Street School into apartments for the elderly has taken two years.
The president of the Chase unit, Mark Willis, said he objected to state proposals to revise the criteria for community reinvestment. "The time and effort put into one $50,000 loan that would not otherwise have happened is more important than 10 loans that are easy and any bank would do," Mr. Willis said.
 
For Rough Area in Wyandanch
 In another community-improvement effort, to help Wyandanch "restore, revitalize and recapture" a shopping center that had become a center for drugs and prostitution, Chemical Bank has given $15,000 to Wyandanch Entrepreneurial Development Inc., which was established a year ago to be the landlord of the seven-store center.
"The plan is for the Town of Babylon to condemn the site and for us to acquire it and restore it before turning it over to W.E.D. Inc." said Bill Klatsky, director of the Suffolk Community Development Corporation, the largest administrator of Section 8 programs for the town.
The board of the development agency, led by Daria Cooper, a Citibank employee who is on a leave of absence to administer the project, is interviewing prospective tenants.
EAB, with the Roosevelt Chamber of Commerce, is planning to aid businesses that would not ordinarily qualify for loans, Ms. Mullarkey said. Bank representatives and chamber members will examine applicants, and the bank has agreed to accept the chamber's recommendations.
"You're either too small or too big to qualify for most banks' business loans," said Jonathan Warren, owner of the Roosevelt Check Cashing Center, the first business participating in an alliance between EAB and the chamber.
EAB has set aside $100,000 to assist small and minority-owned businesses in low- to moderate-income communities.
Mr. Warren has a $20,000 loan, repayable in five years, that helped him extend his business's hours. The Carver Savings Bank is the sole bank in Roosevelt, and, Mr. Warren said, "many residents don't have the amount required to keep on deposit."
Mr. Warren said that 30 percent of his customers were elderly people who did not have transportation and that many people depended on him to honor their Nassau County benefits cards, which replaced checks in 1992.
Mr. Warren, who has paid off personal loans since going into business eight years ago, laughed at the idea that banks wanted to help small minority-owned businesses to expand.
"When you apply," he said, "it's a whole different ball game. The rules and regulations are so rigid. They said we couldn't qualify, even though we have shown a profit every year, have paid back our other loans and offered our building for collateral."
There will be "no problem" repaying the EAB loan, Mr. Warren said. The business meets state standards, is audited annually and has shown small profits every year, he noted.
Mayra Fuentes-Jimenez, owner of Dream World Travel in a shopping center in Wheatley Heights, credits the Minority Business Development Center in Melville with obtaining approval for a seven-year $100,000 loan that Chemical Bank gave the agency last year.
 
Embezzlement While Planning
 In business for 18 years, Dream World incurred major losses from embezzling in 1989 about the time that the owners were planning to renovate the rented office and buy new computers for the four employees, Ms. Fuentes-Jimenez said, adding: "Rejected for a few loans, we were afraid we wouldn't survive, until the National Minority Business Development Center helped us to put together a package for a Small Business Administration loan that was acceptable to the bank. When bank executives physically came to the office from Manhattan we finally believed we'd go someplace with this."
A spokeswoman for the State Banking Department, Clare E. Sykes, said there had not been much pressure on banks to show activity under the reinvestment act, unless they applied to expand. Under the law, she said, the banks have to include poorer areas for lending. Individual examiners decide the level of compliance.
Large banks have to include all the low- to moderate-income Census tracts on Long Island in their community-service areas. Small banks may not include any, "but also may not be penalized if they never apply for expansion," Ms. Sykes said.

HEADLINE: Hotel's Fate Poses a Preservation Test

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES 

DATELINE: CAPE MAY

 BODY:
FOR those approaching Cape May by sea, the Christian Admiral Hotel vies with the Cape May Lighthouse as the first sighting of land in the state's southernmost coastal city.
As might be expected in this Victorian city with its national historic landmark status, when the lighthouse needed restoration, Cape May rallied in 1990 to refurbish the 165-foot brick structure, built in 1859. The work was completed in 1994 to the satisfaction of all concerned. But the eight-story brick Beaux-Arts Christian Admiral Hotel, built in 1908, may not have as happy an ending. 
 Its fate is in the hands of two groups: Federal Bankruptcy Court and the Resolution Trust Corporation on the one hand, and the Lojis Corporation, a developer from Everett, Wash., on the other.
Lojis must first decide if the building is salvageable, something that 80 previous potential buyers doubted. Lojis, however, recently saved the Monte Cristo Hotel in Everett, similar in size to the Christian Admiral but in far worse condition, company officials say.
"This country has many wonderful old buildings that may become an embarrassment to the community, like the Christian Admiral," said David Mandley, president of Lojis. "The dilemma facing Cape May is a recurring one: finding alternative uses for old historic buildings, which may also stretch the limits of how far preservationists will go."
The plight of historic buildings fits a pattern, said Elan Zingman-Leith, a former deputy of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, who owns a bed-and-breakfast inn here and is the consultant to the Cape May Historic Preservation Commission. "In cases like this when it comes to preserving a big old building, the players often turn out to be the same," he said.
Mr. Zingman-Leith outlined the usual questions raised: Has the owner maintained the building? Is the city cooperative enough in its regulation and taxing policy? Will a nonprofit group get enough return to take care of the building? What effect do the state and different regulatory agencies have on the operation of the building in terms of fire and safety?
At the turn of the century, the Christian Admiral was known as the Hotel Cape May, built to reflect opulence. Today, its huge lobby with faux marbre columns continues to be illuminated by the light coming through the dome's stained glass ceiling, while underfoot is a hand-laid mosaic marble floor. Chairs in the Chippendale style surround large round tables in the dining room, with its sweeping views of the sea.
But no one can check in here, even though all 330 rooms are unoccupied. A sign on the loading dock in the back of the hotel tells the story: This building is condemned.
The hotel's terra-cotta tile roof has been extensively damaged by winds, allowing rain to percolate through the upper floors and damage the walls. Even the steel beams have begun to corrode inside the masonry.
In 1990, the owner of the hotel, the Christian Beacon Press, a religious group headed by a the Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Included in the debt of $3.5 million are municipal charges that add up to $500,000 and a $2.4 million mortgage held by the Resolution Trust Corporation on two properties, the Christian Admiral and a 100-room hotel, Congress Hall.
The bankruptcy judge set Dec. 31, 1993, as the date for payment to all creditors. If the debt was not paid, auction of both hotels was to have begun on April 1 of this year. The receipt of a demolition permit was used to show a good-faith intent to sell the underlying land and raise the money, so the auction was halted.
The Christian Admiral building itself is valued at just $120,000, though the seven acres on which it sits are worth an estimated $5 million. If the building were razed and the property subdivided into single-family lots, estimates are that more than $5 million could be raised to satisfy the creditors.
The Christian Beacon Press has established that any money remaining after settling the debts would go to refurbish historic Congress Hall, where five Presidents of the United States have spent summers.
Last November, as the December deadline neared with no buyer in sight, the Christian Beacon Press applied to the city and was granted a demolition permit for the Christian Admiral.
Curtis Bashaw, a grandson of Dr. McIntire, serves as a consultant to the Christian Beacon Press and is a local hotelier. Mr. Bashaw, who showed the property to the 80 potential purchasers, concluded that no commercial developer wanted to buy it.
"The demolition permit," he said, "was like an insurance policy for all the creditors. The bankruptcy court and the Resolution Trust Corporation have been very generous to us with their stays."
 
Spirit of Preservation
 But in a community that prides itself on preservation, where the last demolition occurred 20 years ago, tearing down an old building borders on heresy.
Both Mr. Bashaw and another grandson of Dr. McIntire, Norris Clark, who serves as vice president of the three-member board that control the Christian Beacon Press, resent being cast as the villains who want the hotel torn down.
Sitting on the veranda of the Virginia Hotel, a stately Victorian building, once in shambles, that Mr. Bashaw bought in 1988 and restored, he said: "People wear the mantle of preservationists, and that may not always be tractable. To save the Christian Admiral, a coalition of preservationists has got to roll up its sleeves and jump-start the project."
What is needed is to find an adaptive re-use of the building and meet Federal, state and city building codes in the refurbishing, Mr. Bashaw said.
He said that to make the Christian Admiral more attractive to potential developers, there has to be some trade-off, which the community, to date, has not seen fit to make. "Their approach borders on sitting around and wishing for a savior to come," he said.
While the City of Cape May opposes tearing down the hotel, the residents do not want to subsidize the building or forgive some of the back taxes, Mr. Bashaw said.
"The state has mandates," he said. "The hotel's roof was badly in need of repair, but we had to put in fire safety improvements like a sprinkler system and smoke alarms at a cost of $800,000, money that could have been used to fix the roof.
"People want to save these old buildings that must be brought up to code. You have to comply with other mandates like the Americans With Disabilities Act. To rid the building of asbestos alone could cost as much as $750,000."
 
Community Support Sought
 Searching for community support, Mr. Bashaw approached the Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts, a nonprofit organization based in Cape May that specializes in historic preservation. He said he had been told that the group would assist in any way it could but that saving the Christian Admiral was a project too grand in scale for it.
In the efforts to restore the Cape May Lighthouse, the money raised was in the thousands of dollars, about $750,000, Mr. Bashaw said; the Christian Admiral restoration requires millions.
Larry Muentz was chairman of the Historic Preservation Commission hearing on the demolition application, which the commission denied, but which was later granted by the Planning Board. "The problem," Mr. Muentz said, "is not fixing the stones and mortar; it's finding an adaptive commercial use for the building. It's all in the economics. You're looking for answers to: 'Who is going to pay for it? Who is going to run it?' "
Once a demolition permit has been granted, a Cape May ordinance requires a six-month waiting period in a last-ditch effort for a possible buyer. That appeared to have happened in January, when R. Steven Scherfel, president of the Senior Living Centers in Cherry Hill, came forward with a proposal to transform the Christian Admiral into the Breakers at Cape May, a continuing-care retirement community with apartment accommodations.
Mr. Scherfel agreed to the asking price of $3.5 million. But he withdrew his offer when the Resolution Trust Corporation said a 5 percent cash deposit was required, about $175,000.
The decision was a blow to Cape May's Mayor, Robert Elwell, who is eager to have the building back on the tax rolls. "This is a very valuable piece of property," he said. "But I am enough of a realist that if someone doesn't come forward soon, the building is going to fall down anyway. But we have to give it every last breath we can."
Mr. Mandley, the Lojis president, said his company had saved the Monte Cristo by "using housing tax credits combined with national historic tax credit." He said in that case, the upper floors were rented as affordable housing, "while public spaces are on the lower floors."
"Low-income housing terrifies some people," he continued. "What they fail to realize that it provides affordable living quarters for the elderly and those who are just starting out."
Mr. Mandley has sent an engineer to check on the structural condition of the Christian Admiral. "Foremost in our mind," he said, "is making the numbers work so that the banks will invest in the project."
Mr. Bashaw, who is meeting with the Lojis people, likens the company's proposal to a "missing link" in finding an adaptable use for the hotel. He said, "The lower floors could be used as public space to accommodate Cape May's cultural projects like the art and musical festivals, and my grandfather's group could continue to hold their religious services there."
Mr. Clark joins his cousin, Mr. Bashaw, in continuing to explore opportunities to save the hotel. Mr. Clark said his ambition has been to establish a Cape May institute, patterned after the Aspen Institute in Colorado, at the Christian Admiral.
"I spent summers at the Christian Admiral doing every job from bellhop to baker," Mr. Clark said. "I'll see this through to the end. I just can't turn my back on it."
