HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
The Odd Pull Of 'Jeopardy' On 62 Flutes

BYLINE: By Michael Beckerman; Michael Beckerman teaches music history at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
WE ARE IN A HUGE, MILDEWED AUDITOrium with a decrepit ceiling missing several panels. The hard wooden seats are filled except for the dozens of broken ones; thousands of proud parents and friends chatter in two dozen languages. The tune "Long, Long Ago" emanates from the front, behind a stained green curtain. Though it sounds for all the world like some gigantic exotic instrument or the auditory equivalent of root canal, it is something more: it is the sound of the future. Two hundred tiny fiddlers are getting ready for the first half of the Elementary Music Festival at Lincoln High School Auditorium, a concert featuring the finest beginning musicians of the San Francisco Unified School District.
The disrepair in the hall is symbolic: the school district has fallen on hard times, as California continues to reel under inexorable recession. Many schools are in trouble. There is little money for new technology, special subjects or new staff. Some schools don't even have basketball rims (although in fairness, the absence of rims may have more to do with discouraging gang activity in certain areas after school). There are 10,350 students taking music lessons in the district and only 13 music teachers. Each is responsible for five or more schools, and they ride the circuit like judges of yore. Simple arithmetic says that each teacher sees about 800 students per week. 
 Yet despite all obstacles, the level of instruction is high. In addition to support from the school district, the music program relies on generous grants from the Ewald Foundation, which provides instruments for the many students who cannot afford them, and sponsors the festival this afternoon. A few hundred award-winning students have been invited to attend.
Sally Ann Ryan, the program administrator for the visual and performing arts, thanks the parents for their patience and support. The curtain opens for the first act: the little fiddlers. Of those 10,000-plus taking music lessons, more than 1,200 are violinists. Some of the 200 selected for the festival are clad in white chiffon or blue gossamer, suspenders and polka-dot ties; others sport black jeans and white shirts. They are almost all Americans, though their parents come from dozens of countries and may speak Tagalog, Vietnamese, Cambodian, Spanish, Arabic, Chinese or Japanese. They perform on fiddles of all sizes and look very serious as they play their warm-up, "Long, Long Ago," followed by a tune called "Popcorn Party."
Calling off the names and numbers of the instruments that follow rings like some fractured Christmas carol or an inner city "Music Man": 38 trumpets blare "Lightly Row"; 72 clarinets honk out "Yankee Doodle" and "British Melody" (formerly "Aura Lee"); 62 flutes toot Beethoven's "Ode to Joy" and the theme from "Jeopardy." The culmination of this part comes when the three groups play a round, "Oh, How Lovely Is the Evening," and somehow manage to finish at the same time, to the delight of all present and the palpable relief of all the teachers. Twenty soprano recorders pipe "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" and "Loch Lomond," and a choir 42 strong shouts out "Getting to Know You," "Music Alone Shall Live" and "Open the Window, Noah."
These public images of beautiful children and musical beginnings lie somewhere on the plane between multiculturalism and elitism. Despite the range of languages and cultures represented, the music is vintage white America ("Long, Long Ago," "Go Tell Aunt Rhody"), as if all music education texts had mysteriously stopped in 1958. Although violin lessons may represent an entree to the world of high culture, the tune that generates the most excitement is the theme from "Jeopardy," which seems to cut across all cultural barriers -- a slightly scary thought.
The week after the concert, an unrelated newspaper article presents the complaints of childless workers who resent the time taken off by parents for child-rearing tasks; they demand equity in the workplace. Such a view seems to represent a curious lapse in reasoning. Who do they think will bring them their bedpans in 30 years if not some of these young performers? Who will serenade them with sweet sounds in their final days if they are lucky enough to end up in a retirement home -- or find cures for the diseases that torment them? Yet these young musicians and their friends receive only tiny bits of support from a society that will be quick to vilify and incarcerate them if they falter.
The San Francisco Unified School District has a commitment to multicultural education that can sometimes be divisive, since not all minority groups are equally privileged, but these children playing in their ensembles surely grasp the larger truth. The celebration of diversity needs to go far deeper, to its ultimate core, and acknowledge that each human being is a separate culture, with a unique view, a separate language and a separate reality. If we really love music and hope for a future in which it can flourish, our heroes should be the school music teachers who are fighting our fight on the front lines by teaching these children to celebrate their separate identities by performing together.

HEADLINE: A Fine Mess They've Got Us Into

BYLINE: By William C. Taylor; William C. Taylor is a founding editor of the business magazine Fast Company.

 BODY:

SELF-INFLICTED WOUNDS
From LBJ's Guns and Butter
to Reagan's Voodoo Economics.
By Hobart Rowen.
Illustrated. 447 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $25. 
 HOBART ROWEN, the Washington Post columnist, is the dean of America's economic journalists. When the Federal Reserve Board boosts interest rates or finance ministers prop up the dollar or the International Monetary Fund imposes an austerity program on some bankrupt developing country, Mr. Rowen is usually the first (and most influential) newspaper writer to pass judgment.
"Self-Inflicted Wounds" is a book-length judgment on 30 years' worth of such decisions, ending more or less before the election of Bill Clinton. The verdict is not pretty. Mr. Rowen believes that the story of the United States economy over the last three decades is one of uninterrupted drift and decline. The roots of that decline are clear to him: "mismanagement, stupidity and irresponsibility by officials whose chief obligation to govern the nation was betrayed by their embrace of policies misconceived and ineptly applied."
Unfortunately, "Self-Inflicted Wounds" is as flawed as the economic policies it attacks. For one thing, it's dull -- or at least duller than necessary. There aren't many writers who can transform an analysis of exchange rates, wage and price guidelines and monetary reform into a page turner. But Mr. Rowen might have provided some relief by mining his notebooks for more color and texture. After all, he has had close encounters with globe-trotting characters from Treasury Secretary John Connally to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. It would be nice to see more of them in private moments.
Instead, we get just the slightest hint of what might have been. Mr. Rowen paints a sympathetic portrait of Jimmy Carter's first Treasury Secretary, Michael Blumenthal, whose clout, the author says, was undermined by narrow-minded political operatives. He recounts his 15-year grievance with Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post, who Mr. Rowen feels did not defend him vigorously enough in the mid-1970's from attacks by Robert McNamara. (Mr. McNamara was upset by a series of articles Mr. Rowen had written criticizing his policies as president of the World Bank.)
It was only a few years ago, when Mrs. Graham interviewed Mr. Rowen for her book, that he cleared the air. "Kay had forgotten about the McNamara affair," he reports in a lengthy footnote. "But until our conversation in 1991, I had not been able to let go of my resentment." Regrettably, these flesh-and-blood moments are all too rare.
The more serious problem with Mr. Rowen's book involves substance rather than style. "Self-Inflicted Wounds" doesn't advance a sustained argument about what has gone wrong over the last 30 years. Instead, it offers critical judgments on specific economic decisions in six Administrations. Many of those decisions were big news when they were being debated; today, however, most of them seem remote, almost quaint.
Indeed, reading this book is a bit like leafing through a photo album. It revives memories: Did Gerald Ford really campaign to "whip inflation now"? Did Dad really wear that lime green leisure suit? But with a few exceptions, such as its justified, if unsurprising, attack on Reagan-era budget deficits, the book does not genuinely explain how these past decisions have shaped who and where we are today.
An example is Mr. Rowen's discussion of wage and price controls in the Nixon Administration -- specifically, the January 1973 decision to lift controls 18 months after they were imposed. "In retrospect," he writes, "dropping Phase II [price controls] was a monumental blunder. . . . There were indeed some distortions, as in the lumber industry. But the Administration never proved the general case. Phase II should have been left in place: it wasn't broke, and didn't need fixing."
PERHAPS. But it is awfully hard to detect the long-term implications of Richard Nixon's decision. In fact, just a few chapters later, Mr. Rowen blasts President Ford's obsession with inflation. By 1975, he argues, "the real enemy" was "a deepening recession," not runaway prices.
To Mr. Rowen, it seems from this book, making economic policy is like adjusting the dials on a stereo system: a little more bass on monetary policy, a little less treble on tax cuts, and the United States economy will make sweet music. The trouble, as he sees it, is that for 30 years the people turning the knobs have been tone-deaf.
But his reporting in "Self-Inflicted Wounds" creates an altogether different impression. It's not that Washington is messing up the dials. It's that the dials have been disconnected from the real economy, and no one has noticed. The issue is less stupidity than futility -- the declining
effectiveness of traditional policy tools in the face of fundamental economic changes: revolutionary technologies, aggressive global competitors, exotic new financial instruments. The real problem is not what Washington has been doing, but what it has been missing.
The same can be said of "Self-Inflicted Wounds." Mr. Rowen's exhaustive analysis of America's economic predicament ignores the most powerful forces transforming the economy -- forces whose significance has finally begun to penetrate the Washington agenda. Consider just three: the computer revolution, the telecommunications revolution and health care.
Mr. Rowen writes at great length on the rise and fall of OPEC's hold over oil, the essential raw material of the industrial age. But what about the rise of the microprocessor, the essential raw material of the computer age? Information technology has changed how companies are structured, how people work, what they get paid. No serious discussion of unemployment and income inequality can ignore the economic and social impact of computers.
He chronicles the breakup of the Bretton Woods monetary system under President Nixon. But what about the breakup of the Bell System under Ronald Reagan? It may be the most important (if unintended) industrial policy ever devised. Competition among AT&T, the Baby Bells, MCI, Sprint and hundreds of other post-breakup companies has created the technological innovations behind the information highway. No serious discussion of the competitive battle between the United States and Japan can ignore our commanding lead in the most important industry of the future.
Similarly, he devotes an entire chapter to the third world debt crisis. But what about the health care crisis? For 20 years, health care has been a growing sector of the economy, a huge competitive burden and a big drain on the Federal budget. No serious discussion of inflation and the deficit can ignore health care.
Mr. Rowen ignores these and other critical developments because for too long our political leaders ignored them as well. Washington's negligence may be the ultimate self-inflicted wound.
 
 
 
WINNING ONE WAR, LOSING ANOTHER
 In my years of reporting on the economic scene in Washington and from foreign capitals, only Japan's enormous success story aroused persistent and intense emotions on the part of Government officials and the American public alike. While "Japan-bashing" may have been popular, it was counterproductive; it lulled the American public into thinking that if only the Japanese would behave themselves, our economy would magically revive, and employment would boom once again. As former U.S. trade representative William E. Brock quipped: "My nightmare is that Japan does everything I ask it to do, then I wake up, and our deficit stays the same." But even Representative Richard A. Gephardt (D.-Mo.) -- the most strident critic of Japan in Congress -- admitted during his fruitless effort to win the 1988 Democratic nomination for President that no more than 20 percent of the trade deficit with Japan could be attributed to their "unfair" trading practices. . . .
The success of the Japanese in marketing goods here had an odd effect on some Americans: they rushed to buy the Toyotas and Sonys because their performance and quality were high. At the same time, they linked Japanese success with American failure. And the connection they tended to make was not that we might have been doing something wrong -- but that the Japanese must be taking unfair advantage. They failed to consider that, in the postwar period, Japan placed its bets on industrial and technological development, while America, especially under Presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, devoted too much of its financial and human resources to military competition with the Soviet Union. Today, it is little solace that we have won the cold war with the Soviet Union only to realize that we are losing on another front, against Japan, in terms of trade and markets.
 From "Self-Inflicted Wounds."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW;
President Considers a Cuban Blockade

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
As the flood of refugees out of Cuba continued unabated, the Clinton Administration warned President Fidel Castro today that the Administration would consider further steps, including a blockade of the island, if he did not take meaningful steps toward democracy.
Angrily accusing Mr. Castro of orchestrating the exodus, the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said on the ABC News program "This Week," "We want to see Castro move toward a democratic government, and that clearly is not happening. As a consequence, we're putting pressures on the Castro Government." 
 Mr. Panetta's tough comments came as part of an aggressive new Administration strategy that intends to hasten the demise of the 35-year-old Communist government in Cuba and to pressure Mr. Castro to stanch the flow of refugees.
But hours after Mr. Panetta said the Administration would consider a blockade of the island, Administration officials began backing away from the threat. Acknowledging that mounting a unilateral blockade around the island would be difficult and would face widespread opposition in Latin America, they said the remarks were hypothetical and that no such action was imminent.
Despite President Clinton's announcement on Friday that he was ending the 28-year-old practice of granting entry to virtually all Cuban refugees, the flood of refugees continued this weekend. The Coast Guard said that, as of midnight, it had picked up 1,293 Cubans today, the most in a single day since the Mariel boatlift in 1980, and that it intercepted 1,189 Cubans on Saturday.
The two daily figures represent not only the most Cubans fleeing their nation by boat since the exodus began early this month, but also the highest daily totals since , when 125,000 Cubans fled to the United States.
The Coast Guard has brought additional ships and crews from ports along the Gulf Coast and Eastern Seaboard to help cope with the wave of refugees. Moreover, Navy vessels began picking up refugees at sea today, said a Coast Guard spokesman, Lt. (jg) Bob Engle.
The Administration toughened its approach toward Cuba after more than 4,000 Cubans took to ramshackle rafts and dinghies since Aug. 1. President Clinton announced on Friday that Cubans heading to Florida would be intercepted and held at the United States base at Guantanamo Bay.
With refugees continuing to surge out of Cuba this weekend despite the President's new strategy, the Administration today increased Guantanamo Bay's capacity to keep up with the wave of Cuban boat people.
"We are concerned about this," said a White House official. "We didn't expect the number to drop off immediately. We are redoubling our efforts to get the message across that this trip is very dangerous and you can't get to the U.S. this way."
In his television appearance today, Mr. Panetta repeated President Clinton's accusation that Mr. Castro has been trying to sweep masses of disgruntled Cubans toward United States shores to take some of the heat off the Cuban leader.
"We've got to continue to put pressure on Castro because the problem here is not the problem of refugees," Mr. Panetta said. "It's the problems within the Castro regime. That's what's causing this. And he's trying to use these migrants as a tool to try to influence our foreign policy."
Also appearing on "This Week," Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida called for imposing a blockade if Mr. Castro allowed the exodus of boat people to escalate. With the United States virtually alone in pursuing a trade embargo against Cuba, a blockade would aim to cut off Cuba's trade with the rest of the world.
 
Saturday's Measures
 On Saturday, President Clinton announced that he would increase anti-Castro radio and television broadcasts and cut off the flow of about $500 million a year that Cuban-Americans send each year to relatives in Cuba. The President also moved to greatly restrict charter flights to Cuba and said he would push the United Nations to condemn Cuba's human-rights record.
The most potent new measure is the ban on sending hard currency to Cuba, a move that Administration officials say will severely squeeze the Castro Government because such cash shipments are Cuba's largest source of hard currency, after sugar exports and tourism.
"I think it will have a drastic effect on Cuba's economy," said Domingo Moreira, a board member of the Cuban-American National Foundation.
By some estimates these cash gifts to relatives in Cuba represent more than one-fourth of Cuba's hard currency earnings each year.
A State Department official said today, "Castro's refusal to do anything to try to put his economy back in order has gotten Cuba to the point where things are so perilous that additional sanctions like this may make them face the fact that they have to do something different in terms of reform."
In the view of Administration officials, the flow of American cash has helped prop up Mr. Castro by reducing hardship for thousands of Cuban families and by providing the Cuban Government with hard currency.
 
Harm to Average Cubans
 Administration officials admitted that the tightened sanctions could hurt average Cubans, the very people that Washington wants to help. These officials said they hoped the sanctions would make it plain to Mr. Castro that the economic situation was so untenable that he would have to give in to pressures for reform.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, defended the new measures.
"It is impossible to bring fundamental political change to Cuba without doing damage to the people who live on the island," he said. "If it were possible, we would attempt it. It will hurt near-term, but it is the only way of achieving the long-term goal of establishing freedom in Cuba."
For many Cubans, getting just a few dollars from relatives in Florida can help a family obtain basics like soap and cooking oil. These items are rationed but are readily available in hard-currency stores.
Most of the hard currency sent to Cubans ends up in the hands of the Government because those fortunate enough to obtain dollars often spend them in the Government's hard-currency shops.
The Cuban Government angrily denounced the Administration's new sanctions. The state-controlled news agency, Prensa Latina, said the sanctions "contradict the genuine international consensus favoring an end to pressures."
Cuba's state radio denounced President Clinton's moves as "reinforcing the harassment of Cuba," while the Foreign Ministry accused him of building a "concentration camp" for Cuban boat people at Guantanamo Bay.
The first 1,000 Cuban refugees bound for detention in Guatanamo Bay were scheduled to arrive there Monday aboard three Coast Guard cutters. Hundreds more were being transferred at sea to other ships that will make the day-and-a-half voyage around the western end of Cuba as they are filled with passengers.

HEADLINE: End of Russia's Economic Slide Brings Eerie Calm

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 21

 BODY:
A year ago, President Boris N. Yeltsin announced that he was preparing a "September barrage" against his sworn opposition in the Russian congress. By October, the metaphor had turned real, with tanks shelling the Parliament building.
This August, there is an eerie stability. Monthly inflation is down to 6 percent compared with 26 percent a year ago. Salaries are worth more with the ruble stronger, and consumer spending is up. There is consensus on economic policy under Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who has adopted the tight-money policies he criticized in January. Mr. Yeltsin appears more energetic, the new Parliament is behaving itself and a divided opposition is apparently looking more toward 1996 elections than to counterrevolution in the streets. 
 On a trip this week down the Volga River, talking to ordinary Russians, Mr. Yeltsin had a new announcement: "I see that in many regions the economic slide has stopped."
That is a vast improvement, but how stable is it? Made pessimistic by their tortured history, few Russians like to hazard any bets. The country has been in tumult so long that any extended period without calamity is deeply unsettling.
Opinion polls still show ambivalence about the future, even as the newspapers debate whether the August 1991 coup attempt against Mikhail S. Gorbachev was an effort to save the country or to strangle it. Among Muscovites, traditionally the most cosmopolitan Russians, only 30 percent think capitalism will improve their lives and that of their families, while 37 percent say they still do not know. About 23 percent think things will become worse. A year ago, 26 percent expected improvement.
There are enormous problems in Russia, from crime, corruption and moral disorder to growing unemployment, unpaid salaries and intercompany debt. But as Sergei Pavlenko, head of Russia's Center for Economic Reforms, says: "The high-temperature fever crisis of the Russian economy is over."
A senior Western finance official put it differently: "We're happy with Russia now. Why? Because it's not on the precipice anymore. It may get there again, but it's kind of back-burner. It's costing us less in money and less in nerves."
 
Trying to Buy Time for Stability
 For lack of a better strategy in an extended period of thin budgets and greater domestic demands, Washington and other Western allies seem simply to be trying to buy Russia time.
Such a policy annoys Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev, who fears that Western miserliness and strategic neglect now, in such sharp contrast to the effort made to contain the Soviet Union, may feed political extremism. But Mr. Kozyrev agrees that Western aid is far less important than private investment, and that time is precisely what Russia needs.
Time to nurture democratic institutions, like political parties and juries. Time to pass practical laws governing free-market business. Time to learn new economic behavior. Time to get over the humiliation of the Soviet Union's collapse and regain some patriotic pride. Time to get rich enough not to feel embarrassed. Time to get used to stability itself.
For all Russia's problems, Mr. Pavlenko said, "Economic behavior among the population is beginning to change."
There are many positive signs this August.
At the VDNKh center, built to display the glories of Soviet technology, memorials to Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, are ignored as Russians shop for imported televisions, videos, stereos and cars. VDNKh -- the All-Union Exhibition of the Achievements of the People's Economy -- is now a kind of shopping mall.
Russian stores are full of better clothes and groceries. Russians fill nightclubs, restaurants and health clubs whose prices would make a New Yorker blanch. Russians are lunching and brunching with cellular phones, electronic diaries and Hugo Boss suits. Russians are building huge, crenellated brick dachas, restoring Moscow's tattered office buildings and hiring foreign accountants. Russians are pouring into once-forbidden European vacation spots like Cyprus and Rimini, let alone Paris and London.
 
Hard-Line Influence Beginning to Wane
 For many people life is getting better. Their salaries buy more and they are spending more, with real household consumption up 18 percent over the same quarter last year.
In January, Mr. Chernomyrdin lost the most visible Westernized reformers in a Government deeply divided over economic policy after the strong showing of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, a hard-line nationalist, in December's elections. Mr. Chernomyrdin, a former Energy Minister and industrialist, spoke of the need for an expansionary, big-spending budget, with inflation going up to 18 percent a month.
But pressed by the West and without reformers like Yegor T. Gaidar, Mr. Yeltsin's first Prime Minister, to blame, Mr. Chernomyrdin soon reversed himself. Not only did he begin to preach the need for low inflation and a tight hold on credits, he also enforced an economic consensus within the Government. The head of the Central Bank, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, without the former Parliament's support, took his cue from Mr. Chernomyrdin. Just as important, the bank stopped giving credits directly to enterprises, but only to the Government itself.
Having once compared privatization to Stalinist collectivization, Mr. Chernomyrdin has come to support the Privatization Minister, Anatoly B. Chubais, and has echoed his calls for managers to reform their enterprises or face bankruptcy.
Despite much wailing over steep drops in industrial production, much of that drop is statistically questionable because Russian figures barely touch the growing private economy. If in the old days production reports were inflated to meet quotas and earn bonuses, today they are minimized to reduce taxes and bribes. Economists also point to electricity consumption, which has dropped only about 2 percent despite higher prices, as a strong indicator that private production is taking up much of the slack.
The second stage of privatization, in which the Government sells its remaining 49 percent share of many companies, will bring at least $2 billion into state coffers this half-year alone. There will be more money next year, a transfusion that will lessen pressure to raise taxes or finagle special loans from the International Monetary Fund. Foreign investment itself is increasing, and could total $6 billion this year.
 
Benefit of Doubt From Power Elite
 As a centrist representative of the country's real power elite -- managers and bureaucrats -- Mr. Chernomyrdin has gotten a bigger benefit of the doubt than Mr. Gaidar, an academic economist who represents a much thinner slice of Russian life. Mr. Chernomyrdin, to the disgust of the Communist and nationalist opposition, has been carrying out the essence of Mr. Gaidar's policies. But with less dissent, he's doing a more effective job.
He and Mr. Yeltsin, who has been moving into the political center, have made a reassuring team, both at home and abroad. They have been helped by the new Constitution forced through in December, which established a strong presidency.
By stressing more muscular, nationalist themes, like fighting crime and enhancing Russian prestige, Mr. Yeltsin has been coopting the nationalist opposition, itself divided.
Mr. Zhirinovsky, who won 22.8 percent of the party-preference vote and does not dominate Parliament, is tiring his own supporters, half of whom would not vote for him again, according to opinion surveys. The former Vice President, Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, who was in jail during the December election for leading the old Parliament's revolt, is pardoned and on the campaign trail, likely to dilute the nationalist vote in 1996 elections, if they happen at all.
But if Russia follows other former Communist countries like Poland and Hungary, a lot of the disaffected vote will go to neo-Communists. Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist Party leader, speaks more like a social democrat. He's in favor of private property and ownership of land, he says, "but the state, with honest officials, should regulate matters so the people are protected." It's not Locke, but it's not Stalin, either.
On the negative side, of course, there is a considerable weight of crime, corruption, confusion and economic distress. While most Russians seem to be doing better, many are not. In big military-industrial centers like Novosibirsk, huge factories are restructuring very slowly, keeping workers on minimum wages or forced vacations or not paying them at all for months. Underpaid nuclear scientists are striking. Companies, strapped for cash or preferring to invest it, are again running up huge debts to one another, totaling nearly $15 billion.
 
Fighting Inflation Or Unemployment
 This is the other side of a tight-money policy, which can work only if companies are convinced that the Government will not bail them out. Mr. Chernomyrdin is talking tough, but pressure to spend is growing from military, agricultural and industrial lobbies. Inflation is likely to hit 10 percent a month by autumn -- not awful, but not the 10 percent a year that would mark economic stabilization.
The Government continues to face a terrible choice between high inflation, with continued subsidies to industry, and rising unemployment, which could reach 10 percent of the workforce by year's end but produce faster recovery. High unemployment could also produce unrest, especially in cities like Novosibirsk.
Finding a medium path would be easier if the Government could make strategic decisions about which sectors to help and how to create a solid social safety net for those displaced by change.
The budget is also unreal, with tax revenues far below projections and new spending "off budget" to pacify vital players like the military. Deficit and other targets agreed on with the International Monetary Fund are sure to slip.
To raise more money, the bureaucracy is imposing bizarre taxes, which can take 80 percent of profits. Such taxes encourage evasion and corruption and are a big disincentive to foreign investment. Mr. Chernomyrdin complains, but the bureaucrats remain a state unto themselves.
In a more general way, there is a deep sense of moral disorder, with too many crooks profiting and too many honorable scholars scraping by. Russia's democratic roots are thin; its political parties are weak and personalized; its courts are laughable; the average Ivan has little more recourse against the state than he did under the Soviet Union.
Mr. Yeltsin, when he's visible, acts more like a czar or a Communist general secretary than an elected President. The new Parliament is more interested in electioneering than in making laws, allowing Mr. Yeltsin to continue to rule by decree, many of which are ignored.
Some Western diplomats, worried about 1996 elections, say few will complain if that vote, though mandated in the Constitution, is postponed until 1998 -- buying Russia a little more time.
"Even if the situation improves just a little bit, and people feel this -- and I'm not talking about attaining world standards -- then this will help lessen the appeal of nationalism," said Kronid Lyubarsky, deputy editor of New Times magazine. "If we can live through the next two or three years without a significant worsening of the economy, then I believe we'll overcome the greatest danger."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 22, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2776 words

HEADLINE: Baseball's Bottom Line -- A special report.;
Colleagues or Competitors? 28 Owners in the Spotlight

 BODY:
The following article is based on reporting by Richard Sandomir, Barry Meier and Matthew Purdy and was written by Mr. Purdy with Mr. Sandomir.
The Yankees' $40 million-a-year cable television contract -- the biggest in baseball and the envy of other club owners -- is the financial equivalent of a changeup pitch. When it was signed in 1988, it looked like a potential bonanza to other owners who were due to share in the contract. Until it faded away. 
 American League regulations say the Yankees must give about one-quarter of their annual cable money -- potentially $10 million -- to other teams. But the way the game is played, the Yankees and George Steinbrenner, their shrewd principal owner, manage to give up only $4.4 million a year and keep the rest.
In baseball, as the rich teams get richer, the gap is widening between clubs like the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox and poorer teams like the San Diego Padres and the Pittsburgh Pirates, which felt compelled to shed expensive players to stay afloat.
The players strike has halted a season of remarkable performances by players like Ken Griffey Jr. and Matt Williams and soured a season of redemption for fans of first-place teams like the Yankees and the Montreal Expos. But the strife between the owners of baseball's have and have-not teams is likely to have a more profound impact on the game.
The delicate finances of a few teams are making the fractious group of 28 team owners confront a question it has long avoided: whether to continue as competitors or become partners in a new financial structure that forces richer teams to more generously share their wealth with their less-fortunate brethren.
The notion of forming a partnership is inimical to the culture of baseball, where owners regard their clubs as fiefdoms, jealously guarding their financial secrets and resolutely protecting their profits.
Any change in the financial relationship among teams could affect their ever-rising resale values, which make even the most troubled franchises attractive to investors. The Baltimore Orioles, a financially stable team with a heralded new stadium, were sold three times from 1979 to 1993, the price rising from $12 million to $173 million. But even the Pittsburgh Pirates are attracting considerable interest despite their well-known problems. The Pirates are on the block for an initial price of $85 million, which is more than twice what they sold for nine years ago.
The issue is being brought to a head as less profitable clubs -- lacking lucrative television deals and friendly stadium leases from host cities -- claim they cannot compete for players in the existing open market and will either fail financially or be driven to seek more lucrative markets.
"It is a system that frankly is broken, that just doesn't work," said Tal Smith, a former executive with several baseball teams, including the Yankees and Houston Astros, who is now a consultant to teams.
In January, after lengthy and divisive discussions, the wealthier clubs reluctantly agreed to aid poorer teams through a revenue-sharing plan. But they said the plan would take effect only if the union agreed to a limit on player payrolls in a new labor contract. The union has rejected the proposed salary cap, sparking the strike that is in its 11th day today.
The owners have agreed to share an estimated $50 million in revenues with less profitable teams, according to people familiar with the plan. Under the plan, one team executive said, the Seattle Mariners and the Expos would each receive about $10 million annually from the pool, while other aggrieved teams would receive less.
Jeff Smulyan, the former owner of the Mariners, said he understood the attitude of less-profitable teams. "They're saying, 'It's more important that we survive than your profit margin go down,' " he said.
Whatever the resolution of the strike, forging an equitable partnership among the teams will be difficult because of the different kinds of ownership, from corporations like Anheuser-Busch, to limited partnerships, like the Yankees, or single proprietorships, like the Dodgers.
Each structure has reasons to reduce profits and uses various types of financial legerdemain to reach that goal. When a team owner has several other businesses related to the ball club, " the only way you can get an accurate picture is to consolidate all the businesses, which they don't do," said Roger Noll, a Stanford University economist who has examined the owners' books for the players union.
 
Art of the Deal
The Envy of All Cable Contracts
 A true, unvarnished account of owners' finances is likely to ignite controversies, like the one concerning the Yankees' cable contract.
Teams can legally reduce profits by undervaluing contracts for their TV rights, by charging expenses from an owner's outside businesses against a team's revenues, by paying owners high salaries or by selling stadium refreshments and by advertising through separate corporations controlled by team owners, rather than through the team itself. These practices allow teams to reduce money available either for player salaries or for sharing with other teams.
The Yankees' 12-year, $486 million cable TV contract with the MSG Network is one of the most envied deals in baseball. Under the current revenue sharing system, which was adopted in the mid-1960's, about 25 percent of each club's revenues from cable TV is allocated to a league pool.
But rather than signing a single cable contract with MSG, Mr. Steinbrenner signed several MSG contracts, which pay the team unusually large fees for promotional considerations, the rights to videos, the team's film library and broadcast TV rights. This practice greatly diminishes the amount of money paid strictly for putting the games on cable television, the only category of payments subject to baseball's sharing plan.
As a result, the Yankees shared 25 percent of only $19.9 million with American League owners last year, a contribution of $4.4 million, instead of 25 percent of the team's full fee of more than $40 million from MSG, which would have been a contribution of more than $10 million.
"The A.L. was in revolt a few years ago, trying to get more of that money," said Tom Villante, a broadcasting consultant to several teams.
Poorer teams may go into full-scale revolt if broader-based revenue sharing is not enacted soon. Peter Angelos, owner of the Orioles, predicts there will be a plan, but he is against one that would be simple charity. He said he favored one that would encourage cities to subsidize the cost of new stadiums and help put teams on sound financial footing.
Many wealthier owners agreed to the revenue sharing plan in January even while saying it smacked of welfare. "This is socialism at work and baseball is still a free-enterprise sport," Mr. Steinbrenner said after the plan was adopted.
Just as some of the richer owners are reluctant to form a partnership, players do not want to tie their salaries to the financial fortunes of the owners. Union officials say that while owners cry poverty, they always make profits when they sell their teams and bidders are waiting to buy even the most distressed teams. The union also argues that bad management, not player salaries, accounts for teams' financial misfortunes.
"What they say on their profit and loss statements doesn't matter," said Eugene Orza, the associate executive director of the players union. "It's the viability as an institution. It's the record attendance, people going to more games than ever before."
Baseball executives have rarely been as candid about how profits and losses are determined as Paul Beeston, the Toronto Blue Jays' president. "Under generally accepted accounting principles," he said in 1978 when he was a team vice president, "I can turn a $4 million profit into a $2 million loss, and I can get every national accounting firm to agree with me."
Team owners in other sports have operated more like financial partners than those in baseball. For more than 40 years, the National Football League has shared gate receipts, 60 percent for the home team, 40 percent for visitors. Network television and licensing revenues are split equally, leaving only stadium concessions and luxury box cash kept by home teams. Since the league sells all games to broadcast and cable networks, there are no disparities in local TV revenues.
But in baseball there has been little effort to level the playing field. Baseball is still largely a game of local appeal with roots and fan bases for some teams dating to the last century. As a result, baseball revenues have mostly been held close to home.
American League home teams split gate receipts on an 80-20 basis with visiting teams. In the National League, visiting teams get a mere 43 cents from each ticket sold, or perhaps about 5 percent of the receipts.
Baseball teams split national TV and licensing money equally, and each team shares about 25 percent of its revenues from local cable contracts. But there is no sharing of revenue from local broadcast TV and radio contracts or from luxury boxes, concessions or parking.
Baseball owners have resisted leadership. While strong commissioners in both basketball and football have forged revenue sharing arrangements and salary caps with players, baseball owners ousted Commissioner Fay Vincent two years ago for involving himself in matters the owners wanted to control, likelabor and divisional realignment.
The owners then watered down the commissioner's powers, removing him from labor affairs, and installed as the acting commissioner Bud Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, a needy small-market team that would benefit from the largess of wealthier teams.
 
Two Case Studies
One Team Up, One Team Down
 The recent history of the Pirates and the Orioles is a striking contrast in team finances.
The Pirates, National League East champions from 1990 to 1992, have seen their financial and division standing plummet as star players like Bobby Bonilla, Barry Bonds and Doug Drabek signed free-agent contracts with other teams. The team had a combined operating loss of $24.9 million in 1992 and 1993, according to team financial records, reflecting low attendance, a meager TV contract and a subpar share of stadium and concession revenues.
Some economists linked to the players union said the team inflated expenses to paint the gloomiest picture possible, but few who are familiar with the team doubt it is troubled.
"We're trying to do everything we can at this level -- improved lease and improved stadium -- but we don't think that's going to be enough unless major league baseball also makes some changes," said Mark Pollack, special counsel to Mayor Tom Murphy of Pittsburgh.
In Baltimore, the high-caliber play is barely keeping pace with the business boon from the 1992 opening of Oriole Park at Camden Yards, the old-style, $150 million stadium that is regularly sold out. Stadium revenues let the team lavish an extra $10 million on player salaries this year, according to club records. Team coffers have swelled from its lease with the city that gives the team all but a small fraction of every dollar spent on tickets, concessions and luxury boxes.
The Orioles exemplify what some experts believe other teams must do to prosper -- persuade politicians and taxpayers to finance a new stadium and then to let the team keep most of the ball park's operating profits.
State and local officials were determined to keep the Orioles in Baltimore, said Michael Megna, a Milwaukee-based expert on team values and finances, and "as a result, the Orioles got a very sweet deal."
That deal has also dramatically affected the team's value. Major league clubs have appreciated 15 to 20 percent annually, some economists said, and few have done as well as the Orioles.
The Orioles were purchased last October by Mr. Angelos, a Baltimore lawyer, and a group of investors for $173 million. Four years earlier, Eli Jacobs, a New York investor, had acquired the Orioles for $70 million from the estate of the Washington lawyer Edward Bennett Williams. In 1979, Williams had bought the team for $12 million.
But losing money doesn't necessarily ruin a ball club's resale value. The Pirates, which were last sold nine years ago for $40 million, are on the block again and suitors are lining up. Bidding starts at $85 million.
In any case, can owners be financial partners, with or without a cap?
"I don't think they have the emotional or psychological drive," said Andrew Zimbalist, author of "Baseball and Billions," a study of baseball economics. "The game has an engineering problem in its ownership structure. But it is possible."
Those engineering problems have let owners use their discretion, as well as tax and accounting rules, to reduce profits.
For example, Mr. Jacobs, the former Orioles owner, took a loan of $6 million from the ball club to help another one of his businesses. The loan was never repaid to the Orioles, according to Mr. Angelos.
The owners of two teams also control the television stations that broadcast their games. According to financial analysts and baseball executives, these owners pay their teams less than a market rate for the right to broadcast games, which reduces team revenues. The Chicago Cubs and WGN, a superstation picked up by more than 30 million cable TV subscribers nationwide, are both owned by the Tribune Company. The Atlanta Braves and TBS, a larger superstation, are owned by the Turner Broadcasting System.
Mr. Noll, the Stanford economist, said, "The Cubs' local broadcasting revenue is one-third to one-half than if you had a competitive bidding for them."
Although Mr. Turner paid major league baseball about $15 million in 1993 because TBS has become a national carrier, it pays the Braves, its corporate cousin, less than $10 million for its local rights. WGN is believed to pay the Cubs about $6 million.
"Whatever the Braves are getting from TBS is minuscule compared to what TBS means to Turner's empire," said Bryan Burns, president of the Paragon Alliance, a sports TV consultant.
In St. Louis, the Cardinals' owner, Anheuser-Busch, has a separate corporation, Civic Center Properties, which records all the team's parking and concession revenues. Until recently, Mr. Noll said, Anheuser-Busch's financial reports never reflected those revenues. Now the brewery provides unaudited figures to baseball. "It's not that no one knew how much they got in parking and concessions, and they've been open that this is how they did their finances," Mr. Noll said. "The nefariousness comes from Bud Selig saying teams are losing money, knowing full well there are good reasons for that. To their credit, the Cardinals have never said they're in desperate straits."
 
Outlook
Teams Encouraged To Stay Put
 The effects of more generous revenue sharing in baseball are uncertain. Money may buy proven talent in ballplayers, but it doesn't necessarily translate into a winning club. The Expos illustrate that point, in reverse: with an $18.8 million payroll, baseball's second-lowest, they had the best record before the strike.
The more profitable clubs are likely to continue to have qualms about expanded revenue sharing -- especially without a salary cap -- because it will not only cut into their cash but could also eventually reduce their resale value.
But for less-profitable teams, revenue sharing should reduce the need to move to cities that promise a better financial picture. Not that teams are free to move wherever they want. Under baseball's exemption from antitrust law, owners control not only the creation of new franchises but also the movement of existing teams.
Baseball wants its teams to stay put even if the policy appears to ignore economics. The owners do not want to antagonize fans of current teams and risk igniting a political reaction that could lead to a review of their antitrust status. Also, they want to reserve attractive new cities for expansion teams that would have to pay hefty franchise fees to the owners to buy into baseball.
The recent experience of the San Francisco Giants demonstrates how firmly the owners seek to control the culture and finances of baseball.
In 1992, Bob Lurie was forced by his fellow owners to accept an 11th-hour offer of $100 million from local interests to buy the Giants rather than a $115 million bid by investors who wanted to move the team to a stadium in Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla.
Tampa-St. Petersburg remains a likely market for expansion -- or for a struggling team seeking new life.

HEADLINE: Used American Jeans Power A Thriving Industry Abroad

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
When the giant flea market outside the Rose Bowl opens at dawn, bargain hunters from Thailand and Japan are the first on the field. Pockets bulging with wads of $100 bills and carting big empty suitcases strapped to luggage dollies, they load up on American artifacts like weathered leather jackets and rock-and-roll memorabilia.
But the real quarry is used jeans -- especially Levis -- which can fetch as much as several thousand dollars back home. 
 As another generation of teen-agers the world over embraces American culture, secondhand jeans have become status symbols. A cottage industry, a thriving underground economy, has sprouted west of the Mississippi to buy, wash and repair used Levis for resale in countries from Finland to Australia.
No one knows for sure how many pairs are being shipped abroad. Precisely how much profit is made is also a mystery because dealers are preternaturally closed-mouthed about this all-cash business, as much to keep their competition from rooting out their precious sources of supply as, in some cases, to stay clear of the Internal Revenue Service.
What the dealers do say is that a vintage pair of jeans -- like Levis from the 1950's and 60's -- can bring $3,000 or more abroad, although most of the jeans they sell there bring less than $100.
All in all, millions of pairs of used jeans are changing hands each year, worth tens, even hundreds, of millions of dollars at retail. And the opening of new markets like Vietnam and China will only add to the demand.
It is a business almost as secretive as the drug trade, and nearly as splintered. But on the second Sunday of every month, outside the Rose Bowl, everyone who is anyone in this exclusive circle, grown to perhaps 100 people from a handful a few years ago, shows up to buy and sell used jeans by the bale and to bargain for the vintage pieces.
On a recent Sunday, Max Shapiro, a San Francisco dealer, was having what he called an uncharacteristically slow day. His biggest sale was a pair of Levis from the 60's that brought $150, meager compared with the $3,300 he made on one sale another day.
Nat and Lucky Wongchaiwat, a brother-sister team from Thailand, frequently hunt here. In their early 20's, they make a monthly pilgrimage for 10,000 pairs for their store in Bangkok. Recently, they placed a big order at Mr. Shapiro's warehouse in San Francisco. At the Rose Bowl, they look for vintage pairs and new sources of jeans.
Japan is still the biggest customer for used jeans, though the boom there has cooled somewhat. But even Thailand, a much less prosperous nation, has become a major importer, buying about 100,000 pairs a month, some dealers say.
"They can buy jeans made in Hong Kong for $6 but would rather have 501's for $100," said Val Marco, a Los Angeles dealer who left his job as a vice president at a Silicon Valley robotics company to sell jeans after repeatedly getting offers for his Levis on business trips abroad.
 
A One-by-One Search
 Dealers collect used jeans one by one at flea markets, garage sales and thrift stores. They scour small towns and farm communities like Lubbock, Tex., and Cody, Wyo., advertising in local papers that they will pay 50 cents to $15 a pair.
On the appointed day they pull into town and do business out of tents or the backs of tractor-trailers. They sort their purchases by quality and send them to laundries, some of which clean nothing but used jeans, and then on to shops that patch and mend them.
They sell some jeans through trendy vintage-clothing, jeans and urban-cowboy stores. Encouraged by the grunge, retro and recycling movements, dress-down days at the office and perhaps even the casual style of the Democratic White House, these stores abound on the West Coast.
The bulk of the market, however, is abroad. It doubtless helps that most used jeans are cheaper than new Levis, which cost $80 to $100 overseas, compared with about $35 here. But the market really exists, both sellers and buyers agree, because foreign youth is obsessed with the American past. Used Air Jordan athletic shoes from the 1980's, sweaty and soiled, can sell for $800 or more in Japan. Old Pendleton shirts go for $40 in Tokyo.
 
Cool and Rugged
 But nothing says Made in America louder than jeans, especially the denim 501's with the button fly that Levi Strauss & Company has made since 1873. Worn to a softness that takes five years to achieve, used 501's are as cool as James Dean and as rugged as the Wild West.
Kazuhiko Hanzawa, a sales clerk at Marvin's, a used-jeans and sneakers store in the Harajuka district of Tokyo, says 501's are the most popular brand sought by teen-age buyers. Prices at the store range from 10,000 to 100,000 yen, or about $100 to $1,000.
Retail prices vary depending on the age, condition and country. "Grade A" 501's -- those without holes or stains -- may fetch $40 to $50, while lower-quality Grade B's go for about $20. Vintage 501's are among the most prized; predating 1983 and known as Red Lines, they are hand cut from a single piece of fabric whose red-selvage edge is the inseam. They typically retail abroad for $70 or more.
 
A Tightening Supply
 But the highest prices are commanded by a fuller-cut and wider-legged Levis design popular in the 1950's and 60's. The jeans are called Big E's, for the "E" used until 1971 in the logo on the distinctive tiny red Levi tag. They typically bring $500 to $2,000 in Japan.
Prices of all used jeans have jumped as supplies have tightened.
"I could easily sell 40,000 pair a month if I could find them," said Peter Anestos of Pocatello, Idaho, who became a dealer four years ago after his business as a steel mill equipment dismantler fell apart. "When I started, I was getting $10 to $13, wholesale, for the best 501's and now I'm getting $25. Of course, the price I pay for jeans has also doubled."
Many people in the business estimate there are 30 to 50 big dealers, who may ship 10,000 pairs a month, with a few handling double or triple that volume. Some are so aggressive that they try to corner the market in certain states. Most dealers are on the West Coast because the more valuable button-fly 501's are prevalent there. (Easterners tend to prefer the zipper fly because it doesn't let in cold air.)
No one believes the rage in used jeans has hurt Levi Strauss, the biggest marketer of jeans in the world, whose sales of Levis, estimated at $4.8 billion last year, dwarfs the used-jeans market. In fact, Levi itself has responded to the vintage wave. Last year it introduced, both here and abroad, 501's with a "broken in" finish achieved by a combination of stone washing and sand blasting.
"It's probably the second- or third-most-popular finish after stone-washed and after black," said Susan Shepherd, manager of the Original Levis Store, opposite Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, where many shoppers are foreigners. "People definitely want that look."
Even high-fashion designers like Ralph Lauren have recognized the trend. The designer introduced a line last year called RRL to duplicate the quality and construction of hard-to-find vintage pieces like old leather jackets, untailored tweed coats and worn and weathered jeans. It took a year to develop the washing technology to make the worn look possible.
Levi has also come out with something for vintage lovers like the singer Bryan Adams, one of the biggest Levis collectors in the world. Last year, the company reissued the "Big E's" design. Called "Capital E's," the jeans sell for $100 a pair.
 
Limited Number Sold

No one expects the Capital E's to cut into sales of used jeans. For one thing, Levi is selling only a limited quantity (it will not say how many). For another, the new denim cannot compare with the original nubbier, inkier fabric, which fades to the most desirable deep blue. Petrochemical-based indigo dyes were reformulated during the oil crisis of the 1970's, and Levi Strauss changed fabrics in the 1980's, when it switched from hand cutting of fabric to jigsaw cutting to improve efficiencies.
In any case, used-jean dealers are more worried about their smaller rivals. Competition in the last year has driven a few dealers to search for jeans in cities as well as in the country by setting up networks of collection sites like pawn shops, video stores and dry cleaners that buy jeans from their patrons for a cut of the revenue.
Mr. Shapiro has signed up 90 drop points in California and 20 in Texas for Green for Jeans, the used-jeans company in Point Richmond, Calif., that his brother Bruce started. The company has an additional 15 jeans collection sites in Missouri, and next month it will open a warehouse in Osaka to be closer to buyers.
Like many dealers, the Shapiros have also branched into new lines, like Air Jordans and Pendleton shirts.
 
Looking for Trends
 Mr. Marco says rock-and-roll clothes from the 1960's and 70's are also hot. He watches vintage-savvy designers like Ralph Lauren for the latest trend. Though Mr. Lauren will not talk about his shopping habits, Mr. Marco has heard that he is buying sweatshirts from the early 1900's. "He'll copy them and sell them this fall," Mr. Marco predicts.
Still, for dealers like Mr. Marco, nothing compares with the romance, history and mystery of old jeans.
"I bought 40 pieces from the Great Depression a few weeks back from a lady in Oklahoma who had boxes of her mother's clothes in the garage," he said. "She had the whole family's jeans and they must have had six or seven kids. You could see how much that family suffered from their jeans, how the grandma had sewed on the patches. One pair had 100 patches."

HEADLINE: Fund Set Up To Help City With Projects

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In an unusual effort to enlist big business in the economic development of New York City, a prominent group of executives is trying to raise $100 million in private funds to invest in such diverse projects as a new Central Park restaurant, expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and keeping the Yankees in the Bronx.
The New York City Partnership, whose members include the top executives of more than 150 of the city's largest companies, said those companies and many wealthy individuals would be asked to donate $1 million each to the fund, which would be operated with no intent to turn a profit. 
 Partnership officials said that the campaign to create an investment fund was approved by the group's board of directors on Wednesday and that the group would begin seeking contributions next month.
The idea for the fund was hatched in early 1993 by Henry R. Kravis, the Wall Street financier and leveraged-buyout specialist, who is a member of the Partnership and has been appointed chairman of the fund's board. In an interview yesterday, he said he conceived of the fund as a vehicle for "pulling together" the city's corporate leaders and "emulating what has been done in other cities," including Atlanta, Minneapolis and Tulsa, Okla.
 
Selecting of Projects
 No projects have been selected, and Mr. Kravis said the fund's board, which would select the projects to be financed, would include Partnership members from both corporations and the world of cultural and educational institutions. Partnership officials, who have been privately preparing their campaign for months, agreed to discuss it after a copy of their board's descriptive material was obtained on Friday by The New York Times.
Jerry I. Speyer, a Manhattan real-estate developer and chairman of the Partnership, said $15 million had already been committed in the first 15 "cold calls" -- contacts made without any advance preparation -- to members of the group last week.
In documents circulated among the Partnership's board members last week, the group said the fund was intended to "serve as a vehicle to rally the city's private sector" and generate money for public improvements "as a civic initiative rather than a money-making venture."
Mr. Speyer said the fund would not finance any project completely but would provide the "front money" to pay for such things as environmental studies, architectural work, reviews by neighborhood groups and other work that often bogs down large developments and public improvements.
The investments would come largely through short-term loans or loan guarantees, he said, in the hope that those would lead to more financing from other sources. Once loans are paid back, the money would be recycled into other projects.
Mr. Speyer, who is the president of Tishman Speyer Properties, which has built large office buildings in several American and European cities, said the goal was to invest in "large, high impact" projects that the Partnership believes would be of particular benefit to New York City.
Projects that would warrant consideration might include an addition to the Javits Convention Center, loan guarantees necessary to bring political conventions to the city, a new transit hub in the Sunnyside Yards in Queens, a restaurant at the north end of Central Park and neighborhood improvements around Yankee Stadium, Partnership officials said.
They said the Partnership might also consider helping finance a new building to house the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.
Final plans for the fund have been worked out in recent months by a team that included two economic-development authorities who had been members of the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins -- Barry F. Sullivan, the former Deputy Mayor for Finance, who is now president of the Partnership, and Carl Wiesbrod, formerly head of the city's Economic Development Corporation, who worked on plans for the investment fund as a consultant.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who had been told of the broad outline of the Partnership's plan months ago, was informed of the details on Friday. In an interview, he said raising $100 million "is certainly viable in the weathiest city in the world."
Even if the fund-raising target is not reached, he said, the Partnership's effort would benefit New York. "It is evidence of a very powerful new synergism between the private sector and government," he said.
 
'A Great Idea'
 At City Hall, economic aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani were informed of the plan for the first time on Friday. "We think it's a great idea," said Cristyne F. Lategano, a spokeswoman for the Mayor. "This is the kind of thing necessary to jump-start the economy."
Mr. Sullivan said the campaign to enlist business support for public projects was in some ways similar to the marshaling of corporate support that occurred in the mid-1970's, when the city was close to bankruptcy. Several Wall Street executives acted as volunteer consultants, and many landlords volunteered to pay their real-estate taxes in advance.
The difference now, he said, "is that we are not in a crisis."
"This is a vote of confidence in the city," he said. "Business people feel good about Mayor Giuliani's effort to downsize government, and we are offering a flip side to that, an effort to create jobs and build the economy."
Although Mr. Kravis said his idea for the fund sprang from the success of economic-development efforts in some other cities, Partnership officials said they knew of no other fund like the one the Partnership envisions for New York. The closest parallel is in Cleveland, where a business group called Cleveland Tomorrow has raised $50 million for projects, including a new sports complex for that city's professional baseball and basketball teams.
But unlike the fund planned by the Partnership, the one in Cleveland makes long-term loans to developers at interest rates that will bring in a profit. "We absolutely try to make as much money as possible," said Joe Roman, executive director of Cleveland Tomorrow.
Some details of how the Partnership's fund will be set up -- whether it is entirely a nonprofit corporation or includes a profit-making limited partnership -- remain to be worked out, Mr. Weisbrod said.
But Mr. Speyer said the intent was not complicated: each contributor of $1 million would be committed to the fund for 15 years and then could only expect to get $1 million back, plus enough to account for inflation. "The return will be psychic," he said.
Creation of the fund, which is to be called the New York Investment Partnership, would not be the first project by the Partnership that sets it apart from most big-city business groups. Formed in 1978 as an adjunct to the city's Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Partnership has for years sponsored the city's largest summer-jobs program for young people and, through a housing-development arm, has had more than 9,000 new homes constructed for low- and moderate-income families.
 
Behind-the-Scenes Role
 The Partnership's members include a who's who of the city's corporate elite, including the board chairmen of Morgan Stanley, American Express, Philip Morris, Chase Manhattan, NBC, Grey Advertising, Price Waterhouse, Liz Claiborne and Mitsubishi International, as well as top officials of universities, museums and civic groups.
The group has also played a behind-the-scenes role in trying to persuade companies to remain and expand in New York City, providing a fraternity of corporate movers and shakers who are not reluctant to twist the arms of any of their colleagues who are about to stray.
Mr. Speyer suggested that the same spirit would apply to the Partnership's fund-raising effort.
"I wouldn't say that our members are absolutely obligated to participate," he said. "Let's just say I'd be very surprised if they don't."

International

HEADLINE: New Tax Hits Stocks In Israel

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The Israeli stock market plummeted nearly 10 percent today, as jittery investors were given the first chance to react to a Government decision last week to impose a capital gains tax on stock profits.
The benchmark Mishtanim index fell 18.22 points, or 9.93 percent, to 165.18, and analysts expect further declines Monday morning. 
 The market erupted into pandemonium early as sellers unloaded stocks. Tel Aviv Stock Exchange officials said trading started with sell orders of two billion shekels, or $660 million.
Market officials, for the first time in the exchange's 40-year-history, lifted a 10 percent limit on the fluctuation of share prices within a single day. The market's usual closing time was also extended by four hours. Losses on individual share prices ranged from 10 to 20 percent.
 
A Surprise for the Market
 Ninety minutes into trading, the Government tried to soften the effects of the new tax, allowing stock profits to be offset against losses. But brokers said the change had little effect on the market.
"If every sale that was profitable was taxed a flat 10 percent, regardless of other losses, your grand total at the end of the day could be a big loss," said Eddy Shalev, the director of the Tel Aviv office of Oscar Gruss & Son, the largest dealer of Israeli stocks in the United States. "You would end up not with a 10 percent real tax, but a much higher tax."
The market was taken by surprise on Tuesday when the Government announced that it would impose a 10 percent tax on stock profits beginning Jan. 1. The Government then closed the market until today.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said in June 1993 that he would not impose a capital gains tax. But on Monday, Israel announced a higher-than-expected rise of 1.1 percent in inflation for July. The figure brought the annual inflation rate to 13.5 percent, well above the official forecast of 8 percent. Mr. Rabin, treasury officials said, was persuaded to adopt the tax in hopes of curbing inflation.
"When speaking of a Prime Minister and Finance Minister, don't expect them to tell the whole truth when speaking of a devaluation or when speaking of a new taxation policy," Mr. Rabin said after the announcement last week.
Finance Minister Avraham Shohat said: "This temporary instability will finally result in a much more stable stock market. To make big changes, and to be part of the outside world, we must, like other countries, impose a capital gains tax."
The opposition Likud party, which opposes the measure, called today for a special session of the Parliament to debate the tax, which, in its initial form, is expected to raise about $167 million a year.
"This is total chaos," said Binyamin Netanyahu, the head of Likud. "It is not the way to build an economy."
Treasury officials said today, after the amendment to the tax, that investors could choose between options when purchasing stocks. The first option will allow investors to pay a flat 10 percent on any profits. The second option will allow investors to make any losses tax deductible, but subject any profits made in the market to a 20 to 25 percent tax.
 
Only Limited Orders
 The capital gains tax comes as other taxes, such as import taxes on items like computers as well as purchase taxes on housing, have been lowered. Taxing share profits, officials said, will bring in revenues that will permit the Government to cut other taxes, like import duties on raw materials, that have fueled rising retail prices.
"I hope this in-between stage is short," said Jakov Frenkel, the governor of Israel's Central Bank. "The main reason for taxing capital gains was to introduce reason and order into the economy and to cut other taxes that have a much more destructive effect on the public."
The stock exchange, to prevent a steeper decline, only permitted limit orders, thus making it impossible to access the full impact of the new law. Heavy losses, at least early in the day, are expected Monday when the market, will, for the first time, allow market orders.
The tax is seen by many brokers as a severe blow to Israel's mutual fund companies.
 
Sales to Pension Funds
 "This is very bad for mutual funds because it will make it unwise for institutional investors, such as pension funds or insurance companies, to invest in mutual funds," Mr Shalev said. "If the mutual fund companies are forced to implement a 10 percent tax on the profits of each sale, corporations will, in essence, be taxed twice.
"It will also be unwise for pension funds to invest in mutual funds in the stock exchange because pension funds are totally exempt for any taxes," he said, "even with the new law. It will be better for them to invest directly in the stock exchange."
Once stocks dip low enough, investors expect the pension funds to step in and begin to buy. This could happen, brokers said, as early as Monday afternoon.
The new tax is also expected to slow foreign investment in Israel's stock market. In the last few months, brokers estimate that the market attracted between $200 million and $300 million, most from Britain and the United States. Israel, given the peace prospects, has been touted by many brokers as an emerging market.
"It will be very difficult for institutions in America to explain the primitive tax scheme to investors," said Mr. Shalev. "American taxes take into consideration losses, even from previous years. This will not be the case here."
Israel's stock market has a capitalization of about $35 billion. The Mishtanim index involves 99 of the most-traded stocks out of a total of about 700 companies are traded. The market has fallen about 25 percent since the end of the year.
A middle-aged coule from Lod with five children were among the small investors despondent after today's trading. The wife, who like her husband insisted on anonymity, said that all year "the bank kept telling us not to sell, so we didn't sell."
"Everyday our stocks went down," she said. "Now we have lost 60 percent of our savings."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brokers in the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange look for buyers as stocks fell 10 percent yesterday. It was the first time the market had been open since the Government said on Tuesday that it would tax stock profits. (Rina Castelnuovo for the New York Times) (pg. D2)
