HEADLINE: Haiti Rulers Hold Relief Fuel, Endangering Lives

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The mothers and fathers of half-starved children stand over their beds in the tuberculosis ward at Grace Children's Hospital and mumble prayers for mercy, miracles and diesel fuel.
The patients are kept alive by medicine that must be chilled in refrigerators, which are powered mostly by generators in a country where electrical power winks in and out like fireflies. Now the level of care at this charity hospital, like much of the medical care and feeding of Haiti's poor, is being threatened by the Government's refusal to release fuel donated by the United States and other nations hoping to insure that relief efforts continue. 
 Some hospitals, unable to use their generators because the fuel was held back, have already been forced to throw out crucial medical supplies that became ruined during long power blackouts. Relief workers say most of Haiti's free clinics, water-pumping stations, food distribution centers and almost all relief efforts will eventually cease if the military Government does not release the fuel.
More than 500,000 gallons in 55-gallon drums -- mostly diesel fuel and gasoline -- have been stored in Port-au-Prince since the shipments began arriving this year while relief organizations used up the last of their reserves, said Ross Mountain, the relief coordinator in Haiti for the United Nations.
 
Fuel Is Called Vital
 "The fuel program is the essential part of the total operation," Mr. Mountain said. "It is vital to the provision of water in and outside Port-au-Prince, the transportation of food, the function of hospitals, the transportation of medical supplies, and essential to the lives of millions of Haitians."
Without that fuel, millions of Haiti's poor in the countryside will almost certainly endure more hardship because they depend on food provided by aid groups. People who depend on hospitals and medicines in the cities and all over Haiti will suffer and die, say relief workers who did not want to be identified for fear of angering the Haitian Government.
The Government provides little or no aid, so the welfare of many of its 7 million people depends on outsiders. The feeding and care of Haitians by international relief operations has continued even as the embargo squeezes the economy and as threats of an invasion by the United States deepen tension.
Responding to the crisis, Haitian officials said on Friday that the Government, which has not officially seized the fuel, understood the difference between politics and aid.
"We remain hopeful that the authorities understand the severity of the situation," Mr. Mountain said. "I remain optimistic."
But to the people who depend on that fuel for the medical treatment of their children, the distinction between "seized" and "held" has little meaning.
During visiting hours last week at the hospital, Dieu Bon Desama stood over his 7-month-old son, Abdiass, and watched him struggle to breathe. The hospital treats 300 children every day, children whose parents cannot afford to pay for the care.
There are not enough cribs to go around in the hospital, so some children are tied with strips of cloth to narrow beds to keep them from falling off the side. Abdiass is so thin that his eyes seem huge in his narrow face, but his father said that he was getting better and that the hospital had saved him.
"If the hospital cannot work," he said, motioning down the row of beds, "then they have no future."
 
Looking for Miracles
 Julio Valle, who is 6, has been told by his father, Bernilio Valle, that the doctors and nurses will take care of him, if they can work miracles.
"But without fuel?" said Dr. Marie Renee Lubin Francisque, the hospital's director. She shakes her head.
The hospital's X-ray machines use an enormous amount of power, but the great concern here is for the medicine. Drugs like insulin and anesthetics have already started to disappear because the fuel shortage has limited the refrigeration need to store them.
Countless other services depend on the fuel, including the most crucial one: food. There is plenty of food in Haiti, relief workers said, but not enough fuel for the trucks that would normally be hauling food all across the country.
CARE, which feeds 590,000 Haitians every day, said it had enough fuel to continue operations until Sept. 3. After that, said Chris Sykes, a spokesman, the resourceful Haitian people will probably find some other way to feed themselves for a few days.
But in the long term, Mr. Sikes said, malnutrition and the diseases that go along with it will begin to settle in. Relief centers take time to set up, he said, and many relief workers could see their apparatus for feeding the poor fall apart if the trucks do not come.
Government officials have said they are waiting only for the proper paper work to come through for arranging the distribution of the fuel. But some relief workers, speaking on the condition that their names not be used, said the Government was playing games. If they really wanted the fuel to be released, the relief workers said, it would already be on its way to the poor.
The embargo, imposed on Haiti to punish the military and their supporters, was supposed to have exempted the delivery of relief supplies so the country's poor would not have to absorb the penalties.
The 500,000 gallons of fuel was intended to carry relief organizations through September and October. Relief workers, afraid of angering the Haitian military, do not openly accuse it of hoarding the fuel.
The Government has said it has fuel reserves to carry it through February 1996, when the term of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, expires.
 
Gasoline Very Costly
 On the streets, it can cost as much as $250 to fill a tank with relatively clean gasoline -- much of what is sold in jugs on the street is part water and filled with debris -- and more and more people are walking. The cost of riding in a taxi has more than doubled. Even the rich are complaining.
Some relief workers say the Government is hurting itself by refusing to release the fuel on time.
"People who are hungry are angry," a worker said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The parents of children in the Grace Hospital are not surprised that the fuel needed to run the country's relief organizations is running out. They expect things like this to happen to them.
"We are poor," Mr. Desama said. "It is only the poor children who die."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Will Rising Prices of Cars Imperil Detroit's Recovery?

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation recently rolled out a new compact sedan, the Cirrus, aimed at value-conscious import buyers. Chrysler promises that the car will offer plenty for the money, which means it better offer an awful lot: The base price is an eye-popping $17,970.
Perhaps the most astonishing thing about the price is that it makes the Cirrus one of the cheapest competitors in its segment, which includes the Honda Accord and Nissan Altima. 
 This raises important questions for investors in auto stocks: Are cars becoming too expensive, particularly with interest rates on the rise as the 1995 model-year prices are announced? And will this halt the industry's recovery?
The average car today does take a bigger bite of the average worker's wallet than in the past. In 1993, the average car purchase consumed 25.9 weeks' pay for someone with the median family income of $36,764, compared with 22.5 weeks in 1983 and 17.5 weeks in 1973.
Auto executives typically argue that much of the increase is a result of safety and emissions regulations. Indeed, Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, said in a recent interview that the company was considering adding a line to a car's sticker stating how much of the price is attributable to government regulations.
The rest of the increase, the executive said, was driven by customer demand. Don Hilty, the chief economist of Chrysler, said that a "constant car" -- a new car built to 1966 specifications -- would use up only 12.4 weeks of pay. Emissions and safety regulations, he said, add 4.8 weeks to that. Bringing the total to 25.9 weeks are 8.7 weeks' worth of options, like air-conditioning, that customers want.
"The cost hasn't gone up," Mr. Hilty said. "The outlay has gone up. People are buying steak instead of hamburger."
But do so many customers really want steak, or are the auto makers pushing it down their throats?
Some analysts said that auto makers were limiting customer choice by making more equipment standard so that they could raise prices. Added features like anti-lock brakes and compact-disk players fatten profit margins. "This upscaling of product really reflects a quest for profit," rather than a pure response to customer demand, said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an auto consulting firm in Rutherford, N. J.
The tendency is masked by the way auto makers announce price increases. The auto makers compare prices on a "comparably equipped basis," meaning they factor out the prices of optional equipment on the old model that was made standard on the new one. That tactic has allowed many auto makers to say that their price increases have trailed the Consumer Price Index for years.
For example, because the 1995 Chevrolet Blazer sport-utility vehicle comes with standard air-conditioning, AM-FM radio and other features, General Motors says it costs only 2 percent more than the less-well-equipped 1994 model it replaces.
But to a customer, the price of the basic two-door Blazer has jumped 7.8 percent over the price at the end of the 1994 model year, to $18,630.
Similarly, an analysis by Ms. Jacobs shows the price of a 1995 Ford Taurus GL rose 8.3 percent over the final 1994 price, to $17,585, while the price of a Mitsubishi Eclipse coupe jumped 17.8 percent, to $15,059.
Mr. Hilty of Chrysler said that if customers wanted stripped-down cars with fewer options, an auto maker would have exploited that opportunity. Further, while Chrysler's Cirrus comes fully loaded -- with power windows and locks and even remote keyless entry -- Chrysler plans to offer simpler Dodge and Plymouth versions in 1995 that could sell for less than $14,000.
Other auto analysts agreed that stripped versions of cars do not sell, adding that if customers really need cheap new cars, they can find them. "You can buy a stripped Neon," said Ronald A. Glantz, auto industry analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, referring to a Chrysler subcompact. "It's a damn good car, and it's 9,000 bucks."
But the auto makers are sacrificing some sales, Ms. Jacobs said. "Those market opportunities at the lower end of the market are being siphoned off elsewhere -- to the used-car market," she said.
Many auto analysts have argued that the strength of the yen, which has drive up the cost of Japanese goods in the United States, has provided the Big Three with an umbrella for their price increases. But the true umbrella permitting rising prices is leasing. The lower monthly payments required by leasing effectively cut a car's price by 35 to 40 percent, said Art Spinella, vice president and general manager of CNW Marketing/ Research in Bandon, Ore.
Without leasing, Mr. Spinella said, this recovery would barely have occurred. "Last year's increase was almost exclusively because of leasing," he said. "It's equally important this year." Without leasing bringing cash-strapped customers into the market, more than one million cars and trucks out of a 13.9 million market would have gone unsold in 1993, according to CNW's research. In 1994, Mr. Spinella said, that figure is likely to reach 1.4 million.
In the short term, then, investors concerned that rising prices could choke off sales can take comfort from most auto makers' enthusiasm for leasing. Long term, however, leasing poses enormous risks to the companies, which must manage the huge flow of well-maintained off-lease vehicles into the used-car market. Those cars and trucks could drag down used-car prices and present a more affordable alternative to those customers willing to settle for hamburger.

HEADLINE: Texas Challenger Uses Thick Skin and a Smile

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Tex., Aug. 21

 BODY:
George W. Bush did not like it when Ann W. Richards joked to the nation six years ago that his father was "born with a silver foot in his mouth." And he certainly did not like it when Ms. Richards, on the campaign trail the other evening, described him as "some jerk" who was running against her for governor.
But don't look for the 48-year-old Mr. Bush, the Republican nominee, to respond in kind to the tart-tongued Ms. Richards. As he travels around the state, Mr. Bush freely concedes that the incumbent Governor is "an interesting, entertaining person," if, well, a tad abrasive sometimes. 
 "I don't have to erode her likability," Mr. Bush explained the other day on a swing through this refinery town. "I have to erode her electability."
Or, as he later put it even more succinctly, he has been trying to follow some advice from his parents, including a father who knows something about the politics of coming off as a nice guy. "Kill her with kindness," the younger Mr. Bush explained with a grin.
 
Inside Baseball
 It is an uphill battle for the son of the former President, making only his second bid for elective office after losing a Congressional race in West Texas 16 years ago. And his campaign for the highest office in the nation's second-largest state has had its bumpy spots, the latest being, of all things, the baseball strike.
As the managing partner of the Texas Rangers, Mr. Bush's political dream was a World Series starting 17 days before the election and featuring his team, which was first in its division when the strike began, although it was playing below .500 ball. Now he has the makings of a political nightmare on his hands. At some campaign stops, the first question is about the strike.
Nonetheless, Mr. Bush gamely insists that the voters will have good government, educational change and tougher crime measures on their minds, not baseball, when they vote in November. And polls suggest he is well within striking distance of Ms. Richards, a first-term Democrat, with many voters only just beginning to focus on the campaign anyway.
Moreover, he may be buoyed by the political cross-currents in Texas, which is increasingly Republican, last year having sent two Republican senators to Washington for the first time since Reconstruction. It is a state where the elder George Bush is still popular and Bill Clinton is not. And it has an irascible electorate that has not re-elected an incumbent governor in two decades.
Still, the methodical Mr. Bush faces questions about whether he can handle the mayhem of a big campaign down the home stretch this fall, including a likely series of debates with the quick-witted Ms. Richards.
Mr. Bush, facing a dilemma not unlike the one that dogged his father in the 1992 Presidential campaign, is also under increasing pressure from Christian conservatives to take a firm stand on abortion, school prayer and other issues.
The religious right all but took over the state party apparatus at the Republican convention in Fort Worth earlier this summer and produced a party platform that in many respects Mr. Bush has either disavowed or ignored. The conservatives are hardly likely to flock to Ms. Richards, but the degree to which they will actively support Mr. Bush, or to which such support might drive moderates to Ms. Richards, remains to be seen.
And as even Mr. Bush admits, Ms. Richards is generally well liked. One recent set of statewide surveys by Political/Media Research Inc., a national polling concern, suggested that Ms. Richards's favorable rating of 54 percent was well above those of other incumbent governors facing major challenges this fall in big states like California, Florida and New York.
 
Welfare, Schools and Crime
 The state, having taken its worst economic dive in the oil bust of the 1980's, weathered the more recent economic downturn better than either the East or West Coast. Today its economy is far more diversified than it was a decade ago, and many economists point to major growth in its biggest cities and along its 1,200-mile Mexican border because of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
And so the question becomes whether Mr. Bush can get to the Governor's Mansion in Austin by earnestly hammering away at his major campaign themes, which he repeatedly says arise from failures in Ms. Richards's leadership: welfare change, increased autonomy and state financing for local school districts and a crackdown on crime, especially juvenile crime in light of a series of murders committed by young people in the last year.
At a minimum, Mr. Bush's approach has so far provided Texas with a markedly different contest from the one that propelled Ms. Richards to office four years ago.
That was a bitter, tumultuous spectacle of a campaign, in which Ms. Richards's Republican opponent, a West Texas oilman named Clayton Williams, promised supporters he would "head her and hoof her and drag her through the dirt" in a debate. Ms. Richards skillfully took advantage of a series of gaffes by Mr. Williams, including a joke about rape, and when he refused to shake her hand in front of television cameras, she charmed voters with a memorable put-down in a demure, old-girl twang, "Well, I'm sorry you feel that way about it, Clayton."
But there will be none of that hostility in this campaign, Mr. Bush promises, nor will he will try to tar Ms. Richards, as did her primary opponent four years ago, with allegations of illegal drug use to which she refused to respond.
In fact, Mr. Bush said he would not have any response to questions about drug use in his own past. "Maybe I did, maybe I didn't," he told The Houston Chronicle in May. "How I behaved as an irresponsible youth is irrelevant to this campaign."
Another issue that emerged in the rancorous 1990 campaign was past alcohol use, which has also emerged this time, but only as an intriguing illustration of style differences between the two candidates when discussing the matter.
Like Ms. Richards, Mr. Bush admits to drinking too much in past years; unlike Ms. Richards, a fervent supporter of the 12-step approach who has publicly talked about her recovery from alcoholism, Mr. Bush simply says he woke up with a hangover after his 40th birthday and decided to quit drinking, which he did.
 
Stiff, but Reaching Out
 On the campaign trail, Mr. Bush is still widely perceived as a bit stiff in stump speeches, certainly when compared with Ms. Richards, but he appears at ease in smaller groups, as in an appearance at Adella Young Elementary School here in this Houston suburb the other day.
With a group of parents and teachers, he wasted no time launching into an animated and well-received discussion of his plan to give school districts greater autonomy.
And he had no trouble attracting a crowd of very young students, two of whom called him "George Washington," as he read the children's book "The Very Quiet Cricket."
Texas reporters following him the other day were certainly curious about Ms. Richards's remarks to a group of teachers in Texarkana a few days before. "You just work like a dog, do well," she said, "and all of a sudden, you've got some jerk who's running for public office telling everybody it's all a sham and it isn't real. And he doesn't give you credit for doing your job."
But Mr. Bush held back. "The last time I was called a jerk was at Sam Houston Elementary School in Midland, Tex.," he said. "I'm not going to call the Governor names. I'm going to elevate this debate to a level where Texans want it."
Bill Miller, a political consultant in Austin who has worked for candidates from both parties and who is not involved in this campaign, said that Mr. Bush was smart not to engage Ms. Richards on a personal level. "People like her sauciness and her wit," said Mr. Miller. "But he's out there saying, 'I'm closer philosophically to what you want in a governor.' "
Some recent statewide polls have given Ms. Richards a lead of eight percentage points or more, but others have suggested the race to be a statistical dead heat. Early indications of a close race were discounted by pollsters' caveats that many voters might be confusing Mr. Bush with his father; but even as he is increasingly recognized on his own, the younger Mr. Bush has kept pace.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George W. Bush campaigns for governor in San Antonio. (Craig Stafford for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Travel Agents, a Tough Life

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Bobbie Sylvester had been a home economics teacher in Salt Lake City until she decided to become a travel agent 20 years ago. "My best day as a home economics teacher wasn't as good as my worst day as a travel agent," she used to boast.
But now, with people and businesses pinching their travel pennies and with a big decline in the percentage of agency revenue from airline commissions -- the agents' traditional bread and butter -- hundreds, perhaps thousands, of the nation's 32,500 travel agencies are struggling to survive. 
 "It's tougher than ever," said Ms. Sylvester, president of the Rocky Mountain chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents. "What kills you is writing $59 tickets to Boise, because you don't make any money."
 
Earnings Are Less
 Travel agents earn a commission of about 10 percent on every airline ticket they sell. But with the growth of discount airlines and fare wars, that 10 percent is not as much as it used to be. In 1992, airline tickets accounted for 61 percent of travel agency revenues. Now it is thought to be closer to 50 percent and is expected to shrink further.
Much to the furor of some travel agents, some of their services are being taken over by machines. A Florida company, for example, has installed video kiosks in more than 800 pharmacies to help travelers.
And another company says that within a year, it will place 1,000 machines in supermarkets where travelers can pick up tickets.
 
 
The Commission Question
 Many travel agents think they have been chosen as sacrificial lambs as airlines and other companies try to cut costs, even though agencies sell more than 80 percent of all airline tickets. Agents say the airlines have dropped hints that they intend to cut commissions by as much as one-fourth. And they point to a recent move by almost 20 companies, including the General Motors Corporation and the Whirlpool Corporation, to seek lower fares from airlines. Under the proposal, the companies would forfeit frequent-flier miles and would buy tickets through a single clearinghouse, instead of through traditional travel agencies.
Four large travel agencies, including the Carlson Travel Network and US Travel, earned less in air fare commissions last year than in 1992, according to estimates by Travel Weekly magazine. Four other giant agencies, including the 1,500 company-owned properties of American Express, barely exceeded 1992's air sales. And Rosenbluth International, another industry giant, recently laid off 200 employees, almost 7 percent of its payroll, blaming falling air fares in recent months.
Agency revenues could suffer even more if the Justice Department rules that "overrides" -- cash bonuses that airlines give to the travel agents that supply them the most passengers -- offer established carriers an unfair advantage over newer or smaller competitors.
Air fare commissions are airlines' third-biggest expense, behind labor and fuel. Delta Air Lines recently stirred industry wrath by seeming to suggest that it would reduce the traditional 10 percent commission, perhaps to 7.5 percent, as part of its effort to slash expenses by almost 20 percent in the next three years.
While Delta subsequently denied any such intention, it did not rule out the possibility of someday making a change. Meanwhile, Dick Knodt, executive vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents, said that every 1 percent reduction in commissions could put 5,000 small travel agencies out of business.
 
 
'Never Been as Tough'
 At Odyssey Travel in West Chester, Pa., airline commissions have fallen about 35 percent over the last year. "This business has never been as tough as today," said Jutta Goss, the owner. "Everything has suddenly been turned upside down."
Industry woes are reflected in the record 2,820 travel agencies that last year either went out of business or defaulted on payments to the Airlines Reporting Corporation, the industry clearinghouse that provides agents with tickets. The total was double that of five years earlier.
And many agents fear problems will be compounded by the growing use of self-service machines.
Docunet Inc., the San Francisco company that will install airline ticket machines in supermarkets beginning in late October, says its machines will also eventually dispense cash and traveler's checks. And the video kiosks, from the Automated Travel and Health Center, a travel agency in Tampa, Fla., display brochures, photographs and tour prices on color monitors and allow browsers to dial an "800" number for inquiries or to book trips or buy travel insurance.
Travel agencies will still collect a commission from sales made on some automated systems, but will have to pay a fee to the company that owns the machine. In the case of the video kiosks, Automated Travel receives a commission and pays the pharmacies 2 percent on sales and a monthly rental fee.
Individual Thomas Cook Travel agencies will receive commissions from a recently announced computerized speech recognition system that will allow customers to book airline tickets, hotel rooms and rental cars over the telephone 24 hours a day.
But many travel agents, especially the small agencies that dominate the industry, fear that as automated ticketing spreads they will be bypassed.
 
Service Charges on Tickets
 To cushion the effect of lagging commissions, some agents are dusting off an old idea and charging their customers fees of $10 to $25 for time-consuming transactions like writing or reissuing low-cost airline tickets. Travel agents estimate that it costs them about $25 an air ticket.
"We have a $10 service charge per ticket on anything under $100," said Alice Lambie of Apex Travel Service in Brookfield, Wis. Other agencies charge as much as $300 for canceled bookings of elaborate itineraries.
Aware that they can no longer survive mainly by writing tickets, many agencies are emphasizing, as never before, a need to employ specialists on a wide range of travel destinations, from the Grand Ole Opry to the Great Barrier Reef. Many others have developed specialties in niche markets by catering to seniors, art or music aficionados, honeymooners or bird watchers. Some agencies specialize in renting apartments or villas for vacationers to Europe.
More than 800 travel agencies now sell cruises exclusively, and most other agencies now push cruises at every opportunity. Travel agents typically receive a 12 percent commission to book a cruise, and unlike a discount airline ticket, cruises are not cheap. A cruise averages about $200 a day, per person, including round-trip air fare. Seven-day cruises to the Caribbean can easily cost $5,000 a couple.
"Twice a year we hold seminars where clients can come listen to officials," said Virginia Cobb of Cobb Travel in Birmingham, Ala. "We end up with many bookings. The last time we had 250 people attend, and 70 percent of them booked. A few years ago we had 85 people on a Cunard cruise to the Canary Islands."
Cruises are time consuming for agents, Ms. Cobb added, "but you can make good money selling them."
Another striking industry change is the speed with which many large travel agencies, with a preponderance of volatile business accounts, are now seeking more leisure customers. These agencies include Uni-globe Travel International, with more than 1,000 franchise locations, which hopes to change its mix of 70 percent business travel and 30 percent leisure travel to a 50-50 split, largely by focusing on selling cruises. Northwestern Travel Service, a $305 million company, hopes to change its mix from 80 percent corporate to 60.
To be sure, travel agents have had to cope with change ever since Thomas Cook, a one-time temperance missionary, founded his travel agency in England in the mid-19th century to escort well-heeled ladies and gentlemen on grand tours of the Continent.
"But rarely has major structural change come so fast and so furiously, with more on the way," said William Chiles, president of Hickory Travel Systems, a consortium of more than 100 agencies. "Agencies," he warned, "will either adapt or disappear."

HEADLINE: The Nuclear Black Market

 BODY:
Recent reports that German police have intercepted small amounts of nuclear material on Europe's black market are a chilling reminder that the end of the cold war brings no guarantee of nuclear safety. Indeed, the disintegration of the former Soviet Union with its huge stockpiles of weapons and nuclear materials may actually make the world more dangerous than it was when such materials were under police-state control.
Surely there is no more urgent task before the world's governments than eradicating this embryonic trade. Yet Russia resists, and the Clinton Administration has been slow to press the issue. 
 The materials intercepted in four recent incidents by German authorities were not in themselves a weapon threat -- the amounts of plutonium and highly enriched uranium were too small and too impure to make a bomb. What is unnerving is that these small amounts appear to have been samples designed to generate future sales of larger amounts to foreign countries or terrorist groups eager to make nuclear weapons.
There is no evidence yet that any warheads or enough material for a bomb have actually been spirited out of Russia. But German officials were right to sound the alarm. The known seizures could be a mere fraction of the dangerous traffic.
The former Soviet Union relied on physical security at installations and close monitoring of its population to prevent anyone from making off with nuclear materials. But with the police state now gone, criminal gangs proliferating and social turbulence rising, conditions seem ripe for thefts.
The most immediate need is for intensified police work to intercept smugglers. That will require an unusual degree of cooperation among police and intelligence agencies in Europe and the former Soviet Union, with help from the U.S.
Stronger protective measures are also required at all military and civilian nuclear sites in the former Soviet bloc. At a minimum there must be an accurate inventory; even Russian officials acknowledge they have lost track of who possesses what nuclear material.
Only the Russians can truly fix the security breakdown, and they are sending mixed signals. President Boris Yeltsin has promised to block the trade in nuclear contraband, and many Russian officials seem eager to upgrade security. But nationalist politicians and many atomic energy officials in Russia dismiss the concerns as Western propaganda. Unless responsible leaders prevail, the task appears hopeless.
Securing Russia's nuclear stockpiles is a matter of great urgency. Yet the Clinton Administration, distracted by domestic battles and other foreign crises, has given it only fitful attention. No high-level official is working on the problem full time, and diplomacy is going very slowly. As the President prepares for a meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in September, there is no more important issue for the White House to engage.

HEADLINE: No Field of Dreams at Baseball Assembly Plant

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The strike by major league baseball players on so-stated "philosophic" grounds, to protect the interests of future colleagues, exemplifies the enormous disparity in compensation for services and freedom of action in today's world. While a Bobby Bonilla makes $10,000 for every at bat, the women who assemble the baseballs he either hits or misses earn about two cents per ball. 
 According to data compiled by the National Labor Committee for Worker and Human Rights in Central America, these women must stitch a quota of some 48 baseballs or softballs a day and earn $1.07 for a workday of 10 1/2 hours on their feet. They work for Wilson, the supplier for the National League, which until very recently had a baseball assembly plant in Haiti, for Star Sports Inc. and three other United States companies that are allowed to trade with Haiti despite the embargo imposed by the Organization of American States.
The treatment of women workers in baseball assembly plants in Haiti and in Central America has long been a concern. Unions, or even talk of unions, are forbidden and grounds for dismissal. Inspection of these plants by outsiders has long been prohibited.
The argument given for this continued exploitation has been that if Wilson and the others were not employing the poor, the poor would have no share at all in the economy.
The philosophical concerns of the players' union might well also embrace the lives of the poor in the third world who make possible the game that earns them an average salary of $1.2 million a year.
It would shatter people's perceptions of professional ballplayers as grasping, self-interested individuals to see the players form a committee to visit the plants in Haiti and elsewhere during this interim period to study working conditions. Would even they be forbidden entrance and contact with workers?
After striking the owners, such a visit might give the major league players grounds for striking Wilson et al. too and lead to the ending of the salary cap for Haitian and other workers.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH C. TOWLE
Bronx, Aug. 17, 1994
 
The writer is a member of the Society of Jesus.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Suburban Office Space

 BODY:
Helped by an improving economy, the commercial real estate market in New York City's suburbs has begun to emerge from its recession, real estate brokers say. Asking rents for office space have bottomed out and vacancy rates have started to fall. With rising prices in Manhattan, companies could once again begin looking to the suburbs for office space, but the tightening of markets in New Jersey and on Long Island means most growth in those areas should continue to come from the expansion of local businesses. Westchester is still very attractive to large companies because there are more large blocks of space available. The Equitable Life Assurance Society and MasterCard are two companies looking for space in the county.

HEADLINE: For Japan, a Growing Deficit in Foreign Visitors

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Dressed in T-shirts, shorts and sunglasses, Mike and Jo Ozimek of Philadelphia were strolling recently along the Ginza, Tokyo's glitziest shopping district. Mr. Ozimek described Japan as the safest and most interesting country in East Asia, and said he would love to live here. It was his fifth visit and his wife's first.
But Mr. Ozimek admitted that he would probably never have come to know Japan if his job with a computer company had not brought him here on business trips, like this one. And Mrs. Ozimek said that, while she was enjoying the trip to a country she had hardly given a thought to visiting before, she was intimidated by the $400 cost of a brief visit to Mount Fuji, a little more than an hour away. 
 Their experience is hardly unique. Japan is in the heart of its summer vacation season, a paralyzing ritual of mobbed airports, train stations and roadways. But there is a serious problem with this mass peregrination -- the travelers are almost all Japanese. Few foreigners come to Japan, and lately the number has been dropping.
 
Political Difficulties
 That is a politically uncomfortable fact for a country that complains incessantly that it is misunderstood. Japanese officials insist that their country, though it has the world's largest trade surplus, would be viewed as something other than a predatory economic animal if foreigners only took the time to get to know it better.
For reasons from the astronomical costs in Japan and the lack of interest in the West to the difficulty of obtaining student visas, getting acquainted has not proven easy.
More than 13 million Japanese are expected to travel abroad this year -- triple the level of a decade ago -- as the Japanese have become, and have felt, more affluent.
Japan is expected to receive only about 3 million foreign visitors, the second year in a row that the total has declined, at least in part because costs have risen even higher with the soaring value of the yen. Japan, with a population of 124.3 million people, is the third most populous nation in East Asia and economically the largest, yet it ranks just 25th as an international destination, well behind China, Thailand and even the minuscule Portuguese colony of Macao, near Hong Kong.
 
Not Many U.S. Students Either
 With students, the story is similar. Japan sends abroad roughly double the number of students it takes in every year, despite a nearly decade-long campaign to balance the figures because of the increasingly important political need to make Japan better-liked abroad.
The imbalance with the United States is even worse. A total of 42,840 Japanese studied in American schools last year, a steep rise from 18,050 in 1988. Japan, however, was host to fewer than 2,000 Americans. According to a recent study by the Laurasian Institution, an educational exchange organization, the number of American undergraduates here was 1,423 and has been dropping for two years.
There are more than 5,000 American students in the United Kingdom, more than 4,000 in Germany and more than 3,500 in France. Foreign students make up nearly 3 percent of students in the United States, but less than 1 percent in Japan.
This is, in short, one of the least known but most tenacious imbalances in Japan's dealings with the world, and one that officials worry could carry the most negative long-term implications. "This conveys the impression to foreign countries that Japan is a closed country, even in the cultural sphere," a high-level advisory body reported to the Prime Minister in a study released in June.
The paucity of such exchanges is one reason why Japan often feels like an intimate stranger to Americans, a massive presence in the statistical records, but a curiosity in the popular imagination.
The advisory group recommended tax incentives to the private sector to encourage it to play a greater role in bringing foreign students and workers to Japan and that the difficult procedures for establishing nonprofit organizations that arrange exchanges be eased.
 
Government's Efforts Faulted
 The report was tough in its criticism of the branches of Government that promote exchanges, like the Japan Foundation, and suggested that they be doubled in size during the next few years and that their budgets be increased sharply. It also encouraged development of a database of information on exchange programs.
The report also called for more housing for foreign students, more language courses, simpler visa procedures and more money for scholarships.
"Japan has to establish itself as a cultural country, not just an economic giant," said Akito Arima, the former president of Japan's leading university, Tokyo University, and head of the advisory committee. "Japan's whole raison d'etre must change. France is a country of arts and culture. Why not Japan?"
No one doubts that a big part of the problem rests in the United States and other foreign countries. Few Americans learn Japanese and courses in Japanese history or culture have generally not been popular at Western universities. Culturally, Americans tend to feel more connected with Europe, despite the fact that Japan is America's largest overseas trading partner and the critical link in America's Pacific defense strategy.
 
Tokyo Is No Paris
 Even when costs in Japan were far lower, few Americans came here. And while the distance is great, that does not deter Americans from visiting China, for instance, in greater numbers.
Many Americans benefit from studying here, but for some, coming to Japan is the opposite of the dreamy experience many enjoy in Europe.
"When you're in Paris, it's the expatriate American in Paris thing; it's great," said Robert Rosin, 24, who has studied in both Japan and France. "In Japan, it's completely different. You're struggling for your life it seems. It's not easy."
He said he ran into real estate agents or landlords who refused to rent to foreigners, and he found costs a burden. Mr. Rosin admitted, though, that ignorance and indifference in the United States were factors. "When people found out I had studied here they would wonder how I learned about Japan and how I did it," said Mr. Rosin, who will soon begin working here for the Sony Corp.
Mr. Arima said he felt the problem represented something close to a crisis for Japan. But he expressed little hope that the situation could be corrected quickly.
"One big reason is very simple, language," he said. "English is a universal language. Japanese is not. This is a serious problem that will not go away."
But he said that he puts much of the blame on the Government. "The infrastructure for foreigners in Japan is still very primitive, especially in the bigger cities," said Mr. Arima, a nuclear physicist who studied abroad himself. "I tried to build up our facilities at Tokyo University for foreigners. But they were still too small."
 
An Economic Function
 To some degree, the imbalance is clearly a matter of intention, though this is little discussed. When Japan sends more visitors abroad than it receives, money flows out of the country. In other words, Japanese spend abroad more than visiting tourists spend in Japan. This travel deficit amounted to $23.3 billion last year.
Economically, that was significant, since it reduced Japan's yawning surplus in the broadest measure of trade, known as the current account. The current account includes both trade in manufactured goods and trade in services, including areas like tourism, banking and insurance.
Those flows have had a big impact on the travel business, which generally regards efforts to lure Americans as a waste. However, huge efforts are made to send tour groups from Japan to such popular destinations as Hawaii and Guam.
"For Japanese there is no doubt, the United States is a kind of dream destination," said Fumio Kanaya, a deputy general manager at the Japan Travel Bureau, the country's largest agency. "But it's not the same for Americans. Americans usually come here on business."

The Economy
The biggest savings and loan in Maryland agreed to open new branches and mortgage offices in poor neighborhoods to settle Justice Department allegations of racial bias. The settlement, with Chevy Chase Federal Savings Bank, challenged lending institutions to open new offices in black neighborhoods, a significant shift from previous Justice Department cases that simply instructed lenders to cease refusing to make loans to minorities. [D1.]
 
International
Russia's turn to capitalism now includes the church. The Russian Orthodox Church has teamed up with a California businessman in a joint venture to bottle natural water from the Saint Springs in Kostroma, Russia. The church is seeking money for restoration work after seven decades of Communist persecution. The Saint Springs water is sold mainly to tourists and Western business people who fear Russian tap water. [D1.]
 
Markets
Stocks slipped in quiet, cautious trading. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 3.89 points. [D6.]
 The dollar dropped against the yen amid pessimism about trade talks between the United States and Japan. [D13.]

 Prices of Treasury securities fell, following the decline in the value of the dollar on currency markets. [D16.]

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: The Policy;
Cuba Strategy: Reactive or Planned?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The way Administration officials tell it, their new policy toward Cuba has two straightforward goals: stopping the flood of refugees and pressuring Fidel Castro to take meaningful steps toward democracy and a free market.
With Cuba's economy in a shambles and with Mr. Castro facing the most dissent in years, it is an opportune time to get Mr. Castro to bend to outside pressures, Administration officials say. 
 While these officials insist that the new strategy grew out of a lengthy policy review, foreign policy experts say it has been awkwardly improvised ever since the the flood of refugees appeared on the horizon two-and-a-half weeks ago. Hardly a day has gone by without a new policy offshoot or without one Administration official making a statement that seems to contradict that of another.
So far, many foreign policy experts say, much of the new policy -- abandoning automatic asylum for Cubans and tightening economic sanctions -- appears to be in response to short-term domestic considerations, without recognizing the potential long-term consequences. In this respect, these experts say that the Administration's short-term focus is little different from its strategies toward Haiti and Somalia.
 
Will Sanctions Increase Flow?
 One big concern is that the tougher sanctions the White House imposed last weekend will cause more misery or a violent eruption in Cuba, encouraging tens of thousands more refugees to go to sea -- precisely what the Administration is trying to prevent.
White House officials say their policy aims not to topple Mr. Castro but to pressure him to embrace reforms. But Gillian Gunn, director of Georgetown University's Cuba Project, and many other experts assert that Mr. Castro will never agree to reform if the United States keeps his back pinned against the wall. Mr. Castro is too shrewd to consent to free elections if Cuba's economy is so wretched that he is bound to lose, they argue.
Despite the Administration's professed policy of seeking peaceful change in Cuba, many experts say the likely result of the toughened sanctions will be to foment violence by making the anti-Castro opposition more desperate.
"This whole policy seems to be drawn up hastily, without consulting experts within the Administration who can warn them about what they're doing," Ms. Gunn, of the Cuba Project, said in an interview. "This policy will either lead to a stalemate in which Castro remains in power, but the Cuban people suffer more and migration pressures rise, or it will lead to some kind of instability and uprising, which could lead to American intervention and a huge outflow of refugees."
Whatever the Administration's policy objectives may be, the President revised his Cuba policy in direct response to pleas from Florida's Democratic Governor, Lawton Chiles, who faces a tough re-election battle this fall. Mr. Clinton's political team worried that a tidal wave of refugees could cause the Democrats to lose the governor's mansion in Florida this fall and cause Mr. Clinton problems in the fourth most populous state in 1996.
Responding to Governor Chiles's appeals, Attorney General Janet Reno announced in an unusual late-night news conference an end to the 28-year-old practice of welcoming virtually all Cubans.
Even for an Administration long accused of flip-flopping, her announcement seemed extraordinary because that very morning, she had told reporters that the refugee situation was under control and no change in refugee policy was under consideration. Administration officials explained her about-face as a response to the surge in Cuban refugees, but it was widely read as an attempt at political damage control in Florida.
While that policy reversal aimed to comfort Floridians worried about a flood of refugees, it created another problem: many Cuban-Americans were angered. They protested against sending Cubans back to the navy base on Guantanamo Bay.
Two days later, as if to placate the Cuban-Americans, the Administration tried to show that the new policy would hurt not just fleeing Cubans, but also Mr. Castro. President Clinton announced tougher sanctions: more anti-Castro broadcasts, steps to prevent Cuban-Americans from sending cash to Cuba, and reducing charter flights.
"It's troubling that the whole process seems not to be driven by humanitarian motives or by any serious foreign policy consideration, but by narrow political calculations, following pretty much what hard-liners in the Cuban-American community demanded," said Peter Hakim, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based research institute on hemispheric issues. "It increases the danger of a less peaceful, less satisfactory transition to a post-Castro Government."
Like many experts, he predicted the sanctions would worsen the lot of most Cubans: the very people the Administration wants to help. To this criticism, a White House official responded that as is usually the case with sanctions, the masses have to be squeezed somewhat if the regime is to be pressured.
 
How Long at Guantanamo?
 Showing just how much extemporizing the Administration is doing, Mr. Clinton's aides admit they have no idea how long the Cubans intercepted by the Coast Guard will be detained at Guantanamo Bay or where they will go next.
Last Friday, Ms. Reno said the refugees would be held there "short-term" before being taken to safe havens in third countries. But in a news conference today, Defense Secretary William Perry said the refugees would be held at Guantanamo Bay "indefinitely."
The Administration seems to be improvising so openly because its new policy has not elicited the anticipated response. When the President ordered the Coast Guard to detain fleeing Haitians in Guantanamo Bay rather than grant them interviews for asylum, the flood of Haitians slowed to a trickle.
But the Cubans keep going to sea in record numbers even though the welcome mat has been withdrawn. With the Cuban exodus climbing to new highs today, Administration officials were scrambling to ask Caribbean countries to provide safe havens to hold the overflow of Cubans.
The Cubans keep streaming onto flimsy rafts for a reason that has often plagued President Clinton: a lack of credibility on foreign policy. Many fleeing Cubans simply do not believe President Clinton's assertion that they they won't be allowed into the United States.
These people are convinced that their cousins or step-brothers in Miami will somehow arrange for them to be moved from Guantanamo to Florida -- and ultimately to American citizenship.

HEADLINE: Border Crossings;
Migration for Work and Play Is Binding a Working-Class Village to a Gilded Neighbor

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22

 BODY:
Luis Lopez had long wanted to open a Mexican restaurant in Rye, confident that there was a fortune to be made in that gilded community of country clubs, estates and, more important, disposable wealth.
But after discovering the high rents for commercial space there, he opened his restaurant just a few steps from the Rye border in this scruffy harbor village on Long Island Sound, where he has slowly tapped the Rye market. 
 "I wanted to be near where the rich people are," said Mr. Lopez, whose restaurant, El Coyote Flaco on Midland Avenue, offers a menu of low-fat specialties meant to entice the health-conscious gentry. "My plan was to draw these kind of American customers and acquaint them with quality Hispanic foods."
His strategy suggests the unusual ties between Rye and Port Chester -- a kind of cross-pollination between two strikingly different communities: one made up largely of affluent white residents, the other increasingly of working-class immigrants, many from Latin America. It is a union of expedience that, with occasional exceptions, has led to cooperation in many areas, from government and commerce to the arts, entertainment, education and recreation.
As Jan Kelsy, a local historian from Rye, put it: "Both of these communities have evolved differently, but they're tied together in many ways. There's always been a flow back and forth between them."
Teeming with a cluster of ethnic groceries and herbal shops, Hispanic restaurants, a leather craftsman and other mom-and-pop ventures, Port Chester has become something of a magnet for well-heeled Rye residents seeking the exotica of the village's downtown.
But the relationship runs the other way as well. Rye provides a wealth of jobs in housekeeping, gardening, baby-sitting and the like to many South and Central American immigrants who have come to this suburb in search of opportunities.
"We could not find this much work in our country," said a 22-year-old gardener from El Salvador who identified himself only as Manuel. "We are fortunate that there are people who need workers like us."
There is also a small circle of artists and other intellectuals from Rye (as well as other Westchester County communities) who have begun using Port Chester's vacant factories and other commercial spaces as studios and galleries.
"There's a commonality between these communities," said Mike Graessle, the village manager for Port Chester. "There's an enrichment that they share in commercial experiences, cultural experiences and recreational experiences."
But there have been tensions as well.
For years, both were villages governed by the larger Town of Rye. But in 1942, residents in the village of Rye broke away by incorporating as a city, in part because of complaints that a disproportionate share of local taxes was going to services in Port Chester.
To this day, many in Port Chester feel their village is regarded with more than a little bit of derision.
"Port Chester is very maligned," said Randy Solomon, who grew up in Port Chester but now lives in Rye Brook. "It's very easy for people to look down on Port Chester because it's a blue-collar community."
The most recent standoff between Port Chester and Rye came several months ago, when Home Depot, a home-improvement retailer, proposed a sprawling store on Midland Avenue in Port Chester, near the Rye border.
Saying the new store would bring traffic, noise and pollution, a group of Rye residents waged a campaign against the proposal, even mounting a successful court challenge. But Port Chester officials and many residents have supported it as a way to bolster the sagging economy of a village that has lost major employers like the Life Savers candy factory. A revised proposal by Home Depot is expected soon by Port Chester officials.
Port Chester residents were angered by the Rye campaign because they felt their village had far more at stake than Rye, a community where the median family income is $86,000 a year, more than double what families in Port Chester make, according to the 1990 Census.
Regardless of that disparity, many in Port Chester are proud that this village of 25,000 has maintained its character as a gritty, bare-knuckle enclave in a region that is far from that.
"The elite have always been in Rye," said Goldie Solomon, a lifelong Port Chester resident who is president of the village's historical society. "But Port Chester is like the hub on a wheel, an industrial community that's always provided the blue-collar labor for its neighbors."
No place illustrates the interdependence between the two communities more than Port Chester's downtown, where day laborers cluster on street corners waiting to be hired for jobs, very often in Rye, and where many merchants say they try to cater to the tastes of customers from Rye.
"We are all interested in keeping the image of this community up, so that people from Rye and all over keep coming," said George Kanlonj, an Ecuadorean immigrant who owns one of the 84 Salvadoran, Mexican, Peruvian, Italian and other ethnic restaurants in Port Chester's downtown.
One of the people who has come to Port Chester from Rye is Anne Barringer Spaeth. When she decided to open an avant-garde bookstore, she looked past obvious spots in her own community, whose main drag is dominated by coffee shops, ice-cream parlors and upscale boutiques, and chose a vacant storefront on North Main Street in Port Chester.
There, she sells the works of Hispanic authors like Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Octavia Paz as well as self-help books focusing on alcoholism and domestic violence, published in both Spanish and English.
 
Cross-Pollination
 But she says her decision to open the shop in Port Chester goes well beyond the business of selling books. The bookstore, called Panacea, has been the site of voter registration and a forum for musicians, authors and poets.
"I now have the ability to cross-fertilize and get people to know each other," Mrs. Barringer Spaeth said, noting that her mailing list of 1,000 includes people not only from Port Chester but also from her own community and others.
To many, such efforts have helped bridge a cultural divide. Guillermo Brown, a young drummer from Port Chester, and his quartet recently appeared at the bookstore to play jazz standards for an audience that was anything but standard.
"We got to reach a real cross-section of people at the bookstore," said Mr. Brown, 18. "Reaching out to people in music is really what we're interested in."
The crossing of these disparate worlds has also helped turn misfortune into fortune. One example is the Simon Building, a five-story former factory on Irving Avenue that had many vacancies before a group of artists packed up their easels, brushes and paints and moved their studios there.
Janet Levine, a painter and sculptor from Rye, relocated her studio to the fourth floor of the building about seven years ago, along with a handful of other artists.
"There weren't that many of us in the building back then," Mrs. Levine said. "But today, we may have as many as 40 to 50 artists in the building."
On occasion, she said, the artists have opened the studios to visitors, offering the artists an opportunity to gauge how people from all walks of life react to their work.
"It's an interesting experience because you're looking for as many different types of responses as you can get," she said.
"Port Chester is special in that it hasn't been totally gentrified," she said. "It's got a nice mixture. There are so many different kinds of stores and people. You make a lot of interesting discoveries.
And, she added, "It's only minutes away from home."

Graphs: "SNAPSHOT: Coexisting Communities"
With little in common, Rye, a wealthy Westchester County community, and Port Chester, its working-class neighbor, have long been interdependent. Immigrants, many from Latin America, find apartments in Port Chester and jobs in the homes and on the estates of Rye. And people from Rye come to Port Chester to try the restaurants and explore the shops and art galleries that its lower rents have attracted.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Fall Along With Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday, as bonds moved in tandem with the dollar's decline in world currency markets. Traders said that the absence of new economic data or major events left the spotlight on currency.
According to analysts, the dollar's decline against the yen has been sparked by fears that the United State and Japan will not be able to settle their differences about reducing Japan's huge trade surplus with America. 
 Traders said the coming supply of Treasury issues might also have been a factor in putting pressure yesterday on the prices of shorter-term maturities. This week, the Treasury will be auctioning $28.25 billion of new two-year and five-year notes. Analysts expect, however, that supply will lighten considerably after the auctions.
The 30-year bond fell 25/32 of a point, to 9913/32 , for a yield of 7.55 percent, up from 7.49 percent on Friday. All the sharp gains made after last week's rate increase by the Federal Reserve have now disappeared.
 
 
Concern Over Rates
 Traders said investors were growing concerned about another interest rate rise by the Fed, even though many analysts do not expect the Fed to lift interest rates again until after the November elections. Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the conversation among trading desks yesterday was about the chances of another rate increase.
In addition, with the dollar down, fewer foreign investors may want to chance buying Treasuries for fear of seeing their investment erode.
Mr. Roden said he was starting to see the flow of new money coming into the market, but it was gravitating toward to the shorter maturities because of the higher returns created by recent Fed interest rate jumps. This, in turn, is putting pressure on the longer end of the market, he believes.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note, which will be auctioned today, was trading at a price to yield 6.30 percent, while the five-year to be auctioned tomorrow was trading at a price to yield 6.98 percent.
Yesterday, the Treasury held its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, with rate results on the mixed side. The average rate for a three-month bill was 4.62 percent, up from 4.59 percent last week. Traders said it was the highest rate in nearly three years.
For the six-month Treasury bill at auction, the average rate was 4.98 percent, one basis point under last week's rate. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
 
'Good Shape'
 There are expectations that this week's auctions will do well, in part because the threat of an interest rate rise is off until the fall. But there are those like George Mateyo, who manages $3 billion in investment at Carnegie Capital Management in Cleveland, who believes yields will not come down anytime soon because the Fed, he thinks, will be forced to raise rates at least once more before the end of the year. "The economy's growing too fast to slow down without another rate increase," he said.
"The economy's in good shape, and as a consequence inflation is bound to rise," Mr. Mateyo added.
But not everybody sees rapid economic growth. Ray Worseck, chief economist and manager at A. G. Edwards & Sons, said that final sales of goods and services were rising more slowly, and the economy appeared to have shifted from a phase in which economic momentum was accelerating to a phase in which it was waning.
He said that during the second quarter the output of the economy, as measured by real gross domestic product, increased at a 3.7 percent annual rate. On the surface, that looked strong, he said. However, Mr. Worseck added that much of the increase in output did not get sold and instead accumulated on retailers' shelves as inventories, which means production could now begin to slow down.
In the municipal market, which has also been adversely affected by the drop Government securities prices, many tax-exempt investors have put off purchases.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concern About Trade Talks Sends Dollar Lower vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled to a five-week low against the yen yesterday as traders grew more pessimistic about progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan.
Losses against the yen helped drag the dollar lower against the German mark and other leading currencies, traders said. The dollar fell to 97.71 yen, its lowest level since July 18, before settling at 97.85 yen in late New York trading, down from 98.65 yen on Friday. It fell to a six-week low of 1.5264 marks before settling at 1.5288 marks, down from 1.5396 marks on Friday. 
 The dollar's latest slide against the yen started on Thursday after the Commerce Department said the United States trade deficit with Japan widened to $5.518 billion in June. The trade report came two days after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, a move that usually bolsters the dollar's value by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive to investors.
But the swollen trade deficit means that Japanese exporters have a wealth of dollars to sell for yen when they bring revenues home, depressing the value of the dollar.
"The focus in the currency market is back on Japan's trade surplus," said Frank Pusateri, a vice president at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "It's looking like trade war time."
Amy Smith, senior currency market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm, said she expected the dollar to face a "difficult September" against the yen as a deadline for progress in the trade talks drew closer. The United States set a deadline of Sept. 30 for negotiations aimed at getting Japanese Government agencies to buy more American goods.
 
Strength in the Peso
 The Mexican peso, meanwhile, rallied to a three-month high against the dollar after preliminary results showed that Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, the candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party won Mexico's presidency in Sunday's elections.
The election prompted investors to buy Mexican assets, for which they needed pesos, said Guillermo Estebanez, senior economist at Bank of America in San Francisco.
The peso closed the day at 3.3375 to the dollar, its highest level since June 6, and stronger than Friday's 3.3575 pesos.
The peso slipped from the day's highs after the Mexican central bank told currency traders that it would buy dollars if the peso reached 3.25 pesos to the dollar, to limit big swings in the currency market -- even swings that benefit the peso.

HEADLINE: Dow Eases 3.89 as Traders Show Caution

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Worried by the dollar's continuing fall, despite a rate increase by the Federal Reserve that should have raised its value, stock traders pulled back sharply from trading yesterday.
The leading stock indexes closed essentially unchanged, while bonds fell with the declining dollar. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 3.89 points, to 3,751.22, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.36 point, to 462.32. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 0.14 point, to 742.29.
Even for typically quiet Mondays, trading volume was restrained. About 236 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, or 17 percent below this year's average of 285 million shares and below even the more restrained trading average of the third quarter of 259 million shares.
 
Movement in Bond Prices
 Bond prices followed the fate of the dollar but did not closely track stocks. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell, yielding 7.55 percent, up from 7.49 percent.
Last week's half-point increase in short-term rates by the Fed ought to have made dollar-denominated assets, like stocks and bonds, more attractive to investors, especially foreigners.
Instead, the dollar has fallen in three of the last four sessions against the Japanese yen and four out of four sessions against the German mark. Yesterday, the dollar fell to 97.85 yen from 98.65 yen and plunged as low as 97.71 yen. The dollar also fell to 1.5288 marks, from 1.5396 marks on Friday.
Currency traders cited continuing pessimism that trade talks between the United States and Japan would reduce the $60 billion United States trade deficit. By exporting to the United States more than it imports and by selling the resulting dollars rather than investing them in American goods and services, Japan tends to depress the value of the dollar and strengthen that of the yen.
While the trade deficit persists, the Fed's interest rate moves will likely have little effect on the currency markets because currency traders are more often moved by their own speculation rather than assessment of economic conditions.
Currency traders also cite relatively attractive German interest rates, which do not seem to be coming down soon, and stable American rates, which may not rise again until after the Congressional elections in November.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.54 point, to 255.27, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 922 to 1,238. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.32 point, to 445.77.
 
Dow Industrial Stocks
 Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 fell, led by Boeing, which dropped 7/8, to 44 1/8, following newspaper reports of defense budget cutbacks that would hurt contractors like Boeing.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 276 fell, led by General Motors, which fell 3/4, to 48 3/8, despite trade reports that G.M. would make more cars than Japan this year, for the first time since 1980.
There were other notable stocks. LDDS Communications fell 3/4, to 231/16 , after announcing plans to buy Wiltel, the long-distance telephone network, from the Williams Companies for $2.5 billion.
Johnson & Johnson rose 1/8, to 49 1/8, after it announced plans to buy Neutrogena for nearly $1 billion. And Novell dropped 1 1/8, to 14, after the software developer warned that third-quarter earnings would be below expectations. Wordperfect, recently acquired by Novell, will likely hurt Novell's earnings, Novell said.

HEADLINE: LDDS to Purchase Wiltel for $2.5 Billion

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 22

 BODY:
LDDS Communications Inc., striving to turn the Big Three of long-distance telephone service into the Big Four, agreed today to buy the Williams Companies' national fiber optic network for $2.5 billion in cash.
In acquiring Wiltel, the Williams telecommunications unit, LDDS would join AT&T, MCI Communications and Sprint in having its own network. Owning a network, instead of leasing capacity, will cut LDDS's costs and allow it to reach for major corporate customers, analysts said. 
 "In order to position themselves to be a full-fledged No. 4 competitor,' said Stuart Conrad, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence/Deutsche Bank Securities, "they had to do a Wiltel type of deal.'
Just three weeks ago, LDDS bounded into the international long-distance market with its agreement to buy IDB Communications Group Inc. for $900 million in stock and the assumption of debt.
LDDS now has about 3 percent of the $64 billion United States long-distance market. The extra two percentage points gained by the two acquisitions would still leave LDDS well behind AT&T's 59 percent of the market, MCI's 19 percent and Sprint's 10 percent.
Although Wiltel already serves many large companies, some analysts wonder how many more corporate accounts LDDS can take from its rivals.
The deal ends an ardent, sometimes fractious, four-month pursuit of Wiltel by Bernard J. Ebbers, the chief executive of LDDS.
"Wiltel is recognized as a leading 'carrier's carrier,' " Mr. Ebbers said in a statement, "but it is also well recognized for its development of leading-edge technology for larger telecommunications users.'
Mr. Ebbers initially offered Keith E. Bailey, his Williams counterpart, $2 billion in person on April 6. With no response from the company a month later, Mr. Ebbers increased the pressure by publicizing his offer.
The Williams board, loath to part with a business growing far more rapidly than its larger natural gas divisions, soon rejected it. But even as Williams executives loudly proclaimed their intent to stay in the telecommunications business, the board told them to keep talking with LDDS and other possible buyers, several of them foreign.
LDDS will buy only the Wiltel fiber optics network, leaving Williams with two much smaller operations, in telecommunications service and equipment and in video transmission. LDDS will leave its new unit in Tulsa, Okla., where Williams is based.
 
Cables in Pipelines
 Williams plans to use as much as $800 million of the sale proceeds to buy back its stock over the next 12 months, and the rest for investments in the energy field. After taxes and other costs, Williams expects to receive $1.6 billion, including a gain of at least $950 million.
These amounts represent the returns on a business Williams began only in 1986 by threading fiber optic cables through its abandoned natural gas pipelines and along other pipelines still in use.
Shares of Williams, having risen from the low $20's since early April in anticipation of the Wiltel sale, fell 25 cents today, to $31.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of LDDS fell 75 cents, to $23.0625, in Nasdaq trading, on news that had been expected. Analysts said the $2.5 billion price was a windfall for Williams but would ultimately be worth it for LDDS.
In a telephone conference today, Mr. Bailey tussled with some analysts and investors, including Leon Cooperman, a hedge-fund manager, who questioned how well Williams would be able to deploy the proceeds.
Mr. Bailey said the Wiltel video network, which Williams will keep, had the potential to grow as rapidly as the telecommunications network being sold. "We've been as successful as anyone in the business with respect to building value in the long-distance business,' he said. "We have the potential to be as successful as anyone in the video media business."
 
Hurdle for a Growing Company
 LDDS, based in Jackson, Miss., has grown rapidly through acquisitions since Mr. Ebbers became one of the original investors in 1983. John W. Kluge, the billionaire investor, gained about 19 percent of LDDS's stock when his Metromedia Communications merged with LDDS last September.
But LDDS has remained only a marketer, packager and paperwork handler for telephone service provided on network capacity leased from other companies, including Wiltel. Without the economies of its own network, LDDS has concentrated on serving small and medium-sized businesses.
These businesses are likely to be the first quarry of the regional Bell companies, should they win permission to enter the long-distance market in the next several years.
Several analysts said LDDS might then be swallowed up itself. "I don't think there's any question that this asset is for sale,' said Craig Ellis, an analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer. He added that Mr. Kluge already had close ties to the regional Bells.
In a brief interview, Mr. Ebbers said his company would also expand its efforts to win residential business. "If you are creditworthy," he said, "you could be getting a call from a company that represents LDDS."
The Wiltel purchase, to be financed by a group of banks, is subject to Federal and state approvals, which the companies expect by the end of the year.
