HEADLINE: A Russian Bottled Water With a Saintly Twist

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KOSTROMA, Russia

 BODY:
In earlier times, it might have been considered an unholy alliance, but the Russian Orthodox Church is working with a California businessman in a joint venture to bottle natural water from the Saint Springs for sale in Russia and soon the United States.
"New times," Archbishop Aleksandr explained as he briskly led an inspection tour of the bottling plant. The Archbishop, who led the effort to turn the output of the church's natural spring into Russia's only domestically bottled still water, said he expected to turn a profit this fall. 
 "We need a lot of money to restore what was lost," the Archbishop said, referring to seven decades of Communist persecution of the church. "Donations just are not enough."
 
An Unusual Step
 The Saint Springs Water Company is the church's first commercial undertaking since before the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. And it is the first venture that the insular, hierarchical patriarchate has entered with a foreign partner.
Unlike participants in most joint ventures in Russia, both sides seem content. The church, which is trying to reclaim and restore property confiscated under Communism, acquired a potentially abundant source of revenue without putting up any money of its own.
And John V. R. King, a retired plastics manufacturer from Lake Arrowhead, Calif., got a resourceful and well-connected Russian partner that intervenes in business matters only when asked.
"The church has this appearance of power, and nobody really knows how much it has," Mr. King explained. "When they ask for something, they generally get it."
Mr. King said the Archbishop's office had cut through red tape, wheedled concessions from local authorities, kept interfering local government officials at bay, and even won some tax breaks. When Government officials told him he would have to provide housing and a food store for his 30 employees, Mr. King turned to the Archbishop.
"Basically, he said, 'We'll take care of it,' and he did," Mr. King said.
In a country where consumers are increasingly disillusioned with authority and mistrustful of foreigners, the church has proved deft at public relations. In July, Patriarch Aleksei II went to Kostroma to bless the venture and gamely pressed the button for the maiden journey of bottles down the conveyor belt. Archbishop Aleksandr's signature is printed on the label as a kind of religious good-housekeeping seal.
The church does not contend that the water can produce miracles, but it does try to appeal to a certain consciousness. As the Archbishop put it, "It is an ecologically clean product."
Nonsparkling bottled water is still a delicacy for ordinary Russians. Saint Springs, which is sold in the Metropol Hotel in Moscow, the Grand Hotel Europa in St. Petersburg and in hard-currency shops, is mainly sold to tourists and Western business people who fear Russian tap water. The price of a 1.5-liter bottle ranges from 90 cents to $1.80, depending on the outlet.
"This is a charitable endeavor for us," Archbishop Aleksandr said. "All the profits we plan to make will go to noble purposes."
Mr. King said the plant was already bottling and distributing one million bottles a month, which is about 20 percent of its total capacity. In the first week of September, it will be adding half-liter bottles for sale in hotel mini-bars and on airline flights.
Unlike such big bottling conglomerates as Pepsi-Cola or Schweppes, which ship bottled water to Russia, Mr. King's product is exempt from Russia's stiff import tariffs because it is domestically produced.
Mr. King put together a small group of American investors to raise millions of dollars in start-up capital. One of them, a Napa Valley wine maker, found a California craftsman to design the onion-domed plastic bottle and elegant label.
Mr. King said he planned to begin exporting Saint Springs water to the United States this autumn, marketed as an exceptionally pure water that bears the seal of approval of the highest spiritual authority in Russia. The company plans to start with cities that have large Russian populations, like New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The Russian Tea Room, a prominent Russian restaurant in Manhattan, requested a sample case.
"We'd definitely like to taste a Russian spring water," said John Hankinson, assistant manager at the Russian Tea Room. He said the restaurant would offer a tasting of Saint Springs with other bottled waters next week.
 
Idea Born on River Cruise
 The project began two years ago when Mr. King, who had retired after selling a company that manufactured plastic fittings for electrical conduits, took a cruise down the Volga River with a group of Dartmouth College alumni.
The group stopped at Kostroma, nearly 200 miles northeast of Moscow, to tour the restored 17th-century Church of the Resurrection. There, they met with Archbishop Aleksandr, who at the time was the Bishop of Kostroma and Gallich, and who began describing the sorry state of most churches after 70 years of state-enforced atheism.
He had decided to seek a Western partner and he listed a number of church assets, including natural springs, that might interest visiting American entrepreneurs. Mr. King was smitten.
"The idea of bottling the church's spring water just blew me away," Mr. King recalled. "I didn't sleep that night."
It took a year to select and test a water source, and then months to convert an abandoned leather warehouse into an up-to-date bottling plant, with German and American equipment. The factory walls are painted a soothing, pale aquamarine, and icons decorate every room and storage area.
Saint Spring began selling its water last month, using bottles manufactured at the site. The plant has the capacity to process 600 bottles a minute.
 
Few Financial Details
 The agreement calls for Mr. King and his fellow investors to begin splitting the profits with the church after they recoup a percentage of their initial investment. Mr. King would not disclose the details of the contract, nor the exact amount spent, except to say it involved "multiple millions" of dollars.
Archbishop Aleksandr said he checked Mr. King's credentials before signing. "Through acquaintances," he explained, then smiled slyly. "Russia is a land full of rumors."
The Archbishop gave credit to Mr. King for risking his time and money. "Many American businessmen are afraid of Russia," he said. "The economy is unstable; we have a scary tax system."
Mr. King, however, said the church was as close as he could come to a sure bet. "It's the only stable institution in Russia," he said.

HEADLINE: Banks Easing Loan Terms

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Banks have offered better terms on loans in the last three months, but there was some tempering in demand, especially for home mortgages, the Federal Reserve said today, a sign that higher interest rates are discouraging borrowing.
In a survey of senior loan officers at 58 United States banks and 18 United States branches of overseas banks, the Fed found the terms that banks put on loans to businesses and households had eased, although not as quickly as in the previous three-month survey period that ended in May. 
 The Fed study looked at the interest rate spread between what banks charge for loans and their base rates as well as the cost and size of the credit lines they offer.
Easier terms mean businesses have freer access to credit, which helps fuel their expansion.
The Fed survey showed demand for mortgages had fallen significantly from already low levels in the spring. The Fed gave no explanation why mortgage loan applications were down.
The drop in mortgage applications forced banks to step up efforts to attract customers. The institutions were "more willing to make consumer and residential mortgage loans," the Fed said.
Demand by business for bank loans grew, although slightly below the record levels reported in May, the Fed said.
The survey said many banks had loosened their lending restrictions, particularly on loans to medium-sized concerns, because of increased competition for credit and an improving economic outlook.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. WILL EXPAND PATROLS TO STOP CUBAN REFUGEES

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The United States moved today to expand its picket line of patrol vessels in the Florida Straits as hundreds of Cubans set sail for Florida despite the Clinton Administration's efforts to stem the exodus.
The Coast Guard reported that 2,548 refugees had been picked up at sea by midnight Monday, adding to the 1,293 refugees taken aboard United States ships on Sunday. Today's was the highest daily figure since Cubans began the newest mass departure from their island home. All will be transferred to the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay. 
 More than 2,000 Cuban refugees, the first to be denied asylum in the United States in 28 years, arrived at the Guantanamo base today. [Page A17.]
Three days after President Clinton ended the special status for fleeing Cubans and announced that they would no longer be allowed into the country, there was no sign that the change in policy was slowing the flight. The pace of departures from Cuba threatened to overwhelm the Administration's plans for intercepting Cubans and housing them at Guantanamo or at "safe havens" in the Caribbean area that have yet to be identified.
The Clinton policy seemed to be intended to dissuade individual Cubans from leaving the island and to put pressure on President Fidel Castro to stop the exodus by increasing the economic pressure on his Government. Neither strategy appears to be working.
Secretary of Defense J. William Perry, touring interception and detention operations, said at a news conference in Key West that three more Navy vessels would be added by Tuesday to the three Navy ships and 19 Coast Guard cutters already on patrol to sweep the waters for refugees and transport them to Guantanamo, on the southeast coast of Cuba.
He said that all efforts were directed at intercepting the flow of refugees from Cuba and that the Guantanamo installations could house 10,000 Cubans in addition to the 15,000 Haitians already detained at the Navy base.
The refugees continue putting out to sea despite word spreading in Cuba that they would be detained at Guantanamo, instead of being granted immediate political asylum, the practice before Mr. Clinton reversed the policy last week.
There were also indications coming from refugees already picked up that the growing presence of United States rescue ships greatly reduced the hazards of crossing the Florida Straits. The shortest distance between Cuba and Key West is 90 miles. Strong currents, however, and flimsy vessels -- many powered only by oars, paddles and grit -- often mean a much longer voyage for a departing refugee unless his craft is intercepted after leaving Cuban waters.
"These ships right now are magnets for people who want to emigrate illegally from Cuba," Rafael Dausa, political and press officer for the Cuban Mission in Washington, said in a telephone interview.
Before flying to Guantanamo to inspect the detention quarters, Mr. Perry appealed to Cubans not to embark on the high-risk voyage across shark-infested waters in boats and rafts patched together with inner tubes, plywood and rope.
 
Bigger Blockade 'an Option'
 He also said a stepped-up blockade of Cuba remained "an option, but that's not part of our present planning."
An economic blockade of an island that is more than 700 miles long would be "a very different operation" from the relief exercise now in place off Cuba's north coast, he pointed out. "It would require more resources, more ships than we have located here to do that," he said.
The Navy is currently maintaining a sea blockade of Haiti.
Speaking of the increased naval presence, Adm. Paul David Miller, commander of the United States Atlantic Command, said it was necessary to shift one Navy vessel involved in the Haitian blockade to help out in the Florida Straits. Six Navy ships were left to enforce sanctions off Port-au-Prince and other Haitian ports, an adequate force, said Admiral Miller, who accompanied the Secretary of Defense to Key West.
A tight blockade of Cuba would presumably require a much larger flotilla to circle the island. Haiti, by comparison, occupies only the western part of the island of Hispaniola and seaborne trade is compressed into a much smaller area.
In Havana, an official Cuban newspaper condemned Washington in an editorial for racheting up pressure on Mr. Castro and said the United States had long encouraged Cubans to flee their country, the Reuters news service reported.
After beckoning Cubans to freedom, an editorial in the trade union newspaper Trabajadores stated, the United States was jailing them. It also raised questions about the American decision to detain the refugees at the Guantanamo base.
"The illegal transfer of these people to the military enclave will add a new element of friction to the already tense relations between Cuba and the United States," the editorial said.
There has been no official Cuban response to Mr. Clinton's order last Saturday that reduces charter flights between Miami and Havana, halts cash remittances from Cubans living in the United States to relatives in Cuba, and increases daily broadcasts to the island.
At his Key West news conference, Mr. Perry said it was unclear at this stage how many refugees were still putting out to sea from Cuba. More than 6,000 refugees have been picked up by the Coast Guard in the last 8 days, some 12,500 so far this year.
 
Room for 10,000 Cubans
 Tent camps at Guantanamo will be ready by the end of the week to hold 10,000 Cubans, and if the present flow continues past that mark, 2,500 might be sent to "safe havens" in the Turks and Caicos Islands, Suriname and Panama, he said.
Asked how long the United States could maintain 25,000 refugees at Guantanamo, the Secretary of Defense said, "Indefinitely." He conceded, however, that detention under those conditions "is tough for people" and said he hoped that the likelihood of detention there was enough to persuade other Cubans who were thinking about leaving the island to stay home.
He and Admiral Miller left open the prospect that even more Coast Guard and Navy ships would join the force if the crisis showed no sign of abating.
Government efforts are already supplemented by rescues of Cuban rafters by commercial ships and other boating in the area. Cruise ships and cargo vessels have docked at Florida ports with dozens of refugees, and the number held at a Miami detention center has risen to more than 500, the Immigration and Naturalization Service reported.
Private boaters are encouraged by the Coast Guard to follow the Good Samaritan law and rescue anyone in distress at sea. Crews of pleasure and fishing boats haul refugees aboard their vessels on the average of three or four times a day and rendezvous with Coast Guard cutters to transfer them aboard, said Chief Petty Officer Steve Aitkins.
As a standard search operation the Coast Guard uses 110-foot cutters to sweep areas marked on charts as boxes that reach right up to the 12-mile territorial limit off Cuba, said Lieut. Comdr. Jim McPherson. They are directed to rafters by overhead spotters in Coast Guard Falcon jets and helicopters, he said, pick up the refugees and later transfer them to 270-foot cutters or Navy frigates for transportation to Guantanamo.
Forty-one-foot Coast Guard patrol boats, for the most part, are stationed along an offshore reef line paralleling the Keys to catch refugees who managed to get past the larger patrol ships, he added.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Negotiators Ready: Anybody Know Squeeze Sign?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Baseball's 11-day-old strike produced two definite developments yesterday, but nothing occurred to create the possibility of a third development: that the two sides will squeeze out of their stalemate when they resume meeting tomorrow.
In development No. 1, representatives of the striking players and their employers, with the help of Federal mediators, agreed to meet at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow for the first time since the day the strike began, Aug. 12. 
 In development No. 2, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, announced the roster of 12 owners and club executives who will be available to join the talks. Five or six had been expected to attend tomorrow's session, but one management person said it was possible all 12 would be there.
But the primary problem remained the stalemate involving the two sides after 141 missed games. The owners still want a salary cap to create what they call cost control and the players still want no part of it.
"We do not intend to negotiate with ourselves," Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, said at an early evening news conference. "We are still awaiting the union response to our problems."
The relationship between the sides has not improved. That was evident from comments made yesterday by Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader. He described Ravitch as the owners' "hatchet man" and said "we assume at the first meeting we'll get the management chorus of 'Solidarity Forever' and 'We love Dick.' "
Ravitch declined to respond to Fehr's remarks. "I guess the last time I found name-calling to be meaningful was when I was in grade school," he said.
After meeting with Ravitch and the mediators to establish tomorrow's session, Fehr, noting that the players have been willing to meet anytime, said: "It's clear to me that he didn't want to be having these meetings, that he had to be forced into it, that they're not ready to talk yet. Nothing significant will happen. We'll be there, but it's their game, their rules."
Later, at a news conference, Fehr said: "If the owners were interested in serious negotiations, we wouldn't be having all these preliminary meetings. We'd be in there negotiating."
Each side will meet separately today with the mediators. The 12 owners and club executives will attend the management session, and Fehr said he expected somewhere between 25 and 40 players to be present for the union meeting.
Management's roster includes only three owners -- Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies and Drayton McLane Jr. of the Houston Astros.
The rest of the roster has two club chairmen, Bill Bartholomay of Atlanta and David Glass of Kansas City; two presidents, Stan Kasten of Atlanta and Paul Beeston of Toronto; one chief executive officer, John Harrington of Boston; two executive vice presidents, Dave Montgomery of Philadelphia and Andy MacPhail of Minnesota; one vice president, Wendy Selig-Prieb of Milwaukee, and one former president, Stuart Meyer, who left the St. Louis Cardinals last Friday.
Asked why two Atlanta officials were included, Selig said: "They bring different perspectives. Kasten brings the N.B.A. economic experience. Bartholomay brings 30 years of experience. Except for Gene Autry, he's been in the game the longest of anybody."
Kasten also is president of the Atlanta Hawks, which is also owned by the Turner Broadcasting System.
 
Six Possible Hard-Liners
 The group includes six people from each league. Based on the views the individuals have expressed or their clubs' position on the owners' salary cap demand, three of the group (McMorris, Harrington and Beeston) could be classified as moderates. Six could be called hard-liners and three (Bartholomay, Kasten and Meyer) could be considered as somewhere in between, though closer to the hard-line position of wanting to change the game's economic system.
Harrington was asked at the news conference why it took owners until now to join the talks.
"This may still not be the best time to come to the table," he said. "The players haven't spoken about our proposal. We're hopeful our injection into the process will bring about a change of heart by the players to address our proposal."
Fehr declined to assess the makeup of the group.
 
Few Changes After All
 The list did not change substantially from last Friday, when Selig first issued the names, then received some complaints about the makeup, in terms of league affiliation and philosophical stance.
"Someday someone is going to have to define that," Selig said by telephone from Milwaukee, referring to a "doves and hawks" characterization. "I can look at a lot of people on this list and say I don't know where they are. The fact that they're in a small market or a big market doesn't say where they are. The fact that a small-market club needs a change, does that make them a hawk?"
Selig noted that four of the group -- McMorris, Harrington, Beeston and Meyer -- were part of the caucus of high-revenue clubs during the owners' battle over a new revenue-sharing plan. Meyer was the one who produced a compromise idea that led to an agreement among the high-revenue and low-revenue clubs last January. However, the agreement was contingent on the players' acceptance of a salary cap.
 
Fear Decrease in Salaries
 The players steadfastly have refused to accept a cap on payrolls, contending it would lower salaries artificially, impede the movement of free agents and undermine competitive balance.
Fehr also noted yesterday that "there have been no agreements on any issues. The owners still have a proposal on the table that they can fire a player 'for any reason.' "
He also commented on an oft-suggested solution to the dispute, the elimination of salary arbitration for earlier free agency.
"The fact is Ravitch has made it clear 20 to 25 times in my presence that in no circumstances are clubs interested in that," he said.

HEADLINE: Pesticides May Leave Legacy of Hormonal Chaos

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
IN a new wave of concern about synthetic chemicals in the environment, some biologists are warning that trace amounts of pesticides and other man-made substances may be interfering with the action of reproductive hormones and thereby damaging the fertility of various animal populations, including humans.
The evidence is far from conclusive. But the economic and political stakes are high; should the new fears prove justified, a large group of important industrial chemicals might have to be curbed. 
 At least 45 synthetic chemicals, most of them pesticides, have been found to upset the workings of the hormonal, or endocrine system, and for this reason they are known as endocrine disruptors. There is little doubt, many scientists agree, that when people or animals are exposed to large doses of these chemicals, as has happened in chemical spills or contamination of food, serious derangements of reproductive function sometimes result. Male alligators born in Florida's Lake Apopka after a large pesticide spill in 1980 were found to be incapable of producing sperm. In Taiwan, reproductive and other defects have been noted in the sons of women who in 1978 and 1979 ingested cooking oil contaminated with PCB's.
The question at issue is whether trace amounts of these chemicals that are now widely distributed in the environment are exerting a less visible but still pernicious effect on the reproductive fitness of many species of wildlife and possibly even humans.
For at least some wildlife populations, "I'd say we are on a fast track to extinction," said Dr. Theodora Colborn, a zoologist with the World Wildlife Fund, a conservation organization in Washington, who is a leading exponent of the view that endocrine disruptors pose a potentially serious threat. "You would expect the same thing to happen with human populations."
Other experts disagree. "I don't think it is a huge problem at this point," said Dr. Thomas Goldsworthy, a toxicologist with the Chemical Industry Institute of Technology, a nonprofit research organization at Research Triangle Park, N.C., that is largely supported by industry. Said Dr. Tom Orme, a Washington-based toxicologist with the American Council on Science and Health in New York, which has long held claims of harm from chemicals in the environment to be exaggerated: "We suspect there is a lot of baloney here. On the other hand, to develop the hard science to refute it is going to be a formidable task."
Still other experts view the issue as possibly serious but say it is too early to call it one way or the other. "We don't want to argue we've got a massive problem," said Dr. Larry Reiter, the director of the Environmental Protection Agency's Health Effects Research Laboratory at Research Triangle Park. But he also said, "I don't think we want to argue there is no problem."
Although many biologists are convinced that endocrine disruptors are pervasive, they have not yet been able to assess the quantity and distribution of the chemicals in the environment. Nor is there any good survey to tell what burden of these chemicals is carried in the body fat of the general population.
But a number of studies suggest grounds for concern, particularly from the combined effects of several different chemicals acting in concert either to mimic or block the crucial effects of natural estrogens on sexual development in the fetus.
Dr. Ana M. Soto and Dr. Carlos Sonnenschein, biologists at Tufts University, have found that doses of estrogen-mimicking pesticides too small to have any effect individually on test-tube cultures of cells from breast-cancer tissue have a powerful effect when combined. Estrogens spur the growth of such cells. Other laboratory studies have shown that the synthetic chemicals can disrupt the reproductive development of mammal fetuses. And field investigations have traced reproductive disorders in mammals and birds to the consumption of fish whose flesh contained the chemicals.
Dr. Colborn, Dr. Soto and others who are alarmed about endocrine disruptors say that all chemicals that reach the environment should be tested for their hormonal effect just as they are already tested for ability to cause cancer or mutations. Some environmentalists are calling for a phaseout of endocrine-disruptor chemicals, and already there is legislation before Congress to replace some chlorine compounds, many of which have been identified as endocrine disruptors, with feasible alternatives. The E.P.A. and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service have asked the National Academy of Sciences to investigate the problem. Meanwhile, those who are raising the alarm about endocrine disruptors have been energetic in seeking attention in the press and on television, where the subject has lately been explored, sometimes in apocalyptic tones.
The debate is in some ways a replay of "Silent Spring," Rachel Carson's landmark book published in 1962, in which she argued that fat-soluble pesticides in the bodies of birds were interfering with reproduction. Her thesis provoked a barrage of criticism, but biologists in time learned that many chlorinated hydrocarbons like DDT do indeed sabotage reproduction, for example by making the shells of birds' eggs too fragile.
 
Persistent Chemical Residues
 DDT and similar pesticides like aldrin and dieldrin were banned long ago in the United States. But their residues persist in the environment, not the least because they remain in use in much of the world and are being transported to America on globe-girdling winds.
Moreover, there are many industrial chemicals that are hormonally active and that may find their way into the environment even though, unlike pesticides, they are not deliberately released. These include some members of a family of chemicals known as alkyl phenols, which Dr. Soto has found to have estrogen-like effects. These chemicals are used in plastics, including some food wrappings, as well as in several industrial processes, in paper and pulp production, textiles, hair colorings, spermicides and condom lubricants and as inert ingredients in pesticides. They are also used in industrial detergents, and their estrogenic components are released into the environment when the detergents break down. Dr. Soto has found that some of the chemicals can leach out of plastic containers and contaminate the contents.
The new phase of the debate about endocrine disruptors started with a meeting of 21 scientists in Racine, Wis., organized by Dr. Colborn in 1991. They concluded that many man-made chemicals released into the environment certainly possess "the potential to disrupt the endocrine systems of animals, including humans." Among the observed symptoms linked to these chemicals by the scientists were the feminization of male fish, birds and mammals; decreased fertility in birds, fish, shellfish and mammals; hatching failure and serious birth defects in birds, fish and turtles, and impaired metabolism in birds, fish and mammals.
The 1991 meeting focused biologists' attention on the problem, and further evidence has been gathered of endocrine disruptors at work. But it is in many ways equivocal and no clear picture has yet emerged from the data. A second group of wildlife scientists who met last December in Racine said it has been difficult to demonstrate causal relationships between the chemicals and declines in wildlife populations. They found that different species metabolize the chemicals in different ways, and that the mix of endocrine disruptors in the environment constantly changes from time to time and place to place. The experts also noted that other factors, including naturally occurring fluctuations in animal populations, could be at work.
Recent field and laboratory studies in the Great Lakes, a region often cited as a prime example of the problem, are revealing. Levels of chemicals like dioxins, furans and PCB's, three prime suspects as causes of gross birth defects and reproductive malfunctions, have declined in the lakes since the 1970's, Dr. John P. Giesy, an aquatic toxicologist at Michigan State University in East Lansing, and two colleagues reported this year in the journal Environmental Science and Technology. Their study found that some bird populations, including those of herring gulls and double-crested cormorants, have made "dramatic recoveries" since then.
But they also found that at several locations around the Great Lakes, including Saginaw Bay and Green Bay, overall concentrations of this class of chemicals still exceed thresholds at which they cause population declines. Only in these more contaminated areas are the chemicals still having significant effects on bird populations, which continue to display abnormally high rates of developmental defects and embryo deaths. These ill effects, Dr. Giesy and his colleagues wrote, "are caused by the toxic effects of multiple compounds, which expressed their effects through a common mechanism of action."
 
Danger in the Great Lakes
 Concentrations of the chemicals in the Great Lakes have stopped falling and are "bouncing around at the same level, and it looks like they're going to be there for some time to come," said Dr. Geisy. The reasons, he said, are that atmospheric deposits of chemicals from other parts of the world still land there and the waters of the Great Lakes are replenished slowly -- up to 100 years for Lake Michigan and 300 years for Lake Superior.
In most instances, Dr. Geisy said, people are exposed to much lower concentrations of the chemicals than are animals, "but there is a lot of uncertainty and a lot of data gaps." The difference, he said, is that while both people and animals can ingest the chemicals in food, people can and do restrict their intake of, for example, fish contaminated by the chemicals. "If we ate the fish they do," he said, speaking of the wildlife, "we would probably exhibit some of the same effects."
Indeed, one study found that children of mothers who ate two or three fish a month from contaminated Lake Michigan waters for at least 6 years were born slightly early, weighed less at birth, had smaller skulls, and displayed cognitive, motor and behavioral defects at birth. The effects were associated with what the mothers ate during a lifetime rather than just during pregnancy.
But perhaps the greatest fears expressed about the effects of endocrine disruptors on humans have to do with sex and reproduction. The case of the Taiwanese boys may reflect the effects of high doses. But more insidious and threatening in the long run, say Dr. Colborn and others, may be the subtle effects of low doses in the womb. As was shown with the synthetic hormone DES, prescribed from 1948 to 1971 to prevent miscarriages, exposure of the fetus to endocrine disruptors can cause reproductive problems that do not become evident until many years later.
Much attention has been given to an alarming finding by a Danish study that the sperm count of men from industrialized countries seriously dwindled between 1938 and 1991. Reporting in the British Medical Journal in 1992, the researchers concluded that there had been a "genuine decline" in sperm counts and volume of semen over the previous half-century. The paper also cited an apparent parallel rise in other reproductive tract problems such as undescended testes, malformed penises and testicular cancer. The researchers cited environmental rather than genetic factors as the probable cause but carefully noted that it remained to be determined whether synthetic estrogens were responsible.
A 1994 paper in the same journal has challenged the study's method. Even if the basic finding is correct, some experts say, there is no clear evidence to blame a decline in semen count on environmental chemicals. The study "did raise a legitimate concern that should be followed up, but there's no way on earth that study could be considered definitive," said Dr. Neil MacLusky, a researcher in reproductive endocrinology at the University of Toronto Medical School. "They say the most likely explanation is an environmental factor, but there's no way they can control for patterns of sexual activity in the last 40 years, or levels of sexually transmitted diseases. These factors could just as easily be responsible for changes in sperm count."
 
'Serious Long-Term Threat'
 Nevertheless, Dr. MacLusky considers that environmental contaminants in general are "a very serious long-term threat not just to animals but to all vertebrate life."
Dr. Stephen Safer, a toxicologist at Texas A & M University, demurs, arguing that the synthetic estrogens are far weaker than natural estrogens both in the body and in the environment. The synthetics, he says, would be "swamped out" by a "whole huge spectrum" of natural estrogens and anti-estrogens. "But," he added, "it's still an area of concern; I don't want to sweep it under the rug or anything like that."
Dr. Lynn Goldman, an environmental epidemiologist who is the assistant administrator for prevention, pesticides and toxic substances at the E.P.A., may speak for many when she says that at this stage of the scientific investigation, "I think the data would argue that we are seeing some effects" of endocrine disruptors in the environment.
But for now science simply does not know enough to say just how serious a threat they pose.

Diagram: "Shifting Cycles Of Pollution"
 A case study of the Great Lakes shows that different species metabolize chemicals in different ways and that the mix of chemicals constantly changes from time to time and from place to place.
 The owl preys on the tern, a species that feeds on small lake fishes.
 The pollution-tolerant Great Lakes herring gull has made a dramatic population recovery from the effects of DDT.
 The bald eagle preys on ducks, which get contaminants from fish and plants that live in polluted sediment.
 The peregrine falcon, a duck hawk, joins the owl and eagle at the top of the food chain.
 The otter feeds on fish, including bottom-dwelling species, and is very sensitive to effects of PCB's.
 The cormorant feeds on forage fish like the alewife, a high-fat fish that accumulates contaminants.
 Large predatory fish consume smaller forage fish.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Choice

 BODY:
Although Sunday's presidential election in Mexico was not as clean as it should have been, on present evidence it was the cleanest in living memory. That should give President-elect Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon the mandate he needs to carry political and economic reform through its difficult next phase.
A credible Mexican election is also a relief for the U.S. Immigration, border commerce and the North American Free Trade Agreement increasingly link the fates of North America's two giants. 
 Despite heavy spending on electoral safeguards and intense international scrutiny, there were embarrassing incidents. Some people could not get ballots. Others complained that voting secrecy had been compromised. Independent monitors reported instances of multiple voting. But preliminary figures suggest so wide a margin for Mr. Zedillo, of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, that hanky-panky is unlikely to have affected the outcome.
As of late yesterday, official returns from more than a third of the polling stations gave Mr. Zedillo around 48 percent of the vote, Diego Fernandez de Cevallos of the National Action Party around 30 percent and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the Democratic Revolutionary Party around 16 percent. In Congress, the combined opposition will come close to a majority in the new lower house. If the main opposition parties can find a way to work together on legislative issues, they could introduce a measure of pluralism into Mexican political life.
Mr. Zedillo has up to now been known as a technocrat and economic reformer. But it is increasingly evident that economic reform cannot go forward unless it marches in tandem with political liberalization. The wrenching changes Mexico has been going through demand a government with the kind of legitimacy the PRI lost years ago. Regaining that legitimacy requires accountability, checks and balances, openness and decentralization.
A powerful, autocratic President like Carlos Salinas de Gortari could sell off state companies, oust union bosses, renegotiate bank debt and secure Nafta. But for investors, entrepreneurs and consumers to make the new market structures work for Mexico requires that power be decentralized and government made accountable to its citizens.
To achieve that, Mr. Zedillo will have to challenge the PRI bosses and bureaucrats with whom Mr. Salinas chose to coexist. In their place, he will have to develop new constituencies among reform's beneficiaries -- not just obvious winners like big business, but also urban consumers and workers who fear the insecurities of a market economy as much as they appreciate its benefits.
If Mr. Zedillo identifies himself with political reform, he could draw support from the independent civic organizations that sprang up to monitor this year's vote. He could make a good start by following through on campaign pledges to reform the PRI, particularly by democratizing the way it chooses candidates. Past Presidents have kept the choice of nominees under tight personal control.
Clean elections are only a first step toward political reform, but an essential first step.

HEADLINE: Medisave Appeals to Low-Income Employees;
Healthier and Wealthier

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Don't Be Seduced by Medisave" (editorial, Aug. 16) contains inaccuracies about medical savings accounts. But most surprising is your lack of understanding about how markets work. 
 The Business Coalition for Affordable Health Care, which represents 900,000 businesses participating in markets every day, believes medical savings accounts will help alleviate health care inflation, the root of many reasons for health care reform.
Medical savings accounts are working well in a number of companies, although without the favorable tax treatment that would make them even more desirable and widespread.
NBC News reported on medical savings accounts at Forbes magazine and found employees happier, healthier and wealthier because of their medical savings accounts. Forbes has dramatically reduced its health care costs in an era when such costs for businesses have increased an average of 13 percent a year.
We see medical savings accounts as an opportunity to (1) reduce health care costs for employers; (2) improve the benefits we offer our employees, and (3) preserve and extend consumer choices. Medical savings accounts create incentives for employees to use health care efficiently and appropriately. That's good for employees, for employers and for all Americans.
 
KEVIN L. KEARNS
Chairman, Business Coalition
for Affordable Health Care
Washington, Aug. 17, 1994

HEADLINE: Good News Looks Bad

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Top economic officials are frustrated that the Clinton Administration has not received more credit for recent economic growth. The reason is simple. The Federal Reserve Board's perverse logic has conditioned investors, economic analysts and everyone else to view growth not as a boon but as a dire portent of inflation and higher interest rates. Nowadays, good news is bad news. The Administration cannot receive credit where credit is due.
 
LOUIS JAY HERMAN
New York, Aug. 17, 1994

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW -- U.S. Scrambling to Cope With the Rising Tide of Cuban Refugees;
Washington Considers Housing Newcomers at Mainland Sutes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Alarmed that its new policy of keeping out Cuban boat people has failed to stem the flow of refugees, the Clinton Administration is considering greatly expanding the capacity of the naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to handle them.
With the flood of Cubans picked up at sea exceeding 2,000 for the second straight day, some Administration officials said they might be forced to consider an emergency option: placing the Cubans in military bases and other Federal properties on the mainland, as was done during the Mariel exodus of 1980 when 125,000 Cubans left for the United States. 
 At a White House meeting this afternoon, senior officials discussed what to do if the exodus of Cubans did not slow down. One option was expanding Guantanamo's capacity to accommodate more than 16,000 Cubans and to rapidly open "safe havens" for Cubans in countries around the Caribbean. They said that negotiations to establish such havens were going well, but they did not announce any agreements.
More than 7,000 refugees have been picked up since Friday. Under the Administration's contingency planning, Guantanamo and the safe havens are expected to accommodate between 20,000 to 25,000 refugees.
In a development that Administration officials found ominous, more and more Cubans are arriving in small boats, rather than rafts, signaling that the Cuban Government may be letting Cubans leave in larger craft than the ones used a week ago.
White House officials say they continue to hope that President Clinton's decision to deny entry to Cubans will staunch the refugee flow before the available places are filled. The Coast Guard said that 2,886 Cuban refugees had been picked up in the Florida Straits as of 10 P.M. On Monday, American ships picked up 2,548 refugees, the largest daily amount since the Mariel boatlift.
"It's not clear why the Cubans aren't reacting the way we expected," said a State Department official.
Given the trend, the Administration has begun to plan for accommodating an outpouring well beyond the worst projections of last week. At the same time, U.S. officials say they are worried that any move that could be construed as giving hope to would-be immigrants would undermine efforts to persuade Cubans to remain at home.
 
Sticking With the Plan
 President Clinton was briefed today on the Cuba situation by Sandy Berger, the deputy national security adviser. Administration officials said that at a White House meeting this afternoon on Cuba, senior officials decided to stick with the new policy of turning away refugees.
Officials are trying to slow the refugee flow by accelerating plans to expand radio and television broadcasts that will urge Cubans not to set to sea.
Administration officials also said today that they planned to increase ways for Cubans to migrate legally to the United States by applying within Cuba. One plan is to allow Cubans with relatives in the United States to be taken off a waiting list so that they would be allowed to migrate during the next few months.
Immigration experts said that such measures would not affect a large number of Cubans and were unlikely to have much effect on the recent exodus of Cuban boat people.
The Administration is also considering expanding the number of categories -- such as being imprisoned for political views -- under which Cubans could qualify for refugee status. These moves are intended to demonstrate that the Administration is sincere about urging Cubans who want to immigrate to apply at processing facilities in Cuba.
"If you get 150,000 people coming out of Cuba, you may have to look at all kinds of options," said an Administration official.
 
A Political Risk
 One option under consideration is to revive parts of a classified contingency plan developed during the 1980's after the Mariel boatlift. It calls for, among other things, distributing Cuban refugees around the United States so that Florida is not unduly burdened. Under that plan, many Cuban refugees would be detained at Federal sites until the Administration figures out when and where to release them.
Such a move would undoubtedly be a political hot potato for the President and for many governors, who remember an incident that helped cause Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas to lose his race for re-election in 1980. Several hundred Cuban refugees who were taken to Fort Chaffee in Arkansas rioted, injuring several military police officers. About 200 Cubans escaped but were captured.
Several officials said that after the Administration vowed in recent days not to allow Cuban boat people into the country, they would be reluctant to reverse that policy and place the Cubans on the mainland. A senior White House official said tonight: "The President's not going to do that. It's not on the table." Indeed, one official said the President might favor returning refugees directly to Cuba before he would accept them into the United States.
Another option, Administration officials said, is to expand Guantanamo's capacity by clearing unused, scrub-covered parts of the base's beachfront to hold tents and sleeping bags.
Fourteen thousand Haitians are being held in one portion of the Guantanamo Base, and the Administration has said that within days it will expand the base's capacity so it can hold about 10,000 Cuban refugees.
Nonetheless, Pentagon officials said that it that would be extremely difficult to prepare Guantanamo for tens of thousands more refugees because of problems providing water and sewage disposal.
One Defense Department official said the Pentagon might soon send additional security and medical personnel to Guantanamo to handle the increase of refugees at the base, which usually houses 5,000 military and civilian workers and their dependents.
Administration officials say they hope that within the next week or two, they will receive permission to place up to 10,000 Cubans in safe havens around the Caribbean. To accommodate the Cubans, the Administration is rushing to renegotiate agreements with nations that had previously promised to temporarily shelter for Haitian refugees. Brunson McKinley, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Refugee Programs, is visiting Caribbean capitals this week to discuss safe havens.
 
Havens in the Caribbean
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said today that Surinam and Dominica had each previously agreed to hold 2,500 Haitians, while St. Lucia said it would accept 5,000. She said Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica and El Salvador have said "they will be willing to explore the possibility" of housing Cubans. Other countries that have been approached to hold Cubans are Antigua, Grenada, Panama and Britain's Turks and Caicos Islands.
Although the flood of refugees has become a headache for the Administration, officials said today that they were optimistic that turmoil created by the exodus would pressure Fidel Castro to adopt political and economic reforms.
"If you get a lot of people starting to move, and it backs up, that could create an uncomfortable situation for Castro," one State Department official said. "There's a lot more privation in Cuba than there was during Mariel and there's much more willingness now to challenge the regime."

HEADLINE: Resurgence in Export Trade Invigorates Port of New York

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J.

 BODY:
As long as three football fields, its decks piled with so much foreign cargo that it looked like a floating warehouse, the freighter Raleigh Bay plodded into a dock here the other day for a stopover that once might have been decidedly lopsided: imports off, nothing back on.
But this time, in an increasingly common sight at the Port of New York and New Jersey, the ship took on a heartland's worth of American products, from chemicals to animal feed to medical supplies. It was another indication that the export business, dormant for years, is revitalizing a port that had begun to slip from the ranks of the world's great maritime centers. 
 Since 1985, the volume of exports of containerized cargo from New York Harbor has jumped about 53 percent, from 2.68 million long tons to 4.10 million long tons. (A long ton, the traditional measure of shipping, is 2,240 pounds; a regular ton is 2,000 pounds.) The value of that cargo, an indicator that underscores the port's influence on the region's economy, rose from $9.59 billion to $17.14 billion, a 32 percent increase after inflation is factored in.
The port is snatching back export cargo from the Midwest and Canada that it had lost to rivals like Baltimore; Philadelphia; Norfolk, Va.; Charleston, S.C., and Halifax, Nova Scotia. It has reclaimed customers like General Motors, which has consolidated all its exporting to Europe in Newark, shipping 35,000 vehicles a year, most of which are assembled in the Midwest.
The turnabout has been a boon for a maritime industry that remains a powerful economic engine in the region; the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey estimates that the port handled $56.31 billion in cargo last year, directly or indirectly generating 180,800 jobs.
Before the recent climb in exports, the port was considered dangerously dependent on import traffic -- delivering stereos and beer and countless other foreign wares to the 17 million consumers within a day's drive of Elizabeth and Newark, the two cities where shipping activity has been concentrated since the advent of containerized operations in the 1960's.
The port's new strength to some extent reflects the overall increase in the country's export business and a decline in the value of the dollar, which depresses the price of American products. Factories across the nation are churning out higher-quality goods, like Detroit's new generation of vehicles, which are luring more and more buyers in foreign lands.
 
Fighting a Reputation
 
 
But perhaps just as important have been the efforts by the Port of New York and New Jersey to shed its reputation as a rickety giant that was falling behind in a business being transformed by technology.
"We as a country and as a port have to learn that there is a tremendous opportunity for us in the export marketplace," said Lillian C. Liburdi, director of port operations at the Port Authority. "What we are really seeing now is the result of us going after that business more thoughtfully and more aggressively."
For centuries, New York Harbor dominated the country's maritime commerce, dealing in imports and exports in roughly equal measure, sending off goods that poured out of the many factories that were the bedrock of the Northeast's economy. But with the steep decline in manufacturing in the region in recent decades, as well as competition from lower-cost ports that were quicker to modernize, the Port of New York and New Jersey suffered.
 
Competition From Railways
 Exports fell to 10 to 20 percent of its trade in the late 1970's and early 1980's, officials said. At the same time, imports dropped as companies discovered that instead of shipping products from eastern Asia to the East Coast through the Panama Canal, they could save money by shipping them to the West Coast and use new, advanced railways for the rest of the journey.
Deregulation of the nation's transportation industries in the 1970's also sliced into the port's revenues. New trading patterns arose as manufacturers were able to choose the cheapest and fastest routes from among dozens of trucking lines, railroads and ports, many of which were actively courting customers.
"It has become quite clear to ports big and small that there is precious little cargo that is naturally linked to their ports," said Erik Stromberg, president of the American Association of Port Authorities. "The competitive dynamics have actually gone much farther afield than was ever envisioned when surface transportation was deregulated 15 years ago. We have a situation where ports are looking to grab cargo literally from the backyard of other port cities."
 
No Longer Top Port
 This revamping of the shipping business stripped the Port of New York and New Jersey of its standing as the nation's top port in terms of value and volume of containerized cargo, pushing it to second or third, after Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif.
And even though the port was still handling tens of billions of dollars in cargo, some experts predicted that its decline would continue because its terminals were outmoded, its productivity low and its costs excessive.
The Port Authority has responded by investing hundreds of millions of dollars in technology, including new railway links, a crucial addition in an era when most cargo moves in 20- or 40-foot containers that are put directly from freighters onto trucks and trains -- all the while tracked by computers.
The agency has improved its marketing and relations with government, shipping companies and manufacturers. Seeking to make up for the drop in export cargo that mirrored the decline in the Northeast's industrial base, it has wooed business from other areas of the country by offering discounts for goods that originate more than 260 miles away.
 
Labor Situation Improves
 There have also been improvements in the notoriously inefficient labor situation at the port, a legacy of the days when the longshoremen's union had to be guaranteed jobs before it would allow more mechanized operations.
"We are very pleased to say that they have made some pretty significant changes there over the past four or five years," said John J. Baisley, director of international transportation for General Motors, which ships 30 percent of its exports through the port. "The Port Authority has really made a concerted effort to get business back."
Other companies like Mazda and Pfizer, the pharmaceuticals manufacturer, are also using the port more.
As a result of these moves, trade in containerized cargo has remained level at the port over the last decade, ranging from 10 million to 13 million long tons, as exports have replaced imports that were depressed because of the rise of the West Coast ports.
 
380% of North Atlantic Trade
 Still, it seems unlikely that the port will soon return to the days of the 1960's, when it held well over 60 percent of the North Atlantic trade. Now, officials say, the port handles about 38 percent of the North Atlantic trade for containerized cargo and certain other goods, like autos and steel.
Philadelphia has about 21 percent of that business; Norfolk, 19 percent, and Baltimore, 16 percent.
Many manufacturers and transportation companies still consider the port a mess, citing numerous problems, from the delays that trucks encounter on New Jersey's roadways to fears about the involvement of mobsters to environmental disputes over the dredging of New York Harbor, which keeps the shipping channels clear for huge freighters.
"We would still prefer not to use the Port of New York if we can avoid it," said Stanley Filipiak, director of transportation for National Starch and Chemical Company, based in Bridgewater, N.J. "Coming from the Midwest, it's usually less expensive going through Baltimore, even if New York is closer. It's a hassle as far as New York is concerned. The access is so antiquated."
 
A Better Balance
 Despite such criticisms, the spurt in exports appears to be making the port a more attractive hub for transportation companies, which had often complained that a balance of trade heavily tilted toward imports was inefficient for them because they hauled cargo in only one direction.
In the early 1980's, a freighter like the Raleigh Bay, which is owned by Sea-Land Service, might have earned money carrying pasta and glassware and perfume to New York, but then made little returning directly to Spain and Italy because it picked up few goods here. This year, exporting has been so profitable for Sea-Land that it has added an extra weekly stopover here.
The port's rivals, once the beneficiaries of its woes, have noted its resurgence.
"There has been more diversion of our cargo through the U.S., particularly through New York," said David F. Bellefontaine, president of the Halifax Port Corporation. "That affects our competitive position. I would rather have a competitor that is in a state of disarray, like New York used to be."
Given the huge demand for imports in the region, the port will probably not attain a 50-50 ratio between imports and exports any time soon. But the percentage of exports has climbed to between 30 percent and 35 percent for containerized cargo, from 10 to 20 percent, and could reach nearly 40 percent by the end of the decade, said Michael L. Sclar, an analyst at the consulting firm of DRI/ McGraw-Hill.
Port officials and executives at transportation companies said they hoped that a more balanced trade here will become permanent, because that, they maintained, would send ripples throughout the region's economy.
"The average person has no idea what export volume means to the economy," said R. Gregory Moore, general manager at Newark for the Maersk steamship company, which runs six vessels a week into New York harbor, each capable of carrying several thousand containers.
"There are a lot of people that are involved: trucking companies, distribution companies, manufacturing companies," he said. "It's not only the people who work in the terminals and with the carriers. Increased exports increase jobs."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: CHARTER FLIGHTS;
Despite Clinton's Order, Travelers Going to Island

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Charter flights have continued flying to Cuba despite President Clinton's weekend announcement that he was halting them to punish Fidel Castro for encouraging refugees to escape the island.
The delay in implementing his order was forced by the need to work out new regulations on air travel between Miami and Havana, Treasury Department officials said today. 
 The department's Foreign Assets Control Office, which oversees restrictions on travel to Cuba, has been working on the regulations and is scheduled to publish them on Wednesday, officials said.
Meanwhile, Cuban-Americans rushed to book tickets on a flight scheduled to leave Wednesday. Ten charter flights a week carry about 65,000 round-trip passengers a year to Cuba, said Francisco Aruca, who runs Marazul Charters, one of three companies authorized to operate flights to Cuba. About 40,000 of these passengers live in the United States. The rest are Cubans with American visas allowing them to visit the United States, he said.
 
Other Travelers From U.S.
 In addition to Cubans with families on the island, those permitted to visit the island are journalists, professional researchers and scholars, official government travelers and "sponsored travelers," those whose trips are paid for by Cuba or another nation.
While the Treasury Department declined to say how travel would be restricted, speculation in Miami was that travel by Cuban-Americans would be sharply reduced except for humanitarian reasons, such as for the illness or death of a family member.
Travelers who leave this week or are already in Cuba will probably return to Miami aboard a few planes allowed to fly to Havana after Wednesday, Mr. Aruca said.
Hundreds of Cuban-Americans who have already booked reservations for future flights were left in doubt. "We're supposed to go next week," said Irene Fernandez, a 31-year-old nurse in Key West, who for the past week had helped treat Cuban refugees escaping by sea from Cuba.
 
Money to Cuba at Stake
 She and others waited for the other shoe to drop on the Presidential edict. "Is he really taking all the trips off?" she asked. "If so, who can go?" She and others said if direct charter flights were grounded they might attempt to get into Cuba through third countries like Mexico.
New rules are also expected on the amount of money sent from the United States to Cuba. Under present regulations the limit on money sent to a Cuban household is $280 a quarter.
"If they prohibit sending money from here it's going to be worse," said Milton Serret of Cuba Paquetes, a Miami agency that ships cash and packages. He said that if similar agencies opened in another country the United States would lose control over how much cash is sent.
The President on Saturday prohibited Americans from sending cash to Cuba and said he was cutting off charter flight as a way to deprive Mr. Castro of hard currency and weaken an already shaky economy.
Mr. Aruco's agency flies a 123-seat Boeing 727 jet on the 45-minute flight to Cuba on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, he said, usually at 80 percent capacity.
 
Political Move Is Seen
 His company originated the first charter flights to Havana in 1979 after a dialogue between Mr. Castro and Cuban exiles led to bilateral easing of tensions between the two countries. He said he felt the new hard-line policies embraced by Mr. Clinton in reaction to the new wave of refugees trying to reach the United States from Cuba was motivated more by politics than anything else.
"I have no doubt this decision was made to help Lawton Chiles this year and Mr. Clinton in 1996," he asserted.
Mr. Chiles, the Democratic Governor of Florida, is in a tough re-election race. The President would benefit in the 1996campaign if a Democrat is governing the state, with 25 electoral votes.
Mr. Aruca also suggested that Mr. Chiles and the President were wooing right-wing Cuban-American interests by making life more difficult for Mr. Castro. Right-wing elements have targeted Mr. Aruca and his travel agency since 1979 as a sympathizer of Mr. Castro's regime.
 
Violence Aimed at Him
 "To be called a pro-Communist in America is not dangerous," he said. "But in Miami it is a death sentence."
Two pipe bombs exploded outside his office in 1989. He said he is regularly assailed by right-wing Cuban radio commentators.
Yet, Cuban-Americans longing for a brief return home from exile have been flying with him for 15 years. Mr. Aruca feels the impact of the passenger traffic between Miami and Havana has been telling. He said the first year of charter flights sent 100,000 exiles back to Cuba for a visit, carrying gifts to impoverished relatives.
"The next year what happened?" he asks. "The Mariel boatlift! All those Cubans got a taste of what life was like in America by seeing how well off their exiled relatives were."
Mr. Castro's reaction to "the headaches" caused by Cuban-American travelers was to sharply curtail the number granted visas, Mr. Aruca said. From 1980 to 1985, Cuba cut back sharply on the number of visitors from the United States, while the cost of a one-week package doubled to $1,500, including mandatory payments to Government-operated hotels, Mr. Aruca said. "He wanted the hard currency, exchanged at an official rate of one peso for one dollar, but he didn't want the social unrest the visitors caused," he said.
 
Dollars Make Difference
 When Radio Marti began broadcasting to Cuba from the United States in 1986, Mr. Castro retaliated by cutting travelers on family visits down to 50 a week, a level gradually increased to 96 by 1993 when negotiations increased it by 500 a week.
Another important difference made by the visitors came when they were permitted to send or carry dollars to relatives in Cuba, Mr. Aruca said. The United States limited the amount to $280 every three months for each household, he said.

HEADLINE: Outside Income for British M.P.'s Is Questioned

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
As a consultant to a Scottish electricity company, Philip Gallie keeps it up to date on what is happening in the House of Commons and sets up meetings with legislators. The company, Scottish Power P.L.C., pays him an undisclosed fee -- probably around $15,000 a year -- and gives him use of a company car.
But the consulting job is just a sideline for Mr. Gallie. He is better known as the Member of Parliament for Ayr, on Scotland's west coast, and for serving on the Select Committee on Scottish Affairs. 
 Although the practice is now coming under growing scrutiny, the fact that Mr. Gallie is on Scottish Power's payroll even as he serves his constituents as a legislator at nearly $50,000 a year is neither illegal nor even unusual in British politics.
"I'm very pleased to do the work I do with Scottish Power," said Mr. Gallie, a Conservative, who was employed by the company for 28 years before being elected to Parliament in 1992. "At all times it's clearly understood that my constituents come first."
 
Disclosed in Official Register
 Allowed to cultivate nearly any business relationships they wish as long as they are publicly disclosed in an official register, members of Parliament, especially from the governing Conservative Party, routinely sign on as advisers or consultants to corporations, trade groups and lobbying enterprises.
Unlike their counterparts in the United States Congress, who are barred from having any outside earned income and who face limits on gifts and speaking fees, British M.P.'s also continue to practice law, run companies, write newspaper columns or do whatever other work they have time and inclination for. The exception is Government ministers, who must end their outside business deals.
The 1,200 members of the unelected House of Lords, which has little legislative power, have no limits on outside work, and the only disclosure requirement they face is to identify any relevant outside interests when speaking during debates.
The British practice dates back to a time when a seat in Parliament was a part-time commitment in a country that eschewed professional politicians. It has grown in recent years as the old class and school ties that once bound Government and industry leaders in an old-boy network have broken down, leaving companies and trade groups scrambling for information and access.
Given the intermingling of money and politics in the corridors of Westminster, there have been remarkably few influence-peddling scandals. Perhaps that is because few M.P.'s have any real say in policy making -- the Prime Minister and his Cabinet do that -- and because M.P.'s are expected to vote as directed by their party.
 
Reporters Pose as Executives
 But the subject burst into the news again recently when The Sunday Times of London sent two reporters into the halls of Parliament posing as business executives who needed help getting information from the Government.
The reporters asked 20 M.P.'s to submit a written question to the Government on behalf of their companies, and offered 1,000, or about $1,500, for their trouble. Eighteen of the M.P.'s declined, suggesting for the most part that the businessmen go to their local M.P. for help, but two, both members of the Conservative Party, accepted the offer. Both men, Graham Riddick and David Tredinnick, subsequently returned the checks sent to them, and denied they had done anything improper.
The case led Prime Minister John Major to call for a parliamentary investigation into the matter, and reopened a debate over the responsibilities of M.P.'s and conflicts of interest.
"The wider question bears very heavily on the relationship between Parliament and the community," said Philip Norton, a professor of government at the University of Hull. "Are members of Parliament representing the interests of constituents or are they spending a lot of their time seeking rewards for themselves?"
 
No Inclination to Change
 Parliament has debated the issue a number of times, and starting this year has required members to be more specific in listing their outside ties in the annual Register of Members' Interests.
But Parliament has shown no inclination to change the system significantly, and critics of the practice say there is little chance of wholesale reform now. Many members argue that the salary from Parliament is inadequate, even with supplements for travel, housing in London and office staff, and that cutting off outside ties would drive qualified people away from public service.
"The problem fundamentally is that there are a lot of people in Westminster who have dug in deep with outside interests and are not prepared to give it up without a fight," said Dale N. Campbell-Savours, an opposition Labor Party M.P. who has long sought tighter restrictions but considers a ban on all outside financial ties unrealistic.
The practice remains most prevalent by far among the Conservatives, who have the benefit of being in political power as well as being ideologically in tune with the corporate world.
Most Labor M.P.'s receive campaign contributions in the range of $1,000 and other support, like donated office space or use of researchers, from unions. But they do not receive money personally from the unions.
 
Amounts Not Disclosed
 Members of Parliament are not required to specify how much they make from their outside business relationships, but many of the 650 members of the House of Commons pull down tens of thousands of dollars a year in extra income. Of the 650, 182 listed themselves as paid advisers or consultants in the annual Register of Members' Interests. Scores more are directors of companies and essentially serve the same purpose.
According to the Register of Members' Interests in the House of Commons and company reports, Peter Ainsworth, a Conservative, is a director of JLI Group, a food company, and a Parliamentary consultant to S. G. Warburg, one of Britain's largest investment banks. Jack Aspinwall, a Conservative, is parliamentary consultant to British Gas, the utility company; BAA, the company that operates Britain's airports, and Rentokil, a pest control and environmental cleanup company.
Patrick Nicholls, a former low-level Government minister, has signed on as parliamentary adviser or consultant to no fewer than nine organizations, including the British Shops and Stores Association, the Minotels Europe Group hotel chain and Hill & Smith Holdings, a large manufacturer of steel and other metal products.
Until he was appointed to the Government this month to a major Government transportation job, John Watts, a Conservative, was an adviser to British Bus P.L.C., which operates bus lines around the country.
In part, the willingness of Parliament to allow near total freedom to sell access and expertise seems to stem from a deeply held belief that members are all "honorable," as they like to call each other, and that all will keep duty to Queen and country, not to mention their constituents, above mere pecuniary gain.
 
'We Are the Least Corrupt'
 Many British politicians maintain that the system is far less abused than campaign fund-raising practices in the United States, and that they are far less prone to corruption than counterparts in other countries.
"I believe that compared with any other parliament or democratic assembly in the world, we are the least corrupt," Sir Geoffrey Johnson Smith, the Conservative who heads the Select Committee on Members' Interests, said at a Parliament hearing last year.
Mr. Gallie, the M.P. who is paid by Scottish Power, has faced questions about his relationship with the company from Labor legislators. They have criticized his support for a plan by Scottish Power to build large power transmission pylons across a neighboring district despite the opposition of some residents.
Mr. Gallie said the pylons were part of a plan by Scottish Power to export electricity to Northern Ireland, a plan that he said would create jobs in Scotland. He said his support for the plan was based on the economic interests of his constituents and of Scotland, not on what is best for Scottish Power.
 
Making Up Salary Difference
 In an interview, Mr. Gallie declined to say how much he is paid by Scottish Power, though he did say that it is substantially less than the rumored $30,000 a year. He said the amount represents the difference between his salary up until 1992 as a power station manager for the company, before his election to Parliament, and his current $50,000 salary as an M.P. Lobbyists said $15,000 a year would be a common payment from a big company to an M.P. hired as a consultant.
For his money, Mr. Gallie said, he provides Scottish Power with information about legislation, advises the company about whom to make contact with about particular issues in the Government and the bureaucracy and occasionally arranges meetings.
His constituents benefit because when they have a problem or question regarding Scottish Power, he can get quick action, he said.
"I see no reason why people shouldn't use their talents in some way as long as they put their constituents first," Mr. Gallie said. "If money were to be the only criteria, a lot of people with talent wouldn't make the financial sacrifice to come to the House of Commons."

HEADLINE: Embargo Dries Up Haiti Fuel Supply

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The sweating and ragged men and women who sell gasoline in the black market on the side of the road here have a saying: you never appreciate the tail of a donkey until you try to catch one running downhill.
In one more absurdity in an absurd place and time, the United States and relief groups may have to rely on this market to power hospital generators and the trucks that take food and medicine to Haiti's poor in a nation slowly being squeezed dry by an international embargo. 
 The United States, which is trying to put soldiers on the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic to stop the flow of smuggled gasoline and diesel fuel, and whose warships prowl offshore to stop other fuel from being slipped into the country, might have to buy smuggled fuel in the name of relief.
 
'Can't Let People Starve'
 "We can't let people starve," said Stanley Schrager, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince. "These are crucial programs, and we will not let these programs die."
The money would have to come from special appropriations, he said.
The problem is that the Haitian Government, while not formally seizing or illegally stealing it, has refused to release some 500,000 gallons of fuel donated by the United States and other countries for relief purposes.
The feeding centers and hospitals have fuel for a few more days, and some perhaps for a few weeks. But if the fuel is not released soon, or if the military government seizes it for its own use, as some relief workers fear, Washington will have to find another source, Mr. Schrager said.
The smuggled gasoline is the only option. Mr. Schrager refuses to call it black-market fuel, choosing instead to call it "spot market."
Regardless of the term, the United States Embassy has been buying the fuel to run its cars and for other needs for weeks now. There is nowhere else.
When asked why the United States does not simply let more fuel into the country, he replied, "If you lift the embargo, you will never get the military out."
 
Embargo Brings Suffering
 And the United Nations embargo is working, people in the streets say, if you rate success by how much people are suffering.
Even as a spotlight in the Caribbean shifts to the flood of refugees from Cuba, the tensions here are increasing. Now, even the wealthiest Haitians are beginning to grumble about runaway food prices, shortages and wildly rising inflation. "There is no one here tonight to drink," said one Haitian bar owner, a member of the country's elite, "because there is no gas to get here."
For perhaps the first time, it is becoming clear that the embargo is affecting all parts of the society, Mr. Schrager said. "And creating a rising level of frustration," he added.
The inflation rate is dizzying. From the traditional 5 Haitian gourdes to the American dollar, the currency's value fell to more than 23 gourdes to the dollar in just a few weeks.
And the phenomenon shows no sign of stopping. While Government officials have refused to comment on it, people in all of Haiti's economic classes say it is only a matter of time -- perhaps a few weeks -- before the economy begins to collapse.
In the last two months, the price of gasoline has skyrocketed from roughly $2.50 a gallon to $8 and climbing, so expensive that most of the tap-taps, as the taxis are known, simply no longer run. The roads are clogged not with cars but with people, many of them well-dressed members of the middle class who walk as far as five miles to work.
 
Military Hoards Gasoline
 The military is hoarding its own supply of gasoline, but the civilians have to buy theirs on the market.
"Wouldn't it be funny," said one middle-class Haitian, who spoke on condition of anonymity, "if the rich people and the poor people got so mad they joined together and tossed the military out?"
There are now signs of impatience in the city's slums, and continuing signs of fragmentation in the ranks of the civilian supporters of the military junta.
Earlier this week, plainclothes supporters of the military government went through the slum called Cite Soleil, beating people with sticks and threatening them with guns and machetes, apparently because there had been rumors of a coming uprising.
And on Sunday, two pro-military gunmen, referred to here as attaches, were found dead in one of the slums, their arms bound behind their backs and shot in the head.
But some Haitians said it was more than likely that the men had been killed by other attaches because of some internal dispute than by people loyal to the Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide, the President who was chased out of the country by a coup in September 1991.
"But it shows," said one Haitian, who asked not to be identified, "that things are getting more difficult, for everyone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite an international oil embargo, gasoline was being sold openly yesterday in plastic containers along the side of the street in Port-au-Prince. United States relief groups say they may have to start buying the smuggled gas soon in order to keep up the flow of food and medicine to Haiti's poor. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)
