HEADLINE: On Campus;
Study of Sign Language Booming at Rochester

 BODY:
After Spanish and French, the most popular foreign language at the University of Rochester is American Sign Language.
More than 120 sophomores, juniors and seniors have already pre-registered for American Sign Language 101, filling six sections and squeezing out most freshmen. 
 The number exceeds the number of students enrolled in German, Italian, Russian, Arabic, Hebrew, Japanese, Greek and Latin, said Ted Supalla, the director of Rochester's sign-language program. The number of sign-language courses has more than doubled over the past two years.
Two years of studying sign language satisfies the university's foreign-language requirement, but students and teachers say the interest stems from other factors: a desire to communicate with the large deaf community in Rochester, home to the National Institute of Technology for the Deaf; careers in health or social services, or simply a new challenge.
Only a handful of colleges and universities around the country offer extensive sign-language programs. Rochester began its program in 1988 with one part-time instructor. There are now four instructors, a translator and two administrators.
Except for the very first day, all classes are taught entirely in sign language. Second-year classes teach students how to conduct more complex conversations, and there are upper-level courses in the history and culture of sign language, sociolinguistics and literature. This fall, a deaf graduate student from Japan will teach Japanese Sign Language.
The university also now has a sign language club.
"I know Spanish and French have practical uses," said one of the club's founders, Jill C. Bernstein, a junior majoring in an interdisciplinary program called health and society. "But you don't see people around campus speaking Spanish or French. I see people sitting at tables in the student union signing all the time."
 
UMass Freezes Tuition and Fees
 The University of Massachusetts at Amherst has frozen tuition and mandatory fees for the first time in 29 years after an intense lobbying effort by students, parents and school officials succeeded in getting the State Legislature to allocate more money for higher education.
Students at the university, one of the most expensive state universities in the country, had been protesting the continually rising costs -- by more than 25 percent in some years -- and one day in February they occupied the admissions building for nearly 20 hours to demand a tuition freeze.
The administration responded by agreeing to keep tuition and fees at $5,467 a year, the same as 1993-94, if the Legislature would increase state aid by at least the amount of the rise in the cost of living.
The students then took on the Legislature.
"We called all the parents of all the students who live in districts represented by members of the House Ways and Means Committee," said Mirran Raphaely, a 20-year-old junior from Worcester, Mass., who is president of the university's Student Government Association. "We got 4,000 parents to say they would call."
It worked. A $6.3 million increase in state appropriations was needed to freeze tuition at the university's Amherst campus. The five-campus system got an increase of $15 million.
 
Truth in Grades, Dartmouth Style
 While Stanford University has taken on grade inflation by bringing back the failing grade and giving more C's and D's, Dartmouth College is trying another approach: more information on report cards.
Beginning this fall with the class of '98, the college will include class size and median grades on students' transcripts. Grade inflation on the Hanover, N.H., campus has been gradual, to 3.23 in 1992-93 from 3.06 in 1976-77, on a 4.0 scale.
"Grades, without putting them into some sort of context, mean little," said Gary Johnson, a chemistry professor and the chairman of a faculty committee that proposed the change.
But some professors said the new system, based on one used at McGill University in Montreal, would increase competition among students. It will "pit one student against another," Delo Mook, a physics professor, told The Dartmouth, the daily student newspaper. "I don't think that's something we want to encourage."
One student leader said it was a worthy idea, but the wrong approach. "I think bringing institutions like Dartmouth back to a point where you are actually earning a grade, not getting a grade, but really working and learning and earning a grade is important," said the summer student-body president, Grace Chionuma, a 19-year-old junior. "But I think that struggle begins with the faculty, it doesn't begin with the student transcripts. This seems a very roundabout way of getting to a central issue."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN HAVANA;
Silent Castro Puzzling U.S. Aides

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 23

 BODY:
After encouraging an immigration crisis with the United States by permitting disgruntled Cubans to take to the high seas, Fidel Castro has suddenly and unexpectedly fallen silent, raising concerns about what additional moves he might be planning.
Normally not a man at a loss for words, the Cuban leader has made no significant public statements since President Clinton announced on Saturday that Cuban-Americans will no longer be allowed to visit or send remittances to relatives on the island and that anti-Castro broadcasts to Cuba will be increased. 
 The few pronouncements out of Havana in recent days have come from lower-ranking officials and do not directly address the Clinton Administration measures.
Mr. Castro's uncharacteristic reticence has both American officials and other Cuba analysts baffled. They say that he probably did not expect the Clinton Administration to respond with harsh punitive measures to his threat to unleash another uncontrolled exodus of Cuban refugees on Florida, and is pondering what to do next.
 
Response Is Studied
 "The Cubans tend to respond relatively rapidly to things," one State Department official said today. "On the other hand, the fact that they have not said much of anything may be an indication that they are reflecting on how they should respond."
Wayne Smith, a former head of the United States Interests Section in Havana, said, "I think they have realized that the United States is not going to discuss anything with them." Mr. Smith, who visited Cuba last week, said the Cuban Government appeared to be considering economic reforms that could lessen food shortages on the island, but had not reached a decision.
Speaking of the possibility of an economic reform package that would allow farmers to sell some of their crops on the open market, Mr. Smith said he had been told that "Fidel is dead set against it, but Raul and the military are pressing for it." He was referring to Mr. Castro's younger brother Raul, who is Minister of Defense.
The only senior Cuban official to have commented in any detail on the Clinton Administration's new policy is Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina, who is on an official visit to six South and Central American countries aimed at lessening Cuba's diplomatic isolation. Arriving in Santiago, Chile, late on Monday, Mr. Robaina described relations between the United States and Cuba as "extremely tense" and said they would "heat up" as a result of the decision to send Cuban refugees to Guantanamo Bay naval base.
 
Guantanamo Issue Assailed
 "Without Cuban emigrants, this base continues to be worthy of condemnation," he said. "With Cuban emigrants, I think that, to sum things up, it can make this tense relationship even more dangerous."
Those comments have been echoed in Cuba's Government-controlled press. In a broadcast from Havana monitored here today, Radio Rebelde warned that Cuban refugees at Guantanamo "could be used for acts of provocation or as cannon fodder" in the event of hostilities between the United States and Cuba.
At his news conference in Chile, Mr. Robaina also scoffed at a statement by Leon Panetta, White House Chief of Staff, that the United States was considering the possibility of imposing a blockade on Cuba. "Threats don't frighten us, because Cuba has been living with threats for 34 years," he said.
At the same time, however, Mr. Robaina repeated Cuba's longstanding desire to sit down with American officials to discuss a whole gamut of differences. "The problem is not purely one of migration, it is much more than that," he said.
Mr. Castro's sudden silence contrasts sharply with his actions earlier this month, when he denounced the United States in a series of speeches and news conferences. On Aug. 5, after rioters in downtown Havana clashed with police and chanted "Down with Fidel!" Mr. Castro was speaking on Cuban television when he was handed a note that he said contained a threat from the head of the United States Interest Section in Havana "that a serious situation would develop" if the Cuban leader did not abandon his aggressive talk.
"Well, I am not only speaking, but also confirming this point," Mr. Castro then said. He added, referring to the American policy of treating Cuban boat people as political refugees: "Anyone can see that the country cannot allow these things to happen and just sit back with folded arms."
That speech and others that Mr. Castro delivered later make it clear that he blames the United States for the current crisis. In particular, the Cuban leader has argued that the only thing that distinguishes the flow of people out of Cuba from that in other Latin American countries is Washington's three-decade-old policy of isolating Cuba economically.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: ON THE AIRWAVES;
U.S. Government Broadcasts to Cuba, And Wonders If Anyone Is Listening

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Hour after hour, the airwaves in Cuba are filled with a single message: Don't go.
In Spanish, from antiseptic United States Government studios here, the reasons are listed again and again: The waters are unsafe. Hurricane season has started. People are dying. American policy has changed. There is no welcome for survivors. Refugees are detained. Don't go. 
 Radio Marti's transmissions blanket most of Cuba. Yet the refugees keep coming, day by day surging into the choppy seas and confounding those who fear yet more death in the Straits of Florida.
"They want us to warn people," said Margarita Rojo, the harried general manager of the United States Government's Radio Marti. "We are the only link some Cubans have to what is happening."
In an emergency intensification of its message, Radio Marti, a Ronald Reagan brainchild designed to beam democracy toward one of the hemisphere's last Communist hold-out, nearly doubled its capacity to transmit today, said Richard M. Lobo, the director of the Office of Cuban Broadcasting, a division of the United States Information Agency.
By adding four new Voice of America shortwave channels to the six it already uses, radio experts hope to jump the program across the dial like a nervous mouse to evade jamming devices, which Mr. Lobo says are used by the Castro Government in Havana.
A medium-wave signal, 1180 AM, transmitted from a military base in Marathon Key, Fla., is surging from 50 kilowatts to 100, Mr. Lobo said. And a television signal will be staying on the air from 3:30 A.M. until 8 A.M., three hours longer than usual, starting on Wednesday.
The programming has changed, too. In the past four days, news broadcasts have doubled in length and a skeletal staff reduced by summer vacations has struggled to produce special commentary shows and news alerts.
 
'We Are All Exhausted'
 "It's crazy," Ms. Rojo said. "Today is worse than yesterday. Yesterday was worse than the day before. We are all exhausted."
The emergency expansion, called for by President Clinton in a news conference last week, but not made until today, is hoped to work on both a practical and a political level. By telling Cubans not to head to sea, the Administration wants to stop the exodus while underscoring its message that Castro's reaction may be costing perhaps thousands of Cubans their lives.
"With these new frequencies we should be able to break through loud and clear," said Rolando Bonachea, Radio Marti's director. "There is a human tragedy unfolding."
The Radio Marti staff has scrambled for days to alert Cubans to shifts in the Clinton Administration's policy and to reach out to a country many once called home. The staff says the station's mission is balanced, fair journalism. As the crisis has unfolded, the station's programmers have sought to include voices both supporting and opposing Mr. Clinton's sudden shift on the issue of refugees.
But the delicacies of working with the Government as boss seem clear, if sometimes subtle. When one man was widely quoted saying that he would rather be in Haiti than in Cuba, the reference was cut in deference to the State Department's ongoing struggles over restoring democracy in Haiti.
More often, though, the immediate challenge is simply meeting deadlines. Barred from traveling to Cuba, the staff tries to reach out by telephone and through a network of stringers. At one desk for the past several days, Elizardo San Pedro Marin has spent hour after hour trying to reach Cuba by telephone. Most conversations abruptly end moments after the connection is made, presumably because of interference from Castro's government.
 
Nothing Is Normal
 These days, almost nothing is normal. Even the station's once reliable mix of talk shows, news bites, salsa music and soap operas has been transformed. The staff has toned down music and entertainment programs both to make way for news and not to seem to make light of an escalating tragedy.
Since its first broadcast on Cuban Independence Day, May 20, 1985, Radio Marti has operated with built-in obsolescence in mind. Always, its success was defined as Fidel Castro's failure.
Yet now that political and economic tensions in Havana have boiled into the warm waters off Florida, the radio is reporting not on a celebration but on an agonizing drama that, for many, involves countrymen and relatives.
"It's your own people," said Camelia Townsend, the station's Cuba-born director of the evening news. "When you see people and they say they would rather go to Haiti than stay in Cuba, it hurts, it is very emotional. I can't hold back the tears."
The lighter moments that remain sometimes sound dissonant. Monday, the station fluttered between "The Passion of Sylvia Eugenia," a saga of a woman in the midst of a divorce because she has fallen passionately in love with a man about to be married to another woman, and news reports that listed the names of Cubans detained at the Krome Detention Center in Miami.
On Monday, the news staff fretted over reports of 1,000 bodies washed up in brackish waters near Havana. The numbers added up. All day Sunday, a Miami-based group called Los Hermanos de Rescate, or Brothers to the Rescue, called in with reports of up to 200 rafts adrift.
"There were probably four to six people per raft," said Ms. Rojo, pulling on a cigarette and pacing in a light rain during a short break. "You multiply it. That's 1,000 dead. But we can't report it because we can't be sure of our sources."
That caution is perhaps heightened for Radio Marti's employees. "We'd rather be last than wrong," Mr. Lobo said. "Too many people listen to us, too many people believe us for us to take any chances."
Tonight, as the station prepared to stretch its reach even further, the staff could only hope that someone out there was listening.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down Against Yen After Rise in Early Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended trading with little change yesterday after an early surge on signs that Japan's central bank bought dollars to brake its slide against the Japanese yen.
"The Bank of Japan bought pretty aggressively last night," said Joe Francomano, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. 
 But the dollar gave back most of its gains in the afternoon after an influential economist predicted that trade tensions between Washington and Tokyo would push the dollar to a new low against the yen. It did manage to recover against the Mexican peso, however.
The dollar rose as high as 98.54 yen, before ending the day at 97.82 yen, down from 97.85 yen on Monday. It also rose to 1.5315 German marks from 1.5288 marks.
 
Traders Cite Bank Moves
 Traders in Tokyo said the central bank began buying dollars in Asian trading. The Bank of Japan declined to comment. The central bank's purchases, which have often proved ineffective, helped drive the dollar higher early yesterday because many traders were short the American currency, Mr. Francomano said.
In a short sale, traders sell borrowed dollars, hoping to buy dollars at a lower rate later to cover the borrowing; the difference is profit. The Bank of Japan's purchases forced them to buy dollars back to pare losses, Mr. Francomano said.
The Bank of Japan has spent trillions of yen buying dollars this year trying to keep the yen from strengthening. A strong yen makes Tokyo's exports more expensive.
 
Bergsten Comments
 But in late New York trading, the dollar pulled back after C. Fred Bergsten, an independent Washington economist with close ties to the Clinton Administration, was quoted as having said that the dollar might fall to new lows against the yen because of the standoff in American-Japanese trade negotiations over government contracts. The dollar's current postwar low is 96.60 yen, set on July 12.
"Bergsten's comments hit a nerve," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. Traders eager to sell the dollar when it rose saw his comments as justification for doing so, he said.
The United States has set a Sept. 30 deadline for talks aimed at getting Japanese Government agencies to buy more American medical and telecommunications equipment. Otherwise, the Administration may impose sanctions on Japanese exports.
The dollar often falls against the yen when Washington talks tough on trade because many traders suspect that the White House will call for a strong yen to put pressure on Japan.
The dollar, meanwhile, rebounded against the Mexican peso, which rallied to a three-month high against the dollar on Monday after preliminary results of the Mexican election. The dollar traded at 3.3420 pesos today in the spot market, up from 3.3375 pesos on Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Drought in Parts of Brazil Pushes Coffee Prices Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Coffee prices surged yesterday on continuing concerns that dry weather in Brazil will further damage a crop already harmed by two frosts.
Some parts of Brazil's coffee-growing regions have had no rain for a month, and no rain is forecast for the rest of the week. Brazil is the world's leading coffee producer. 
 "It continues to be dry there," said Oscar Schaps, a coffee broker with Hencorp Coffee Group in Miami. "The critical time is in two weeks. If it's still dry then," prices could surge again, he said.
At the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee for December delivery rose 8.1 cents, to $1.976 a pound, its highest price in a week. Coffee has surged 7.5 percent in the last two days.
The dry weather in Brazil comes after two frosts in the growing regions during June and July, eliminating an estimated 40 percent of next year's crop. Traders still do not know the full extent of the frost damage.
"I'm bullish in general," said John Rapinchuk, controller at Knutsen Coffees Ltd. in San Francisco. Even though 20 million bags of coffee stored in producing countries would cover the decline in Brazil's crop, he said, "If we don't get the traditional rain that starts the flowering in September and October, then there'll be additional difficulties."
On other commodity markets, crude oil gained and lumber fell. The Commodity Research Bureau's index rose 0.42 point, to 228.91.
Crude oil prices rebounded from their lowest levels since early May, and traders cited optimism that a surge in demand this winter will absorb higher production in the North Sea during the next two months. Crude oil for October delivery rose 19 cents, to $17.09, a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute said crude oil stockpiles fell 2.8 million barrels, less than 1 percent, while gasoline inventories were lower.
Elsewhere, lumber prices slumped on traders' expectations for a slowdown in the housing market. September lumber futures dropped the $10 daily trading limit, to $357.20 for 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
"You're over the peak of the housing market, and now you're coming into an area where you have to be concerned," said Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. "Housing has been negatively impacted by the rise in interest rates."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
California's plan to control insurance rates stirs industry ire.

BYLINE: By Michael Quint 

 BODY:
SHOULD insurance companies be treated like utilities, with state regulators controlling their prices so that no company makes too much profit, or too little?
That is the approach being adopted in California, where the state's Supreme Court last week upheld the voter-approved Proposition 103, which requires the insurance commissioner's approval before companies can change prices. The court also supported the commissioner's right to approve insurance prices by a formula that sets a range of profits, expressed as a rate of return on the capital, that each company would be allowed. 
 Insurance companies have been fighting the plan for seven years. Now, they are gaining new support from investors and analysts who contend that the state-set rate of return will discourage insurance companies from expanding in California and deter investors from buying stock of companies with a concentration of business in California.
Some analysts expect that the new rules, if they are not overturned in an appeal to the United States Supreme Court, will prompt companies to begin reallocating costs, revenues and capital to minimize the California constraint on profits.
"I don't think the doomsday scenarios of a massive flight by companies out of the California market will happen, just because the forces of inertia are so powerful," said Orin S. Kramer, a director of a private investment partnership and a former consultant for the insurance industry. "But if there was a company planning a public stock issue whose business was concentrated in California, I don't think that stock issue would sell."
Even if the California commissioner adopts regulations allowing companies to set prices that result in a more generous return than the 10 percent target set in the late 1980's, investors worry that insurance company profits will be vulnerable to attacks by commissioners looking to raise their popularity before the next election. And, they say, utility-style regulation has no place in the insurance industry, particularly in a competitive state like California where 700 companies offer a wide range of prices and service.
"Borrowing the principles of utility regulation and applying them to the insurance industry makes no sense," said David Snyder, assistant general counsel for the American Insurance Association. "With utilities that operate as monopolies, government should have a wide role in rate regulation to protect consumers who have no choice about where they buy their electricity. But insurance is a competitive industry where consumers do have choices."
Despite such concern, only a few companies have been hurt in the stock market. Shares of Twentieth Century Insurance and the Mercury General Corporation, two highly profitable auto insurers with a business concentration in California, have declined 23 percent and 5.3 percent, respectively, since the court decision.
Other companies are either mutually owned like State Farm, the state's largest insurer, with no stock to be traded; have only a small part of their business in California, like Allstate, or are owned by large foreign companies like B.A.T. Industries of Britain and Allianz of Germany.
John Snyder, senior vice president at A. M. Best, the insurance rating firm, said the new regulatory arrangement could backfire for California consumers, despite the one-time refunds of $100 or more ordered by Proposition 103.
In the past, he said, the best-run companies, like Twentieth Century Insurance, could make high profits and at the same time offer their customers prices and service that were among the best in the state. "But if their profits are capped, you may not get that kind of success story in the future," he said. The inefficient companies, he added, may be more comfortable with the profit target, since they were not highly profitable anyway, and may endure longer if better run companies avoid the state.
The formulas for the target rates of return are expected to be published within a few months, or shortly before the end of the term in office of John Garamendi, the insurance commissioner. In 1989 the commissioner set a 10 percent return target when calculating the rebates companies should pay under Proposition 103.
A 10 percent return is well below the 18.2 percent five-year average for the 50 best-run property and casualty insurers, but differs little from the industry average of 10.6 percent, according to the Ward Financial Group of Cincinnati.
Mr. Garamendi said fears of an excessively low target for rates of return were misplaced, because there would be an adjustment for efficiency so that well-run companies could earn more. The target rates of return will also vary, he said, with changes in economic conditions, such as inflation and interest rates.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
New Game In Town As Baseball Talks Begin

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In place of the usual position-by-position matchups that precede the World Series, Major League Baseball was left yesterday with a matchup of verbal positions by owners and players as they prepared for their first face-to-face bargaining-table confrontation of the 13-day-old strike.
The positions, as articulated by John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox and Brett Butler of the Los Angeles Dodgers, spelled out in painfully precise terms where each side stands for today's session in the presence of a team of Federal mediators. 
 Harrington, the Red Sox's chief executive officer, and Butler, the Dodgers' veteran center fielder, offered their positions after each side met with John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, and three aides, Wilma Liebman, John Martin and Brian Flores.
At the meetings -- three and a half hours for the owners, two hours for the players -- the mediators determined that each side was willing to permit as many representatives of the other side to attend today's session as each wanted.
 
15 Players Expected
 Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said he expected about 15 players to join their negotiators. Richard Ravitch, management's chief labor executive, did not say how many of the 12-person team of owners and club executives would be present, but all 12 were expected at the 10:30 A.M. meeting at the Hotel Intercontinental in Manhattan.
Harrington, serving as a spokesman for the owner-executive group assigned to meet with the players, said he had been impressed listening to the members speak during the previous 24 hours.
"Everyone had a different way of articulating their concerns for the economics of the game," Harrington said at a news conference, "but the unanimity of the final message was that we have to bring about some fundamental change to the player compensation system in order to insure the future viability of the game. That's where we've been at; that's where we're still at."
 
Owners Hold Ground
 In other words, at the bargaining session, the owners will adhere to the salary cap they desperately want to implement to control their player costs.
Butler, speaking at a later news conference, was equally clear on the players' position.
"You sit and talk about salary caps as they have," he said as the strike brought to 155 the number of games lost. "Representing the players behind me and the other 750 as well, absolutely there's no way the players are going to go with a salary cap. If they understand that, which we hope they do, and they can come in tomorrow with the thought process that there isn't going to be a salary cap, now let's fix it. We want to play baseball, but we are not going to play baseball with the thought process of a salary cap existing in this industry. It just will not happen."
 
'A Lot of Golf'
 And a minute later, he added, "If they stick to the salary cap, guys are going to play a lot of golf."
Butler was one of 18 players who attended the meeting with the mediators. Eleven owners and club executives went to the management session. David Glass, chairman of the Kansas City Royals, was the missing person for the second straight day.
When mediators last week announced the resumption of talks -- the two sides haven't met since Aug. 12, the first day of the strike -- they talked of five owners joining the talks. When Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, appointed his 12-person squad, he did not specify a first team and a second team, but a group of five was designated just in case only five would meet with the players.
Ravitch played down the talk that had been generated by the first team-second team approach.
"This game of which owner is present, which owner is sitting in which seat takes attention away from the central subject, which is the issue," he said. "We have a strike going on. We are trying to bring this to a resolution. Let's keep our eye on that ball. The outcome of that is not going to be affected by which particular owner is going to be sitting in which particular chair at any given moment in time."
Fehr said he didn't think the owners asked to have their whole team at the table as much as they suggested it.
 
'Rotating Groups' Unusual
 "We'd be more than happy to have them do it," Fehr said. "It seemed sort of unusual to have rotating groups."
Neither Ravitch nor Fehr would discuss the specific matters they covered in their meetings with the mediators. But Ravitch said, "At the moment, the mediators are primarily listening."
The meeting with the union, Fehr said, made "the mediators aware of how the players feel individually. This no longer is staff speaking for a group. These are individuals."
At their news conference, Ravitch and Harrington made some comments that were confusing enough to prompt speculation that the owners might have something different to present to the players.
When asked if the owners would have a different proposal, Ravitch said: "I am not going to comment on that, the question of whether we take a proposal to the table tomorrow or not. I don't want to suggest by my silence on this subject that there's going to be a proposal, that that proposal is going to be of a particular nature at all."
 
'The Central Issue'
 But then he added: "It's fair to say the owners are not going to change their view that the issue of cost certainty, the nexis between revenues and costs, are the central issue in this negotiation. We are not going to change our view on that tomorrow."
Harrington was asked if he had learned "anything new" yesterday.
"Yes," he replied, "but I can't discuss it." Later he was asked about it again and said, "I don't want to talk anymore about what went on today."
Harrington did say the owners-executives were prepared to remain in New York for further meetings if they are scheduled.
"Eleven and hopefully 12 will stay here for as long as it takes, as long as there's productive dialogue," he said, adding he hoped the two sides would continue meeting after today's session.
Ravitch said he hoped the sessions would be conducted on a high level and not include the name-calling he declined to become involved in the day before. But he couldn't resist taking a swipe at Fehr.
"Don said yesterday I've never run a team," Ravitch said. "I've never seen Don's picture in a uniform on a playing card, either."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
2 1/2 Decades Later, A Very Good Year

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THEY will be celebrating a milestone at Opus One next week. Opus One is the name of a winery, an architectural tour de force in the Napa Valley in California; it's also the name of its wine.
The celebration is for the 1991 vintage, the first to be made at the winery. But the party has been almost 25 years in the making, having survived big egos, a big price on the wine, a big construction problem and a serious disease in the vines. 
 The idea for Opus One was born at a wine and spirits industry convention in Hawaii in 1970 when Baron Philippe de Rothschild casually proposed it to Robert Mondavi, the California wine maker. Baron Philippe was the owner of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, one of the most famous wine properties in France, at Pauillac, near Bordeaux. Mr. Mondavi's winery in the Napa Valley had opened to almost instant acclaim only four years earlier.
The two men met again in 1978, at Chateau Mouton-Rothschild. After 25 minutes of discussion, they agreed on the outlines of a joint wine making venture. They would create a California wine combining the best of two worlds, or more precisely, two wine regions, Bordeaux and the Napa Valley.
The two men had much in common, even though one was the son of poor Italian immigrants and the other a scion of one of the wealthiest families in Europe. Both had been athletes in their youth. Both were restless innovators. Both were clever showmen possessed of outsize egos.
Baron Philippe loved California. Briefly during the 1930's, he had dabbled in Hollywood as a producer. After World War II, he and his wife, Pauline Fairfax Potter, an American, vacationed regularly in Santa Barbara. In the early 1970's, the French economy was more unstable than usual, and the booming California wine business seemed like a most prudent investment.
For the visionary Mr. Mondavi, the French connection offered a partner with deep pockets and a measure of prestige that was undreamed of in the days when, as a boy, he had nailed together crates for shipping cheap grapes to the East Coast.
The project moved along rapidly. Even the unusual name of the red wine was chosen quickly.
According to one version of the event, Baron Philippe called from Paris and suggested Opus. Mr. Mondavi demurred; it was too musical.
Two days later the Baron called back. "How about Opus One?" he said. And that was it.
Until a separate winery was built, Opus One would be made from Mondavi grapes at the Mondavi winery in Oakville. Mouton-Rothschild would supply its wine makers and oak barrels for aging and would underwrite other costs. The first vintage was in 1979. The Opus One telephone number commemorates that year: 963-1979.
Thanks to a carefully orchestrated promotional campaign, the 1979 vintage was in demand almost from the time the grapes were picked. One case went for $24,000 at a charity auction three years before the wine was sold commercially.
When the 1979 vintage was released in 1984 -- simultaneously with the 1980 vintage -- it was obvious that a star had been born, even though it cost $50 a bottle, which was then a startling price. Opus One was truly a California wine with a French pedigree.
That same year, 1984, the Mondavis and the Rothschilds chose Johnson, Fain & Pereira Associates, architects in Los Angeles, to design their winery. By then, Baron Philippe's daughter, Philippine, was leading the French half of the Opus One team on behalf of her aging father, then 82. The Baron died in 1988.
The architects drew up plans for a building, across the highway from the Robert Mondavi Winery, that would have 80,000 square feet of space, of which 15,000 square feet would be reserved for a huge, curved barrel room. Throughout the wine making process, an ingenious gravity-flow system would eliminate the need to pump juice or wine from one level to another. The winery was budgeted at $10 million. Construction started in July 1989 and was finished in December 1991.
Then misfortune struck. Twice.
The plan was to bury much of the winery below ground, for natural cooling. The engineers discovered, too late, that the building was sitting on an exceptionally high water table. What's more, it was found to be close to geothermal springs that raised the ground temperature to about 72 degrees. An expensive cooling system had to be devised and installed.
Meanwhile, a new phylloxera epidemic had begun to destroy California's vineyards. Phylloxera is an aphid that feeds on grapevine roots. In the late 19th century, the bug, which originated in this country, wiped out most of the world's vineyards. Only the discovery of phylloxera-resistant rootstocks enabled the wine business to survive. Since the bug works only underground, the vulnerable vines can be grafted, above ground, to the resistant roots.
A new strain of the bug, which attacks rootstocks once considered impervious to it, has forced extensive replantings in California. In 1990, 40 of Opus One's 75 acres of vines were found to be infected and had to be replaced. Thus, 15 years after its first vintage, the wine is still being made with grapes from vineyards owned or leased by the Mondavi winery. "We expect Opus One to be made entirely from its own grapes in three, maybe four years," Mr. Mondavi said.
New construction and replanting increased the cost of the Opus One winery. The winery's management said the final cost was $15 million, although industry estimates have put it as high as $25 million.
The winery, which opened in 1991, has been variously described as a space station, a Mayan temple and a futuristic mausoleum. In fact, it's a strikingly handsome structure built from white Texas limestone and untreated redwood and filled with imported antiques. Its elegance, inside and out, reflects the elegance of its wine and to some extent perhaps the almost casual excess of the mid-1980's.
The wine, a blend predominantly of cabernet sauvignon, with cabernet franc and merlot, has maintained its quality and popularity through the 13 vintages released to date. It is one of the most expensive wines produced in this country: its recent vintages sell for about $65 a bottle, and older ones, when they turn up, can bring $200 or more.
Production began at about 12,000 cases in 1979. Some 27,000 cases of the 1991 vintage were bottled last year, according to winery figures. Production should eventually level off at 30,000 cases, Mr. Mondavi said.
Opus One sells around the world -- except, it seems, in France.
"The French are amused by Opus One," Baroness Philippine said. "They're interested, but they're not for the moment prepared to buy it."

TASTINGS
Les Jamelles Mourvedre, Vin de Pays d'Oc (France), 1992; about $5.
 
This is yet another contender in the new wave of varietal wines from the Midi, the south of France. Les Jamelles is the brand name, and mourvedre is the name of the grape from which this particular red wine is made. After a century or so of turning out mostly junk, the Midi is switching to good wines. The growers have learned that the day of cheap but vile wine has passed. Vineyards have been replanted, and wine makers are changing to the American system of identifying wines by the name of the grape -- like this one -- instead of by geographic area. Historically, mourvedre was a hot-climate grape that produced a dry, astringent wine used mostly in blending. Les Jamelles mourvedre has none of the harsh tannins of old; it is smooth, medium bodied, easy to drink and attractively packaged. It also has the advantage of being native to the area in which it is made -- more than can be said for some of the inexpensive cabernets and chardonnays from the same torrid climes.

HEADLINE: Long Island's Wines Gain in Stature

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND is steadily emerging as New York State's signature wine region, as maturing producers offer ever more sophisticated whites and reds to a growing clientele.
The wine business is only 21 years old on the East End of Long Island, and many of the wineries are less than half that age. But with the trial-and-error fumblings of the early years largely behind them, Suffolk County's leading producers are seeing sales rise along with quality. 
 "Our first year's sales were about 3,500 cases," said Robert J. Palmer, whose Palmer Vineyards in Aque bogue, L.I., opened in 1986. "By the end of 1994, they should hit 12,000 to 12,500."
But it is proximity to New York City that gives the region its advantage. Many of the choicest wines from the 49 producers in the Finger Lakes area, the state's biggest winegrowing region, are sold only upstate; they rarely enter New York City's market and its East End orbit, which can build national reputations.
Because the East End's 16 wineries are so close to New York City, it is easy to attract New Yorkers' attention and to get products into New York retail stores and restaurants. Producers can also rebuild customers' inventories within a few hours.
"Long Island has clearly become No. 1 in importance in the state and elsewhere, because New York State is New York City," said Jon Newmark, the owner of Orange Plaza Wines and Liquors in Middletown, N.Y. "Long Island's proximity makes all the difference."
Gene Pierce, the president of Glenora, a major Finger Lakes producer, agreed. "It's hard to overcome the geography," he said. "Besides, we're agricultural. Long Island owners have been businessmen. They have had more experience in marketing and sales than we. We need to learn to cooperate to promote the region's reach and image."
And tourism on the East End, especially winery visits that often end in sales, is rising, said Carol Gristina of Gristina Vineyards in Cutchogue, L.I. "I noticed last year that our season has become longer," she said. "It used to be Memorial Day to Labor Day. Now it's the beginning of May through Thanksgiving."
East End wineries are open all year long, with seasonally adjusted hours. For day trippers, the region is 90 miles from midtown Manhattan, about a two-hour drive (the Finger Lakes are five hours away).
Knowledgeable wine buyers tend to head for Bedell, Gristina, Hargrave and Pellegrini, all in Cutchogue; Lenz and Pindar in Peconic; Palmer and Paumanok in Aquebogue, and Sagpond in Sagaponack.
"My favorite North Shore wine is Pindar's Special Reserve Sunflower Chardonnay," said Robert Bernstein, the general sales manager of WALK-AM and -FM, in Patchogue, and a frequent visitor to the wine country. "And Bidwell makes a good reserve merlot. In truth, I have not found Long Island's sparkling wines to be as good as those from California."
East End producers are elated by the 1993 vintage. They say the overall quality of last year's wines is the best ever (only a few '93's have been released). Alex Hargrave of Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue pronounced the '93 growing conditions virtually perfect from start to finish. "So far, '94 is on track with '93, and we have our fingers crossed," he said.
Mr. Palmer, of Palmer Vineyards, said: "Long Island is on a roll. The North Fork is New York City's Napa Valley."
Any hyperbole aside, visitors are more likely to confuse the North Fork with Indiana. Offering miles of flat fields, ponds, farm stands bending under vegetables and fruits, wooden frame houses, white clapboard churches, picket fences and old cemeteries, the area is rural and small-town middle American in appearance and spirit.
"On the North Fork you feel very far away from New York City," said Alice Kossin, a preschool teacher from Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., who was visiting the area recently. "This is our first visit. We'll be back. We hope to discover a small label and a wine we really love."
Producers are now introducing sophisticated agricultural and cellar techniques. And as their vines age, in good years they can deliver grapes of great complexity.
"By the standards of discerning wine lovers, most are turning out wines of fine quality," said Mary Ewing Mulligan, the director of the International Wine Center, a Manhattan wine school. "The wines are well made and typify their grape variety."
Many of the wineries are converted potato barns or barn knockoffs. Lenz occupies a funky old barn. Pindar's immense salesroom, lighted by a huge stained-glass window with a kitschy winegrowing motif and faux Tiffany lamps with grape motifs, seems perpetually thronged.
Pellegrini's two-story cathedral-like tasting room, buttressed by an oak post-and-beam frame, is the handsomest on the East End. Palmer's tasting room is furnished with remnants of a London pub.
Chardonnay and merlot are Long Island's top wines. Some chardonnays tend to be Chablis-like -- lighter, leaner and crisper than California's -- and the barrel-fermented versions somewhat Burgundian. The outstanding merlots, typically medium-bodied, stress lively aromas and flavors and, in ripe vintages, display plenty of meatiness and depth.
John Bedell -- Kip to everyone -- expressed barely restrained enthusiasm this spring as he poured opulent '93 samples of his regular and reserve merlots aging in American-oak barrels. Bedell merlots have steadily taken top honors in contests sponsored by the New York Wine and Grape Foundation, a trade group.
Mr. Bedell and everyone else have other specialties. Bedell's off-dry non-vintage Cygnet is a tasty blend of gewurztraminer and riesling grapes. Gristina is making a mark with pinot noir. Hargrave's cabernet franc can be profound. Pellegrini features a tantalizing off-dry blend of pinot blanc, chardonnay and gewurztraminer, called Commonage White.
Lenz's Alsace-style gewurztraminer and pinot blanc are delicious. Palmer's sauvignon blanc rises toward California's best. Pindar turns out a stylish sparkling wine, Cuvee Rare, wholly from pinot meunier grapes. Paumanok is making headway with riesling.
On the North Fork, two new producers are about to go into business. Osprey's Dominion, in Peconic, may open to the public in early September, said Bill Pollina, the general manager. Corey Creek in Southold plans to begin building a sales office in September, said Matthew C. Gillies, the vineyard manager. For the moment, both will feature chardonnays made for them by Dan Kleck at Palmer.
Long Island's wine industry was born in 1972, when Alex and Louisa Hargrave planted 17 acres of cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir and sauvignon blanc. Today, they have 50 acres under vines, and the region has at least 1,500, virtually all devoted to European vinifera grapes. (Nassau County, to the west of Suffolk, has two wineries.)
This spring, the East End Economic and Environmental Task Force estimated the total average annual production at 250,000 cases and sales at $27 million and said that 30 percent of all sales took place in the tasting rooms. Most premium wines range from $9 to $20 a bottle.
The revival of South Fork wine making was signaled in May when Dr. Herodotus Damianos, a Stony Brook, L.I., internist and the owner of Pindar, bought the nearly defunct Southampton Winery in Water Mill and its 56 acres for "more than $2 million," he said. He renamed it Duck Walk.
Dr. Damianos acquired the assets from Barclays Bank, which in 1992 foreclosed on the bankrupt winery, called Le Reve when it opened in 1987. The bank had held a $6.6 million mortgage. With 51,000 cases produced from the '93 vintage, Pindar is by far Long Island's biggest winery.
In May, Peter Carroll, who operates and has an option to buy Lenz, acquired the financially troubled Bridgehampton Winery, the East End's third-oldest winery.
Founded in 1989, the well-financed Sagpond Vineyards is the South Fork's newest producer. It features promising chardonnays and expects to start building a winery by next year.
In June, Mr. Palmer, of Palmer Vineyards, became the region's second-biggest grape-grower behind Dr. Damianos, who has 250 acres planted. Mr. Palmer bought the 52-acre Ressler Vineyards, a leading grape farm in Cutchogue, for $1 million, increasing his holdings to 88 acres.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Palmer, the owner of Palmer Vineyards. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Why Punish the Cuban People?

 BODY:
President Clinton's abrupt reversal of 28 years of Cuban refugee policy last Friday looked clumsy enough, but over the weekend he made it worse. Seeking to punish Fidel Castro for unleashing the latest refugee tide, Mr. Clinton ended up also punishing ordinary Cubans. He cut off all cash support from their relatives in the U.S., rather than the 50 percent cut originally announced. By raising the temperature on Cuba when it should be trying to cool it, the Administration could yet convert a rhetorical emergency into a real one.
The package of pressures the President unveiled on Saturday did include two legitimate spurs to greater freedom in Cuba -- increased radio broadcasts and a new U.N. initiative on human rights. It also included a cutoff of charter flights from the U.S. -- unwise, since Cuban freedom is served by more contacts with Americans, not less. 
 The Administration suspended the payments because they not only help stretch family budgets but also provide hard currency to Havana as recipients exchange their dollars for goods in special Government-run stores. The policy seems designed to bring Cuba to a political boil by closing off the refugee safety valve and driving down living standards. Presumably that will hasten a popular revolt, but this course entails a pointless risk to the Cuban people since the Castro regime is already withering.
Even in decline, Mr. Castro has again shown his uncanny power to get Washington to tie itself in knots. Following a familiar pattern, the U.S. is overreacting to his provocations and letting domestic politics distort foreign policy priorities.
In any rational calculus, Mexico, with its 92 million people and a North American Free Trade Agreement, should be the Administration's main Latin concern following a critical and tense election. Instead all eyes are fixed on Cuba and continuing efforts to contain the refugee flow, promoted in one frantic day by Attorney General Janet Reno from non-problem to national emergency.
The Administration's new offensive against Havana is supported by Cuban-Americans, who were upset when Washington reclassified those who risk their lives to flee Mr. Castro's economically battered police state as "illegal immigrants" rather than refugees from tyranny. They believe the time has finally come to get rid of the Castro regime, and inflicting increased short-term pain on Cuba's people seems worth the long-term gain.
The voice of a million Cuban-Americans should be heard, but it should not be allowed to drive U.S. policy against humane values and larger national interests. Those values weigh against punishing innocent victims, and those interests do not include detonating a large explosion in the Caribbean. Discontented Cubans do not relish rising up only to be mowed down by a totalitarian regime. They would rather get out and start anew somewhere else. It is unconscionable for Washington to tell them, in effect, no, we will lock you in until you revolt.
Getting rid of Fidel Castro is a job for the Cuban people themselves, not for the U.S. Government or Miami exiles. This cold-war orphan can still annoy the U.S. but poses no serious threat. Instead of gearing up for another round of sterile confrontation, Washington should be spelling out what Cuba could gain, under this regime or a successor, by embracing democracy and respecting human rights. That, rather than increased hunger and misery, might actually encourage those Cubans who remain in Cuba to work for political change.

HEADLINE: In America;
Chavis's Noisy 15 Minutes

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
There were a few hundred people in the auditorium of Paul Laurence Dunbar High School on Monday night, but for all practical purposes Ben Chavis was alone. Clinging desperately to the final seconds of his 15 minutes in the spotlight, Mr. Chavis has chosen, in his typically clumsy and contentious way, not to go quietly.
Just an hour or two earlier his lawyers had gone to court to try to block Mr. Chavis's ouster as executive director of the N.A.A.C.P. Now he was onstage, attempting to salvage whatever ego gratification he could from his so-called "crucifixion." 
Outside, just blocks away, neighborhoods were suffering. But Mr. Chavis, for all his rhetoric about helping the poor and the young, is dedicated to the pursuit of his own childishly defiant agenda. And so he offered a couple of special, in-your-face greetings Monday night.
"To all the brothers and sisters who are in America's prisons," said Mr. Chavis, "we send greetings to you."
That, of course, generated big applause, which is the narcotic that satisfies the raging addiction of so many public figures, black and white. There were a lot of brothers and sisters right around the corner from Dunbar High who could have been helped by a competent director of the N.A.A.C.P., but that's too complex and unrewarding an effort to contemplate. Mr. Chavis chose to acknowledge those in prison.
Mr. Chavis's other greeting was for his good friend Louis Farrakhan, who missed Monday's gathering because he wasn't feeling well. "He's our brother!" cried Mr. Chavis to wild cheers. "He's our brother! He's our brother! He's our brother! He's our brother! He's our brother!
The shouts carried out into the streets and echoed into the night.
East Baltimore, where Monday's rally was held, is a neighborhood in danger of sinking into despair. Many adults, their eyes red-glazed and their legs wobbly from alcohol or drugs, will tell you there is nothing that can be done about the collapse of any semblance of civilized behavior by many of the neighborhood's young residents.
"They won't listen to nobody," said Heywood Callendar, an unemployed auto mechanic who lives in a housing project on Gough Street. "Do I drink? Yes, sir. You would too, if you lived around here."
Those adults who still harbor some hope say two things are essential. Parents, especially fathers, must take real responsibility for teaching and raising their kids. Without that, nothing good can happen. The second issue is jobs. No jobs, zero hope.
"For the older ones it's too late," said police officer Edgar Allen, who drove his patrol car slowly through the neighborhood. "For the younger ones, you have to get the parents more involved, and they have to discipline the kids, really discipline them. Right now you have parents who aren't involved at all. The community can only do so much."
Parental involvement and jobs. It should be repeated like a mantra in every neighborhood from Baltimore to Los Angeles and beyond. Ben Chavis never looked more alone on Monday than when a man sitting beside him on the stage complained loudly that American corporations were exporting jobs to Mexico and other third-world countries. That, too, was greeted with loud cheers. There didn't seem to be many who realized that Mr. Chavis had secretly lobbied against their interests and on behalf of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which the N.A.A.C.P. officially opposed.
Civil rights groups are supposed to be the antidote to despair. The purpose of civil rights leaders is to focus on desperate problems and show what can and must be done. The great civil rights leaders of the past were politically skillful men and women blessed with the rare qualities of intelligence, maturity, strength and moral vision.
Ben Chavis is a graduate of the school of pseudo-leadership that mistakes civility and thoughtfulness for weakness, and bombastic rhetoric for strength. The East Baltimores of America are ill served by this approach, which succeeds only in raising false hopes.
When I think of the old-line civil rights leaders, I hear the greatness of the music of Ellington. Ben Chavis and his noisy allies are perfectly suited to the loud and empty era of rap.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York City's Pot of Gold

 BODY:
New York may be on the verge of acquiring an unexpected windfall -- millions of dollars in private money to be dipped into for the public good. A new investment fund sponsored by the New York City Partnership is seeking to raise $100 million from wealthy individual and corporate donors; $15 million has already been pledged on the basis of a mere 15 telephone calls. The Partnership's fund-raising is based on a powerful and proven idea: spread development money in the right places at the right moments and the whole city will profit.
Formed in 1978, just as New York was emerging from its last great fiscal crisis, the Partnership includes executives from more than 150 of the city's largest companies. Among them is the Wall Street financier Henry R. Kravis, who proposed the new fund after researching similar economic-development efforts by corporate leaders in cities like Atlanta and Minneapolis. Mr. Kravis has been named chairman. 
 His idea is smart and simple. Corporations and wealthy individuals will be asked to contribute $1 million each to the fund, which is to be operated with no intent to turn a profit. At the end of 15 years the donor could get the money back, along with enough to account for inflation. The fund would issue short-term loans or guarantees to help with projects ranging from neighborhood improvement around Yankee Stadium -- thus, perhaps, insuring that the team will stay put -- to a new restaurant in Central Park to new transportation facilities in Queens.
The project is heartening on several levels. It is clearly a vote of confidence in the city by some of its most powerful corporate chieftains. It also reflects shrewd self-interest: the health of the fund's sponsors and donors is inevitably linked to the city's well-being. Finally, private money may well be able to speed up projects that too often bog down in bureaucratic red tape.
New York is now and always has been a city of great opportunity surrounded by formidable obstacles. It has also been the source of considerable riches for many. Today, as ever, it is heartening to see some of that gold coming back.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Population Conference Isn't About Abortion;
A Planet Threatened

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Population Enrichment vs. Population Control," a full-page ad Aug. 15, misrepresents and misstates important aspects of the draft program of action to be considered at the International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo. 
 Nowhere in the document does the term population "control" appear. The position of the United States and of the entire community of nations that will be at the conference is to improve human freedom by supporting access to high-quality, fully voluntary family planning services.
The United States recognizes that abortion is widely used in all countries and that where it is unsafe it represents a serious threat to the health of women. The United States position is that abortion should be safe, legal and rare, and recognizes that other sovereign nations make their own laws regarding this isssue. The United States Government has never supported abortion as a method of family planning.
Both the draft program of action and the United States strongly support strengthening family life, while reocognizing that a variety of strong and functional family structures are found throughout the world.
The draft document recognizes that the increase in consumption per person, especially in industrialized countries, and population growth of about a billion every decade, are degrading the planet's life-supporting ecosystems. Lower population growth rates are consistent with the desire for smaller families in developing countries. Slower growth will also promote economic progress and help preserve natural resources.
United States support of population policies and programs is conditional on voluntarism and respect for indigenous cultural values.
Far from de-emphasizing "population enrichment," almost 99 percent of development assistance from donor countries goes for economic development activities in areas such as health and agriculture. A modest shift of resources into the neglected area of population would result in a more balanced development strategy.
 
ROBIN CHANDLER DUKE
National Chairwoman
Population Action International
Washington, Aug. 18, 1994

HEADLINE: Downsizing's Casualties

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Albert J. Dunlap is a symbol of capitalism's contradiction. At Scott Paper Company, he has been brought in to fire 30 percent of the employees (Business Day, Aug. 15). In the bargain, he has made a tidy profit. 
 Another scalp on his belt, he will move on to downsize the next company. Left behind is the devastation inflicted: financial, social and family dislocation suffered by those who have lost livelihoods. Wall Street is pleased and bids up the stock.
Capitalism needs a reasonably prosperous middle class. As hardworking workers lose their jobs, they devolve to the middle-class fringes. A market economy's excesses become more apparent to a growing number of citizens. This miserable scenario, repeated frequently today, is irrefutable evidence that capitalism's triumph is as overstated as the death of socialism.
 
LARRY J. GALLAGHER
Reno, Nev., Aug. 18, 1994

HEADLINE: Mexico's Perilous Second Act

BYLINE: By Dick J. Reavis; Dick J. Reavis is author of "Conversations With Moctezuma: Ancient Shadows Over Modern Life in Mexico."

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico

 BODY:
During the terms of Mexico's last two presidents, the purchasing power of consumers has declined by 60 percent, unemployment has doubled, emigration to the United States has not abated and nearly a quarter of the work force has taken to moonlighting -- or to hawking cheap wares on the streets -- in a struggle to survive.
On Sunday, three major presidential candidates stood before the electorate. Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party promised economic justice for the peasants. Diego Fernandez de Cevallos of the National Action Party, a right-of-center group, promised to throw out the crooks who have been running the country. In contrast, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has monopolized the presidency since 1929, promised only more of the same. 
 Yet partial tallies give Mr. Zedillo almost 50 percent of the total, with Mr. Fernandez around 30 percent and Mr. Cardenas about 16 percent. If democracy means that voters seek self-interest, what happened? Jorge Castaneda, a political scientist and a leading critic of the PRI, says he's not quite sure. "There was a lot of the traditional, retail vote peddling," he told me. "But I think that the results reflect the will of the people."
Most watchdog organizations are indicating that the election was probably the cleanest ever in Mexico. But Eduardo Arguijo Baldenegro, a 38-year-old engineer, isn't buying that. He was the mayoral candidate of the Democratic Revolutionary Party in Villa de Garcia, a small town of adobe walls and pecan orchards in the state of Nuevo Leon.
The most striking exhibit for Mr. Arguijo's case is a pair of brown leather work shoes, shiny new, wrapped in a plastic bag emblazoned with the emblem of the PRI. The manufacturer's marking on the thick soles have been buffed away so that their origin can't be traced. "These shoes were given to people in this district so that they'd vote for the PRI," insisted Mr. Arguijo, who narrowly lost the mayoral contest in 1991 to the PRI candidate.
On Sunday, nearly 90 percent of the town's eligible voters showed up at the polls. Shortly before midnight, local election officials told Mr. Arguijo that he had lost by about 250 votes. On Monday, he had his followers demonstrate outside the town's Office of Electoral Affairs. That night they were rewarded: the vote was annulled on account of electoral fraud.
Mr. Arguijo's crusade proves that in Mexico, where crooked victories are sometimes bargained away, the electoral curtain may not fall for weeks to come. Still, Mr. Zedillo's ascension to the presidency is assured. And the real loser will be the organized left. That bodes ill for the country.
Cuauhtemoc Cardenas called his supporters to town squares across the nation at noon on Monday, urging them to to contest election results in their hometowns. Fewer than 50,000 supporters answered the call in Mexico City, a mere fifth of the crowd that Mr. Cardenas drew there two weeks ago.
When the meeting ended, Jorge Castaneda, who was present, told me that at least a thousand people were recruited to sessions organized by armed groups that proclaim alliances with the guerrilla leader in Chiapas, Subcommander Marcos. These people have no stake in the peaceful reordering of things. Mr. Zedillo is not the only beneficiary of Mr. Cardenas's faltering strength: Subcommander Marcos is smiling, too.
Mr. Cardenas is a unique figure in Mexican politics: a man with moral authority. Yet his poor showing this year may fatally undermine his standing. To stay relevant, Mr. Cardenas must become Mexico's Martin Luther King Jr. -- he must start a nationwide wave of nonviolent civil disobedience against the the PRI's electoral and political abuses.
If he cannot or will not lead his followers into the streets, the armed radicals on his left will step into the vacuum created by his political demise, as the Black Panthers did when Dr. King was assassinated. A wave of violence and repression will begin. The reputation of Mexico's Government and its opposition will be bloodied.
Only one person, a Mexico City resident named Eduardo Rosas Rosas, was arrested for an electoral crime on Sunday. Mr. Rosas may be more worthy than his fame. According to the authorities, he walked into a polling station, took his ballots and tore them up; destruction of electoral materials is a crime. The Government says Mr. Rosas was drunk. But like the millions of Mexicans who cast their ballots, he may have done all that he could to stop the carnage that lies ahead.

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE OVERVIEW;
CASTRO RULES OUT ANY MOVE TO HALT FLOW OF REFUGEES

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Challenging President Clinton's decision to send Cuban refugees to Guantanamo naval base as an "absurd response" to the mounting immigration crisis between the United States and Cuba, Fidel Castro said tonight that he would make no effort to halt the flow of people leaving his country.
Speaking on state television, the Cuban President said the United States was to blame for the exodus that began earlier this month and is growing by the day. New policy measures announced by Mr. Clinton in recent days only "make the problem more complicated," Mr. Castro said. 
 "They cannot blame us for that situation," Mr. Castro said. "They created a mentality in a lot of people" in Cuba that "they had the right to travel to the United States illegally."
American efforts to provoke what Mr. Castro described as massive illegal immigration gave Cuba "no alternative" but to loosen its rules on leaving the country and instruct its Coast Guard to allow malcontents to take to the seas. He characterized Cuban policy as eminently humane, and contrasted it with the American decision to send Cuban refugees to Guantanamo, which he called a "concentration camp."
The Cuban leader also portrayed Mr. Clinton as a prisoner of Cuban exile groups here, which he called "a fascist mafia of the extreme right." Mr. Clinton, he said, had been "pressured by ultra-rightists" to take steps intended to destroy the Cuban revolution, only to see his efforts backfire.
Wearing the familiar olive green uniform of the commander in chief of the Cuban military, Mr. Castro spoke for more than 90 minutes, offering his interpretation of hijackings in Cuba and actions by Washington that he said initiated the crisis. His remarks were broadcast live in the United States, in a simultaneous English translation on CNN and in Spanish by the Telemundo network.
The speech was Mr. Castro's first public comment on the crisis since Mr. Clinton announced last Friday that Cuban refugees would no longer be allowed to enter the United States, and followed up a day later with a package of harsh new measures intended to further isolate Cuba. For the most part, Mr. Castro reiterated statements he made in similar appearances on Cuban television earlier this month, indicating that he is not interested in striking a conciliatory tone in an effort to resolve the crisis.
Mr. Castro also referred to a statement last weekend by Leon Panetta, the White House Chief of Staff, that the Clinton Administration is considering a blockade of Cuba. He warned against such an action, saying it would be "an act of war."
As he has done innumerable times in the past, Mr. Castro fixed the blame for most of Cuba's problems on the economic embargo the United States has enforced against his country since the early 1960's. "These measures compel the massive exodus," he said.
Earlier today, two senior Cuban officials also said that Washington was mainly to blame for the exodus, and said Cuba would try to end the flow of refugees only if the United States agreed to broad talks on a full range of bilateral matters.
Speaking at a news conference in New York this morning, Cuba's chief delegate to the United Nations, Fernando Remirez de Estenoz Barciela, said that, though his Government regards the exodus as primarily an American problem, Cuba is willing to discuss ways to halt the flow of refugees that has filled the Straits of Florida for the last two weeks.
But he added that the United States must in turn demonstrate its willingness to address the questions Cuba believes are the "true causes" of the migration, including Washington's three-decade ban on trade with Cuba.
"Migration itself could be one of the topics," Mr. Remirez said. But he said "the issues of lifting the blockade, the Guantanamo naval base" and "subversive radio and TV transmissions against Cuba would have to be part and parcel of a comprehensive negotiation process."
 
Washington Rejects Talks
 American officials had no immediate reaction to Mr. Castro's speech late tonight, but earlier today the Administration promptly rejected the Cuban diplomat's suggestion of bilateral talks, dismissing it as an attempt by Mr. Castro to divert attention from his own internal problems. And the Administration reiterated its resolve to house fleeing Cubans at expanded camps at Guantanamo Bay and elsewhere rather than allow them into the United States.
The Cuban population at Guantanamo, estimated at 2,000 before today, was certain to grow drastically, with 7,000 Cubans on their way there in Coast Guard boats this morning and another 2,791 fetched from the sea by 10 P.M.
Presaging Mr. Castro's remarks this evening, the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, said at a news conference in Santiago, Chile, today that in the absence of broad negotiations, the Cuban leader is prepared to continue with his current policy of turning a blind eye to the hundreds of rafts and boats that are now leaving Cuba daily.
Under the new rules announced by President Clinton on Saturday, Cuban-Americans would no longer be allowed to visit or send money to relatives in Cuba. In addition, anti-Castro broadcasts to the island will be increased, a step that Mr. Castro bitterly criticized tonight, calling it a provocation.
 
Fancy Chairs or Plain Seats
 Addressing reporters at the end of an official visit to Chile, Mr. Robaina said his Government was prepared to meet with American representatives at any time, at any place and on any level. "We are willing to talk with the United States with one condition, which is that there be no conditions," he said.
But both Mr. Robaina and Mr. Remirez indicated that the Cuban Government is not willing to discuss bringing an end to Mr. Castro's 35 years in power, which the United States argues is the only way to solve Cuba's political and economic crisis. "Any negotiations will have to include accepting us as we are, with full respect for the Cuban people," Mr. Remirez said.
"Cuba does not have to return to democracy, because Cuba is in a democracy," Mr. Robaina argued. "The question of when Fidel decides to go to elections or not is a problem of a personal decision of Fidel.
 
Reject Third-Party Role
 The Cuban diplomats also rejected suggestions that either the United Nations or a third country might act as a broker between the two nations, which have not maintained diplomatic relations in more than 30 years. "Any negotiation ought to be direct," he said.
In dismissing the Cuban offer, American officials called it an attempt by Mr. Castro to win some breathing space from his deepening domestic problems. At a news conference in Washington, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Peter Tarnoff, said the real issue was Mr. Castro's aversion to democracy and his economic policies.
"We see nothing to be gained from the kind of talks" the Cuban diplomats proposed, Mr. Tarnoff said. "It should be clear after 35 years to Fidel Castro and his Government that the way he is managing the affairs of the island is a failure."
By arguing that the real cause of the immigration crisis is the American economic embargo, Mr. Castro was repeating a long-standing Cuban position. In a speech delivered just as the refugee exodus was beginning earlier this month, he argued that Cuba could no longer afford to be "the guardian of the North Americans' coasts" if Washington continued to strangle the faltering Cuban economy.
When President Clinton took office 19 months ago, Mr. Castro made overtures, hoping to capitalize on the change in Washington. But in recent months he has expressed exasperation at the Administration's willingness to deal with other old enemies while continuing to ignore Cuba.
"The United States talks with Vietnam and looks for solutions to the problems of Vietnam, and even talks with the Democratic People's Republic of Korea," Mr. Castro said, referring to North Korea, in a speech earlier this month. "But it will not talk with Cuba."
In fact, since Mr. Clinton took office, there have been some low-level contacts between the United States and Cuba on technical issues, including immigration. But Mr. Castro has made it clear that he expected more progress with the Democrats in power and was growing impatient with that slow pace.
