HEADLINE: New Wrinkle in Korea Issue: Who Is in Charge in North?

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The North Korean nuclear issue, already fraught with dangerous uncertainties, is now punctuated by another troubling question mark: who is in charge in North Korea?
In recent days there has been a string of reports, some from North Korea, some amplified by the South Korean Government for its own purposes, hinting at strife over choosing a successor to Kim Il Sung, the Communist dictator who ruled North Korea for more than four decades until his death nearly two months ago. 
 Despite much talk in the North Korean news media since then of the importance of a smooth succession and the virtues of Mr. Kim's chosen heir, his son, Kim Jong Il, North Korea still has no head of state, and the Workers' Party, which dominates all aspects of life, has no secretary general. Kim Jong Il, 52, holds the important position of head of the military, but he has been out of sight now for a month.
The younger Mr. Kim has always been a mysterious and reclusive man, and there have been some reports that he is simply sitting out a period of mourning for his father before assuming titles that would only acknowledge the power he already holds. Intelligence officials in both South Korea and the United States say that they have no evidence he is having trouble taking over those top leadership positions, but the latest reports have added to the suspicions about the country that is perhaps the most closed society on earth.
One report out of South Korea maintains that leaflets criticizing Kim Jong Il were distributed in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, while another recirculates rumors that have been unproved for years, that the younger Mr. Kim is suffering serious health problems. Even South Korean intelligence officials acknowledge that, while they have suspicions, they do not know what is happening in Pyongyang and who is really in power since the death of the man the North called the Great Leader.
Most important, this vacuum has come when Pyongyang is engaged in the most far-reaching and risky negotiations with the outside in decades -- talks with the United States that could lead to the abandonment of North Korea's nuclear ambitions as the country's first steps toward integration with world economics.
The prospect of such an opening -- and the possibility that a breakdown could lead to a military confrontation -- has made the uncertainties surrounding North Korea's leadership even more troubling.
The recent wave of concern began over the weekend when North Korean radio broadcast a report that sounded like a warning to those who might resist the succession of Kim Jong Il.
The radio report, monitored here, said, "A historical lesson is that if we fail to resolve forthwith the issue of the successor who would take over the revolutionary tasks initiated by the Great Leader, the party and revolution would be made a mockery of by the traitorous acts of ambitious people and conspirators."
That followed a hostile blast that came out on Saturday, in which a Foreign Ministry official was quoted as insisting that North Korea would never agree to a critical point being demanded by Washington in the nuclear talks, that Pyongyang permit international inspections of two nuclear waste sites that, it is believed, hold evidence of how much bomb-making material the North may have already produced.
A wide ranging framework for an agreement was announced in Geneva on Aug. 12, and in it North Korea agreed in vague terms to opening its nuclear program to the inspections. So the latest report appeared to mark a hardening of Pyongyang's position after a brief period of flexibility.
After the announcement on Saturday came reports in South Korea that leaflets saying "Down with Kim Jong Il" were found in the diplomatic quarter of Pyongyang. Two western diplomats in Pyongyang, interviewed by telephone, said they had neither seen nor heard of such leaflets, and said such an open show of defiance was doubtful. In addition, a Pyongyang-based correspondent for Tass, the Russian news agency, reported that no leaflets were found.
[A German diplomat in Seoul said that the German Foreign Ministry in Pyongyang confirmed the existence of the leaflets but had not actually seen them, Reuters reported.]
 Nevertheless, the South Korean Government seized on the reports, hinted it believed them, and appeared to go out of its way to convey publicly a sense of worry and drama.
 
Address to Citizens
 Kim Young Sam, the South Korean President, was widely quoted as telling a group of members of the ruling party in Seoul: "Every citizen should stay alert and cautious enough to cope with any contingency in light of a number of serious moves being observed in North Korea." Government officials admitted that this admonition did not entail any unusual steps by the Government.
Mr. Park added that, ultimately, this raised the issue of whether the negotiations on the nuclear issue, which are scheduled to reconvene in Geneva next month, can produce an agreement that will be carried out.
"That is exactly the point the United States and South Korea should look into carefully, whether we are dealing with the right people or not," said Mr. Park. "It's a guessing game."
 
Grist for Stories
 An American official who has followed the situation commented on the rumblings about succession problems in the North: "We're treating it as a rumor. But it's still too early to say that it's not true. We don't know."
The official North Korean news media, as usual, have been providing plenty of grist for stories that the succession is proceeding smoothly. The Workers' Party newspaper today carried an article, quoted by the official Korean Central News Agency, saying, "The Dear Leader, Kim Jong Il, who has fully inherited all the noble virtues and qualities of the fatherly leader, is the great leader who is leading the Korean people to victory."
The article also characterized Mr. Kim as the head of the party and of the state, the two titles he is still formally missing.
 
Demands by the North
 "To all these questions, my answer is this: let's wait and see," said Kim Sam Hoon, South Korea's chief official on nuclear issues.
If anything, these developments only underscored how much is at stake in this sensitive phase in one of the world's most dangerous regions. For example, North Korea has said that, in principle, it would be willing to scale back its nuclear program if it received modern light-water reactors for generating electricity, economic aid and diplomatic recognition. Any agreement along those lines would entail not a moderate turn in North Korea's policy, but a radical shift in course.
The construction of a new nuclear reactor by outsiders, which would also require the revamping of the country's outdated electrical grid, diplomatic engagement with the United States and an opening to investment, would represent a burst of light into the shadowy world of North Korea. That would bring enormous social and political risks to both North and South Korea, since no one knows how such a rigidly controlled society would respond to these contacts.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: GOVERNMENT POLICY;
Hardening Its Stance, U.S. Expands Guantanamo Camp

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today ordered a vast and immediate expansion of its capacity to house fleeing Cubans at Guantanamo Bay and said it was prepared to maintain encampments of Cubans at the base or perhaps in third countries for the indefinite future.
Faced with an ever-surging flow of refugees, the Administration made clear that it intended to expend enormous effort to accommodate the Cubans in tent cities abroad without allowing them to spill onto American shores. 
 "They will absolutely, in no way, have any way of coming to the United States," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman.
By painting the prospect of a bleak life in rough camps, the White House sought to convince Cubans somehow that setting out to sea will no longer get them to the United States. But at the same time, Mr. Clinton's deputies showed clear concern over the mounting financial and political costs of an exodus that has confounded the Administration and begun to stretch Government resources thin.
 
Policy a Failure, Dole Says
 As Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, labeled Mr. Clinton's policy a failure, Defense Secretary William J. Perry conceded that days of broadcast warnings and other messages by the Administration had failed to convince Cubans that they would fare better at home.
"We have a flood of boat people on the way to Guantanamo now," Mr. Perry told reporters at a special White House briefing.
To underscore Mr. Clinton's determination to insulate Americans from the impact of the exodus, Ms. Myers declared today that the President would never move Cubans intercepted at sea to military bases, to Federal facilities on the United States mainland or, in fact, to the nation at all.
But no one in the Administration could offer a clear picture today of how the United States hopes to create conditions that might entice Cubans who have fled Fidel Castro's regime to return home. And as aides to Mr. Clinton acknowledged that establishing havens for them would require enormous expense and manpower, they said the relentless arithmetic of the refugee crisis might yet leave the White House little choice but to return fleeing Cubans to their country, a last-ditch move they would seek at all costs to avoid.
With the hasty drive to erect more tents and cots, the capacity of refugee camps in the 45-square-mile base in Guantanamo Bay will nearly double to 40,000 by the end of the next week, Mr. Perry announced. Under a directive issued by the Pentagon today, it could grow to 60,000 or beyond; at the same time, the Administration moved toward agreements with Panama and other countries that could provide the option of transferring refugees to havens there.
Since the abrupt reversal in the United States' open-door policy for Cuban refugees last Friday, more than 2,000 Cubans have been shipped to Guantanamo after being intercepted in the Straits of Florida. They have joined 14,000 Haitians who have been there for weeks, and 7,000 more Cubans were being carried there this morning aboard Coast Guard and Naval vessels.
Even after 10 P.M. today, however, by which time the United States had already plucked 2,791 more Cubans from the sea and set them on a course toward Guantanamo, senior aides to Mr. Clinton said they believed the rapid expansion of the base could keep pace for now with an alarming refugee tide.
From Attorney General Janet Reno, who sought to project toughness as she glared into television cameras at the White House, to Administration officials who met with Cuban-Americans in Florida, aides to Mr. Clinton sought every opportunity today to try to find some new way to persuade Cubans to stay home.
"It is too dangerous," Ms. Reno, a former Dade County prosecutor, said in a message intended to be relayed to Cubans in expanded Spanish-language broadcasts by Radio Marti. "You are going to Guantanamo or to other safe havens and you will not be processed -- not be processed -- for admission to the United States."
At the same briefing, Mr. Perry appeared intent on quashing suspicions that the Administration's will to provide for vast numbers of Cubans on its leased territory in Guantanamo might expire. "We are preparing to maintain that base indefinitely, if necessary, until such time as the people can be repatriated to Cuba," the Defense Secretary said.
Fernando Remirez de Estenoz Barciela, the Cuban representative to the United Nations, said in New York today that the refugee crisis could end if the United States opened talks with the Castro Government as a step toward lifting its economic embargo against Havana. Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff quickly responded that the United States saw "nothing to be gained" from such a course.
"It should be clear after 35 years to Fidel Castro and his government that the way he has been managing the affairs of the island is a failure," Mr. Tarnoff said. But that stance came under immediate criticism from some Democrats on Capitol Hill, who said that an Administration that has proven willing to open high-level talks with North Korea and grant preferential trade status to China should open a dialogue with Mr. Castro.
"The cold war is over," Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, said from the Senate floor. "Cuba no longer presents the type of threat that it did even a few months ago."
The sense of alarm within the Administration about the refugee flow could nevertheless be measured in the sheer numbers of Coast Guard vessels and Navy ships assigned to the effort. At least 30 Coast Guard cutters, some from the West Coast, along with a similar number of smaller Coast Guard craft, were patrolling the waters off Florida tonight, where they were joined by 10 Navy ships and awaited the arrival Thursday of three more Navy vessels.
 
Threat of Opening New Door
 Administration officials expressed apprehension that the Castro Government, which they believe has deliberately loosed the refugee flow, might make another destabilizing move. At the White House today, Mr. Tarnoff, the third-ranking official at the State Department, warned that the United States would regard as "an unfriendly act" a decision by the Cuban Government to permit Cubans to enter the Guantanamo Bay base over land, a step that could quickly overflow tents and cots now in place in the compound.
Even if it can be maintained, Administration officials acknowledged today, the decision to house Cuban migrants in the Guantanamo base or third countries carries heavy costs in energy and expense. They noted that the cost of intercepting and housing Haitian refugees since the spring has already soared over $200 million.
Even if the Cubans were moved to a haven in Panama or another country, those costs would continue to mount, Administration officials said today. They said the Pentagon had concluded that 800 American troops would be needed at a proposed camp in the British-owned Turks and Caicos to watch over just 2,500 refugees there.
For that reason, the officials said, the Administration is unlikely to move swiftly to transfer Cubans or Haitians to third countries even if it can reach agreements with them to provide havens.

HEADLINE: All Haitians Are Tuned In to the Rumor Mill

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The story spread like wildfire: a secret underground pipeline had been built under the border and was pumping gasoline from the Dominican Republic into Haiti, defying international sanctions. That fanciful tale going around this month was then succeeded by reports of dozens of clandestine laboratories being built in the countryside to make poison for use against American invaders.
Millions of Haiti's people live beyond the reach of newspapers, television and even radio, but everyone here, from illiterate peasants to the rich, has a lifetime subscription to the flourishing word-of-mouth network known as "telediol," or "mouth television." Part rumor mill, part oral news service, telediol is one of the most accessible and effective means of communication for Haitians. 
 The importance of the medium was demonstrated again last month when the number of people leaving by boat for the United States suddenly surged, threatening to wreck the Clinton Administration's policy on Haitian refugees, and then just as quickly dropped to a trickle. In both instances, Haitians and foreign diplomats say, people were responding to information obtained via telediol.
 
Word Spreads Fast
 Initially, boat people picked up by the Coast Guard were allowed into the United States, and sent word back to their villages that chances of success were high. But when Washington switched to a policy of sending refugees to the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, or to "safe havens" in other countries, people in even the most remote areas learned of that change within a few days.
"What Washington had to say throughout that exodus was far less important than the message transmitted by Haitians who had made it to Miami or had ended up in Guantanamo," a diplomat here said. "Thanks to telediol, that word got up into the hills and out into the hinterland with a speed and a degree of accuracy that was astonishing."
Even when information passed along the network turns out not to be true, it can influence events. This spring, for instance, after news spread that a foreign tanker loaded with fuel would soon dock in the port of Jacmel, the price of gasoline dropped sharply, rising again only after the United States Embassy said no such vessel existed.
Sometimes known as "Radio 32," a reference to the number of teeth in the mouth, telediol is also of vital importance to supporters of Haiti's ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Denied access to most other media, which are increasingly controlled or censored by the military-dominated Government, they have been forced to rely on word-of-mouth to make their case.
Telediol has always been an important means of transmitting information in a country in which an estimated 65 to 80 percent of the people are illiterate and the principal language, Creole, did not develop a full written form until a generation ago. But the importance of oral communication has been sharpened by the current political crisis, in particular the economic embargo imposed on Haiti by the United Nations with the intention of forcing Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the military leader, and his associates to step down.
Even before the embargo, there were just two newspapers of any note in the capital, each publishing only three times a week, and a mere five televisions for every 1,000 Haitians. But because of the extensive gasoline shortages brought on by the sanctions, electricity is available in most areas less than a quarter of the day, making television reception impossible except for the very few wealthy enough to afford their own gas-powered generators.
Radio, traditionally the most popular mass medium, has been just as severely affected. Poor people living in areas with no electrical service -- about two-thirds of Haiti's population of seven million -- are big users of transistor radios, but the batteries to power them are no longer available.
"If I can't afford to feed my children, then I certainly can't afford to buy radio batteries on the black market," said Jean-Leonel Antoine, an unemployed carpenter who lives on the outskirts of the capital in the sprawling slum called Cite Soleil. "So I rely on word of mouth to know what's going on."
In addition, the state of siege that the "provisional President," Emile Jonassaint, decreed on Aug. 1 includes measures intended to prevent radio and television from presenting balanced coverage, warning stations to "avoid the diffusion of all alarmist or tendentious news" and not to allow themselves to become "instruments of foreign propaganda."
Another order forbids stations from broadcasting any "communique from foreign embassies or press services" and threatens "appropriate measures to enforce these restrictions" if there are violations.
Other unpopular Haitian rulers have tried to stamp out telediol, without success. The dictator Francois Duvalier, for one, made rumormongering a crime, but telediol went underground, and was often quite accurate in predicting what he would do. Though telediol may not always be accurate, it is always fast. One old Haitian joke tells of a man whose boss tells him he has lost his job and who then heads straight home, only to have his wife greet him by saying, "I heard -- you've been fired."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Stocks staged a powerful late rally that startled Wall Street and left analysts divided on its meaning. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 70.90 points, or 1.88 percent. Some saw the surge as a sign that the market was ready to recover the losses that began after the Federal Reserve started raising rates, while others said the rally would be short-lived. [Page D1.]
Treasury prices surged, helped by weakness in orders in durable goods and a stronger dollar. A auction of five-year notes also bolstered the bond market. [D13.] 
 The dollar strengthened against the yen as the Bank of Japan intervened. The dollar also rose against the German mark. [D16.]
Natural gas prices tumbled on signs that electric utilities are cutting demand. Crude oil prices and copper rose. [D16.]
 
The Economy
Orders for durable goods fell sharply in July. Although the data were weaker than expected, many economists were skeptical that it reflected a slackening in actual business activity. [D1.]
The Government has widened its attack on lending bias, telling banks in a settlement of a case against a Maryland savings and loan that they cannot simply serve affluent white suburbs and ignore poor and minority areas. The settlement suggests that banks will now have to do much more. News Analysis. [D1.]
An economist hired by baseball players disputes the owners' assertions about the financial problems facing the clubs. [B9.]
 
Companies
Jeffrey Katzenberg is leaving as head of Disney Studios. Mr. Katzenberg -- one of the most powerful executives in Hollywood -- had apparently sought, and failed, to get the No. 2 job at Walt Disney. Joe Roth will assume some of his responsibilities. [D1.]
3DO plans to adopt the Power PC chip for its next generation of video-game players. Analysts say that 3DO's move portends the blurring of computers and consumer-electronics in the households of the future. [D1.]
Will there be a renewed price war in personal computers? Analysts were uncertain after I.B.M. said it would cut prices of selected models by an average of 22 percent. I.B.M.'s announcement follows similarly steep price cuts made by Compaq. [D3.]
Two mutual fund companies will merge. American Capital plans to merge with Van Kampen Merritt. [D3.]
Honda Motor said operating earnings rose 15.8 percent, buoyed by strong sales in the United States. [D3.]
The parent company of Florsheim and Converse will split its four businesses into three publicly traded companies. [D3.]
Lac Minerals agreed to a friendly takeover. [D4.]
Novell plans to cut 1,750 jobs. The company also reported a loss for the third quarter. [D4.]
The Los Angeles Kings hockey team's president is expected to plead guilty to four criminal counts related to a U.S. investigation of his banking practices, investigators and lawyers say. [D5.]
ABC was smart in moving "Roseanne" from Tuesday, analysts said, because it will protect its investment in the show. [D17.]
 
Today's Columns
Some lawmakers are proposing tax-based fixes for health care. New limits on the deductibility of medical benefits would raise money and make people more cost-conscious. One Congressman calls for using vouchers. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Shareholders of Blockbuster Entertainment are angry that the company will be sold to Viacom at a price lower than what it had negotiated eight months earlier. But analysts bet the deal will hold as long as Viacom's stock does not tumble. Market Place. [D6.]
Why can't Madison Avenue write? More ads in magazines and newspapers -- and sometimes on television -- have misspellings and grammatical errors. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE HOUSE;
House Democrats Far Short of Votes for Health Care Plan, Tallies Find

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Confidential vote counts by the most ardent supporters of universal health insurance show that House Democrats are far short of the votes needed to pass sweeping health care legislation.
The counts are hardly a surprise. Democratic leaders in the House have not begun to whip their partisans into line, and they have conceded for weeks that they cannot pass the legislation they want today. The Senate is even less eager to embrace widespread changes in the health care system. 
 The House is considering a bill proposed by the Democratic floor leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, that would require employers to pay 80 percent of their workers' health insurance premiums.
 
Such Surveys Feared
 The vote counts show so many Democrats opposing the Gephardt bill that White House officials recently urged their allies outside Government not to compile or distribute such lists for fear they could be used to undercut people lobbying for an employer mandate. A lobbyist who heard the White House appeal summarized the concern this way: "Members of Congress are already nervous about voting for an employer mandate. If they saw these numbers, they'd be less willing to walk the plank."
The tallies, the most systematic effort to tabulate sentiment in Congress to date, were compiled by a coalition of more than 75 labor, business, health, consumer, civil rights and disability groups. The coalition supports universal insurance coverage with a requirement for employers to help pay for it. Lobbyists from the organizations meet daily to share political intelligence, discuss strategy and parcel out lobbying assignments.
 
60 Firmly Opposed
 The lists classify House members in five categories, according to their positions on the Gephardt bill. The latest list, circulated this week, shows more than 60 Democrats firmly opposed to the Gephardt bill or likely to vote against it. The tally names 153 Democrats as supporters of the Gephardt bill and 22 leaning in favor, with 15 undecided or neutral. This leaves the Democrats well short of the 218 votes needed to pass a bill if all 435 House members vote. Democratic leaders have not been counting on any House Republicans to back the Gephardt bill.
In the Senate, similar tallies suggest that 51 of the 100 senators are, at the moment, likely to vote against a proposal to make employers contribute to the cost of health insurance for their employees. The Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, wants to impose such a requirement on companies with 25 or more employees if voluntary efforts do not achieve insurance coverage for 95 percent of Americans by the year 2000.
Laura Nichols, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gephardt, said, "We have not taken an official whip count, a formal up or down count" of House members. She said some lawmakers were waiting for cost estimates from the Congressional Budget Office before they decided how to vote.
Ned McCulloch, a lobbyist at the Service Employees International Union, said the coalition's vote counts were based on statements by members of Congress to lobbyists in Washington and to constituents back home. Spot checks by The New York Times confirmed the accuracy of the assessments.
 
Opposition From South
 The latest list shows that much of the Democratic opposition to Mr. Gephardt's bill comes, as expected, from the South and the Southwest. Among those listed as likely to vote against it are Representatives Michael A. Andrews of Texas, Jim Cooper of Tennessee, Mike Parker of Mississippi, J. Roy Rowland of Georgia, Charles W. Stenholm of Texas and W. J. (Billy) Tauzin of Louisiana.
But the list also suggests opposition among House Democrats in other parts of the country. For example, Representatives Robert E. Andrews of New Jersey, Cal Dooley and Jane Harman of California, Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, Richard H. Lehman of California, Paul McHale of Pennsylvania, Collin C. Peterson of Minnesota and Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota are listed as likely to vote against the Gephardt bill.
Robert A. Chlopak, a coordinator of the coalition supporting the Gephardt bill, said the situation was in flux. "There's a strong base of support for Gephardt," he said. "We have work to do to get the votes to go over the top, but it's within reach."
 
Employer Burden Feared
 In an interview, Representative Pomeroy, who served as Insurance Commissioner of North Dakota for eight years, said he objected to the Gephardt bill because it would impose a new burden on employers and create "a substantially larger role for Government," expanding Medicare to cover millions of people who are uninsured or work for small businesses. "Private insurance would not be able to compete with the new Part C of Medicare," he said.
In two other tests of party loyalty, Mr. Pomeroy voted for President Clinton's budget plan last year and for the anti-crime bill this month. But he said today: "If one listens closely, one can hear the air going out of the balloon for the Gephardt proposal." Passage of an omnibus health bill like the Gephardt bill is simply not going to happen in the final weeks of this session. The leadership is losing a whole tier of moderate Democrats that they would need to pass it."
Mr. Hamilton, a member of Congress for 30 years, has not said publicly how he will vote on the Gephardt bill. But in a recent report to constituents, he wrote:
"Hoosiers are becoming more cautious as they learn more about health care reform. I think Congress and the President should proceed with reforms which have strong public support, such as insurance reform, reducing red tape and promoting managed care. What we should not do is try to reform the entire health care system in one year."
 
'Social Engineering'
 Congressman Andrews of New Jersey, explaining his opposition to the Gephardt bill, said: "We don't want a plan that disrupts the coverage or raises the taxes of people who have coverage. People see it as social engineering with 15 percent of the economy."
The Senate tally shows how lawmakers are expected to vote on a motion to eliminate the employer mandate from Mr. Mitchell's bill. Eight Democrats and all but one of the Senate's 44 Republicans are listed as likely to support such a motion.
The tally of Democrats shows Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama as firmly opposed to an employer mandate. Listed as leaning against the mandate are Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
YESTERDAY
The bipartisan coalition of senators that has offered an alternative proposal held the spotlight, as President Clinton criticized the plan while the group was working to complete it and a variety of lobbyists attacked it.
 
CONGRESS
The self-styled "mainstream coalition," led by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, argued that its plan would broaden the number of insured Americans to about 92 percent of the population from about 85 percent. Members also said their plan would slow the flow of Federal red ink by about $100 billion over 10 years.
 
WHITE HOUSE
 President Clinton criticized the coalition's proposal for not requiring employers to pay for their workers' insurance. He said this meant there could not be prescription drug coverage for the elderly or much money for long-term care. Mr. Clinton said the group was "walking away from what is the only known way to provide universal coverage, control cost increases in the out years, and still generate enough money."
 
LOBBYING
Organizations representing businesses, the elderly, unions and the disabled attacked the plan. The United States Chamber of Commerce called it "unacceptable," complaining of new taxes on employers who do offer insurance to workers. The National Association of Manufacturers said it would lead to excessive litigation. At the same time, a group of nearly 100 labor, medical and civic organizations denounced the proposal, for, among other things, lacking "any requirement for employer contributions." Those critics included the American Academy of Family Physicians, the League of Women Voters and the United Steelworkers of America. Eugene Lehrmann, president of the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "We oppose it. It doesn't get health care reform right."

HEADLINE: Stopping Blight at the Border;
Two Paths for Ridgewood, Queens, and Bushwick, Brooklyn

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
For the residents of Ridgewood, Queens, the invisible jagged line separating them from Bushwick, Brooklyn, has long been an object of both anxiety and opportunity.
A small but sturdy community on the southwest edge of Queens, across the street from Brooklyn, Ridgewood watched in fear as Bushwick set itself aflame in the 1960's and 70's, culminating in the July 1977 blackout that produced a night of smoke and looting. "Ridgewood has only five years left to go" was the popular phrase 25, 20 and 15 years ago among doomsaying residents, convinced that Bushwick's blight would spread. 
 But Bushwick's example proved an incentive for Ridgewood to prevent an onslaught of flight, decay and urban fatalism. A group of civic and business associations coalesced around the idea that a neighborhood could remain stable while becoming ethnically diverse.
Now, 17 years after the blackout, which many thought would set the stage for Ridgewood's destruction, the neighborhood has emerged as one of the few stable, diverse blue-collar areas left in New York. Much of Ridgewood's success comes from an ability to hang on to its own manufacturing industry, providing jobs and a tax base. Economists and planners say this mixture of self-determination and good fortune is what New York City needs in its less sure-footed neighborhoods.
 
Business Groups and Vigilance
 "Ridgewood has become a model for what needs to be done in other areas of New York," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University's graduate school. "It's one of the most important blue-collar ethnic communities we have left."
The neighborhood has successfully used many tools from the city and state, including a business improvement district that taxes merchants along Myrtle Avenue to keep the main commercial strip clean and vigorous, a local development corporation that fosters industry, and a restoration corporation that helps keep its brownstones from falling into disrepair and being abandoned.
But residents attribute much of their success to simple vigilance: a never-ending campaign to wash off graffiti, fill an empty store, keep a knitting mill from moving or a landlord from letting his apartment house decay. Bushwick stands nearby as a constant reminder of what could happen when a neighborhood lets its guard down.
 
Success Without Quiche
 "It's always an uphill battle," said Paul Kerzner, chairman of the Greater Ridgewood Restoration Corporation, which plants street trees and works with landlords to preserve housing. "When you see graffiti, you have to clean it up right away. When you hear of a drug location, you have to scream bloody murder to the police captain until you get results. Little by little, you create a climate of civility that people respect, and you make sure that standard never gets lowered."
In the early 1980's, after the civil unrest but before the crack epidemic that ravaged much of Bushwick, Mr. Kerzner and other residents dreamed of creating another Park Slope or Brooklyn Heights. "In a very short time, we'll be a household name," Mr. Kerzner said in a newspaper interview in 1983, just after 3,000 Ridgewood homes were listed in the National Register of Historic Places. "We're going to get the quiche crowd."
But neither the quiche nor the crowd ever showed up. Ridgewood remains working-class, with a Mandee store instead of a Gap. Parents shop at large children's stores like Happy Days, where inexpensive strollers hang from the ceiling. Mothers who work in the knitting mills on Ridgewood's southern tier walk home with their children after school.
Though its German bakeries and restaurants still do a brisk business -- a lingering remnant of the neighborhood's European heritage -- a growing number of Hispanic and Asian merchants have opened shop on Myrtle and on Fresh Pond Road. Their presence reflects the neighborhood's population, which is now one-quarter Hispanic, one-tenth Asian and the rest mostly white.
Though the border with Brooklyn is unmarked -- and known primarily to longtime residents, mail carriers and politicians -- anyone driving through the two neighborhoods would have no trouble distinguishing them.
 
Two Myrtle Avenues
 In Ridgewood, Myrtle Avenue is swept by a private sanitation crew hired by the local business improvement district. The Ridgewood part of Myrtle is not only far cleaner than the part that runs through Bushwick, which is kept in permanent shadow by an overhead subway track, but is also cleaner than that in adjoining Glendale, a much more homogenous neighborhood farther east in Queens.
Though Bushwick has built some attractive public housing in recent years, many private homes, owned by outside landlords, are in poor repair or boarded up. By contrast, most of Ridgewood's housing is made up of well-kept brownstones and small apartment buildings, most of them occupied by their owners.
Ridgewood has its own manufacturing base in the abundance of knitting mills that make it the country's knitting capital. Most of the mill workers are neighborhood women of Hispanic or European heritage, who often provide a second income for their families. While Bushwick's industrial base crumbled decades ago when the big national breweries forced local beer manufacturers out of business, the knitting mill owners have survived despite growing pressure from foreign competitors.
Ridgewood's interlocking network of civic groups and improvement associations stops abruptly at the Brooklyn border. Ridgewood leaders concede they have done little to assist in Bushwick's halting climb out of the blight that began in the 1970's and the spread of drugs and crime in the 1980's. Instead, they have concentrated on keeping problems out of their neighborhood, and by extension, much of the rest of Queens.
 
Racism, but Diversity
 "You could make a case that Ridgewood is the most important neighborhood in America," said Gary Giordano, a longtime resident and manager of the local community board, only half joking. "Here you've got Queens, which has the largest and most stable middle-class tax base of any borough in the largest city in the country. If working-class residents started to abandon Ridgewood, and were replaced by people who are unemployed or substance abusers, it would have a devastating effect on the adjacent neighborhoods and the rest of Queens."
Mr. Giordano is aware that such words, coming from a white man living near a racial divide, carry the familiar whiff of code phrases for minorities. But he said that while racism is present in Ridgewood, the neighborhood is among the more diverse in Queens. According to 1990 Census figures, Ridgewood is 64 percent white, 26 percent Hispanic and about 9 percent Asian. Though it has few blacks, it is more diverse than Middle Village and Howard Beach, both 91 percent white; Bayside, which is 78 percent white; and St. Albans, which is 95 percent black.
There are still residents in Ridgewood who lower their voice when saying the word "Brooklyn," as if the very name embodied the other-ness of the people who live across the county border, which runs in an irregular line across Cypress, Wyckoff and Irving avenues. Politicians have been known to campaign in Ridgewood on a platform to "keep Brooklyn out of Queens," which is often interpreted as keeping Ridgewood mostly white.
 
Shopping Across Border
 Nonetheless, the neighborhood has tolerated and absorbed a large number of Hispanic residents, many of whom moved across the border from Bushwick, which is 65 percent Hispanic and a quarter black. And some Bushwick residents say they prefer shopping in Ridgewood rather than on their less prosperous commercial strip on Knickerbocker Avenue.
Vincent Hall Jr., a longtime Bushwick community leader, who is black, said he felt far more at ease shopping in Ridgewood than he would in more predominantly white Queens neighborhoods like Howard Beach.
"I don't blame them for working hard to improve themselves," said Mr. Hall. "We don't have any jealousy or conflict between our neighborhoods; in fact, more power to them. Now what we have to do in Bushwick is learn how they did it and see if we can do it ourselves."
Bushwick's decline began with the postwar demise of the breweries and accelerated with the migration out of dense urban areas. Because Queens was seen as newer and more suburban, it attracted many Brooklyn residents seeking escape. Many European immigrants who had lived crowded into neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Greenpoint felt comfortable amid the old-world atmosphere of Ridgewood. Crossing the Brooklyn-Queens line was an important psychological passage for many families, and it remains so today.
 
Keeping the Stoops Clean
 The descendants of those Europeans have no doubt that a certain Germanic fussiness played a large role in Ridgewood's continuing insistence on staying physically fit.
"The most public face of Ridgewood has always been clean," said Joannene Coppinger-Borock, who grew up in the neighborhood and is now industrial coordinator for the Ridgewood Local Development Corporation. "It goes back to those old German ladies keeping their stoops so clean you could eat off them."
The European tradition of guilds and improvement associations made Ridgewood an ideal testing ground for innovations like the business improvement district, under which the state grants local groups taxing authority. Ridgewood's, established in 1988, was the first such district in Queens.
Theodore M. Renz, a lifelong resident who is executive director of the development corporation, said he is concerned that there isn't a next generation of leaders, white or minority, waiting to take over the structures of neighborhood power that have supported Ridgewood in the past.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN FLORIDA;
Waiting Anxiously For Rules On Cuba

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 24

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration delayed announcing new rules on trade with Cuba today, small businesses here that depend on sending visitors and goods to Cuba waited anxiously to find out whether the escalating United States crackdown would put them out of business.
New regulations reflecting President Clinton's order restricting money transfers and charter flights to Cuba were supposed to be published today by the Treasury Department's Foreign Assets Control Office. But Administration officials said this evening that the publication of the rules would be delayed. 
 The people who help Miami's Cuban residents send money orders and packages of food, clothing and medicine to relatives in Cuba said they would have to close shop if such shipments are banned.
"We are going to do what the Government will allow us to do," said Carlos Hernandez, manager of Va Cuba, one of about 80 outfits in the Miami area that specialize in shipments to Cuba.
"But no one can control the individual," he cautioned, predicting that many Cubans in Miami would find other channels to assist their families. "Blood bonds are stronger than any regulations, and sooner or later Cubans will use third countries to send money to their families."
 
Checking the Details
 President Clinton said last weekend that he was prohibiting cash remittances and reducing charter flights to Cuba to punish Fidel Castro for encouraging refugees to flee the island by boat and makeshift vessels.
It was anticipated that the revised regulations would be published today but the process was taking longer than expected. "The regulations will be provided as soon as possible, probably in the next day or two, after completion of an interagency review," said Charles Peacock, a Treasury Department spokesman. "Everyone wants to make sure all the details are correct and all the i's dotted and all the t's crossed."
Most of the Miami shipping agencies are mom-and-pop operations, small family-run businesses perhaps employing 500 people, including about 20 similar agencies in New York, New Jersey and the District of Columbia, which also have large colonies of Cuban-Americans.
Washington's new tough line on Cuba, triggered by the refugee situation, seems to be gaining grudging acceptance by many Cubans in Miami. That acceptance is helped mainly by the conservative hardliners among Miami's Cuban leaders who went to the White House last week and helped shape the policy.
 
In Little Havana
 Mr. Hernandez and Eugenio Morales, general manager of El Espanol, another package shipping outfit with five offices in Miami, said they supported the proposed measures but hoped they would leave room for shipments of food, clothing and medicine.
In the Little Havana section of Miami, contradictions abounded.
People supported any measures taken by the United States that might help bring down the Castro Government. But they openly spoke of circumventing the revised regulations, which are designed to keep dollars from flowing into Cuba and buttressing the island's economy, by keeping up payments to relatives there through Mexico or other countries.
Francisco Gonzalez, 52, manager of a tailoring shop, said he would continue sending money to his sister, though he expressed concern that it might indirectly aid Mr. Castro.
John Zamora, 26, has a half-brother in Cuba and sends him money and medicine. Next month, he said, he plans to visit Cuba by going through a third country and he will be taking money to his half-brother.
 
An Intractable Threat?
 Another element of the new policy that appears to be sinking in is Washington's insistence that refugees transported to Guantanamo Bay in Cuba will not be admitted to the United States anytime soon. After the decades during which political asylum was available to nearly any Cuban who reached these shores, there was skepticism that asylum would not be granted to the "balseros," the collective term -- literally "rafters" -- that is used to describe all the refugees taking to the sea.
Even today, there was a feeling that the warning was being used by high Government officials to scare off those still in Cuba who were thinking of joining the exodus and that it was not an intractable threat that meant the balseros would never set foot on the United States mainland.
"If my brother and his family decide to come over here, going to Guantanamo will not stop them," insisted Felix Perez, the 53-year-old owner of a hardware store in Little Havana. "They will go anywhere as long as they get out of Cuba."
Rubin Avilla Jr., 46, said that his family in Cuba had told him two days ago that his niece and nephew were intent on becoming refugees.
"I beg them not to leave; their mother begs them not to leave," said Mr. Avilla, owner of an alarm company. "They say Guantanamo is better. At least they'll have food and water. I say it's not. They will be detained. At least in Cuba they have family."

HEADLINE: Mayor's Veto of Food Vendor Bill to Stand

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Backing away from a confrontation with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council has decided not to challenge his veto of a bill that would have allowed food vendors to operate on streets where the Mayor had sought to crack down on illegal vending.
The bill would have allowed food vendors to operate on 17 midtown streets that had previously been restricted and that have been subject to a vigorous enforcement effort by the Giuliani administration. The bill was approved in June by the Democratic-controlled Council by a 40-to-11 vote. 
 But Mr. Giuliani rejected the measure last month, calling it a piecemeal effort to solve a widespread problem. The Council had 30 days to override the veto, and yesterday was the last.
 
Significant Compromise
 The decision not to try to override the veto was a significant compromise between the Mayor and the Council.
Karen Koslowitz, a Councilwoman from Queens who is the head of the Council's Consumer Affairs Committee and sponsor of the bill, said she was persuaded by the Mayor to abandon the attempt to override after Mr. Giuliani agreed to develop a vending plan for the city and after he agreed to consult with her committee and allow it to review the plan.
Mr. Giuliani has vetoed three bills since becoming Mayor. Apart from the vendor bill, he vetoed a measure that would have directed the Water Board to set annual rates at the time the budget is adopted. The third bill gave the Council a role in reviewing most mayoral initiatives to turn over city functions to private companies.
The privatization veto was overridden by the Council by an overwhelming margin. But it took no action on the water-rate measure because the Water Board itself took a step toward setting annual rates when the budget is adopted.
Ms. Koslowitz said yesterday that she expected the administration to develop a plan on illegal vending by the time her committee holds hearings on the issue in November.
"I would like to see something in place by November so that, when spring comes, these vendors can go back on the street," she said. "Now that there is some time, I would like to see a plan that addresses the problem in all the boroughs. But if they don't have a plan in place by then, we might have to act."
The administration says its crackdown on midtown vendors is part of his administration's emphasis on quality-of-life issues. The Mayor has maintained that he is merely enforcing 11-year-old regulations enacted by the Council, under which the Consumer Affairs Department banned food vending from certain congested streets. But before he took office, the regulations were seldom enforced.
Also yesterday, the City Council backed away from its confrontation with the administration over $14 million in unbudgeted spending by the Police Department in last year's budget.
Three weeks ago, members of the Council's Finance Committee refused to approve the Mayor's request to modify the budget to take account of the unexpected costs, half of which comes from higher than anticipated overtime costs.
But yesterday, despite renewed criticism from members, the committee voted unanimously to approve the budget modification, which uses money from the general reserves to pay for the costs. The full Council later voted, 36 to 9, to approve the change.
The committee's chairman, Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat, complained again that the Mayor's office and the Police Department had not explained why costs had crept above what was budgeted.
Mr. Berman said he was not satisfied with the administration's explanation that increased arrests had caused the unexpected overtime costs. He said that, examining the number of arrests in the last four months of the fiscal year that ended in July, each arrest averaged $150 in overtime costs.
 
Extraordinary Expense
 "This is an extraordinary overtime expense per arrest," Mr. Berman said. "Somewhere, someplace, somehow this has got to be brought under control."
Mr. Berman, who announced that the committee would hold hearings in September because overtime costs are projected to rise throughout the city's agencies, then voted to approve the budget modification, followed by the other committee members.
Despite their criticism, members made it clear that they had little choice but to approve the Mayor's request since the money had already been spent.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: BEHIND THE SCENES;
Health Care's Genial Wheeler-Dealer

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
When John Berlinger Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who is at the center of fading hope for compromise on health care legislation, emerged from a Senate Democratic caucus the other day, a pile of waiting reporters glommed onto him like iron filings on a magnet.
"We're going in circles," the trim, tanned Senator told them with the merest hint of a smile. "But we're moving aggressively." 
 It was vintage Breaux: the genial operator who never gives up on a deal (until he has to) and the discreet negotiator who never gives up much of anything (at least in public). This is a man who likes to say that the best press secretary is not one who can get a Senator's name in the paper but one who can keep it out, and who lives by Earl Long's maxim: "Never put anything in writing that you can convey by a wink or a nod."
These days he may also be something very like an indispensable man.
"In this Congress and under this Presidency, if you want to know where legislation is going to end up, just check where John Breaux is standing," said Lawrence O'Donnell Jr., chief of staff to the Senate Finance Committee, where Mr. Breaux has been a bellwether on issues from President Clinton's failed economic stimulus package last year, to the budget package, to health. "He tends to be in the middle on these things."
 
'No Passion in the Middle'
 Right now Mr. Breaux is in the middle of a last-ditch effort -- he puts its chance of success at "less than 50-50" -- to persuade wavering members of both parties that his modest proposal for increasing access to health insurance and reducing the Federal deficit is worth taking a deep breath and passing. The plan is the work of a group of nearly 20 moderates, led by Mr. Breaux and his Republican colleague John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, that first took shape in the Finance Committee earlier this summer.
But it is a tough sell, and Mr. Breaux knows it. As he explained in an interview today: "There's no passion in the middle. There's passion on the left, and there's passion on the right."
Indeed, the so-called "mainstream" proposal falls so far short of Mr. Clinton's goal of universal coverage that at least one member of the compromise group, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, has withdrawn his support. More liberal Democrats are balking, the Republican leadership looks askance at the whole notion, and Mr. Chafee has signaled limited willingness to revise the plan further.
By his own admission, Mr. Breaux has been all over the map on health care in the last six months, first supporting a plan that relied mostly on market forces, then one to require employers to pay for insurance, then one that might require them to, and finally his latest idea.
He has not drawn the attention that the authors of some rival Democratic proposals have. (He once cracked in his Cajun accent that the free-market plan he co-sponsored with Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee was seen as the "Coopuh, Coopuh, Coopuh, Coopuh, Coopuh-Breaux bill.") But neither has he drawn as much scorn from the White House and other advocates of universal coverage. The reason may be that they remember the flexibility captured by his most famous quip: In 1981, he explained his support for Ronald Reagan's social spending cuts, in return for concessions on natural gas policy and sugar subsidies, by saying that while his vote could not be bought, "it can be rented."
To his admirers, he is not inconsistent, just flexible, and reflective of the deep strains in his party and in the Senate on health care.
"What I'm trying to do is to find something that will work," Mr. Breaux said simply. "My goal in all of this is to make it work."
 
The Youthful Veteran
 Mr. Breaux is only 50, and constant tennis keeps him fit, but he is a Capitol Hill veteran. He whetted his appetite on the jambalaya of Louisiana politics as apprentice, driver and administrative assistant to the state's then and now reigning rogue: former Representative, current Governor and perpetual gambler Edwin W. Edwards. He comes from the Governor's hometown, Crowley, in Cajun country, where he first won election to Congress in 1972, at age 28.
He won his Senate seat in 1986, built a rock-solid base of rural Cajuns and New Orleans blacks and, to protect his national political standing, has put some friendly distance between himself and his old mentor. Although friends say he has "calmed down a lot" in recent years, he says the best way to keep early-morning appointments is still to stay up all night, and colleagues refuse even to try to clean up the best stories about him for telling in polite print.
"I think the Ragin' Cajun image in some ways disarms people, and then he moves in for the kill," said Larry Harrington, who was political director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee when Mr. Breaux headed it in the 1990 election cycle. "Better than a lot of other politicians, he is capable of having not just a mastery of the substance but an understanding of what is politically do-able."
Mr. Breaux's reputation as fun-lover does not faze him. "I think it's the French heritage, really," he said. "It's a joie de vivre down there, it's a love of life and not taking yourself too seriously, and knowing that you only go around once."
"People where I'm from understand that," he added. "They would hate dull people."
In his soupy voice, "dull" sounds at first like "Dole," as in Bob, the Senate Republican leader, whose scowl has been deepened these days by the work of the Chafee-Breaux group. "Dole?" the Senator giggles. "Dole and Dull."
But Mr. Breaux is deadly serious about his fear: that increasing partisanship and instant, organized, telecommunicated opposition has derailed the spirit of collegiality that he remembers from his early days in Congress. "I'm really concerned," he said, "that we are moving in the direction of having the demand for perfection in legislative proposals be to the detriment to ever getting anything done."
And he is just as serious about his mission: to help his President, a personal friend from their days together in the moderate Democratic Leadership Council, even if doing so means differing with him, as he has on health, or did last year by helping to kill a complicated energy tax in the Finance Committee. "I want to help this President make it work." he said. "There's a lot a stake in having it work. I mean, I'm in fear of a meltdown."
He credits the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton with focusing attention on health but says the White House misdefined the problem early on, by stressing the 15 percent of Americans who have no health insurance instead of explaining to the 85 percent who do that they already pay dearly -- and inefficiently -- for those who do not.
"The Republicans, on the other hand, focused on the 85 percent of Americans who have health insurance, and they scared the bejesus out of those people by telling them that we were going to make their lives worse," he said. "It's much easier to scare people into opposing something than it is to convince them to support something."
So what is his own bottom line?
"I don't have bottom lines," he said. "You can't afford to have them in this business. I mean, we deal with the art of the possible. That's what we have to be guided by: What can we get? What can you do? And as long as it's better than what we have, that's the bottom line."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Defining what is possible is nothing new to Senator John B. Breaux. "If you want to know where legislation is going to end up," said one Senate aide, "just check where John Breaux is standing." (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CATHOLIC CHURCH;
Catholic Leaders' Dilemma: Abortion vs. Universal Care

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
The nation's largest private provider of health care, the Roman Catholic Church, finds itself of two minds when it comes to new health care legislation.
It desperately wants universal coverage. But it cannot live with a provision that many legislators are likely to insist on including: guaranteed coverage for abortion. 
 As a result, the church finds itself pursuing a lobbying strategy that is at the least exceptionally complicated and at the worst paradoxical.
In dioceses from Albany to Yakima, Wash., Catholic leaders are using telephone calls, postcards and personal visits to Congress to make the two-pronged argument summed up in a flier inserted in church bulletins passed out to people arriving for Mass at various parishes over the last month.
"We can have health care reform that does not include abortion coverage and that does provide coverage for all," it says. The flier, distributed by the bishops' public policy arm, the United States Catholic Conference, includes the number of the Capitol Hill switchboard.
In a speech in Washington in May, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago declared passionately that "justice and the common good" demanded a thorough restructuring of health care, but he added that "insistence on abortion coverage will turn millions of advocates of reform into adversaries of health care legislation."
Most of the proposals before Congress now include a requirement that Americans be offered a standard package of benefits including "pregnancy-related services," a phrase widely taken to include abortion. But this provision is certain to provoke bitter debate if and when the House and Senate begin serious efforts to pass legislation.
The church's opposition to abortion is, of course, well known. But to grasp the bishops' position, one must understand that the Catholic stake in health care is institutional as well.
As the largest private health care provider in the United States, the Catholic Church accounts for a total of about one of every six hospital beds. Through various dioceses and religious orders, the church operates 566 hospitals, many of them founded by congregations of nuns. They have a disproportionately large stake in the quest for universal coverage, as they treat large numbers of the poor and uninsured.
The hospitals have already been struggling to preserve that sense of charitable mission in the face of the market forces that are reshaping the medical system. Further complicating matters, many institutions are in the midst of a generational handover, as a dwindling cadre of nuns hands over control to lay administrators.
The institutions can be found in every state but Wyoming, and run the gamut from large-scale teaching hospitals to geriatric-care centers, besides inner-city clinics and associations of visiting nurses. They predate the Revolution, going back at least to 1727, with the founding of Charity Hospital in New Orleans.
People who work in these institutions are quick to point out that they are staffed by professionals of many backgrounds and open to patients of any religious faith or none at all. Still, they say, the religious origin and values impart a special dimension to the business of healing the sick. The mission statement of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx, for example, cites a passage in the Gospel of Matthew (25:40), in which Jesus tells his disciples that to care for "the least" -- the poor, the hungry and the sick -- is to serve God.
 
Long Record of Support
 Given this kind of imperative, the prospect of universal coverage should be a time for profound excitement within official church circles.
After all, the bishops as a body have been on record supporting some form of universal access to health care since 1919, when they declared that "the state should make comprehensive provision for insurance against illness, invalidity, unemployment and old age."
Thirteen years ago, they issued a pastoral letter, calling health care a "basic right" that government must provide. "It is the responsibility of the Federal Government to establish a comprehensive health care system that will insure a basic level of health care for all Americans," the letter said. "The Federal Government should also insure adequate funding for this basic level of care through a national health insurance program."
But the Democratic bills now before Congress that would move the nation much closer to that goal have each included abortion coverage.
Many private insurance policies now provide abortion coverage. Under the major Democratic bills, abortion would be covered as part of a standard package of health benefits guaranteed to all Americans, many of whom have either no access or limited access to abortion.
To be sure, the Democratic bills all include a "provider conscience clause," intended to allow hospitals and doctors to refuse to perform abortions.
But the bishops have said this does not answer their objections, because Catholics would still have to pay into insurance plans that cover abortion, and Catholic hospitals could not ethically join the networks of insurers, doctors and hospitals. Market forces already at work are promoting the formation of these networks, but they might become even more widespread under some of the health proposals now under consideration.
So being left out could prove a financial disaster, the bishops argued in a recent letter sent to everyone in Congress.
"Because they could not agree to coordinate access to abortions or solicit abortion providers to join their network, Catholic facilities could be effectively barred from leading such provider networks," their letter said. "Many Catholic institutions simply may not survive in such a situation."
The letter was written by Roger Cardinal Mahony, Archbishop of Los Angeles, chairman of the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities, and Bishop John J. Ricard of Baltimore, chairman of the Domestic Policy Committee.
At the local level, archdiocesan officials and hospital administrators voice many other concerns as well, a reflection of concern over shifting ground on the business side of health care and deep uncertainty over the level that Congress will finance Medicare and Medicaid programs.
"How does one maintain a sense of ministry, at the same time surviving in a rapidly changing marketplace?" asked Patricia A. Cahill, director of the department of health and hospitals for the New York Archdiocese.
Last month, in a step in that direction, the archdiocese and the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul of New York said they were committed to creating a network among the 10 institutions they run in Manhattan, the Bronx, Westchester County and Staten Island. Ms. Cahill said the plan was intended to produce a "system of care," a sort of decentralized corporation, rather than a health maintenance organization.
"We're looking to protect a religious mission," Ms. Cahill said. "It is our concern if we do not band together to assure a network based on a shared-values system, over time, we may be picked off," she added. "And into the next century, we would find our ministry and religious traditions lost or seriously weakened."
Few suggest that such a shared-values network would need be restricted to Catholic institutions alone. Last year, for example, Mercy Hospital of New Orleans merged with Baptist Hospital to create Christian Health Ministries, according to the Catholic Health Association, which represents 560 Catholic hospitals.
What complicates the response to market changes for some Catholic institutions is that this is occurring at the time of transition unique to Catholic health care. The vast majority of Catholic hospitals were founded by congregations of religious women, like the Daughters of Charity and Sisters of Mercy, both of them prodigious builders.
Yet since the mid-1960's, the stream of young women entering religious orders has plummeted, sharply reducing the number of members available to run the hospitals, while also causing the average age of the remaining nuns to rise.
At an increasing number of these hospitals, the nuns are turning over the administrative reins to lay men and women. What is crucial, Ms. Cahill said, is for these hospitals to find administrators "in tune with your philosophy," who will be committed to maintain the institutions' essential religious identity and values.
Some institutions have already made the transition.
Founded by Catholic lay women to care for abandoned sick people, and run for many years by religious orders, Calvary Hospital in the Bronx these days cares for people with terminal cancer, a move spurred by the advent of Medicare.
On a wall just inside the main entrance is a framed, hand-letter sign that reads: "Respect Life. What does that mean for Catholic health care?"
But here the sign reflects a concern with more than just abortion. "We're more concerned with the ethical issues at the other end of the spectrum," Frank A. Calamari, the hospital's president and chief executive said.
Standing near a nurses' station surrounded by patients' rooms, Dr. James E. Cimino, co-coordinator of the hospital's medical program, said, "This kind of care, of all the types of care, epitomizes the church's commitment, because we're committed to helping people who are dying." He added, "One of the problems with urban areas like this, a lot of people don't have homes that are comfortable to die in."
Mr. Calamari said he was most concerned about the possibility that Congress would cut Medicare and Medicaid to finance a national health program, which would reduce reimbursements to hospitals like Calvary, forcing them to scale back services.
Equally threatening, he said, would be the emergence of an "unfettered free market" among health care providers, in which profit-makers who provided the least expensive care came to dominate the scene.
"That's why we set up a nonprofit hospital system in this country," Mr. Calamari said. "What works so well with computers, refrigerators and grapefruits is not going to work so well with human beings in sickness and in life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Torn by its support for universal health care and its opposition to abortion, the Catholic Church's health care system in the United States may face a financial threat if Congress passes a plan that clashes with its ethical values. Officials like Dr. Michael Brescia, above, medical director at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx, fear that Medicare and Medicaid money may be cut to finance a national health program. With Dr. Brescia on Tuesday were Marilyn Crocket, a nurse, and Beatrice Lamberta, a patient. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. A17)

HEADLINE: Gender Gap Continues to Close on S.A.T.'s

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Citing significant strides in math and science by women of all ethnic backgrounds, the College Board said today that the male-female gap on Scholastic Assessment Test scores continued to narrow among high school students last year.
Releasing the annual report on S.A.T. scores, Donald A. Stewart, the president of the College Board, which oversees the tests, said: 
 "Since 1987, women have narrowed the male-female gaps in S.A.T. scores by six points for math and verbal, even though they are the majority of S.A.T. takers and come from families with less income and education than men -- factors which tend to depress scores."
 
Black Women Doing Better
 For the past eight years, black women have improved their scores more than any other group on the S.A.T., the most frequently used standardized college admission test. In 1987, the average verbal score for black women was 349, and in 1994, it edged up to 354. In 1987, the average math score for black women was 367, and in 1994, it was 381. For all groups in 1994, the verbal score was 423 and the math score was 479.
White males from higher income groups have historically done best on the S.A.T., prompting complaints that the test has sex and cultural biases. But the board insists it has made strides to eliminate these problems.
In March, the College Board changed the S.A.T. for the first time in 20 years to add more questions to test reading comprehension and analytical skill in math. But most students took the old test this year, and only 3.2 percent took the new test.
At a news conference to explain the results on Tuesday, Mr. Stewart attributed the narrowing gap between men and women, and especially the increase in scores by black women, to better preparation rather than changes in the test.
"This narrowing of the gap has been a general trend for some time now," said Janice Gams, associate director for public affairs at the College Board.
Not unexpectedly, the board reported that students enrolled in rigorous, yearlong courses like pre-calculus and physics did better on the test than those enrolled in semesterlong, standard courses.
Average scores for city and rural students were below the national average because, the board said, these regions tended to have fewer students enrolled in 20 or more yearlong courses than suburban areas.
Starting with this fall's freshman class, New York City plans to require such courses as a condition of graduation for all students. Other cities, like Charlotte, N.C., and Newark, have tried to raise standards, but New York's plan is believed to be the most sweeping in the country.
Eric P. Geisser, director of marketing for Kaplan Educational Centers, which gives S.A.T. preparation tests, said the courses and test success could not be correlated. "Generally those kids taking the more rigorous courses are studying more and more aware of the S.A.T. anyway," he said.
The College Board also noted that grade inflation in high schools was apparently continuing: 32 percent of students had "A" averages in 1994, compared with 28 percent in 1987. But the average S.A.T. score for this same group fell 6 to 15 points. Board officials suspect that grade inflation is part of teachers' efforts to motivate students, said Al Phillips, a data analyst for the board.
 
A.C.T. Scores Released
 On Tuesday, 1994 scores for the A.C.T., or American College Testing, another standardized test for college admissions, were released. Women's scores improved for the third consecutive year, while men's scores dropped. The average male score was still slightly higher than the female score.
Both sets of tests are used in college admissions, but critics say they do not predict a student's success in college.
"The S.A.T. is measuring a set of nonacademic skills which for whatever reason boys excel in, but are irrelevant," said Robert A. Schaeffer, publication education director for FairTest, a nonprofit education organization based in Cambridge, Mass.
 
'20 Years to Close'
 "Based on their own literature, there should be no gender gap whatsoever," Mr. Schaeffer said. "Young women earn higher grades than young men in college. The test is supposed to predict first-year college grades. Moreover, they're bragging that the gap is narrowing, but at the rate its narrowing, it will take another 20 years to close."
The S.A.T has two sections, math and verbal ability. The A.C.T. includes two more, scientific reasoning and reading. Thus, math scores get less weight in the A.C.T.
"The gap between men and women in the ACT is much narrower," said Kate Foster, director of undergraduate programs for Kaplan Educational Centers. 'The A.C.T. is closer to a quarter math, and we've not yet solved the puzzle of why men do better in math."
