HEADLINE: In Debate, Change and Record Are Cited

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 24

 BODY:
In the first debate between the two Democratic candidates for governor, John B. Larson proudly embraced his eight-year tenure as president of the State Senate and said he should not be blamed for the state's fiscal troubles.
Although his opponent, State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., branded Mr. Larson part of the old guard that left the state with a deep deficit at the end of the 1980's and raised taxes, Mr. Larson spent much of the hourlong debate citing his legislative accomplishments as evidence that he was the experienced hand that the government needed. 
 And in perhaps the only dramatic gesture in the debate, Mr. Larson -- the party-endorsed candidate in the Sept. 13 primary -- announced that, if he is elected, he will cut the state income tax by 25 percent, or about $260 million, in his first two years. He declined to elaborate on the proposal after the debate, saying that he would detail the plan in a news conference on Thursday.
Mr. Curry greeted the proposal with skepticism and his spokesman, Roy Occhiogrosso, said, "If he's so committed to the cut, why didn't he propose it this year when he had the chance."
The debate was largely devoid of fireworks, as the two men spoke to each other respectfully and on several occasions seemed to agree on issues like hiring more police officers, improving community policing and using voluntary means to accomplish school desegregation.
Still, they appeared to be trying to expand their bases of support, with Mr. Larson, who is generally considered the more conservative candidate, emphasizing social programs he supports, and Mr. Curry, whose backing comes from liberal Democrats, stressing his fiscal conservatism.
 
Carried on Cable
 The debate was carried this evening on Cablevision's Channel 12 and is to be shown again on Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 6 P.M and 9:30 P.M.
So far, the race appears to have generated little public interest. The Connecticut Poll, a regular political survey by The Hartford Courant and the University of Connecticut, showed that at the end of July, more than half of 500 randomly selected respondents said in telephone interviews that they did not know enough about either candidate to have an opinion.
The poll had Mr. Larson leading, 32 percent to 15 percent, with a margin of error of 5 percentage points, but the survey was not limited to people who were likely to vote in the primary. With primary turnout generally limited to party stalwarts and those active in grass-roots politics, it is possible that Mr. Curry, who has been endorsed by the state employees union and other labor groups, may be much closer to Mr. Curry than the poll suggests.
Mr. Curry, 42, served two terms in the State Senate before losing a bid for a seat in Congress and then served as the director of Freeze Voter, the political arm of Nuclear Weapons Freeze. In 1990, he defeated the incumbent Democratic comptroller in a primary, using his outsider status as a campaign theme. It is a formula that Mr. Curry is trying to use again.
 
On the Offense
 In his opening statement, Mr. Curry said: "The politicians of this state owe the people of this state an apology. In the best of times, they squandered our tax dollars, watched as our cities eroded and made no real plan for the economic future of this state. For the average Connecticut citizen, state and local tax bills have doubled."
And he added later: "If you're satisfied with the leadership of the General Assembly and the state over the last decade, then I'm not your guy. But if you believe that we need fundamental change, then this is the campaign that gives us the shot to make that happen in Connecticut."
Mr. Curry outlined a program that he said would lead to a cut of $1 billion in the roughly $9 billion state budget. The savings would come from a 5 percent reduction in purchasing, from lowering payroll by not replacing workers who retire and from cutting state mandates to towns and other measures.
This savings, Mr. Curry said, would be given to municipalities to reduce property taxes, a key difference in emphasis between himself and Mr. Larson.
While Mr. Larson was more concerned with the income tax, Mr. Curry maintained that the property tax was a more serious and inequitable burden.
 
Proposal Attacked
 But Mr. Larson said Mr. Curry's proposal was "not real" and that the "money is not there." And he called on Mr. Curry to detail precisely which of the state mandates he planned to drop.
"This would disassemble a large section of state services," said Martha Carlson, Mr. Larson's campaign manager. "Is he talking about prescriptions for the elderly, safety checks on bridges? He needs to say."
In the debate, Mr. Larson, 46, listed the measures he had worked on, from pushing through bills for more prisons to expanding immunizations for children to writing the nation's first family-leave bill. And he emphasized his experience in government, from serving on a city council and school board to running the State Senate.
He criticized Mr. Curry as being "on the periphery," while he "stepped into the arena" to grapple with the tough issues.
"I've already been up there making the difficult decisions," he said, adding later, "I think it's important for the people to understand my record, and I put that record before every citizen of this state."

HEADLINE: Durable Orders Slid 4.2% in July

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Orders for machinery and other big-ticket goods dropped in July by the biggest amount in two and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today, a surprisingly weak figure that tended to allay fears of an overheated economy.
But while today's report of a 4.2 percent slide in orders for durable goods contributed to smart rallies in the inflation-wary bond and stock markets, many economists were skeptical that it reflected a slackening in actual business activity. 
 For one thing, more than half the drop was in the automotive sector, much of which was shut down for two weeks last month. Such distortions are normally smoothed over by the seasonal adjustment process, but this had little effect since adjustment is normally done for August, and the industry now concentrates its annual retooling shutdowns in July.
 
Waiting Is Advised
 "It's wise to wait several months before you conclude any shift in trend has occurred," said John R. Williams, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company.
He and other economists said that while there was much evidence that the rise in long-term interest rates that began last fall had taken a toll on some sectors, particularly housing, there was little to suggest there had been much effect so far from the five increases in short-term rates that the Federal Reserve has made since February.
In its latest move, on Aug. 16, the Fed cited "continuing strength in the economic expansion." Its action was denounced by some Congressional Democrats and business groups as unnecessarily risking overkill.
 
Business Groups Critical
 One of these, the United States Chamber of Commerce, seized on today's report to contend that the economy was indeed slowing and posed no discernible inflation threat. Robert D. Barr, its deputy chief economist, said the broad-based decline in durables orders was symptomatic "of an economy slowing in the face of higher interest rates, lower personal income growth and a buildup in inventories -- forces that were with us before the Fed moved to raise short-term rates another half-percentage point last week."
Although the National Association of Manufacturers also expressed concern that today's report "could be signaling a sharper slowdown," most analysts remained skeptical.
"I'm writing the whole thing off," said David Orr, chief economist at the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C. He called the effect of Fed credit-tightening "nil" so far, noting that commercial and industrial loans by banks have been rising sharply of late, not declining.
Bond prices rose modestly in the wake of the report but then settled back, as traders appeared to find in it less weakness than a 4.2 percent drop in orders -- accompanied by declines in shipments and backlogs -- might imply. The financial markets' surge came after a successful auction of Treasury securities in the afternoon.
The orders decline, although severely exaggerated by statistical "noise," was only the second since July 1993 and was the biggest since December 1991, when orders for durables, items from bathtubs to bazookas designed to last at least three years, tumbled 5.4 percent.
The July decline followed advances of 1.4 percent and 1.2 percent for May and June, respectively.
Transportation equipment, the largest sector, dropped 15.8 percent, with aircraft and motor vehicles both lower. Industrial machinery and equipment fell 1.5 percent, and orders for primary metals edged down eight-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed. Electronic and other electrical equipment, however, posted a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Military Orders Skid
 Military orders skidded a sharp 16.4 percent, with the biggest factor being lower orders at companies making aircraft and parts.
Excluding military goods, however, orders for durables were still down 3.6 percent, while capital goods other than military and aviation items -- a widely watched indicator of the civilian economy -- fell 3.8 percent following a 7.7 percent advance in June.
So far in 1994, overall new orders are still running 13.3 percent ahead of the first seven months of last year, a fact that reassured many analysts. July's $144.9 billion of orders was 12.1 percent ahead of July 1993.
Shipments of durables declined 2.8 percent, to $145.8 billion, following two straight increases, today's report also showed. Unfilled orders edged two-tenths of 1 percent lower, to $424.9 billion, following three straight increases.

HEADLINE: Goods Data Help to Raise Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities surged yesterday on a weaker-than-expected economic report, a better-than-expected Treasury auction and a stronger dollar. The combination lifted the market to its best day since the Federal Reserve raised interest rates a week ago.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 30/32 , to 10016/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.46 percent, from 7.54 percent on Tuesday. The yield was the lowest since Aug. 17, when it was 7.39 percent. 
 Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh, called the durable goods figure for July issued by the Commerce Department the economic indicator of the day. "As I read it, it clearly shows a moderation in manufacturing activity, mostly centered in aircraft and automobile orders," he said.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that orders for durable goods fell 4.2 percent in July, the sharpest drop in two and a half years. The overall number was weaker than expected, easing concerns that the economy might be growing too quickly.
David Cohen, an economist for MS International, said the weakness in durable goods, which includes cars, appliances and other items meant to last at least three years, largely resulted from a drag from seasonal auto plant shutdowns. Orders excluding transportation were still soft, down three-tenths of 1 percent.
"Between auto and aircraft orders, the drop in transportation orders was a big 15.8 percent decline," Mr. Cohen said. "The rest of the report was only slightly weaker than expected."
The report also included a 1.5 percent dip in industrial machinery and a modest lift in electrical machinery, up eight-tenths of 1 percent. "The weak tone of the report cannot be completely dismissed, but it is not as bad as the headline plunge of 4.2 percent seems," Mr. Cohen said.
The bond market will be looking carefully at all coming economic reports to see if any can change the Fed's current strategy.
"With the Fed now in its monetary mode," Mr Hoffman of PNC Financial said, "only real bad inflation and poor economic reports would prod them to move."
A stronger dollar also helped lift the market, Mr. Hoffman said. The dollar rallied against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday after the Japanese central bank bought dollars.
 
Strong Treasury Demand

 
 The Treasury's auction of five-year notes was a pleasant surprise, giving the market another lift as it turned higher in the afternoon.
Traders described yesterday's note auction as well bid, with noncompetitive bids coming in at a strong $809 million, much more than the average of $622 million. The high yield at auction was 6.91 percent, down from 6.98 percent last month and the lowest since June 1994, when it was 6.77 percent.
Unlike two-year notes, which because of their shorter maturity are sought in bear markets, the five-year issue is often a good sentiment for market sentiment. Until yesterday, analysts said, fund managers and institutional customers had shown reluctance to hold a maturity that long, and dealers have not been especially keen on owning any. With a light auction calendar ahead, analysts expect the market's bullish tone to continue.
The market seesawed a bit as it rose on the weaker durable data and then pulled back a bit ahead of the note auction, which was not expected to sell as well as it did.
The following are the results of yesteray's Treasury auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Intervention By Japanese Central Bank

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen and other leading currencies yesterday after the Japanese central bank bought dollars for a second day.
Rallies in American stock and bond markets also helped the dollar gain, traders and analysts said. 
 "The Bank of Japan is keeping the currency market on its toes this week," said Jim Raphael, assistant vice president at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City.
 
 
$1 Billion a Day
 The Bank of Japan probably spent $1 billion a day in the last two days to keep the dollar from falling toward its post-World War II low against the yen, said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a consulting firm. The purchases were the bank's most aggressive since June, he said.
Japanese monetary authorities often try to keep the dollar from weakening against the yen because a strong yen makes Japanese exports more expensive, slowing economic growth.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 99.01 yen, up from 97.82 yen on Tuesday and its highest level in almost a week. The dollar rose to 1.5473 German marks, from 1.5315 marks on Tuesday. Many traders expect the Clinton Administration to call for a strong yen, or at least let the dollar fall without comment, in an effort to put pressure on the Japanese to cut their $60 billion trade surplus with the United States.
"The outlook is grim for the fall because trade tensions will build," Mr. Gilmore of Foreign Exchange Analytics said.
Buying by the Bank of Japan and rallies in American stock and bond markets gave the dollar a reprieve yesterday, traders said.
 
 
'Looks Cheap'
 The dollar, stocks and bonds were feeding on each other's strength, said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "People are buying dollars to buy U.S. stocks and bonds," he said. "The dollar looks cheap" to foreign investors, he said. Stocks and bonds, in turn, benefited from the dollar's relative strength since that made foreign investors more willing to buy United States assets. The dollar's slide this year has cost those holding American assets dearly.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Taxing employee medical benefits may help cure some of the problems in the health care system.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SURPRISE: Senator Phil Gramm, doyen of the hard right, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., standard-bearer for the remnants of the New Deal coalition, stand as one on a key element of health care reform.
Well, maybe it is not such a surprise. For the subject is taxes -- specifically, why their constituents should not have to pay more. 
 But it is just such views that are driving economically sophisticated legislators to despair. For many believe that adding new limits on the deductibility of medical benefits -- as called for in two key Senate bills -- could provide both the revenue to extend coverage and the incentives to hold down costs. Indeed, Representative Thomas Petri, a Republican from Wisconsin, offers a sweeping but disarmingly simple tax-based fix for many of the problems that apparently ail the health care system.
Coverage for those who earn too much to receive free benefits from Medicaid but too little to pay their own premiums would cost a bundle. Some cash could be raised from a new cigarette tax, the favorite levy of Americans who don't smoke. A bit more might come from affluent oldsters who pay only a fraction of the cost of their Government health insurance.
But that leaves a big hole, which the plan of the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, as well as that of the bipartisan "mainstream coalition" would fill with taxes on health insurance premiums. The coalition plan, like other proposals inspired by the idea of "managed competition," would limit the amount of money that could be deducted for insurance premiums to some benchmark figure. Bare-bones coverage would be fully deductible, but more generous plans would not.
That would simultaneously generate revenues to offset the cost of added direct subsidies to the poor. And it would make beneficiaries more sensitive to the financial workings of insurance now provided as fringe benefits. If, for example, richer benefits would add $500 to an auto worker's income tax, he might think twice about the value. "There's just no argument," concludes Joseph Newhouse, an economist at Harvard: taxing medical fringes would make people more cost-conscious.
If modest tax changes would help, how about immodest ones? Representative Petri would go all the way to break what he calls "the third-party-payer syndrome," by counting all medical insurance premiums paid by employers as taxable income.
Harsh medicine? Not really. He would return all the revenue -- something on the order of $92 billion -- in the form of vouchers to cover part of the cost of private medical insurance.
Every family of four would get a yearly voucher worth about $1,800. That is hardly enough to buy insurance, which typically cost three to four times that much annually. But it would be a good start for a working-poor family with an income of, say, $12,000 that pays no income tax. And it would be a better than break-even proposition for a family making, say, $40,000 that currently receives, say, $7,000 worth of untaxed fringe benefits and pays income taxes in the 15 percent bracket. After all, 15 percent of $7,000 is just $1,050 -- far less than the $1,800 value of the voucher.
The losers would be truly affluent earners in the 30 percent-plus tax bracket who now typically enjoy generous, tax-sheltered medical benefits. But, then, somebody has to pay to extend health care coverage. And this revenue approach would offer the bonus of making almost everyone sensitive to costs.
What's more, providing a voucher to everyone, rich or poor, would solve a problem that plagues every health care plan seeking to extend coverage voluntarily -- namely how to entice the near-poor with subsidies without reducing their incentives to earn their way into the middle class.
"Even relatively modest voucher-based subsidies would induce many of the working poor to buy insurance," concludes Michael Chernew and Catherine McLaughlin of the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. But since the subsidy would not change as their income rose, it would not deter work.
A cap on the deductibility of health insurance -- or the more radical Petri approach -- would raise money from the people who could afford it, distribute it to people who need it and create incentives for cost control. Why, then, is the idea so widely scorned?
The ungenerous answer is that the health care debate has brought out the worst in taxpayers. "Politicians will have to try everything first," before they raise the T-word, Representative Petri suggests. The generous answer is that even at this late date hardly anyone outside the health care cognoscenti understands the issues.
Neither answer leads to optimism about the outcome of the health care debate.

HEADLINE: Saving Neighborhoods One Gate at a Time

SERIES: Second of two articles about home security.

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio

 BODY:
GOOD fences may make good neighbors, but iron gates make good neighborhoods. That's the opinion of a majority of the 5,000 residents of Five Oaks, a mixed-income, racially diverse neighborhood five miles north of downtown Dayton.
In 1992, after robberies had doubled in three years, the people of Five Oaks, in collaboration with local police officials, city planners and an urban-design consultant, adopted a crime-prevention technique that has been around for decades but is only now becoming an inescapable feature of the residential landscape -- iron gates designed to rebuff prostitution and drug dealing and the automobile traffic that often supports them. 
 Judging from recent statistics, the results have been striking. Since the 35 iron gates and 26 alley barricades were installed in the fall of 1992, violent crime in Five Oaks has fallen by 50 percent and nonviolent crime by 24 percent, according to a report from Dayton's Office of Management and Budget.
"I am absolutely ecstatic," said Maj. Jaruth Durham-Jefferson, the superintendent of the professional standards division of the Dayton Police Department. She added that in 1989, the arrival of crack cocaine had caused Five Oaks, a half-mile square of modest prewar duplexes and 70-year-old Spanish colonials, to deteriorate from a "pretty stable middle-class neighborhood" to one riddled with "incivilities."
Today, even communities bordering Five Oaks have reported a 28 percent decline in crime. "Criminals don't seem to know where the gates end," said Bernice Gamble, a Five Oaks resident.
Although closing off a troubled street is nothing new, closing off two dozen is. This is the first time an entire neighborhood has agreed to embrace the idea, said Oscar Newman, the urban planner who helped mastermind the Five Oaks strategy.
As crime rates rise, so do the number of neighborhood barricades. Thoroughfares from Coconut Grove, Fla., to Austin, Tex., to Los Angeles have been closed with gates, primarily to stop through traffic and its attendant crime and noise.
In Bridgeport, Conn., 40 intersections in the city's East End have been blocked with concrete barricades to prevent drug traffic and to bring back a sense of community. And in New York City, Greenwich Village residents are lobbying Federal and state officials to block the traffic they expect to flow through the narrow streets if plans for a $380 million redesign of the West Side Highway are not amended.
Gates, once the rich man's preogative, are now becoming an egalitarian option. But even their defenders will admit that gates are not a solution in themselves. They are merely one of the most visible elements of a broader philosophy whose name is becoming a household word among police officers and citizens' groups: Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design, also known as Cpted (pronounced SEP-ted).
"I'm not saying street closures don't work, but there's a bigger picture to consider," said Christine Saum, the executive director of the Mayors' Institute on City Design, a cooperative program developed by the National Endowment for the Arts and the University of Virginia. "Crime prevention can be addressed only on a case-by-case basis, because what works in Dayton may not work in Fort Lauderdale, or even in other parts of Dayton."
One of the effort's primary goals is "to consider how the entire community can work together to combat crime," said Capt. Stan Carter of the Sarasota (Fla.) Public Safety Department. "There has to be more to crime prevention than just putting more cops on the street. Everybody's fighting for funding, but nobody wants to impose higher taxes, and there's a lot of pressure at the municipal level" to do more with less money.
Simple, often inexpensive improvements can often help, from installing brighter street lights to providing safer landscaping: small shrubs and trees with no low limbs provide few hiding places for muggers and rapists. Such improvements, Mr. Newman and other advocates contend, foster an atmosphere of security that can inspire a community to take charge of its space again, improve the appearance of its buildings and rebuild social relationships.
The reconstruction of Bryant Park in Manhattan, which cost $8.9 million and was completed in 1992, included the removal of towering hedges and forbidding walls that had long acted as a sanctuary for crime. "Criminals are like roaches: they like dark spots to hide in," said Bruce Cohen, a spokesman for the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation and the Grand Central and 34th Street partnerships.
In Dayton, Five Oaks' moss-green iron gates, their brick supports ornamented with bas-relief plaques depicting oak leaves, cost $693,375 to build and install. The money was raised through the sale of city bonds.
Police officials said that four years ago, Five Oaks was a stable community, proud of its racial and economic diversity. Then the sound of gunshots started to reverberate, rattling Joan Means. So did the crack-dealing grandmother with a young child in tow who had taken up residence across from the stolid Victorian home where Mrs. Means and her husband, Michael, an associate professor of English at the University of Dayton, have lived for 31 years.
"That 3-year-old child took the drugs to customers parked outside and brought the money back to his grandmother," said Mrs. Means, 61, who teaches English at a vocational high school.
Day and night, she recalled, drivers were using the streets of Five Oaks to avoid delays on Main Street, Salem Avenue and Interstate 75. Drug dealers and prostitutes set up camp along the vulnerable edges of Five Oaks, following what urban-design experts contend is a classic pattern of neighborhood decline.
Homeowners fled, absentee landlords came in and short-term renters with no equity in the community allowed their houses and apartments to fall into disrepair. At the same time Mrs. Means and other members of the Five Oaks Neighborhood Improvement Association were reviewing its long-range goals, Mr. Newman came to town at the invitation of police officials interested in his theories. Groups met to talk about erecting gates in the neighborhood, petitions circulated, and a door-to-door campaigning ensued. By the spring of 1993, the gates had been installed.
"We were able to take back our neighborhood," Mrs. Means said.
The gates transform Five Oaks' grid plan into a maze of mini-neighborhoods characterized by multiple cul-de-sacs and few through streets. Unlike the typical stockade of high walls and fences and air of purposeful isolation, Five Oaks wanted to remain a neighborhood: porous, communal, connected to the life of Dayton.
Consequently, Five Oaks is not impenetrable. Pedestrians can walk around the gates freely. And keys to the gates allow fire, sanitation and other essential city services unrestricted access to Five Oaks as well. But the drive-through traffic and the crime it attracted have been forced back onto the main streets that mark Five Oaks' perimeter, which is exactly where Mrs. Gamble says they belong.
"If you don't live in Five Oaks, then what are you doing here?" said Mrs. Gamble, a member of the Five Oaks Neighborhood Improvement Association.
Today, although some buildings remain boarded up and an abandoned sofa lolls in a littered driveway, most of Five Oaks' lawns are brightly planted, children race bicycles down the streets again, and not one of the dozen people interviewed said he or she was afraid to venture out after dark.
"The way you see it now is the way it usually stays," said Roland Miller, a hospital worker who has followed Five Oaks' rebirth with interest, especially its real estate renaissance. Since the gates were installed, the average sale price of a single-family home has risen from $45,417 in 1992 to $52,017 in 1993, an increase of nearly 15 percent, according to figures from the Dayton Board of Realtors.
Just this sort of economic incentive may prompt more neighborhoods to take crime prevention into their own hands. "Good neighborhoods go bad because people won't fight for them," said Paul R. Soglin, the Mayor of Madison, Wis. To cut down on after-hours crime along State Street, which has been turned into a pedestrian mall in downtown Madison, Mayor Soglin's administration has encouraged restaurants to open sidewalk cafes and local businesses to extend their hours, "any kind of activity that will bring more people into the area," he said.
Mr. Newman, the urban planner, said: "We used to think that we lived in a society with commonly held values and that crime was an aberration the police could deal with. That idea of society is now found wanting."
Mr. Newman, who is an adviser in the Yonkers housing-discrimination case, recently received a grant from the Justice Department to work with 50 neighborhoods in 10 cities around the country to help restructure their physical design and improve security in everything from single-family residential areas to public housing.
Jack A. Nadol, the acting director of the department's Bureau of Justice Assistance, called Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design "a proven method of crime reduction." At the end of September, the department's Comprehensive Communities Program will release about $17 million in grant money to be used for fighting drug-related or violent crime in six cities. They will be chosen from 16 cities invited to submit comprehensive crime-prevention plans, among them Seattle; Baltimore; Wichita, Kan., and Columbia, S.C. Mr. Newman has visited all 16 and made recommendations to city officials on fine-tuning their proposals.
Not everyone is smitten with the idea of street gates. Although Bruce Ramm, a former police officer who now works as a security consultant in Orange, Calif., frequently recommends them, "sometimes they backfire," he said.
"In parts of Southern California, for example, closing off streets reduced drug-dealing," he said, "but it also made the neighborhoods more conducive to gang activity. If a neighborhood is already controlled by a gang, creating cul-de-sacs only gives them more control over the territory."
In Five Oaks, some residents denounce the gates as barricades designed to encourage segregration. "This is just like South Africa, caging people in like this," said Curtis Print, a black resident who works in a manufacturing plant.
Major Durham-Jefferson dismisses the notion of segregation. "I'm an African-American," she said, "so I think I would have noticed" if any of the gates had been racially motivated.
In the future, the Five Oaks Neighborhood Improvement Association plans to try to encourage renters from minority groups to buy houses, working with local banks to provide low-interest loans. And it is asking landlords to restore subdivided single-family houses and duplexes to their original, more spacious layouts. Landscaping and more recreation programs for neighborhood children are on the drawing board, too.
The only universal complaint about gates, one cited by opponents and proponents alike, seems to be that of inconvenience. The gates have transformed a once easily accessible neighborhood into an obstacle course.
Eric Bell, a resident, said that they have ruined life on Harvard Avenue, one of the few remaining through streets. "It's hell," Mr. Bell said. "You can't get your car out to go to work, traffic's backed up so bad."
Mrs. Means, the English teacher who supported plans for the gates, said: "It's dreadful. Traffic's gone up 120 percent on that street alone."
But other members of the association and the Police Department said that residents of the most heavily trafficked streets had only themselves to blame. They pointed out that many renters refused to take part in the review process or ignored the petitions and questionnaires.
Mrs. Gamble, an association member, says she does not mind having to go several blocks out of the way to reach her own garage. "Criminals stay away now," she said. "They may know how to get in, but they don't know exactly how to get out."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Lesson In Economics Is Ignored

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
IF God is truly "in the details," as the saying goes, the major league baseball owners and the striking players must worship different deities.
Because both sides can offer up proof positive that the game is only the way they say it is. 
 The game is healthy, players say. The game is on a collision course with economic disaster, owners say.
So divergent are the courses the two sides take to get from here to there, it often seems as if they are traversing two different planets. Never was that more apparent than yesterday, when 12 owners or their representatives joined in battle for the first time during this strike with the players union. And they offered as their opening salvos at the bargaining table a litany on how the current system is killing many teams and, therefore, must be reworked.
The owners and their representatives gave their interpretations of this crisis, knowing that the 21 players and their union representatives believe the claim to be indefensible. The players as much as said so less than 48 hours before, when the union delivered to the owners a financial analysis of the game.
The report, commissioned by the players but based on confidential figures provided by the clubs, was compiled by Roger Noll, an economist from Stanford University who previously served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Noll's report, in one word, is damning. To any argument the owners have yet to offer as reason for their pursuit of a new economic order, that is.
Because Noll charges that baseball has underestimated its expected revenues by between 3 and 8 percent for 1994, which, if one extrapolates from baseball's projections of $1.78 billion, means that another $50 million to $140 million could have come baseball's way this year -- if the strike had not cut the season off as it did on Aug. 12.
Noll calls forecasts of widespread doom fiction. As for those much-maligned player salaries, Noll writes, "Total player compensation in professional compensation, contrary to widespread belief, is not increasing faster than revenue and cannot reasonably be said to be causing a decline in the financial status of the sport."
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief negotiator, dismissed the Noll report as biased. And the prophecies of doom remain.
Small-market teams, like Milwaukee and San Diego, even big-market clubs, like Boston, Atlanta and the two Chicago franchises, trumpet them. And when the players put the report on the table yesterday, the owners did not even deign to comment on it.
Still, Noll contends such dire predictions are far more implausible in 1994 than 1985, when owners predicted financial disaster only to see their concessions followed by tremendous windfalls in the areas of national and local broadcast revenues.
Now, in 1994, owners are singing a similar tune, saying that the only way to harness financial troubles and turn them around is to harness players' salaries. And, if one takes a Bud Selig, a Jerry Reinsdorf, a Ravitch at their word, that tune just isn't going to change, no matter how many reports the players commission.
So they stand, in the same negotiating room of a midtown Manhattan hotel, but so obviously in different universes.
It does not seem to matter that the public continues to lacerate both players and owners for shutting the game down for the eighth time in 22 years.
It does not seem to matter that the amount of anger will multiply a thousandfold if this fight for money and power kills the World Series, something that the Great Depression, two world wars and an earthquake in 1989 did not do.
Alas, the owners probably won't agree with the economist's conclusions, let alone claim that they've seen the enemy and that enemy is themselves. They didn't buy in when Noll reached similar conclusions in 1985.
It is as if the parties are doomed to play out their roles, the same as in all the previous lockouts, strikes and fights in between. Just as they did in 1985, with the owners as doomsayers, Noll as a naysayer and the players as the grave doubters.
Fourteen days into the strike and no one has come close to breaking out of character. And sadly, as the season slips away, one gets the idea that even if a new interpretation of where the game stands economically were carved in stone and brought down from the mountain, nothing will change. Which may be good for economists as each side lines up more and more expert witnesses. But none of this will ever be said to be good for the game.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: Nigeria's Tarnished Brass

 BODY:
The reckless soldiers who govern Nigeria seem to have a single response to anything that displeases them: Lock up everybody who is out of step, even if that means half the country. Since the country in question happens to be the most populous in Africa, a major exporter of oil and a volatile mix of a dozen cultures, 250 languages and 3 unstable regions, this martial misrule has to be of serious concern to Africa, Washington and the world.
It would appear that the army manual stipulates these rules for dividing, demoralizing and impoverishing a potentially great nation: 
 * If elections are held and voters favor the candidate least liked by the soldiers, then annul the election. That happened in June 1993 when the presumed winner was Moshood Abiola, whose victory would have ended a decade of military rule and for the first time allowed a Yoruba from the thriving southwest to serve as president.
* If the presumed winner refuses to accept defeat, then charge him with treason, hold him incommunicado and ignore court orders to produce him for a judicial hearing. That happened this June to Mr. Abiola, a wealthy entrepreneur and a Muslim whose generous benefactions have given him national standing and a national following.
* If newspapers publish what is obvious to everybody, that these steps have provoked an argument within the military, then silence them. This has happened to a score of publications in Lagos, including the well-respected Guardian, depriving Nigerians of an outspoken free press that has tempered military rule during 24 of the country's 34 years of independence.
* If oil workers demand Mr. Abiola's release and call a strike, then fire the union leaders. This happened after 90,000 of Nigeria's 100,000 oil workers struck, cutting by half the petroleum exports that account for fully 80 percent of Government revenues. But the dismissed labor leaders went into hiding and the protest action continues.
How aggravating it must be to Gen. Sani Abacha, Nigeria's exceptionally inept ruler, that none of this has worked. A defiant federal high court judge has reinstated the dismissed union leaders. The Academic Staff Union of Universities has closed all the country's colleges until the Government recognizes Mr. Abiola's election. Banks remain closed in much of the country despite Government threats to revoke their licenses.
All this has prompted fresh arrests of scores of prominent Nigerians, including former ministers and army commanders, and an order dissolving the five-million-member Nigerian Labor Congress. At this rate, most of the country may soon be in jail, and the entire economy may stutter to a standstill. Before this happens, Americans can only hope that General Abacha, after deep thought, will finally locate a major source of Nigeria's miseries, and arrest himself.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The En-En Document

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's most revealing policy document laying out "the national security strategy of the United States," no less -- has been kept secret by the fiendishly clever device of making it public.
Issued a month ago in the dead of night, the blue-covered "National Security Strategy of Engagement and Enlargement" was dubbed "the En-En Document" by engaging reporters and enlarged pundits. 
 The struggle over naming the policy engagement (a Gary Hart term favored by the State Department) vs. enlargement (a Tony Lake term favored by the N.S.C. staff) was resolved in a quintessentially Clintonian way: Both are used, conjuring a vision of involved tumescence.
But when a President signs off on a 25,000-word exposition of his global strategy, attention must be paid.
Some of it is silly political posturing: "With U.S. leadership, NATO has provided the muscle that is helping to bring about a peaceful settlement in the former Yugoslavia." Some leadership; some muscle.
The En-En Document -- a serious articulation of this Administration's approach to the world -- deserves academic dissemination and respectful or infuriated analysis by think tanks. It can serve as the basis for "great debate" hearings when Richard Lugar becomes chairman of Senate Foreign Relations in January.
That's because the strategy has become so determinedly anti-controversial that it should provoke controversy. By examining its drafting, we can see its policy evolution.
In an early version of the document, this line led a paragraph in the President's cover letter: "Ultimately, the strength of our security derives from the strength of our values." Gutsy human-rights rhetoric. In the final version, perhaps after the M.F.N. China decision, a line from a pragmatist was brought up from below as a substitute: "Our national security strategy reflects both America's interests and our values."
Similarly, the following fix illuminates a switched emphasis: "We believe that our goals of promoting democracy, protecting our security, and enhancing our economy are mutually supportive" was changed, at perhaps the highest level, to "We believe that our goals of enhancing our security, bolstering our economic prosperity, and promoting democracy are mutually supportive." Different priorities.
A section on European defense, undermining NATO with a controversy-averse "Partnership for Peace," invites debate. "In keeping with our strategy of enlargement, PFP is open to all former members of the Warsaw Pact as well as other European states . . . with PFP the best path toward NATO membership."
That means we are pretending to plan to invite Russia to join NATO, an organization that exists to protect Europe from Russia. The strategy, as stated, is an absurdity. Clinton's "Partnership for Peace" is a device to avert debate about admitting Poland, Ukraine and other Eastern European states into NATO now.
"The aim of NATO's future expansion, however," according to En-En, "will not be to draw a new line in Europe further [sic] east, but to expand stability, democracy, prosperity and security cooperation to an ever-broader Europe."
That's strategic hot air. As Henry Kissinger writes, "The Administration's Atlantic policy is creating two categories of frontier in Europe: those that are guaranteed are not threatened, and those that are threatened are not guaranteed."
The forum for talk of bringing "security cooperation to an ever-broader Europe" already exists in the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Russia and its former satellites are part of that U.N.-minus-the-third-world.
But NATO is an Atlantic military alliance with a clear purpose to subsume Germany and keep Russians in Russia. It works; it should now include the countries most at risk from any future Moscow yearning to visit the irredentist twice a year.
Foreign relations debaters should use "Engagement and Enlargement" as their text. The near-final draft rang with resolution: "Our national security requires the patient application of American will and resources, and, at times, lives."
The printed version, formally signed by William J. Clinton, recoiled from such boldness: "and, at times, lives" was stricken out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Itself to Blame for Cuban Refugees

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton has made the first real change in Cuba policy in 28 years by "adjusting" the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966. But by stating once again that he will continue to enforce the embargo against Cuba and the Cuban Democracy Act, the President is allowing a small minority of ultraconservatives in Miami to dictate United States policy. 
 Now Representatives Robert Menendez and Robert G. Torricelli call for a military and complete economic blockade of the island. Cubans will continue leaving the island. We should ask ourselves, Why wasn't there such a flow of Cubans before passage of Mr. Torricelli's Cuban Democracy Act?
United States policy is forcing these people to sea, a policy that first encouraged them to commit such desperate acts through Radio Marti and then encouraged exodus by using hunger and deprivation.
Doesn't President Clinton realize that these raft people, "balseros," as we call them, will eat better and feed their families better in a United States detention camp than in Cuba? I also know that they will consider their chances much better for getting to Miami than for staying in Cuba.
They are not taking to the sea because they lack the right to vote in a two-party election. They are taking to the sea because they cannot bear the hardship anymore of going without electricity, water, cooking oil, chicken, milk, soap, even toilet paper.
The exodus will continue until conditions improve in Cuba. The Administration will have to grant political asylum sooner or later to Cubans who make it to the detention camps because it is the law of the land. The detainees know what to say to be granted asylum. They have heard the script over and over on Radio Marti.
So the United States will have people for three months in a detention camp (paid for with tax dollars) before they join their relatives in Florida. At least they will arrive with a full stomach, now unheard of in Cuba.
Why is President Clinton so afraid to lift the trade embargo against Cuba? Canada, Spain, Mexico, Japan and others consider the Cuban economy free enough to invest in.
It is time this Administration stopped listening to Jorge Mas Canosa and his small expatriate clique, who have not been on the island in 30 years and have no close family suffering there.
Cuban policy is not being made in the real interest of the American people, in the real interest of the United States economy or in the interest of the Cuban-American community.
Representative Torricelli has stated, and I agree, that things in Cuba will get a lot worse before they get better. Of course, he is ready to accept a civil war and bloodbath in Cuba, as well as a mass exodus, with the United States Navy's help. The exodus will continue. The real test for President Clinton is to lift the embargo and normalize relations with Cuba. The emigration "crisis" will resolve itself.
 
RAYMUNDO DEL TORO
President, Cuban American
Committee for Peace
Linden, N.J., Aug. 19, 1994

HEADLINE: A Not-So-Odd Mideast Couple

BYLINE: By Stephen P. Cohen; Stephen P. Cohen is president of the Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation, a small nonprofit organization.

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
Like it or not, Middle East peace is in the firm grasp of the same tough and idiosyncratic characters we have hated and distrusted in the regional conflict. Our ambivalence about these Arab leaders is becoming a major obstacle in managing the transition from war to peace -- especially the implementation of the Palestinian-Israeli agreement and efforts to produce a Syrian-Israeli peace, which would transform the region.
Yasir Arafat makes all the decisions for the new Palestinian authority. This frustrates many Palestinians, the Israelis and virtually all foreigners and world economic institutions. 
 President Hafez al-Assad is, of course, the supreme authority in Syria. We so much emphasize this fact that we have trouble believing that he has political constraints other than his own inhibitions and rigid positions.
Both leaders are determined to pursue peace by using the very ideas and methods that they have exploited to retain power in the long years of the conflict. They are convinced that their mastery of internal political complexities and of inter-Arab rivalries, and their careful modulation of the conflict with Israel, have enabled them to survive to this watershed. Their peoples, including their harshest critics, share their basic assumption that only they can bring peace to their nations.
Israeli and American officials are convinced that these leaders are essential. With Mr. Arafat, this acceptance is grudging and contemptuous; with Mr. Assad, it is grudging and respectful, but wary. In light of Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization terrorism, public opinion, understandably, shares the grudges more than the acceptance.
These Israelis and Americans believe that peace can succeed only if Mr. Arafat and Mr. Assad abandon their old methods and concepts. Thus, while they acknowledge that Mr. Arafat is the decision-maker, they prefer to deal with his politically weak advisers. That is often a mistake, because the advisers -- angry over Mr. Arafat's habit of using money, jobs and threats to control them -- can and do provide advice that is more misleading than helpful.
 President Assad is admired for his strength, but his critics think his conceptual world is rigid and outdated. His emphasis on a comprehensive peace is seen as empty rhetoric, with a touch of a dream of Syrian hegemony. At most, it is accepted as a euphemism for Syrian influence in Lebanon. It is not seen as a shrewd, practical strategy for managing conflict, either within Syria or with Arab rejectionists. Mr. Assad's talk of popular support is dismissed by the West as a code word for iron-fisted control and intimidation. The politics of an autocratic state are certainly not the politics of a democracy, but there are political processes nonetheless. Not only does Mr. Assad seek to maintain his monopolistic control over the multiplicity of military and security forces, he also strives to balance rival ethnic groups and regional interests against one another.
Most of all, Mr. Assad's politics are the politics of maintaining the rationale for rule. Regimes can become captives of their own dogmas and claims. If Syria is the "beating heart" of the Arab world, as Syrians always say, and is pre-eminent in the struggle against Israeli dominance, then Mr. Assad must explain his peace initiatives to cadres of activists who have followed that dogma. The cynical are not as hard to deal with as those who believe too fiercely or those who have built their lives and livelihoods around the maintenance of the security state and the conflict.
Middle East peace is not arriving through the excitement of popular upheaval and overthrow of regimes, as in Eastern Europe. On the contrary, peace is a central part of a calculated policy to prevent such upheaval and chaos. It is a strategy of change to preserve the leaders' rule and to reinforce it as the barrier to extremism and internecine warfare.
Popular upheaval would mean that extremist anti-Western movements that invoke Islam would come to power. It would mean the eruption of ethnic and political rivalries that could tear the societies apart and wreak revenge against former ruling groups. There would be no wave of democracy and pluralism led by enlightened critics of the regime and supported by emerging Western-oriented middle classes. These forces are not yet politically strong enough to win in a no-holds-barred struggle for succession.
The West's desire is to see authoritarian rule replaced by democracy and respect for human rights. We want state socialism and corruption superseded by open-market economies. But to condition our diplomacy in any way on the prospect of such transformations may slow the peace process and bring to power the most bitter enemies of peace and Western values.
Like it or not, the two key figures for the removal of the ideology of hatred toward Israel are Mr. Arafat and Mr. Assad, who pursued that enmity with great effectiveness and ruthlessness. In Washington in July, King Hussein of Jordan provided a respite from this hostility. His formal agreement to end 46 years of enmity to Israel produced a wave of good feeling in Israel and America. His benign image is due in part to his Western manners and style, which contrast sharply with Mr. Arafat's deliberately provocative image.
But the other side of King Hussein's image is his weakness as an enemy of Israel. This heightens the contrast to President Assad's insistence on military strength and unabashed willingness to use force. Still, the King has played a weak hand with panache, dignity and determination. Now that he has played it, we must hurry to strengthen it.
Mr. Arafat exploits his own weakness by masterly and maddening brinkmanship, his unique brand of guerrilla diplomacy. He uses his one credible threat again and again -- that if he fails, the extremists on the left and right will rise and chaos will ensue.
Mr. Assad flaunts his ability to make war while seeking peace. But he can deliver peace. The burden is on him to show that it can be done comprehensively, relatively quickly and with Israel as a full partner.
We should listen with close attention to President Assad's analysis. He has led Syria and the forces of rejection almost throughout the period since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. No one knows better than he how the logic and emotion of that rejection can be put to rest. He says he is determined to make peace. He is very convincing to those who hear him (as I did on Aug. 16 in Damascus as part of a Council on Foreign Relations delegation) and to those who overhear him.
Mr. Arafat is determined to build his Gaza-Jericho rump entity into a Palestinian state that lives in peace and economic cooperation with Israel. He has already staked his life on that belief and has maneuvered his people into that gamble. Perhaps we should be a little more reticent in denouncing his strategies for controlling Hamas terrorism and building Palestinian institutions. Maybe we can be more creative in developing economic strategies that fit his style of governing.
Israel's leaders are dealing with Arab leaders as they find them. Mr. Assad and Mr. Arafat have decided to make peace. There will be a time for different leaders with other values and practices that are closer to ours. But we will never get to that promising next generation if we undermine today's leaders by burdening the present with our too lofty hopes for the future.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: AT THE WHITE HOUSE;
Castro vs. Clinton

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
To a limited but important degree, Fidel Castro has done what President Clinton vowed to keep him from doing.
Mr. Castro's actions -- chiefly his decision to permit an unlimited number of disgruntled Cubans to set sail into the perilous Florida Straits on rickety rafts -- have prompted Mr. Clinton to change United States immigration policy, and to change it into something difficult to sustain. 
 If the refugees keep coming by the thousands, the detention centers at Guantanamo Bay will eventually fill to bursting, even after such costly measures as the building of more camps, an idea that was announced on Tuesday, and the evacuation of some civilian workers to make more space available, a measure announced today. And there is no sign of a diminution in the flow, despite all the fervent American warnings; indeed, many Cubans seem more eager than ever to flee, fearing that this may be their last chance.
Officials here admit they have no full answers. So why not grasp the straw proffered by the Cubans? Why not talk about at least some of the issues between the countries, including the refugees?
Mr. Clinton said during a Rose Garden exchange with reporters this afternoon that he was restudying the regulations governing legal immigration by Cubans, and indicated that he would be willing to discuss such questions with Havana.
But on the larger issues -- the refugees and the long freeze between the two countries -- he answered brusquely. The 30-year-old policy of isolating Cuba would stand, he said, "and Mr. Castro knows the conditions for changing that policy."
In fact, Mr. Clinton has said that the United States should never agree to negotiate when it is under foreign attack, and he has argued that what he sees as an effort to destabilize south Florida socially and economically constitutes an attack. Like many another President before him, he has spoken recently of his determination not to buckle under pressure from abroad.
Opening broad-scale talks would be "political suicide," a White House official said this afternoon, but that is by no means a unanimous opinion, even among Democrats.
No doubt such a move would be unpopular with some conservatives, for whom Mr. Castro remains a demonic presence, even though the end of the cold war has rendered him strategically all but insignificant. But conservatives are not likely to be Clinton supporters in any case.
The President's apprehensions, his associates say, are focused on the big Cuban-American colony in Florida, a state whose rapid growth -- it is now the fourth largest -- has increased its weight in national politics.
According to several Florida politicians, Mr. Clinton's decision to prevent the refugees from entering the United States angered many Cuban-American leaders, who were not consulted. He then imposed new punitive measures against Havana and met last Friday evening with a group that included Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation. The politicians said Mr. Mas sought and gained a pledge that the United States would undertake no talks with Cuba.
 
Big Factor in Miami Area
 Cuban-Americans constitute about a quarter, or perhaps as much as a third, of the electorate in Dade County, which is the state's most populous, but account for less than 10 percent of the state total.
In this fall's elections, disillusionment with Mr. Clinton and his party could badly hurt the re-election hopes of Gov. Lawton Chiles, who is already hard-pressed and who in November may have to battle former President George Bush's Spanish-speaking son Jeb. Mr. Bush's wife, Columba, is Mexican-American. At a time when the Democrats are facing trouble in the gubernatorial races in other big states, like New York, California, Texas and Pennsylvania, they are especially eager to hold on to Florida, with its 25 electoral votes.
Other than that, Mr. Clinton stands to lose little in Florida this fall. Senator Connie Mack, a Republican, is considered a shoo-in, and the two majority Hispanic districts in the state are already represented by Republicans. Most Cuban-Americans have been emotionally Republican.
The Democrats have fared poorly in Florida in recent Presidential elections, winning 39, 35 and 39 percent in the voting in 1980, 1984 and 1988, respectively. But in 1992, with three candidates in the race, Mr. Clinton's 39 percent fell only two percentage points short of victory, and he harbors hopes for 1996. The state Democratic Party says that its polls show Mr. Clinton to be the most popular Democrat among Cuban-Americans since President Jimmy Carter.
There is a larger diplomatic dimension to Mr. Clinton's reluctance than generally acknowledged. Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, a Democratic specialist on Latin America who backs the President, says the United States "could not accept an invitation to negotiate without granting validity to Castro's tactics in sending people out to die."
"Why should we get involved with a guy who has nothing to deliver to us?" asked a senior State Department official.
But of course, any talks between the United States and Cuba could be limited, and need not entail the lifting of the 30-year American economic embargo with Cuba. At first, experts say, they could be confined to matters like telephone and other communications links between the two countries, drug trafficking and nuclear energy as well as refugee issues.
The Administration is doing all it can to establish normal relations with the few nations that still embrace Communism as well as those that were stranded by its collapse in Moscow. Mr. Clinton chose not to go to the mat with China over human rights. He has agreed to open a mission in Hanoi and announced his intention of opening diplomatic relations with North Korea.
Yet he rejects talks with Havana. Members of Congress and others find that hard to understand.
 
'Foolish,' Dodd Says
 Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat, argued this week that it was "mindless and foolish" to talk to dictators around the world yet refuse to talk to Cuba "because of parochial politics." On Friday, a Task Force on Cuba put together by Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research group, will call for talks not only on short-term questions but on the whole relationship.
Returning the refugees to Cuba does not seem a live option. For one thing, it is not at all clear that Mr. Castro would accept them; besides, that would defy the profound American belief in comforting the oppressed. Nor is a naval blockade in the cards, given the trade between Cuba and important American allies.
The President, who was stung politically in 1980 when Mariel boat people held in Arkansas rioted during his governorship, talks often to his aides about that incident, making it clear that above all he is determined to keep the latest throngs of refugees from entering the United States.
So unless Mr. Clinton negotiates, he must hope that one of two things happens soon: Either there is an uprising against Mr. Castro, hastened by the political and economic pressures he is applying, or Mr. Castro decides, for some reason, to halt the flow of refugees. But again, it is the Cuban who occupies the catbird seat.
In Eastern Europe five years ago, Communist dictators tried to keep people from fleeing to the West. It did not work, and their regimes disintegrated. Having watched what happened, Mr. Castro is unlikely to make the same mistake. While he might miscalculate, he is likely to keep the valve of emigration open to let off the steam of popular discontent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
One Manager's Little Gamble Prompted Big Shift in Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
A strategy designed to earn the smallest of profits -- about an extra 1 percent a year -- backfired late Wednesday and played a major role in sending the Dow Jones industrial average up more than 70 points.
That surge, which was followed by a slump in stock prices yesterday, shows how the stock market can be roiled by little-known strategies using sophisticated securities. 
 The money manager whose strategy is being widely credited -- or blamed -- for the explosive move late Wednesday said yesterday that he was stunned by the action. "I'm surprised it could have that kind of effect," said William T. Mullen of Loomis, Sayles & Company. "We're talking about less than $100 million of stocks," he said of the trading that appears to have been set off by his strategy.
Much of the impetus for the stock market's surge came from the unraveling of Mr. Mullen's complex investment strategy that used a type of security not widely understood on Wall Street. The strategy turned on him, prompting other traders to scramble to protect themselves from losses and still others to buy in the hope of making their gain bigger and Mr. Mullen's loss larger.
Mr. Mullen's gamble -- essentially a bet that stock prices would not rise very rapidly -- was not the only factor in the stock market rise Wednesday, which was also influenced by a report of weak orders for durable goods like cars and appliances and by nice -- but smaller -- rallies in the currency and bond markets.
But in all likelihood it would have been a much quieter day had not Mr. Mullen chose to place a large bet to be won or lost on closing stock prices Wednesday. The reaction of other stock market players, evidently including those who had taken the opposite side of some of Mr. Mullen's bets, were an important impetus in the final leap in prices, which sent the Dow up 40 of its 70.90 points in the final two hours of trading.
But when trading ended Wednesday it was still a mystery to many why stocks had rallied so sharply. Only yesterday did many traders begin to decide that the surge was not caused by investors with confidence in corporate earnings and the economy, the usual reasons for a jump in prices.
To figure out Wednesday, traders and analysts had to learn about "flex options," another of the specially designed securities being invented regularly by Wall Street to allow traders, investors and speculators to do everything from minimize their losses to eke out a few extra percentage points of return.
The move appears to be the first sizable one clearly traceable to the flex option, which is named for its flexibility because it can expire on almost any day. That means the volatility brought on by the scramble to avoid losses or solidify gains on the day the option expires can happen at any time, rather than only on the third Friday of a month, the time normal options expire.
That volatility stems from the fact that a wide variety of financial instruments -- including futures, options and swaps -- enable money managers, traders and others to shift part of the risk that comes with their investments to others, who can, in turn, shift part or all of the risk to someone else using another kind of financial instrument. It is often impossible to know where the risk has landed, or even in what instrument.
"The marketplace has gotten used to dealing with the volatility that can occur around standard option expirations dates," said Tom McManus, a strategist at Morgan Stanley. But, he added, this was something new.
Mr. Mullen, who manages money at Loomis's Washington office, does his trading in stock index options, usually trading the most popular stock index options -- those on the Standard & Poor's 500 and 100 indexes. But in this case he traded a lesser known index, the American Stock Exchange institutional index, which is based on the performance of 75 large stocks. That index includes such household names as Ford Motor, Caterpillar, Sears, Roebuck and Eastman Kodak, all of which advanced strongly Wednesday and then fell back yesterday.
Index options enable a buyer to make big money if he can correctly forecast the direction of a stock market index. Mr. Mullen's strategy is to sell options that will be worth money to the people who buy them from him only if the stock market rallies at least 5 percent over the next month or two. If that happens, he can lose money. But most often it does not, and his clients profit because the options expire worthless while they keep the fee they earned when they were sold.
His goal is to take in enough money from selling options to enable his clients -- mostly pension funds -- to earn about 1 percent a year above what they would otherwise earn from their stock market investments. He now uses that strategy to write options on about $8.5 billion of stock investments, a figure that has more than doubled in the last two years as more and more pension funds have signed up.
About six weeks ago, Mr. Mullen said yesterday, he sold 2,000 option contracts on the Amex institutional index, covering almost $100 million in stocks. The options were of the new flex type and were to expire at the close of trading Wednesday. If the index closed at or below 468, the options would be worthless, and those who bought them from Mr. Mullen would be losers, having paid a fee for the options but gotten nothing. But every hundredth of an index point above 468 would require Mr. Mullen's clients to pay $2,000, a dollar for each contract.
The index, which had ended Tuesday at 466.76, spent much of Wednesday below 468. But it went above that level a bit before noon, and after dipping back to it a little after 1 P.M. it was off to the races. At the close, the index was at 471.74, and Mr. Mullen's position, which looked in the morning as it if would end the day costing him nothing, actually cost $748,000. But Mr. Mullen said that those losses did not come close to wiping out the profits his clients had made earlier in the year from using the same strategy.
Those were not the only options that expired with a profit on Wednesday. The others were 4,000 contracts on the Amex major market index -- an index of 20 stocks designed to mirror the Dow industrials. Those contracts were clearly in the money long before Wednesday arrived, meaning that those involved in them had more time to react to offset projected losses or enhance gains and were less likely to have been scrambling late Wednesday.
It is at this point that what happened Wednesday afternoon becomes less clear. It appears that those who bought the options from Mr. Mullen had not been speculating. Instead they were brokers who regularly deal in options and bought them because Mr. Mullen is a good customer. So they laid off the risk they had incurred by buying the options by taking positions in other markets, possibly by selling stocks short -- that is borrowing shares and selling them, hoping to buy them back later at a lower price. They also could have sold other products, like stock index futures. As Wednesday went on, they decided to buy stocks, effectively canceling their own hedge. That buying, much of it in the final minutes, helped to push up prices even more.
"In the last half-hour, when the market did not come down, apparently there was a lot of effort to cover shorts," said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a market analysis firm.
Flex options have been around since February 1993. But it is only this year that they have really come into their own. Flex options on the S.& P. 500, the most popular such contract, covered $3.6 billion of stocks at the end of last year, a figure that had more than tripled to $12 billion by the end of last month.
By Wall Street standards, the size of Mr. Mullen's trades were not large. But the reaction to them -- coming late on a day when traders are not accustomed to looking for options-related volatility -- came as a shock and no doubt led some to believe that the market was moving for other reasons more closely related to fundamentals and economic expectations. And that helped to set off buying that moved the market and left a lot of analysts shaking their heads.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An investment strategy backfired on William T. Mullen, managing partner for Loomis, Sayles & Company, and played a big role in the 70-point surge of the Dow Jones industrial average on Wednesday. "I'm surprised it could have that kind of effect," he said yesterday. (Karin Anderson for The New York Times) (pg. D4)
 
Chart/Graph: "A Strategy Wnt Awry, and the Market Soared"
 William Mullen of Loomis, Sayles & Co. adopted an investment strategy that was designed to make money if the stock market did not rise sharply. Perversely, that strategy helped to cause Wednesday's big rise in share prices.
 
WHAT HAPPENED
 1. In July, Mr. Mullen sold 2000 flex index options tied to the performance of the American Stock Exchange Institutional Index, betting that the stock market would not rally sharply before Wednesday Aug. 24, when the options expired. If the market did not advance at least 5 percent by then, the options would be worthless to their buyers when they expired. The options are called flex options, short for flexible, because they can mature on almost any date.
 
BEHIND THE SCENES
 1. An index option is a security that allows an investor to bet on the performance of a stock index without having to buy any of the stocks that make up the index. The index option is bought with cash for a premium. When the option expires, if the index is above the stated value, it is "in the money" and the buyer of the option is paid the difference between the actual index value and the stated figure.
 Most index options expire on the third Friday of the month, but flex index options can be set to expire on almost any date.
 Among the indexes options are sold on are the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks or the American Stock Exchange Insitutional Index, which includes 75 stocks that are popular with major institutional investors.
 
WHAT HAPPENED
 2. On Aug. 24, the stock market began to rally early, propelled in part by the unexpected sharp decline in orders for durable goods in July, a sharp rally in the dollar and hopes that the Federal Reserve would be able to delay another interest rate increase until near the end of the year. The American Stock Exchange Institutional was up at noon, but not high enough yet to put Mr. Mullen's index options "in the money" and make profit for the buyers.
 
BEHIND THE SCENES
 2. The Dow Jones Industrial Index was up 23.63 points at 1 P.M., but ended the day up 70.90 points.
 The 4.2 percent decline in durable goods signalled that the pace of economic growth is slowing. If that is the case, there will be less pressure on production capacity, which means less pressure on prices.
 
WHAT HAPPENED
 3. But by 1 p.m., the Dow had jumped 24 points and the American Stock Exchange Institutional Index was up 1.81 to 468.57. That suddenly put all the 2000 flex options Mr. Mullen had sold into the money.
 
BEHIND THE SCENES
 3. Because this is the day that the option expires, Mr. Mullin has to pay up. In the end, the American Stock Exchange Institutional Index closes at 471.74 and Mr. Mullen pays $374 for each contract, or $748,000.
 
WHAT HAPPENED
 4. As the options moved into the money, several traders and analysts said that buying of stock by people who had bought the flex index options from Mr. Mullen helped push stock prices higher.
 
BEHIND THE SCENES
 4. Traders said there were two reasons for this late day buying.
 One is that Mr. Mullen sold his index options to other brokers on Wall Street who make a business of dealing in options and buy them to satisfy customer needs. But they do not want to make the bets implied, and so they made other trades to offset their risks. Those other positions became losers when stock prices began rising and the brokers scrambled to buy stock.
 That buying was at first interpreted as a wave of institutional demand for stocks, not as an aberration brought on by the options. So others bought, trying to get in on the trend.
 
WHAT HAPPENED
 5. The stock market got another push from investors who have been betting generally that the stock market, which was down 5 percent from its January all time high as trading began Wednesday, would continue to decline. So they also sold stocks they did not own in hopes of buying them back at lower prices to make a profit. To cut their losses, many of them bought stocks as prices soared late Wednesday.
 
BEHIND THE SCENES
 5. On Thursday, the stock market took a breather, with the Dow falling 16.84 points to 3829.89. The American Stock Exchange Insitutional index ended at 470.27, down 1.47. (pg. D4)
