HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN CUBA;
For Cubans Facing Sea: Last Chance

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Neither the fierce rains whipping the palm trees today nor the harsh new measures by President Clinton were going to keep Juan Carlos Gonzalez from making another attempt to take to the sea in search of a new future in the United States.
In fact, thousands of people like Mr. Gonzalez, fearing this may be their last chance to leave the country, are speeding up their exodus, rather than hesitating over the uncertainty of the voyage. 
 "Maybe if I wait, things will change here," Mr. Gonzalez said. "Maybe things will improve economically here for people. Or maybe tomorrow they will let me leave on a plane. But I think this is the moment. It is my destiny to go now."
All along a stretch of the Cuban coast, from the Malecon Boulevard in downtown Havana to Cojimar several miles east where Mr. Gonzalez waited, small clusters of Cubans could be seen bobbing in the water. Others were on the beaches, bartering for provisions and making final arrangements to leave now, rather than waiting for a change in either the weather or politics.
Mr. Gonzalez said he first tried to leave on Saturday when he and five friends boarded a boat crafted of inner tubes and boards. After almost 40 hours at sea they were out of water and food. One became ill, saying he was hearing voices and insisting that he could walk on the water. With no rescue boat in sight, the dejected group decided to turn back. Mr. Gonzalez showed his palms marked with blisters by his ordeal.
A worker in a perfume and soap factory, Mr. Gonzalez said he earns about $3 a month and makes candies on the side to help his household of six, including his parents. As the youngest son, he has an obligation to try to find a different life, he said.
And so this morning he looked again toward the treacherous sea. Along the beaches in Cojimar, many people were aware of the dangers and said they had seen bodies washing ashore. But Mr. Gonzalez said he was determined to go.
"To me the most beautiful thing in the world is Cuba," he said softly. "But truthfully it hasn't worked. I don't know if it is the fault of the United States or of those who govern us here. Politics don't interest me. I only want to provide a good life for my mother and myself."
Every day those who want to leave are becoming more brazen about their attempts -- leaving in broad daylight, in view of the lovers strolling along Havana's seaside boulevard, in sight of the foreign tourists who are a mainstay of the economy.
"I think it will be Clinton who will stop this first, so we must hurry," said Roberto Carlos Rivera, who was waiting to take off in his boat. "We hear that the American people are beginning to protest that so many of us are going over."
For the first time in years, President Fidel Castro has called off the coastal patrols that in the past had guarded the shore to prevent Cubans fleeing by sea and is now allowing Cubans to flee unimpeded.
After heavy rains Wednesday night, another downpour was drenching Havana by midday today, whipping palm trees in high winds and forcing those on the beach to take cover under the canvas sails they had planned to use at sea. By late afternoon, the skies were still gray but the ocean looked calmer, and there was more talk of setting out.
Most people on the beach said they knew they could end up at the Guantanamo Bay naval base or another military camp. They said they knew it might be weeks or months before their applications for asylum would be granted. But for most it was almost an irrelevant point.
"The most frightening choice would be to stay here," said a man who would only identify himself as Rodolfo. "You don't know hell until you've lived here."
 
Patriotism for Pork
 He said that this month the Government provided each member of his family with a quarter-pound of pork. "It had been years since we had seen pork," he said. His family subsists on rice and soy beans, usually cooked without oil because that, too, is scarce.
Because much of the news they receive comes from word of mouth, many Cubans were ill-informed about the extent of President Clinton's punitive measures. But rumors were passing rapidly from one bunch of would-be refugees to another.
"I heard that England is taking 50,000 refugees," said Felix Perez, who is 35. "We also heard that Julio Iglesias is offering to take 100 Cubans."
With the same urgency of those who wanted to go, entrepreneurs were taking advantage of an opportunity. One group was selling a rubber and wooden boat for $1,200. Another man was trying to peddle an inner tube for $50.
 
Coastal Graffiti
 Beyond the coastal areas the discontent that was driving so many people to take to the sea was less evident. Workers continued on to their jobs on bicycles or waited in long lines for the state-owned buses that trailed black smoke.
All along the boulevards, especially those facing the United States, messages of the revolution, some in six-foot-tall letters, were written.
"Into battle with our morals and our principles, secure in our victory," one sign proclaimed.
Another said: "This land is 100 percent Cuban."
 
Front-Porch Politics
 In Old Havana three men were sitting outside their apartment building, a crumbling relic of a once-beautiful Colonial-style house. None of them said they planned to leave, but it was not necessarily because they supported Mr. Castro.
"Let them all go, so there will be more food for everybody else," said Carlos Moises Menendez, who stocks food shipments for a living. "I see food all the time but I can eat none of it."
His neighbor, Carlos Marcelino Iglesias, said: "They should allow one quarter of us to go. But let's send them in seaworthy vessels, not these flimsy rubber and wood contraptions."
They complained about how the economy has strangled the average Cuban. Their apartments are state-owned and they are falling down piece by piece on passersby. The utilities are also state-owned and the electricity often fails.
 
Tuning Out Castro
 They can watch state-owned television for only about four hours a night, but they said they did not bother listening to Mr. Castro's address to the nation on Wednesday night.
The gas for their stoves is available only after 6 P.M. "We have to cook tonight what we want to eat tomorrow," Mr. Iglesias said.
All three work for the Government and say their wages will not allow them to afford Government-subsidized food. Moreover, the Government is always out of food, they said.
"I can't remember the last time I ate beef," said Mr. Iglesias.
Mr. Menendez added, "I got a quarter-pound last month but I let my son eat it."
 
Waiting for a Chance
 All three said that if they had the opportunity they would leave Cuba.
"But not like that in these risky boats," said Mr. Menendez.
"That is like sending people to their deaths," said another neighbor, Jose Miguel Garcia.
Since the fall of the Soviet Union, Cuba has struggled to survive economically. Certain sectors of production were cut back to put the emphasis on agriculture, health and tourism, which brings in much-needed foreign currency.
The official exchange rate of the Cuban peso to the dollar is one to one, but anyone on the street can tell you that a dollar will buy about 120 pesos.
 
2d Class of Citizens
 All tourists must pay in dollars, and those who work in the tourism industry get dollars, especially from tips, so they have access to certain goods not available to others. The three men said it has only created a second class of citizens.
Mr. Iglesias earns 120 pesos a month as a construction worker. A bottle of cooking oil, he said, costs 200 pesos and a pair of pants 1,800 to 2,000.
Yet, he and his neighbor said they would not take the risk of fleeing, even though they have the biggest chance ever in the years.
"The only ones who are leaving are those who can no longer stand this," said Mr. Menendez. "I wish them well."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
 One money manager's small gamble played a big role in the surge in stocks on Wednesday, when the Dow jumped 70.90 points. Much of the impetus for buying on Wednesday came from the unraveling of a complex investment strategy involving the trading of less than $100 million. The surprising surge that resulted shows how the market can be roiled by little-known strategies using sophisticated securities. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page A1.] 
The rally on Wall Street ran out of steam, and stocks ended mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.84 points. [D4.]
Stock markets in Asia and Europe were mostly higher, inspired by Wednesday's jump in the Dow industrials. [D11.]
Treasury prices sagged as traders awaited today's revised report on the gross domestic product. [D11.]
The dollar advanced against the yen on optimism that there would be progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan. But the dollar fell against the German mark. [D14.]
Wheat prices climbed after the International Wheat Council reduced its global forecast for the crop. [D14.]
 
Companies
 AT&T was cleared to buy McCaw Cellular for $12.6 billion. A ruling by the Federal judge who oversaw the breakup of the old Bell System removes the main legal obstacle and sets the stage for a battle between AT&T and the regional Bell companies. [D1.]
Disney's chief, Michael D. Eisner, took a risk in not promoting Jeffrey Katzenberg, Hollywood executives and agents said. Disney has been bedeviled by strains in its management and its businesses that have been compounded by the turbulence surrounding Mr. Katzenberg's departure as head of Disney Studios. [D1.]
A court-appointed examiner rebuked Weil, Gotshal & Manges, asserting that the law firm had numerous potential conflicts of interests in its handling of the bankruptcy case of the Leslie Fay Companies and did not properly disclose them. [D1.]
A strike at a General Motors components plant ended. The three-day strike had idled 13 G.M. assembly plants. [A14.]
Toyota reported a sharp decline in profit, but the company, Japan's biggest car maker, said it thought the worst was over. [D2.]
Two software specialty retailers agreed to merge. Babbage's and Software Etc. will join in an exchange of stock. [D3.]
The Rickel and Channel home-remodeling retail chains will be acquired and combined by an investment partnership. [D3.]
GE Capital will buy consumer finance businesses in Japan. The deal with Minebea may be the first big move by a foreign company into the Japanese consumer finance industry. [D3.]
Mikael Salovaara will join the Blackstone Group as a limited partner. Mr. Salovaara, 40, was a former head of Goldman, Sachs & Company's Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund. [D3.]
Dell Computer reported a $28.6 million profit in the second quarter, continuing to rebound from losses last year. [D3.]
 
International
 Japan's auto makers are returning to their roots, forsaking fancier and more expensive cars to build cheaper vehicles with fewer frills and less obsessive attention to detail. With Japan mired in an economic slump, domestic consumers are looking for less expensive cars. A series of such vehicles have been introduced in Japan in the last few months and have done quite well. [D1.]
A new round of ventures in Mexico is being planned by United States companies and investors. The renewed interest comes after the recent victory by Mexico's ruling party, which has calmed fears of potential upheaval in the country. [D1.]
 
Today's Column
 A dispute over research on magazine readers is causing concern among marketers and ad agencies. Two companies conduct research on magazine and newspaper readership, and the methodology of one is being questioned. The data are used to buy billions of dollars of ads a year. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Gore Wants U.N. to Leave Abortion Up to Each Nation

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore said today that although the United States will insist at a United Nations conference next month that every nation should decide for itself whether to permit abortions, the United States would never assert that a woman's right to choose an abortion should be internationally guaranteed.
Mr. Gore, who will head the American delegation to the International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo in two weeks, defended the Clinton Administration's policies on issues to be discussed there. 
 The draft program to be debated in Cairo has been strongly criticized by the Roman Catholic Church, which opposes abortion and contraception, and by some fundamentalist Islamic leaders, largely for the same reasons. The draft's final position on abortion and other issues is still being negotiated.
The current draft calls population policies "the sovereign right of each nation, consistent with national laws and in conformity with international human rights standards." It urges nations to insure universal access to health-care services, and one point in the dispute over abortion and contraception is whether they are included in those services.
In a speech to the National Press Club, Mr. Gore defended the Administration's position at length and in detail, but broke no new ground. The Vice President reaffirmed the Administration's position that abortions should be "rare" and that a key to insuring this is to make contraception widely and readily available.
 
Consensus Is Seen
 Mr. Gore's speech was arranged hastily this week at the White House's initiative in an attempt, he said, to make sure that news reports of the Administration's dispute with the Vatican did not obscure what he called a broad consensus behind the United Nations program.
"Sometimes if the focus is only on the disagreement and only on the controversy, the real substantive development can be missed," Mr. Gore said. "The real substantive development here is the remarkable range of consensus, the dramatic change in the way in which the world views this critical challenge, a challenge which many view to be the most critical challenge humankind faces in the next century."
The Vice President cited the draft program's calls for supporting education, women's rights, children's health and economic development as tools to rein in the global population explosion.
He said the Administration does not promote abortion, nor does it view abortion as an appropriate method of family planning, and it condemns any coercive abortion, whether legal, economic or psychological.
"We believe that decisions about the extent to which abortion is acceptable should be the province of each government within the context of its own laws and national circumstances," Mr. Gore said. "Therefore, throughout these negotiations, we have supported language and sought to have added to the text, language that clearly establishes this principle for all of the Cairo recommendations. And we fully expect, and will insist at Cairo, that this principle be affirmed in the final document."
He added: "Let me be clear, our Administration believes that the United States Constitution guarantees every woman within our borders a right to choose abortion, subject to limited and specific exceptions. We are unalterably committed to that principle. But let us take a false issue off the table. The United States has not sought, does not seek and will not seek to establish any international right to an abortion. That is a red herring."
The same principle, he said, should apply to contraceptives: nations have the right to make them legal, but the United Nations is not seeking to establish a basic human right to their availability. Mr. Gore made clear, however, that the Administration wants contraceptives and information about contraception to be widely available.
"Our view is that the most effective way to reduce population growth and abortion is through a comprehensive global strategy that makes family planning information and services as widely available as possible, that promotes sustainable economic development, that increases child survival rates and literacy, that fosters women's health, that strengthens families, and that focuses on the education and empowerment of women," he said.

Islamic Suit Against Parley
 CAIRO, Aug. 25 (Special to The New York Times) -- A group of Islamic lawyers and a leading Muslim fundamentalist preacher have filed a lawsuit seeking to prevent a United Nations conference on population from being held here.
Three lawyers and Sheik Hafez Salama, the popular head of an Islamic religious society, joined both moderate and hard-line fundamentalist groups in condemning the conference, which they regard as a plot to spread "corrupt" Western values in the Muslim world.
"This conference will deal with topics that are against the traditions of Islam," said one of the lawyers, Abdel Halim Mandour, who has defended some of Egypt's most militant Muslim figures, including Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the cleric being held in the United States in connection with an alleged bombing plot. "They are encouraging sex outside marriage, homosexuality and abortion."
